 = Du Fu = 
 
 Du Fu ( Wade[MASK]– Giles : Tu Fu ; Chinese : 杜甫 ; 712 – 770 ) was a prominent Ch[MASK]nese poet of the Tang dynasty . Along with Li Bai ( Li Po ) , he is freq[MASK]ently ca[MASK]led th[MASK] great[MASK]st of the Chinese poets . His greatest ambition was to serve his country as a successful civil servant , but he proved unable to make the necessary accommodations . His life , like the whole country , was devastated by the An Lushan Rebellion of 755 , and his last 15 y[MASK]ars were a time of almost constant unr[MASK]st[MASK]. 
 Alth[MASK]ugh initially he was little @-@ know[MASK] to other writers , his works came to be hugely influential in bo[MASK]h Chinese and Japanese liter[MASK]ry culture . Of his poetic writ[MASK]ng[MASK], nearly fifteen h[MASK]ndred poems have been prese[MASK]ved over the ages . He [MASK]as be[MASK]n cal[MASK]ed the " Poet @-@ Historian " and the " Poet @-@ Sage " by Chinese critics , while the r[MASK]nge of his work has all[MASK]wed him to be [MASK]ntroduced to Western readers as " the Chinese Virgil , Horace , Ovid , Shakespeare [MASK] M[MASK]lton , Burns , Wordsworth [MASK] Béranger , Hugo or Baudelaire " . 
 
 = = Life = = 
 
 Tr[MASK]ditional Chinese literary criticism emphasized the life of the author when interpreting a work , a practice which Burton Watson attributes to " the close links that traditional Chinese thought[MASK]posits between art and m[MASK]rality " . Since many of Du Fu 's poems feature morality and history , this practice is particularly important . Another reason , identified by the Chinese historian William Hung , is that Chinese poems are typically concis[MASK] , omitting context that might be rele[MASK]ant , but which an informed contemporary could be assumed to know . For modern Western readers , " The le[MASK]s accurately [MASK]e kn[MASK]w the time , the plac[MASK] and the circumstances in the backgro[MASK]nd , the more liable we are to imagine it incorrectly , an[MASK] the result will be that we either misunderstand the poem or fail to understand it altogether "[MASK]. Stephen Owen suggests a third fac[MASK]or particular to D[MASK] Fu , arguing that the variety of [MASK]he [MASK]oet 's work required con[MASK]iderati[MASK]n of his whole life , rather than the " reductive " cate[MASK]orizations used for more limited [MASK][MASK]ets . 
 
 = = = Early years = = = 
 
 Most o[MASK] what is[MASK]known of Du Fu 's life comes from his poems . His paternal grandf[MASK]ther was Du Shenyan , a noted polit[MASK]cian and poet during the reign of Empress Wu . Du Fu wa[MASK] bo[MASK]n in 712 ; the exact birthplace [MASK]s unknown , except that it was[MASK]near Luoy[MASK]ng , Henan province ( Go[MASK]g county is a favourite candid[MASK]te ) . In l[MASK]ter life , he considered himself to belong to the capital city of Chang 'an , a[MASK]cestral hometown of the Du family . 
 Du Fu 's mother died shortly after he was born , and he was partially raised by his aunt . He had an elder brother , who died young . He also had three half brothers and one half sister , to whom he frequently refers in his poems , although he never mentions his stepmother . 
 The son of a minor scholar @-@ official , his youth was spent on the st[MASK]ndard education of a [MASK]uture civil [MASK]ervant : study and memo[MASK]isation of[MASK]the Confucian classics of philosophy , history and poetry .[MASK]He later claimed to have produced creditable po[MASK]ms by his early teens , but these have b[MASK]en lost . 
 In the early 730s , [MASK]e travelled in the Jiang[MASK]u / Zhejiang area ; his earliest surviving poem , describing a poetry contest , is thought to da[MASK]e from the end of this perio[MASK] , around 735 . [MASK]n that year , h[MASK] took th[MASK] civil service exam , likely in Chang 'an[MASK]. He failed , to his surprise and that of centuries of later crit[MASK]cs . Hung concludes that he probably failed because his prose style a[MASK] the time was too dense and obsc[MASK]re , while Chou suggests his failure to cul[MASK]ivate connections in the capital may ha[MASK]e been to blame . After this [MASK]ailu[MASK]e , he went back to traveling , this time around [MASK]handong and Hebei . 
 His father died around 740 . Du Fu w[MASK]uld have been allowed to enter the [MASK]ivil service because of his father 's rank , but he is thoug[MASK]t to have given up the privilege in favour of one of his half brothers . He spent the next four[MASK]years living in the Luoyan[MASK] area , fulf[MASK]lling his duties in domestic affairs . 
 In[MASK][MASK]he autumn of 744 , he met Li Bai ( Li Po ) for the first time , and the two poets formed a friends[MASK]ip . David Young describes this as " the most significant formative element in Du Fu 's artistic development[MASK]" because it gave him a li[MASK]in[MASK] example of the reclusive poet @-@ scholar life to which he was attracted after [MASK]is failure in [MASK]he civil service exam . The rel[MASK]tionship was somewhat one @-[MASK] sided , however . Du Fu was by some years the younger [MASK] while Li Bai was already a poetic star . We have twelve poems to or about Li Bai from the younger poet , but only one in the other direction . They met again only once , in 745 . 
 In 746 , he moved t[MASK] t[MASK]e capi[MASK]al in an attempt to resurrect his official career . He took the civil service exam a second t[MASK]me during the following year , but all the candidates were failed by the prime minister ( apparently in order to prevent the emergence of possible[MASK]rivals ) . He never again a[MASK]tempted the examinations , instead petitioning the emperor directly in 751 , 754 and probably again in 75[MASK] . He married around 752 , and by[MASK]757 t[MASK]e couple had h[MASK][MASK] five children — thr[MASK]e [MASK]ons and tw[MASK] daughters — but one of the sons died in infancy in 755 . From 754 he began to have lung problems ( probably asthma ) , the first of a series of ailments which dogged him for the rest of his life . It was in that year that Du Fu was forced to move his family due to the turmoi[MASK] of a famine brought about by massive floods in the region . 
 In 755 , [MASK]e received an appointment as Registrar of the Right Commandant 's office of the Cr[MASK]wn Prince 's Pal[MASK]ce . Although[MASK]this was a minor post , in nor[MASK]al ti[MASK]es it would [MASK]av[MASK] been at least the start of an official career . Even before he had begun work , however , the position was swept aw[MASK]y by events . 
 
 = = = War[MASK]= = = 
 
 The An Lushan Rebell[MASK]on began in December 755 , and was[MASK]not completely suppressed for[MASK]almost ei[MASK]ht yea[MASK]s . It caused e[MASK]ormous disruption to Chinese society : the census of 754 rec[MASK]rded 52 @.@ 9 [MASK]illion people , [MASK]ut ten[MASK]years later , the census counted just 16 @.@ 9 million , the remainder having been displaced or killed . During thi[MASK] time , Du Fu led a largely itinerant life unsettle[MASK] by wars , associated fa[MASK]ines and imperial [MASK]ispleasure . This period of unhappiness was the making of Du Fu as [MASK] poet : E[MASK]en Shan C[MASK]ou has written that , " What he saw ar[MASK]und him — the lives of his family , neighbors , a[MASK]d strangers – what he heard , and what he hoped for or feared from the progress [MASK]f various campaigns — these became the enduring themes of his poetry " . Even when he learned of the death [MASK]f his youngest child , he turned to the suffering of others in his poetry instead [MASK]f dwelling upon his[MASK]own misfortunes . Du Fu wrote : 
 Brooding on what I have lived through , if even I know such suffering , the common man must surely be r[MASK]ttled by the[MASK]winds . 
 In 756 , Emperor Xuanzong was forced to flee the capital[MASK]and abdicate . Du Fu , who had been away from the city , took his family to a place[MASK]of safety and attempted to join the court of the new emperor ( Suzong ) , but he was captu[MASK]ed by the rebels and taken to Cha[MASK]g 'an . In the autumn , his youngest son , [MASK]u Zongwu ( Baby Bear ) , was born . Around this time Du Fu is thought to have contracted malaria . 
 He escaped from[MASK]Chang 'an[MASK]the following year , and was appointe[MASK] Reminder when he rejoined the court in May 757 . This post gave access to the emperor but was lar[MASK]ely cerem[MASK]nial . Du Fu 's conscientiousness com[MASK]elled him to try to make use of it [MASK] he caused trouble for himself by protesting[MASK][MASK]he removal of his friend and patron Fang Guan on a petty charge . He was arrested but was pardoned in June . He was granted leave to visit[MASK]his family in September , but he soon re[MASK]oined the [MASK]ourt and on December 8 , 757 , he r[MASK]turned to Chang 'an with the emperor following[MASK]its recapture by government forces . However , his advice continued to be unappreciated , and in the summer of 758[MASK]he was demoted to a post as Commissioner of Education in Huazhou . The position was[MASK]not to his [MASK]a[MASK]te : in one poe[MASK] , he wrote : 
 I am a[MASK]out to scream madly in th[MASK][MASK]office / Especially wh[MASK]n they bring more [MASK]apers to pile higher on my desk . 
 He moved on in the summer of 759 ; th[MASK]s has tra[MASK]itionally been ascribed to famine , but Hung believes that frustration is a [MASK]ore likely reason . He next spent around six weeks in Qinzhou ( now Tianshui , Gansu province ) , where [MASK]e wrote more than sixty poems . 
 
[MASK]= = = Chengdu = = = 
 
 In December 759 , he briefly stayed in Tonggu ( modern Gansu ) . He departed on D[MASK]cember 24 for Chengdu ( S[MASK]chuan province ) , where he was hosted by local[MASK]Prefect and fellow poet Pei Di . Du subsequently based himself in Sichuan for most of the next five years . By the autumn of that year he was [MASK]n fina[MASK]cial trouble , and sent poems begging help to various acquaintances . He was relieved by Yan Wu [MASK] a [MASK]riend and former colleague who wa[MASK] appointed governor general [MASK]t Chengdu . Despite his financial problems , this was one of [MASK]he happiest and most peaceful periods of his[MASK]life . Many of Du 's poems from this period are peaceful depictions of his life at " thatched hut " . In 762 , he left the city to escape [MASK] rebellion , but he returned in summer 764 when he was appointed an advisor to Yan , who was involved in campaigns against the Ti[MASK]etan Empire . 
 
 = = = Last years = = = 
 
 Lu[MASK]yang , the region of his [MASK]irthplace , was recovered by government forces in the winter of 762 , an[MASK] in the [MASK]pring of 765 Du Fu and his family sailed[MASK]down the Yangtze , apparently with the intention of making their way there . They traveled slowly , held up by his ill @-@ health [MASK] by thi[MASK] time he was suffering from poor eyesight , deafne[MASK]s and general[MASK]old age in addition to his previous [MASK]ilments ) . They stayed in Kuizhou ( in what is now Baidicheng , Chongqing ) at the entra[MASK]ce to the Three Gorges for almost two years from late spring 766 . This period was [MASK]u Fu 's last great poetic flowering , and her[MASK] he wrote 400 poems in his dense , late s[MASK]yle . In autumn 766 , Bo Maolin became governor of the region : he suppo[MASK]ted Du Fu financially and employed[MASK]him as his unofficial secretary . 
 In March 768 , he began his journey again and got as far as Hunan pro[MASK]ince , where he died in Tanz[MASK]ou ( now C[MASK]angsha ) in November or December 770 , in his 58th yea[MASK] . He was survived by his wife and two sons , who remaine[MASK] in the area f[MASK]r some years at [MASK]east . His last known descendant is a gra[MASK]dson who requested a grave inscription for the poet from Yuan Zhen in 813 . 
 Hung summarises his life by concluding that , " He appeared to be a filial son , an affectionate father , a genero[MASK]s brother , a faithful [MASK]usband , a loyal friend , a dutiful offi[MASK]ial , and a patriotic subject . "

Like many other [MASK]oems in the Tang [MASK]t featured the theme of a long parting[MASK]between friends , which was of[MASK]en due to officials being frequ[MASK]ntly transferred to the provinces : 
 
 = = Works = = 
 
 Criticism of Du Fu 's works has focused on his strong sense of history , his mor[MASK]l engagement , and [MASK]is tech[MASK]ical excellence . 
 
 = = = History = = = 
 
 S[MASK]nce the Song dynasty , critics have call[MASK]d Du Fu the " poet histo[MASK]ian " ( 詩史 shī shǐ ) . The most directly historical of his poems are those commenting on military tactics or the suc[MASK]esses and failures of the government , or the poems of advice which he wrote to the emperor . Indirectly[MASK], he wrote about the effect of the times in [MASK]hich he lived on himself , and on the ordinary people of Chin[MASK] . [MASK]s Watso[MASK] notes , this is information " of a kind seldom found in the officially compiled histories of the era " . 
 Du Fu 's political commen[MASK]s are based on emotion rather than calculation : his prescriptions have been paraphrased as , " Let us all be less s[MASK]lfish , let us all do what we are supposed to do " . Since[MASK]his views were impossible to disagree with , his forcefully expressed truisms enabled his installation as the central figure of Chinese poeti[MASK] history . 
 
 = = = Moral engagement = = = 
 
 A second favourite epithet of Chinese critics is that of " poet sage " ( 詩聖 shī shèng ) , a counterpart to the philosophical sage , Confucius . One of the earliest surviving works , The Song of the W[MASK]gons ( from around 750 ) , gives voice to the sufferings of a conscript so[MASK]dier in the imperial army and a clear @-@ sighted consciousness of suff[MASK]ring . These concerns are continuously[MASK]articulated in poems on the lives of both soldiers an[MASK] civilians produced by Du Fu throughout his life . 
 Altho[MASK]gh Du Fu 's [MASK]requent references to his own diffi[MASK]ulties can give the impression of [MASK]n all @-@ consuming solipsi[MASK]m , Hawkes argues that his "[MASK]famous compassion in[MASK]fact includes himself , viewed quite objectively and almost as an afterthought " . He therefore " lends grandeur " to the wid[MASK]r picture by comparing it to " his own slightly comical triviality " . 
 Du Fu 's compassion , for himself and for others , was part of his general broadening of the scope of poetry : he devoted many works to topics which had previously been co[MASK]sidered unsuitable for poetic treatment . Zhang Jie wrote[MASK]that for D[MASK] Fu , " ever[MASK]thing in this world is poetry " , Du wrote extensively on subjects such as domestic[MASK]life , calligraphy , paintings , animals , and other poems . 
 
 = = = Technical excellence = = = 
 
 Du [MASK][MASK] 's work is notable above all for its range . Chinese critics tra[MASK]itionally used the te[MASK]m 集大成 ( j[MASK]dàchéng- " complete symphony " ) , a reference to Mencius ' description of Confuciu[MASK] . Yuan Zhen was the first to not[MASK] the bre[MASK]dth of Du[MASK]F[MASK] 's achievement , writing in 813 that his predec[MASK]ssor , " united in his work traits which previous men had displayed onl[MASK] singly[MASK]" . He mastered all the forms of Chinese poetry :[MASK]Chou says th[MASK]t in every form he " either made outst[MASK]nding advances or con[MASK]ributed outstanding examples " . Furthermore , his poems use a wide range of registe[MASK]s , from the direct and colloquial to the allusive and self @-@ consciously literary[MASK]. This varie[MASK]y is manifested even within[MASK]individual wor[MASK]s : Owen identifies the , " rapid stylistic and thematic shi[MASK]ts " in [MASK]oems which enable the p[MASK]et to represent d[MASK]fferent facets o[MASK] a[MASK]situation , while Chou uses the term " juxtaposition " [MASK]s the major analytical tool in he[MASK] work . Du Fu is noted for[MASK]having written mo[MASK]e on poetics and painting than any other w[MASK]iter of his time . He wrote eighteen poems on painting alone , more than [MASK]ny other Tang poet[MASK]. Du Fu 's seemingly negative commentary on the prized horse paintings of Ha[MASK] Gan ignited a controversy that has persisted to the present day . 
 The tenor of his work changed as he developed his style and adapted to his[MASK]sur[MASK]o[MASK]ndings ( [MASK] chameleon @-@ like " according to Watson ) : his earliest works are in a relatively derivative , courtly style , but h[MASK] came into his own in the years of the rebellion . Owen comments on the " grim simplicity " of [MASK]he Qi[MASK]zhou poems , which mirrors the desert landscape ; the works from his Chengdu period are " light , often finel[MASK] observed " ; while the poe[MASK]s from the late Kuizhou period have a " density and power of vision " . 
 Although he wrote in all poetic[MASK]forms , Du Fu is [MASK]est known for his lǜshi , a type of poem with strict constraints on form [MASK]nd content , for ex[MASK]mple : 
 About two thirds of Du Fu 's 1500 extant works are in this form , and he is generally considered[MASK]to be its leading exponent . His best lǜshi use the parallelisms require[MASK] by the [MASK]orm to add expressive content rather than as m[MASK]re technical re[MASK]trictions . Hawkes comments [MASK]hat , " i[MASK] is amazing that Tu Fu is able to use so imm[MASK]nsely stylized a f[MASK]rm [MASK]n so natural a manner " . 
 
 = = Influence = = 
 
 According to the Encyclopædia Britannica , Du Fu[MASK]'s writi[MASK]gs are considered by many literary critics to be among the greatest of all time , and it states " his dense , compressed language makes use of all the connotative overtones of a phrase and of all the intonational potentials of the individual word , qualities that no translation can ever reveal . " 
 In his[MASK]lifetime and immediately following his death , Du Fu was not gr[MASK]atly appreciated . [MASK]n part this can be attri[MASK]uted to his stylistic and formal innovations , some of which are still " considered extremely daring and bizarre by Chinese critics . " There are few cont[MASK]mporary references to him — only ele[MASK]en poems from six writers — and these describe [MASK]im in terms of affec[MASK]ion , but not as a paragon of poetic or moral ideals . Du Fu is also poorly represented in contemporary anthologies of poetry . [MASK] However , as Hung notes , he " is the only Chinese poet whose influence grew with time " , and [MASK]is works began to increase in popularity in the ninth century . Early positive comments came [MASK]rom Bai Juyi , [MASK]ho praised the moral sentiments of some of Du Fu 's works ( although he found these in only a small fraction of the poe[MASK]s ) , and from Han Yu , who wrote a piece defending Du Fu and Li Bai on aesthetic grounds from attacks made against them . Both[MASK]th[MASK]se writers showed the influence of Du Fu in their own poetic wo[MASK]k . By the beginn[MASK]ng of the 10th century , Wei Zhuang constructed the first replica of [MASK]is thatched cottage in Sichuan . 
 It was in the 11th century , [MASK]uring the Northern Song era that Du Fu 's reputation reached its [MASK]eak [MASK] In this period a comprehensive re @-@ evaluation of ea[MASK]lier poets t[MASK]ok place , [MASK]n which Wang Wei , Li Bai and Du[MASK]Fu came to be regarded as representing respectively the Buddhist , Daoist and Confucian strands of Chinese culture . At the same time , the development of Neo [MASK]-@ Confucianism ensured that Du Fu , as its poetic exemplar , occupied the paramount[MASK]position . Su Shi famously expressed [MASK]his reasoning when he wrote [MASK]hat Du Fu w[MASK]s " preeminent ... because ... through all his vicis[MASK]itude[MASK] , he never for the space of a meal forgot his sovereign " . His influ[MASK]nce was helped by his ability to reconcile [MASK]ppare[MASK]t opposites : political conservative[MASK] were attrac[MASK]ed by his loyalty to the est[MASK]blished order , while political radicals embraced his concern for the poor . Literary conservatives could look to his technical mastery , while literary[MASK]radicals were inspired by his innovations . Si[MASK]ce the establishment of the People 's Republic of China , Du Fu 's loyalty to the state and concern for the poor have been interpreted as embr[MASK]onic nationalism and socialism , and he has been praised for his use of simp[MASK]e , " people 's language " . 
 Du Fu 's popularity grew to such an extent that it is as hard to measure his infl[MASK]ence as that of Shak[MASK]s[MASK]eare in England : it was hard for any Chinese poet n[MASK]t to be influenced by h[MASK]m . While ther[MASK] was [MASK]ever another Du Fu , i[MASK]dividual poets followed in the traditions of specific aspects of his work : Ba[MASK] Juyi 's concern for the po[MASK]r , Lu You 's patriotism , and Mei Yaochen 's refle[MASK]tions on the[MASK]quotidian are a few examples . More broadly , Du Fu 's work in transforming the lǜshi from mere word p[MASK]ay into " a vehicle for serious poe[MASK]ic utterance " set[MASK]the stage for every subsequent writer in the genre . 
 In the 20th century , he was the favourite poet of Kenneth Rexroth , who has described him as " the grea[MASK]e[MASK]t non @-@ epic , non @-@ dramatic poet who has survived in any language [MASK] , and commented that , " he has made me a better man , as[MASK]a moral agent and as a perceiving organism " . 
 
 = = = Influence on Japanese literature = = = 
 
 Du Fu 's poetry has made a profound impact on Japanese literature , especially on the [MASK]iterature from the Muromachi period and[MASK]on scholars and poets in the Edo period , including Matsuo Bashō , the very greatest of all haiku poets . Even in m[MASK]dern Japanese , the term[MASK]Saint of Poetry ( 詩聖 , shisei ) is mostly synonymous with Du Fu . 
 Until the 13th century , the Japanese preferred Bai Juyi above all poets and there were few references to Du Fu , although his influence can be seen in some kanshi ( " Chinese poetry made by Japanese poets " ) anthologies such a[MASK] Bunka Shūreishū in the 9th c[MASK]ntury . The first notable Japanese appreciator of Du Fu 's poetry was Kokan Shiren ( 1278 – 1346 ) , [MASK] Rinzai Zen patriarch and one of the most prominent authors of the literature of the Five Mounta[MASK]ns ; he highly praised Du Fu and made a commentary on so[MASK]e poems of Du Fu from the perspective of a Zen[MASK]priest in Vol . [MASK]1 of Saihokushū . His student Chūgan Engetsu composed many kanshi which were clearly stated " influenced by Du Fu " in their prefaces . Chūgan 's student Gidō Shū[MASK]hin had close connection with the Court and Ashikaga Shogunate and propagated [MASK]u Fu 's poetry in the mundane world[MASK]; one day Nijō Yoshimoto , the Kampaku regent of the Court and the highest authori[MASK]y of renga poetry , asked Gidō , " Should I [MASK]earn the p[MASK]etry of Du Fu and Li Bai ? " G[MASK]dō dared to reply , " Yes if you do have enough capability . No if do not . " Since then , there had been m[MASK]ny seminars on Du Fu 's p[MASK]etry both in Zen temples and in [MASK]he aristocratic societ[MASK] , and as a result his poetry was often cited in Japanese literature in the Muromachi period , e.g. , Taiheiki , a hist[MASK]rical epic in the[MASK]late 14th century , and some noh [MASK]lays such as Hyakuman , Bashō , and Shunkan . 
 During th[MASK] Kan 'ei era of the Edo[MASK]period ( 1624 – 1643 ) , Shào Chuán ( 邵傳 ) of the Ming Dynasty 's Collective Commentary on Du Fu 's Lǜshi ( 杜律集解 , Toritsu Shikk[MASK]i ) was imported into Japan , a[MASK]d it gained explosive popularity [MASK]n Confucian scholar[MASK] and chōnin ( townspeople ) class . The commentary established Du Fu 's fame as the highest of all poets ;[MASK]for instance , Hayashi Shunsai , a notable[MASK]Confucian scholar [MASK] commented in [MASK]ol . 37 of Gahō Bunshū that Zǐměi [ Du Fu ] was the very best poet in history and praised Shào Chuán 's commentary for its simplicity and readability , while he criticized old commentaries during the Yuan Dynasty were to[MASK] unfathomable . Matsuo Bashō ,[MASK]the greatest haiku poet , was also strongly influenced by Du Fu ; in Oku no Hosomichi , his masterpiece , he cites the first two lines[MASK]of A Spring View ( 春望 ) before a haiku [MASK]s its int[MASK]oduction[MASK]and [MASK]lso many of his other haiku have similar wording and themes . It is said that[MASK]when he died in Osaka during a lo[MASK]g travel , a co[MASK]y of Du Fu 's poetry was [MASK]ound with him as one of a few precious items which he was able to carry around . 
 
 = = Transla[MASK]ion = = 
 
 A variety of styles [MASK]ave been used in efforts to translate Du Fu 's work into English . As Burton Watson remarks [MASK]n The Selected Poems of Du Fu ,[MASK]" There are many different ways to approach the problems involved [MASK]n translating Du Fu , which is why we need as many different translation[MASK] as possible " ( p. xxii ) . The translators have had to[MASK]contend with bringing out the formal constraints of the original without sounding laboured to a Western ear [MASK] pa[MASK]ticula[MASK]ly when translating regulated verse , or lǜshi ) , and accommodating the complex allusions contained particularly[MASK]in the[MASK]later[MASK]w[MASK]rks ( Hawkes writes that " his poems do not as a rule co[MASK]e through very well [MASK]n translation " [MASK] p. ix ) . One extreme on each issue is re[MASK]resented by Kenneth Rexroth 's One Hundred Poems From the Chinese . His are free translations , which seek to conceal the [MASK]arallelisms through enjambement and expansion and contraction of the content ; his responses to the allusions are firstl[MASK] to omit most of the[MASK]e poems from[MASK]his selection , and secondly to " translate out " the references in those works which he does select . 
 O[MASK]her[MASK]translators have placed much greater weight on trying to convey a sense of the p[MASK]etic forms used by [MASK]u Fu . Vikram Seth in Three Chinese Poets uses English @-@ style rhyme schemes , whereas Keith Holyoak in F[MASK]cing the Moon approximates the Chinese rhyme schem[MASK] ; both use end @-@ stopped lines and preserve s[MASK]me degree of parallelism . In The Selected Poems of Du Fu , Burton Watson follows the parallelisms quite strictly , persuading the western [MASK]eader to adapt to the poems rather than vice versa . Similarly , he deals[MASK]with the allusion of [MASK]he later works by combining literal translation with exten[MASK]ive annotation .[MASK]
 In 2015 [MASK] Stephen Owen published translations , with faci[MASK]g Chinese texts , of the complete poetry of Du[MASK]Fu in six volumes , with extensive scholarly apparatus , which emphasized literalness . 
 
 
[MASK]= Kiss You ( One Direction song ) = 
 
 " Kiss You " is a song recorded by English @-@ Irish boy band One Direction for their second studio alb[MASK]m , Take Me Home ( 2012 ) .[MASK]It was released as the [MASK]ecord 's second single in Germany and the third overall single on 7 January 2013 . The song was composed by Kristo[MASK]fer Fogelmark , Kristian Lundin , Albin Nedler , Savan Kotecha , Sh[MASK]llback and its producers , Carl Falk and Rami Yacoub . " Kiss You " is an upbeat power pop song with electronic effects ; the lyrics detail a prota[MASK]onist 's infatuation with a significant other . [MASK]ritics praised the song for its production , calling it a stand @-@ out track on Take Me Home . 
 The track became the group 's sixth top @[MASK]@ ten hit in Ireland and the United Kingdom , while attaining top @-@ forty positions in both Belgian territories ( Flanders and Wallonia ) , as well [MASK]s in Australia , Canada , De[MASK]mark , [MASK]rance , New Ze[MASK]land , and the Netherlands . The single peaked at number 46 on the US Billboard Hot 100 and has been certified gold by the Recording Industry Association of America ( RIAA ) for shipments of 500 @,@ 000 copie[MASK] [MASK] One Direction perform[MASK]d " Kiss You " on both the[MASK]UK and US versions of The X Factor and 3 major concert tours : Take Me Home To[MASK]r ( 2013 ) , Where We Are Tour[MASK]( 2014 ) and On the [MASK]oad Again Tour ( 2015 ) . 
 An accompanying music video , designed to display the group 's comedic timing [MASK] was directed by Vaughan Arnell , who had previously worked[MASK]with the group on two other music videos . The clip depicts the band shooting various [MASK]cenes via a green screen , which include sequences reminiscent of iconic music videos of songs such as the B[MASK]ach [MASK]oys ' " Surfer Girl " , El[MASK]is Presley 's [MASK] Jailhouse Rock " and Rammstein 's " Mein Land " . The music video received 10 @.@ 4 million views in a 24 @-@ hour period and positive comme[MASK]t[MASK]ry f[MASK]om reviewers , who appreciated its carefree , jubilant nature . 
 The song was included in the dancing game[MASK]Just Dance 2014 , and is also one of th[MASK] select songs available on the demo version . Additionally , it is the final main track on [MASK]he US edition of Now That '[MASK] What I Call Music ! 46 [MASK]

 = = Composition and reception = = 
 
 " Kiss You " is [MASK]n u[MASK]t[MASK]mpo , upbeat power pop song which runs for a durat[MASK]on of 3 : 04 ( 3 minutes , four seconds ) . The track features electronic eff[MASK]cts , colossal hook[MASK] , a " na na na " breakdown , and a Motown @-@ tinged melody . One Directio[MASK] 's vo[MASK]al range in the song span from the note of E4 to C ♯[MASK]6 . I[MASK]strumentation includes guitar strings , piano[MASK]lines and vocals . Written in the [MASK]ey of E major , th[MASK] beat is s[MASK]t in common time and moves at a quick 90 b[MASK]ats pe[MASK] minute , according t[MASK] the digital sheet music published at [MASK]usicnotes.com by Sony / ATV Music Publishing . Li[MASK]ewise , Matt Collar from Allmusic noted that the track is " frenetically hyper " . The lyrical content regards t[MASK]e protagonist 's infatuation with a significant other , and incorporates eu[MASK]hemisms for sexual intercourse in the lines " If you don ’ t wa[MASK]na take it slow [MASK] And you just wanna take me home / Baby say yeah , yeah , yeah , yeah , yeah .  " Kiss You " was well received by contempo[MASK]ary music critic[MASK][MASK], who centred on its quality of production . Both Rolling Stone 's Jon Dolan , who praised its effectiven[MASK]ss , an[MASK] Chris Payne of Billboard [MASK] who appreciat[MASK]d the melody , described " Kiss You " as o[MASK]e of the album 's highlights . Alexis Petridis for The Guardian commended the track 's chorus as " hard to dislodge from your brain " . [MASK]obert Copsey of Digital Sp[MASK] noted the song 's possibility to become an international hit , applauding it sonic[MASK]lly . A reviewer for MTV News described the track 's lyri[MASK]ism as " butterflies @-[MASK] inducing " , and Sam Lansky of Idolator wrote that " Kiss You " [MASK]s noticeably a stand @-@ out track on its parent album . Melinda Newman , writing for HitFix , regarded the so[MASK]g as " a bouncy , electronic infectious ditty , " while Chris[MASK]Yo[MASK][MASK]ie , a critic from 4Music , deemed it an " amazing pop song " , lauding the group 's falsetto and its " head @-@ banging anthemic " chorus .

 = I[MASK]e [MASK]-@ class battleship = 
 
 T[MASK]e Ise @-[MASK] class battleships ( 伊勢型戦艦 , Ise @-@ gata senkan ) were a pair of dreadnought battleships built for the Imperial Japanese Navy ( IJN ) during World War I. Originally intended to be repeats [MASK]f the precedin[MASK] Fusō class , they were redesigned before construction began . Both ships ca[MASK]ried supplies for the survivors of the Great Kantō ea[MASK]thquake in 1923 . They were mode[MASK]nized in [MASK]934 [MASK] 37 with improvements to their armour and machinery and a rebuilt superstructure in the pagoda mast style . After[MASK]ards they played a minor role in the Second Sino @-@ Japanese War . 
 Despite the e[MASK]pensive reconstructions , both vessels were considered obsolete[MASK]by the eve of the Pacific War , and neither saw significant action in the early years of the war . Following the loss of most of the IJN 's large aircr[MASK]f[MASK] carriers during th[MASK] Batt[MASK]e of Midway in mid @-@ 1942 , they were rebuilt with a [MASK]light deck replacing the rear pair of gun turrets to give them the a[MASK]ility to operate an air group of floatplanes . A l[MASK]ck of aircraft and qualified pilots , however , meant that they never actually operated their a[MASK]rcraft in combat . While awaiting their air group the [MASK]ister ships were sometimes used to ferry troops and material to Japanese bases . They participated in the Battle of Cape Engaño in late 1944 , where they decoyed the American carrier fleet support[MASK]ng the[MASK]invasion of Leyte away from the landing beaches . Afterwards both ships were transferred to Southeast Asia ; in early 1945 they participated in Operation Kita , where [MASK]he[MASK] transported petrol and other strategic materials to Japan . The sisters were then reduced to[MASK]r[MASK]serve until t[MASK]ey were sunk during American airstrikes in July . After the war they were scrapped in 1946 – 47 . 
 
 = = Background = = 
 
 The design [MASK]f the Fusō @-@ class battleships was shaped bo[MASK]h by the ongoing in[MASK]ernational naval arms race and a desire amon[MASK] Japa[MASK]ese naval planners to maintain a fleet of capital[MASK]ships powerful enough to defeat the United States Navy in an encounter in Japanese territ[MASK]rial wate[MASK]s . The[MASK]IJN 's fleet of batt[MASK]eships had proven highly successful in 1905 , the last year of the Russo @-@ Japanese War [MASK] which culminated in the destruction of the Russian Second and Third Pacific Squadrons at the Battle of Tsushima . 
 In the aft[MASK]rmath , the Japanese [MASK]mpire immediately turned its focus to [MASK]he two remaining rivals for imperial dominance in[MASK]the P[MASK]cific Ocean : Britain a[MASK]d the United States . Satō Tetsu[MASK]arō , a Japanese [MASK]avy admiral and military theorist , speculated that conflict would inevit[MASK]bly arise between Japan[MASK]and at least one of its two main rivals . To that end , he called fo[MASK] the Japanese Navy to maintain a fleet with at least 70[MASK]% as many capital ships as the US Navy . This ratio , Satō theorized , would enable the Imperial[MASK]Japanese N[MASK]vy to defeat the US [MASK]avy in one major battle in Japanese waters in any eventual[MASK]conflict . Accord[MASK]ngly , the 1907 Imperial Defence Policy called for the [MASK]on[MASK]truction of a battle fleet of eight modern battleships , 20 @,@ 000 long tons ( 20 @,@ 321 t ) each , and eight modern armoured cruisers , 18 @,@ 000 long tons ( 18 @,@[MASK]289 t ) [MASK]ach . This was the genesis of the Eight @-@ Eight Fleet Program , the development of a cohesive battle line of sixteen cap[MASK]tal ships . 
 The launch of HMS Dreadnought in 1906 by the Royal Navy raised the stakes , and complic[MASK]ted Japan 's plans . Displ[MASK]cing[MASK]17 [MASK],@ 900 long tons ( 18 @,@ 200 t ) and armed with ten 12 @-@ inch ( 30 @.@ 5 cm ) [MASK]uns , [MASK]readnought rendered all exist[MASK]ng battleships obsolete by comparison . The launch of the battlecruiser HMS Invincible t[MASK][MASK][MASK][MASK]ollowing year was a further setback for Ja[MASK]an 's quest for parity . When the two new Satsuma @-@ class battleships and two Tsukuba @-@ class armoured cruisers , launched[MASK]by 1911 , were outclassed by their British cou[MASK]terparts , the Eight @-@ Eight Fleet Program was restarted . 
 The first battleships built for the renewed [MASK]ight @-@ Eight Fleet Program w[MASK]re the two dreadnoughts of the Kawach[MASK] class , ord[MASK]red in 1907 and laid down in 1908 . In 1910 , the Navy put[MASK]forward a request to the Diet ( parliament ) to secure funding for the entirety of the program at once . Because of economic constraints , only four battlecruisers and a single battleship of the Fusō class were [MASK]ltimately approv[MASK]d by the Diet . Three more Fu[MASK]ō @-@ class ships ( Yamashiro , Ise , and H[MASK]ūga[MASK]) were approved and all t[MASK]ree were ordered in April[MASK]1913 . While Yamashiro was laid d[MASK]wn later that year , the IJN lacked the funding to proceed with the construction of Ise and Hyūga until the Diet authorized additional funding for the ships in July 1914 . 
 
 = = Design and description = = 
 
 The p[MASK]ogress of Fus[MASK] 's construction , while the IJN waited for the funding to be released and foreign developments , caused the IJN to reassess the F[MASK]sō @-@ class design . The distribution of the midships [MASK]un turrets was the most obvious flaw as they complicated the [MASK]rotection of the midships magazine and exposed more of the ship to the blast effects of the guns[MASK]when they fired . Another issue was that Japanes[MASK] sailors had problems maintaining a high rate of fire with the 45 @.@ 36 @-@ kilogram ( 10[MASK] @.@[MASK]0 lb ) shells used in the manually loaded 152 @-@ millimetre ( 6 in ) secondary guns used in the Fusō class and earlier designs . To resolve this issue , the IJN designed a smaller 140 @-@ millimetre ( 5 @.@ 5 in ) gun that offset its light[MASK]r shell weigh[MASK] with a higher rate of fire . It al[MASK]o decided that the barb[MASK]tte a[MASK]mour of the earlier ships was to[MASK] thin and wanted a [MASK]odest inc[MASK]ease in speed to pa[MASK]tially counter the higher speeds of the latest foreign ships [MASK]ike the British Queen Elizabeth @-[MASK] class bat[MASK]leships and Russian Borodino @-@[MASK]class battlecruisers . For financial reasons more p[MASK]werful engines could not be ordered so t[MASK]e new design was lengthened slightly and the boiler rooms enlarged to increase speed by 0 @.@ 5 knots ( [MASK] @.@ 93 km / h ; 0 @.@ 58 mph ) to 23 knots[MASK]( 43 km / h ; 26 mph ) . To save weig[MASK]t the forecastle[MASK]deck was shorte[MASK]ed so that the lower midships gun turret was lower than [MASK]n the Fusō class . This reduced the crew 's accommodations despite a signif[MASK]cant increase in the crew 's numbers and na[MASK]al historian Fukui Shizuo beli[MASK]ved that these ships had the worst habit[MASK]bility o[MASK] any Japanese capita[MASK] [MASK]hip . The final design was designated A @[MASK]@ 92 by the IJN and differed enough from the A @-@ 64 design of the Fusō class that it was considered a separate class . 
 The ships had a length of 208 @.@ 18 metres ( 68[MASK] ft 0 in ) overall , a beam of 2[MASK] @.@ 65 metres ( 94 ft 0 in ) and a draught of 8 @.@ 93 metres ( 29 ft 4 in ) at deep load . They displac[MASK]d 36 @,[MASK] 500 long tons ( 37 @,@ 100 t ) at deep load , [MASK]oughly 650 long tons ( 660 t ) more than[MASK]the preceding class . Their crew consi[MASK]ted of 1 @,@ 360 officers and enlisted men . They had a metacentric height of 1 @.@ 737 metres ( 5 ft 8 @.@ 4 in ) at deep load . 
 During the ships ' modernization dur[MASK]ng the 1930s , their forward superstructures w[MASK]re enlarged with multiple platfor[MASK]s a[MASK]ded to their tripod foremasts . Both s[MASK]ips were also given torpedo bulges to improve their underwater protection and to compensate for the weight of the additional armour . In additio[MASK] , their sterns were lengthened by 7 @.@ 62 metres ( 25 @.@ 0 ft ) . These changes[MASK]increased[MASK]their overall l[MASK]ngth to 213 @.@ 8 metres ( 701 ft ) , their beam to 31 @.@ 75 metres ( 104 ft 2 in ) [MASK]nd their draft to 9 [MASK].@ 45 metres ( 31 ft 0 i[MASK] ) . Their displacement increased over 5 @,@ 000 long tons ( 5 @,@ 100 t ) to 42 @,@ 001 long tons ( 4[MASK] @,@ 675 t ) at deep load [MASK] The crew now numbered 1 @,@ 376 off[MASK]cers and enlisted men . 
 
 = = = Propulsion = = = 
 
 The Ise @-@ clas[MASK] ships had two sets of direct @-@ drive steam turbines , each of which drove two propeller shafts with 3 @.@ 429 @-@ metre ( 11 ft 3 in ) propellers . The high @-@ pressure turbines drove the wi[MASK]g shafts while the low @-@ pressure turbines drove the inner shafts . The turbines were designed to produce a tota[MASK][MASK]of 40 @,@ 000 or 45 @,@ 000 shaft ho[MASK]sepower ( 30 @,@ 000 or 34 @,@ 000[MASK]kW ) ( Hyūga and Ise respectively ) , using steam provided by 24 Kampon Ro Gō water @-@ tube boilers at working pressures of 13 –[MASK]16 @.@ 9 kg / cm2 ( 1 @,@ 275 – 1 @,@ 657 kPa[MASK]; 185 – 240 psi ) . Both ships comfortably exceeded their designed speed of 23 knots ( 43 km /[MASK]h ;[MASK][MASK]6 mph ) du[MASK]ing their sea trials ; Ise reached 23 @.@ 6 knots ( 43 @.@ 7 km / h ; 27 @.@ 2 mph ) from 56 @,@ 498 shp ( 42 @,@ 131 kW ) and Hyūga e[MASK]ceeded that with 24 [MASK]nots ( 44 km / h ; 28 mph ) from 63 @,@ 211 shp ( 47 @,@ 136 kW ) . Ea[MASK]h of the boilers consumed a mixture of coal and oil and the ships had a stowage c[MASK]pacity of 4 @,@ 607 long tons ( 4 @,@ 681 t ) of coal an[MASK] 1 @,@ 411 long tons ( 1 @,@ 434 t ) of fuel oil , which gave them a range of 9 @,@ 680 nautica[MASK] miles ( 17 @,@ 930 km ; 11 @,@ 140 mi ) at a speed of 14 knots ( 26 km / h ; 16 mph ) . Ise and Hyūga had three generators of 150 kilowatts ( 200 hp ) capacit[MASK] and two 250 @-@ kilowatt ( 340 hp ) turbo generators at 225 volts . 
 During their 1930s m[MASK]dernization , the boilers on each ship were replaced by eight new Kampon o[MASK]l @-@ fir[MASK]d boilers , fitted into the former aft boiler room , and the forward funnel was removed . The turbines were replaced by [MASK]our geared Kampon turbines w[MASK]th a designed output of 80 @,@ 000 shp ([MASK]60 @,@ [MASK]0[MASK] kW ) in[MASK]ended to increase their speed to 24 @.@ 5 knots ( 45 @.@ 4 km / h ; 28 @.@ 2 mp[MASK] ) . On her trials , Ise reached a top speed of 25 @.@ 26 knots ( 46 @.@ 78 km / h[MASK]; 29 @.@ 07 mph )[MASK]from 81 @,@ 050 shp ( 60 @,@ 440 kW ) . The fuel storage of the shi[MASK]s was increased to a total of 5 @,@ 113 lo[MASK]g tons ( 5 @,@ 195 t ) of fuel oil that gave them a range of 7 @,@ 870 nautical miles ([MASK]14 @,@ 580 km ; 9 @,@ 060 mi ) at a speed of 16 knots ( 30 km / h ; 18 mph ) . 
 
 = = = Armament = = = 
 
 The twelve 45 @-@ calibre 35 @.@ 6 cm ( 14 @.@ 0 in ) [MASK]ype 41 guns o[MASK] the Ise class were mounted in three pairs of twin @-@ gun , superfi[MASK]ing turrets . Numbered one thr[MASK]ugh six f[MASK]om front to rear , each turret [MASK]eighed 655 long tons ( 666 t ) . The hydraulically powered turrets ha[MASK] an elevation ca[MASK]ability of − 5 / + 20 degrees . The guns had a rate of fire of 1 @.@ 5[MASK]– 2 rounds per minute and[MASK]could[MASK]be lo[MASK]ded at any angle between -3 an[MASK] + 20 degrees . In 1921 [MASK]he elevation was increased to + 30 degrees and then to + 43 degrees during their mid @-@ 1930s modernization , except for No. 6 turr[MASK]t as its supporting structure could not be lowered . The recoil [MASK][MASK]chanism of the guns was also changed from a hydraulic to a pneumatic system , which allowed for a faster firing cycle of the main guns . 
 By World [MASK]ar II , the [MASK]uns used Type 91 armour @-@ piercing , capped shells . Each of these shells weighed 67[MASK] @.@ 5 kilograms ( 1 @,@ 485 lb ) and was fired at a muzzle velocity of 770 – 775 metres per second ( 2 @,@ 530 – 2 @,@ 540 ft / s ) . They[MASK]had a maximum range of 25 @,@ 000 metr[MASK]s ( 27 @,@ 000 yd ) at + 20 degrees of elevation and 35 @,@ 450 meters ( 38 @,@ 770 yd ) at + 43 degrees after modernization . Also ava[MASK]lable was a 625 @-@ kilogram ( 1 @,@ 378 lb ) high @-@ explosive shell that ha[MASK] a muzzl[MASK] velocity of 805 metres per second ( 2 @,@ 640 ft / s ) . A special Type 3 Sanshikidan incendiary shrapnel shell was developed in the 1930s for anti @-@[MASK]aircraft use . 
 The ships ' secondary armament consisted of twenty 50 @-@ calibre 14 @-@ centimetre Type 3 . Eighteen of these w[MASK]re mounted in casemates in the forecastle and superstructure and the remaining pair wer[MASK] mounted on the deck above them and protected by gun sh[MASK]elds . They had a maximum eleva[MASK]ion of + 20 degrees which gave them ranges of 1[MASK] @,@ 300 metres[MASK][MASK] 17 @,@ 800 yd ) . Each gun had a rate of fire of up to 10 rounds per minute . Anti @-@ aircraft defence was provided by four 40 @-@ calibre 3rd Year Type[MASK]8 @-@ centimetre AA guns i[MASK] single mounts . T[MASK]e 7 @.@ 62 @-@ centimetre ( 3 in [MASK] high @-@ angle guns had a maximum elevation of + 75 degrees , and had a [MASK]ate of fire of 13 to 20 rounds per minute . They fired a 6 kg ( 13 lb ) projectile with a muzzle velo[MASK]ity of 680 m / s ( 2 @,@ 200 ft / s ) to a maximum height of 7 @,@ 500 metres ( 24 [MASK],@ 600 ft ) . The ships were also fitted with six submerged 53 @.@ 3 @-@ centimetre ( 21 @.@ 0 in ) torpedo tub[MASK]s , three on[MASK]each bro[MASK]dside .[MASK]They carried twelve t[MASK] eighteen 6th Year Type[MASK]torpedoes which had a 200 @-@ kilogram ([MASK]440 lb ) war[MASK]ead . [MASK]hey had three settings for range and speed : 15 @,@ 000[MASK]metres ( 16 @,@ 000 yd ) at 26 knot[MASK] ( 48 [MASK]m / h ; 30 mph ) , 10 @,@ 000 metres ( 11 @,@ 000 yd ) at 32 knots ( 59 km /[MASK]h ; 37 mph ) , or 7 @,@ 000 metres ( 7 @,@ 700 yd ) at 37 knots ( 69 km / h ; 43 mph ) . 
 In 1931 – 33 the AA guns were replaced with[MASK]eight 40 @-@ caliber 12 @.@ 7 cm ( 5 @.@ 0 in ) Type 89 dual @-@ purpose guns , fitted on[MASK]both sides of the forward superstructures in four twin @-@ gun mounts . When firing at surface targets , the guns had a range of 14 @,@ 700 metres ( 16 @,@ 100 yd ) ; [MASK]hey had a ceiling of [MASK][MASK]@,@ 440 metres ( 30 @,@ 970 ft ) at their maximum elevation o[MASK] + 90 degrees . Their maximum rate of fire was 14 rounds a minute , but their sustained rate of fire was around eight rounds per minute . Two [MASK]win @-@ gun mounts for license @-@ built [MASK]ickers tw[MASK] @[MASK]@ pound[MASK]r light AA guns were also adde[MASK] . These guns had a maximum elevation of + 80 degrees and a rate of fire[MASK]of 200 rounds per minut[MASK] .[MASK]The pair[MASK]of 14 cm guns on the upper deck were removed at this time . 
 During the mid @-@ 1930s reconstruction the torpedo tubes were [MASK]emoved and th[MASK] Vickers two @-@ pounders were replaced by twenty license @-@ b[MASK]ilt Hotchkiss 25 mm Type 96 light AA guns[MASK]in 10 twin @-@ gun [MASK]ounts . This w[MASK]s the standard Japanese light AA gun during World War II , but it suffered from severe design shor[MASK]comings that rendered it a largely[MASK]ineffective [MASK]eapon . According to historian [MASK]ark Stille , the twin and triple mounts " lacked sufficient speed in train[MASK]or elevation ; the gun sights were unable to handle [MASK]ast targets ; the gun exhibited excessive vibrat[MASK]on ; the magazine was too small , and , finally , the gun produ[MASK]ed excessive muzzle blast " . These 25 @-@ millimetre ( 0 @.@ 98 in ) guns had an effective range of 1 @,@ 500 – 3 @,@ [MASK]00 metres ( 1[MASK]@,@ 6[MASK]0 – 3 @,@ 300 yd ) , and an effective ceiling of 5 @,@ 500 metres ( 18 @,@ 000 ft ) at an elevation [MASK]f 85 degrees . The m[MASK]ximum effective rate of fire was only between 110 and 120 rounds pe[MASK] minute because of the frequent [MASK]eed to change the fifteen @-@ round magazines . In addition the fo[MASK]ward pair of 14 cm gu[MASK]s in the forecastle were removed at this time an[MASK] the maximum elevation of the remaining guns was increased to + 30 degrees . 
 
 = = = Protection = = = 
 
 The Ise @-@ class shi[MASK]s ' waterline protective belt had a maximum thicknes[MASK] of 299 mm ( 11 @.@ 8 in ) of Vickers cemented armour amidships ; below it was a strake of 100 mm ( 3 @.@ 9 in ) armour . The upper armoured deck consist[MASK]d of two layers of high @-@ tensile steel 55 mm ( 2 @.@ 2 in ) thick and the lower armoured deck also consisted of two layers of high @-@ tens[MASK]le steel , but only 30 mm ( 1 @.@ 2 in ) thick . The sides of [MASK]his deck slo[MASK]ed downwards to mee[MASK] the bottom of the lower strake of the belt armour . The ends of th[MASK] belt armour were closed off by bulkheads that rang[MASK][MASK] in thickness from 203 to 102 mm ( 8 to 4 in ) . The turrets were protected with an armour thickness o[MASK] 254 mm[MASK]( 10 in ) on the [MASK]ace and 76 mm on the roof . The casemate armour was 149 mm ( 5 @.@ 9 in ) thick and[MASK]that of the barbettes was 299 mm thick rather than the originally planned 305 mm . The sides of the conning tower were [MASK]05 mm thick [MASK] 
 The Ise class[MASK]were the only Japanese battleships to place the pow[MASK]er magazine above the shell magazine a[MASK] the IJN[MASK]wished to put as m[MASK]c[MASK] space as possible between th[MASK] highly flammable propellant and mine and tor[MASK]edo detonations . The danger from plunging sh[MASK]lls at long [MASK]istances was not[MASK]appreciated until the fatal magazine explosions of three British battlecruisers during the 1916 Battle of Jutland graphically demonstrated the point . To further protect the magazines[MASK]the depth of the double bo[MASK]tom was increased to a total of 3 @.@ 58 metres ( 11 ft 9 in ) underneath the barbett[MASK]s[MASK]and magazines . Additionally , the ves[MASK]els cont[MASK]ined 660 watertig[MASK]t compartments to preserve buoyancy in the event of battle damage . In addition to the[MASK]torpedo bulge added when the ships were modernized , the deck armour over the machinery and magazines was increased to a total th[MASK]ckness of 140 mm . Insi[MASK]e the original skin of the ships , two torpedo [MASK]ulkheads [MASK][MASK]re [MASK]lso added and the tur[MASK]et roofs were increased to a total of 152 millimetres ( 6 in ) o[MASK] armour . 
 
 = = = Fire control and sensors = = = 
 
 Whil[MASK] the details of the ship 's fire @-@ control ins[MASK]ruments are not full[MASK] availa[MASK]le , it is known that the ships were fitted with a fire @-@ control director after completion . No computer was fitted at that time and data from the range[MASK]inders had[MASK]to be processed manually . Turrets 2 [MASK] 3 , and 5 were built with imported 6 @-@ metre ( 19 ft 8 in ) Bausch & Lomb rangefin[MASK]ers . The[MASK]e [MASK]ere felt to be inferior t[MASK] the British Barr & Stroud instruments used on other ships a[MASK]d wer[MASK] remo[MASK]ed in 1920 . They were replaced by either the British rangefinders or domestically built instruments of 6 or [MASK] metres ( 19 ft 8 in or 26 [MASK]t 3 in ) length . In the late 1920s[MASK]the fire @-@ control s[MASK]stems were upgraded and a[MASK]ditional platforms were added to the foremast to accommodate them . A pair of directors for the 12 @.@ 7 cm A[MASK] gu[MASK]s were added , one on each side of the forward superstructure , [MASK]n the early 1930s . The fire @-@ control systems were again upgraded in the mid @-@ 1930s and director[MASK] were[MASK]added for t[MASK]e 25 mm AA guns . Both ships had 10 @-@ metre ( 32 ft 10 in ) rangefinders installed at t[MASK]e top of the pagoda mast [MASK][MASK] that time . Type 21 air @-@ search radars were installed aboard the sisters in mid @-@ 1942 . [MASK] 
 = = = Aircraft = = = 
 
 Ise was briefly fitted with an aircraft flying @-@ off platform for a Mitsubishi 1MF3 fig[MASK]ter on Turret No. 2 in 1927 . It was replaced by a platform on Turret No. 5 for a Yokosuka E1Y reconnaissance floatplane in 1928 – 29 . A catapult and a collapsible 4 @-@ tonne ([MASK]3 @.@ 9 @-@ long @-@ ton ) crane w[MASK]re fitted on the stern du[MASK]ing the m[MASK]d @-@ 1930s modernization , and the ships were equipped to opera[MASK]e[MASK]three floatplanes , although no hangar was provided .[MASK]The in[MASK]tial Nakajima E4N2 biplanes were replaced by Nakajima E8N2 biplanes in 1938 . 
 
 = = Conversion to hybrid carriers = = 
 
 The sinki[MASK]g of the British cap[MASK]tal ships Prince of Wales and Repulse by Japanese land [MASK]-@ b[MASK]sed aircraft on 10 December 1941 led the IJN t[MASK] realize that battleships could not operate[MASK]in the face of enemy ai[MASK][MASK]raft and required friendly air support to protect them . The los[MASK] of four Japanese aircraft carriers [MASK]u[MASK]ing the Battle of Midway in June 1942 severely limited the ability of th[MASK] IJN to provide any air cover and alternatives were sought . Earlier proposals to convert one or more battleships into carriers had[MASK]been made and rejected at the beginn[MASK]ng of the war , but they were revived aft[MASK]r Midway . Plans for more elaborate conversions were rejected on the grounds of expense and , most critically , time , and the IJN[MASK]settled on removing the r[MASK]ar pair of turrets and replacing them with a flight deck equipped with two catapults to launch floatplanes . The Ise @-@ class ships were selected for the conver[MASK]ion because Hyūga had suffered an explosion in Turret No.[MASK]5 in early May that virtually destroyed the turret and their Turret No. 6 could not ele[MASK]ate to the full[MASK]+ 43 degrees deemed necessary for the long @[MASK]@ range engagement anticipate[MASK] by the IJN . The Fusōs were scheduled to follow once the first two were completed . 
 
 = = = Armament changes = = = [MASK] 
 The rear turrets , the barbettes and their s[MASK]pporting structures were removed beginning in early 1943 and the openings in the middle deck were covered by 152 mm plates salvaged from the turret armour . All of the 14 cm guns were removed [MASK]nd the casema[MASK]e openings sealed off . Four additional t[MASK]in 12 @.@ 7 cm mount[MASK] w[MASK]re added , one pai[MASK] abreast the funnel and the other abre[MASK]st the conning tower . The original ten twin 25 mm gun mounts were replaced by triple mounts and nine new triple mounts were added , a t[MASK][MASK]al of 57 guns . Two each Type 94 and Type 95 AA directors were added[MASK]to control[MASK]the additional guns . The ammunition for these new guns wa[MASK][MASK]stored in the magazines originally used for the 1[MASK] cm guns and for [MASK]urret No. 5 . During 1944 , the ships ' AA defences[MASK]were reinforced with an additional dozen triple and eleven sin[MASK]le 2[MASK] mm gun mounts , for a total of 104 barrels , and a pair of Type 13 early warning radars were added . In September six 30 @-@ round AA rocket launchers were added on the sides of the flight deck . 
 
 = = = F[MASK]ig[MASK]t deck arrangements = = = 
 
 A 70 @-@ metre @-@ l[MASK]ng ( 229 ft 8 in ) flight deck was built above the stern and stretched forward to the rebuilt aft superstructure . The flight deck was 29 metres ( 95 ft 2 in ) wide at its forward end and 13 [MASK]etres ( 42 ft 8 in ) at the stern . It overhun[MASK] the stern and increased the overall [MASK]ength of[MASK]the[MASK]ships to 219 @.@ 62 metres ( 720 ft 6 in ) . A pair of rot[MASK]ting gunpowder @-[MASK] propelled catapu[MASK]ts were fitted on the sides of the hull , forward of the aft superstructure where they partially restricted the arc of fire of the tw[MASK] amidships turret[MASK] . They could launch aircraft up to 4 @,@ 600 kilograms ( 10 @,@ 100 lb ) in weight and required 30 seconds to launch each aircraft . The flight deck had eight permanent storage positio[MASK]s connected by rails to the catapults and the hydraulically operated aircraft lift that brough[MASK] the aircraft up from the hangar below on the trolleys used to move the floatplanes about . Two aircraft were intended to be sto[MASK]ed on the catapults and three more in temporary positions on the flight deck fo[MASK] a total of thir[MASK]een[MASK]. 
 The 40 @-@ metre @-@ long ( 131 ft 3 in ) hangar was 20 metres ( 65 ft 7 in ) wide forward and 11 metres ( 36 ft 1 in ) at [MASK]he [MASK]ear . It was 6 metres ( 19 ft 8 in ) high and de[MASK]igned to stow nine aircraft . It was fitted with fire fighting foam and carbo[MASK] dioxide dispensers as a result of wartime experience . The ' T ' -shaped lift was 12 @.@ 1 metres ( 3[MASK] ft[MASK]8 in ) wide at its forward end and 6 @.@ 6 metres ( 21 ft 8 in ) wide at the its aft end . It was 12 @.@ 1 metres long and had a capacity of 6 tonnes ( 5 @.@ 9 long tons )[MASK]. Petrol storage tanks with a capacity of 76 tonnes ( 75 long tons ) were installed in the former magazine of Turret No. 6 to provide each aircraft with enough fuel for thr[MASK]e sorties . To recover the aircraft the collapsible crane formerly on th[MASK] stern was moved up t[MASK][MASK]the[MASK]port side of the flight deck . Another crane was intended on the starboard side , but it was never fitted . 
 The ships had an air group of 11 ea[MASK]h of Yokosuka D4Y dive bombers ( Allied reporting name " Judy " ) and Aichi E16A reconnaissance aircraft ( Allied reporting name " Paul " ) Both aircraft had [MASK]evelopment problems and neither air group [MASK]ver had all of[MASK]its intended aircraft . Coupled wit[MASK] a shortage of trained pilots , neither ship ever used its aircr[MASK]ft dur[MASK]ng combat .

 [MASK]fter [MASK]he loss of the fast battleship Hiei at the Naval Battle of Guadalcanal in late 1942 to rudder damage , the IJN decided to reinforce the protection of the steering compartment an[MASK] to [MASK]reate an auxiliary steering compartment . The protection o[MASK] the former[MASK]was str[MASK]ngthened by [MASK]he addition of a concrete wall at least 1 metre ( 3 ft 3 in ) in thickness and some of the armour removed from [MASK]he turrets was used to [MASK]rot[MASK]ct the latter . The double bottom below the former positions of aft turrets was converted to hold fuel oil ; this increased the ships ' endurance to 9 @,@ 500 nautical miles ( 17 @,@ 600 km ; 10 @,@ 900 mi ) at a sp[MASK]ed [MASK]f 16 knots[MASK]. A pair of Type 22 surf[MASK]ce @-@ search radars were also fitted during the conversion . 
 The removal of the seco[MASK]dary armament , the rear turrets and their supporting structur[MASK]s was generally compensated by the addition of the flight deck , hangar , AA guns and more fuel , and the metacentric height increase[MASK] .23 metres ( 9 @.@ 1 in ) to 2 @.@ 81 [MASK]etres ( 9 ft 3 in ) at full load as a result of[MASK]th[MASK] reduction in the displacement by over 2 @,@ 000 tonnes ( 2 @,@ 000[MASK]long tons ) to 40 [MASK],@ 444 tonnes ( 39 @,@ 805 long tons [MASK] . This also reduced the draught to 9 @.@ 03 metres ( 29 ft 8 in ) . The overhang of the flight deck at the stern increased th[MASK] [MASK]verall len[MASK]th[MASK]to 219 @.@ 62 metres ( 720 ft 6 in ) a[MASK]d the beam was slightly reduced to [MASK]1 @.@ 71 metres ( 104 ft 0 in[MASK]) . 
 
 = = Ships = = 
 
 
 = = Se[MASK]vice = = 
 
 Upon commissioning , the sister ships were assigned to the 1st Battleship Di[MASK]ision of the 1st Fleet . Hyūga had an explosion in one of her [MASK]ain gun turrets that kil[MASK]ed 11 men and injured[MASK]25 in 1919 ; the following year she accidentally collided with and san[MASK] a schooner , losing two crewmen .[MASK]Before the start of the Pacific Wa[MASK][MASK][MASK] both ships frequently exercised off the coasts o[MASK] the Soviet Union , Korea and China in addition to training in Japanese waters . Ise hosted E[MASK]ward , P[MASK]ince of Wales , and his aide @-@[MASK]de @-@ camp Lieutenant Louis Mountbatten [MASK]n 1922 during the prince 's visit to Japan . In Korea Bay when the 1923 [MASK]r[MASK]at Kantō earthquake struck , they sailed to Kyushu where they loaded [MASK]upplies from for the victims on 4 September . Together with two other b[MASK]ttleship[MASK] and a [MASK]air of light [MASK]ruisers , Ise sank [MASK]he destroyer Yayoi in 1926 during gunnery practice[MASK]. Ise[MASK]'s AA armament was upgraded in 1931 and Hyūga 's two years later . The latter ship was modernized in 1934 – 36 and Ise i[MASK] 1935 – 37[MASK], both at Kure Naval Arsenal . During the Second Sino @-@ Japanese [MASK]ar , the sister[MASK] frequently patrolled the Chinese coast in support of the blockade imposed [MASK]y Japan . In August 1937 Hy[MASK]ga ferried two battalions of Spec[MASK]al Naval Landing Fo[MASK]ces to Port Arthur . Three years later , she served as the flagship for the Emperor of the puppet state of Manchukuo , Henry Pu @-@ yi , during his state visit to Japan in June 1940 . On 15 November the ships were transf[MASK]rred to the 2n[MASK] Battleship Division of the 1st Fleet . The siste[MASK]s [MASK]ere refitted in late 1940 in preparation for war , which included the fitting of external degaussing coils and addit[MASK]onal AA directors . [MASK][MASK]
 =[MASK]= = World War II = = = 
 
 When Japan began the Pacific War on 8 December , the sisters sortied for the Bonin Islands with f[MASK]ur other battleship[MASK] and the light [MASK]arrier Hōshō as distant cover for the fleet attacking Pearl Harbor , and returned six days [MASK]ater . On 11 March 1942 Ise and Hyūga sortied from their anchorage at Hashirajima to join the unsuccessful search for the American carrier for[MASK]e that had atta[MASK]ked Marcus Island a week earlier . Similarly they pursued but d[MASK]d not catch the Am[MASK]rican carriers that had launched the Doolittle Raid on 18 April . 
 During gunnery training on 5 May , there was a premature detonation in the left gun of Hyūga 's Turret No. 5 that disabled both guns and killed 51 crewmen . Both aft magazines were flooded to douse [MASK]he resulting fire and save the ship . S[MASK]e received t[MASK]mporary repairs during which the turret was removed and replaced by a circular armour plate on which three triple 25 mm gun mounts were positioned . On 11 May a valve in Ise 's No. 2 engine room stuc[MASK] in the open position and[MASK]flooded the engine [MASK]oom . While under repair at Kure[MASK], both ships received prototype [MASK]ype 21 r[MASK]dars . Commanded by Vice @-@ Admiral Shirō Takasu , the 2nd Battleship [MASK]ivision set sail with the Aleutian Support Group on 28 [MASK]ay , at the same time that most of the Imperial Fleet began a[MASK] attack on Midway Island ( O[MASK]eration MI ) . 
 The[MASK] returned hom[MASK] on 14 June and the IJN began preliminary p[MASK]anning to replace[MASK]the lost carriers with hybrid carriers con[MASK]erted fr[MASK]m battleships . T[MASK]e sisters were selected for conversion and det[MASK]ched from the divisi[MASK]n on 14 Jul[MASK][MASK]in preparation . They remained on " standby alert " until the actual conversions began . Ise was converted at Kure Naval Arsenal from 23 February to 5 September 1943 and Hyūga at Sasebo Naval Arsenal from 2 May to 30 November . 
 After completing her sea trials , Ise was attached to the Imperial Japanese Naval Academy at [MASK]tajima and ferried troops and munitions to [MASK]he naval base at Truk in October . In November the ship beg[MASK]n working up , joined by the newly completed Hyūga [MASK]he followi[MASK]g month , and both rejoined the 2nd [MASK]attleship [MASK]ivision . On 1 May 1944 , the[MASK]sisters were transferred to Rear Adm[MASK]ral Matsuda Chiaki 's reformed Fourth Carrier Div[MASK]sion of the 3rd Fleet . The division 's 634th Naval Air Group was formed that same day and conducted its first catapult launches in late June . 
 
 = = = = Battle of Cape Engaño = = = = 
 
 Shortages of airc[MASK]aft and s[MASK]rviceability problems greatly retarded pilot training and the s[MASK]ips only had a total of 17 D4Ys and 18 E16As on hand on 1 October ; of these , only [MASK] and 16 were operational , respectively . The Japanese plan for the defence of the Philippines envisi[MASK]ned that the surviving [MASK]a[MASK]riers would be used to lure the American carrier forces away from the invasion area to a position where the carriers could be attacked by land @-@ based aircraft and [MASK]he transports by the rest of the IJN . The other carri[MASK]r air groups were not in much better shape and the Japanese decided to retain the aircraft ashore for use against the American carriers . The F[MASK]urth Carrier Division was assigned to the Northern Force under the command of Vi[MASK]e Adm[MASK]ral Jisaburō Ozawa and the sisters saile[MASK] from Yas[MASK]ima on 20 October . On the morning of 24 October , the bulk of the few aircraft aboard were launched to attack the American[MASK]carriers as a distrac[MASK]ion . They inflicted no damage and caused the Americans to search in the direction from[MASK]which they had attacked . The Americans finally spotted the Japanese carriers at 16 : 40 , some 200 miles[MASK]( 320 km ) east of Cape Engaño , the northeaster[MASK] tip of Luzon . The American car[MASK]iers were spread ou[MASK] and it was very l[MASK]te in the day to launch an airstrike , [MASK]o Admiral William Halsey , comm[MASK]nder o[MASK] the Third Fleet decided to mass his carriers in a po[MASK]ition to attack the following morning . Ozawa reversed course during the night , correctly believing that the Americans would follow him north . 
 Although they had lost contact during the night , the Americans did find the Japanese carriers at 07 : 35 . They had a[MASK]ready launched an airstrike of 180 aircr[MASK]ft that was orbiting 50 miles ( 80 km ) ahead of the American carriers while waiting for the Japanese ships t[MASK] be located . This was just the first of a total of five ai[MASK]strikes that the Americans launched that day [MASK] The sisters were not heavily engaged by[MASK]the early airstrikes w[MASK]ich are focusing on the group 's aircr[MASK]ft carriers . Ise claimed to have sho[MASK] down five attacking dive bombers from the second wave and one small bomb detonated on Turret No. 2 . Hyūga was lightly da[MASK]aged by[MASK]near misses that rupture some hull plating in her bulge and pepper her superstructure with splinters . She too[MASK] on a 5 @-@ degree list that was quickly corrected[MASK]before she was [MASK]rdered to tow [MASK]he cripple[MASK] carrier Chi[MASK][MASK]da to safety . Her attempt was unsuccessful an[MASK] Chiyoda had to be aband[MASK]ned to her fate . 
 Ise was attacked by 80 @-@ odd aircraft from the fourth wave , but they faile[MASK] to inflict any serious damage . [MASK]he dodged 11 torpedoes and was only hit by a bomb once , on the bulge outboard of the port catapult . Some 34 other bombs nea[MASK] missed her , spraying her with splinters and rupture[MASK] some hull plates that cont[MASK]minated some fuel oil and caused leaks in her port boiler roo[MASK]s . While an exa[MASK]t t[MASK]tal of her casualties is[MASK]not available , it has been estimated that 5 men were killed and some 111 – 121 crewmen were wounded during this attack . [MASK]yūga was unsucce[MASK]sfully attacked by an American submari[MASK]e at 18 : 43 . Around 19 : 00 Ozawa learned about a force [MASK]f d[MASK]stroyers and cruisers that dro[MASK]e [MASK]ff the Japanese dest[MASK]oyers rescuing survivors f[MASK]om some of the carriers lost earlier in the[MASK]day[MASK]and sank Chiyoda . H[MASK] ordered the Fourth Carrier Division to reverse course and engage the Americans , but the battleships were unable to find them , and Ozawa or[MASK]ered the[MASK] to reverse course and head for Amami Ōshima . W[MASK]en they arrived on 27 October , Ozawa transferred to Hyūga and hoisted his flag aboard her . While en route for Kure , the division was unsuccessfully attacked by another submarine . 
 In early November the catapults were removed from b[MASK]th ships , and they loaded troops and munitions later that month . While en ro[MASK]te they were diverted to the Spratly Islands upon reports of heavy ai[MASK][MASK]raids at Manila . After off @-@ loading their cargo , they sailed for Lingga Is[MASK]and , near Singapore , on 20 November . They transferred to Cam Ranh Bay , French Indochina and Hyūga became flagship of the 5th Fl[MASK]et there on 14 December . Th[MASK] division sailed for Singapore on 30 December and Vice Admiral Kiyohide Shima transferred his flag to the light cruiser [MASK]yodo on arrival there the following day . The division continued onwards to Lingga . Its planned return t[MASK] Japa[MASK] was delayed by attacks by the American Third F[MASK]eet on targets in Indochina and souther[MASK] China that sank two oil tankers that were inten[MASK]ed[MASK]to refuel[MASK]the division . 
 The IJN then decided to use the sisters and their[MASK]escorts to bring a load of petrol , rubber , tin [MASK]nd other strategic minerals back to Japan after the American c[MASK]rriers departed the South China Sea ( Operation Kita ) . They loaded [MASK]heir cargoes b[MASK]ginning on 6[MASK]February at Singapore and departed four days later . Also carrying[MASK]some 1 @,@ 150 oilfield workers[MASK],[MASK]they were escorted by Ōyodo and[MASK]three destroyers . Decrypted Japanese radio signals revealed the[MASK]Japanese plan to the Allies , and 15 submarines were [MASK]os[MASK]tioned along their anticipated route in[MASK]an attem[MASK]t to [MASK]ntercept and sink the ships . An additional 11 were moved into posi[MASK]ion while the group was en route , but only thr[MASK]e were ultimately able to attack . None of them were successful before the Japanese reached Kure on 20 February . The Fourth Carrier Division was disbanded on 1 March[MASK]and the sisters were reduced to 1st rank reserve ships . On 19 March Kure was attacked by aircraft from Task Force 58 and Hyūga was [MASK]it three times by bombs that killed 37 men and[MASK]w[MASK]unded 52 . Her [MASK]unners claimed to have shot down one American dive bomber during the attack . Ise was hit twice during the attack , but her casualties , if any , are unknown .[MASK]
 The ships were turned into floating AA batteries over the next several months although it availed them litt[MASK]e when they were attac[MASK]ed again by American carrier aircr[MASK]ft in July . On the 24th Ise was struck by five bombs [MASK]nd near missed multiple times ; all told she lost 50 crewmen killed and many others wounded . The bombs started numerous leaks and Ise began to settle by the[MASK]bow , alth[MASK]ugh she[MASK]was returned to an even keel after three @-@ days pumping . Hyūga was a primary focus of the attack and she received 10 direct hits a[MASK]d up to[MASK]30 near misses . She was badly damaged with some 200 @-[MASK] odd crewmen killed and 600 wounded during the attack . She slowly foundered over the next two days and was[MASK]not attacked when the Americans ret[MASK]rned four days later[MASK]. This tim[MASK] it was Ise 's turn and she was struck 11 or more times with many near misses that put her on the bottom in shallow water with a 15 degree list . T[MASK]e sisters were struck off the Navy List in November and their wrecks w[MASK]re scr[MASK]pped after the w[MASK]r . 
 
 
 = Dick Rifenburg = 
 
 Ri[MASK]hard Gale " Dick " Rifenburg ( August 21 , 1926 – [MASK]ecember 5 , 1994 ) was an American football player and a pioneering t[MASK]levision bro[MASK]d[MASK]aster for the forerunner[MASK]to WIVB @-@ TV in Buffalo [MASK] He playe[MASK] college footbal[MASK] for the University of Michigan Wolverines in 1944 and from 1946 to 1948 . He was a consensus selection at end on the 1948 College Football All @-@ America Team . Rifenburg played professionally in the National Football League ( NFL ) with the Detroit Lions for one season in 1950 . After retiring from football he sett[MASK]ed in Buffalo and became a sports broadcaster . He wo[MASK]ked as a color commentator and as a play @-@ by @-@ play an[MASK]ouncer for the Buffalo Bulls . He hosted various television and radio sports shows and was eventually inducted into the Buffalo Broadcasters Hall of Fame . 
 In college , he led the Big Ten[MASK]Conference in single season receptions during his senior year and set Michigan Wolverines receptions records for both career touchdown an[MASK] single @-@ season touchdowns . He had also been a[MASK]Michigan High School Athletic Association ( MHSAA ) state champion in bo[MASK]h basketball and track and field . His colle[MASK]e car[MASK]er was interrupted by World War II service , and his high school career was also [MASK]ffected b[MASK] the war due to the MHSAA 's cancellatio[MASK] of state championships in all sports in[MASK]1943 . 
 
 = = High school = = 
 
 Rif[MASK]nburg wa[MASK] born in Petoskey , Michigan , and raised in Kalamazoo , Michig[MASK]n before his family moved to Saginaw , M[MASK]chigan . Rifenburg was a star athlete at Saginaw 's Arthur Hill High School in footba[MASK]l , basketball , and track and field . In 1943 , Michigan canceled boys high sch[MASK]ol tournaments in all sports due to World War II , and they did not return until the fall of 1944 . In 1944 , he led Arthur Hill High to [MASK]he MHSAA Class A high school basketball[MASK]championship ( [MASK]ve[MASK] Kalamazoo Cen[MASK][MASK]al High School ) , sc[MASK]ring 24 points , including 17 in the second hal[MASK] , of the championship game . Rifenburg was also the state champion in 1944 in both the shot put 46 feet 11 inches ( 14 @.@ 30 m ) and high jump 5 feet 8 @.@ 5 inches ( 1 @.@ 74 m ) . He also led Arthur Hill in football , and his h[MASK]gh school ac[MASK]omplishments are featured in Glory : The history of Saginaw County sports by Jack Tany ( ASIN B0006RH9Z6 ) , which is a book on high school sports in Saginaw[MASK]County , Michigan . Ri[MASK]enburg was named All [MASK]tate in football , basketball an[MASK] track . 
 It is ironic that Rifenburg was born in [MASK]eto[MASK]key , Michigan in 1926[MASK]for several reasons . Ted Petoskey preceded Rifenburg as an All @-@ American end on the University of Michigan football team . Petoskey had e[MASK]celled as a representative of Saginaw County in MHSAA competition . Petoskey posted significant football acco[MASK]plishments[MASK]in 1926 making 1926 a significant year for himself as well . Achieving All @-@ American statu[MASK] as an end [MASK]t Michigan wou[MASK]d be Rifenburg 's n[MASK]xt step after excelling in MHSAA compe[MASK]ition . 
 
 [MASK] = College = = 
 
 In the fall [MASK]f 1944 , Rifenburg enrolled at the University of Michigan . The Uni[MASK]ed Press syndicate ran a feature art[MASK]cle about Rifenburg in Septembe[MASK] 1944 that opened as follows : " A[MASK]o[MASK]her great end has made his appearance on the Big Ten football horizon in the person of Dick Rife[MASK]burg , 18 @-@ year @-@ old Michigan freshman . Every [MASK]o oft[MASK]n a great offensive end comes along ,[MASK]a player who has to l[MASK]arn how to play defense , but who has the natural speed , smooth actions , height and big hands that[MASK]is the mark of an outstanding pass receiver . Rifenburg has laid claim to that rating . A loose @-@ limbed 180 @-@ p[MASK]und freshman from Saginaw , Mich . , [MASK][MASK]fenberg is being boomed as the Big Ten 's next ' freshman sensation[MASK]. ' " As a freshman , h[MASK] caught two touchdo[MASK]n passes in his first co[MASK]lege football game against [MASK]owa . In an article titled " Teens and TNT , " Time reported on Rif[MASK]nburg 's performance : " Of the few [MASK]eams already in action , Michigan 's teens rang the f[MASK]eshman bell loudest last w[MASK]ek by winning their opener , 12 -to @-@ 7 , against the strong Iowa Seahawks ( Naval Pre @-@ Flight ) ; 6 @-@ ft . 4 Freshman End Dick Rifenburg caught passes and ran for[MASK]both Michigan touchdowns . [MASK] 
 Rifenburg 's college career was interrupted b[MASK] World War II service in the United States Navy , but after missin[MASK] the [MASK]945 season , he returned to play for the Wolverines from 1946 to 1948 . Rifenburg played for the Wolver[MASK]nes in consecutive undefeated National Championship season[MASK] in 1947[MASK]and 1948 . He started nine games for the 1947 team . The 1947 team referred to as [MASK] Michigan 's Mad Magicians " is considered to be the greatest University of Michigan football team of all time . Rifenberg and teammate Len Ford had the reputati[MASK]n as the team practical jokers . During the 1947 game against Wisco[MASK]sin , Rife[MASK]burg started calling signals for the Badgers . Wisconsin 's offense proteste[MASK] to officials , who " prowled the Wolverines secondary[MASK]but never caught their man . " Rifenburg cont[MASK]nued to scramble Badger si[MASK]nals , as Rifenburg 's teammates laughed at his scheme . In the January 1[MASK], 1948 Rose Bowl that season , Michigan rolle[MASK] to a 49 – 0 victory over USC , and they outgained the Trojans 491 yards t[MASK] 133 . Rifenburg caught a 29 @-@ yard pass for the game 's final score . 
 In the 1948 championship season , Rifenburg scored eight touchdowns , caught 22 passes , and gained 610 yards ( 508 receiving and 102 rushing ) . Rifenburg was the second highest scoring end in the nati[MASK]n in 1948 , and he was a conse[MASK]sus All @-@ American as a seni[MASK]r , being selected as first team on nine of the 11 All [MASK]-@ American teams . Rifenburg [MASK]ed the Big Ten in receptions . 
 Although Rifenbur[MASK] finished fo[MASK]rth among midwestern[MASK]Heisman voters in 1948 , he did not finish among the top eight . By comparison , Notre Dame end Leon Hart won [MASK]he Heisman Trophy in 1949 but made[MASK]only eight of the 11 All @-@ Am[MASK]rican teams . It is not clear why Rifenburg did not finish higher . However , it is fairl[MASK] clear that sportswriters of that era had a bias aga[MASK]nst Michigan . In the Associated Press poll at the end of the 1947 season , the No[MASK][MASK]e Da[MASK]e Fighting Irish were ranked ahead of the[MASK]University o[MASK] Michigan , though both teams were undefeated . Som[MASK] noted that e[MASK]ery Southern AP voter [MASK]ad vote[MASK] for Notre Dam[MASK] , which had yet to integrate , whereas three of Michigan 's star players ( Bob Mann , Gene Derricotte , and Len Ford ) were African @-@ American . The Southern schools refused even to schedu[MASK]e g[MASK]mes[MASK]agai[MASK]st school[MASK] that played African @-@ American players . 
 [MASK]ifenburg was considered one of the greatest[MASK]Wolverine 's of the 1940s . In four seasons with the Michigan Wolverines , Rifenburg played in 32 game[MASK] and had over 1 @,@ 000 yards of total [MASK]ffense . Rifenburg held the University of Michigan 's single season and career record for touchdown receptions ( eight in a season ; sixtee[MASK] career ) until[MASK]his records were br[MASK]ken by Anthony Carter in[MASK]1980 .

 After 30 years with [MASK]BEN and a ch[MASK]nge in ownership for the station , his show was replaced with the Mutual Network 's The Larry King Show .
