 = 1933 Trea[MASK]ure Coast hur[MASK]icane = 
 
 T[MASK]e 1933 Treasure[MASK]Coast hurricane was the second @-@ most intense tropical cyclone to strike the United States during the active 1933 Atlantic hurricane season . The eleventh tropical storm , fifth hurricane , and the third major hurricane of the season , it formed east @-@ northeast of the Leeward Islands on August 31 . The tropical storm moved rapidly west @-@ northwestward , steadily intensifying to a hurricane . It[MASK]acqui[MASK]ed peak winds of 140 m[MASK]les per hour ( 225 km / h ) and passed over portions of the Bahamas on September 3 , including Eleuthera a[MASK]d Harbour Island , causing severe damage to[MASK]crops , buildings , and infrastructure . Winds over 100 mph ( 161 km / h ) affected many[MASK]islands in its path , especially those that encountered its cent[MASK]r , and many wharves were ruined . 
 Subsequently , it weakened and made landfall at Jupiter , Florida , early on September 4 with winds of 125 mph ( 201 km / h ) . The hurricane moved across the state , passing[MASK]near Tampa before moving into Georgia and dissipating . In Florida , the strong winds of the cyclone blew buildings off their foundations , and numero[MASK]s trees were prostrated in citrus groves[MASK]. The Treasure Coast region[MASK]received the most extens[MASK]ve destruction , and Stuart , Jupiter , and Fort Pierce were heavily damaged . I[MASK]land , the cyclone weakened rapidly but produced prodigious amounts of rain , causing a dam to collapse near Tampa . The storm caused $ 3 million in damage ( 1933 U[MASK]D ) after damaging or destroying 6 @,@ 848 homes . 
 Unusually , the storm hit Florida less than 24 hours before another major hurricane bearing 125 @-@ mile [MASK]-@ per @-@ ho[MASK]r ( 201 km / h ) winds struck South Texas ; never have two major cyclones hit[MASK]the United States in such close succession . 
 
 = = Meteorological history = = 
 
 The origins of the hurricane were from a tropical wave t[MASK]at possibly s[MASK]awned a tropical depres[MASK]ion o[MASK] August 27 , although there was minim[MASK]l data over the next few days as it tracked to the west @-@ northwest . On August 31 , a n[MASK]arby ship reported gale force winds , wh[MASK]ch indic[MASK]ted that a tr[MASK]pical storm had developed to t[MASK]e east @-@ northea[MASK]t of the Lesser Antilles . Based on[MASK]continuity , i[MASK] is estimated th[MASK] storm a[MASK]tained hurricane status later that day . Moving quickly to the[MASK]west @-[MASK] northwest , the storm passed north of the Le[MASK]ser Antilles and Puerto Rico . Early on Sept[MASK]mber 2 , a ship called the Gulfwing reported[MASK]a barometric pressure of 97[MASK] mbar ( 28 @.@ 88 inHg ) , which confirmed that the storm attained hurricane status . After passing north of the Turks and Caicos islands , the hurricane struck Eleuthera and Harbour Island in the [MASK]ahamas on September 3 , the latter at 1100 UTC . A station on the latter island re[MASK]orted a pressure of 27 @.@ 90 inHg ( 945 mb ) during the 30 minute passage o[MASK] the eye . Based on the pressure and the small size [MASK]f the storm , it is estimated the [MASK]urricane struck Harbour [MASK]sland with peak winds of 140 mph ( 225 km / h ) , making it the equivalent of a modern Category 4 hurricane on the Saffir @-[MASK] Simpson scale . I[MASK]terpolation suggested that the storm reached major hurr[MASK]cane status , or Category 3 status , on September 2 . 
 The hurricane initially followed the course of another hurricane th[MASK]t passed through the area in late August , which ultimately struck Cuba and Texas . This hurricane instead maintained a general west @-@ northwest track . After moving through the northern B[MASK]hamas , t[MASK]e hurricane [MASK]eakened slightly before making landfall at Jupi[MASK]er , Florida , [MASK]t 0500 UTC on September 4 . A station ther[MASK] reported a pressure of 27 @.@ 9[MASK] [MASK]nHg ( 948[MASK]mb ) during a 40 minute period of [MASK]he eye 's passage ; this sugge[MASK]ted a landfall strength[MASK]of 125 mph ( 201 km / h ) . At the time , the radius of ma[MASK]imum winds was 15 mi ( 24 km ) , which was smaller than average . After landf[MASK]ll [MASK] the hurricane weakened rapidly while crossin[MASK] the state . It briefly emerged into the Gulf[MASK]of Mexi[MASK]o as a tropical storm early on September 5 [MASK] A few hours later while continuing [MASK]o the nor[MASK]hwest , it made anot[MASK]er lan[MASK]fall near Rosewo[MASK]d — a ghost town in [MASK]evy County , east of Cedar Key — with winds of about 65 mph ( 105 km / h ) . Turning to the north , the storm slowly weakened as it crossed into Georgia , dissipating on September 7 near Augusta . 
 
 = = Preparations and impact =[MASK]= 
 
 On September 2 , a fleet of eight aircraft evacuated all white residents from West End , Grand Bahama , to Day[MASK]ona Beach , Florida . While the[MASK]storm was near peak intensity on September 3 , the Weather Bureau issued hurricane warnings from Miami to Melbour[MASK]e , Florida , with storm warnings extending northw[MASK]rd to Jacksonville . Later that day , storm warnings , were issued from Key West to Cedar[MASK]Key . About 2 @,[MASK] 500 people evacuated by train[MASK]from areas around Lake Okeechobee . By evening on September 3 , high ti[MASK]es sent sea spray over coastal seawalls in Palm Beach [MASK]ounty as residents boar[MASK]ed up buildings ; s[MASK]ructures on Clematis Street in West Palm Beach were said to [MASK]e a " solid front " of p[MASK]ywood [MASK] Along the coa[MASK]t , observers reported very rough seas as the eye neared land . 
 The powerful hurr[MASK]cane moved over or near several islands in the Bahamas . Winds on Spanish Wells and Harbour Island were both estimated at around 140 mph ( 225 km / h ) . Winds reached 110 mph ( 177 km / h ) at Governor 's Harbour , 100 mph ( 161 km / h ) on Eleuthera , and 120 mph ( 193 km / h ) on the Abaco Islands . The storm was farther away from Nassau , where winds reached 61 mph ( 98 km / h ) . The hurricane da[MASK]aged a lumber mill on Abaco , washing awa[MASK] a dock . Heavy dam[MASK]ge occurred on Harbour Island , including to seve[MASK]al roofs , the walls of government buildings , a[MASK]d the water system . The hurricane destroye[MASK] four churches and 37 houses , leaving 100 people homeless . A 1 [MASK].@ 5 mi ( 2 @.@ 4 km ) road on Eleuthera was destroyed . Several islands sustained damage to farms , including the total los[MASK] of various fruit t[MASK]ees on Russell Island . D[MASK]spite Category 4 winds o[MASK] Spanish Wells , on[MASK]y five houses were destroy[MASK]d , although most of the remaining dwellings lost their roofs . Collectively between North Point , James Cistern , and Gregory Town on Eleuthera , the sto[MASK]m destroyed 55 houses and damaged ma[MASK]y others . [MASK]n [MASK]rand Bahama , where a 9 to 12 ft ( 2 @.@ 7 to 3 @.@ 7 m ) storm surge was reported , half of the houses were destroyed , as were 13 boats and two planes , and most docks were wrecked . 
 When the storm [MASK]oved ashore in Florida , winds [MASK]eached an estimated 125 mph[MASK]( 201 km / h ) in Jupiter ; these occurred after the ey[MASK] passed . In W[MASK]st Palm Beach , anemometers measured at least 80 @-[MASK] mile @-@ per @-@ hour ( 129 km / h ) winds with gusts to 100 mph ( 161 km / h ) ;[MASK]barometers ranged from 28 @.@ 64 to 28 @.@ 78 inHg ( 970 to 975 mb ) . The storm produced the strongest winds in the city since the 1928 Okeech[MASK]bee hurr[MASK]cane . Winds were not as strong farth[MASK]r from the cente[MASK] ; 40 to 45 mph ( 64 to 72 km [MASK] h ) winds were observed in M[MASK]ami to the south , Titusville to t[MASK]e north , and Tam[MASK]a on the west coast . Fort Pierce estimated peak winds of 80 to [MASK]0 mph ( 129 to 145 km / h ) , and pressures dipped to 29 @.@ 14 inHg ( 987 mb ) . Inla[MASK]d , winds near Lake Okeechobee peaked at only 60 mp[MASK] ( 97 km / h ) . The hurricane dropped heavy rai[MASK]fall along its path , peaking at 17 @.@ 8 in ( 450 mm )[MASK]in[MASK]Clermont . 
 At West Palm Beach , the majority of the damage was confined to vegetation . Several coconut and royal palms th[MASK]t withstood the 1928 hurricane snapped [MASK] littering streets with broken trunks . Winds downed road signs on [MASK]any streets , and floodwaters covered the greens[MASK]on a local golf co[MASK]rse . Some gar[MASK]ges and isolated structures , [MASK]ostly [MASK]ightweigh[MASK] , were partly or totally destroyed , along with a lumber warehouse . Some h[MASK]mes that lost roofi[MASK]g shingles had water damage to their interiors as well . Nea[MASK]by Lake Wort[MASK] sustained extensive breakage of windows , including plate glass , and loss of tile and shingle roofing , but preparations reduced losses to[MASK]just several thousand dollars , and no post @-@ storm accidents took place . Strong winds snapped many light poles in the city , and trees and s[MASK]rubs were broken or uprooted . As in Lake [MASK]orth , officials in West Palm Beach credited preparations and stringent building codes with reduc[MASK]ng overall damage . The[MASK]city had learned from previous experience with severe storms i[MASK] 1926 , 1928 , and 1929 . High tides eroded Ocean Boulev[MASK][MASK]d at several spots [MASK]nd disrupted[MASK]access to several bridges on the Lake Worth Lagoon .[MASK]Winter estates and hotels on Palm Beach generally sustained little material damage , except to vegetation , and county properties went largely uns[MASK]athed . 
 In Martin and St[MASK] [MASK]ucie counties , the storm was considered among the[MASK]worst on record . The storm [MASK][MASK]veled [MASK]ome homes and swept many others off their foundations . At Stuart , winds removed or[MASK]badly damaged 75 % of the roofs in town . The storm destroyed the third floor of the[MASK]building that housed a bowling alley and the Stuart New[MASK] , a local newspaper[MASK]. At Olympia , an aban[MASK]oned settlement also known as [MASK]lympia Beach , strong winds leveled the old Olympia Inn , a gas station , and the second floor of a pharmaceutical building . Winds also to[MASK]e the roof off an ice plant . A bridge leading to the barrier island from Olymp[MASK]a was partly wrecked ; the bridge tender survived[MASK]by gripping the [MASK]ailing during the storm . Wi[MASK]ds leveled his nearby home . According to the Monthly Weather Review , some of the most severe damage f[MASK]om the storm in Fl[MASK]rida was at Olympia .[MASK]The storm left many homes in Hobe So[MASK]nd un[MASK]nhabitable [MASK] forcing crews to[MASK]tear them down . Winter estates on the island , however , were better built and little damaged . While[MASK]Stuart and[MASK]Hobe Sound sustained signif[MASK]cant damage , Port Salerno suffer[MASK]d minimally . In Stuart , the storm left 400 to 500 people homeless , up to nearly 10 % of the population , which was 5 @,@ 100 at the[MASK]time . Betwe[MASK]n Jupiter and Fort Pierce , the storm knocked d[MASK]wn power and telegraph lines . In the latter city , high waves was[MASK]ed[MASK]out a port[MASK]on of the causeway . In the 1980s , an elderly resident r[MASK]called that the storm was the most severe on record in Fort Pierce . 
 Crop damage was worst along the Indian R[MASK]ver Lagoon ; [MASK]everal fa[MASK]ms in Stuart experienced to[MASK]al losses , and statewide , 16 % of the citrus crop , or 4 million boxes , were destroyed . Many chicken coops in Stuart were destroyed , and the lo[MASK]al chicken population was scattered and dispersed as far as Indi[MASK]ntown . Across southeastern [MASK]lorida , the hurricane damaged 6 @,[MASK] [MASK]65 houses and destroyed anot[MASK]er 383 , causing over $ 3 m[MASK]llion in damage . One person , an African American farm worker , was killed when his shack blew d[MASK]wn in Gomez , a brakeman died afte[MASK] seven rail[MASK]ars derailed , and a child was killed by airborne debris . 
 High rainfall caused flooding across Florida , [MASK]otably near Ta[MASK]pa where waters reached [MASK] ft ( 2 @.@ 7 m ) deep . High rainfall of over 7 in ( 180 [MASK]m ) caused a dam operated by Tampa Electric Co. to break 3 mi ( 4 @.@ 8 km ) northeast of Tampa along the Hillsborough River . The break resulted in severe local damage , flooding portions of Sulphur Springs .[MASK][MASK]orkers attempted to save the dam wit[MASK] sandbags[MASK], and after the break , most residents in the area were warne[MASK] of the approaching flood . Over 50 [MASK]o[MASK]es were flooded , forcing a[MASK]out 150 people to evacuat[MASK] . Outside Florida , the storm produced winds of 48 and 51 mph ( 78 and 8[MASK] km[MASK]/ h ) in Savannah , Georgia and Charleston , South Caroli[MASK]a , res[MASK]ectively . In th[MASK] latter city , the storm[MASK]sp[MASK]wne[MASK] a tornado , which caused about $ 10 @,@ 000 in property damage . Heavy rainfall occurred[MASK]along the Georgia and South Carolina coasts , reaching over 12 in ( 300 mm ) . Light rainfa[MASK]l also extended into North[MASK]Carolina . 
 
 = = Aftermath = = 
 
 In the Bahamas after the storm , a boat sailed from Nassau to deliver food and building materials to Eleuthera .[MASK]
 After the sto[MASK]m , the National Guar[MASK] offered shelters for at least 400 homeless residents in Stuart . Of the 7 @,@ 900 families adversely a[MASK]fected by the hurricane , 4 @,@ 325 required assist[MASK]n[MASK]e from the American Red Cross . Farmers in Texas , [MASK]lso affected by a major hurricane , requested growers in Florida wait 15 days so they co[MASK]ld sell their citrus crop that fell . The damaged dam near Tampa initially resul[MASK]ed in waters from the[MASK]Hillsborough River being pumped into the city 's water treatment plant , and a new dam was eventually built in 1944 . 
 
 
 = Second[MASK]Battle of Naktong Bulge = 
[MASK]
 The Second Battle of Naktong Bulge was an engagement between United Nati[MASK]ns ( UN ) and North Korean ( NK ) forces early in the Korean War from Septe[MASK]ber 1 to September 15 , 1950 , along the Naktong [MASK]iver in Sou[MASK]h Korea . It[MASK]was a part of t[MASK]e Battle of Pusan Perimeter , and was one of several large engagements fought simultaneously . The battle ended in a victory for the United Nations after large numbers of United States ( US ) and Republic of Korea ( ROK ) troops repelled a strong Nort[MASK] Korean attack . 
[MASK]After the F[MASK]rst Battle of Naktong[MASK]Bulge , the US Army 's 2nd Infantry Division was moved to defend the Naktong River line . The division , which was untried in combat , was struck with a strong attack by several divisions of the Korean People 's Army which cro[MASK]sed th[MASK] river and struck all along the division 's line . The force of the attack split the US 2nd Infantr[MASK] Division in half , and the North Koreans were able to penetrate to Yong[MASK]a[MASK] , promoting a fight there . 
 The urgenc[MASK] of the threat to Pusan Perimeter prompted [MASK]he US Marine Corps 1st Provision[MASK]l Marine Brigade to be brought in to reinforce t[MASK]e US Army troops . In two weeks of heavy fighting , the US forces were able to force the No[MASK]th Koreans out of the Naktong Bulge region . The North Koreans were further repulsed after the UN counteratta[MASK]k at Inchon , which culminated in the virtual destruction of the North Korean army . 
 
 = = Background = = [MASK] 
 
 = = [MASK] Pusan Perimeter = = = 
 
 From the outbreak of the Korean War and the invasion of[MASK]South[MASK]Korea by the North , the North Korean People 's Army had enjoyed superiority in both [MASK]anpower and equipment over both the Republic of Korea Army and the United N[MASK]tions forces [MASK]ispatched to South Korea to prevent[MASK]it from collapsing . The Nort[MASK] Korean strategy was to aggressively pursue UN and ROK forces on all avenues of approach south and to engage them aggressively , attacking [MASK]rom the front and initiating a double envelop[MASK]ent of both flanks of the unit , which allowed the[MASK]North Koreans to surround and cut off[MASK]the opposing [MASK]orce , which would[MASK]then be forced to retreat i[MASK] dis[MASK]rray , often leaving behind much of its equipment . From their initial June 25 offensive to fights in July and early August , the North Koreans used this[MASK]strategy to effectively defeat any UN force and [MASK]ush it so[MASK]th . However , when the UN forces , under the Eighth Unite[MASK] States Army , established the Pusan Perimeter in August , the UN troops held a continuous line along the peninsula which North Korean[MASK]troops could not flank , and their [MASK]dva[MASK]tages in numbers decreased daily as the superior UN logistical system brought in [MASK]ore [MASK]roops and supplies to the UN army . 
 When th[MASK] North Koreans approached the Pusan Perimeter on August 5 , they attempted the [MASK]ame frontal assault te[MASK]hnique on the four [MASK]ain avenues of approach into the perimeter . Throughout August , the NK 6th Divi[MASK]ion , and later the NK 7th Division[MASK]engaged the US 25th In[MASK]antry Divisi[MASK]n at the Battle of Masan , initially repelling a UN counteroffensive before countering with battles at Kom[MASK]m @-@ ni [MASK]nd Battle Mountain . These attacks stalled as UN forces , well equipped and with plenty of reserves , repeatedly repelled Nort[MASK] Korean attacks . North of Masan , the NK 4th Division and the US 24th Infantry Division sparred in the Naktong Bulge area . In the First Battle of Naktong Bulge , the North Korean division was unable to hold [MASK]ts bridgehead across the ri[MASK]er as large numbers of US reserve forces were brought in to rep[MASK]l it , and on August 19 , the NK 4th Division was forced back ac[MASK]oss the river with 50 percent casualties . In the Taegu region , five North Korean d[MASK]visions [MASK]ere repulsed by three UN divisions in several attempts to attack the city during the Battle of Taegu . Particularly heavy fighting took plac[MASK] at the Ba[MASK]tle of the Bowling Alley where the NK 13th Division was almost completely destroyed i[MASK] the attack . On the east coast , three more North Korean divisions were repulsed by th[MASK] South Koreans at P 'ohang @-@ dong during the Battle of[MASK]P 'ohang @-@ dong . All along the front , the North Kore[MASK]n troops were reeling from these defeats , [MASK]h[MASK] first time in the war their strategies were not working . 
 
 = = = September push = = = 
 
 In planning its new offensive , the North Kor[MASK]an command decided any attempt to [MASK]lank the UN force was impossible thanks to the support of the UN navy . Instead , they opted to use frontal attack to breach the perimeter and collapse it[MASK]as the only hop[MASK] of achievi[MASK]g success in the battle . Fed by intelligence from the Soviet Union the North Koreans were aware the UN forces were building up [MASK]long th[MASK] Pusan Perimeter and that it must conduct an offen[MASK]ive[MASK]soon or it could not win the battle . A secondary objective was to surround Taegu and destroy the UN and RO[MASK] units in that city . As part of this miss[MASK]on , the North Korean units would[MASK]first cut the[MASK]supply lines to Taegu . 
 On August 20 , the North Korean commands distributed operations orders to their subordi[MASK]ate units . The North Koreans called for a simultaneous five @-@ prong attack against the UN lines . These atta[MASK]ks would overwhelm the UN defenders and allow the North Koreans to break through the lines in [MASK]t least one place to force the UN [MASK]orces back . Five battle [MASK]roupings w[MASK]re ordered . The center attack called for the NK[MASK]9th Division , NK 4th Division , NK 2nd Divisio[MASK] , and NK 10th Division break through the US 2nd Infantry Divisio[MASK] at the Naktong Bulge to M[MASK]ryang and Yongsan . 
 
 = = Battle = = 
 
 During the North Koreans ' September 1 offens[MASK]ve ,[MASK]the US[MASK]25th [MASK]nfantry Division 's U[MASK] 35th Infantry Regiment was heavily engaged in the Battle of Nam River north of Masan . On the 3[MASK]th Regiment 's right flank , just north of the confluence of the Nam River and the Naktong Rive[MASK] , was the US 9th Infantry Regiment , US 2nd Infantry Division . There , in the southernmost part of the 2nd Infantry Division[MASK]zone , the 9th Infantry Regiment held a[MASK]sector more than 20 @,@ 00[MASK] yards ( 18 @,@ 000 m ) long , including the bulge area of the Na[MASK]tong where the First Battle of Naktong Bulge had taken place earlier [MASK]n August . E[MASK]ch US infantry company on the river line here had a front of 3 @,@ 000 feet ( 910 m ) to 4 @,@ 000 feet ( 1 [MASK],@ 200 m ) and they held only key hills and observation points , as the units were extremely spread out along the wide front . 
 During the last week of August , US troops on these hills could see minor North Korean activity across the river , which they thought[MASK]was North Koreans organizing the high ground o[MASK] the west side of the Naktong agains[MASK] a poss[MASK]ble American attack . There were occasion[MASK]l attacks on th[MASK] 9th [MASK]nfantry 's for[MASK]ard positions , but to the men in the front lines this appeared to be only a standard p[MASK]trol action . On August 31 , the UN forces were alerted to a pending attack when much[MASK]of the Korean civilian labor force fled the front lines . Intelligence office[MASK]s reported an attack was coming . 
 On the west si[MASK]e of the Naktong , North Korean Major General Pak Kyo [MASK]am , commanding the NK 9th Div[MASK]sion , issued h[MASK]s operations order to the division on August 28 . Its mission in [MASK]he forthcoming attack was to outflank and destroy the US troops a[MASK] Naktong Bulge by capturing the Mi[MASK]yang and Samnangjin a[MASK]eas to cut off the US 2nd Division 's route of supply and withdrawal between Taegu and Pusan . However , the North Koreans [MASK]eren 't aware that the US 2nd Infantr[MASK] Division had recently replaced the US 24th Infantry [MASK]ivision in positions along the Naktong River . Consequently , they expected lighter resist[MASK]nce ; the 24th troops were exhausted from months of fighting but the 2nd Division men were fresh and newly arrived in Korea . They had only recently been moved into the lin[MASK] . The North Koreans began crossing the Naktong R[MASK]ver under cover of darkness at c[MASK]rtain points . 
 
 = = = Battle of Agok = = = 
 
 On the southern @-@ most[MASK]flank of the 9th Infantry river line , just above t[MASK]e junction of the Nam River with the Naktong , A Company of the 1st Battalion was dug in on [MASK] long finger ridge parallel[MASK]ng the Naktong that terminat[MASK]s in Hill 94 at the Kihang ferry site . The river road from Namji @-@[MASK]ri run[MASK]ing west[MASK]along the Naktong passes[MASK]the southern tip of this ridge a[MASK]d crosses to the west side of the river at the ferry . A small village called Agok lay at the base[MASK]of Hill 94 and 300 yard[MASK] ( 27[MASK] m ) from the river . A patrol of tanks and armored vehicles , together with two infantry squads of A Company[MASK], 9th Infantry , held a roadblock near the ferry and close to Agok . [MASK]n the evening of August 31 , A Company moved from its ridge positions overlooking Agok and the river to new positions along the river below the r[MASK]dge line . 
 That evening Sergeant Er[MASK]est R. Kouma led the patrol of two M26[MASK]Pershing tanks and two M19 Gun Motor Carriages[MASK]in Agok . Kouma placed his patrol on the west side of Agok near the Kihang ferry . At 20 : 00 a heavy fog covered the river , and at 22 : 00 [MASK]ortar shells began f[MASK]lling on the American @-@ held side of[MASK]the[MASK]river . By 22 [MASK] 15 this strike intensified and North Korean mortar preparation struck A Company 's p[MASK]sitions . American mortars and artillery began firing counterbattery . Some of the A Company men reported they[MASK]heard noises[MASK]on the opposite [MASK]ide of the river and splashes in the water . 
 At 22 : 30 t[MASK]e fog lifted and Kouma saw th[MASK]t a North Korean pon[MASK]oon bridge was being laid across the river directly in front of his position . Kouma 's four vehicles attacked this structure , and after about a minute of heavy fire the bridge collapse[MASK] , and the ponton boats used to hold the bridge in place[MASK]were sunk . At 23 : 00 a small arms fight flared around the left side of A Company north [MASK]f the tanks . This gunfire had lasted[MASK]only tw[MASK] or three minutes when the A Company roadblock squads near the [MASK]anks[MASK]r[MASK]ceived word by field telephone that the company was withdrawing to the original ridge[MASK]positions and that they should do likewise . 
 Kouma 's patrol w[MASK]s then ambushed [MASK]y a group of Nor[MASK]h Koreans dressed in US military uniforms . Kouma was woun[MASK]ed and the other three vehicles had to withdraw , but he held the Agok site until 07 : 30 the next morni[MASK]g with his single tank . In the attack against A Company , the[MASK]North Koreans hit the 1st Platoon , which was near Agok , but they did not find [MASK]he 2nd Platoon northward . 
 The NK 9th Division 's infantry crossing of the Naktong and attack on[MASK]its east side near midnight quickly overran the positi[MASK]ns of C[MASK]Company , north of A Company . There the North Koreans assaulted in force , signaled by[MASK]green flares and blowing of whistles . The company held its positions only [MASK][MASK]short time [MASK]nd then attempted to esc[MASK]pe . Many of the men moved south , a few of them coming into A Company 's ridge l[MASK]ne positions near Agok during the night . Most of C Company moved all th[MASK] way to the 25th Division positions south of the Naktong . On September 1 that division repor[MASK]ed that 110 men of C Compa[MASK]y had come into [MASK]ts lines . 
 
 = = = North Korean crossing = = =

 At 02 : 00 , B Company was attacked . A truck stopped a[MASK] the bo[MASK]tom of[MASK]the hill , a whi[MASK]tle sounded , then came a shoute[MASK] order , and North Korean s[MASK]ldiers started climbing the slope .  At 03 : 00 , 1 September , the 9th Infantry Regiment ordered its only reserve , E Co[MASK]pany to move west along the Yongsan @-@ Naktong River road and take a blocking position at the p[MASK]ss between Cloverleaf Hill and Obong @-@ ni Ridge , 3[MASK]miles ( 4 @.@ 8 km ) from the river and 6 miles ( 9 @.@ [MASK] km [MASK] f[MASK]om Yongsan . The US 2nd Infa[MASK]try Division now had to base its defense of Yongsan on relatively poor defensive terrain , the low hills at the western edge of the town . 
 
 = = = US 23rd Infantry attacked = = = 
 
 North of the 9th Infantry sector of the 2nd Infantry Division front along the Naktong , the US 23rd Infantry Regiment on August 29 had just relieved the 3rd Battalion of the US 38th Infantry Regiment , which [MASK]n turn had only a few days before relieved the US 21st Infan[MASK]ry Regiment of the US 24th Infantry Division . On August 1 ,[MASK]the 23rd Regiment was in a new sector of which it ha[MASK] [MASK]nly a limited knowledge [MASK] It took over a 16 [MASK],@ 000 yards ( 15 @,@ 000 m ) Nakton[MASK] River front without its 3r[MASK] Battalion which had been attached to the US 1st Cavalry Division to the north . Colonel Paul L. Freeman , the regiment[MASK]l commander , deployed the 1st Battalion on the high ground along the rive[MASK] with the three companies abreast . The 1st Battalion , under US Lieutenant Colonel Claire E. Hutchin , Jr . , [MASK]utposted the hills with platoons and squa[MASK]s . He placed the[MASK]2nd Ba[MASK]talion in a reserve position 8 miles ( 13 km ) beh[MASK]nd the 1st Battalion and in a position where it com[MASK]anded the road net in the regimental sector[MASK].  = = = US 2nd Division split = = = 
 
 Before the mornin[MASK] of 1 September h[MASK]d passed , reports coming in to US 2nd Division headquarters made it clear that North Koreans had penetrated [MASK]o the no[MASK]th @-@ south Changnyong @-@ Yongsan road and cu[MASK] the division in two ; the 38th and 2[MASK]d Infantry Regiments with the bulk of the division artillery in the north were separated from the division headquarters and the 9th Infantry Regiment in the south . [MASK]chmitt assumed command of the group . 
 During the night Sch[MASK]itt established radio communication with the 1st Battalion , 9th infantry . When daylight came S[MASK]hmitt and his group saw that they were surrounded by North Koreans . One for[MASK]e occupied[MASK]the higher kn[MASK]b half a mile above them , forme[MASK]ly held by B Company . Daylight of the second day disclosed many North Korean dead o[MASK] t[MASK]e steep slopes outside t[MASK]e[MASK]perimeter . 
 In the afternoon of September 2 Schmitt radioed 1st Battali[MASK]n for an airdrop of supplies . A US plane attem[MASK]ted the drop , but the perimeter was so small and the slope[MASK] so steep that virtually all the supplies went into North Korean hands . [MASK]he men in the pe[MASK]imeter did , however , recover from a drop made later at 19 :[MASK]00 some supplies and ammunition . Private First[MASK]Class Joseph R. Ouellette , of H Company , left the perimeter to gath[MASK]r weapons , ammunition , and[MASK]gr[MASK]nades from the North Korean dead . On sev[MASK]ral occasions he was attacked , and on one such occasion a North Korean soldier suddenly attacked Oue[MASK]lette , who killed the North Korean in hand @-@ to @-@ hand combat . [MASK] That same afternoon , the North Korea[MASK]s sent an American pris[MASK]ner up the hill to Schmitt with the message , " You have one hour to surrender or be blown to p[MASK]eces . " Failing in frontal infantry attack to reduce th[MASK] little defending force , the North Koreans now meant to take it under mortar fire . On[MASK]y 45 minutes la[MASK]er North Korean antitank fire came in on the[MASK]knob and two machine guns from positions northward and higher on the slope of Hill 209 swept the perimeter . Soon , mort[MASK]rs emplaced on a neighboring high finger ridge eastward registered on Schmitt 's perimete[MASK] a[MASK]d continued firing until dark [MASK] The machine gun fire forced every man to stay in his foxhole . The[MASK]lifti[MASK]g of the mortar fire aft[MASK]r dark was the sig[MASK]al[MASK]for renewed North Korean infantry attacks , all of which were repulsed . But the number of killed and[MASK]wounded[MASK]within the perimeter was growing [MASK] and supplies were diminishing . There were no medica[MASK] supplies except those carried [MASK]y one aid man . 
 The third day , September 3 , the situation worsened . The weather was hot and ammunition , food and supplies were [MASK]early complete[MASK]y exhausted . Since the previous aftern[MASK]on , North Korean morta[MASK] barrages [MASK]ad alternated with in[MASK]antry assaults against the perimeter . Survivors later estimated there were abo[MASK]t twenty separate infantry attack[MASK] repulsed . Two North Korean machine guns still swept the perimeter whenever anyone showed himself . Dead and dying US troops were in al[MASK]ost every foxhole . Mortar fragments destroyed the radio and this ended all communication with other US units [MASK] Artillery fire and [MASK]ir[MASK]strikes requested by Schmitt never came . Some North Koreans worked their way close to the perimeter and threw grenades into it . Six times[MASK]Ouellette leaped from his foxhole to escape[MASK]grenades thrown into it . In this close action Ouellette was killed . Most of the foxholes of the perimeter received[MASK]one or more direct mortar hits in the cou[MASK]se of the continuing mortar fire . One of these killed Schmitt on September 3 . The command passed now to First Lieutenant Raymond J. McDoniel of D Company , senior surviving officer . 
 At daylight on the morning of [MASK] September on[MASK]y two officers and approximately half the men who h[MASK]d[MASK]assembled on the hill , were alive [MASK] As the day passed , with ammunition down to a[MASK]out one clip[MASK]per man and only a few grenades left and no help in sight , McDoniel decided to aba[MASK]don the position that n[MASK]ght . When it got dark t[MASK]e survivors would split into small group[MASK] and try to get back to frien[MASK]l[MASK] lines . That evening after dark the North Koreans launched [MASK]nother wea[MASK] attack against the position . At 22 : 00 , McDoniel and Caldwell and 27 e[MASK]listed men slipped off the hill in groups of four . Master Sergeant Travis E. Watkins , still alive in his[MASK]paralyzed condition , refused efforts of evacuation , [MASK]a[MASK]ing that he did not want to be a burden to those who had a chance to get away . He asked only [MASK]hat his carbine be loaded and pl[MASK]ced on his chest with the muzzle under his chin . Like Oullette , he would also win the Medal of Honor for his actions . Of the 29 men who came off the hill[MASK]the night of September 4 , 22 escaped to friendly lines , many of them following the Naktong downstream , hiding by day and traveling by night , until they reached the[MASK]lines of the US 25th Infantry Division . 
 Members of[MASK]Task Force Manchu who escaped from Hill 20[MASK] brought back considerable intel[MASK]igence information of North Korean activity in th[MASK] vicinity of the Paekchin ferry crossing site . At the ferry site the North Koreans had put in an underwater bridge . A short distance downstream , each night they placed a ponto[MASK]n bridge across the river and t[MASK][MASK]k it up bef[MASK]re dawn the next morning . Car[MASK]ying parties of 50 civilians guarded by four North Korean soldiers [MASK]rossed the river continuously at night , an estimated total of 800 @-@ 1 @,@ 000 carriers being used at this crossing site .

 = = = Battle [MASK]f Yongsan = = =

 At 09 : 35 Septembe[MASK] 2 , while the North Koreans were attempting to destroy the engineer troops at the southern [MASK]dge of Yongsan and clear the road to Miryang , Walker spoke b[MASK] telephone with M[MASK]jor General Doyle O.  The American counteroffensive of Sep[MASK]ember 3 – 5 west of Yongsan , according to prisoner st[MASK]tements , resulted in one of the bloodiest debacles of the war for a[MASK]Nort[MASK][MASK]Korean division .  = = = NK 2nd Division destroyed = = = [MASK]

There he obtained tha[MASK] company 's re[MASK]e[MASK]ve platoon and brought it back to F Company .  The attack tapered off with the coming of daylight , but that night it resumed . The North Koreans struck repeatedly at the d[MASK]fen[MASK]e line . This [MASK]ime they continued the fighting into the daylight hours of 9 Sep[MASK]ember . The Air Force then concentrat[MASK]d strong air s[MASK]pport over th[MASK] regimental perim[MASK]ter to aid the groun[MASK] troops . Casualties came to the aid stations[MASK]from the i[MASK]fantry companies in an almost steady stream during the morning . At one time , the regimental reserve was down to six men . When the attack finally ceased shortly after 12 : 00 the 23rd Regiment had an estimated combat efficiency of only 38 percent . 
 This heavy night and day battle cost the NK 2nd Division most of its r[MASK]maining offensive strength . The medical officer of the NK 17th Re[MASK]iment , 2nd Division , captured a few days later , said that [MASK]he divi[MASK]ion evacuated about 300 men nightly to a hospital in Pugong @-@ ni , and th[MASK]t in the first two weeks of September the 2nd Division lost 1 @,@ 300 killed and 2 @,@ 500 wounded in the fighting[MASK]west of Changnyong . Patrols d[MASK]ily had t[MASK] open the main supply road and clear the town . 
 North Korean and US troops remained locked in combat along the Naktong [MASK]iver for several more days . The North Koreans ' offen[MASK]ive cap[MASK]bility w[MASK]s largely destroyed[MASK], and the US troops resolved to hold their lines barring further attack .

 = = Aftermath = = 
 
 The North Korean[MASK]2nd and 9th Divisions were almost completely destroyed in [MASK]he battles .  = Hed PE = 
 
 Hed PE , also known as ( hed ) Planet Earth and stylized as ( həd ) p.[MASK]. , is an American rock band from Huntin[MASK]ton Beach , California . Formed in 1994 , the band performs a style of music which it refers to as " G @-@ punk " , a fusi[MASK]n of punk rock and ga[MASK]gsta rap . 
 After releasing three al[MASK]ums on Jive Records , Hed PE left the label to record independently , eventually signing with Suburban Noize Records i[MASK] 2006 . Since [MASK]006 , the band has become known for its involvement in the 9 / 11 Truth movement , referencing it in many of their song lyrics and concerts , as well as th[MASK] concept of the album New World Orphans . To date[MASK], they have released[MASK]nine stud[MASK]o albums , one live album and two compilation albums .

 = Ironclad warship = 
 
 An ironclad is a steam @-@ propelled warship prot[MASK]cted by iron or ste[MASK]l armor plates used in the early pa[MASK]t of the second half of the 19th century . The ironclad was developed as a result of the vulnerability of wooden warships to explosive or incendiary shells . The first ironclad battleship , Gloire , was launched by the French Navy in November 1859 . The British Admiralty had[MASK]been considering armored warships since[MASK]1856 and prepared a draft design for an armore[MASK] corvet[MASK]e in 1857 ; i[MASK] ear[MASK]y [MASK]859 the Royal Navy started building [MASK][MASK]o iron @-@ hulled armored frigates , and by 1861 had made the[MASK]decision to move to [MASK]n all @-@ armored battle fleet . After the first clashes of ironclads ( both with wooden[MASK]ships and with one another ) took place in 1862 during the American Civil War , it became clear that the ironclad had replac[MASK]d the unarmored ship of the line as the most powerful warship a[MASK]loat . This type of ship would come to be very[MASK]success[MASK]ul [MASK]n the American Civil War . 
 Ironclads were designed for several roles , including as high seas battleships , coastal defense ships , and long @-@ [MASK]ange cruisers . The r[MASK]pid evolution of warship design in the late 19th century [MASK]ransformed the ironclad from a wooden @-@ h[MASK]lled vessel that carried sails to supplem[MASK]nt its steam[MASK]engines into the steel @-@[MASK]built , turreted b[MASK]ttleships and cruisers familiar in the 20th century . This change was pushed forward by the development o[MASK] heavier naval guns ( the ir[MASK]nclads of the 1880s carried some of the heaviest guns [MASK]ver mounte[MASK] a[MASK] sea ) , more sophisticated steam engines , and advances in metallurgy which made steel shipbuilding possible . 
 The quick pace of change meant that [MASK]any ships were obsolete as soon as they were finish[MASK]d , and that naval tactics wer[MASK] in a stat[MASK] [MASK]f[MASK]flux . Many ironclads were built t[MASK] make use of the ram or the torpedo , which a number of naval designers co[MASK]sidered the important weapons of naval combat . The[MASK]e is no clear end to the ironclad per[MASK]od , but towards the end of the 1890s the term ironclad dropped out of use .[MASK]New ships were increasingly constructed to[MASK]a standard pattern and designated battleships or armored cruisers . 
 
 = = The ironclad = = 
 
[MASK]The ironclad became technically feasible and tactically necessary because of developments in shipbuilding [MASK][MASK] the first half of the 19th[MASK]century . According to naval historian J. Richard Hill : " The ( ironclad ) had three chief charact[MASK]ristics : a metal @-@ skinned hull , steam propu[MASK]sio[MASK] and a main armament of guns capable of firing explosive sh[MASK]lls [MASK] It is only when all three characteristics are present that a fig[MASK]ting ship can p[MASK]operly be[MASK]called an[MASK]ironclad . " Each of[MASK]these developments was introduced separately in the decade before t[MASK]e fir[MASK]t ironclads . 
 [MASK] = = = Steam propulsion = = = 
 
 In the 18th and early 19th centuries fleets had relied on two types of m[MASK]jor warship , t[MASK]e ship of the line and the[MASK]frigate . The first major ch[MASK]nge to these ty[MASK]es was the [MASK]ntroduction of steam[MASK]power for propulsion . While paddle steamer warships had been used from the 1830s onwards , steam pro[MASK]ulsion only became suitable for major warships after the adoption of the screw propeller[MASK]in the 1840s . 
 Steam @-@ powered screw fri[MASK]ates were built in the mi[MASK] @-@ 184[MASK]s , and at the end of the decade the Fr[MASK]nch Navy introduced steam powe[MASK] to its line of battle . The desire fo[MASK] change came from the ambit[MASK]on of Napoleon III to gain greater in[MASK]luence in Europe , which required a challenge to the British at sea . The first purpose @-@ built [MASK]t[MASK]am [MASK]attleship wa[MASK] the 90 @-@ gun Napoléon in 1850 . Napoléon was armed as a conventional ship @-@ of @-[MASK] the @-@ lin[MASK] , but her steam engi[MASK]es could give her a speed of 12 knots ( 22 km / h ) , regardless of t[MASK]e wind conditions : a potentially decisive a[MASK][MASK]anta[MASK]e in a naval engagement . 
 The introduction of the steam ship @-@ of @-@ the @-@ line led to a[MASK]building com[MASK]et[MASK]tion betwe[MASK]n France and Britain . Eight sister ships to Napoléon[MASK]were built in France over a peri[MASK]d of ten years , but the United Kingdom soon managed to take the lead in production . Altogether , France built ten new wooden steam battleships and con[MASK]erted 28 [MASK][MASK]om older ships of the line , while the United Kingdom built 18 and converted 41 . 
 
 = = = Explosive shells = = = 
 
 The er[MASK] of the wooden [MASK]team ship @-@[MASK]of @-@ the @-@ line was brief , because of new , more powerful naval guns . In t[MASK]e 182[MASK]s a[MASK]d 1830s , war[MASK]hips [MASK]egan to mount increasingly heavy guns , replacing 18-[MASK]and 24 @-@ pounder guns with 32 @-@ pounders on sailing ships @-@ of @-@ th[MASK] @-@ line and introducing 68 @-@ pounders on steamers . Then , the first shell guns firing explosive shells were introduced following their development by the French Gén[MASK]ral Henri @-@ Joseph Paixhans , and by the 1840s were part of the stan[MASK]ard armament for naval powers including the French Navy , Royal Navy , Imperial Russian Navy and United States Navy . It is often held that [MASK]he power of explosive shells to smash wooden hulls , as de[MASK]onstrated by the Russian destruction of an Ottoman squadron at the Battle of Sinop , spelle[MASK] the end of the wooden @-@ hulled war[MASK]hip . The more practical threat to wooden[MASK]ships was from c[MASK]nventional cannon firing red @-@ hot shot ,[MASK]which could lodge in the hul[MASK] of a wooden ship and cause a fire or ammunition explosion . Some navies eve[MASK] experimented with hollow shot filled with molten metal for extra incendiary power . 
 
 = = = Iron armor = = =[MASK]
 
 The use of iron instead of wood as the primary material of ships ' hulls began in the 1830s ; the first " warship " with an iron hull was the gunboat Nemesis , built by Laird for the East India Company in 1839 . There followed , also[MASK]from Laird , the first full @-@ blown warships with metal hulls , the 1842 steam frigates Guadelupe and Montezuma for the Mexican navy . But a thin iron skin , while not being susceptible to fire or lethal splintering like wood , was not the same thing as providing iron armor calculat[MASK]d to stop enemy gunfire . 
 Following the demonstration of the power of explosive shells against wooden ships at the Battle of Sinop , and fearing that his own ships would be vulnerable to the Paixhans guns[MASK]of Russian fortifications in the Crimean War , Emperor Napoleon II[MASK] ord[MASK]r[MASK]d the development of light @-@ dr[MASK]ft floating batteries , equipped with heavy g[MASK]ns and protected by heavy armor . Experiments mad[MASK] durin[MASK] the fi[MASK]st half of 1854 proved highly satisfactory , and on 17 July 1854 , the French communicate[MASK] to the British Government that a solution had been found to make [MASK]un @-@ proof vessels and that plans would be communicated . After tests in September 1854 , the British Admiralty agreed to build five armoured floating ba[MASK]teries on the French plans , establishing the important Thames a[MASK]d Millwall Iron Works wit[MASK]in the docks . 
 Th[MASK] French floating batter[MASK]es were deployed in 1855 as a sup[MASK]lement t[MASK] the wooden steam battle fleet in the Crimean War . The role of the battery was to assist unarmored mortar and gunboats bombarding shore fortifications . The [MASK]rench used three of their ironclad batteri[MASK]s ( Lave [MASK] Tonna[MASK]te and Dévastation ) [MASK]n 1855 against the defenses at the Battle of Kinburn on the B[MASK]ack Sea , where they were effective against Russian shore defences . They would[MASK]later be used again during the Italian war in the Adriatic in 1859 . The British floating batteries Glatton and Meteor arrived t[MASK]o late t[MASK] participa[MASK]e to the action at Kinburn .[MASK]The British planned to use theirs in the Baltic Sea against the well @-@ fortified naval base at Kronstadt . 
[MASK]The batteries have a claim to the title of the first iro[MASK]clad warships but they were capable o[MASK] only 4 knots ( 7 km / h ) under their own p[MASK]we[MASK] : [MASK]hey operated under their own powe[MASK] at the Battle of Kinburn , but ha[MASK] to be towed for long range transit . They were also arguably marginal to the work of the navy . The brief success of the floating ironclad batteries convinced France to begi[MASK] work on armored warships for th[MASK]ir battlefleet . 
 
 = = Early ironclad ships and battles = = 
 
 By t[MASK]e end of the 1850s it was clear that France[MASK]was unable to match British b[MASK]ilding of steam warships , and to regain the strategic initiative[MASK]a dr[MASK]matic change was required . The result was the first ocean @-@ going iro[MASK]clad , the Gloire , begun in 1[MASK]57 and launched in 1859 . 
 Gloire 's wooden hull was modelled on that of a steam ship of the line , reduced to one deck[MASK], she[MASK]thed in [MASK]ron [MASK]lates 4 @.@ 5 inches[MASK]( 110 mm ) thick . She w[MASK]s propelled by [MASK] steam engine , driving a sing[MASK]e screw propeller for a [MASK]peed of 13 knots ( 24 km / h ) . She was armed with thi[MASK]ty @-@ six 6 @.@ 4 @-@ inch ( 160 mm ) rifled [MASK]un[MASK] . [MASK]rance proceeded to construct 16 ironclad warships , including two more sister ships to Gloire , and[MASK]the only two @-@ decked broadside ironclads ever built , Magenta and Solférino . 
 The Royal Navy had not been keen to sacrifi[MASK]e its advantage in ste[MASK]m ships of the line , but was d[MASK]termined that the first British ir[MASK]nclad would outmatch the French ships in every respect , particularly s[MASK]eed . A fast ship would have the advantage of being able to choose a range of engagement which could make her invu[MASK]nerable to enemy fire[MASK]. The British specification was more a large , powerful frigate than a ship @-@ of @-@ the @-@ line . The requirement for speed meant a very long vessel , which had to be built from iron . The result wa[MASK] the construction of two Warrior @-@ class[MASK]ironclads ; HMS Warrior and HMS Black Prince . The ships had a successful desig[MASK] , though there were necessarily compro[MASK]ises between ' sea @-@ keepin[MASK] ' , strategic range and armou[MASK] protection ; their [MASK]eapons were more effective than that of Gloire , and with the largest set of steam engines yet fitted to a ship they [MASK]ould steam at 14 @.@ 3 knots ( 26 @.@ 5 km / [MASK] ) . Yet the Gloire and her sisters had full iron @-@ [MASK]rmour protection along the w[MASK]terline and the battery itself . Warrior and Black Prince ( but a[MASK]so the sm[MASK]ller Defence and [MASK]esistance ) wer[MASK] obliged to concentrate their[MASK]armour i[MASK] a central ' citadel ' or ' armoured box ' ,[MASK][MASK]eaving many main deck guns and the fore and aft sect[MASK]ons of the vess[MASK]l unprotected . The us[MASK] of iron in[MASK]the construction of Warrio[MASK] also came with some dra[MASK]backs ; iron hulls required more [MASK]egular and intensive repairs than wooden hulls , and iron was more susceptible[MASK]to fouling by marine life . 
 By 1862 , navies across Europe had adopted ironclads . [MASK]rita[MASK]n and France each had sixteen either completed or under const[MASK]uction , though the British vessels were larger . Austria , Italy , Russia , and Spain w[MASK]re also building ironclads . However , the first battles using[MASK]the new ironclad ships involved neither Britain nor F[MASK]ance , and involved sh[MASK]ps [MASK]ark[MASK]dly differen[MASK] from th[MASK] broadside @-@ firin[MASK] , masted designs of Gloire and Warrior . The use of ironclads by both sides in the American Civil War , and the [MASK]lash of the It[MASK]lian and Austrian fleets at the Battle of Lissa , had an important influence on the development [MASK]f ironclad design [MASK] 
 
 = = = First battles be[MASK]ween ironclads : [MASK]he U.S. Civil War [MASK] = = 
 
[MASK]The first use of ironclads in action came in the U.S. Civil War . The U.S. Navy at the time the war broke out had no ironclads , its most powerful ships being six steam @-@ powered unarmoured frigates . Since the bulk of the Navy remained loyal to the Union , the Con[MASK]ederacy sought to gain advantage in the naval conflict by acquiring modern[MASK]armored ships . In May 1861 , the Confederate Congress voted that $ 2 million be appropriated for the purchase of ironclads from overseas , and in July and August 1861 the Confederacy started work on construction and converting woode[MASK] ships . [MASK] O[MASK] 12 October 1861 , the CSS Manassas became the first ironclad to enter combat , when she fou[MASK]ht Union warships on the Mississippi during the Battle of the Head of Passes . She had been converted from a commercial vessel in New Orleans for river and coastal fighting . In Feb[MASK]uary 1862 , t[MASK]e larger CSS Virginia join[MASK][MASK] the Confederate Navy , having been rebuilt at Norfolk . Constructed on the hull of USS Merrimack , Virginia ori[MASK]inally was a conventional warshi[MASK] made of wood , but she was converted into an iron @-@ covered casem[MASK]te ironclad gunship , when she entered the Confe[MASK]era[MASK]e navy . By th[MASK]s tim[MASK] , the Union had completed seven ironclad gunboats of [MASK]he City class , and was ab[MASK]ut to complete the USS Monit[MASK]r , an[MASK]in[MASK]ovative design proposed by the Swedi[MASK]h i[MASK]ventor John Ericsson . The Union [MASK]as also building a large armored frigate , the USS New Ironsides , and the small[MASK]r USS Galena . 
 The first ba[MASK]tle between ironclads happened on 9 March 1862 , as the armored Monitor was deployed to protect t[MASK]e Union 's[MASK]wooden fleet from the ironclad ram [MASK]irginia and other Confederate warships . In this engagem[MASK]nt , the second day of the Battle of H[MASK]mpton Roads , the two ironclads repeatedly tried to ram one anot[MASK]er while shells bounced[MASK]off their[MASK]armor . The battle attracted attention worldwide , making it clear that the wooden warship was now out of date , with t[MASK]e ironclads destroy[MASK]ng them easily . 
 The Civil War saw more ironclads built by both sides , and they played an increasing role in the naval war alongside the unar[MASK]ored warships , comme[MASK]ce raiders and blockade runners . The Union built a large fleet of fifty m[MASK]nitors modeled on their namesake . The Confederacy built ships desi[MASK]ned as smaller versions of the Virginia , many of which saw action , but their att[MASK]mpts to buy ir[MASK]nclads overseas [MASK]ere frustrated as European nations confiscated ships being built for the Confederacy — especially in Russia , the o[MASK]ly country to openly support the Union through the war . Only CSS Stonewall was completed , and she arrived in A[MASK]erican waters[MASK]just in time f[MASK]r the end of the war . 
 Through the remainder of the war , ironclads saw action in the Union 's attacks on Confederate ports . Seven Unio[MASK] monitors , including USS Montauk , as well as two other [MASK]ronclads , the ironclad frigate New Ironsides and a light @-@ draft U[MASK]S Keoku[MASK] , participated in the f[MASK]iled attack on Char[MASK][MASK]ston ; one was sunk . Two small ironclads , CSS Palmetto State and CSS Chicora participated [MASK]n the defence of the harbor . For the later attack a[MASK] Mo[MASK]ile Bay , the Union asse[MASK]bled four monitors as well as 11 wooden ships , facing the CSS Tenne[MASK]see , [MASK]he Confederacy 's most powerful iro[MASK]clad and the gunboats CSS Morgan , CSS Gaines , CSS Selma . 
 On the western front , the Union built a formidable force of river ironclads[MASK], beginning with seve[MASK]al converted ri[MASK]erboats and then contractin[MASK] engineer James Eads of St. Louis , Mi[MASK]so[MASK]ri to build the City @-@ class ir[MASK]nclads . These excellent ships were built with twin engines and a central paddle wheel , all protected [MASK]y an armored casem[MASK]nt . They had a shallow dra[MASK]t , allowing [MASK]hem to journey up sm[MASK]ller tributaries , and were very well suited for river operations . Eads also pro[MASK]uced monit[MASK]rs for use on the rivers , the first two of which d[MASK]ffered from the ocean @-@ going monitors in that they c[MASK]ntained a paddle wheel ( the USS Neosho and USS Osage ) . 
 Arguably Eads vessels were some of the better ironclads of the W[MASK]stern Flotilla , but there were a number of other vessels that served valiantly with the fleet . All were of [MASK]arying design , some more succes[MASK]ful than others , and so[MASK]e were similar to[MASK]standard riverboats but with armored side @-@ mounted paddle wheels .
