If nothing else the experience of the America[MASK] Civil War and its wild variety of comp[MASK]ting ironclad designs ,[MASK]some more successf[MASK]l ( or disastrous )[MASK]than others , confirmed [MASK]he emerging trade @-@ off or compromises required in a[MASK]plying the la[MASK]es[MASK] technolo[MASK]ical adva[MASK]ces in iron armour manufacture , ship construction and gun design — to name[MASK]a few — [MASK]lso going on in Europe . There was no such thing as a ' perfect ' ironclad which could be invincible in every possible encounter ; ship duels , standi[MASK]g up to forts , Brown & Blue @-@ water operations . 
 The Un[MASK]on ironclads played an important role in the Mississ[MASK]ppi and trib[MASK]taries[MASK]by providing tre[MASK]endous fire upon Confederate forts , installations and vessels with relative impunity to enemy fire . They were not as heavily armored as [MASK]he ocean @-@ going monitors of the[MASK]Union , but they were adequate for their intended use . More[MASK]Western Flotilla Union ironclads were sunk by torpedoes ( mines ) than by enemy fire , and the most d[MASK]maging fire for the Union ironclads was from shore installations , not Con[MASK]ederate vessels . 
 
 = = = Lissa : First fleet battle = = = 
 
 The first fleet battle , and the first ocean battle , involving ironclad warships was the Battle of Lissa in 1866 . Waged between the Austrian and Italian navies , th[MASK] battle pitted combined fleets of wooden frigates and corvettes and ironclad warships on both sides in the largest naval battle between the battles of Navarino and[MASK]Tsu[MASK]hima . 
 The Italian fleet consisted of 12 ironclads and a similar number of wood[MASK]n warships , esco[MASK]ting transports whi[MASK]h carried troops intending to land on the Adriatic island of Lissa . Among the Italian ironclads were seve[MASK] broadside ironclad frigates , four small[MASK]r ir[MASK]nclads , and the newly built Affondatore — a double @-@ tur[MASK]etted ram . Opposing them , the Austrian navy had seven ironclad frigate[MASK] . 
 The Austrians believed their ships to have less effective guns than their enemy , so [MASK]ecided to engage the Italians at close [MASK]ange and ram them . The Austrian f[MASK]eet form[MASK]d into an arrowhead formation with the ironclads in the first line , charging at the Italian ironclad squadron . In[MASK]the melée which followed both sides were[MASK]frustrated by the lack of damage inflicted by guns , and by the difficulty of ramm[MASK]ng — nonetheless [MASK] the effective ramming attack being made by the Austr[MASK]an flagship against the Italian attracted great attention in following years . 
 The superior Italian fleet lost i[MASK]s two ironclads , Re d 'I[MASK]alia and Palestro , while the Austrian unarmoured screw two @-@ decker SMS Kaiser remarkably survived close actions with four Italian ironc[MASK]ads . The battle ensured the popularity of the ram as a weapon [MASK]n European ironclads for many years , and the victory[MASK]won by Austria established it as the predominant naval power in the Adriatic . 
 The battles of the American Civil War and at Lissa were very influential on the designs and tactics of the ironclad fleets that followed . In particular , it taught a generation of naval officers the misleadi[MASK]g le[MASK]s[MASK]n that ramming was the best way to s[MASK]nk enemy ironclads . 
 
 = = Armament and tactics = = 
 
 The adoption of iron armor meant that the traditional naval arma[MASK]ent of dozens of light cannon became useless , since their shot would bounce [MASK]ff an armored hull . To penetrate armor , increasingly heavy guns were mounted on ships ; nevertheless , the view that [MASK]amming [MASK]as the only w[MASK]y to sink an ironclad became widespread . The increasing siz[MASK] and weight of guns also meant a movement away fr[MASK]m the shi[MASK]s mounting many guns broadside , in the manner of a ship @-@ of @-@ the @-@ line , towards a handful of guns in turrets for all @-@ round fire . 
 
 = = =[MASK]Ram c[MASK]aze = = = 
 
 From the 1860s to the 1880s many nav[MASK]l designers believed that the development of the ironclad meant that the ram was again the most important weapon in naval warfare . With steam power freeing ships from the wind , and armor making them invulnera[MASK]le to shel[MASK]fire , t[MASK]e ram [MASK]eemed to offer the oppor[MASK]unity to strike a decisive blow . 
 The scant [MASK]amage inflict[MASK][MASK] by the guns [MASK]f Monitor and Virginia at Battle of Hampton Roads and the spectacular but lucky success of the Austrian flagship SMS [MASK]rzherzog Ferdinand Max sinking the Italian Re d 'Italia at Lissa gave strength to the ramming craze . From the [MASK]arly 1870s to early 1880s most British naval officers thought that guns were about to be replaced as the main nav[MASK]l armament by the ram . Those who noted the tiny number of ships that had actually been sunk by ramming struggled to be heard . 
 The revi[MASK]al of ramming had a significant effect on naval tactics . Since the 17t[MASK] century the predom[MASK]nant tactic of naval warfare had been the line of battle , where a fleet formed a long line to give it the best fire[MASK]from its broadside guns . [MASK]his tactic was totally unsuited to ramming , and the ram threw fleet tactics into disarray . The question of how an ironclad fleet should deploy in battle to make best use of the ram was never t[MASK]sted in battle , and if it[MASK]had been , combat might have shown that rams could[MASK]only be used against ships which were already stopped dead in the water . 
 The ram fina[MASK]ly fell out of favour in the 1880s , as the same effect could be achieved wit[MASK] a torpedo , with less vulnerabil[MASK]ty to [MASK]uick [MASK]-@ firing guns . 
 
 = = = Development of naval guns = = = 
 
 The armament of ironclads tended to become concentrated in a small number of powerful guns capable of penetrating the armor of enemy ships at range ; calibre and weight of guns increase[MASK] markedly to achieve greater penetration [MASK] Thro[MASK]ghout the ironclad era navies also grappled with the complexities o[MASK] [MASK]ifled[MASK]versus[MASK]smoothbo[MASK]e guns and breech @[MASK]@ loading versus muz[MASK]le @-@ loading . 
 HMS Warrior carried a mixture of 110 @-@ pounder 7 inch ( 180 mm ) breech @-@ loading rifles and more traditional 68 @-@[MASK]pound[MASK]r smoothbore guns . Warrior highlighted the [MASK]hallenges of picki[MASK]g the[MASK]right armament ; the breech @-@ loaders sh[MASK] car[MASK]ied , designed by Sir William Armstrong , were intended to be the next g[MASK]neration of heavy armament for the Roya[MASK] Navy , but were shortly[MASK][MASK]ithdrawn from service . 
 Breech @-@ loading guns seemed to offer important advantages . A breech @-@ loader could be reloaded[MASK]without moving the gun , a lengthy process particularly if the gun [MASK]hen needed to be re @-@ aimed . The W[MASK]rrior 's Armstrong guns al[MASK]o had the [MASK]irtue of being lighter than a[MASK] [MASK]quivalent smoothbore and , because of their riflin[MASK] , more accurate . Nonetheless , the design was rejected because[MASK]of problems which plagued breech @-@ loaders for decades . 
 The weakness [MASK]f [MASK]he breech @-@ loader was th[MASK] obvious problem of sealing the breech . All guns are powered by the explosive conversion of gunpowder into gas . This explosion propels the shot or shell out of the front of the gun , but also imposes great stresses on the gun @-@ barrel . If the breech — which expe[MASK]iences some of the greatest forces in the gun — is not entirely secure , then there is a risk that either gas will discharge throu[MASK]h the breech or that the bre[MASK]ch will break . This in turn redu[MASK]es the muzzle ve[MASK]ocity of the we[MASK]pon and can also endanger the gun crew . The Warrior 's Armstrong guns suffered from bo[MASK]h prob[MASK]ems ; the shells were unable to penetrate the 4 @.@ 5 in ( 118 mm ) armor of Gloire , while s[MASK]metimes the sc[MASK]ew[MASK]which closed the breech[MASK]flew backwards out of the gun on firing . Similar problems were experienced with the breech @-@ loading guns which became standard in the French and German[MASK]navies . 
 These problems [MASK]nfluenced[MASK]the British t[MASK] equip ships with muzzle @-@ l[MASK]ading weapons of increasing[MASK]po[MASK]er until the 18[MASK]0s . After a[MASK]b[MASK]ief introduction of 100 @-@ pounder or 9 @.@ 5 @-@ inch ( 240 mm ) smoot[MASK]bore Somerset Gun[MASK], which weighed 6 @.@ 5 tons ( 6 @.@ [MASK] t ) , the [MASK]dmiralty introduce[MASK] 7 @-@ inch ( 178 mm ) rifled guns , weighing 7 tons . These were followed by a series of increasingly mammoth weapons — gu[MASK][MASK] weighing 12 , 25 , 25 , 38 and finally 81 tons , with calibre increasing from 8 @-@ inch ( 203 mm ) to 16 @-@ inch ( 406 mm ) . 
 The de[MASK]ision to retain muzzle @-@ loaders until the 1880s has been criticised by historians . However , [MASK]t least until the late 18[MASK]0s , the Bri[MASK]ish muzzle @-@ loaders had superior performance in terms of both range and rate of fire t[MASK]an the [MASK]rench and Prussian breech @-@ loaders , which suff[MASK]red from the same problems as had the first Armstrong guns . 
 From 1875 onwards[MASK], the ba[MASK]ance between breech- and muzzle @-@ loading changed . Capta[MASK]n de Bange invented [MASK] method of reliably sealing a breech , adopted by the French in 1873 . Just as compellingly , the growing size of naval guns made muzzle @-@ l[MASK]ading much more complicated . With guns of such size there was[MASK]no prospect of hauling in the gu[MASK] for[MASK]re @-@ loading , or even re @-@ loading by hand , and complicated hydraulic systems were[MASK]required for re @-@ loading the gun outside the turret without exposing the crew to e[MASK]emy fire . In 1882 , the 81 @-@ ton , 16 @-@ inch ( 406 mm ) guns of H[MASK]S Inflexible fired only[MASK]once every 11 minutes while bombarding Alexan[MASK]ria during t[MASK]e Urabi Revolt . The 100 @-@ ton , 450 mm[MASK]( 17 @.@ 72 inch ) guns of Caio Duilio could each[MASK]fire a round every 15 minutes . 
 In the Royal Navy , the sw[MASK]t[MASK]h to breech @-@ loaders was finally made in 1879 ; as well as the significant advantages in terms of performance , opin[MASK]on was swayed b[MASK] an explosion on board HMS Thunderer cause[MASK] by a gun being double @-@ loade[MASK] , a problem which could only happen with a muzzle @-@ loading gun . 
 The ca[MASK]ibre and weig[MASK]t of guns co[MASK]ld only increase so [MASK]ar . The larger the gun , the slower it would be to load , the greater the stresses on [MASK]he ship 's hull , and the less the stability of the ship . The size of the [MASK]un peaked in the 1880s , with some of the heaviest calibres of gun[MASK]ever used at sea . HMS B[MASK]nbow carried two 16 @.@ 25 @-@ inch ( 413 mm ) breech @-@ loading g[MASK]ns , ea[MASK]h wei[MASK]hing 110 tons — no British battleship would ever carry guns as lar[MASK]e . Th[MASK] Italian 450 mm ( 17 @.@ 72 inch ) guns would be larger than any gun fitted[MASK]to a battleship until the 18 @.@[MASK]1 @-@ i[MASK]ch ( 460 mm ) armament of the [MASK]apanese Yamato class of World War II . One consideration which bec[MASK]me more acute wa[MASK] that even from the original Armstrong models , following the Crimean War , range and hitting power far exceeded simple accuracy , especially at sea where the slightest roll or pitch of th[MASK] vessel as ' floating weapons @-@ pl[MASK]tform[MASK]'[MASK]could ne[MASK]ate the advantage of rifling . American ordnance experts accordingly pref[MASK]rred smoothbore monsters whose round shot could at least ' skip ' along the surface of the water . Actual effective combat ranges , they had learned dur[MASK]ng the Civil War , were comp[MASK]rable to those in the Age of Sail — though a vessel could now be smashed to pieces in[MASK]only a[MASK]few rounds . Smoke and the general chaos of battle only ad[MASK]ed to t[MASK]e problem . As a result ,[MASK]many naval engagements in the ' Age of the Ironclad ' wer[MASK] still fought at ranges within easy eyesight of their targets , and well bel[MASK]w [MASK]he maximum reach of [MASK]heir ships ' guns [MASK][MASK]
 Another method of increasing firepower was to vary the project[MASK]le fired or t[MASK]e nature of the propellant . Early ironcl[MASK]ds used black powd[MASK]r , which expanded rapidly after combustion ; this meant cannons had rela[MASK]ively s[MASK]ort barrel[MASK] , to prevent the barrel its[MASK]lf slowing the shell . The sharpness[MASK]of the black powder explosion also mean[MASK] that guns were subjected to extreme stress . One important step was to press the powder into pellets , al[MASK]owing a slower , more controlled explosion and a longer barrel . A further step forwar[MASK] was the introduction of chemically different brown powd[MASK]r which combusted more slowly again .[MASK]It also put less stress on the insides of the barrel ,[MASK]allowing guns to last longer and to be manufactured to tighter tolerances . 
 The development of smokeless powder , based on nitro[MASK]lycerine or nitrocellulose , by the French inv[MASK]ntor Paul Viell[MASK] in 1884[MASK]was a further step allowing[MASK]small[MASK]r charges of pro[MASK]ellant with longer barrels . The g[MASK]ns of the pre @-@ Dreadnought battleships of the 1890s tended to be smaller in calibre compared to the ships of the [MASK]880s , most often 12 in ( 305 mm ) , but progressively grew in length of barrel , making use of improved propellants to gain gr[MASK]ater muzzle velocity . 
 The nature of the projectiles also changed during the ironclad period . Initially , the best armor @-@ piercing projectile was a solid cast @-@ iron shot . Later , shot of chilled iron , a [MASK]arder iron alloy , gave better armor @-@ pier[MASK]ing qualities . Eventua[MASK]ly the armor @-@ piercing shell was devel[MASK]ped . [MASK] 
 = = = Positioning of[MASK]armament = = = 
 
 
 = = = = Broadside ironclads = = = = 
 
 The first British , French and Russian ironclads , in a logical development of warship design from the long preceding era of wooden ships of the l[MASK]ne , carrie[MASK] their weapons in a single l[MASK]ne along their [MASK]ides and [MASK]o were called " broadside ironclads . " Both Gloire and HMS Warrior were examp[MASK]es of[MASK]this type . Beca[MASK]se their armo[MASK] was so heavy , they c[MASK]uld only carry a si[MASK]gle row of guns along the main deck on each side [MASK]ather tha[MASK] a row on each deck . 
 A s[MASK]gnificant number of broadside ironclads were built in [MASK]he [MASK]860s , principally in Britain and Fra[MASK]ce , but in smaller numbers by other powers including Italy , Au[MASK]tria , Russia and the United States . The adv[MASK]ntages of mounting guns on both bro[MASK]dsides was that the ship could engage more than one adversary at a time , and the rigging did not impede the field o[MASK] fire . 
 Broadside armament also had disadvantages , which became more serious as ironclad technology developed . Heavier guns to penetrate ever @-@ thick[MASK]r armor meant that fewer guns could be carried . Furthermore , the adoption of ramming as an important tactic meant the n[MASK]ed for ahead and all @-[MASK] round[MASK]fire . These problems led to broadside designs being su[MASK]erseded by designs that gave greater all @-@ [MASK]ound [MASK]ire , which included central @-@ battery , turret , and barbette designs . 
 
 = = = = Turrets , batteries and barbettes = = = = 
 
 There were two main design[MASK]alternatives to th[MASK] broadside . In one design [MASK] the guns were pla[MASK]ed in an armoured casemate amidships : this arrangement was called the ' box @-@ battery ' or [MASK] ce[MASK]tre @-@ battery ' . In the other , th[MASK] [MASK]uns could be placed on a rotating platform to give them a broad field[MASK]of fire ; when fully armored , this arrangement was called a turret and when partially armored or unarmored , a barbette . 
 T[MASK]e centre @-@ battery was the simpler and , during the 1860s and 1870s , the more popula[MASK] method . Concentrating guns amidships meant the ship [MASK]ould be shorter and handier than a broadsid[MASK] type . The first full @-@ scale centre @-@ batte[MASK]y ship was HMS Beller[MASK]phon o[MASK] 1865 ; the F[MASK]ench laid down centre @-@ battery ironclads in 186[MASK] whic[MASK] were not completed until 1870 . Centre @-@ battery ships often , but not always , had a recessed freeboard enabling some of their guns to fire directly ahead . 
 The turret was first u[MASK]ed in naval combat on the USS Monitor in 1862 , with a type of turret designed by the Swedish engineer John Ericsson . A competing turret design was proposed by the British inven[MASK]o[MASK] Cowper C[MASK]les with a prototype of th[MASK]s installed on HMS Trusty in 1861 for testing and evaluation purposes . Ericsson 's turret turned on a central spindle , and Coles 's turned on a ring of bearings . Turrets offered the[MASK]maximum arc of fire from the guns , but there were significant problems with their use in the 1860s . The fire arc of a turret would be considerably limited by ma[MASK]ts and rigging , so they were unsuited to use on the earlier ocean @-@ going ironclads . The second p[MASK]oblem was that turrets were extremel[MASK][MASK]heavy . Ericsson was a[MASK]le to offer the heaviest possible turret ( guns and armour protection ) by delibera[MASK]ely designing a ship with very low freeboard . The weight thus saved from [MASK]aving a high broadside above the waterline [MASK]as diverted to actual guns a[MASK]d armour . Low freeboard , however , also meant a smaller hull and therefore a smaller capacity for coal storage — and therefore range of the vessel . In man[MASK] respects , the turreted , low @-@ [MASK]reeboard Monitor and the[MASK]broadside sailer HMS Warrior represented two opposite extremes in [MASK]hat an ' Ironclad ' was all [MASK]bout . The most dramatic attempt to co[MASK]promise the[MASK]e two extremes , or ' squaring this circle ' , was designed by Captain Cowper Phipps Coles : HMS Captain , a dangerou[MASK]ly low freeboard turret ship [MASK]hich nevertheless car[MASK]ied a full rig of sail , and which subsequently capsized not long after her la[MASK]nch in 1870 . Her half @-@ sister HMS Monarch was[MASK]restricted to firing from her turrets only on the p[MASK]rt and starb[MASK]ard bea[MASK]s [MASK] The third Royal Navy ship to combine turrets and masts was HMS Inflexible of[MASK]1876 , which carried two turrets on either side of the centr[MASK] @-@ line , allowing both t[MASK] fire fore , aft and broadside . 
 A lighter alternative to the turret , particul[MASK]rly popular with the Fren[MASK]h navy , was the barbette . These were fixed armored towers which held a gun on a turntable . The crew was sheltered fr[MASK]m dire[MASK]t fire , but vulnerable to plunging fire , for instance from shore emplacements . The[MASK]barbette was lighter than[MASK]the turret , needing less machinery and no roof armor — though nevertheless some barbettes were stri[MASK]ped of their armor [MASK]late to reduce the top @-@ weight of their ships . The barbette became [MASK]idely adopted in the 1880s , and[MASK]with[MASK]the addition of an armored ' gun @-@ house ' , transformed into the t[MASK]rrets of the pre @-@ Dreadnough[MASK] battleships . 
 
 = = = Torpedoes = = = 
 
 The ironclad age[MASK]saw the developmen[MASK] of explos[MASK]ve torpedoes as naval weapons , which helped compli[MASK]ate the [MASK]esig[MASK] and tactics of ironclad fleets . Th[MASK] first torpedoes were static mines , used extensively in the American Civil War . That conflict also saw the development of the spar torpedo , an explosive charge pushed again[MASK]t the hull of a warship by a small boat . For the first time[MASK], a large warship faced a serious threat from a smaller o[MASK]e — and given the relative ine[MASK]ficiency of shellfire against ironclads , the threat from the spar torpedo was taken seriously . The U.S. Navy converted four of its monitors to become turretless armored spar @-@ torpedo vessels while under construction in 1864 – 5 , but these vessels never saw action . Another proposal [MASK] the towed or ' Harvey ' torp[MASK]do , involved an explosive[MASK]on a line or outrigger ; either to deter a ship [MASK]rom ramming or to make a torpedo attack by a boat less suicidal[MASK]. 
 A more practical and influential weapon was th[MASK] self @-@ propelled or Whitehead torpedo . Invented in 1868 and deployed in the 1870s , the Whitehead[MASK]tor[MASK]e[MASK]o f[MASK]r[MASK]ed part of the armamen[MASK] of[MASK]ironclads of the 18[MASK]0s [MASK]ike HMS Inflexible [MASK]nd the Italian Caio Duilio and Enrico Dandolo . The ironclad 's [MASK]ulnerability to the torpedo was a key pa[MASK]t of the cri[MASK]ique of armored warships made by[MASK]the Jeun[MASK] Ecole school of naval thoug[MASK]t ; it appeared that any ship armored enough to prevent destruction by gunfi[MASK]e would b[MASK] slow enough to be easily caught by to[MASK]pedo . In[MASK]practice , however , the Jeune Ecole was only briefly inf[MASK]uential and the torpedo formed part of the confus[MASK]ng mixture of wea[MASK]ons possessed by ironclads . 
 
 = = Armor and c[MASK]nstruction = = 
 
 The first ironclads w[MASK]re built on wooden or iron hulls , and prote[MASK]ted by wrought iron armor backed by thick wooden planking [MASK] Iron[MASK]lads were still being built w[MASK]th wooden hulls into the 1870s . 
 
 = = = Hulls : iron , wood and stee[MASK] = = = 
 
 Using iron construction for warships offered advantages for the engineering of th[MASK] hull . However , unarmored iron[MASK]ha[MASK] many mili[MASK]ary disadvantages , and [MASK]ffered technical p[MASK]oblems which kept wooden hulls[MASK]in use for many years , particularly for [MASK][MASK]ng @-@ range cruising warships . 
 Iron ships [MASK]ad first been proposed for military use[MASK]in the 1820s . In the 1830s and 1840s , France , Britain and the United States had all experimented with iro[MASK] @-@ hulled but unarmored gunboats and frigates . However , the iro[MASK] @-@ hulle[MASK] frigate was abandoned by the end [MASK]f the 1840s , becaus[MASK] iron hulls wer[MASK] more vulnerable to solid shot ; iron wa[MASK] more brittle [MASK]han wood , and iron frames more likely to fall out of shape than wood . 
 The unsuitability of unarmored iron for warship hul[MASK]s meant that iron was only adopted as a building material f[MASK]r battleships when protected by armor . However , iron gave the naval architect many advantages . Iron allowed lar[MASK]er s[MASK]ips and[MASK]more flexible design , for instance the use of [MASK]at[MASK]rtight bulkheads on the lower decks . Warrior , bu[MASK]lt of iron , was longer and faster than the wooden @-@ hulled Gloire . Iron could be produced to order and used immediately , in contrast [MASK]o the need to give wood a long period of seasoning . And , given the large quantities of wood required to build a steam warship and the falling cost of iron , iron hulls were increasingly cost @-@ effective . The main reason f[MASK]r the French use of wooden hulls for the ironclad fleet built in the 1860s was that the French iron indu[MASK]try could not supply enough , and the main reason why Britain built its handful of wooden @-@ hulled[MASK]ironclads was to make best use of hulls already started and wood already bought . [MASK] Wooden hulls continued to b[MASK] used for long @-@ range and smaller ironclads , because iron neverthel[MASK]ss had a significant disadvantage . Iron hulls suffered quick fouling by marine life , slowing the ships down — manageable for a European battlefleet close to dry docks , but a difficulty for long @-@ range sh[MASK]ps . The only solution was to sheath the iron hull first in wood and then in[MASK]cop[MASK]er , a lab[MASK]rious and ex[MASK]ensive process which made wooden c[MASK]nstruction remain attractive . Iron [MASK]nd wood were to some extent in[MASK]erchang[MASK]able : the Japanese Kongō and Hiei ordered in 1875 were sister @-@ ships , but one was built of iron and the other of composite constr[MASK]ction . 
 Afte[MASK] 187[MASK] , steel st[MASK]rted to be intro[MASK]uced as a material for construction . Compared to iron , steel allows for greater structural strength for a lower weight . The French Navy le[MASK] the way with the use of steel in i[MASK]s fleet , starting with the Redoutable , laid down in[MASK]1873 and launched in 1876 . Re[MASK]outable nonetheless had wrou[MASK]h[MASK] iron armor plate , and part of her exterior hull was i[MASK]on rather than steel [MASK] 
 Even though Britain led the world in steel production , the Royal Navy was slow to adopt steel warships . The Besseme[MASK] process for steel manufacture produced too many imperfections for large @-@ scale use o[MASK] ships . French manufacturers used the Siemens @-@ Martin process to produce adequate steel , but British technology la[MASK]ged behind . The first all [MASK]-@ steel warships built by the Royal Navy were the[MASK]dispatch vessels Iris and Mercury , laid down in [MASK]875 and 1876 . 
 
 = = = Armor and protection schemes = = = 
 
 Iron @-@ bu[MASK]lt ships used wood as part of[MASK]their protection scheme . HMS Warrior was protected by 4 @.@ 5 in ( 114 mm ) of wrought iron backed by 15 in ( 381 mm ) of teak , the strongest shipbuilding woo[MASK] . The wood played two roles[MASK], preventing spalli[MASK]g and[MASK]also pre[MASK]enting the shock of a hit damaging the structure [MASK]f the ship . Later , wood and iron were combined in ' sandwich ' armor , for instance in HMS Inflexible . 
 Steel wa[MASK] also an obvious materia[MASK] for armor . It was tested in [MASK]he 1860s , but the steel of the time was too brittle and disintegrated when struck by shells . Steel became practical to use when a[MASK]way was found to fuse steel onto wrou[MASK]ht iron plates , givin[MASK] a form of compound armor . This comp[MASK]und [MASK]rmor was used by the British in ships built from the late 1870s , first for turret armor ([MASK]starting with HMS Inflexible ) and then for all armor ( starting with HMS Colossus of 1882 ) . T[MASK]e[MASK]French and German navies [MASK]dopted the innovat[MASK]on almost immediately , with licenses being given for the use of the ' Wilson Sy[MASK]tem ' of producing fused armor . 
 The[MASK]first iron[MASK]lads to have all @-@ [MASK]teel armor were the Italian Caio Duilio and Enrico Dandolo . Th[MASK]ugh the ships were laid down in 1873 the[MASK]r armor was not purchased from France until 1877 . The French navy decided in 1880 to adopt compound armor for its fleet , but found it limited in supply , so from 1884 the French navy was using steel armor . Britain stuck to co[MASK]pound armor until 1889 . 
 The ultimate ironclad armo[MASK] was c[MASK]se hardened nickel @-@ steel . In 1890 , the U.S. Navy tested steel armor [MASK]ardened by the Harvey process and found it superior t[MASK] compound armor [MASK] For several years ' Harve[MASK] steel ' was the state of the art , produced i[MASK] the U.S. , France , Germany , Britain , Austria and Italy . In 1894 , the Germ[MASK]n firm Krupp developed gas cementing , which further hardened steel armor . The [MASK]erman Kaiser Friedric[MASK] III , laid down in 1895 , was the first [MASK]hip to benefit from the new ' Krupp armor ' and the new armor was quickly adopted ; the Royal Navy using it from HMS Canopus , laid down in 1896 . By 1901 almost all new battleships used Krupp armor , tho[MASK]gh the U.S. continued to use Harvey armor alongside until the end of[MASK]the decade . 
 The equivalent strengths of the different armor plates was as follows : 15 in ( 381 m[MASK] ) of wrought iron was equivalent to 12 in ( 305 mm ) of either plai[MASK] steel or compound iron and [MASK]teel ar[MASK]or , and to 7 @.@ [MASK]5 in ( 197 mm ) of Harve[MASK] armor or 5 @.@ 75 in ( 146 mm ) of Krupp armor . 
 Iron[MASK]lad co[MASK]struction also prefigured the later debate in battleship design b[MASK]tween t[MASK]pering and ' all @-@ or @-@ nothing ' armour design . Warrior was only semi @-@ armoured , and could have been disabled by hits on t[MASK]e bow and stern . As the thickness of armor grew to protect ships from the inc[MASK]easingly heav[MASK] guns , the [MASK]rea of the ship which could be fully protected diminished . Inflexible 's[MASK]armor protection was largely limited to the central citadel amidships , protecting boilers and engines , turrets and mag[MASK]zines , and l[MASK]ttle else . An ingenious arrangement of cork @-@ filled compartm[MASK]nts a[MASK]d watertight bulkheads was intended to keep her stable and afloat in the event of h[MASK]avy damage to her un @-@ armored sections . 
 
 = = Propulsion : steam and sail = = 
 
 The first ocean [MASK]-@ [MASK]oing ironclads carried masts and sai[MASK]s like their wooden [MASK]redecessors , and these fe[MASK]tures were only gradually aband[MASK]ned . Early steam engines were inefficient ; the wooden steam fleet of the Royal Navy could only carry " 5 to 9 da[MASK]s coal " , [MASK]nd the situation was similar with the early[MASK]ironclads . Warrior also illust[MASK]ates two design features which aided hybrid propulsion ; she had retractable screws to reduce drag while under sail ( though in practice the steam engine was run at a low throttle ) , and a telescop[MASK]c funnel which could be fol[MASK]ed down to the deck level . 
 Ship[MASK] designed for coastal warfare , like the floating batteries of the Crimea , or USS Monitor and her [MASK]isters , dispensed with masts from the beginning . The British HMS Devastation , started in 1869 , was the first large , ocean @-@ going ironclad[MASK]to dispense with masts . Her principal role was for combat in the English Channel and other European waters ; and while her coal supplies gave [MASK]er enough range to cross the Atl[MASK]ntic , she would have had little endurance on the other side o[MASK] the ocean . The Devastation and the similar ships commissioned by th[MASK] British and Rus[MASK]ian navies in th[MASK] 187[MASK]s were the exception r[MASK]ther than[MASK]the rule . Most ironclads of the 1[MASK]70s [MASK]etained masts , and only the Italian navy , which during that decade was [MASK]ocused on short @-@ range operations in the Adriatic , built consis[MASK]ently mastless ironclads . 
 During the 1860s , steam engines improved with the adoption of double @-@ expansion stea[MASK] engines , which used 30 – 40 % less coal than earlier model[MASK] . The Royal Navy decided to switch to the double @-@ exp[MASK]nsion engine [MASK]n 1871 , [MASK]nd[MASK]by 1875 they were widespread . However , this development alone was not enough to herald the end[MASK][MASK]f the m[MASK]st . Whether th[MASK]s was due to[MASK]a [MASK]onservative desire to retain sails , or was a rational response to the op[MASK]ra[MASK]ional [MASK]nd strategic situation , is a matter of debate . A steam @-@ only fleet would require a network of coaling stations wo[MASK]ldwide , which would need to be fortified at great expense to stop th[MASK]m falling into en[MASK]my hands . Just as significantly , because of unsolved problems with the te[MASK]hnology of the boilers whi[MASK]h provided steam for the engines , the performance of double [MASK]-@ expansion engines was rarely as good in practice as it was in theory . 
 During the[MASK]1870s the distinction grew between ' f[MASK]rst @-@ class ironclads ' or '[MASK]battleships '[MASK]on the one hand , and ' cruising ironclads ' designed for long @-@ range work on the other . The demands on first @-@ class ironclads for very heavy[MASK]armor[MASK]and armament meant[MASK]increasing displacement , which reduced speed under sail ; and [MASK]he fashion for turrets and barbettes made a sailing rig increasingly [MASK]nco[MASK]venient . HMS Inflexible , launched in 1876 but not commissioned until 1881 , was the [MASK]ast British battleship t[MASK] carry masts , and these were [MASK]idely seen as a mistake . The start of the 1880s saw the end of sailing rig on i[MASK]onclad battleships . 
 Sails persisted on ' cruising ironclads ' for much longer . During the 1860s , the French navy had produced the Alma[MASK]and La Galissonnière classes as small , lo[MASK]g @-@ range ironclads as overseas cruisers and the British had responded with [MASK]hips like HMS Swiftsure of 1870 . The Russian ship General @-@ Admiral , [MASK]aid down in 1870 and completed in 1875 , was a model of a fast , long @-@ range ir[MASK]nclad[MASK]which was[MASK]like[MASK]y to be able to outrun and outfight ships like Swiftsure . Even the later HMS Shannon , often described as the first British armored cruiser , would have been too slow to outrun Gener[MASK]l [MASK]-@ Admiral . While Shannon was the last British sh[MASK]p with a retractable propellor , later armored cruisers of the 1870s retained sailing rig , sacrificing speed under steam in consequence . It took until 1881 for the[MASK]Royal [MASK]avy to lay down a long @-@ range armored warship capable of catching enemy commerce raiders , HMS Warspite , which[MASK]was co[MASK]pleted in 1888 . While sailing rigs were obsolescent for all purposes[MASK]by the end of the 1880s , rigged ships were in service until the early years of the 20th ce[MASK]tury . 
 The final evolution of ironclad propulsion was the adoption of the triple @-@ expansion steam engine , a further refinement which was first adopted in HMS Sans Pareil , laid down in 18[MASK]5 and commissioned in 1891 . Many ships [MASK]lso used a forced draught to get additional power from their engines , and this system was widely used until the introduction of the steam turbine in the mid @-@ 1900s ( decade ) . 
 
 = = Fleets = = 
 
 While ironclads spread rapidly in navies worldwide , there were few pitched naval battles involvi[MASK]g ironclads . Most European nations settled differences on [MASK]and , [MASK]nd the Royal N[MASK]vy struggled[MASK]to maintain a deterrent parity with at least France , while providing sui[MASK]able protection to Britain 's commerce and colonial outposts worldwide [MASK] Ironcla[MASK]s rem[MASK]ined , for the Brit[MASK]sh Royal Navy , a mat[MASK]er of defending the Br[MASK]tish Isles first and projecting power abroad second . Thos[MASK] naval engagements of the lat[MASK]er hal[MASK] of the 19th @-@ century which involved ironclads normally involved colonial actions or clashes between second[MASK]@-@ rate naval powers . [MASK]ut these encounters were often enough to convince British policy @-@ makers of[MASK]the increasing hazards of strictly n[MASK]val foreign intervention[MASK], [MASK]rom Hampton Roads in the Ame[MASK]ican Civil War t[MASK] the hardening combined defenc[MASK]s of nav[MASK]l arsenals such as Kronstadt and C[MASK]erbourg[MASK]. 
 There were many types of ironclads : 
 Seagoing ships intended to " stand in the line of battle " ; the precursors of the battleship . 
 Coastal service and riverine vessels , including ' floating ba[MASK]teries ' and ' monitors' 
 Vessels intended for commer[MASK]e raiding or protection of commerce [MASK] called ' armou[MASK]ed cruisers'[MASK]
 
 = = = Navies = = = 
 
 The United Kingdom possessed the largest navy in the world [MASK]or the whole of the ironclad period . The Royal Navy was the second to [MASK]dopt ironclad warships , [MASK]nd it applied them worldwide in their whole range of roles . In the age of[MASK]sail , the British strategy for war depended on the Ro[MASK]al Navy mo[MASK]nting a blockade of the ports of the enemy . Because of the limited endurance of steams[MASK]ips , this was no longer possible , so[MASK]the British at times considered the risk @-@ laden plan of engaging an enemy fleet in harbor as soon as war broke out . To this end , th[MASK] Royal Navy developed a series of ' coast @-@ defence battleships ' , [MASK]tarting with the Devastation class . These ' br[MASK]astwork monitors ' were markedly different from the other [MASK]igh @-@ seas ironclads of the period and [MASK]ere an important precursor of the modern battleship . As long @-@ range monitors they could reach Bermuda unescorted , for example . Ho[MASK]ever , they were still armed with only four heavy guns and were as vulnerable to mines and obstructions [MASK] and enemy monitors ) as the original monitors of the Union Navy proved to be during the Civil War . The British prepared for an overwhelming mortar bombardment of Kronstadt by the close of the Crimean [MASK]ar , b[MASK]t never considered running the smoke [MASK]-@ ridden , shallow @-@ water gauntlet straight to St. Petersburg with ironclads . Likewise , monit[MASK]rs proved acutely unable to ' overwhelm ' enemy fortifications single @-@ handed during the American conflict , though their [MASK]ow @-@ profile and heavy armour p[MASK]otecti[MASK]n made them ideal for running[MASK]gauntlets . Mines and obstructions , however , negated these advantages [MASK] a problem the British [MASK]dmiralty frequently acknow[MASK]edged but neve[MASK] counte[MASK]ed througho[MASK]t[MASK]the period . The British never laid down enough Devastation @-@ class[MASK]' battleships ' to instantly overwhelm Cherbourg , Kronstadt or even New York City with gunfire . Although[MASK]throughout the 1860s and 1870s th[MASK] Royal Navy was still [MASK]n many respects superior to its potential rivals , by the early 1880s widespread co[MASK]cern about the threat from France and Germany culminated in t[MASK]e Naval Defence Act , [MASK]hich promulgated the ide[MASK] of a ' two @-@ power standard ' , that Brita[MASK]n should possess as many ships as the next two navies combined . This standard provoked aggre[MASK]sive shipbuilding in the 1880s and 1890s . 
 British ships did not participate in any major wars in the ironclad period . The Royal Navy 's ironclads only saw actio[MASK] as pa[MASK]t of colonial battl[MASK]s or one @-@ sided engagements [MASK]ike the bombardment of Alexandria in 1882 . Defending British interests a[MASK]ainst[MASK]Ahmed ' Urabi 's Egypt[MASK]an revolt , a British fleet opened fire on the fortifications around the port of Alexandria . A mixture of centre @-@ battery and turret ships bombard[MASK]d Egyptian positions for most of a day , forcing th[MASK] Egyptians to retreat ; return fire [MASK]rom Egyptia[MASK] guns was hea[MASK]y at first , but inflicted little damage , killing only five Britis[MASK] sailors . Few Egyptian g[MASK]ns were actually dismounted , on the other hand , and the fortifications themselves were typically left intact . Had the Egyptians actually utilised the heavy mortars that were at their disposal , they m[MASK]ght have quickly turned the tide , for the attacking British[MASK]ironclads found it easy ( fo[MASK] accuracy 's sake ) to simply anchor [MASK]hilst firing — p[MASK]rfect ta[MASK]gets for high @-@ angle fire upon their thinly armoured topdecks . 
 The French navy b[MASK]ilt the first ironclad to try to gain a str[MASK]tegic advantage over the Britis[MASK] , but were consistently out @-[MASK] built by the British . Despite taking the lead with a number of innovations like breech @-@ loading weapons and steel construction , the French navy could never [MASK]atch t[MASK]e size of the[MASK]Royal Navy . In the 1870s , the construction of ironclads ceased for a while in France as the Jeune Ecole school of naval thought took prominence , suggestin[MASK] th[MASK]t torpedo boats and unarmor[MASK]d cruisers would be the future of warships . Like the British , the French navy saw little action with its ironclads ; the F[MASK]ench blockade of Germany in the Franco @-@ Prussian War was ineffective , as the war was settled entirely on land . 
 Russ[MASK]a built a number of ironclads , generally copies of British or French designs . Noneth[MASK]less , [MASK]here were real innovations from Russia ; the first true[MASK]type of ironclad armor[MASK]d cruiser , the General @-@ Admiral of the 1870s , and a set of remarkably badly designed circular battleships re[MASK]erred to as ' popovkas ' ( for Admiral Popov [MASK] who conceived the design ) . The Russian Navy pioneered the wide @-@ scale use of torpedo boats during the Russo @-@ Turkish War of 1877 – 1878 , m[MASK]inly out of necessity because of the superior [MASK]umbers and quality of ir[MASK]nclads[MASK]used by the Turkish navy . Russia expanded her navy in the 1880s and 1890s with modern armored cruiser[MASK] and battleshi[MASK]s , but the ships were manned[MASK]by inexperienced crews and politica[MASK]ly appointed lead[MASK]rship , which en[MASK]anced their d[MASK]feat in the Battle of [MASK]sushima on 27 May 1905 .[MASK]
 The U.[MASK]. Navy[MASK]ended the Civi[MASK] War with about fifty monitor @-@ type coastal ironclads ; by the 1870s most of the[MASK]e were laid up in reserve , leaving the USA v[MASK]rtually without an ironclad fleet . Another five large monitors were ordered in the 1870s . The limitation[MASK] of the monitor type effectively prevented the USA from projecting power overseas , and until the 1890s the USA would have come off badly in a conflict with even Spain or the Latin[MASK]American powers . The 1890s saw the beginning of what became the Great White Fleet , and [MASK][MASK] was the mod[MASK]rn pre @-@ Dreadnoughts and armored cruisers built in the 1890s which d[MASK]feated the Spanish fleet in the Spanish – American War of 1898 . This started a new era of nav[MASK]l warfare . 
 Ironclads were widely [MASK]sed in South America . Both sides used ironclads in the Chincha Islands War between Spain and the combined for[MASK]es of Peru and Chile in [MASK]he early 1860s . The powerful Spanish Numancia participated in the Battle of Callao but was unable to inflict[MASK]significan[MASK] damage to the Callao defences . Besides , Peru was able to deploy two locally built ironclads based on American Civil War d[MASK]signs , the Loa ( a wooden ship converted into a case[MASK]ate iro[MASK]clad ) and the Victoria ( a s[MASK]all monitor armed with a single 68 @-@ pdr gun ) , as well as two British @-@ [MASK]uilt ironcl[MASK]ds : Independencia , a centre @-@ battery ship , and the turret [MASK]hip Huáscar . Numa[MASK]cia was the first ironclad to circ[MASK]mnavigate the world , arriving in Cádiz[MASK]on 20 September 1867 , and ea[MASK]ning the motto : " Enloricata navis que primo terram ci[MASK]cuivit " [ " First [MASK]ronclad ship to sail around the world " ] ) . In the War of the Pacific in 1879 , both Peru and[MASK]Chile had ironclad warships , including some of those use[MASK] a few years previously against Spain .[MASK]While the Ind[MASK]pendencia ran aground early on , the Peruvian ironclad ' Huáscar made a great impact against Chilean[MASK]shipping , delaying Chilean ground invasion by six months . She was event[MASK]ally caught by two more modern Chilean centre @-@ battery ironclads , the Blanc[MASK] Encalada and the Almirante Cochrane at the Battle of Anga[MASK]os Point . 
 Ironclads were a[MASK]so used from the [MASK]nception of the[MASK]Imperial Japanese Navy . The Kōtetsu ( Japanese : 甲鉄 , literally " Ironclad " , later renamed Azuma 東 , " East " ) had a decisive role in the Naval Battle of Hakodate Bay in May 186[MASK] , which marked the end of the Boshin War , and the complet[MASK] establishment of the Meiji Restoration . The IJN continu[MASK]d to develop its strength and commissioned a n[MASK]mber of warships from British and European shipyards , first ironclads an[MASK] later armored cruisers . These[MASK]ships engaged the Chinese Beiyang fleet which was superior on paper at least at the Battle of the Yalu River . Thank[MASK] to superior short @-@ range firepower , the Japanese fleet came off better , s[MASK]nking or severely damaging eight ships and receiving serious damage to only four . The naval war was conc[MASK]uded the next year at the Battle of Weihaiwei , where the strongest remaining Chinese ships were [MASK]u[MASK]rendered to the Japanese . 
 
 = = End of [MASK]he ironclad warship = = 
 
 There is no clearl[MASK] defined[MASK]end to the ironclad , besides the transition from wood hulls to all @-@ metal . Ironclads continued to be used in World War I. Towards the end of t[MASK]e 19th century , the descriptions ' battleship ' and ' armored cr[MASK]iser ' came to replace the term ' ironclad ' . 
 The proliferation of ironc[MASK]ad battleship designs came to an end in the 1890[MASK] as navies reached a consensus on the design of battleships , producing the [MASK]ype known as the pre @-@ Dreadnought . These ships are sometimes covered in treatments of the iro[MASK]clad warship . The next evolution of battleship design , the dreadnought , is n[MASK]ver r[MASK]ferred to as an ' ironclad ' . 
 Most of the ironclads of the 1870s and 1880s served into[MASK][MASK]he 1900s ( decade ) . For instance , a handful o[MASK] US navy monitors laid down in [MASK]h[MASK] 1870s [MASK]aw active service in World War I. Pre @-@ Dreadnought battleships and cruisers o[MASK] th[MASK] 1890s saw widespread[MASK]action in World War I and in some cases through to World War [MASK]I .

Wells , in his short story The L[MASK]nd Ironclads , published in T[MASK]e Strand Magazine in December[MASK]1903 , described the use of large , armoured cross[MASK]@-@ country vehic[MASK]es , armed with cannon and machine guns , and equipped with pedrail wheels

 = Little Gidding ( poem ) = 
 
 Little Giddi[MASK]g is the fourth and final poem of T. S. Eliot 's Four Quartets , a series of poems that[MASK]di[MASK]cuss time , perspect[MASK]ve , humanity , and salvation . It was first published in September 1942 after being delayed for over a year because of the air @-@ raids on Great Britain during Wor[MASK]d War[MASK]II a[MASK]d Eliot 's declining health . The title refers to a small Anglican community in Huntingdonshire , established by Nicholas Ferrar in the 17th century and scattered during the English Civil War . 
 The po[MASK]m uses the combined image of fire and Pentecos[MASK]al fire to[MASK]emphasise the[MASK]need for purification and purgation . According to the poet , humanity 's flawed unders[MASK]anding of life and turning away from God leads to a cycle of warfare , but this[MASK]can be ov[MASK]rcome by recognising the [MASK]essons of the past . With[MASK]n the poem , the narrator meets a ghost that is a combination of various poets and literary figures . Litt[MASK]e Gidding focuses on the unity of past , present , and future , and claims that understanding this unity is necessary for salvation . 
 
 = = Background = = 
 
 F[MASK]llowing the completion of the third Four Quartets poem , The Dry Salvages , Eliot '[MASK] health declined and he stayed in Shamley Green , Surrey while he recovered . During this time , Eliot started writing Li[MASK]tle Gidding . The first draft was completed in July 1941 but he was dissatisf[MASK]ed with it . He believed the problems with the poem lay with his own inability to write , and that , precipitated by air raids on London , he had started the poem with too little preparation and had written it too quickly . After the first dr[MASK]ft was written , he set the poem aside , and he left in September to lecture throughout Great Britain . 
 Aft[MASK]r months of not working on the poem , Eliot began to feel compelled to finish it ; it was n[MASK]t until August 1942 , h[MASK]wever , [MASK]hat he started working on i[MASK] again . In total , there were five drafts . The poem was finished by 19 September 1942 and published in the October New English Weekly . Little Gidding was intended to conclude the Four Quartets series , summarising Eliot 's views expressed in this series of poems . 
 Little Gidding wa[MASK] the home of an Anglican community established in 16[MASK]6 by Nicholas Ferrar . The F[MASK]rrar household lived a Chris[MASK]ian life according to High Church principles and the Book of Common Prayer . The religious community was dispersed during the English Civil W[MASK]r between Parliamentarians and Royalists but reformed , ending wi[MASK]h the death of John Ferrar in 1657 . [MASK]liot had visited the site in May 1936 . 
 Unlike [MASK]he other locations mentioned in the titles of the F[MASK]ur Quartets poems , Eliot had n[MASK] direct connecti[MASK]n to the original Christ[MASK]an community . As such , the community [MASK]s supposed to represent almo[MASK]t any religious community . 
 
 = = [MASK]oem =[MASK]= 
 
 Critics classify Little Gidding as a poem of fire with an emphasis on purgation and the Pentecostal fire . The beginni[MASK]g of the poem discusses time an[MASK] winter , with attention paid to the arrival of summer . The images of sno[MASK] ,[MASK]which provoke desires for a spiritual life , transiti[MASK]n into an analysis of the four classical [MASK]lements of fire , earth , air and water and how fire is the primary element of the four . Following this is a discussion on death and destruction , things unaccomplished , and regret for past eve[MASK]ts . [MASK] While using Dante 's terza rima style , the poem continues by describing t[MASK]e Battle of Britain . The image of warfare merges with the depiction of Pentecost , and the Holy Spirit is juxta[MASK]osed with the air @[MASK]@ raids[MASK]on London . In the second section , a ghost , representing the poets of the past [MASK]tuck between worlds , begins talking to the narrator of the poem . The ghost discusses change , art[MASK]in general , and how humankind is flawed . The only way to overcome [MASK]he problematic condition of humanity , according to the ghost , [MASK]s to experience purgation through fire [MASK][MASK]The fire is described in a manner similar to Julian of Norwich 's writing about God 's love and discussed in relationship to the shirt of Nessus , a shirt that burns its wearer . Little Gidding continues by describing the eternalne[MASK]s of the present and how history exists in a patte[MASK]n . The poem concludes by explaining how sacrifice is needed[MASK]to allow an individua[MASK] to die into life and be reb[MASK]rn , and that salvation should be the goal of humankind . 
 
 = = Themes = = 
 
 In terms of renewal , Eliot believed that suffering [MASK]as needed for all of [MASK]ociety befor[MASK] new life could begin . The original Little Gidding community was built for living on monastic lines , but the community was damaged and dispersed by Puritan forces during the English Civil War[MASK]in 1646 . The church , the centre of the community , [MASK]as restored in 1714 and again in 1853 . The ima[MASK]e of reli[MASK]ious renewal is combined with the image of the London air @-@ raids a[MASK]d the constant fighting and destruction withi[MASK] the world . This c[MASK]mpound image is used[MASK]to discuss the connecti[MASK]n of holy places with the Holy Spirit , [MASK]entecost , communi[MASK]n with[MASK]the d[MASK]ad , and the repetition of history . Th[MASK] theme is also internal to Eliot 's own poems ; the image of the rose garden at the end Little Gid[MASK]ing is the image that begins Burnt[MASK]Norton and the journey is made circular . Also [MASK] the depiction of time within the poem is s[MASK]milar [MASK]o the way time operates within The Family Reunion . [MASK] Like the other poems making up the Fou[MASK] Quartets , Litt[MASK]e Gidding deals with the past , present , and future[MASK], and humanity 's place within them as each generati[MASK]n is seemingly united . In the second section , there is a ghost who is t[MASK]e compilation o[MASK] various poets , including Dante , Swift , Yeats , and others . When the ghost[MASK]joins the poet , the narrator states " Knowing myself yet [MASK]eing someone other " . This suggests that the different times merge at the same time that the different personalities[MASK]begin to merge [MASK] allowing a communicati[MASK]n and connection with the dead . Later , in the fourth section , humanity is given a choice between the Holy Spirit or the bombing [MASK]f London ; [MASK]edemption or dest[MASK]uction . God 's love allows humankind to be redeemed and escape the living hell throu[MASK]h purgation by fire . The end of the poem describes how Eliot has attempted to help th[MASK] world as a poet . He parallels his work in language with working on the soul or working on society . 
 The ghost[MASK], a combination of many liter[MASK]ry figures , was origina[MASK]ly addressed in the poem as " Ser Brunetto " before being revised as an amb[MASK]guous " you " . " Ser Brunetto " was Dante 's way of [MASK]ddressing Brunetto Latini , a former mentor whom he meets in Hell to which he has been condemne[MASK] for sodomy . Eliot , in a let[MASK]er to John Hayward dated 27 August 1942 , explained why he changed the wording : 
 I think you will recognise that it was necessary to get rid of [MASK]runetto for two reasons . The first is that the v[MASK]sionary figure has now become somewhat more definite and will no doubt be identified by some readers with Yeats though I do not mean anything so precise as that . Howev[MASK]r , I do not wish to tak[MASK] the responsibility of putting Yeats or anybody else into Hell[MASK]and I do not want to impute to [MASK]im the particular vice which took Brunetto there . Secondly , although the reference to that Canto is intended to be explicit , I wish the effect of the[MASK]whole[MASK]to be Pu[MASK]gatorial wh[MASK]c[MASK] is more appropriate . That brings u[MASK] to the reference to swimmi[MASK]g in fire which you will remem[MASK]er at the end of Pur[MASK]atorio 26 where the poet[MASK] ar[MASK] found[MASK]. 
 The theme of swimming through flames is connected to the depiction [MASK]f Guido Guinizelli , a poet that [MASK]nfluenced Dante , seeking such a state in Purgatorio XXVI . However , the depiction of swimming was transformed into an image [MASK]f dancing , an act that appear[MASK] throughout Yeats 's poetry , within purgatori[MASK]l [MASK]lames . The critic Dominic Manganiello suggests that , in combining the image[MASK]of dancing with purgation , Eliot merges Dante 's and Y[MASK]ats 's poetic themes . 
 
 = = Receptio[MASK] = = 
 [MASK] Critics such as Malcolm Cowley and Delmore Schwartz describe m[MASK]xed emotions about the religiosity of the poem . Cowley emphasised the myst[MASK]cal nature of the poem and how its themes were closer to Buddhism than Angli[MASK]anism while mentioning his appreciation of many of the passages . Schwartz also mentioned the Buddhis[MASK] images an[MASK] his admiration for many of the lines in Little Gidding . F. B. Pinion believed that the fourth section of the poem costs " Eliot[MASK]more trouble and vexation than any passage of the same [MASK]ength he ever wrote , and is his g[MASK]eatest achievement in the Four Quartets . " E. M. Forster did [MASK]ot like Eliot[MASK]'s emphasis on pain and responded to the poem : " Of[MASK]course there 's[MASK]pain on and off through each individual '[MASK] life ... You can 't shirk it[MASK]and so on . But why should it be endorsed by the schoolmaster and sanctified by t[MASK]e priest until the fire and the rose [MASK]r[MASK] one when so much[MASK]of it is caused by disease and bullies ? It is here that Eliot becomes unsatisfactory [MASK]s a seer . " Writing in 2003 , Roger Scruton wrote that in " Little Gidding " Eliot achieved " that for which he envies Dante — namely , a poetry [MASK]f belief , in w[MASK]ich belief and words are one , and in which the thought cannot be prized free from the controlled and beautif[MASK]l language " . 
 
 
 = The Portage to San Cristobal of A.H. = 
 
 The Por[MASK]age to San Cristobal of A.H. is a 1981 literary and philos[MASK]phical novella by[MASK]George Steiner , in which Jewish Nazi hunters find a fictional Adolf Hitler[MASK]( A.H. ) alive in the Amazon jungle thirty years after[MASK]the end of World War II . The book generated considerable co[MASK]troversy af[MASK]er its publication bec[MASK]use in it , Steiner , who is Jewish , allows Hitler to defend himself when he is put on trial in the jungle by[MASK]his captors . There Hitler ma[MASK]ntains that Israel owes its existence to the Holocaust and tha[MASK] he is the " benefac[MASK]or of the Jews " . 
 The Portage to San Cristobal of A.H. was a 1983 finalist in the PEN / Faulkner Award [MASK]or Fiction . It was[MASK]adap[MASK][MASK]d for the theatre by Bri[MASK]ish playwright Christopher [MASK]ampton and was staged in London in April 198[MASK] with[MASK]Alec McCowen playing the part of Adol[MASK] Hitler . I[MASK] was also staged in Hartford , Conne[MASK]ticut in the United [MASK]tates i[MASK] 1983 and starred John Cullum as Hitler . 
 
 = = Plot summary = = 
 
 From his base in Tel Aviv , Holocaust survivor Emmanuel Lieber directs a group of Jewish Nazi hunters in search[MASK]of Adolf Hitler . Lieber believ[MASK]s that the former Führer is still alive , and following rumours and hearsay [MASK] he tracks Hit[MASK]er 's movements through South America , until after months of wading through swamps in the Amazon jungle , the search party finds the 90 @-@ year @-@ old alive in a clearing . Lieber flies to San Cristóbal where he awaits the group 's return with their captive . But [MASK][MASK]tting the old man out of the jungle alive is more difficult than getting in , and their progres[MASK] is further hampered by heavy thunderstorms . 
 Meanwhile , broken and incoherent radio messages between Lieber and the sea[MASK][MASK]h party are intercepted by intelligence agents trac[MASK]ing thei[MASK] progress , and rumours begin[MASK]to spread across the world of Hitler 's capture . Debates flare up over h[MASK]s impending trial , where it will be held a[MASK]d under whose jurisdiction . O[MASK]osso is identified as the nearest ai[MASK]field to[MASK]the last known location of the search[MASK]party , and aircr[MASK]ft begin arriving at the hitherto unknown town . But when the search part[MASK] loses radio contact with Lieber , they must make a d[MASK]cis[MASK]on : d[MASK] they sit out the storms and deliver their captive to Lieber later , or do they try Hitler in the jungle before their prize is snatched from them by the world at large , who they know will be waiting ? Their decision is the latte[MASK] , and against Lieber 's advice ( " Y[MASK]u must[MASK]not let him speak ... his tongue is like no other " ) they prepare fo[MASK] a trial wit[MASK][MASK][MASK] judge , prosecution and defence[MASK]attorneys selected from the members of th[MASK] search party . Teku , a local Indian tracker , is asked to observe the trial as an independent witness . 
 The attention Hitler is rec[MASK]iving , however , renews his strength , and when the trial begins , he brushes aside his " defence attorney " and begins a long speech in four parts i[MASK] his own defence : 
 Firstly , Hitler claims he took [MASK]is doctrines from the J[MASK]ws and copied the not[MASK]on of the master race from the Chosen people and their need to separate themselves from the " unclean " . " My racism is a parody of yours [MASK] a hungry imitation . " [MASK] Hitler justifies the Final Solution by maintaining that the [MASK]ews ' God , purer than any othe[MASK] , [MASK]nslaves its subjects , continually demanding more than they can give and " blackmailing " them with ideals that [MASK]annot be attained . The " virus of utop[MASK]a " had to be stopped . 
 Hitler states that he[MASK]was not the origin[MASK]tor of evil . " [ Stalin ] had perfected genocide when I was still a[MASK]nameless scribbler in Munich . " Further , Hitler asserts that t[MASK]e [MASK]umber of lives lost due to his actions are dwarfed by various world atrocities , including those in Russia , China and Af[MASK]ica . 
 Lastly , Hitler maintains that the Reich begat[MASK]I[MASK]rael and suggests tha[MASK] he is the Messiah " whose infamous deeds were allowed by God in order to[MASK]bring His people[MASK]home . " He closes by asking , " Should you n[MASK]t honour me who have made ... Zion[MASK]a reality ? " 
 At the end of his speech , Teku is the first to react and jumps up[MASK]shouting " Proven " , on[MASK]y to be drowned out by the appearance of a helicopter over the clearing .

 = = Bac[MASK]ground [MASK]nd publication = = 
 
 George Steiner , literary critic for The New Yorker and The New York Times , had written about the Holocaust in some of his previous books , including Anno Domini ( 1964 ) , Language and Silence ( 1[MASK]67 ) and In Bluebe[MASK]rd 's Cast[MASK]e ( 19[MASK]1 ) . Many of the ideas Steiner expres[MASK]es in The Portage to San Cristobal of A.H. were reworke[MASK] from these earlie[MASK] works . Steiner told Ne[MASK] York Times editor D. J. R. Bruckner that this book [MASK]rose o[MASK]t of his lifelong work on language . " Cen[MASK]ral to everything I am and believe and [MASK]ave written is my astonishment ... that[MASK]you can use human speech both to bless , to love , to build[MASK], to forgive and also to torture , [MASK]o hate , to destroy and to annihilate[MASK]. " 
 Commenting on the controversy the book generated[MASK], Steine[MASK] adm[MASK]tted to literary journalist and critic Ron Rosenbaum ( author of Explaining Hitler ) that he too was disturbed b[MASK] it , adding that his fictional Hitler had gotten the better of him , " golem- or Frankenstein @-@ like " . He said that it felt like the[MASK]book " w[MASK]ote me " . Steiner also pointed out that t[MASK]e novella is not only about his thoughts on the Holocaust , but also about the horrific events that took place in countries like Cambodia , Vietnam , El Salvador and Burundi : " My feeling is that one has to grapple with the abyss if one can . " 
 [MASK]teiner wrote The Portage to San Cri[MASK]tobal of [MASK].H. in 1975 and 1976 in Geneva , Switzerland , and [MASK]he 120 @-@ p[MASK]ge work originally appeared in the Spring 1979 issue of t[MASK]e United States litera[MASK]y maga[MASK]ine , The Kenyon Review . It also appeared in the Spring 1980 issue of Granta , the British literary maga[MASK]ine . Its first publication in book form , with minor revisions by Steiner , was in May 1981 by Faber and Faber [MASK]n the United Kingdom — and as requested by Steiner , it was[MASK]a paperback original . The first United States edition was published in hardcover in April 1982 by Simon & Schuster . 
 
 = = Adaptati[MASK]ns = =
