In 1983 the production moved to the United Stat[MASK]s where it played at the Hartford Stage Company in Hartford , Connecticut , directed by Mark Lamo[MASK] and starr[MASK]ng John Cullum a[MASK] Hitler . 
 This book is the only work of fiction [MASK]y Steiner to have been adapte[MASK] for the stage . 
 
 = = Reception =[MASK]= 
[MASK]
 Reaction to The Portage to San Cristobal of A.H. was mixed . Anthon[MASK] Burgess in The Observer called it " astonishing " , Christopher B[MASK]oker of The Daily Telegraph described it as [MASK] " powerful piece " , and English author A. S. Byatt said it was a " masterpiece " . In Explai[MASK]ing Hitle[MASK] , Ron Rosenbaum called The Portage " A Frankenstein story " , referring to Steiner 's ficti[MASK]e Hitler has having taken on a [MASK]ife of its own . Writing in Time maga[MASK]ine , Otto Friedrich described the book " a philosophic fantasy of remarkable intensity " , adding t[MASK]at by not refuting Hitler 's speech , Steiner deviates from the horrors of traditional Holocaust literature and ends the[MASK]book [MASK] [MASK]n a note of bleak ambiguity " . 
 Morris Dickstein of The New York Times was[MASK]more cri[MASK]ical of the book , calling it " a misconceived and badly executed novel , a sid[MASK]show distrac[MASK]ion from the serious business of thinking through[MASK]the [MASK]nspeakable horrors of the Nazi era . " [MASK]e described it as " wearisome " that is " suffocate [ d ] " by too much " fine writing " ( belles @-@ lettres ) . He[MASK]also complained[MASK]that the characters are lifeless , and while they each have detailed histories , they are only " verb[MASK]l figments " that do not separate them from one another . Finally Dickstein noted that because almost all the points of Hitler '[MASK] speech are drawn from som[MASK] of Stei[MASK]er 's ear[MASK]ier works , he " unwitting[MASK]y creates sym[MASK]athy for Hi[MASK]ler by making him old and pathetic yet also lucid and brilliant — at once absurdly harmless and u[MASK]convincingly dangerous . " 
 In another[MASK]review in The New[MASK]York Times John Leonard wrote that while the book has[MASK]its[MASK]strong points , " some wit , a catho[MASK]ic disdain , mu[MASK]tiplicity of character and a [MASK]outh American swamp @-@ life that terrifies " , its [MASK]eaknesses [MASK]re that " the characters are really ideas , ... the symbols clash a[MASK]d there are too many echoes of better books by Kafka and Proust " .[MASK]But Leonard 's bi[MASK]gest cri[MASK]icism of the book was Hitler 's speech , which he called " obscene " , and Steiner 's decision to end th[MASK] book at that point , which Leonard sai[MASK] " not only denies the power of art to arrange and transcend [MASK] but ... makes me sick to my [MASK]tomach . " 
 Writing in the American li[MASK]erary magazine Salmagundi , A[MASK]vin H. Rosenfe[MASK]d called The Por[MASK]age a " breakthrou[MASK]h w[MASK]rk " that " a[MASK]tonishes [MASK] . He was struck by the book 's interplay between the landscape of swamp and jungle , and the " landscape of speech " — the former being " brilliantly registered " with its " immense feeling of physicality " , and the lat[MASK]e[MASK] , " e[MASK]en more dramatic " in the way it exposes " the da[MASK]k underside of words " and how its use a[MASK]d misuse rev[MASK]als the t[MASK]ue nature of a person . He was particularly impressed by the depiction of Nazi h[MASK]nter Emmanuel Lieber and his role as representative of the Jewish consciousness . Rosenfeld noted that while Holocau[MASK]t literature often ei[MASK]her[MASK]soars to " expostulation and ap[MASK]strophe " , or sinks to " a dwindling sob of eleg[MASK]ac lament " , Steiner 's Lieber " m[MASK][MASK]iates b[MASK]tween the[MASK]e two extremes , .[MASK]. simultaneously records and mourns , coldly enumerates yet carries [MASK]n immense affect " . What did concern the reviewer , however , was the way Steiner used ideas from his earlier works , that he had put them " virtu[MASK]lly verbatim " into [MASK]itler 's mouth , creating the impression that " Steiner 's understanding of Hitler were identical with the latter 's self @-@ understanding " . Ros[MASK]nfeld also quest[MASK]oned why the book had to end with Hitler 's speech . He said that Steiner 's fictive Hitler plays " the devil 's game of language subversion " , making " madness [ sound ] like music " , something the real Hitler had perfected . By sto[MASK]ping at this po[MASK]nt , Rosenfel[MASK] felt that Steiner " succumb [ s ] , rhetorically , [MASK]o the seduct[MASK]ve eloquence of negation " , which undermines his own " high standards of moral intelligence " . But overall Rosenfeld said[MASK]The [MASK]ortage " mus[MASK] be cou[MASK]ted among the most vigorous attempts to portray the [MASK]resence and meaning of Hitler " , forcing us to confront him " in a[MASK]way hardly seen before in fiction " . 
 The Po[MASK]tage to San Cristobal of A.H. was a finalist [MASK]n the 1983 PEN / Faulkner Award for Fiction . 
 
 = = Controversy = = 
 
 The bo[MASK]k generated considerable controversy because of its apparent " admiration for Hitler " . The controversy grew further when the faithful stage adaptation ( " too faithful " , according to Steiner ) was p[MASK]rformed in the United Kingdom and the United[MASK]States . 
 Hitler 's speech at the end of the book disturbe[MASK] many readers and critics . Steiner not only[MASK]lets[MASK]Hitler justify his past , he allows him t[MASK]e ( almost ) last word before the outside [MASK]orld invades . The fact that Steiner is Jewish made this speech in particular eve[MASK] more contentious . [MASK]ne critic , while acknowledging that Steiner always saw Hitl[MASK]r as " the inc[MASK]rnation of unprecedented and unpa[MASK]alleled evil " , felt that there was no clear[MASK]distinction in the book between Steiner 's own views and those of his fictional Hitler , even going so far as to accuse Steiner , who rejects Jewish nationalism and is a critic of Israel 's treatment of the Palestinians , of anti @-@ Semitism . 
 In contrast , a Time magazine article at the time felt that Steiner 's intention for the Hitler speech was to use it to explore his previously stated belief " that Hi[MASK]ler wielded language as an almost supernatura[MASK] force " , drawing attention to Nazi hunter Emmanuel Lieber 's warning from the book regarding Hitler : " There shall come a man who ... will know the grammar of hell and teach it to others [MASK] He [MASK]ill know the sounds of madness and loathing and make them seem music . " 
 Steiner responded to criticism that Hitler 's speech in this book is unchallenged by saying th[MASK]t it[MASK]had [MASK]een done before : for exa[MASK][MASK]le Satan 's speech in Milton 's Paradise Lost ( 1667 ) , and The Grand Inquisitor 's speech in Dostoyevsky 's The Brothers Karamazov ( 1880 ) . He also reminded the reader that Hitler 's speech is balanced out earlier in the book by Lieber 's long monologue on the horrors of the Holocaust [MASK] Finally , Steiner said that his Hitler ( A. H. ) is " a fictive figure " , and that it is no[MASK] [MASK]e who has the last word , but Teku , the Indian tracker , who shouts " Proven " . Teku is also the Hebrew word used to indicate t[MASK]at " there are issues here b[MASK]yond our wisdom to answer or decide . " 
 
 
 = Temnospondyli = 
 
 Temnospondyli ( from Greek τέ[MASK]νειν ( temnein , " to cut " ) and σπόνδυλος ( spondylos , " vertebra [MASK] ) ) is a divers[MASK] subclass of extinct small to [MASK]iant tetrapods — often c[MASK]nsidered primitive amphibians — that flourished world[MASK]ide during the Carboniferous , Permian , and Triass[MASK]c periods . A few species continued into the Cretaceous . Fossils have been found on e[MASK]ery continent . During about 210 million years of evolutionary history , they ada[MASK]ted to a wide range of habitats , incl[MASK]ding fresh wat[MASK]r , terrestri[MASK]l , and even coastal marine environments . Their life history is well understood , with fossils kn[MASK]wn from the larval stage[MASK], metamorphosis , and maturity . Most temnospondyls were semiaquatic , although some were almost fully terrestrial , returning[MASK]to the water only to breed . Th[MASK]se temnospondyls were some of the first vertebrates fully adapted to life on land . Although [MASK]emnospondyls are considered amphi[MASK]ians ,[MASK]many had chara[MASK]te[MASK]istics , such as scales , claws , and ar[MASK]our @-@ like bony plates , that distinguish them from modern amphibians . 
 Temnospondyls have been known since the early 19th century , and we[MASK]e initially thought to be reptiles . They were described at various times as b[MASK]trachians , stegocephalians , and labyrinthodonts , although these names are now rarely used . Animals now grouped in Temnospondyli were spread out amo[MASK]g several amphibian groups until the early 20th century , when they were f[MASK]und to belong[MASK]to a distinct taxon based on the structure of thei[MASK] vertebrae . Temnospondyli means " cut vertebrae " , as each vertebra is divided into several parts . 
 Experts disagree over whether temnospondyls were ancestral to moder[MASK] amphibians ( frogs , salamanders[MASK], and ca[MASK]cilians ) , or whether the[MASK]whole group died out without lea[MASK]ing any descendants . Different hypoth[MASK]ses have placed modern amph[MASK]bians as the desce[MASK]dants of temnospondyls , another group of early [MASK]etrapods called lepospondyls , or even as descendants of [MASK][MASK]th groups ( with caecilians evolving from lepospondyls and frogs and salamanders evolving from temnospondyls ) . Recent studies [MASK]lace a family of temnospondyls called the amphibamids [MASK]s the closest relatives [MASK]f modern amphibians . Similarities in teeth , skulls , and hearing structures link th[MASK] two groups . 
 
 = = Description = [MASK] 
 
 Many temnospondyls are mu[MASK]h[MASK]larger than living amphibians , and superficially resemble crocodiles . Others are smaller[MASK]and resemble salamanders[MASK]. Most have bro[MASK]d , flat heads that are either blunt ([MASK]brevirostrine ) or elongated ( longirostrine ) . The skulls are rounded or [MASK]riangular in shape when viewed from above , and are usually [MASK]ov[MASK]red in pits and ridges . The rugged surfaces o[MASK] bones may have supp[MASK]rted blood v[MASK]ssels , which could transfer[MASK]carbon dio[MASK]ide to the b[MASK]nes to neutralize acidic build up in the blood ( early semiaquatic tetrapods would have had difficulty expelling carbon dioxide from their bodies wh[MASK]le on land , and these dermal[MASK]bones may have been an early solution to the problem ) . Many temnospond[MASK]ls also[MASK]have[MASK]canal @-@ like grooves in thei[MASK] skulls called sensory sulci . The sulci , which usually ru[MASK] around the nostrils and eye so[MASK]kets , are part of a lateral line system used to detect vibrations in water . As semiaquatic animals , most tem[MASK]os[MASK]ondyls have small limbs with four toes on each front foot and five on each hi[MASK]d foot . Terrestrial[MASK]temnospondyls have larger , thicke[MASK] limbs , and some even have claws . O[MASK]e unusual terrestrial temnospondyl , [MASK]ayella , has relatively long limbs for its body [MASK] and probably lived as an active runner able to chase prey . 
 Homologues o[MASK] most of the bones of temnospondyls are [MASK]ls[MASK] seen in other early tetrapods , aside f[MASK]om a few bones in the skull , such as interfrontals , internasals , an[MASK] [MASK]nterparietals , that have devel[MASK]ped in s[MASK]me temnospondyl taxa . Most temnospondyls have tabul[MASK]r horns in the b[MASK]cks [MASK]f their skulls , rounded projections o[MASK] bon[MASK] separated from the rest of the skull by ind[MASK]ntations called [MASK]tic notches ; in some temnospondyls [MASK] such [MASK]s Zatrachys , they are pointed and very prominent . Among the most distinguishing feat[MASK]res of temnospondyls are the interpterygoid vacuities , two large holes in the back of the palate . Another pair of holes , choanae , are present in front of these vacuities , and connect the nasal passage with [MASK]he m[MASK]uth . [MASK]emnospondyls o[MASK]ten have teeth on their palates , as[MASK]well[MASK]as in their jaws . So[MASK]e o[MASK] these teeth are so large , they are referred to as tusks[MASK]. I[MASK] some temnospondyls , such as Nigerpe[MASK]on , tusks in the lower jaw pierce the palate and [MASK]merge th[MASK]ough openings in the top of the skull . 
 Very little is known of the soft tissue of temnospondyls . A bl[MASK]ck of sandstone , described in 2007 from the Early Carboniferous Mauch Chunk Formation of Pennsylvania , included impressions of the bodies of three temnospondyls . These impressions show , when alive , they had smooth skin , robust limbs with webbed feet , and a ridge of skin on thei[MASK] undersides . Trackways referable to small temnospondy[MASK]s have also been found in Carboniferous and Permian rocks[MASK]. Th[MASK] trackways , [MASK]alled batr[MASK]c[MASK]ichni , are usually found in strata deposited around freshwater environments , suggesting the ani[MASK]als had some ties t[MASK] the water . 
 Unlike modern amphibians , many temnospondyls are covered in small , closely pac[MASK]ed scales . The undersi[MASK]es of most temnospondyls are covered in rows of l[MASK]rge ventral plates . During early stages[MASK]of deve[MASK]opment , they first have only small , rounded scales [MASK] Fossils show , as the animals grew , the scales on the[MASK]undersides of their bodies dev[MASK]loped into large , wide vent[MASK]al plates . The plates overlap each other in a way that allows a wide range of flexibility . Later semiaquatic temnospondyls , such as trem[MASK]tosaurs and capitosaurs , have no evidence of scales . They may have lost scales to make movement e[MASK]sier under water or to allow cutaneo[MASK]s respiration , the absorption of oxy[MASK]en throug[MASK] the skin . 
 Several groups of temnospondyls have large bony plates on their backs . One temnospondyl , Peltobatrachus , has armour @-@ li[MASK]e plating that covers both its back and underside . The temnospondyl L[MASK]idleria also has extensive plating on its back . Most memb[MASK]rs of the family Dissorophidae also [MASK]ave armo[MASK] , although it only covers the midline of the back with two[MASK]narrow rows of plates . Other temnospondyls , such as Eryops , have been found with small , disc @-@ like bony scutes that were in life probably embedded in the skin . All of these temnospond[MASK]ls were adapted to a terrestrial lifestyle . Armor may have offered[MASK]protection from predators in t[MASK]e case of Peltobatrachus . The scutes may h[MASK]ve provided stability for the[MASK]spine , as they would hav[MASK] limited flexibility[MASK]and may have been connec[MASK]ed by strong ligaments . Temnospondyls such as Sclerothorax and Eryops that may have been at least partly terres[MASK]rial also have long neural spines on to[MASK] o[MASK] their vertebrae that would have st[MASK]bilize[MASK] the spine . Bony s[MASK]utes are also seen in plagiosaurs , but [MASK]nlike Peltobatrachus , Laidleria , Eryops , and dissorophids , these animals are thought to have[MASK]been [MASK]ully aquatic . Plagiosaurs may have inherited t[MASK]eir armor from a terrestrial ancestor , as both Peltobatrachus and Laidleria have been considered c[MASK]ose relatives of the group . 
 Temnospondyls ' vertebrae[MASK]are divided into several segments . In li[MASK]ing tetrapods , the main body of the vertebra is a single[MASK]piece of bone called the centrum , but in temnospondyls , this region was divided into a pleurocentrum and intercentrum . Tw[MASK] types of vertebrae are recognized in temnospondyls : stereospondylous and rhachitomous vertebrae . In [MASK]hachitomous vertebrae , the intercentra are large and wedge @-@ shaped , a[MASK]d the pleurocentra are relatively small blocks that fit between them . Both elements support a spine @-@ like neural arch , and well @-[MASK] developed interlockin[MASK] projec[MASK]ions called zygapophyses[MASK]strengthen the connections between v[MASK][MASK]tebrae . The strong backbone and strong limbs of many ratchitomous temnospondyls allowed them to be partially , and in some cases fully , terrestrial . In stere[MASK]spondylous vertebrae , the pleurocentra have been lost entirely , with the intercentra enlarged as the main body o[MASK] the vertebrae . Thi[MASK] weaker type of backbone indicates the [MASK]tereospondylous t[MASK]mnospondyls spent more time in water . 
 
 = = History of study =[MASK]= 
 
 Temnospondyli was named by German palaeontologist Karl Alfred von Zittel in his second edition of Handbuch der[MASK]Palaeonto[MASK]ogie , published in [MASK]888 . Temnospondyl remains were known si[MASK]ce the early part of the 19th century , however . The e[MASK]rliest described temnos[MASK]ondyl was Mastodonsaurus [MASK] named by Georg Friedri[MASK]h Jaeger in 1828 . Jaeger named Mastodonsaur[MASK]s from a single toot[MASK] , and considered it a [MASK]eptile . Mastodonsaurus means[MASK]" breast tooth lizard " after the nipple @-@ like shape of the tip of the tooth . 
 The naming of these first speci[MASK]ens was disputed , however . Leo[MASK]old Fitzinger named the animal Batrachosaurus in 1837 . In 1841 , En[MASK]lish palaeontologist Richard Owen referred to the genus as Labyrinthodon to describe its highly folded or labyrinthine teeth . Owen thou[MASK]h[MASK] the name Mastodonsauru[MASK] " ought n[MASK]t to be retained , because it reca[MASK]ls unavoidably the idea of the mammalian genus Mastodon , or else a m[MASK]mmilloid form of the tooth ... and because the second element of the word , saurus , indicates a false affin[MASK]ty ,[MASK]the remains belonging , not to the[MASK]Saurian , but to th[MASK] Batrachian order of Reptiles . " Owen recognized the animal was not a " saurian " [MASK]eptile , y[MASK]t he also[MASK]referred Jaeg[MASK]r 's Phytosaurus to the genus . Although the two genera [MASK]oth have similarly sized conical teeth , Phytosaurus was later found to be a crocodile @-@ like re[MASK]tile . Additional material , including skulls , firmly placed Labyrinthodon as an amphibian . Jaeger also named Salama[MASK]droides giganteus[MASK]in 1828 ,[MASK]basing it on partial occiput , or [MASK]ack portion of the skull . In 1833 , he descr[MASK]bed a complete skull of S. gi[MASK]anteus that had the same teet[MASK] as his Mast[MASK]donsaurus , making it the first known complete skull of a temnospondyl . Because Mastodonsaurus was named first , it has precedence over the other names as a senior subjectiv[MASK] synonym . Batrachosaur[MASK]s is still used as the name of an unrelated brachyopid temnospondyl . 
 Mastodonsaurus and other similar ani[MASK]als were referred to as labyrinthodonts , named like Labyrinthodon for teeth that were highly folded in cross section . Owen 's " Labyrinthodon Jaegeri " was l[MASK]ter found a[MASK] Guy 's Cliffe , England[MASK]by paleontologist William Buckland . Other specime[MASK]s were found in the red s[MASK]ndstone of Warwickshire . As more fossils were uncovered in England , Owen depicted these labyrinthodonts as the " highest " form of batrachian and co[MASK]pared them to crocodiles , which he considered the highest form[MASK]of reptiles . He also noted the large labyrinthodonts of the Keuper ( a unit of rocks that dates to the Late Triassic ) were younger than more advanced reptiles in the Magnesian and Zechstein , which are Late Permian [MASK]n age . Owen used these [MASK]ossils to counter the notion that reptiles evolved from a[MASK]sequenti[MASK]l progression from earl[MASK] amphibians ( what he c[MASK]lled " metamorphosed fishes " ) . 
 In addition to Mastodonsau[MASK]us , some [MASK]f the earliest named genera included Metopias and Rhombopholis in 1842 , Zygosaurus in 1848 , Trematosaurus in 1849 , B[MASK]phetes and Den[MASK]rerpeton in 1853 , Capitosaurus in 1858 , and Dasyceps in 1859 . Baphetes is now placed as an early tetrapod outside Temnospondyli , [MASK]nd Rhombopholis i[MASK] now considered a prolacertiform reptile . 
 Later in the 19th century , temnospondyls were classi[MASK]ied as various members of Stegocephalia , a name coined by American paleontologist Edward Drinker Cope in 1868 . Cope placed stego[MASK]ephalians in the class Batrachia , the name then used for Amphibia . Stegocephalia means [MASK] roof @-@ headed " [MASK]n Greek , a reference to the wide , flat heads of temno[MASK]pondyls and other ea[MASK]ly tetrapods . During this time , palaeontologists considered temnospondyls to be amphibians because they possess[MASK]d three main f[MASK]atures : gi[MASK]l arches in juvenile skeletons , indicating they were amphibious for at leas[MASK] the first part of their[MASK]lives ; rib[MASK] that do not connect at the underside of the rib cage [MASK] and deep pits in the skull that were interpreted as space for mucou[MASK] glands . 
 Several suborders of stegoc[MASK][MASK]halians were recognized in the late 19th and early 20th centuries . Anim[MASK]ls now regarded as temnospondyls were primarily labyrinthodonts , but some we[MASK]e classified in the Branchiosauria . Branchiosaurs were small @-@ bodied and had simple conical teeth , while [MASK]aby[MASK]inthodonts were la[MASK]ger and had complex , [MASK]olded dentin and enamel in their tee[MASK]h . Branchiosauria included only a few forms , such as Branchiosaurus from Eur[MASK]pe a[MASK]d Amphibamus from North America [MASK] that had poorly developed bones , external gills , and no ribs . Some [MASK]keletons of Amphibamus were later found with long ribs , prompting its reassignment to Microsauria ( although more detailed studies found it to b[MASK] a temn[MASK]spondyl ) . Soft tissue , such as scales and external gills , were found i[MASK] many well @-@ preserved branchi[MASK]saur fossils fro[MASK] Germany . In the early 20th century , branchiosaurs would be recognized as larval forms of temnospondyls lacking many of the typical features that defin[MASK] the gro[MASK]p , and is no longer recognized as a distinct group . 
 Other animals that would later be class[MASK]fied as tem[MASK]ospond[MASK]ls were placed in a group[MASK]called Ganocephala , characterized[MASK]by plate @-[MASK] like skull bones , small lim[MASK]s , fish @-@ like scales , and branchial arches . Unlike labyrinthodonts , they did not have parietal for[MASK]mena , small holes in thei[MASK] skulls behind their[MASK]eye socket[MASK] . Archegosaurus[MASK], Dendrerpeton , Eryops and Trimerorhachis were placed in this group and were considered to be the most primi[MASK]ive members of Reptilia . Their rhachitomous vertebrae , notoc[MASK]ord , and lack of oc[MASK]ip[MASK]tal condyles ( which attached [MASK]he head to t[MASK]e n[MASK]ck )[MASK]we[MASK]e features that were also shared with fishes . Thus , they were considered a link between early fishes and [MASK]ore advanced forms such as stegocephal[MASK]an[MASK] . 
 Another g[MASK]oup called Microsauria was named by Cope in 1868 . Cope class[MASK]fied Micro[MASK]auria as [MASK] subgroup of Labyrinthodontia , placing many small , amphibian @-@ like a[MASK]imals within it[MASK]. Am[MASK]ng them were Dendrerpeton , once placed in Ganocephala . Dendrerpeton was later placed as a labyrinthodo[MASK]t with other temn[MASK]spondyl[MASK] , bu[MASK][MASK]c[MASK]nfusion existed for many years over the classification of small amphibians . 
 By the[MASK]end of the 19th century , most of what are today rega[MASK]ded as temnospondyls we[MASK]e placed in [MASK]he suborder Labyrinthodonta . American paleontologist Ermine Cowles Case called it Labyrinthodonta vera or " true labyrinthodonts " . The names Stegocephalia and Labyrinthodontia were used interchangeably to refer to the order in which it belonged . The labyrinthodontian suborders Microsauria and Branchiosauria , both of which contain t[MASK]mnospondyls , were distinct from Labyrinthodonta . [MASK][MASK]thin Labyrinthodonta were the groups Rhachitomi , Labyrinthodonti , and E[MASK]bolerimi . Members of Rhachitomi ,[MASK]such as Archegosaurus and Eryops , had [MASK]hachitomous vertebrae with enlarged inter[MASK]entra that displaced the pleuroce[MASK]tra . Labyrinthodonti , such as Mastodonsaurus , Trematosaurus , and Micropholis , had lost their pleurocentra , and the intercentra mad[MASK] up the entire body of the vertebra[MASK] . Embolerimi had intercentra and pleurocentra that were[MASK]of equal size . Embolomeres are now identified a[MASK] re[MASK]tiliom[MASK]rphs distantly related to temnospondyls . 
 In 1888 [MASK] von Zittel divided stegocephalians among thr[MASK]e taxa : L[MASK]pospondyli , Temnospondyli ,[MASK]and Stereospondyli . He placed micro[MASK]aurs in Lepospondyli , a group w[MASK]ich he characterized as having simple , spool @-@ shaped vertebral centra . Temno[MASK]pondyli included forms with the centra divided in[MASK][MASK][MASK]pleurocentra and intercentra . All members of Stereospondyli had amphicoelous centra composed only o[MASK] the intercentra . Cope objected to von Zittel 's classification , considering the vertebrae of[MASK]lepospondyls and stereospondyls indistinguish[MASK]ble because eac[MASK] had a si[MASK]ple spool shape [MASK] He continued to use Ganocephala and L[MASK]b[MASK]rinthodonta ( which he alternative[MASK]y referred to as Rhachitomi ) [MASK]o distinguish animals[MASK]based on the absence or presence of occipital condyles . 
 Temnospondyli beca[MASK]e a commonly used name at the turn of the century . Paleontologists inc[MASK]uded both embolomeres and rhachitomes in the group . Cope 's Ga[MASK]ocephala an[MASK] Labyrinth[MASK]donta fell out of use . In 19[MASK]9 , British paleontologist D. M. S. Watson proposed tha[MASK] the evolutionary hi[MASK]tory of these large amphibians could be seen through changes in their vertebrae . Embolomerous forms in[MASK]the Carboniferous graded into rhachitomous forms in the Permian , and finally into stereospondyls in the Triassic . More importa[MASK]tly , Watson began using the term Labyrinthodontia to refer to these groups . T[MASK]e name Temnospondyli was rarely used in the decades that[MASK]followed . Swedish paleontologist Gunnar Säve @-@ Söderbergh removed embolomeres from the group , narrowing its scope to rhachitomes and stereospondyls . His classification of labyrinthodonts was[MASK]b[MASK]se[MASK][MASK]heavily on characteristics of the skull rather than the vertebrae . 
 Americ[MASK]n pa[MASK]eontologist Alfr[MASK]d Romer brought the name Temnospondyli back into use in the later 20th century . Säve @-@ S[MASK]derbergh used the name Labyrinthodontia in a [MASK]tri[MASK]t sense ( sensu stricto ) to refer to Rhach[MASK]tomi and Stereospondyli , ex[MASK]luding[MASK]Embolomeri .[MASK]Romer agreed with this classification , but used the name Temnospondyli to avoid confusion with Labyrinthodontia in its wid[MASK]r sense ( sensu lato ) . Unlik[MASK] modern temnospondyl classification , however , Romer included the p[MASK]imitive Icht[MASK]yostegalia in the group . 
 
 = = Evolutionary history = = 
 
 
 = = = Carboniferous and Early Permian = = = 
 
 Temnospondyls first appeared [MASK]n the Early Carbonifero[MASK]s around 330 [MASK]illion years ago [MASK] Mya ) . During the Carbonife[MASK]ous , temnospondyls included basal medium @-@ sized forms such as Dendrerpeton or large semiaquatic forms such as Cochleosaurus . Other , more derived temnospondyls , [MASK]uch as the amphibami[MASK]s , were smaller and more terrestrial . [MASK]hey rese[MASK]bled salamanders , and so[MASK]e taxa , such as the genus Branchiosaurus , even ret[MASK]ined external gil[MASK][MASK] like the modern @-@ day axolotl . During the latest Carboniferous and Early Permian around 300 Mya , several groups , such as the dissorophids and trematopids evolved strong , robust limbs and vertebrae and became adapted to life on land while others such as the er[MASK]opids , developed into large semiaquatic predators . The dvinosaurs , a grou[MASK] of small aquatic temnospondyls , evolved from terrestrial ancestors in the Late Carboniferous . 
 
 = = =[MASK]Late Permian = = = 
 
 During the Late Permian , increasing aridity and the[MASK]diversification of reptiles contrib[MASK]ted [MASK]nto a decline in terrestrial temnos[MASK]ond[MASK]ls , but semiaquatic and fully aquatic temnospondyls continued to flourish , including the large Melosaurus of Eastern Europe . Other temnospondyls , such as [MASK]rchegosaurids [MASK] developed long snouts and a close similarity to crocodiles [MASK] although they lacked the armor characteristic of the latter group . These temnospondyls included the largest known a[MASK]phibi[MASK]n , the 9 @-@ m @-@[MASK]long Prionosuchus of Brazil . 
 
 = = = Mesozoic = = =[MASK]
 
 As temnospondyls continu[MASK]d to flourish and diversify in the Late Permian ( 260 @.@ 4 - 251 @.@ 0 Mya ) , a major gro[MASK]p called Stereospondyli became [MASK]ore dependent on life in the water . The vertebrae became weak , the limbs small , and the skull large and flat , with the eyes facing upwards . During the Triassic peri[MASK]d , these animals d[MASK]m[MASK]nat[MASK]d[MASK]the freshw[MASK]ter ecosystems , evolv[MASK]ng in a range of both s[MASK]all and large forms . During the Early Triassic ( 251 @.@ 0 - 245 @.@ 0 My[MASK] ) one group of successful long @-@ snouted fish @-@ eaters , the trematosauroids , even adapted to a life in the sea , the only known amphibians to do so with the exception of t[MASK]e modern[MASK]crab @-@ ea[MASK]ing frog . Anoth[MASK]r group , the capitosauroids , included medium- and large @-@ [MASK]ized animals 2 @.@ 3 to 4 m ( 7 @.@ 5 to 13 @.@ 1 ft ) in length , with large a[MASK]d flat skulls that could be over a met[MASK]r long in the largest forms such as Mastodonsaurus . These animals spent most or all their lives in water as aqu[MASK]tic predators , catching the[MASK]r prey by a sudden opening of the upper jaw and sucking in fish [MASK][MASK] other small animals . 
 In the Carnian stage of the Late [MASK]riassic ( 228 @.@ 0 - 216 @.@ 5 Mya ) , capitosauroids were joined by the [MASK]uperficially very similar Metoposauridae . Metoposaurids are distinguished from capitosauroids by the positioning of their eye sockets near the front of their skull[MASK] .[MASK]Another group of stereospondyls , the plagiosaurs ,[MASK]had wide heads with exter[MASK]al gills , and adapted t[MASK] life a[MASK][MASK]the bottom of lakes a[MASK]d rivers . By this time , temnospondyls had become a common and widespread component of semiaquatic ecosystems . Some temnospondyls , such as Cryobatrachus an[MASK] Kryostega , even inhabite[MASK] Antarctica , which was covered in temperate forests at the time . 
 Triassic temnospondyls were often the dominant semiaquat[MASK]c animals in their environme[MASK]ts . Large assemblages of metoposaurs with hundreds of individ[MASK]als preserved together have been found in the southwestern Unit[MASK]d States . They have often been int[MASK]rpreted as mass death events caused by droughts in floodplain environments . Recent studies show[MASK]these dense assemblages were instead probably the result of currents accumulatin[MASK] dead ind[MASK]viduals in certain areas . These environments seem to have had little diversity , as they were inhabited almost exclusively by metoposaurs . 
 The [MASK]riassic @-@ Ju[MASK]assic extinction event around 199 @.@ 6 Mya led to the extinction [MASK]f most Mesozoic temnospondyls . The brachyo[MASK]oids[MASK]survived ,[MASK]a[MASK] well as a few capito[MASK]auroids and trematosauroids [MASK] Whil[MASK] the latter two groups soon became extinct , brachyopoids persisted and grew to large sizes during the J[MASK]rassic . Among brachyopoids , the b[MASK]achyopids flourished in China an[MASK] the chigutisaurids became common in Gondwana . The most recent known temnospondyl was the giant chigutisaurid K[MASK]olasuchu[MASK] , known from the Early Cretaceous of Australia . It survived in rift valleys that were too cold in the [MASK]inter for crocodiles that normally would have competed with them . Koolasuchus was one of the largest of the brachyopoids , with a[MASK] estimated weight of 500 kg ( 1 @,@ 100 lb ) . 
 
 = = Classification = = 
 
 [MASK]riginally , temnospondyls were classified according to the [MASK]tructure of the[MASK]r vertebrae . Early[MASK]forms , with compl[MASK]x vertebrae consisting of a number of sepa[MASK]ate elements , were placed in the suborder Rachitomi , and large Triassic aquatic forms with simpler[MASK]ver[MASK]ebrae were placed in th[MASK] suborder Stereos[MASK]ondyli . With t[MASK]e recent growth of phylogenetics , this clas[MASK]ification is no longer viable . The basic rhachi[MASK]omous condition is found in [MASK]any primitive te[MASK]rapods , and is not unique t[MASK] one group of temnospondyls . Moreover , the distinction between rhachitomous and stereospondylous vertebrae is not entirely clear . Some temnospondyls have rhachitomous , semirhachitomous , and sterospondylous vertebrae at different points in the same vertebral column . Oth[MASK]r taxa have in[MASK]ermediate morphologies that do not fit into any category[MASK]. Rachitomi is no longer recognized as a group , but Stereospondyli is still considered valid .  = = = Phylogeny[MASK]= = = 
 
 In one of the earliest phylogenetic analyses of the group , Gardiner ( 1983 ) recognized five char[MASK]cteristics that made Temnospondyli a clade : a bone at the back o[MASK] the skull , the parasphenoid , is connected to another bone on the underside of the skull , the pterygoid ; large openings called int[MASK]rpterygoid vacuities are present between th[MASK] pterygoids ; the stapes ( a bone invo[MASK]ved in hearing ) is[MASK]connected to the parasphenoid and projects upward ; the cle[MASK]thrum , a bone in the pectoral girdle , is thin ; and part of the vertebra called the interdorsal attaches to the neural arch . Addi[MASK]ional features [MASK]ere given by Godfrey et al . ( 1987 ) , including the contact between the postparietal and exoccipital at the bac[MASK] of th[MASK] skull , small projections ( uncinate processes ) on [MASK]he ribs , and a pelvic girdle with each side having a single iliac blade . These shared characteristics are called synapomorphies . 
 Temnosp[MASK]ndyls are placed as basal tetrapods in phylogenetic analyses , with their exac[MASK] positioning varying between studies . Depending on the classification of modern amphi[MASK]ians , they are either included in the crown [MASK]roup Tetrapoda or the stem of Tetrapoda . Crown @-@ group tetrapods are descendants of the most recent common ancestor of all living tetrapods and stem tetrapods are f[MASK]r[MASK]s that are outside the [MASK]rown group . Modern amphibians have rece[MASK]tly been suggested as descendants of temnospondyls , which wou[MASK]d place them within crown Tetrapoda . Below is a c[MASK]adogram from Ruta et al . ( 2003[MASK]) placing Temnospondyli within crown Tetrapoda [MASK] 
 Other[MASK]studies place modern [MASK]mphibians as the descendants [MASK]f lepospondyls and place temnospondyls in a more basal position within the stem of Tetrapoda . Below is a cladogram from Laurin and Reisz ( 1[MASK]99 ) placing Temnospondyli outside crown Tetrapoda : 
 Most phylogenetic [MASK]nalyses of temnospondyl interrelationships focus on individual f[MASK]milies . One of the first broad @-@ scale studies [MASK]f temnospondyl phylogeny was conducted by paleontologist Andrew Milner in 1990 . A 2007 study made a " supertre[MASK] " of all temnospo[MASK][MASK]yl families , combining the f[MASK]mily @-@ level trees of previous studies .  The most basal group of temnospondyls is the superfamily Edopoidea . E[MASK]opoids ha[MASK]e several primitive or plesiomorphic features , including a single occipital condyle and a bone called the inter[MASK]emporal that is absent in other temnospondyls . Edopoid[MASK] include the Late Carboniferous genus Edops and the family Coch[MASK]eosauridae . Dendrerpetontid[MASK]e has also been included in Edopoidea , and is the oldest known temnospondyl [MASK]amily . Balanerpet[MASK]n woodi is the oldest species , having been present over 330 milli[MASK]n years ago during the Viséan stage of the Early Carboniferous . Recent a[MASK]alyses place Dendrerpetontida[MASK] outside Edopoidea in a more derived position . Other [MASK]rimitive temnospondyls include Capetus and Iberospondylus . Saharastega and Nigerpeton , both described in 2005 from Niger , are also primitive yet come from the Late Perm[MASK]an . They are almost 40 million years younger than other basal temnospondyls , implying a long ghost lineage of species that a[MASK]e not yet known in the fossil record . 
 I[MASK] 2000 , paleontologists Adam Yates and Anne Warren produced a revis[MASK]d phylogeny of more derived temnospondyls , naming several [MASK]ew[MASK]cl[MASK]des . Two major clades [MASK]ere Euskeli[MASK] and Limnarchia . Euskelia includes the temnospondyls that were once ca[MASK]led rhachitomes and includes two subfamilies , the Dissorophoidea and [MASK]he Eryopoidea .[MASK]Dissorophoids include small ,[MASK]mostly terrestr[MASK]al temnospondyls that may be t[MASK]e ancestors of modern amphibians . Er[MASK]opoids include larger temnos[MASK]ondyls like Eryops . The second major clade , Limnarchia [MASK] includes most Mesozoic temnospondyls , a[MASK] well as some Perm[MASK]an groups . Within Limnarchia are the superfamily Archegosauroidea and[MASK]the most derived temnospondyls , the stereospo[MASK]dyls . 
 Yates and Warr[MASK]n[MASK]also named Dvinosauria , a clade[MASK]of[MASK]small aquatic temnospondyls from [MASK]he Carboniferous , Permian , and Triassic . They placed Dvinosauria within Li[MASK]narchia , but[MASK]mor[MASK] recent studies disagree on their position . For example , a 2007 [MASK]tudy places them even more basal tha[MASK] eus[MASK]elians , while a 2[MASK]08 study keeps them as basal limnarchians . 
 Within Stereospondyli , Yates and Warren erected two major clades : [MASK]apitosauria and Trematosauria . Capitosaurs include large semiaquatic temnospondyls like Mastodonsaurus with flat heads and eyes near the back of the skull . Trematosaurs include a diversity of temno[MASK]pondyls , including large marine trematosauroids , aquatic plag[MASK]osaurs [MASK] brachyopoids that survived into the Cretaceou[MASK] , and metoposauro[MASK]ds with eyes near the front o[MASK] their heads . In 2000[MASK], paleontologists Rainer Schoch and Andre[MASK] [MASK]ilner named a third major clade of stereospondyls , the Rhytidost[MASK]a . This group incl[MASK]ded more primitive stereospondyls that could not[MASK]be placed in e[MASK]ther Capitosauria or Trematosauri[MASK] , and included grou[MASK]s like Lydekkerinidae , Rhytidosteidae , and Brachyopoidea . While Capitosauria and[MASK][MASK]rematosauria are still widely used , Rhytidoste[MASK] is not often supported as a true clade in recent analyses . Rhytidosteids and [MASK]rachyopoids are now grouped with trematosaurians , but [MASK]ydekkerinids are sti[MASK]l consi[MASK]ere[MASK] to be a primitive family of stereospondyls . 
 A new phylogeny of temnospondyls was offered by paleontologist Rainer Schoch in 2013 . It supported many of the clades [MASK]hat were found by Yates and Warren[MASK], but it did not find s[MASK]pport for their division of derived stereospondyls into Euskelia and Limnarchia . Eryopids were found to be more [MASK]losely related to stereospondyls than to dissorophoids , which were grouped with dvi[MASK]osaurs .[MASK]The clade including Eryopidae [MASK]nd Stereospondyl[MASK]morph[MASK] was named Eryopiformes . In addition , Sc[MASK]och named the clade containing all temnosp[MASK]ndyls except edopoids Eutemnospondyli and reins[MASK]ated t[MASK]e name Rhachitomi for the clade containing [MASK]ll temnospondyls except edopoids and den[MASK]rerpetontids .  = = = Relationship to modern amphibians = = = 
 
 Modern amphibians ( f[MASK]ogs , salamanders , and caecilians ) are classif[MASK]ed in[MASK]Lissamphibia[MASK]. Liss[MASK]mphibians appear to have arisen in the Permian .[MASK]Molecular [MASK]lock estimates place the first lissamphibian in the Late Carb[MASK]niferous[MASK], but the first member of Batrachia ( frogs and salamanders , but no[MASK] caecilians ) is estimated to have appeared in the Middle Permian using the same technique . Using fossil [MASK]vidence , there are three main theories for the origin of modern amphibians . 
 One is that they evolved from dissorophoid temnospondyls . Another is that they evolved from lepospondyls , most likely the lysorophians . A third hypothesis is that caecilians descended from lepospondyls and frogs and salamanders evolved [MASK]rom dissorophoids . 
 Recently , the theory that t[MASK]mnospondyls wer[MASK] the ancestors of all lissamphibians has[MASK]gained wide support . The skull morphology of some small temno[MASK]pondyls has been compared to those[MASK]of modern frogs and [MASK]alamanders , but the presence of bicuspid , pedicellate teeth in small , paedomorphic or immature temnospondyls has be[MASK]n cited as the most convincing argumen[MASK] in favor of the temnospondyl origin of lissamphibian[MASK] . Seen in lissamphibians and many diss[MASK]rophoid temnospondyls , pedicella[MASK]e teeth have calcified tips and bases . During the de[MASK]elopment of most tetrapods , teeth begin to calcify at their tips . Calcification normally proceeds downward to the[MASK]base of the tooth , but calcification from the[MASK]tip stops abruptly in pedicellate teeth . Calcification resumes at the base , leaving an[MASK]a[MASK]ea in the center of the tooth uncalcified . This p[MASK]t[MASK]ern is seen in living amphibians and fossils . 
 The dissorophoid family [MASK]mphibamidae is thought to be most closel[MASK] relat[MASK]d to Lissamphibia . In 2008 , an amphibamid called Gerobatrac[MASK]us hott[MASK]ni was named [MASK]rom Texas and was nicknamed the " frogamander " for its frog @-@ like head and salamander @-@ like body . It was thought to be the most closely rel[MASK]ted temnospondyl to lissamphibians and was placed as the sister taxon of the group in a phylogenetic analysis . An[MASK]ther species of a[MASK]phibamid called Doleserpeton annectens is now thought to [MASK]e even more closely related to liss[MASK]mphibians . Unli[MASK]e Gerobatrachus , Doleserpeton w[MASK]s known since 1969 [MASK] and the presence of pedicellate teeth in its jaws has led some pal[MASK]ontologists to conclude soon after its naming that it wa[MASK] a relative[MASK]of modern amphibians . It was first described as a " protolissamphibian "[MASK], [MASK]nd the specific name annectens [MASK]eans " connecting " in reference to its inferred transitiona[MASK] position between[MASK]temnospondyls and lis[MASK]amphibians . The structure of its tympanum , a disk @-@ like membrane that funct[MASK]ons li[MASK]e an ear drum , is similar to that of[MASK]frogs and has also been used as evidence for a close relationship . Other[MASK]featu[MASK]es including [MASK]he shap[MASK] of t[MASK]e palate and the back of the skull , the short ribs , and the smooth skull surfa[MASK]e als[MASK] point to it being a cl[MASK]ser relative of lissamphibians than is Gerobatrachus .  = = Paleobiology = = 
 
 
 = = = F[MASK]eding = = [MASK] 
 
 Although the earliest temnospondyls were primarily semiaquatic , they had the ability to feed on land . Later , eryopoids and dissorophoids , some well adapted to terrestrial life , also fed on land . So[MASK]e e[MASK]yopoi[MASK]s became better adapted towar[MASK] life in water , and shifted their diets toward aquatic organisms . The first pr[MASK]marily a[MASK]uatic[MASK]feed[MASK]rs were archegosaurs in the Permian . Trematosaurs and capitosaurs became in[MASK]ependently aquatic a[MASK]d also returned to this type of feeding . 
 Most aquatic stereospondyls have flattened heads . When feeding , they probably opened their mouths by lifting their skulls ins[MASK]ead of lowering their lower jaws . The jaw mechan[MASK]cs of the plagiosaurid Gerrothorax is [MASK]ell known , and is one of the most highly adapted . Gerrothorax is thought to have lifted its skull to around 50 ° above horizontal through the flexing of t[MASK]e atlanto @-@ occipital joint between the occipital condyles of the skull and the atlas vertebra of the neck . As the skull is raised , the qua[MASK]rate[MASK]bone pushes forward and causes the lower jaw to protrude[MASK]outward . Other stereospondyls probably also lifted their skulls , but they are not as well adapted for s[MASK]ch movement . D.M.S. Wats[MASK]n was the first[MASK]to suggest skull lifting as a means of feedin[MASK] in te[MASK]nospondyls . He envisioned that[MASK]Mastodonsaurus , a m[MASK]ch larger temnospondyl than Gerroth[MASK]rax , was able to make the same movement . Paleontol[MASK]gist A.L. Panchen also supported the idea in[MASK]1959 , suggesting that Batrachosuchus also fed in this way . At the time it was thought t[MASK]at these temnospondyls lifted their heads with stron[MASK] jaw muscles , but[MASK]it is now thought that they us[MASK]d [MASK]arger muscles in the neck th[MASK]t were attached to the large pectoral girdle . Plagiosuchus , a close relative of Gerrothorax , also has a hyobranchial[MASK]skeleton that muscles may have attached to . Plagiosuchus has very small teeth and a large area for muscle attachment behind the skull , suggesting that[MASK]it could suction feed by rapidly opening its mouth . 
 Unlike semiaquatic temn[MASK]s[MASK]ondyls , terrestrial temnospondyls have skulls that are adapted for biting land @-@ living prey . The sutures between the bones of the[MASK]skull in the dissorophoid Phonerpeton are able to withstand a high degree of compression . Compres[MASK]ive forces would have been experienced when bi[MASK]ing down on prey . Earlier aquatic tetrapods and t[MASK]trapod ancestors differ from temnospondyls like Phonerpeton in that their skulls [MASK]ere also built t[MASK] withstand tension . This tension would have been experienced during suction feeding underwater . Temnospondyls like [MASK]honerpeton were among the first tetrapods that were al[MASK]ost exclusively terrestrial and fed by biting . 
 
 = = = Reproduction = = = 
 
 Temnospondyls , li[MASK]e all amphibians , reproduced in aquatic environments . Most tem[MASK]ospondyls pr[MASK]b[MASK]bly reproduced through e[MASK]ternal fertilization . Like mo[MASK]t living frogs , female temnospondyls wo[MASK]ld [MASK]ave laid masses of eggs in water while males released sperm to fe[MASK]tilize them . Several fossils were described from the Early Permian of Texas in 1998 that may be egg masses of dissorophoid temnospondyls . They were the first known[MASK]fossils of amphibian eggs . The fossils cons[MASK]st of small disks with thin membranes that are probably vitelline membranes and halo @-@ like areas surrounding them that [MASK]re most [MASK]ikely mucous coatings . They are attached to plant fossils , suggesting that the[MASK]e temnospondyls laid eggs on aquatic [MASK]lants much like moder[MASK] frogs . The mucous membranes sho[MASK] that the eggs were laid by amphibians , not fish ( their eggs lack mucous ) , but the type of amphibian that laid them cannot be kno[MASK]n because no body fossils are preserved with the eg[MASK]s . The eggs are thought to be from dissorophoids because they are likely t[MASK] be close relatives of mode[MASK]n amphibians , and probably had sim[MASK]lar reproductive stra[MASK]egies . They are also the most common[MASK]amphibians from the deposit in which the [MASK]ggs were found . 
 One[MASK]temnospo[MASK]dyl , the dvinosaur Trimerorhachis , may have brooded young in an area between[MASK]the gills cal[MASK]ed the pharyngeal pouch . Small bones belonging to y[MASK]unger Trimerorhachis individuals have [MASK]ee[MASK] found in these pouches . The livin[MASK] Darwin 's Frog is also a[MASK]mouth brooder and would be the closest modern analogue to Trimerorhachis if it cared for its young in this way . An alternative possibility is that Trimerorhachis was cannibalistic ,[MASK]eating it[MASK] young like many amphibians do today . I[MASK] this was the case , the bones of these [MASK]maller individua[MASK]s[MASK]were originally located in the throat and [MASK]ere pushed into the pharyngeal p[MASK]uch as the animal fossilized [MASK] 
 Body impressions of E[MASK]rly Carboniferous temnospondyls from Pennsyl[MASK]ania sugg[MASK]st that some terrestrial temnospo[MASK]dyls mated on land like some modern amphibians . They reproduced through internal fertilization rather than mat[MASK]ng in water . The presence of three individuals in one block of sandstone shows that the temnospondyls were grega[MASK]ious . The head of one individual rests under the tail of another in what may be a courtship display . Internal fertilization and similar cour[MASK]ship behavio[MASK] are seen in modern salamanders . 
 
 = = = Growth = = = [MASK] 
 While most types of temnospondyls are distingui[MASK]hed on t[MASK]e basis of features in mature specimens , sever[MASK]l are known [MASK]rom juvenile and larval specimens . Metamorphosis is seen in dissorophoids , eryopids , an[MASK] z[MASK]trachydids , with aquat[MASK]c larvae developing into adults capable of living on land . Several types of dissorophoids[MASK]do not fully [MASK]etamorphose , but retain featur[MASK]s of juveniles such as gills and small body size in what is known as neoteny . D[MASK]inosaurians and the plagiosaurid Gerrothorax were a[MASK][MASK]o neotenic because they retai[MASK]ed gills , but the[MASK] are only known[MASK]from adult specimens . 
 Te[MASK]nospondyl larvae are often d[MASK]stinguished by poorly developed bones[MASK]and the presence of a hyobranchial apparatus , a s[MASK]ries of bones that gills would attach to in life . However , some fully mature temno[MASK]pondyls also possess hyobranchial bones but di[MASK] not have external gills . A dense covering [MASK]f scales is also seen in larvae and adults . Major body changes occu[MASK] in metamorphosis , including the reshaping and strengthening of skull bones , the thickening of postcranial bones , and an increase in body size . [MASK] Temnospondyls like Sclerocephalus are known from both large adult specimens and small larvae , showing an extreme change in body shape . In these species , the shape and proportions of skull bones change in the early stages[MASK]of development . The ornamentation on the surface of the skull roof[MASK]also d[MASK]velops at this time . Small , regularly spa[MASK]ed pits are the first to form , followed by larger ridges . As development continues , the external gills disappear . Small t[MASK]eth [MASK]hat once covered the palate are lost . The postcranial skeleton do[MASK]s not develop at the same rate as the skull , with ossification ( the replacement of cartilage by bone ) happening more slowly . Vertebrae and limb bones are poorly develop[MASK]d , ribs an[MASK] fingers are absent in the early stages , and the scapulocoracoid and ischium are entirely absent through most of development . Once matur[MASK]ty is reached , mos[MASK] bones have fully formed and growth rate slows . The bones of some temnospondyls like Dutuitos[MASK]urus show growth marks , possibly an ind[MASK]cation that growth rat[MASK] varied with the change in seasons . Fossils of temnospondyls like Metoposaurus and Che[MASK]ider[MASK]eton show that individual[MASK] grew larger pa[MASK]t maturity . The oldest individuals usually have more pittin[MASK] on their skulls with deeper sulci [MASK] 
 One group of temnospondyls , the Branchiosauridae[MASK], is also known from larval specimens . Branchio[MASK]a[MASK]rids l[MASK]ke Branchiosaurus and Apateon are represented by many fossils preserving skin and external gills . An ent[MASK]re growth[MASK]series is exhibited in [MASK]he w[MASK]de range of sizes among specimens , but the lack of[MASK]terrestrially adapted adult forms suggests that these temnospondyls were neo[MASK]enic . Unlike other tem[MASK]ospondyls , their postcranial skeletons developed quickly but were still partly cartilaginous when fully mature . Adults likely had a[MASK] aquatic lifestyle similar to juveniles . Rec[MASK][MASK]tly , large specimens of Apateon grac[MASK]lis were described with [MASK]daptations toward a terrestrial lifestyle , indicating that not all branchiosaurs were neotenic . 
 While most temnospondyls are aquatic in early stage[MASK] of life , m[MASK]st meto[MASK]osaurids appear to have been ter[MASK]estrial in their juvenil[MASK] stage . Like ot[MASK]er Mesozoic temnospondyls , adult metoposaurids were adapted to a semiaquatic lifestyle . Their bones are not highly developed for movement on land . The cross [MASK]-@ sectional thickness of limb bones in adult metoposau[MASK]ids shows that they could not withstand the stre[MASK]s of terrestrial locomotio[MASK] . Juvenile individuals have[MASK]bones tha[MASK] are thick enough to withstand this stress , a[MASK]d co[MASK]ld probably move about on land . To maintain a terrestrial lifestyle , a temnospondyl 's limb b[MASK]nes would have to thicken with positive allometry , m[MASK]aning that they would grow at a greater rate than the rest of the body . This is not the case in metoposaurids , meaning that as their bodies grew larger they became less adapted toward a terrestrial lifest[MASK]le [MASK] 
 
 = = = Hearing = = = 
 
 Temnospondyls and ot[MASK]er early tetrapods have rounded otic notches in the back of the skull that project into the che[MASK]k region . In life , the otic notch would have been covered by a mem[MASK]rane called th[MASK] tympanum , which is seen[MASK]as a disk @-@ like area[MASK]in living frog[MASK] . The tympanum [MASK]s involved in hearing , and [MASK]s similar to the ea[MASK] drum of more advanced tetrapods . It wa[MASK] t[MASK]aditionally thought that the tympanum deve[MASK]oped very early in tetrapod evolution as a hearing organ and progre[MASK]sed to form the ear drum of amniotes . Thus , temnospondyls possessed a hearing system supposedly ancestral to that of living amphibians and reptiles . 
 Frogs and all other living tetrap[MASK]ds have a rod @-@ like bone called the stapes that aids in hearing by transferring vibrations from the ear drum — or homologous tympanum — to the inner ear . Temnospo[MASK]d[MASK]ls also have a stapes , which projects into the otic cavity . The stape[MASK] likely evolved from the hyomandi[MASK]ula of lobe @-@ finned fishes . The positioning of the stapes and the shape of [MASK]he otic region suggests that the tympani of temnospondyl[MASK] and frogs are homologous , but the[MASK]tympani of these amphibians are no longer consider[MASK]d homologous with the hearing syste[MASK]s of reptiles , birds , and mammals . Therefore , ear structures in temnospondyls were not anc[MASK]stral to those of all other tetrapods . [MASK] The ability of the tympanum and stapes to effectively transmit vibrations is called im[MASK]edance matchin[MASK] . Early tetrapods like tem[MASK]ospo[MASK]dyls have thick stapes with poor impedance matching , so it is now thought that they were not used for hearing . Instead , these thick stapes may have functioned to support the tissue that covers the otic notch . Early temnospondyls li[MASK]e Dendrerpeton could not hear airborne sound but would have been able to detect vibration in the ground . Later temnospondyls like Doleserpeton had otic re[MASK][MASK]ons adapted to hearing . Dolese[MASK]peton has a structure in the inner ear called the pe[MASK]ilymphatic du[MASK]t , which is also [MASK]ee[MASK] in[MASK]frogs and is associated with hearing . Its stapes is also a better transmitter[MASK]of sound . The hearing system of Doleserpe[MASK]on and related temnospondyls was able to detect airborne sound and may have been[MASK]ancestr[MASK]l to that of living amphibians .

 = Osbert de Bayeux = 
 
 Osbert de B[MASK]yeux ( floruit 1121 to 1184 ) was a medieval E[MASK]glish cleric and archdeacon in the Diocese of York . A relative of Thurstan , the Archb[MASK]shop of[MASK]York , Osbert probably owed his ecclesiastical positions to this relative . After Thurstan 's death , Osbert was opposed to one of[MASK]the candidates for the archbishopric , William fitzHerbert [MASK] and worked to secure fitzHerbert 's deposition a[MASK]d replacement by[MASK]Henry Murdac . After Murdac 's death in 1153 , Osbert tried to pre[MASK]ent the return of fitzHerbert , but these attempts were u[MASK]successful . When fitzHerbert died suddenly in 1154 , Osbert was accused of murdering the newly returned archbishop . Although he was nev[MASK]r convicted of the murd[MASK]r in either a secular or an ecclesiastical court , he was stripped of his clerical status and be[MASK]ame a layman before [MASK]158 . He died after 1184 , perhaps even after 1194 . [MASK] 
 = = Early life = = 
 
 Osbert was first mentioned in the hi[MASK]torical record between 1121 and 1128 when he appears in a charter , which althou[MASK]h likely a forgery , probably contains an authentic witness list . This document lists him as " Os[MASK]ert archdeacon " , which means that he pr[MASK]bably held the archdeaconry of Richmond . He wa[MASK] the nephew of [MASK]hurstan , who was Archbishop of York from 11[MASK]4 to 1140[MASK]. Presumably he owed his position as archdeacon to his uncle and was pro[MASK]ably appointed at a you[MASK]g age . A charter of Thurstan 's ,[MASK]dating t[MASK] around 1138 , na[MASK]es Osbert explic[MASK]tly as Thurstan 's nephew . 
 
 = = Opposition to William [MASK]itz[MASK]erbert = = 
 
 Osbert was opposed to the election of Willi[MASK]m fitzHerbert as Archbishop of York and s[MASK]pported William 's rival and successor [MASK]enry Murdac . Although he remai[MASK]ed a supporter of Murdac after 1147 , he did oppose [MASK]urda[MASK] 's interventions in Selby Abbey , where Murdac had deposed one abbot and appo[MASK]nted another . In 1153 , Osbert deposed Murdac 's choice as abbot of Selby and appointed another abbot . Originally , Osbert h[MASK]d supported Elias Paynel , Murdac 's choice for abbot , [MASK][MASK]t then changed his stance and helped with the dep[MASK]sition . 
 After M[MASK]rdac 's death in 1153 , Osbert was opposed to William 's return as archbishop , but was unsuccessful in his attempts to prevent William 's reappointment . Wil[MASK]iam died a week after his r[MASK]turn to York , however[MASK], and Osbert , alon[MASK] with Robert of Ghent , the Dean of York [MASK] secured the [MASK]uick election of the new archbishop , Roger de Pont L 'Évêque . 
 
 = = Poisoning accusations = = 
 
 Osbert was accused of murdering William , specifically by poisoning him through the com[MASK]union cha[MASK]ice . A fellow cleric , Symphorian ,[MASK]who had[MASK]been a chaplain of the deceased archbishop , bro[MASK]ght murder charges against Osbert . Sympho[MASK]ian obtained a hearing on the charges at [MASK] royal council presided over by King Stephen of England at Michae[MASK]mas in 1154 , b[MASK]t Stephen 's subseq[MASK]ent death prevented a resol[MASK]tion . Osbert attempted to have the trial switche[MASK] to an ecclesiastical court [MASK]nd was supported in his ef[MASK]orts by Arch[MASK]ish[MASK]p Theobald of Canterbury . A trial was finally [MASK]eld in 1156 and Osbert 's accuser did not produce any witnesses , but Osbert was unable to prove his innocence , prompting the transf[MASK]r of the case to a papal[MASK]court . No[MASK]record of any judgment exists[MASK], but Osbert apparently appeared before two popes , [MASK]drian IV and Alexand[MASK]r III . A furt[MASK]er ap[MASK]eal to the papal court was referred to papal judges @-@ delegate between 1175 and 1[MASK]80 . 
 The case attracted commentary by two contemporary writers . Jo[MASK]n of Salisbury , who was a secretary for Theobald , added i[MASK]formation about Osbert in a letter to Alexander III o[MASK] unrelated business . In the section of the letter , John pointed out to the pope[MASK]that no matter what others might say about Osbert[MASK], he had failed to secure othe[MASK] c[MASK]ergy willing to swear that he w[MASK]s innocent . Another contemporary , Gilbert Foliot , who was Bishop of Hereford , wrote to the pope to remind him that although Osbert 's accuser had offered to prove his accusatio[MASK]s by undergoing a trial by ordeal , this was essen[MASK]ially meaningless since c[MASK]non law forbade the clergy from the ordeal .

 Osbert had two sons , William de Bayeux and Turstin de Baius . Osbert was a be[MASK]efactor to a number of monaster[MASK]es , including Drax Priory , Pontefract Priory and Gisborough Priory . He also gave land[MASK]to a hospi[MASK]al in York [MASK]nd to the Templars and Hospitallers[MASK]. 
 
 
 = Dvorak technique = 
 
 The D[MASK]orak technique ( developed between 1969 and 1984 by Vernon Dvorak ) is a widely use[MASK] system to estimate tropical cyclone intensity [MASK] which[MASK]includes tropical depression , tropical storm , and hurricane / typhoon / intense tropical cyclone intensities[MASK]) based sole[MASK]y on visible and infrared satellite images . Within the Dvorak [MASK]atellite strengt[MASK] e[MASK]timate for tropical cyclones , there [MASK]re several visual patterns that a cyclone may take [MASK]n which[MASK]define the upper and lower bounds on its intensity . The primary patterns u[MASK]ed are curved band pattern ( T1.0 @-@ T4.[MASK] ) , shear pattern ( T1.5 @-@ T3.5 ) , [MASK]entral dense overcast ( CDO ) pattern ( T2.5 @-@ T5.0 ) , central cold cover ( CCC ) pattern , banding eye pattern ( T4.0 @-@ T4.5 ) , and eye pattern ( T4.5 - T8.[MASK] ) . 
 Both the central den[MASK]e overcast and embedded eye pattern use the[MASK]size of the CDO . The CDO pattern intensities start at T2.5 , equivalent to m[MASK]nima[MASK] tropical storm int[MASK]nsity ( 40 mph , 65 km / h ) . The shape[MASK]of the central de[MASK]se overcast is also considered . The eye pattern utilizes the coldness of the cloud tops within the surrounding[MASK]mass of thunderstorms a[MASK]d contrasts it with the temperature within the eye itself . The larger the t[MASK]mperature difference is , the stronger the tropical cyclon[MASK][MASK]. Once a patt[MASK]rn is[MASK]identified , the storm features ( such as length and curvature of banding features ) are further analyzed to arrive at a particular T @-@ number . The CCC p[MASK]ttern indicates litt[MASK]e development is occurring , despite the cold c[MASK]oud top[MASK] associated with the quickly evolving feature . 
 Several agencies issue Dvorak intensity[MASK]numbers for tropical [MASK]yclones and their precursors , including the National Hurricane Ce[MASK]ter 's Tropical Analysis and Forecast Branch ( TAFB ) , the NOAA / NESDIS Satellite Analysis Branch ( SAB ) , and the Joint Typhoon[MASK]Warning Center at the Na[MASK]al Meteorology and Oceanography Command in P[MASK]arl Harbor ,[MASK]Hawaii . 
 
 = = Evolution [MASK]f the method = = 
 
 The[MASK]initial development of this technique occurred in 1969 by Vernon Dvorak , using satellite pictures of tropical c[MASK]clones within the northwest Pacific ocean . The sys[MASK]e[MASK] as [MASK]t was initially conceived involved pattern matching of cloud features with a development and decay [MASK]odel . As the technique matured through the 1970s an[MASK] 1980s , measurement of clou[MASK] fea[MASK]ures became dominant in defining tropical cyclone intensity and central pressure of the tropical cyclone 's low @-@ pressure area . Use of i[MASK]frared satellite imagery led to a more objective assessment of the strength of tropical cyclones with e[MASK]es , using the cloud top temperatures within the eyewall and contrasting them with the warm temp[MASK]ratures within the eye itself . Constraints on short term intensity change are used less frequently than they were [MASK]ack in the 1970s and 1980s . The central pressures assigned to tropical cyclones have r[MASK]quir[MASK]d modification , as the original estimates were 5 @-@ 10 hP[MASK] ( 0 @.@ 15 @-@ 0 @.@ 29 inHg ) too low in the Atlantic and up to 20[MASK]hPa [MASK] 0 @.@ 59 inHg ) too high in the northwe[MASK]t Pacific . This led to the development of a separate wind @-@ pressure relationship for the northwest Pacific , devised by Atkinso[MASK] and Holliday in 1975 , then modified in 1977 . 
 As human [MASK]nalysts using the t[MASK]chnique lead to subje[MASK]ti[MASK]e biases , efforts have been made to make more objective estimates using computer prog[MASK]ams , which have been aided by higher @-@ resolution satellite imagery and more powerfu[MASK] compute[MASK]s . Since tropical cyclone satellite [MASK]atter[MASK]s can fluctuate ov[MASK]r time , auto[MASK]ated techni[MASK]ues use a six @-@ hour averaging period to lea[MASK] to more reliable intensity estimates . Development of the objective [MASK]vorak technique began in 1998 , which perf[MASK]rmed best with tropical cyclones that had eyes ( of hurricane or typhoon strength )[MASK]. I[MASK] still required a manual center placement , keeping some subjectivity within the process . By [MASK]004 , an advanced objective Dvorak technique was developed which utilized banding features for systems below hurricane intensity and to objectively de[MASK]ermine the tropical cyclone 's center . A central pressure bias was uncovered in 2004 relating to th[MASK] slope of the tropopause and cloud top temperatures which change with latitude that[MASK]helped[MASK]improve central pressure estimates within the objective technique . 
 
 = = Details of the method = = 
 
 In a developing cyclone , the technique takes advantage of the fact that cyclones of similar intensity tend to have certain characterist[MASK]c features , a[MASK]d as they[MASK]strengthen , they tend to [MASK]hange in appearance in a predictable manner . The str[MASK]cture and or[MASK]anizatio[MASK] of the tr[MASK]pical cyclone are tracked over 24 hours to determine if t[MASK]e storm has weakened , maintained its intensity , or strengthened . Various centra[MASK] cloud and banding features are compared[MASK]with templat[MASK]s tha[MASK] [MASK]how ty[MASK]ical storm patterns a[MASK]d their associ[MASK]ted int[MASK]nsity . If infrared satel[MASK]ite imagery is available fo[MASK] a cyclone with a visible eye pattern , then the technique utilizes the difference between the temperature of the warm eye and the surrounding cold cloud tops to determine intensity ( colder cloud tops generally indicate a more intense storm ) . In each ca[MASK]e a " T @-@ number " ( an abbreviation for Tropical Number )[MASK]and a Current Intensi[MASK]y ( CI ) value ar[MASK] assigned to the[MASK]storm . These measurements range between 1 ( minimum intensity [MASK] and 8 ( maximum intensity ) . The T @-[MASK] number and CI value ar[MASK] the same except for weakening storms , in which case the CI is higher . For we[MASK]kening systems , [MASK]he CI is held as the tropical cyclone intensit[MASK] for 12 hours , though research from the National Hurricane Center indicates that six hours is more reasonabl[MASK] . The table [MASK]t right shows the approximate surface wind speed and sea level pressure that corresponds to a given T @-@[MASK]number . The amount a tropical cyclone can change in strength per 24 ‑ hour period i[MASK] limited to 2 @.@ 5 T @-@ numbers per day . 
 
 = = = Pattern types = =[MASK]= 
 
 Wit[MASK]in the Dvorak satell[MASK]te [MASK]trength estimate for tropical cyclon[MASK]s , there are several visual patterns that a cyclone may take on which define the upper and lower bounds on its intensity . The pri[MASK]ary patterns used are curved band pattern ( T1.0 @-@ T4.5 ) , she[MASK]r pattern ( T1.5 @-@ T3.5 ) , central dense overcast ( CDO ) pattern ( T2.5 @-@ T5.0 ) , banding eye pattern ( T4.0 @-@ T4.5 ) , eye pattern ( T4.5 - T8.0 ) , and c[MASK]n[MASK]ral cold cover ( CCC ) pattern . Both the central dense overcast and embedded e[MASK]e pattern utilize the [MASK]ize of the CDO . The CDO pattern inten[MASK]ities sta[MASK]t at T2.5 , equivalent to minimal tropical[MASK]storm intensity ( 40 miles [MASK]er hour ( 64 km / h ) ) . The shape of the central dense overcast is also considered . The farther the center is tucked into the CDO , the stronger it is deemed . Tropical cyclones wit[MASK] maximum sustained winds between 65 miles per hour ( 105 km / h ) and 100 miles per hour ( 160 km / h ) can hav[MASK] their center of circ[MASK]lations obscured by[MASK][MASK]loudiness within visible and infrared satellite imagery , which makes diagnosis of their intensity a challenge . 
 The CCC pattern , with its larg[MASK] and quickly developing mass of thick cirrus clouds spreading out from an are[MASK] of convection near a tr[MASK][MASK]ical cyclone center within a[MASK]short time frame , indicates little development . When it develops , rainbands and cloud lines [MASK]round the tropical cyclone weaken and the thick cloud shield obscures the circulation center . While it resem[MASK]les a CDO pattern , it is rarely seen . 
 The eye pattern utilizes the coldness of the cloud tops within the surrounding mass of thunderstorms and contrasts it with the temperature[MASK]within the eye itself . The la[MASK]ger the temperature di[MASK]ference is , the stronger the tropical cyclone . Winds within[MASK]tropical cyclones can also be esti[MASK][MASK]ted b[MASK] t[MASK]acking fe[MASK]tures within the CDO using rapid scan geostationary satellite imagery , whose [MASK]ictures are taken minutes apart rather than every half @-@ hour . [MASK] Once a pattern is identified , the storm features ( such [MASK]s le[MASK]gth and curvature of banding features ) are further analyzed to arrive at a particular T @-@ number . 
 
 = = Usage = = 
 
 Several age[MASK]cies issue Dvorak intensity numbers for trop[MASK]cal cyclone[MASK] and [MASK]he[MASK]r precursors . These include the National Hurricane Ce[MASK]ter [MASK]s Tropical Analysis and Fo[MASK]ecast Branch ( TAFB ) , the Na[MASK]ional Oceanic [MASK]nd Atmospheric Administr[MASK]tion 's Satellite Analysis Branch ( S[MASK]B ) , and the Joint Ty[MASK]hoon Warning [MASK]enter at the Naval Pacific Meteorology and Oceanography Center in Pearl Harbor , Hawaii . 
 The Nat[MASK]o[MASK]al Hurricane Center will often quote Dvorak T[MASK]@-@ numbers in their tropical cyclone products . The [MASK]ollowing example is from discussion number 3 of Tropical Depression 24 ( eventually Hurricane Wilma ) of the 2005 Atlantic hurricane season : 
 BOTH TAF[MASK] AND SAB CAME IN [MASK]ITH A DVORAK SATELLITE INTE[MASK]SITY ESTIMATE OF T2.5 / 35 KT . HOWEVER ... OFTENTIMES THE SU[MASK]FACE WIND FIELD OF LARGE DEVELOPING LOW PRESSURE SY[MASK]TEMS LIKE THIS ONE WILL LAG ABOUT 12 HOURS BEHIND THE SATELLITE SIGNATURE . THEREFORE ... THE INITIAL INTENSITY HAS ONLY BEE[MASK] INCREASED TO 30 KT .[MASK]
 Note that in this case the [MASK]vorak T @-@ number ( in this case T2.5 )[MASK]was simply u[MASK]ed as a guide b[MASK]t [MASK]ther factors determined how the NHC decided to set th[MASK] system 's intensity . 
 The Cooperative Ins[MASK]itute for Meteorological Satelli[MASK]e Studies ( CIMSS ) at the University of Wisconsin – Madison has developed the Objective Dvorak Technique ( ODT ) . This is a modified[MASK]versio[MASK] of the Dvorak technique which uses computer algorithms rather than subjective human interpretation to arrive at a CI number . This is generally not implemented for tropical depressions or weak tro[MASK]ical sto[MASK]ms . The[MASK]China Meteorological Agency ( CMA ) is expected to start using the standard 1984 version of Dvorak in the near future . The Ind[MASK]an Meteorological Depart[MASK]ent ( IMD ) prefers using visible satellite image[MASK]y over i[MASK]frared imagery due to a perceived high bias in estimates derived from infrared imagery during the early morning hours of convective maximum . The Japan Meteorological Agency ( JMA ) uses the infrared version of Dvorak over the visible imagery v[MASK]rsion . Hong Kong Observatory and JMA continue to utilize Dvorak after tropical cyclone landfall . Various ce[MASK]ters hold on to the maximum current intensity for 6 – 12 hours , though this rule is broken when rapid weakening is obvious . 
 Citizen science site Cyclone[MASK]Center uses a mod[MASK]fied version of th[MASK] Dvorak technique to categorize post @-@ 1970 tropical weather .

[MASK]= = Benefits and[MASK]disadvantages = = 
 
 The most sign[MASK]ficant benefit of the use of the technique is that it has provided a more complete history of tropical cyclone i[MASK]tensity in areas where aircraft reconnais[MASK]ance is neither possible nor routinely[MASK]available . Intensity estimates of maximum sustaine[MASK] wind are currently w[MASK]thi[MASK] 5 miles[MASK]per hour ( 8 @.[MASK] 0 km / h ) of what aircraft are [MASK]ble to measure half of the time , th[MASK]ugh the assignment of intensity of systems with streng[MASK]hs between moderate tropical @-@ storm[MASK]force ( 60 miles per hour ( 97 km / h ) ) and weak hurricane- or typhoon @-@ force ( 100 miles per hour ( 160 km / h ) ) is the least certain . Its overall precision has not always been true , as refinements in the technique led to intensity changes between 1972 and 1977 of up to 20 miles pe[MASK] hour ( 32 km / h ) . The method is internally consis[MASK]ent in that it constrains rapid increases or decreases in tropical cyclone intensity . Some tropical cyclones fluctuate in strength more than the 2 @.@ 5 T numbers per day limit allowed[MASK]by the rule , which can work to the technique 's disadvantage and has led to occasional abandonment of the constr[MASK]ints since the 1980s . Systems with small eyes near the[MASK][MASK]imb , or edge , of a satellite ima[MASK]e can be biased too weakly using the technique ,[MASK]which can be resolved through use of polar[MASK]@-@ orbiting satellite imagery . Subtropic[MASK]l cyclone in[MASK]ensity cannot be determined using Dvorak , which led to the dev[MASK]lopment of the Hebert @-@ Poteat techniqu[MASK] in 1975 . Cyclones undergoing extratropical transition , losing their thunderstorm activity , see their intensities underestimated using the Dvorak technique . This led to the d[MASK]velopment of the Mil[MASK]er and Lander extratropical transition technique which ca[MASK] be used under these circumstances . 
 
 
 = New Yo[MASK]k State Route 31B = 
 
 New Y[MASK]rk Sta[MASK]e Route 31B ( NY 31B ) was a state highway in central New York in the United[MASK]States . It served as a connector betwe[MASK]n NY 31 , its parent route , in the Cayuga County village o[MASK] Weedsport a[MASK]d NY 5 in the Onondaga County tow[MASK] of Elbridge . NY 31[MASK] was assig[MASK]ed c . 1933[MASK], [MASK]eplacing New Yo[MASK]k State Route 293 , a r[MASK]ute assigned [MASK]s part of the 1930 renumbering of state hi[MASK]hways in New York . The NY 31B designation was removed in 1980 and replace[MASK] by County Route 31B ( CR 31B ) in Cayuga County and CR 99 in Onondaga County . 
 
 = = Route description = = 
 
 [MASK]Y 31B began at an intersection with its parent route [MASK] NY 31 , in the Cayuga County village of Weedsport . The highway went eastward , intersecting with NY 34 less than 0 @.@ 1 miles ( 0 @.@ 2 km ) later . Much of W[MASK]edsport was urbanized , with the highway passing residential homes and businesses as it progressed eastward thr[MASK]ugh the village . The highway intersected with CR 12B before leaving Weedsport and en[MASK]ering the town of Brutus as Brutus Road . 
 In Brutus , NY 31B continued to the east through[MASK]th[MASK] rur[MASK][MASK] town ,[MASK]intersecting CR 136A and passing the Weedsport Rural C[MASK]metery before turning to the southeast . After a short distance , the high[MASK]ay went through an isolated area of h[MASK]mes , where it intersected with CR[MASK]14 and CR 15A . NY 3[MASK]B continued on , inters[MASK]cting s[MASK]ver[MASK]l local highways before cros[MASK][MASK]ng into [MASK]nondaga County and[MASK]terminating at an intersection with NY 5 i[MASK] the town of Elbridge . 
 
 = = History = = 
 
 What beca[MASK]e NY 31B was originally designated as NY 293 as part of the 1930 renumbering of state highways in New York . NY 293 was renumbered to NY 31B c . 1933 , allowing the NY 293 desig[MASK]ation to be transferred to another highway in Orange County . NY 31B remained unchanged until January 2 , 1980 , wh[MASK]n the NY 31B designation was removed[MASK][MASK] 
 [MASK]wnership and maintenance of NY 31B 's former routing was gradually transferred to the counties it wen[MASK] through , namely Cayuga and Onondaga . The f[MASK]rst section to be transferred was the portion within Onondaga County , which was given to the county on April 1 , 1980 , and designated as CR 99 . The Cay[MASK]ga County section of former NY 31B was transferred to the county one year later on April 1 , 1981 , and designated as CR 31B for the state route that preceded it .

 = = Pitching style = = 
 
 Kershaw 's pitching[MASK]style relies on deception . He keeps the ball hidd[MASK]n so t[MASK]at it is hard for the batter to pick up the ball and has a consistent [MASK]verhand delivery on all of his pitches . Out of the w[MASK]ndup , Kershaw lower[MASK] his right foot vertically with a slight pause before moving it fo[MASK]ward to[MASK]ard the plate . The motion [MASK]as described during the 2015 National League Division Series as a " kickstand move [MASK] drawing comparison with one setting a kickstand[MASK]on a bicycle . Out of t[MASK]e stretch [MASK][MASK]he uses a slide step as it makes [MASK]t difficult for the base ru[MASK]ner at first bas[MASK] t[MASK] get a read on him . He has stated many times that he has modeled his pitching mechanics after his favor[MASK]te pitcher growing up[MASK], Roger Clemens . 
 Kershaw 's repertoire inc[MASK]udes a four @-@ seam fastball that sits anywhere from 92 miles pe[MASK] hour ( 148 km /[MASK]h ) to 95 miles per hour ( 153 km / h ) and tops out at 98 miles per hour ( 158 km / h ) with late movement , a slider at 84 miles [MASK]er hour ( 135 km / h ) – 87 miles per hour ( 140 km / h ) , a 12 – 6 curveball between 72 miles per hour ( 116 km / h ) –[MASK]76 miles per hour ( 122 km / h ) , and a[MASK]seldom th[MASK]own [MASK]hangeup ( under 3 % ) . As of late in the 2015 season , he is believed to be experimenting with the use of a cu[MASK]ter . He is also known for having one of the better pickoff moves to first base and is considered [MASK]ne of the better fiel[MASK]ing pitchers in the game . [MASK] 
 = [MASK] = Preparation = = = 
 
 According to many teammates , Kershaw is a noted perfectionist . A.J. Ellis describes his preparation a[MASK]d perfectionism during bullpens before each s[MASK][MASK]rt : 
 Three fastball[MASK] when I 'm standing up . I sit , and three fastballs down the middle . Then three fastballs either side . Three changeups away . Fastball inside . Three curveballs to th[MASK] middle . Fastball inside . Three [MASK]liders to the middle . Then he goes to the stretch position . Two fastballs inside , two fastballs away , two changeups , o[MASK]e fastball inside , two curveballs , one fastball inside , two sliders . Back to the windup , and one fastball inside , one fa[MASK]tball away . Thirty @-@ four pitches [MASK]n all .
