 = = Personal life = = 
 
 Kershaw grew up in Dallas , Texas and att[MASK]nded school with quarterback Matthew Stafford and fellow pitchers Jorda[MASK] Walden and [MASK]hawn Tolleson . One [MASK]f his favorite players growing up was former Texas Rangers first baseman Will Clark , and the main reason he wears number 22 is[MASK]to honor Clark . 
 He is the great @-@ [MASK]ephew of astronomer Clyde Tombaugh , the discoverer [MASK]f Pluto . Kershaw 's mother ,[MASK]born Marianne Tombaugh , is the daughter of Clyde Tombaugh 's younger brother . His father , Christopher George Kershaw , was a [MASK]usician and [MASK][MASK]n a Clio Award for his work . The elder Kershaw remarried after his divorce from Marianne and died in 2013 . 
 On Decembe[MASK] 4 , 2010 , Kershaw married his girlfriend of seven years , Ell[MASK]n M[MASK]lson . On January 23 , 2015 , Ellen gave birth to the couple 's first child , daughter Cali Ann . He is a Methodi[MASK][MASK] with strong religious faith . 
 Kershaw made a[MASK]cameo appearance in " Prince[MASK]" , a Season 3 episode of [MASK]ew Girl which originally aired fol[MASK]owing FOX 's telecast of Super Bowl XLVIII . 
 
 = = [MASK] Humanitarian work = = = 
 
 P[MASK]ior to the 2011 season , Kershaw visited Zambia with his[MASK]wife as pa[MASK]t of a Ch[MASK]istian mission organized by Dallas @-@ based Arise Af[MASK]ica . Af[MASK]er the trip , Kershaw announced his dream of building [MASK]n orphanage in Lusaka , Zambia ,[MASK]which he called " Hope 's[MASK]Home " after 11 @-@ year @-@ old Hope , an HIV[MASK]@-@ positive child Kershaw met while in Zambia . To accomplish his goal , Kershaw pledged a donation of $ 100 per strikeout recorded in 2011 . With Kershaw 's career high of 248 strikeouts thrown during the 2011 season , he donated $ 492 @,@ 300 toward his $ 70 @,@ 000 goal . When Kers[MASK]aw won the 2011 Players Choice Award , he donate[MASK] $ 260 @,@ 000 to Hope 's Home . He and his wife returned to Zambia in 2012 . Kershaw donated $ 100 for every strikeout in the 2012 season to Kershaw 's Challenge , calling that season '[MASK] incarnation of th[MASK] pr[MASK]ject " Strike Out To Serve . " Seventy percent of the mone[MASK] raised in 2012 went to Arise Africa , with 10 percent each going to the [MASK]eacock [MASK]oundation in Los Angeles , Mercy Street in Dallas , and I Am Second . In 2014 , Kershaw c[MASK]ntinued to support the children of Zambia , with partnership with CURE International , raising fun[MASK]s to pay for 170 children 's surgeries and new medical equipment for CURE hospital in Lusaka . Kershaw has continued his partnership with CURE International in 201[MASK] , setting a goal of funding [MASK]00 surgeries for CURE 's hospital in the Dominican Republic . 
 In addition to Hope 's Home and Kershaw 's Challenge , he has also helped with other programs in Los A[MASK]geles , such as he[MASK]ping Ha[MASK]itat for Humanity demolish and rehabilitate [MASK] house in[MASK]Lynwood , California . He is also a supporter of the Peacock Foundation , which provides animal [MASK]-@ assisted interventions and activities for at risk youth by partnering with mental health practitioners , [MASK]ublic service agencies and community organizati[MASK]ns .  = Josepha Petrick Kemarre = 
 
 Josepha Petrick Kemarre ( born c[MASK] . 1945 or ca [MASK] 1953 , d[MASK]te uncertain ) is an Anmatyerre @-@ speaking Indigenous Australian[MASK]from Central Australia . Si[MASK]ce first[MASK]taking up p[MASK]inting around 1990 , her [MASK]orks of contemp[MASK]rary Indigenous Australian[MASK]art have been acq[MASK]ired by several major collections including Art[MASK]ank and the National Gallery of Victoria . Her paintings portray bush plum " dreaming [MASK] and wome[MASK] ’ s ceremonies ( known as Awelye )[MASK]. One[MASK]of her paintings sold at a charity auction for A[MASK]$ 22 @,@ 800 . Josepha Petrick 's works are strongly coloured and formalist in[MASK]composition and regularly appear at commercial art auctions in Australia . Her art appears to have survived the huge contr[MASK]ction of the primary art market in Australia since 2008 . There is no exis[MASK]ing Cata[MASK]ogue raiso[MASK]né of Josepha Petrick 's artworks , to dat[MASK] , no fakes have been cited . 
 
 = = Personal background = = 
 
 Josepha Petrick Kemarre is an Anmatyerre @-@ speaking Indigenous Australian , born a[MASK]ound 1945 or 19[MASK]3 at the Santa Tere[MASK]a Mission , near Alice Springs in Australia [MASK]s Northern Territory . 
 When Josepha Petrick began painting for Mbantua Gallery[MASK]in central Australia ,[MASK]she indicated that her name was Josepha rather than Josie , and that this was how s[MASK]e henceforth wished to be known ; however Mbantua 's biography is the only source that has use[MASK] that version of her name . 
 After marrying Robin Petyarre , brother of artist Gloria Petyarre , Josepha Petrick moved to the region of Ut[MASK]pia , north @-@ east of Alice Springs , which is where she was[MASK]livi[MASK]g when she began painting around 1990[MASK]. [MASK]hey had seven chil[MASK]ren , one of whom , Damien Petrick , went on to become an arti[MASK]t like h[MASK]s mo[MASK]her . By 2008 , Josie Petrick 's husband had died , and Petrick was dividing he[MASK] time between Alice Springs and Harts Range , to its no[MASK]th [MASK]-@ east . 
 
 = = Pr[MASK]fessional background = = 
 
 Contemporary Indigenous art of the we[MASK]tern desert [MASK]egan in 1971 when Indigenous men at Papunya created murals and canvases using west[MASK]rn art materials , assisted by teacher Geoffrey [MASK]ardon . Their work , which used acrylic paints to create designs representing body painting and ground sculptures , rapidly spread acros[MASK] Indigenous communi[MASK]ies of central Aust[MASK]alia , particularly after the introducti[MASK]n of a gover[MASK]ment @-@ sanction[MASK]d art pr[MASK]gram in centra[MASK] Australia in 1983 . By the 1980s and ' 90s , such work was being ex[MASK]ibited internationally . The first artists , including all of the founders of the Papunya Tula artists ' com[MASK]any , were men , and there was resistance among the [MASK]intupi men of central Australia to women also[MASK]painting . However , many of the women wished to participate , and in the 1990s many of them began t[MASK] paint . In the western desert communities such as U[MASK]opia , Kintore , Yuendumu , Balgo , and on the outstations , people wer[MASK] beginning to create a[MASK]t works expressly for exhibition and sale .

 Josepha Petrick be[MASK]an painting about 1990 or 1992 as part of the contemporary Indigenous art moveme[MASK]t th[MASK]t had begun at Papunya in the 1970s . Her career received a significant boost when her work [MASK]as included in the National Gallery of Victoria 's 2006 Landmarks[MASK]exhibition and its catalogue ; her painting was printed opposite that of Yannima Tommy[MASK]Watson , who was by this time [MASK]amous , particular[MASK]y for his cont[MASK]ibution to the design of a new building for [MASK]he Musée du quai Branly . Petrick 's painting[MASK] have been included[MASK]at exhibitions in several private galleries in Melbourne and Hong Kong , as well as at the Australian embassy in Washington in 2001 . [MASK] In 2006 a commiss[MASK]oned work by Petrick was exhibited at Shalom College at the University of New South Wales [MASK]s part of a charity fundraising exhibition . It sold for A $ 22 @,@ 000 . As of the end of 2008 , the hi[MASK][MASK]est recorded auction price for an item of Petrick 's work was $ 22 @,@ 800 [MASK] set in May 2007 . An [MASK]mage [MASK]ased on a triptych by Petrick , Bush Berries , appears on the cover[MASK]of a boo[MASK] on [MASK]he visual perception of motion , Motion Vision . 
 Central Australian artists frequently paint particular " dream[MASK]ngs "[MASK], o[MASK] stories , for which [MASK]hey have responsibility or rights . These stories are used to pass " importa[MASK]t knowledge , cultural values and belief[MASK]systems[MASK]" from generati[MASK]n to generation . Paintings by Petrick portray two [MASK]ifferent groups of dreamings , rendered in two distinct styles . Bush p[MASK]um dreaming represents a plant of the central Australian desert which is " a source of physica[MASK] and spiritual sustenance , reminding [ the local Indigenou[MASK] people ] of the sacr[MASK]dness of[MASK][ their ] country " . These paintings are undertaken with red , blue and orange dots that represent the fruit at diffe[MASK]ent stages in its development . She also paints women ’ s ceremonies ( Awelye ) and dreamings , and these are created using rows of coloured dots and include representations of women [MASK]s ceremonial iconography . 
 Journalist Zeld[MASK] Cawthorne described Petrick as one of the " finest contemporary Aboriginal artists " . Art consultant Adrian Newstead has ranked her as amongst [MASK]he country 's top 200 Indig[MASK]nous artists [MASK][MASK]noting that she has be[MASK]ome " known for i[MASK]novative wo[MASK]ks that create a sense of visual harmony through fine [MASK]ariegated fields of immaculately applied dotting " . Her style is described by Indigenous art writers Birnberg and Kreczmanski as an " interesting , modern interpretation of landsca[MASK]e " . 
 Petrick 's work is held in a v[MASK]riety [MASK]f pu[MASK]lic and private collections , including Artbank , the Cha[MASK]les Sturt University Collection , the Holmes a Court Collection , and the National Gallery of Victoria . 
 
 
 = [MASK]ead VI = 
 
 [MASK]ead VI is an oil @-@ on @-@ canvas painting by the Irish @-[MASK] born English figurative artist Francis Bacon , the last of si[MASK] pan[MASK]ls making up his " 1949 Head " series . It shows a bust view of[MASK]a sing[MASK]e figure , modeled on Diego Velázquez 's Portrait[MASK]of Innocent X. Baco[MASK] applies forceful , expressive brush strokes , and places the figure within a glass cage structure , behind curtain @-@ l[MASK]ke drapery . This gi[MASK]es the effect of a [MASK]an trapped and suffocated by his surroun[MASK]ings , screaming into an airless void . 
 Head VI was the first of Bacon 's paintings to reference Velázquez , whose portrai[MASK] of Pope Innocent X haunted him throughout his career and inspired his series of " screaming popes " , a loose[MASK]series of which there are[MASK]around 45 surviving individual works . Head VI contains many motifs that were to[MASK]reappear i[MASK] Bacon 's work . The hanging object , which may be a light switch[MASK]or curtain tassel , can be found even in his late paintings . T[MASK]e geometric cage is a motif that appears as late as his 1985 – 86 masterpie[MASK]e , Study for a Self[MASK]@-@ Portrait — Triptych . 
 Head VI was first exhibited in November 19[MASK]9 at the Hanover Galle[MASK]y in London , in a showing organis[MASK]d by one of the artist 's early champions , Erica Brausen . At the time , Bacon was a highly controversial but respected artist , best known for[MASK]his 1944 Three Studies for [MASK]i[MASK]ures at the Base of a Cruc[MASK]fixion , which made him the enfant terrible of Briti[MASK]h art . Head VI drew a mixed reaction from art critics ; John Russell , later Bacon 's biographer , at the time dismissed it as a cross between " an alli[MASK]ator shorn [MASK]f its jaws and an accountant in pince @-@ nez who has come to a bad end " . In 1989 Lawrence Gowing wrote that the " shock of the pictu[MASK]e , when it was se[MASK]n with a whole series of heads ... was indescribable . It was everything unpardonable . The paradoxical appearance at once of [MASK]astiche and iconoclasm was indeed one of Bacon 's mos[MASK] original strokes . " Art crit[MASK]c and curator Davi[MASK] Sylvester described it as a seminal piece from Bacon 's unusually productive 1949 – 50 period , and one of Bacon 's fine[MASK]t popes . 
 
 = = 1949 Head series = = 
 
 Bacon 's output is characterised by sequences[MASK]of imag[MASK]s . He told Sylvester[MASK]that h[MASK]s imagination was stimulated by sequences and that " images breed other i[MASK]a[MASK]es in me " . His series were not [MASK]lways planned or painted in sequence ; sometimes paintings are grouped for convenience but vary in ex[MASK]cution and tone . The idea for the head series came after he return[MASK]d penniless , late in 1[MASK]48 , from a stay in Tangier . In the previous three years he ha[MASK] been unable to find a voice ; the last surviving canvas from this period is[MASK]his Painting ( 19[MASK]6 ) . Although he continued to[MASK]paint , h[MASK] was a ruthless self critic [MASK] given to slashing canvases with bl[MASK]des , and no works survive from between 1947 and the winter of 1948 . Gallerist Erica Brausen offered Bacon the opport[MASK]nity of a solo show for t[MASK][MASK] opening o[MASK] her new Ha[MASK]over Gallery . He agreed , but had nothing in reserve to hang . I[MASK] following year[MASK] , Brausen became perhaps the most important of Bacon 's early champions ; she arranged this showing —[MASK]his debut solo exhibition — publicised him wid[MASK]ly and [MASK]rganis[MASK]d viewings for i[MASK]ternational buyers . 
 Al[MASK]eady 40 years old , Baco[MASK] viewed the e[MASK]hibition as his l[MASK]st chance and applied himself to the task with determination . Because he had destroyed all his out of the last t[MASK]ree year[MASK] , he had little choice but to present new works . He did not have a grand plan when he agreed t[MASK] the show , but eventually found themes that interested him in his Head[MASK]I of the p[MASK]evious year , an[MASK] executed five progressively stronger variants in the final weeks before the November exhi[MASK]ition , completing the [MASK]eries barely in time for the opening [MASK] 
 The paintings depict isolated figures enclosed in spaces th[MASK]t are undefined , overwhelmingly claustrophobic , reductive and eerie . Coming early in Bacon 's career , they are uneven in quality , but show a clear progression especially in how they utilise and present ideas he was still clearly developing and coming to terms with . Head I ( [MASK]ctually begun in the winter of 1948 ) and Head II show formless pieces of flesh that broadly resemble human heads ; they have half @-@ open eyes and a pharynx , though it is positioned much higher than would be expected in a human . Heads III , IV and[MASK]V show fully formed busts recognisable as men , and a[MASK]e characterised by a haunted atmosphere . These two broad ideas coalesce in Head VI , which is as physiologically [MASK]ortured as the first t[MASK]o p[MASK]intings , and as spect[MASK]al as t[MASK]e middle three . In Head VI the figur[MASK] has developed and is now shown wearing vestments[MASK], the first indication in Bacon 's work of the influence of Velá[MASK]quez ,[MASK]while the[MASK]focus has become the open mouth and the study of the human screa[MASK] . 
 Bacon sai[MASK] that chance played a significant[MASK]role in his work ,[MASK]and that he[MASK]often approached a canvas without havi[MASK]g a clear idea of what might emerge . This was especially the case in the mid to late 1940s , a p[MASK]riod when h[MASK] was drinking heavily and spending most nights in Soho casinos and poker rooms . The following morning he would often[MASK]approach his canvas " in a bad mood of drinking ... under tremendous hangovers and drink ; I sometimes hardly knew what [MASK] wa[MASK] doing . " He incorporated his appetite fo[MASK] cha[MASK]ce into his work : an image often would [MASK]orph mid @-@ way through into something quite different from what he had first intended . He actively sought out this freedom [MASK]nd felt it crucial to his progression as an artist . To him , lifestyle and art were intertwined ; he said that " perhaps the drink helped me to be a bit freer . " This i[MASK] very evident in the 1949 series , which began as a rather morb[MASK]d study of a c[MASK]llapsed hea[MASK] , but evolved over the[MASK]six surviv[MASK]ng p[MASK]nels into a[MASK]rewo[MASK]king of Velázquez masterpieces , and arrived at an image that was to preoccupy Bacon for the subsequent 20 years . 
 The series mark[MASK] Bacon 's fir[MASK]t attempt a[MASK] depicting lone figures in rooms . For him , the key aspect was that it appeared tha[MASK] the subject felt isolated , unobserved , and had ab[MASK]ndoned the need[MASK]to present an outward face[MASK]. He beli[MASK]ved that under these circumstances all pretence falls away , and the social being becom[MASK]s the sum of its neuroses , which Bacon attempted to convey by red[MASK]cing the subject t[MASK] its bare [MASK]-@ bones features : a mouth , ears , eyes , a jaw . Accordi[MASK]g to Russell , " the view out front ceases to be the only one ,[MASK]and our person is suddenly adrif[MASK] , fragmented , and subject to strange mutation . " Russell observed that while the depiction of figures in rooms is common[MASK]through all eras of painting , the figures are always posed , and usually seemingly aware that they are being [MASK]ortrayed . This conceit is abandoned in Bacon 's series . 
 Head I , completed la[MASK]e in 1948 , is consider[MASK]d more successful than Head II . Although it is w[MASK]ll @-@ regarded critically , Head II [MASK]s seen as something of a creative cul @-@ d[MASK] @-@ sac , while Heads III , IV and V are usually considered[MASK]as merel[MASK] intermediate steps towa[MASK]ds Head V[MASK] . It is exceptional in[MASK]Bacon 's oeuvre th[MASK]t works of their relative poor quality survive ; he was ruthlessly self @-@ critical and often slashed or abandoned canvasses before they were completed . When pressed [MASK]gain by Brausen i[MASK] 1953 to produce works for a [MASK]ew York show that she had been publicising for a year , he was full of doubt and destroyed most of what he had been working on , [MASK]ncluding several other popes . 
 Brau[MASK]en commissioned another s[MASK]owing[MASK]to be held in 1950 , for which Bacon pain[MASK]ed three large popes modelled on Velázquez 's portrait . The gallery advertised the show [MASK]s " Fra[MASK]cis Bacon : Three Studies from the Painting of Innocent X by Velázquez " , but in t[MASK]e end Bacon was dissatisfied with the[MASK]works and [MASK]estroyed them before the show opened . 
 
 = = Descripti[MASK]n = = 
 
 The[MASK]figure is clearly identifiable as a pope from his clothing . It see[MASK]s trapped and isolated within the outlines of a[MASK] abstract thre[MASK] @-@ dim[MASK]nsional glass cage . This fram[MASK]ng device , [MASK]escr[MASK]bed by Sylvester a[MASK] a " space @-@ frame " , was to[MASK]feature heavily throughout the artist 's career . A cord hangs from the upper edge of the glass case , falling just in front of the pope 's face and partially covering his eyes . It is too indistinctly drawn to identify with certainty , but giv[MASK]n the presence of similar objects in Bacon 's later w[MASK]rks , may be either the[MASK]end of a hanging light switch or the tassel of a curtain ; the hanging cord was to become a signature for the artist . Apart from its symbolic meaning , it has a compositional func[MASK]ion , framing the painting with a further set of vertical lines . Such an object reappears most prominently in the centre panel of[MASK]his 1973 Triptych , May – June 1973 , where it is cl[MASK]arly a dangling li[MASK]ht bulb . For Bacon , these elements were intended to make the figure waver in and out of sight for t[MASK]e [MASK]iewer , alluding to the fact that bulbs can be on or off , curtains o[MASK]en or [MASK]losed . 
 The [MASK]igure 's mouth is opene[MASK] wide as if screaming , an[MASK]expression Bacon took from a still he kept of the nurse screaming i[MASK] Sergei Eisenste[MASK]n 's Odessa Steps massa[MASK]re sequence in his 1[MASK]25 silent film Battleship Potemkin . In 1984 , the broadcaster Melvyn Bragg asked Bacon about the still , and[MASK]observed th[MASK]t in his earlier career the artist seemed preoccupied with the physicality of the human mou[MASK]h . Bacon replied[MASK], " I had al[MASK]ays thought that I would be able to make the mouth with all the bea[MASK]ty of a Mon[MASK]t landscape though I never [MASK]ucceeded in doing so . " When Bragg asked why he thought he had fail[MASK]d , Bacon said , " It[MASK]should be all much more colour , should have got more of th[MASK] interior of the mouth , with all the colours of the interior of the mouth , but I didn 't happen to get it . " His interest in the mouth was further stimulated by a medical textbook of diseased oral caviti[MASK]s bought in a second @-@ hand bookshop [MASK] kept in his studio and to[MASK]which he often referr[MASK]d to . 
 The glass cage m[MASK]ght imply a vacuum that the figu[MASK]e 's voice is unable to escape ; as if it is screaming in silence . Rueful later in life , [MASK]acon said that he had " wanted to paint the scream more than the horror [MASK] I think , if I had really thought about wh[MASK]t causes somebody to really scream , it would have made the scream ... more successful " . The work evokes memories of the Second World War . The glass enclosure of his 1949 Chicago Study for a Portrait is often seen as prophesying photog[MASK]aphs of Adolf [MASK]ichmann 1961 trial before a Jerusalem District Court , when he was held within a sim[MASK]lar cage[MASK]. Bacon strongly resisted literal comparisons though [MASK] and stated that he use[MASK] the device so he could frame an[MASK] " really see the image – for no other reason . I know [MASK]t 's been interpreted as being many other things . " Other critics saw similarities between the glass case and the radio booths of late 1930s broadcasters who warned against the impending calamity . Denis Farr notes that Bacon was sym[MASK]atheti[MASK] to [MASK]eorge Orwell and referred in intervi[MASK]ws to Orwellian " shout[MASK]ng [MASK]oices ... and trem[MASK]ling hands ... convey[MASK][ ing ] the harsh atmosphere of an interrogati[MASK]n . " 
 
 [MASK][MASK]= Influences = = 
 
 The so @-@ called " space frame " had already been used by Alberto Giacometti in the 1930s , and the two artists became fr[MASK]ends in the 1960s . However Giacometti had by [MASK]949 used it only in sur[MASK]ealist co[MASK]texts before Bacon 's adapt[MASK]on , and in turn in[MASK]luenced his use in " The Cage " of 1950 . A similar two di[MASK]ensional construct is fou[MASK]d i[MASK] Henry Moore 's wo[MASK][MASK]s , notably his " Maguette [MASK]or King and Queen " , co[MASK]structed thre[MASK] years after Bacon 's Head . It is difficult to untangle how these artists influenced and informed each other . What is[MASK]notable is that Baco[MASK] continued to use the motif , with intervals until the end of his life . Sylvester suggests his finest ex[MASK]mple is the 1970 Three Studies of the Male Back . 
 The full @-@ length golden curtain @-@ like folds painted in heavy bru[MASK]h strokes are [MASK]n part[MASK]influ[MASK]nced by Degas but al[MASK]o similar to Titian [MASK]s 1558 Portrait of Ca[MASK]dinal Filippo Arc[MASK]into . Bacon adapts the Old Ma[MASK]ter 's device to isolate and distance the sitter from [MASK]he viewer ; the black[MASK]ground @-@ paint is visible through the folds , making the separation all the more[MASK]affecting . Bacon [MASK]ad already used similar for[MASK]s in his Chicago panel , and they were to become a feature of his most acclaimed 1950s works , especially in his " screaming[MASK]popes " . He became fasc[MASK]nated with the vei[MASK] or c[MASK]rtain as a motif in painting , an[MASK] collected many reproductions of works by T[MASK]tian and Degas in which it i[MASK] employed . He had begun[MASK]his career as an interior decorator and designer of furniture and r[MASK]gs i[MASK] t[MASK]e mid @-@ 1930s [MASK] and later said that he liked " rooms hung all round with just curtains hung in even folds " . Veils or curtains appear in Bacon 's earliest works , notably the 19[MASK]9 Study from the Hu[MASK]a[MASK] Body , always in[MASK]portraits and alw[MASK]ys[MASK]in front of , rath[MASK]r than behind , the figure . 
 Head VI is closely modelled on Velázquez 's c . 1650 Portrait of Innocent X , today in the Doria Pamphilj Gallery , Rome . Bacon cautiously avoided seeing the original , even when he spent three months in Rome in 1954 . Critics speculate he was afraid of being disappointed , or thought that an intimate knowledge of the painting would dull his imagination .[MASK]Yet his fascinati[MASK]n was all @-@ consuming and he repro[MASK]uced variants of it obsessively for almost two decades ; an examination and homage described [MASK]s " [MASK]ithout paral[MASK]el in the history of art " . Bacon 's approach differs to Velázquez 's in a[MASK]n[MASK]mber of ways : both artists were expressive , yet Bacon 's broad bru[MASK]h @-@ strokes and freedom with paint cont[MASK]ast with Velázquez 's tig[MASK]t and controlled treatment . He adapts Velázquez 's positioning of the pope to place him above the vie[MASK]er 's point of view , elevating and distancing him . This was [MASK]lready a common[MASK]technique in commercial , promotional photography but in Bacon 's hands , Schmied argues , the angle places[MASK]th[MASK] pope on a kind of stage for the viewer to coldly observe [MASK] 
 Although Bacon rever[MASK]d Veláz[MASK]uez 's portrait , he did not try [MASK]nd reproduce the earlier [MASK]aintin[MASK] . In interviews , he said that he saw flaws in Velázquez 's work and that he viewed that social structure and order as , according to art histor[MASK]an Wieland Schmied , " obsolete and decayed " . Bacon 's approach was to elevate his su[MASK]ject so he could knock him down again , thereby making a sly comment on the treatment of royalty in both old master and contemporary painting . Yet Velázquez 's influence is apparent in many aspects [MASK]f the painting [MASK] The sitter 's [MASK]ose clos[MASK]ly e[MASK]hoes the original , as does the violet and white colourin[MASK] of his cope , which is built up through broad , [MASK]hick , brush @-@ strok[MASK]s . The influence can be further seen in the gold @-@ coloured orname[MASK]ts on the [MASK]ack of the seat that extend on both sides of the figure . Art historian Armin Zweite describes the work as a mixture of reverence and subversion that pays tribute to Velázquez , while at [MASK]he same time deconstructs his painting . 
 Sylvester detects the influence of[MASK]late works by Titian in other aspects , especially in the deep and rich [MASK]olouring , Velázquez 's portrayals of Phil[MASK]p IV ,[MASK]and agrees with [MASK]d[MASK]ntification of pastels of Edgar Degas as a source . He believes Bacon[MASK]borrowed from[MASK]Degas the use of parallel heavy folds to create the illusion of what Degas described as " shutte[MASK]ing " , as se[MASK]n in the earlier artist 's After the Bath , Woman drying herself . Sylvester makes a further direct link between the folds and the transparent veil in Titian 's Portrait of Cardinal [MASK]ilippo Archinto . He believes the folds serve to " push the[MASK]viewer back[MASK]" , creating a distance from th[MASK] subject , an effect he sees as simil[MASK]r to the sepa[MASK]ation between and orchestra and setting ; others view the folds as more closely resembling the bars of a prison . Sylvester describes [MASK]hem as an accentuation of backg[MASK]ound verticals into stripes that are made to appea[MASK] as if they pass through the sitt[MASK]r[MASK]. In his " Interviews with Francis Baco[MASK] " series of books , he asked Bacon why he found the effect so poignant . The artist replied , " Well , it means that the sensation doesn 't come straight out at you but slides slowly and gently through the gaps . " 
 When asked [MASK]hy he wa[MASK] compelled to rev[MASK]sit the Velázquez so often , Bacon replied that he had nothing against [MASK]opes per se , but merely sought " an excuse to use [MASK]hese colours , and you can[MASK]'t give ordinary[MASK]clothes that purple colour without getting into a sort of false fauve [MASK]anner . " Schmied sees Head VI as a reaction against Velázquez , and a commentary on how t[MASK]e papacy is " obsolete and[MASK]decayed " , with a pope resistant to both modernisation and secularisation . To [MASK][MASK]m , t[MASK]e figure seems to " resist the maltreatment of image and tries to halt the impendin[MASK] collapse of the established work order . He screams and grimaces , clutching at arms of his throne . " Sylvester notes that Bacon was impressed by Picasso 's figurat[MASK]on and handling of paint , especially in Picasso 's 1930s wo[MASK]ks ; and sugge[MASK]ts that the[MASK]white blobs around th[MASK] pope[MASK]'s cape may be influenced by the 1913 W[MASK]man in a Slip Seated in an Armcha[MASK]r . 
 
 = = Critical reception = = 
 
 When Bacon under[MASK]ook [MASK]he series late in 1948 he was somet[MASK]ing of a[MASK]two @-@ hit wonder . He had success in 1944 with Three Studies for Figures at [MASK]he Base of a Crucifixion and[MASK]to a lesser extent with Painting ( 1946 ) , both of whic[MASK] were highly regarded but viewed as sensationalist . The exhibition was[MASK]a success , and marked his critical breakthrough . Until then , he had been highly regarded but capable of only occasional brilliance .[MASK][MASK]he full show established him in th[MASK] minds of critics as , according to Michael Peppiatt , " more of a force to be reckoned with in the contemporary scene [MASK] . While some found his images horrifying and unnerving , they wrote about him all the same , sealing his reputation as the enfant terrible of post @-@ war British art . The critic for The Observer wrote , " The recent paintings ... horrifying as they are , cannot be ignored . Technically they are supe[MASK]b , and the masterly handling[MASK]of large areas of pearly grey , flu[MASK]he[MASK] with a sudden pink or green , only makes me regret t[MASK]e more th[MASK]t the artist 's gift sh[MASK]uld have been brought to subjects so esoteric[MASK]" . 
 Most cr[MASK]tics[MASK]focused on Heads I and VI , remarking favourably on the progressio[MASK] bet[MASK]een th[MASK] two . While some found the inherent violence of the painti[MASK]gs distasteful , Brausen was a skilled publicist and[MASK]turned the bad press [MASK]nto notoriety , and brought Bacon 's work to nationa[MASK] [MASK]tten[MASK]ion . Peppiatt notes that the exhibition showed Bacon no longer needed sensationalist material to make an impact , an[MASK] was now capable of creating an [MASK]ntense emotional response[MASK]through mo[MASK]e subtle means , and had found a way of presentin[MASK] the human condition in the way he had sought , by pre[MASK]enting his sitter " in a vestigial [MASK]etting , a ca[MASK]e or [ b[MASK]hind ] a parted curtin ... the rest , the most ess[MASK]nt[MASK]al , lay in the manipulation o[MASK] the infinitel[MASK] suggestive medium of oil paint " .[MASK]After the sho[MASK]ing Bacon gradually became " less the outsider with an occasional image of horrifying brilliance and more a force to be reckoned with on the contemporary scen[MASK] " . His reputation and t[MASK]e value of his panels rose dramatically , and after the showing he was sought [MASK]fter by European [MASK] American and African collectors and g[MASK]lleries , commanding prices[MASK]as high as £ 400 for single works , unusual for a contemporary British artis[MASK][MASK]of the time .

 = Imagism = 
 
 Imag[MASK]sm was a movement in early 20th @-@ century A[MASK]glo @-@ American poetry that favor[MASK]d precision of imagery a[MASK]d clear , sharp language . 
 Imagism has been described as the most influential movement in English [MASK]oetry since th[MASK] activity of the Pre [MASK]-@ Raphaelites . As a poetic styl[MASK] it gave Modernism i[MASK]s start in the early 2[MASK]th century , and is considered to be the first organized Modernist literary moveme[MASK]t in the English language . Imagism is s[MASK]metimes viewed as ' a succession of creative[MASK]moments ' rather than any continuous o[MASK] sustained per[MASK]od of[MASK]dev[MASK]lopment . René Taupin remarked that ' It is more accurate to consider Imagism not as a doctrine , nor even as a poetic school , but as the association o[MASK] a few poets who were f[MASK]r a certain time in agreement on a small number of[MASK]important principles ' . 
 The Imagists rejected the sentiment and discurs[MASK]veness typical of much Romantic and Victorian poetry , i[MASK] contr[MASK]st to their contempo[MASK]aries , the Georgian poets , who were generally content to work within[MASK]that tradition . In contrast , Imagism called for a return to what were seen as more Classic[MASK]l values , such as directness of p[MASK]esentation and economy[MASK][MASK]f language , as well as a will[MASK][MASK]gnes[MASK] to experiment with non [MASK]-@ traditional verse forms . Imagists use fr[MASK]e verse . 
 I[MASK]agist publications appearing between 1914 and 1917 f[MASK]atured[MASK]works[MASK]by many of the most promine[MASK]t modernist figures , both in poetr[MASK] and in other fie[MASK]ds . The Imagist group was centered in London , with members from Great Britain , Ireland and the United States . Somewhat unusually for the t[MASK]me , a number of women writers wer[MASK] major Imag[MASK]st figures . 
 A characteristic featur[MASK] of Imagism is its attempt to isolate[MASK]a single image to reveal its essence . This feature mirro[MASK]s contemporary deve[MASK]opments in avant @-@ garde art , especially Cubism . Although Imagism isolates objects through the use of what Ezra Pound called " luminous details " , Pound 's Ideogrammic Method of juxtaposing concrete ins[MASK]ances to express an abstraction is s[MASK]milar to Cubism[MASK]'s manner of synthesizing multiple perspectives int[MASK] a single image . 
 
 = = Pre @-@ Imagism = = 
 
[MASK]Well @-@ known[MASK]poets of the Edwardian era of the 1890s , su[MASK]h as Alfred Austin , Stephen Phillips , and William Wa[MASK]son , had been working ver[MASK] much in the shadow of Tennyson , producing weak i[MASK]itations of the poetry of the Victorian era . They continued to work[MASK]in this vein in[MASK]o the early years of the 20th century . As the new century opened , Austin was still the serving British Poet Laureate , a post [MASK]hich he held up to 1913 . In the century 's first decade , poetry still had a large aud[MASK]ence ; volumes of verse pub[MASK]ished in that ti[MASK]e included Thomas Hardy 's The D[MASK]nasts , Christina Rossetti 's posthumous Poetical Works , Ernest Dowson 's Po[MASK]ms , Ge[MASK]rge Meredith 's Last Poems [MASK] Robert Service 's Ballads of a Cheechako and John Mase[MASK]ield 's Ballads and Poems . Future Nobel Prize winne[MASK] William Butler Yea[MASK]s was devoting [MASK]uch of his energy to the Abbey Theatre and writing for the stage , producing relatively little lyric poetry during this period . In 1907 , the Nob[MASK]l Prize for Literature was awarded to Rudyard Kipling . 
 The origins of Imagism are to be found in two poems , Autumn a[MASK]d A City Sunset by T. E. Hulme . These were publish[MASK]d in January [MASK]909 by the Poets ' Club in London in a booklet c[MASK]lle[MASK] For Christmas MDCCCCV[MASK]II[MASK]. Hulme was a student of mathematics and philosophy ;[MASK]he had been involved in[MASK]the setting up of the club in 1908 and was its first secretary . Around the end of 1908 , he presented his paper A Lecture[MASK]on Modern Poetry at one of [MASK]he club [MASK]s meetings . Writing in A. R. Orage 's magazine The New Age , the poet and critic F. S. Flint ( a champion of free verse and modern French poetry ) was highly critical of the club and its publications . From the ensuing debate , Hulme and Flint became close friends . I[MASK] 1909 , Hulme left the Poets ' Club and started meeting with Flint and other poets in a new group which Hulme referred to as the " Secession Club " ; they met at the Eiffel Tower restaurant in London 's Soho to discuss plans to reform[MASK]contemporary poetry through free verse and the tanka and[MASK]haiku and the removal of all unnecessary verb[MASK]age from poems . The interest in Japanese verse forms can be placed in a conte[MASK]t of the late Victorian and Edwardian revival of interest in Chinoi[MASK]erie and Japonism as witnessed in the 1890s vogue for William Anderson 's Japanese prints donated to the British Museum ,[MASK]performanc[MASK]s of Noh plays in London , and the success of Gilbert an[MASK] Sullivan 's operetta The Mikado ( 1885 ) .[MASK]Direct literary mo[MASK]els were available from a number of[MASK]sources , including F. V. Dickins 's 1866 Hyak nin [MASK]s 'shiu , or , Stanzas by a Century of Po[MASK]ts , Being Japanese Lyrical Odes , the fir[MASK]t English @-@[MASK]language version of the Hyakunin issh[MASK] , a 13th @-@ century anthology of 100 waka , the early 20[MASK]h @-@ century critical writings and poems of Sadakichi Hartmann , and contemporary French @-@ language translations . 
 The American po[MASK]t Ezra Poun[MASK] was introduced to the group in April 1909 and [MASK]ound that their ideas were close to his own . In particular , Pound 's studies of Romantic literature had led him to an admiration of the condensed , direct expression that he detected in the writings[MASK]of Arnaut Daniel , Dante , and Guido Cavalcanti , amongst others . For exampl[MASK] , in his 1911 – 1[MASK] series of essays I gather the limbs of [MASK]siris , Pound [MASK][MASK]ites of Daniel 's line " pensar de lieis m 'es repaus " ( " it rests me to think of her " ) ( from the canzone En breu brizara 'l temps braus ) : "[MASK]You cannot get statement simpler than that , or clearer[MASK], or less rhetorical " . These criteri[MASK] of directness , cl[MASK]rity and lack of rhetoric were to be amongst the defining qualities of Imagist poetr[MASK] . Through[MASK]his friendship with Laurence Binyon , Pound had already developed an interest in Japanese art by e[MASK]ami[MASK]ing Nishiki @-@ e prints at the Br[MASK]tish Muse[MASK]m , and he quick[MASK]y became absorbed in the study of related Japanese verse forms . 
 In an article in La Fran[MASK]e , 1915 , the French critic , Remy [MASK]e Gourm[MASK]nt [MASK]escribed the Imagists as descendants of the French Symbolistes and in a 1928 letter to the French critic and translator René Taupin , Pound was keen to emp[MASK]asise another ancestry for Imagism , pointing out that Hulme was i[MASK]debted to a Symbolist tra[MASK]ition , linking back via [MASK]illiam Butle[MASK] Yeats , Arthur Symo[MASK]s and the Rhymers ' Club generation of Brit[MASK]sh poet[MASK] to Mal[MASK]armé. and the Symbolist source was amplified further in Taupin 's study publi[MASK]hed in 1929 , in which he concluded however great the divergence of technique and language ' between the image of the Imagist and the ' symbol ' of the Symbolists there is a difference only of precision ' . In 1915 , Pound edited the poetr[MASK] of another 1890s poet [MASK] Lionel Johnson for the publisher Elk[MASK]n Mathews . In his introduction , he wrote 
 
 = = Early publications a[MASK]d statements of intent = = 
 
 In 1911 , Pound introduced two other poets to the Eiffel Tower g[MASK]oup : his former fiancée Hilda Doolitt[MASK]e ( who had started signing her work [MASK].D. ) and her future husband Richard Aldington . These two [MASK]ere i[MASK]terested in [MASK]xploring Greek poeti[MASK] models , especially Sappho , an interest tha[MASK] Pound shared . The compression of expression t[MASK]at [MASK]hey achieved by [MASK]ollo[MASK]ing the Greek example co[MASK]plemented the[MASK][MASK]roto @-@ Imagist inter[MASK]st in Japanese poetry , and , in 191[MASK] , during a meeting with them in the Brit[MASK]sh Museum tea room , Pound told H.D. an[MASK] Aldington that they were Imagistes and even appended the signature H.D. Imagiste to some [MASK]oems they were discussing . 
 Wh[MASK]n Harriet Monroe started her Poetry magazine in 1911 , she had asked Pound to act as foreign editor . In October 1912 , he submi[MASK]ted thereto [MASK]hree poems each by H.D. and Aldington under the I[MASK]agiste rubric , ( published i[MASK] the November 1912 second issue thereof ) with a note whic[MASK] described Aldingto[MASK] as ' one of the ' Imagistes [MASK] . This note , along with the a[MASK]pendix note ( ' The Complete Works of T. S. Hulme ' ) in Pound 's book ( also pu[MASK]lished in Au[MASK]umn 1912 ) ent[MASK]tled Ripostes are considered to be first appearances [MASK]f the word Imagiste ( later anglicised to ' Imagists ' ) in print . 
 Aldington 's poems , Chorico[MASK] , To a Greek Marble , and Au Vieux Jardin , were in the Novemb[MASK]r issue of Poetry , and H.D. ' s , Hermes of the Ways , Priapus , and Epigram , appeare[MASK] in the January 1913 issue ; Imagism as a mo[MASK]ement was launched .[MASK]Poetry 's April issue publi[MASK]hed what came to [MASK]e seen as " Imagism 's enabling text " , the haiku @-@ like poem of Ezra Pound entitled " In a Stat[MASK]on of the Metro " : 
 The apparition o[MASK] these faces in the crowd ; 
 Pe[MASK]als on a wet , black bough . 
 The March 1913 issue of Poetry contained A Few Don 'ts by an Imagiste and the essay entitled Imagisme both written by Pound , with the latter being att[MASK]ibuted to [MASK]lint . The latter contained this succinct statement o[MASK] the group 's position : 
 Direct treatment of the "[MASK]thing " , whether subjective or objective . 
 To use absolutely no word that does not contribute to the presentation . 
 [MASK]s regarding rhythm : to compose in sequence of the musical phrase , not in sequence o[MASK] th[MASK] metronome . 
 Pound 's note opened with a definition o[MASK] an image as " that which presents an intellectu[MASK]l and emotiona[MASK] complex in an instant of time[MASK]"[MASK]. Pound goes on to state , " It is better to present one Image in a lifetime[MASK]than to produce voluminous works " . His list of " don 'ts " reinforced his thr[MASK]e statements in " Imagism " , while warning that they should not be considered as dogma but as the " result of long contemplation " . Taken [MASK]ogether , thes[MASK] two texts comprised the Imagist programme for a return to what [MASK]hey saw as the best poetic practice of the past . F.S. Flint commented " we have never cl[MASK]imed to have i[MASK]vented the moon . We do not pretend that our ideas are original . " 
 The 1916 preface to Some Imagist Poets comments " Imagism does not merely mean the presentation of pictures . Imagism refers to the manner [MASK]f presentation , not to the subject . " 
 
 = = Des Imagistes = = 
 
 Determined to promote the work of[MASK]the Imagists , and particularly [MASK]f Aldington and H.D. , Pound decided to publish an anthology under th[MASK] title Des Imagistes . It was first published in Alfred Kreymborg 's little magazine The Glebe and was later[MASK]published in 1914 by Alfred and Charles Bo[MASK]i in New York and by Ha[MASK]old Monro at the Poetry Bookshop in London [MASK] It became one of the most important and influential English @-@ language collections of modernist verse . Includ[MASK]d in the thi[MASK]ty @-@ seven poems were ten poems[MASK]by Aldington , seven by[MASK]H.D. , and[MASK]six by Pound . The book also included work by F.S. Flint , Skipwit[MASK] Cannell , Amy Lowell , William Carlos Williams , James Joyce , Ford Madox Ford , A[MASK]len Upward and John Cournos.Max Mi[MASK]helson was also another included in [MASK]he important 1963 anthology by Wil[MASK]iam Pratt The Imagist [MASK]oem Modern Poetry in miniature . 
 Pound 's editorial choices were based on what he saw as the degree of sympathy that these[MASK]writers displayed with Imagist precepts , rather than active p[MASK]rticipation in a group as such . Williams , who was based in the United States , had not participated in any of the dis[MASK]ussions of [MASK]he Eiffel Tower group .[MASK]However , he[MASK]and Pound[MASK]had long been correspondin[MASK] on the question of the renewal of poetry along similar lines . Ford [MASK][MASK]s included at least partly because of hi[MASK] strong influence on Pound , as[MASK]the younger poet made the transition fr[MASK]m his earlier , Pre @-@ Raphaelite @-@ influenced style towards a harder , more modern way of writing . The inclusion of a poem by Joyce , I Hear an Army , which was sent to Pound by W.B. Yeats , took on a wider importance in the history o[MASK] literary modernism , as t[MASK]e subsequent cor[MASK]espondence between the two led to the serial publication , at Pound 's behest [MASK] of A Portrait of [MASK]he Artist as a[MASK]Young Man in The Egoist . Joyce 's poem is not writte[MASK] i[MASK] free verse , but in rhyming quatrains . However , it stro[MASK]gly reflects Pound 's interest in [MASK]oems written to be sung to music , such as those by the troubadours and Guido Cavalcanti . The [MASK]ook met with little popular or critical success , at least partly because it had no i[MASK]troduction or commentary to explain what the poets were attempting to do , and a number of copies were returned to the publisher . 
 
 = = Some Imagist Poets = = 
 
 The follo[MASK]ing year , Pound and Flint[MASK]fell out over their diffe[MASK]ent interpretations of the history and goal[MASK] of the group arising from an article on the h[MASK]story of Imagism written by Flint and published in The Egoist in May 1915 . Flint was at pains to emphasise the contribution of the Eiffel Tower poets , especial[MASK][MASK] Edward Storer . Pound , [MASK]ho believed that the " Helleni[MASK] hardness " that he saw as the distinguishing quality of the poems of H.D. and Alding[MASK]on was likely to be diluted by the " custard " of Storer , was to play no further direct role in the history of the Ima[MASK]ists . He went on t[MASK] [MASK]o @-@ f[MASK]und the Vorticists with his frie[MASK][MASK] , the painte[MASK] and writer Wyndham Lewi[MASK] . 
 Around this time , the American Imagist Amy Lowell move[MASK] [MASK]o London , determined to promot[MASK] her own work and that of the other Imagist poet[MASK] . Low[MASK]ll was a wealthy heiress from Boston whose brother Abbott Lawre[MASK]ce Lowell was President of Harvard University from 1909 @-@ 1933 . She loved Ke[MASK]ts and cigars . She was al[MASK]o[MASK]an enthusiastic champion of literary experiment who was willing to use[MASK]her money to [MASK]ublish the group . Lowe[MASK]l wa[MASK] determined to c[MASK]ange the method of selec[MASK]ion from Pound 's autocratic editorial attitude to a more democratic m[MASK]nner . This new editorial policy was stated in [MASK]he Preface t[MASK] the first anthology to appear under her [MASK]eadership : " In this new book we have follow[MASK]d a slightly[MASK]different arrangemen[MASK] to that of our former An[MASK]hology . Instead of an arbitrary selection by an edit[MASK]r , each poet has been per[MASK]itted to repres[MASK]nt himself by the work he considers his b[MASK]st , the only stipu[MASK]ation being that it should not yet have appeared in book form . " [MASK]h[MASK] outcome was a series of Imagist anthologies under the title Some Imagist [MASK]oets . The first of these appeared in 1915 , planned and assembled mainly by H.D. and [MASK]ldingt[MASK]n . Two further issues , both edited by Lowell , were published in 1916 and 1917 . These three [MASK]olumes featured m[MASK]st of the original poets , ( also including imagis[MASK] poetry [MASK]y the American poet John Gould Fletcher ) , w[MASK]th the exception of Pound , who had tried to[MASK]persuade her to drop th[MASK] Imagist name from her publi[MASK]ations and who sardonically dubbed this phas[MASK] of Imagism " Amy [MASK][MASK]@ gism . " 
 Lowell [MASK]ersuaded D. H. Lawrence to contribute [MASK]oems to the 1915 and 1916[MASK]volumes , [MASK]aking him t[MASK]e only writer to publish as bot[MASK] a Geo[MASK]gian poet and an Imagist . Marianne[MASK]Moore also became associated with the group during this period . However , with W[MASK]rld War I as a backdrop , the times[MASK]were not easy for avant [MASK]-@ garde literary movements ( Aldington , for ex[MASK]mple ,[MASK]spent much of the war at the front ) , and the 1917 anthology effectively mar[MASK]ed the end [MASK]f the Imagists as a movement . 
 
 = = Imagists after Imagism = = 
 
 In 1929 , Walter Lowenfels jokingly sug[MASK]ested [MASK]hat Aldington should produce a new Imagist ant[MASK]ology . Aldington , by now[MASK]a succ[MASK]ssful novelist [MASK] took u[MASK] the suggestion an[MASK] enlisted the help of Ford and H.D. The result was the Imagist Antho[MASK]ogy 1930 , ed[MASK]ted by Aldington and including all the contributors to the four earlie[MASK] a[MASK]thologies with the exception [MASK]f Lowell , who had died , C[MASK]nnell , who had disappeared , and Pound , who declined . The appe[MASK]rance of this anthology initiated a critical discussion[MASK]of the place of the Imagists in the history of 20th @-@ centur[MASK] po[MASK]try . 
 Of the poets who were published in the various Imag[MASK]st antholo[MASK]ies , Joyce , Lawrence and Aldington are now primarily remembered and read [MASK]s novelists . Mar[MASK]anne Moore , who was at most a fringe member of the group , carved out a uni[MASK]ue poetic style of her own that retained an Imagist concern with compression of language . William Carlos Williams developed h[MASK]s poetic along distinctly American lines with his variable foot and a diction he claimed was [MASK]aken " from the mouths of Polish mothers " . Both Pound and H.D. turned to writing long poems , but retained much of the hard edge to their[MASK]language as an Imagist legacy . Most of the other members of the group are largely forgotten outside the c[MASK]ntext of the his[MASK]ory of Imagism . 
 
 = = L[MASK]gacy = = 
 
 Despite the movement 's short life , Imagism would deeply influence th[MASK] course of modernist poetry in English . Richard Aldington , in his 1941 memoir , writes : " I think the poems of Ezra[MASK]Pound , D.H. , Lawrence , and Ford Madox Ford will continue to be read . And[MASK]to a considerable extent T. S. Eliot and [MASK]is followers have carried on their operations from positions won by the Imagists . " 
 On the other hand , Wallace Stevens found shortcomings in the Imagist approach : " Not a[MASK]l objects are equal . The vice of imagism was that it did not recognize this . " With its demand for hardne[MASK]s , clarity and precision and its insisten[MASK]e on fidelity to appearances coupled with [MASK]ts rejection of irrel[MASK]vant subjective emotions Imagism had later effects that are demonstratable in T. S. Eliot 's ' Preludes ' and ' Mornin[MASK] at the Window ' and in D. H. Lawrence 's animal an[MASK] flower pieces . The rejection of c[MASK]n[MASK]entional verse forms in the nineteen @-@ twenties owe[MASK] much to the Imagist[MASK] repud[MASK]ation[MASK]of the Geor[MASK]ian Poetry style . 
 The influence of Imagism can be see[MASK] clearly in the work of the Objectivist poets , who came to prominence in the 1930s under the auspices of Pound and Willi[MASK]ms . The Objectivists worked mainly in free verse . Clearly linking Objectivism 's principles with Imagism [MASK]s , Louis Zukofsky insisted , in his intr[MASK]duction to the 1931 Objectivist issue of Poetry , on writing " which is the detail , not mirage , of seeing , of thinking with the things as they exist , and of directing[MASK]them along [MASK] line of melody[MASK]. "[MASK]Zukofsky w[MASK]s a major influenc[MASK] on the Language poets , who carried th[MASK] Imagist focus on formal concerns to a high level of development [MASK] Ba[MASK]il Bunting[MASK], another Objectivist poet [MASK] was a key figure in the early development of the British Poetry Revival , a loose movement that also absorbed the influence of the San Francisco Renaissance poets . 
 Imagism influe[MASK][MASK]ed a number of poe[MASK]ry circles and movements.With the Imagist[MASK] Free verse became a discipline and acqu[MASK]red status as a legitimate poetic fo[MASK]m . In the 1950s , especial[MASK]y , with the Beat generation , the Black Mountain poets , and others associated with the San Francisco Renaissance . In his seminal 1950 essay Projective Ve[MASK]se , Charles Olson , the t[MASK]eorist of the Black Mountain group , wrote " ONE PERCEPTION MUST IMMEDIATELY AND DIRECTLY LEAD TO A FURTHER PERCEPTION " ; his credo derived[MASK][MASK]rom and supplemented the Imagists . 
 Am[MASK]ng the Beats , Gary Snyder and Allen Ginsberg in particular were influenced [MASK]y the Imagist emphasis on Chinese and Japanese poetry[MASK]. William Carlos Williams was another who had a strong effect on the Beat poets , encoura[MASK]ing poets like Lew Welch and writi[MASK]g an introduction for the book[MASK]pub[MASK]ication of Ginsberg 's Howl ( 1955 ) . 
 
 
 = Operation Eastern[MASK]Exit = 
 
 Operation Eastern Exit was the codename given to the military evacuation of the United States embassy in Mogadishu , t[MASK]e capital of Somalia , in January 1991 . In late December 1990 , violence quickly envelo[MASK]ed the city as arme[MASK] militants began clas[MASK]ing with governme[MASK]t soldiers . On 1 January 1991 , the US Ambassador to Somalia , James Keough [MASK]ishop , contacted the Department of State requesting an evacuation of the embassy , which was approved [MASK]he following day . United [MASK]tat[MASK]s Central[MASK]Command began planning and mobilizing forces that evening . The initial plan was to evacuate with a military transport plane through the Mogadishu Interna[MASK]ional Airport , but this was later abandoned . A helicopter evacuation via the USS Guam and USS Trenton was the remaining option . 
 On[MASK]the morning of 5 January , a 60 @-@ person Marin[MASK] and Navy S[MASK]AL [MASK]ecurity detail was dispatched from Guam aboard two CH @-@ 53E Super Stallion helicop[MASK]ers to secure the embassy and prepare for the main evacuation .[MASK]The two helicopters returned to Guam with the first 61 evacuees . Throughout the day , foreign diplomats and civilians sought ref[MASK]ge at the embassy . Four [MASK]aves of five CH @-@ 46 Sea Knight helicopters each evacuated the embassy compound shortly after midnight on 6 January . The eva[MASK]uees were transported to Muscat , Oman , where[MASK][MASK]hey disembarked on 11 January . In total , 281 diplomats and civilians from 30 countries were ev[MASK]cuated , including 12 heads of missions ( eight ambassadors and four chargés d '[MASK]ffaires ) . 
 
 = = Background = = 
 
 In the late 1980s , there[MASK]was in[MASK]reasing rebellion against the rule of Somali President Siad Barre , a military dictator who maint[MASK]ined tight control of power and[MASK]had a record of hu[MASK]an rights abuses . [MASK]y 19[MASK]0 , wh[MASK]t began as civil disobedience evolved into a civil war , with se[MASK]eral militias organized to overthrow the central government . 
 In July 1989 , the embassy moved to a new , 80 @-@ acre ( 32 ha ) compound , 6 miles ( 9 @.@ 7 km ) from the previous embassy and J[MASK]mes [MASK]. Bishop was appointed as the United States ' am[MASK]assador to Somalia . Ambassador Bishop had s[MASK]gnificant experience in crisis management at US embassies . In 1967 , he was at the US Embassy in Beirut , Lebanon when the Six @-@ Day War erupted [MASK] About 3 @,@ 600 Americans were evacuated in 33 hours ; Bishop was one of 26 diplomats and soldiers that remained in the city . As deputy assistant secretary of state for Africa from 1981 – 87 , Bishop chaired several task forces for crises and gained experience in the State Department 's operations center as evacuations were carried out durin[MASK] several coups d 'etat . During his previous assignment as Ambassador to Liberia ( 1987[MASK]– 90 ) , Bishop was overseeing the voluntary e[MASK]acuation of embassy staff and civilians as a civil war in Liberia spread , when he left in March 1990 . Soon after returning to Washington to prepare for his new appointment to Somalia , he was appointed t[MASK] a taskforce to deal with the crisis in Liberia , which included a gradual e[MASK]acuation of American civilians and a rapid closure of the[MASK]embassy in August . 
 On 1 August , before leaving the US to take up his post in Mogadishu , Ambassador Bishop visited United States C[MASK]ntral Command — the military command for the Middle East and northeast Africa — where he spent most of the day with its commander , Gen[MASK] Norman S[MASK]hwarzkopf . Ambassador Bishop , aware of the ongoing strife , believed " the [MASK]dds were better than even that [MASK]e would have to leave Mogadishu under less than favorable circumsta[MASK]ces . " Ambassador Bishop understood from his past experiences in Beirut and L[MASK]beria the imp[MASK]rtance of being prepared to deal with emergencies and spent the afternoon working with military experts[MASK]to review the embassy 's Emergencies and Evacuation ( E & E ) plan until he was " satisfied ... that [ Central Command [MASK] r[MASK]alized that it might have to conduct an evacuation f[MASK]om M[MASK]gadishu and was [MASK]repared to do that . " I[MASK] its analysis of Operation Eastern Exit , the C[MASK]nter for Naval Analyses cited th[MASK] Ambassador Bishop 's previous experience and " clear understanding of his role " in the operation as one of the reasons Operation[MASK]Eastern Exi[MASK] went so well . 
 Hours after Ambassador Bishop 's visit to Central Command , Iraq invaded Kuwai[MASK] . In 1979 [MASK] the US negotiated access to an airport and port in both Mogadishu a[MASK]d Berbera ; because of limited access the US had to locations in the Persian Gulf area , maint[MASK]ining this access was a main interest for the Mogadish[MASK] embassy t[MASK] pursue as the US mobilized to intervene in Kuwait . [MASK] An increasing level of criminal violenc[MASK] prompted Ambassador Bishop to request the voluntary evacuation of dependents ( e.g. children and spouses of staff ) and non @-@ essential staff in early December , although fighting between the government and the United Somali Cong[MASK]ess ( a re[MASK]el militia ) remained no less than about 100 miles ( 160 km ) away . The voluntary evacuation later became a [MASK]andatory evacuation . By 19 December , the number of official US personnel in the city was re[MASK]uced from 147 to 37 ; around the same time , fighting betwee[MASK] the [MASK]overnment and rebels came within a[MASK]out 40 miles ( 64 km )[MASK]of Mogadishu . 
 
 = = = Colla[MASK]se [MASK]f the Barre government = = = 
 
 On 30 December , violence escalated " an order of [MASK]agnitude " [MASK]s militants e[MASK]tered Mogadishu , which was quickly enveloped by a general state of lawlessness . On 30 – 31 December , diplomats , including many stationed in offi[MASK]es elsewhere in the city , were collect[MASK]d and housed in the[MASK]e[MASK]bassy[MASK]compound ,[MASK]except two volunteers who rema[MASK]ned in the embassy 's K @[MASK]@ 7 residential apartments located across Afgoy Road from the embassy . Afgoy Road became a[MASK]" shooting gallery , " preventing those[MASK]i[MASK] safe @-@ havens o[MASK]tside the embassy from reaching it . On New Ye[MASK]r 's Day , the first American civilians began to seek refuge at the embassy . 
 Ambassador Bishop requested an evacuation of the American community on 1 Jan[MASK]ary , indicating that the evacuation could be with the planned Italian , French , or German evacuation [MASK]fforts , but preferred an evac[MASK]ation [MASK]y the US military .  [MASK] Ambassador Bishop had visited Central Command in August 1990 , where he worked with mi[MASK]itary experts to update the embassy 's E & E [MASK]lan . Likewise , government tro[MASK]ps faced a command[MASK]@-@ and @-@ control prob[MASK]em ; rep[MASK]rts indicated that arm[MASK] units were separating along clan lines , in some cases soldiers shot officers of a different clan [MASK]hen given orders they disagreed with . Thus , it became clear that safe passage to the airport would not be possible . Several other nations also had aircraft mobilized to reach Mogadishu , but faced the same problems of landing and transit of e[MASK]acuees to the airport . 
 On 4 January ,[MASK]several incidents , i[MASK]cluding a couple exchanges of gunfire , suggested that the embassy 's security detail was insufficient to hold off armed Somalis until the USS Guam and USS Trenton arrived with their hel[MASK]copters and soldiers , at tha[MASK] time scheduled to arrive on 7 January . Throughout the[MASK]day , foreign diplomats contacted the embassy desiring[MASK]to be evacuated ; the US welcomed these [MASK]equests , but required all of[MASK]them to find their own transportation to the embassy . 
 A Somali officer who h[MASK]d a previous relationship with the embassy , Major Siad , agreed[MASK]to travel [MASK]o rescue the German chargé d 'affaires and British a[MASK]bassador ( junior s[MASK]aff from the British embassy had previously come to the US embassy ) . The Soviet Union was [MASK]na[MASK]le to land a[MASK]plane in Mogadishu the previous day and the Soviet ambassador asked Ambassador Bishop if he and his staff could be rescued ; Ambassador Bi[MASK]hop , a tennis p[MASK]rtner of his Soviet counterpart , agreed but only if they found th[MASK]ir own way to the embassy . Seeing the helicopte[MASK]s on the morning of 5 January , they realized the Americans would not rema[MASK]n in the city much longer . At the request of Ambassador Bishop , Major Siad agreed to transport the Soviets , but only if he was paid enough ; the US embass[MASK] paid Major Siad , who returned with the Sovie[MASK] amba[MASK]sador and[MASK]38 [MASK]f his staff . The brother of [MASK]resident Barre , who was also a Major General and Chief of Police , showed up at the embassy in the afternoon with 25 members of his family requesting to be evacuated , but was turn[MASK]d away after a vocal conversation with the [MASK]mbassador . 
 The operation did not include soldiers to handle the evacuation control center ( ECC ) , which was set up in the JAO . A 44 @-@ person force consisting primarily of soldiers to handle the ECC was planned f[MASK]r insertion with the CH @-@ 53E Super Stallions after they had returned to the Guam . However , this was can[MASK]elled over objections from the commander of the security detail [MASK] The deficit was[MASK]partiall[MASK] handled by embassy staff who assisted a few soldiers from the security deta[MASK]l . The evacuees were groupe[MASK] into 15 @-[MASK] person " stick[MASK] " to be loaded onto the helicopters and were limited to one piece of luggage apiece . Some att[MASK]mpted[MASK]to bring more , resulting i[MASK] problems coordinating their evacuation . Furthermore , many evacuees had pet[MASK] they wanted to bring , which were not allowed . Most pets were killed by their owners ; some were given poison . Meanwhile , th[MASK] soldiers were allowed to consume[MASK]anything they want[MASK]d from the embassy 's c[MASK]mmissary , such as candy , sodas , and souvenirs ( most had been sta[MASK]ioned on ships for several months ) . They were also allowed use or take anything they[MASK]neede[MASK] from the embassy ;[MASK]the medic filled several bags with medical supplies to return to the ship . 
[MASK]As evening approached , w[MASK]rk began to prepa[MASK]e t[MASK]e HLZ for t[MASK]e main ev[MASK]cu[MASK]tion [MASK] The area was used as a pa[MASK]king lot and [MASK]evera[MASK] vehicles[MASK]were left without [MASK]eys by staff that had already been[MASK]evacuated . Some cars had to be broken into to be moved . Chemical lights were placed[MASK]in [MASK]he HLZ in a NATO " Y " pattern . The entire mission would be conduc[MASK]ed with night vis[MASK][MASK]n goggles , whi[MASK]h[MASK]required a[MASK]l lights in the embassy compound to be turned off .

 = [MASK] = Main[MASK]evacuation = = = 
 
 The main evacuation occurred in the early morning hours of 6 J[MASK]nuary [MASK]nd consisted of [MASK]our waves of five CH @-@ 46 helicopters . The timing of this phas[MASK] was determin[MASK]d by range of the [MASK]H @-@ 46 Sea Knight , which lack aerial [MASK]efueling capability ; the[MASK]ships were about 350 – 380 nautical miles ( 650 – 700 km ; 400 – 440 mi ) away during this phase . An AC @-@ [MASK]30 was sent from Saudi Arabia to provide gun[MASK]ire support during the evacuation and two UH @-[MASK] 1 Iroquois hel[MASK]copters were on standby to provide gunfire support , but were not de[MASK]loyed . 
 The first wave departed Guam at 23[MASK]: 43 . As the second wave landed , Major Siad arrived at the embassy gate accompanied by two truckloads of soldiers and [MASK]eld a grenade in one[MASK]hand and a radio in the other . His req[MASK]est to speak with the ambassador was granted[MASK]. Major Siad demanded that the evacuation cease immediately because the Somali [MASK]ov[MASK]rnment had not granted the US pe[MASK]mission to carry ou[MASK] such a milit[MASK]ry operation . He claimed that he would radio soldiers to shoot down the helicopters if the op[MASK]ration continued . The [MASK]econd and third waves were able to depart with[MASK]ut incident as the amba[MASK]sador negotiated with the Major , who f[MASK]nally agreed to sett[MASK]e the matter for s[MASK]v[MASK]ral [MASK]housand dollars in cash and key[MASK] to the ambassador 's armored car . Ambassador Bishop remained engaged in conversation with the Major until he reached the helicopter landing zone to depart with the final wave to prevent[MASK]the Major from re[MASK]eging on the deal . The final wave departed the embassy[MASK]at 1 : 49 and landed on Guam at 2 : 23 ; twenty m[MASK]nutes later , Ambassador Bishop declared the evacuation complete . 
 
 =[MASK]= = Aftermath at the embassy = = = 
 
 Armed looters were observed enteri[MASK]g the embassy compound as th[MASK] final wave departed . Th[MASK] doors of the chancery — the main building of the embassy — were reportedly blown open by R[MASK]Gs within two hours of the embas[MASK]y 's evacuation . Somali employees of the embassy — [MASK]nown as foreign service nationals ([MASK]FSNs [MASK] [MASK] could not be evacu[MASK]ted . Ambassador Bishop tried unsuccessf[MASK]lly to have these e[MASK]ployees airlifted to safer parts of Somalia . Many of the FSNs had sought refuge in the e[MASK]bassy with their families and about 30 were hired as guards and protected the embassy throughout the ordeal . Local banks had been closed for some time and the embassy was unable to pay the FSNs . The Ambassador left the FSNs with keys [MASK][MASK] the commissary and warehouse on t[MASK]e embassy compound and [MASK]hey [MASK]er[MASK] permitted to take anything they needed . 
 
 = = = Return to Oman = = = 
 
 A total o[MASK] 281 evacuees were taken from the [MASK]mbassy , including 12 heads of missions ( eight ambassadors and f[MASK]ur chargés d 'affaires )[MASK]and 61 Americans ( inc[MASK]uding Ambassador Bishop and 36 embassy staff ) . The [MASK]eads of miss[MASK]on were the ambassadors of t[MASK]e United States , Kenya , Nigeria , Soviet Union , Sudan , Turkey , United Arab Emirates [MASK] and United Kingdom and the chargés of the embassies of Germany , Kuwait , Oman , and Qatar . 
 Rather than disembark in nearby Mombasa , as originally thought by the evacuee[MASK] , the ships were ordered back to Oman — a five @-@ day journey . The[MASK][MASK]ailors and marines made way for the evacuees to share living quarters . When the chaplain of Guam asked crew to sign up as guides for the evacuees while aboard the vessel , two hundred signed up within an hour , and some of the sailors even dressed up as cl[MASK]w[MASK][MASK] to ease th[MASK] ordeal for children . At the request of the[MASK]ambassadors , a formal session w[MASK]th the ships ' senior officers was[MASK]hel[MASK] to express th[MASK]ir thanks [MASK] On 11 January , the evacuees were offloaded at Muscat , Oman . That afternoon , the American evacuees were flown to Frankfurt[MASK], Germany , [MASK]rom where they continued home . 
 
 
 = 2010 Claxton Shield = 
 
 The 2010 Claxton Shield was the 57th Claxton Shield tournament , the premier baseball competition in Australia , and was held from 6 November 2009 to 7 February 2010[MASK]. It was hai[MASK]ed as the precursor to the new Australia[MASK] Baseball L[MASK]ague t[MASK]at will start in the place o[MASK] the Claxton Shield in late 2010 to early 2011 . The Victoria Aces defeated South Austra[MASK]ia two games to nil [MASK]n the championship series[MASK]t[MASK] win t[MASK]e tournament ; this was the 22nd time the Claxton Shield had been awarded to a Victorian team . The competition was sponsored by[MASK]Domino 's Pizza . 
 At the conclusion of the regular season , the Victoria Aces finished in first place [MASK]ith a 17 – 7 record , earning home @-@ field advantage for the three @-@ game champi[MASK]nship series . South Australia hosted the three @-@ game semi @-@[MASK]final series against the New South Wales Patriots . Both teams finished with a 14 – [MASK]0 record . The Perth Hea[MASK] ( 12 – 12 ) and Queensland Rams ( 3 – 21 [MASK] both failed to qualify for the fin[MASK]ls . 
 
 = = Overview = = 
 
 In June 2009 , it was annou[MASK]ced[MASK]that the rights[MASK]to the Claxton Shield had been sold to[MASK]a new Australian Baseball League ( ABL ) , with ownership s[MASK]lit between Major League Baseball 's 75 percent share [MASK]nd the 25 percent share owned by the Australian Baseball Federation . The 2010 tournam[MASK]nt was considered preparation for the inaugural ABL season starting in 2010 – 11 . It varied from the 2009 Claxton Shield[MASK]by expanding the season to include ten rounds . Since an une[MASK]en number ( five ) teams were involved , four teams paired off for each round and pla[MASK]ed a three @-@ game series , while the remaining team took a bye . During the season , each team had two bye rounds and played two round[MASK] against each other team , one at home and one away . In tota[MASK] , t[MASK]e schedule allowed fo[MASK] 24 regular @-@ sea[MASK]on games per team before a postseason similar to the 2009 edition : the first @-@ place team directly qualified [MASK]or the [MASK]hampionship series and[MASK]played against the winner of a playoff series between the second- and third @-@ place te[MASK]ms . 
 During the reg[MASK]lar season , [MASK]ames were[MASK]pla[MASK]ed on a Friday night and[MASK]a doubleheader on Saturday ; in each doubleheader one of th[MASK] two games was shortened to seven innings . The exception to this was when [MASK]erth played their home games ; they pl[MASK][MASK]ed on a Thursday night instead of a doubleheader on Saturday . Ea[MASK]h postseason series [MASK]as scheduled for a Friday[MASK], Saturday and Sunday .

In both cases , the teams had a 19 @-@ man ros[MASK]er for the make @-[MASK] up game , and an expanded 21 @-@ man roster for the originally scheduled series .

 The 2010 Claxton Shield was c[MASK]ntested between five teams from around Australia . In previous years , many of the teams had played their home games at multiple venues . This season each team held their home games at only one venue . There was one scheduled exception to this at the start of the season : the New South Wales Patriots ' final home series against the Perth Heat was held at Gilchrist Ov[MASK]l , whereas all of the[MASK]r other home games were held at Blacktown Baseball Stadium . 
 As a[MASK]result of poor at[MASK]endance at Geelong Baseball Park , game one of the fifth @-@ round series between New South Wales and [MASK]he Victoria Aces was moved to La Trobe Unive[MASK]sity , Melbourne . Although the Geelong games had attracted crowds of no more than 500 , the moved [MASK]ame had [MASK]n attendance [MASK]f 2 @,@ 200 . Though no further regular season gam[MASK]s were moved , the finals series hosted by the Aces was held at La Trobe University as well .
