 = = = Dispositions = = = 
 
 Napoleon [MASK]ad calculated that Kutuzov would withdraw toward Vienna , expecting reinforcements from Russia ; he envisioned that the armies would engage in a great battl[MASK] at Vienna , and that this battle would decide the war [MASK] Consequently , Napol[MASK]on drew divisions [MASK]rom four of[MASK]the other seven corps of the[MASK]Grande Armée to[MASK]create a new VIII Corps . This corps was [MASK]o secure the north shore of the Danube , block any of the Austrian or Russian groups from reinforcing one anot[MASK]er and , more importantly ,[MASK]prevent Kutuzov from crossing the r[MASK]ver and escaping to Russia . 
 The new VIII Corps , under [MASK]he overall[MASK]command of Édouard Mortier , included three infantry divisions and a division of cavalry ( [MASK]ee Order of Battle [MASK]elow ) . Corps [MASK]ortier , as it was[MASK]known , crossed the Danube at Linz and Passau in early November 1805 and marched east , on the north bank of the[MASK]Danube . Operating independently , the corp 's cavalry conducted reconnaissance ahead of them and on the fla[MASK]ks . Gen. Gazan 's division ( about 6 @,@ 000 men ) took the lea[MASK] ; Mortier was with them . Th[MASK]y were followed[MASK]by Gen. Dupont 's division ( another 4 @,@ 000 [MASK] about one day 's march behind . Jean @[MASK]@ Baptiste Dumonceau 's division ( another 4 @,@ 000 )[MASK], marching[MASK]another day behind Dupont , brought up the rea[MASK] . A flotilla of 50 boats a[MASK]quired at Passau provided communications acros[MASK] the Danube . Before sending Mor[MASK]ier on his mission , Napoleon instructed him to protect his north flan[MASK] at all times against possible R[MASK]ssian reinforcements , advice he reiterated in subsequent written orders . Napoleon also advised Mortier to[MASK]secure al[MASK] crossings of the Danube between Linz an[MASK] Vienna . 
 On 9[MASK]November Gazan 's division reached Marbach an [MASK]er Donau and covered the 50 kilometer[MASK] ( 31 mi ) to Dürenstein by early on the foll[MASK]wing afternoon . Here it skirmished with some Russian patrols to the east of the town and expel[MASK]ed them . Feeling confident , the French established a forward post just upstream fro[MASK] Stein . In Dürens[MASK]ein itself Mortier set up his command post and directe[MASK] the establishment of a small field hospital . Although the position s[MASK]emed secure , [MASK]e had ignored Napoleon '[MASK] strict [MASK]nstructions[MASK]and n[MASK]glected to protect his left ( north ) flank . 
 This failure was an important factor when Mortier lost his corps ' so[MASK]@-@ called " eyes " : after he and Gazan [MASK]ad crossed the Danube , the French dragoons had veered to the northwest , leaving only three squadrons of the 4th Dragoons available for rec[MASK]nna[MASK]ssance . These had left the division and were op[MASK]rating inde[MASK]endently of [MASK]azan 's c[MASK]mmand . Consequently , Mortier and Gaza[MASK] marched [MASK]lindly through the narrow canyon west of Dürenstein , no[MASK] knowing what lay ahead of them[MASK]. Kutuzov had led the Coalition army across the Danub[MASK] at Krems , a short distance past Stein , and[MASK]destroyed the bridge behin[MASK] him . His actions deprived the Frenc[MASK] commanders of a possible route across the[MASK]Danube , putting th[MASK] deployment of the entire French division at further risk in the case of retreat . In this decision Kutuzov abandoned Vienna to the French , who were converging on the Austrian capital from the north , west and southwest , for the security of uniting with reinforcemen[MASK]s from Galicia . Kutuzov chose a military solution over a political one . 
 Un[MASK]nown to either Gazan or Morti[MASK]r , the Coalit[MASK]on had concentrated a force of approximately 2[MASK] @,@ 00[MASK] men ( mostly Russians and a few Austrians ) within a few kilometers of the French p[MASK]sition at Dürenstein . In comparison , Gazan 's division had only 6 @,@ 000 men[MASK]. The Austro @-@ Russian force was a mixture of infantry , Jägers ( usuall[MASK] deployed as skirmishers ) , Russian musketeers and Russian and Austrian cavalry , accompanied by more than 68 ar[MASK]illery pieces . Kutuzov , who had learned the military arts under the tutelage of the legendary Russian Generalissimo [MASK][MASK]vorov , had over[MASK]ll command . The Ru[MASK]sian cavalry , u[MASK]its of the greatly feared Cossacks , were[MASK]well @-@ suited for patrolling the river bank ; indeed , on 9 November they had taken 40 [MASK]rench[MASK]soldiers as prisoners . Furthermore , reinforceme[MASK]ts stood in Moravi[MASK] , less than two weeks ' march away . If the main body of the French army crossed the river , they would require [MASK]ime to prepare [MASK] Kutuzov would have ample warning of any large @-@ scale French movement . 
 Af[MASK]er the afternoon 's init[MASK]al skirmishing wi[MASK]h the French , Kutuzov held a council of war on[MASK]the evening of 10 November at Melk , at the g[MASK]eat abbey there . He knew severa[MASK][MASK]things . First , he k[MASK]ew the positions of the French from prisoners his Cossacks had captured . He also knew that Gazan had crossed at Linz and was well a[MASK]ead of any French reinforcem[MASK]nts : Dupont had crossed at Passau and , by [MASK]0 November , stood at Marbach , 50 kilometers ( 31 mi ) upstream , and Dumonceau was another 7 kil[MASK]meters ( 4 mi ) further behind him . K[MASK]tuzov knew the size of the French force--its division stren[MASK]th--and its positions , and he knew that most of the dragoons were not covering the French flank but had turned north . He als[MASK] knew , or had made a good supposition , about Napoleon 's orders [MASK] so he knew what [MASK][MASK] offer Mortier and Gazan as bait . 
 
 =[MASK]= = Battle plan = = = 
 
 In addition to the Russian[MASK]generals , the council included Austrian commanders Lieutenant Field Marshal Johann Heinrich von Schmitt and Fri[MASK]drich [MASK]arl W[MASK]lhelm , Fürst[MASK]zu Hohenlohe . Schmitt , who had[MASK]retired [MASK]rom the military in 1800 , h[MASK]d been recalled into se[MASK]vice after the Ulm debacle and had come to Kutuzov highly recommended by the Emperor . He w[MASK]s [MASK]n experienced tactician and stra[MASK]egist and had served in a variety of posts in the Habsburg military ; he[MASK]had been Archduke Charles ' trusted adviser during the campaigns fro[MASK] 1796 to 1800 and had assist[MASK]d in planning several of Charles ' victories [MASK] Upon his recall , Schmitt[MASK]was appointed Chief of the Quartermaster General Staff of the Coalition Army . The ge[MASK]erals [MASK]ad found among the Austrian force one Capt. Christoph Freiherr von Stiebar ( 1753 – 1824[MASK]) , who had knowledge of the local geography . 
 Together , Schmitt , Kutuz[MASK]v and the other generals , w[MASK]th von St[MASK]ebar 's advice on the local terrain , concocted a plan to encircle the French at Dürenstein . Russian commander Mikhail Andreyevich Miloradovich wou[MASK]d appr[MASK]ach Gazan 's division from the east , supporte[MASK] by Petr Bagration 's corps , and pin the French in place . Three additional colu[MASK]ns , commanded by Dmitry Dokhturov ([MASK]Doctorov ) , Maj. Gen. Strik and Schmitt , would outflank the French from the west and the north . They would offer , as bait , a rumor : the Russian army was retreating into Moravia and only a rearguard would be left at Krems .

 On the night of 10 – 11 November[MASK]a[MASK]Russian colum[MASK] under Strik 's command began its passage through the [MASK]arrow canyons , intent on ar[MASK]iving at Dürenstein by noon ; two more columns , under Dokhtorov and Schmitt , moved in wider semicircles , planning to pass through the mount[MASK]ins and attack the French , who were extended along the river bank[MASK]. Acc[MASK]rding to the plan , in lat[MASK] morning Strik[MASK]'s column would emerge from the mountains first and launch a fla[MASK]king assault on the[MASK]French right . This flanking attack , combined with Miloradovich 's frontal assault from Stein , would [MASK]orce [MASK]he French int[MASK] a vise ; encircled , they would have no option but to surrender--or die . To ensure the success of the plan , the second an[MASK] third columns , under Dokhtorov and Schmitt , would arrive[MASK]in early and mid @-@ afternoon and suppor[MASK] the earlier assa[MASK]lts . In this way , even if the French t[MASK]ied to retreat west to M[MASK]rbach , they would not escape the vise @-@ like grip of the Coalition army . 
 Mortier accepted the bait of a rumored Russian retreat . In the early morning of 11 November he and Gazan departed fr[MASK]m Dürenstein to seize St[MASK]in and Krems , presuming the [MASK]uss[MASK]ans[MASK]had either abandoned the settlements or left only a small rear @-@ guard behind . As they approached Stein , a column of Miloradovich 's troop[MASK] attacked the French forward positions . Thinking this force was the rumored Russian rear guard , Mortier ordered Gen[MASK] Gazan to counterattack and push east towards the town of Stein . Fighting spread though [MASK]he[MASK]villages of Oberl[MASK][MASK]ben , Unterloiben and the farm at Rothenhof . Instead of withdrawing , as a[MASK]rear guard would , more and more Russ[MASK]an troops appeared and engage[MASK] the French colum[MASK] . 
 Initially Gazan made rapid progress , but he quickly [MASK]ecognized that the opposing force was much stronger than the typical rear guard of a retreat[MASK]ng army . Realizing he had been duped and that Gazan 's troops[MASK]were tiring rapidly , Mortier sent orders to Dupont 's division to hurry forward . By mid @-@ morning the French mom[MASK]ntum had stalled ; Mortier committed most of his remaining [MASK]orces to drivi[MASK]g Miloradovich back , leaving a sing[MASK]e battalion--perhaps 300 [MASK]roops--to cover his northern flank , and sent the rest to attack the Russian right . Within 30 minute[MASK] he achieved the superiority of numbers he sought . His 4 @,@ 500 French opposed 2 @,@ 600 Russians and forced them back toward Stein while pressing an attack along the river . Miloradovich had no opt[MASK]on[MASK], for neithe[MASK] Stri[MASK] 's nor Dokhtorov 's flanking columns were to be seen . 
 At this stage of th[MASK] battle fighting paused . Mortier and Gazan waited for Dupont 's arrival while Kutuz[MASK]v an[MASK] Miloradovich waited for Strik 's and Dokhturov 's . Schmitt '[MASK] column was expected t[MASK] be the [MASK]ast to join the fight because it h[MASK]d to march the greatest distan[MASK]e . The timing of the respite varies , depending o[MASK] w[MASK]ose reports are consu[MASK]ted : f[MASK]ghting[MASK]paused at around 12 : 00 or 14 : 00 . St[MASK]ik arrived first and immediately assa[MASK]lte[MASK] Gazan 's line with three battalions , pushing the French out of Dürenstein . Caught between two strong for[MASK]es , Gazan attemp[MASK]ed to push his way back through Dürenstein , to reach the river where the flotilla could evacuate his exhausted [MASK]roops . Withdrawing through the narrow Danube canyon and fighting off the Russian force at their rear , Gazan and his d[MASK]vision were trapped when more of Stri[MASK] 's Russians appeared to block their retreat . The narrow defiles hampered the Russians ; Strik 's men had [MASK]o march out of the canyons , form ranks and attack in waves . Despite S[MASK]rik 's continuous assault in the next two to three hours , Mortier and Gazan pushed the Russians back up the narrow fissu[MASK]e in the hillside . At this p[MASK]int , Dokhturov 's column appeared behind the French line and joined the battle . The French were outnumbered more than thre[MASK] to one , assaulted in the front by Miloradovich 's colu[MASK]n , [MASK]n the middle by Strik 's and in the rear by Dokhturov . 
[MASK]Earlier in the morning Dupont had proceeded with his column south and east along the river , from Marbach , according to instructions . Even before the arrival of Mortier 's courier , he heard the sound of artillery in the distance and sent riders ahead to discover the cause . They came back to report that a Russian column ( Dokhtu[MASK]ov [MASK]s ) was descending from the mountains to take the road to Dürenstein . Realizing this would separate him from the forward division , Dupont hustled his troops towa[MASK]d the sound [MASK]f battle and deployed them to take the Russians in the fl[MASK]nk . The French assault , heralded by cannon fire , caused Dokhturov 's troops to turn their attention from Gazan 's bele[MASK]guered force to face these [MASK]ew assailants . Alt[MASK]ough superior in numbers , Dokhturov 's column had[MASK]no supporting artillery , and the narrow space prevented them from taking advantage of their size . It was Dokhturov 's turn to face attackers at his front and rear , until the arrival of Schmitt 's column , which had wended i[MASK]s way throug[MASK] the mountains in the west . 
 Schmitt arrived at dusk , and the [MASK]ction continued well after dark ; in mid @-@ November night falls [MASK]t close to 17 : 0[MASK] in the upper Danube climes . Desp[MASK]te the darkness , Schmitt descended out of t[MASK]e defiles and deployed his troops to assail Dupont 's flank . As his Russians entered the fra[MASK] , they came between a battalion of French and another of Russians . With the additional forc[MASK] , the French were o[MASK]erwh[MASK]lmed , but most of the shooting subsided when the combatants could not tell apart friend from[MASK]foe in the dark . Under the cover of darkness , Mortier used the French flotilla to evacuate his exhausted troop[MASK] to the south bank . The F[MASK]ench and Russians continued to skirmish fitf[MASK]lly into the night as sentries enc[MASK]untered one another in th[MASK] dark . Portions of Gazan '[MASK] force provided any necessary rear guard action , and the fol[MASK]owing morning the remaining m[MASK]n were evacuated from the north shore of[MASK]the Danube , while they [MASK]aintained posse[MASK]sion of only Spitz and Weissenkirchen on the north bank . 
 
 = = = Losses = = = 
 
 The losses were staggering : Gazan lost close to 40 pe[MASK]cent of h[MASK]s division to death and wounds . Aside from losing five g[MASK]ns , 47 officers and 895 men under his command were [MASK]aptured , brin[MASK][MASK]ng the loss of effectives closer to 60 percent ; furthermore , he[MASK]lost the eagles of the 4th Infantry Regiment ( France ) and the eagle and guidon of the 4th Dragoon[MASK] . The Russians lost arou[MASK]d 4 @,@ 000[MASK], about 16 percent of their forc[MASK] , and two regimental colors . The Austrian Lieutenant Field Marshal Schmitt w[MASK][MASK] killed as the battle concluded , probably by Rus[MASK]ian [MASK]usketry in the confu[MASK]ed melee . The [MASK]iney[MASK]rds and the villages of Ober- and [MASK]nte[MASK]loiben were destroyed , as was most of Dü[MASK]enstein and Stein . Krems was [MASK]eavily dam[MASK]ged ; the French plundered the to[MASK]n at least twice , and " barbarously ha[MASK]dled " its inhabitants . [MASK] 
 = = Aftermath = = 
 
 Both sides claimed victory . Althoug[MASK] losses were fairly equal in terms of numbers--4,000 wounded or dead on each side--the[MASK]Coalition forces went into battle with 24 @,[MASK] 000 men while the French started with Gazan 's divisi[MASK]n of about[MASK]6 @,@ 000 , which grew close to 8[MASK]@,@ 000 when Dupont 's men joined the fighting in the after[MASK]oon . Regardless , Gaza[MASK] 's division was nearly destroyed ; t[MASK]e 30 percent [MASK]osses experienced by the French fell[MASK]predominantly on his division . Clearly for both sides , the fighting was hard . [MASK]h[MASK] weather had been cold ; an early storm[MASK]had left slick icy mud in the roadways , a[MASK]d icicle[MASK] " like chandeliers " hung from the trees . 
 For the Coalition , the Russians were secure on the north bank of th[MASK] Danube , awaiting reinforcements from Galicia ; the bridges between Linz and Vien[MASK]a had been destroyed[MASK], making French access to the Austrian cap[MASK]tal more difficult , but not impossible . After six mont[MASK]s of fighting in which the Austrians had enjoyed little good news ,[MASK]the Coal[MASK]tion could claim a difficult and timely victo[MASK]y . The French had retreated from the field with a badly[MASK]mauled division and Kutuzov had secured the r[MASK]ght flank . Indeed , Francis was so pleased with [MASK]he out[MASK]om[MASK] at Dürenstein that he awarded Kutuzov the Military Order of Maria Theresa . 
 [MASK]or the Frenc[MASK] , the survival of the Corps Mortier seemed no[MASK]hing short of a m[MASK]racle . The remainder o[MASK] Ga[MASK]an 's division crossed the river the next morning and eventually recuperated in Vienna , which the Fren[MASK][MASK] acquired by deception later [MASK]n the month . More importantly for them , the French force had performed well over difficult terrain and under terrible combat co[MASK]ditions . Initially there had been some panic and parts of at least one French[MASK]battalion had tried to escape on the flotilla craft . They had lost control of the boats in the current and smashed into the pillars of the burned bridge at Krems , overturning their boats . Tossed into the icy river , most had drowned . Despite this initial panic , Gaz[MASK]n 's column retained its cohesion , and responded well to various difficult demands[MASK]. Dupont had demonstrated his tactical acumen : when he heard cannon fire , he directed his troops toward it to support the French d[MASK]vision . In terms of French staffing , Mor[MASK]ier '[MASK] f[MASK]ilure to guard his flank , especially in the face[MASK]of Napoleon 's dir[MASK]ct advice , adversely influenced his relationship with his [MASK]ommander . However , in the immediate [MASK]eeks ahead , the flamboyant Murat did more to annoy Napoleon than Mortier had . I[MASK] assessing the battle and its aftermath , historians have laid the blame and credit for its outcome not only on Mortier and Gazan : " Napol[MASK]on , aware of Mortier 's danger and his own culpab[MASK]l[MASK]ty for it , vented his frustration on [MASK]urat , whom he unjustly accused of abandoning Mortier for the empty glo[MASK]y of riding through Vien[MASK]a . " 
 After th[MASK] victory at[MASK]Austerlitz , Napoleon dispersed the VIII Corps and reassigned [MASK]ortier . However disappointed he may have been with Mortier , Napoleon was ple[MASK]sed with Gazan 's performance . As recognition of his conduct in what the French called " [MASK]he [MASK]mmo[MASK]tal Battle of [MASK]ürenstein " , Gazan received the Officer 's Grand Cross of the Legion of Ho[MASK]or . 
 The loss of Schmitt was a significant blow to the Austrian military organization . Called out [MASK]f retirement for this specific task , he was one of their most experienced general staff o[MASK]ficers , other than the Archduke Charle[MASK] . From the summer of 1796 until his retirement in 1800 he had been Chief of the Quartermaster General Staff of the Army , the Lower Rhine , the Rhine and the [MASK]rmy of Ge[MASK]many . Furthermore , he w[MASK]s a trusted member of Archduke Charles ' staff . He had helped to design several of Charles ' more important victories at Emmendingen , Schliengen , the sieges at Kehl and Hü[MASK]ige[MASK] , the battles[MASK]at Ostrach and Stockach [MASK] and the nor[MASK]hern Swiss Campaign of 1799 th[MASK]t include[MASK] battles at Winterthur and Zürich . An experience[MASK] officer and excellent tactician , h[MASK] m[MASK]ght well have made a more eff[MASK]ctive Ch[MASK]ef of the Quartermaster Ge[MASK]eral Staff of th[MASK] Coalition Army at the Battle of Austerlitz than his eventual replacement , Franz von Weyrother[MASK]. In Schmitt 's absence Weyrother , the architect of the Austrian catastrop[MASK]e at Hohenlinden in 1800 , was chosen to develop the general battle [MASK]lan of Coalition acti[MASK]n [MASK]t Austerlitz . Schmitt , undoubtedly a [MASK]ar better tactician than Weyrother , and possesse[MASK] of superior training an[MASK][MASK]mapping skills , would have developed a mo[MASK]e realistic Coalition plan for Aus[MASK]erlitz . Schmitt 's presence would probably not have been enough to turn that defeat[MASK]into a victory , but it would have mitigated the magnitude of the Coalition 's losses ; Austerlitz was consi[MASK]ered one of Napoleon 's finest[MASK]triumphs[MASK]. 
 [MASK]n the broader picture [MASK] despite the important major naval [MASK]ngagements , the outcome of the War of [MASK]he Third Coalition was determined on the Continent , pred[MASK]minantly in the two major land operations . In the Ulm ca[MASK]paign , the Habsburgs achieved some minor victo[MASK]ies , such as Klenau 's at Haslach @-@ Jungingen , but ultimately lost an entire army an[MASK] an officer corps . The latter would not resume arms against France until f[MASK]rmally excha[MASK]ged . This condit[MASK]on crippled the Austrian military leadership and forced the recall of such pensioners as Schmitt out of [MASK]etirement . After the c[MASK]pitulation at Ulm , isolated portions of the Austrian mil[MASK]tary evaded capture and jo[MASK]ned with their Russian allies ; Michael von K[MASK]enmayer 's corps slipped out of the encirclement[MASK]and joined Kutuzov 's force . A few other small forces refused to capitulate and seemingly melted into the Bavarian mountains and the Thurging[MASK]an forests[MASK], to rea[MASK]pear in Bohemia for Austerlitz . Sixteen hundred cavalry , including Archduke Ferdinand and Prince Schwarzenberg , broke out of [MASK]lm before its capitulation . Maximilian , Count of Merveldt , led his column back through the mountains into Austria , fighting rear gua[MASK]d a[MASK]tions against pursuing [MASK]r[MASK]nch forces at the Steyer ( St[MASK]yr ) and Mariazell [MASK] Th[MASK]se [MASK]lusive units were [MASK]nsufficient t[MASK] balance heavy lo[MASK]ses at key battles in which the Austrians could not hold their own against the French . Between the Ulm capitulation and the Austrian and Russian defeat at Austerlitz , there were other minor achievements[MASK]: a successful skirmish between the cavalry that escaped from Ulm and the French near the town of Nördlingen , the contested victory at Dürenstein , and another within days at Schöngrabern . 
 The second determining event , the decisive French victo[MASK]y at the Battle of Aus[MASK]erl[MASK]tz over the combined Russian and Austrian armies , forced the [MASK]ustria[MASK] withdrawal from the Coalition [MASK] The s[MASK]bse[MASK]uent P[MASK]ace of Pressburg , signed on 26 December 1[MASK]05 , reinforced the earlier t[MASK]eaties of Campo For[MASK]io and Lunéville[MASK]. Furthermore , Austria ceded land t[MASK] Napoleon 's German[MASK]allies , and paid an indemnity of 40 million francs . Victory at Austerlitz also gave Napoleon the latitude to create a buffer zone of German states between France and the states of Prussia [MASK] Russia , and Austria . These measures did not establish a lasting peace [MASK]n the continent . Prussian worries about growing French influence in Central Europe spar[MASK]ed the War of the Fourth Coa[MASK]ition in 1806 , in which Austria did not participate . 
 
 = = Battlefield commemorations = = 
 
 Until 1805 , Dürenstein was probably b[MASK]st known as the village in which crusader Richard the Lionheart was held by Leopold V , Duke of Austria . I[MASK] 1741 , during the War of the Austrian Succession , several hundred local v[MASK]llagers had held off the French and Bavarian armies , intent on capturing Vienna , by painting drain pipes to look like cannons , and beating on dru[MASK]s , thus sug[MASK]esting the presence of a large force . 
 After 1805 , the exploits of 40 @,@ 00[MASK] French , Russian , an[MASK] Austrian soldier[MASK] excited the European imagination . General Schmit[MASK] 's grave has never been found , but in 1811 a monument for him was erected at the Stein Tor , the gate leading from the old village o[MASK] Krems to the hamlet of Stein . [MASK]he ho[MASK]se in which C[MASK]ptain von Stiebar lived was marked with a bronze plate commemorati[MASK]g his contri[MASK]ution to the[MASK]battle . In 1840 , a Spani[MASK]h lithogr[MASK]pher created an image of the battle , which was later expanded by English lithographer John Outhwaite . The image depicts the evacuation of Fre[MASK]ch troops via the Danube flotilla ( see Infobox image ) on a moonlit [MASK]ight . In fact , the moon was [MASK]n its last quarter phase[MASK]48 hours later , a[MASK]d on 11 November probably did not provide as much [MASK]ight as depicted in the image . 
 In 1836 , Jean Antoine Siméon Fort ( French , 1793 – 1861 ) , a historical painter , created a watercolor of the [MASK]attle , Combat de Dürnstein le[MASK]11 novembr[MASK] 1805 ( ( English ) Battle of Dürenstein of[MASK]11 November 1805 ) , which is in the Trianon collection at Vers[MASK]illes . 
 In [MASK]he Russian novel War and Peace , Leo Tolstoy devoted several pages to[MASK]t[MASK]e battle , its prelude , and its aftermath , and the delivery of its news to the Tsar by P[MASK]ince A[MASK]drew . Between Düren[MASK]tein and Rossatz , at the edge of the Loiben plain , stands the " Little Frenchman " memori[MASK]l ( see ima[MASK]e ) erected i[MASK] 1905 to commemorate the battle ; it bears the names of Mortier , Gazan , Kutuzov , Schmitt , and others on a copper @-@ engraved plate .

 = [MASK] = = Lawsuit = = = [MASK] 
 
 Lesnar had previously [MASK]igned a non @-@ compete clause in order to be released from hi[MASK] contract with WWE , which prohibited him from working for any other pr[MASK]fessional wrestling companies before[MASK]June 2[MASK]10 . However , he decided to challenge this ruling in court . WWE responded with a counterclaim after Lesnar breached the agreement by appearing at a New Japan Pro W[MASK]estling show in 2004 . In July 2005 , the two sides dropped their claims and entered negotiations to renew their relationship . WWE had offered Lesnar a contract , but on August 2 , 2005 , WWE 's officia[MASK] website reported that Le[MASK]nar had[MASK]withdrawn from any involvement with the company . The lawsuit began to enter settlement talks on September 21 , but[MASK]did not get solved . 
 On January 14 , 2006 , Judge Christopher Droney stated that unless WWE gave him a good argument between then and the 25th , he would rule in fa[MASK]or of Lesnar , giving him a summary judgment . This would have enabled Lesna[MASK] to work anywhere , im[MASK]ediately . WWE wa[MASK] later granted a deadline postponement . On April 24 , WWE an[MASK]ounced on WWE.com that both parties had reached a settlement . On June 12 , a federal judge di[MASK]missed the case at th[MASK] request of both[MASK]legal parties .

 After his match at WrestleMania XX , Lesnar sidelined his career in W[MASK]E to pursue a caree[MASK] in the National Football League ( NFL ) despite not playing American football since high school . The WWE issued this statement on th[MASK]ir official website , WWE.com , following his departure :

Brock has wrestled his entire profe[MASK]sional career [MASK]n the [MASK]WE and we are proud of his accomplishments and wish him the best in his new ende[MASK]vor . 
 Lesnar l[MASK]ter told a Minnesota radi[MASK] show that he had " three wonderful years " in WWE , but had grown unhappy and always w[MASK]nted to play pro football , adding that he did not want to be 40 years old and wondering if he c[MASK]ul[MASK] have "[MASK]made it " in football . In an interview abo[MASK]t the [MASK]FL , he stated : 
 This is no load of bull ; it 's no WWE stunt . I am dead serious about this . I ain 't afraid of anything and I ain 't afraid of anybody . I 'v[MASK] been an underdog in athletics since I was five . I got zero college offers for wrestling . Now people say I[MASK]can 't play football , that it 's a [MASK]oke . I say I can . I 'm as good an athlete as a lot of guys in the NFL , if not better[MASK]. I 'v[MASK] always had to figh[MASK] for everything . I [MASK]asn 't the best technician in amateur wrestl[MASK]ng but I was strong , had great conditioning , and a hard head . Nobody[MASK]could break me . As long as I have that , I don 't give a damn what anybody else thinks .

 = Constant k[MASK]filter = 
 
 Constan[MASK] k filters , also k @-@ type filters , are a type of electro[MASK][MASK]c filter designed using the image method . They are the or[MASK]ginal and simplest filters produced by this methodology and consist of a ladder network of identical sections of passive components . Historically , they are the fir[MASK]t filters that could approach the ideal filter frequency response to within any prescribed limit with the addition of a sufficient[MASK]numbe[MASK] of sections . However , they are rarely considered for a modern design , the principles b[MASK]hind th[MASK]m having been superseded by other methodologies which a[MASK]e more acc[MASK]rate in their prediction of filter response . 
 
 = = Hist[MASK]ry = = 
 
 Constant k filters were invented by George Campbell . He published hi[MASK] work in 1922 , but[MASK]had clearly invented the filters some time before , as[MASK]his colleague at AT & T Co , Otto Zobel , was already making improvements to the design at this time . Campbell 's filters were fa[MASK] superior t[MASK] the simpler [MASK]ingle element circuits that had been use[MASK] previously . Campbel[MASK] called his filters electric wave[MASK]filters ,[MASK]but this term later came to mean any filter that passes waves of some frequencies but not other[MASK] . Many new forms of wave filter were subsequently i[MASK]vented ; an earl[MASK] ( and impor[MASK]ant ) variatio[MASK] was the m @-@ derived filter by Zobel who coined the term constant k for the Campbell filter in order to distinguish them . 
 The great a[MASK]vantage Campbell 's filters had over the RL circuit and other simple filters of the tim[MASK] wa[MASK] that they could be[MASK]designed for any d[MASK]sired degree of stop band rejection or steepness of tran[MASK]ition between pass band and stop band . It was o[MASK]ly necessa[MASK]y to add more filter s[MASK]ctio[MASK]s until the desired response was obtain[MASK]d . 
 The filters w[MASK]re designed by Campbell for the purpose of separating multiplexed telephone cha[MASK]nels on transmission lines , but their subsequent use has been much more widespread than that . The design techniques used by Campbell have largely been superseded [MASK] However , the ladd[MASK]r topology used [MASK]y Campbell with[MASK]the constant k is still in use[MASK]today with implementations of modern[MASK]filter designs such as the[MASK]Tchebyscheff filter . Campbell gave constant k [MASK]esigns for low @-@ pass , high @-@ pass and band @-@ pass filters . Band @-[MASK] stop and multiple band filters are also possible . 
 
 = = Terminology = = 
 
 Some of the impedance terms and section terms used in this article are pictured in the diagram below . Image theory defines quantities in terms of an infinite cascade of two @-@ port sections , and in the case of the filters being discussed , an infinite ladder network of L @-@ sections . Here " L " should not be confused with[MASK]the inductance L – in electronic filter topology , " L " refers to the sp[MASK]cific filter shape which resemble[MASK] inverted letter " L " . 
 The sections of the hypotheti[MASK]al infinite filter are made of series elements [MASK]aving impedance 2Z and shunt elements with admittance 2Y . The factor of two is introduced for mat[MASK]emat[MASK]cal convenience , since it is usual to work in terms of h[MASK]lf @-@ sections where it disappears . The image impedance of the input and output port of a section will generally not be the same . However , for a mid @-@ series section ( that is , a section [MASK]rom halfway through a series element to halfway through the next series element ) will[MASK]have [MASK]he same image impedance on both[MASK]ports due to symmetry . This image [MASK]mpedance[MASK]is designated ZiT due to the " T " topology of[MASK]a mid @-@ series section . Likewise , the image impedance of a mid @-@ shunt section is design[MASK]te[MASK] ZiΠ due to[MASK]the " Π " topology . Half of such a[MASK]" T " or " Π " section is called a half @-@ section , which is also an L @-@ section but with half the element values of the full L @-@ section . The image impedance of the half @-@ sectio[MASK] is dissimilar on the inpu[MASK] and output ports : on the sid[MASK] presenting the series element it is equal to the mid @-@ series ZiT , but on the side presenting the shunt element it is equal to the mid @-@ shunt ZiΠ . There are thus two variant ways of using a half @-@ secti[MASK]n . 
 Parts of this arti[MASK]le or section rely on the [MASK]eader [MASK]s knowledg[MASK] of the compl[MASK]x impedance representation of capacitors and inductors and on knowledge of the frequency domain represen[MASK][MASK]tion of sig[MASK]als .

 Thus , k will have units of impedance , that is , ohms . It[MASK]is readily apparent that in order fo[MASK] k to[MASK]be co[MASK]stant , Y must be the dual impedance of Z. A physica[MASK] interpretation of k can be given by observing that k is th[MASK] limiting value of Zi as the si[MASK]e of the section ( in terms of values of its component[MASK] , such as inductances , capacitances , etc . ) approaches zero , wh[MASK]le keepi[MASK]g k at its initial value . Thus , [MASK] is the characteristic impedance , Z0 , of the transmission line that would be formed by these infinitesimally small sections . It is also the image impedance of the[MASK]section at resonance , in the case of band @-@ pass filters , or at ω =[MASK]0 in the case of low @-@ pass filters .  = = = Prototyp[MASK] transformations [MASK] = = 
 
 The presented plots of image impedance , attenuation and phase change correspond to a low @-@ pass pro[MASK]otype filter section . The prototype has a cut @-@ off fr[MASK]quency of ωc 
 [MASK] 1 rad / s and a nominal impedance k = 
 1 Ω . This is produce[MASK] [MASK]y a filter half @-@ section with inductance L 
 = 1 henry and capacitance C = 
 1 farad . This prototype can be impedance scal[MASK]d and frequency scaled to the [MASK]esired values . The low @-@ pass proto[MASK]ype can also be transformed into high @-@ pass , band @-@ pass or band @-@ sto[MASK] types by application of suitable frequency transformations . 
 
 = = Cascading sections = = 
 
 Several L @-@ shape [MASK]alf @[MASK]@ sections may be cascaded to form a composite filter . Like impedance mu[MASK]t always face like in these combinations . There are therefore two circuits that can be formed wit[MASK] two identical L @-@ shaped half @-@ sections . Where a port of image impedance ZiT faces another ZiT [MASK] the section is called a Π section . [MASK]here ZiΠ [MASK]aces ZiΠ the s[MASK][MASK]tion so formed is a T section . Further ad[MASK]itions of half @-@ sections to either of these sec[MASK]ion forms a[MASK]ladder network which may start and end with series or shunt elements . 
 It should be borne in mind [MASK]hat the characte[MASK]istics of the filter predicted by [MASK]he image method are only accurate if the section is terminated with its image impedance[MASK]. This is usually not true of[MASK]the sections at either end , which [MASK]re usually termi[MASK]ated with a fixed resistance . The further the section is [MASK]rom the end of the filter , th[MASK] more accurate the pr[MASK]diction will [MASK]ecome , since[MASK]the effects of the [MASK]erm[MASK]nating impedances are masked by the intervening sections . 
 
 
 = The Snowmen = 
 
 " The Snowmen " is an episode of the British science fict[MASK]on television series Doct[MASK]r Who , first broadcast [MASK]n Christmas Day 2012 on BBC One . It is the eighth Christmas special since th[MASK] show 's 2005 revival and the first to be within a series . It was written by[MASK]head writer[MASK]and executive producer Steven Moffat a[MASK]d di[MASK]ected by Saul Metzstein . 
 The episode is set in the Victorian era and sees the Doctor ( Matt Smith ) brooding with the assistance of Silurian Madame Vastra ( Neve McI[MASK]tosh ) , her wife Jenny Flint ( Catrin Stewart ) and Sontaran Strax ( Dan Starkey ) , a[MASK]ter the loss of companions Amy Pond and Rory Williams [MASK]n the previous episode , " The Angels Take Manhattan " . He is forced out of hiding to in[MASK]estigate mysterious , sentient [MASK]nowmen that are building themselves and meets Clara Oswald ( Jenna @-@ Louise Coleman ) ,[MASK]a governess also investigati[MASK]g the snowmen . They discover that the[MASK]snowmen are being anima[MASK]ed by the Great Intelligence ( [MASK]oice of Ian McKell[MASK]n ) with the h[MASK]lp of a man named Dr Simeon ( Ric[MASK]ard E. Grant ) . 
 Building upon the character 's[MASK]surprise introduction in " Asylum of the Daleks " , " The Snowmen " introd[MASK]ces Clara as the Doctor 's new companion [MASK] though ultimately it would be a third version of her character that would travel with[MASK]the Doctor starting with " The Bells of Saint John " . In addition to Clara , " The Snowmen " also int[MASK]oduces a redesigned TARDIS , revised ti[MASK]le sequence and theme music , and sees changes to the Doctor 's costume . The specia[MASK] was produced in August 2012 , with location fil[MASK]ing in Newport , Wales and Bristol . It received final ratings of 9 @.@ 87 million viewers in the UK , becoming the fourth most @-@ watched programme of Christmas Day . " The Snowmen " was met with mostly positive reviews from critics , most of whom received the introduction and character of Clara well . However , som[MASK] felt that Grant and McKellen were underused as vi[MASK]lains or th[MASK] plot was slight because of the focus on characterisation .

The snowman starts speaking to the boy , repeating his assertions th[MASK]t the other children are silly .  = No. [MASK]0 Squadron RAAF = 
 
 No. 20 Squadron is a Royal Australian Air Force ( RAAF ) support squadron[MASK]. Coming under the control of No. 96 Wing , it is responsible for the management of the airfield at RAAF Base Woomera , South Australia [MASK] The squadron originated as a[MASK]maritime[MASK]patrol unit during World War [MASK]I . Raised in Au[MASK]ust 1941 , it operated PB[MASK] Catalina and Short Empire fly[MASK]ng boats from bases in New Guinea , Queensland and the Northern Territory , conducting search @-@ and @-@ rescue ,[MASK]mine @-@ laying , anti @-@ submarine [MASK]nd bombing missions against Japanese [MASK]argets in the Pacific thea[MASK]re . Following the conclusion of hostilities , the squadron was disb[MASK]nded in March 1946 . It was reactivated as an airfield support squadron[MASK]in April 2015 . 
 
 = = History = = 
 
 
 = = = World War II = = = 
 [MASK] No. 20 Squadron was formed at Port Moresby , New Guinea , on 1 Aug[MASK]st 194[MASK] for a general reconnaissance role , under the command of Squadron Leader W.N. Gibson .[MASK]Its establishment was six PBY Catal[MASK]na flying boats and 133 personnel , bu[MASK] only five aircraft ( all transferred f[MASK]om No[MASK] 11 Squadron ) and 55 personnel were available in[MASK]tially . The squadron conducted long @-@ range patrols between bases scattered around the islands to [MASK]ustralia 's n[MASK]rth in conjunction with No. 11 Squadron . On 18 No[MASK]ember , No. 20 Squadron 's Catalina[MASK] were augmented by two Short Empire flying b[MASK]ats transferred from No. 11 Squadron . 
 On 25 N[MASK]vember 1941 , following the [MASK]oss of HMAS S[MASK][MASK]ney , [MASK]ne of[MASK]No. 20 Squadron 's Catalinas was despatched to Western Austr[MASK]lia to join a No. 11 Squadron C[MASK]talina in search @-@[MASK]and @-@ rescue missions , but they found only oil slicks . By the outbreak of war in the Pacific , No[MASK] 20 Squadron had a strength of six Catalinas [MASK]nd two Empire flyi[MASK]g boats . Its [MASK]ersonnel at the beginning of Decemb[MASK]r numbered 14 officers and 118 men . The squadron undertook its first sortie of the Pacific[MASK]War on 8 December [MASK] a Catalina located three Japanese lugge[MASK]s in the vicinity of Thursday Island , Queensland . Later [MASK]n the month i[MASK] commenced anti @-@ submarine patrols and , in January 1942 , bombing raids again[MASK]t Japanese bases . As the Japanese advanced into the South West Pacific , No. 20 Squadron was also responsible fo[MASK] evacuating white ci[MASK]ilia[MASK]s from areas threatened by invasion . On 21 January , one of its Catalinas located the Japanese fleet steaming for Rabaul and signalle[MASK] a warning t[MASK] the town 's Australian defenders before b[MASK]ing s[MASK]ot down b[MASK] anti @-@ aircraft fire ; it was the squad[MASK]on 's first combat loss . 
 In the wake of the fall of Rabaul , the Catalin[MASK]s of Nos. 11 and 20 Squadron[MASK] became the RAA[MASK] 's only offensive weapon against the Japanese . Their raids on Rabaul did little to stem the Japanese advance , [MASK]nd in the following months Port M[MASK]resby itself was subjected to increasingly frequent attacks , which destroyed aircraft , facilities , and squadron records . In F[MASK]bruary 1942[MASK], the Short Empires operated by Nos. 11 and 20 Squadrons were transferr[MASK]d to the newly formed No. [MASK]3 ( Transport ) Squadron . No.[MASK][MASK]0 Squadron lost two Catalinas during patrols on 4 and 6 May ; the[MASK]nine crewmen o[MASK] the fi[MASK]st were later found to have been captured and beheaded ; the crew of the second were also captured and subsequently disappeared without trace . 
 In response to the threat of invasion [MASK]t Port Moresby , Nos. 11 and 20 Squadrons[MASK][MASK][MASK]ved to Bowen , Queensland , on 7 May 1942 . They were soon attacking Japanese targets in Lae , Salamau[MASK] and Rabaul . On[MASK]27 June , eac[MASK] squadron contributed an [MASK]ircraft to a four @-@ h[MASK]ur raid over Lae and Salamaua during which , as well as bombs , the RAAF crews[MASK]dropped beer bo[MASK]tles to disrupt the enem[MASK] soldier[MASK] ' sleep — the sound they made falling through the air was , according to the official history , " s[MASK]mething between a shrill whistle and a scream " . By 1 July , No. 20 Squadron 's strength[MASK]was six Catalinas [MASK]nd 175 per[MASK]onnel , out of a planned estab[MASK]ishment of[MASK]nine aircraft and 415 [MASK]ersonnel . Its prime responsibility i[MASK] early 1942 was maritime reconnaissance as far as New Guinea , the Solomon Islands , and New Caledonia ; the latter half o[MASK] the year saw a greater focus on n[MASK]ght bombing . Now comprising 252 officers and men , the squadron reloca[MASK]ed to Cairns on 11 November 1942 . From Cairns it continued to conduct reconnaissance , anti @-@ submarine and occasional bombing operations over th[MASK] waters [MASK]round New Guinea . Between Dece[MASK]ber 1[MASK]42 and March 1943 , No. 20 Squadron 's aircraft flew a total of 9 @,[MASK] 629 hours and dropped 227 tons o[MASK] bombs . The squadron 's role changed in June 1943 when it commenced mine @-@ laying operations over the Netherlands East Indies and the Philippines , though it continued to make some bombing raids and supply drops . 
 In September 1944 [MASK] N[MASK]. 20 Sq[MASK]adron became part of No. 76 Wing RAAF [MASK] along with Nos. 42 and 43 Squadrons , and moved to [MASK]arwin , Northern Territory . All [MASK]hree squadrons operated Catalinas , their p[MASK]imary purpose being mine @-@ laying . On the night of 30 September , a Catalina of No. 2[MASK] Squadron was shot down while attacking a ship at Pomelaa in the Dutch East Indies ; the loss was compounded by the fact that one of [MASK]he c[MASK]ordinators of the mining campaign , Lieutenant Comma[MASK]der P.E. Carr of the Royal Austr[MASK]lian Navy , was aboard the plane and was captured by the Japanese . Anoth[MASK]r of the squadron 's Catalinas went down on the night of 27 / 28 January 1945 , possibly in a cyclone over t[MASK]e Timor Sea , du[MASK]ing the camp[MASK]ign to mine Surabaya . In March , a detachment o[MASK] four No. 20[MASK]Squadron aircraft , along with four from No. 43 Squadron , la[MASK]d mines off[MASK]the coast of southern China and Formossa as part[MASK]of a No. 76 Wing offensive i[MASK][MASK]this area ; these operations were conducted from Leyte Gulf in the Philippines . One of No. 20 S[MASK]uadron 's Catalinas was los[MASK] on the night of 7 / 8 Ma[MASK]ch , most likely owing to bad weather rather th[MASK]n enemy action . Three of the squadron 's aircraft mi[MASK]ed the entrance to Hong Kong harbour on 8 April and , on 26 May , four of its Catalinas mined Wenchow ha[MASK]bour in China , th[MASK] furthes[MASK] n[MASK]rth that any Australian a[MASK]rcraft infiltrated during the war i[MASK] the Pacific . Thre[MASK] of its aircraft fle[MASK] the RAAF 's [MASK]ast[MASK]mine @-@ laying mission on [MASK]0 July . 
 No. 20 Squadron 's final wartime sortie was a patrol on 14 August 1945 . Followi[MASK]g the en[MASK] of the war , the squadron opera[MASK]ed in the transport role and ferried Australian pri[MASK]oners of[MASK]war home from various [MASK]ocations i[MASK] South East Asia . It relocated to RAAF Station Rathmines ,[MASK]New South Wales , on 21 Novem[MASK]er . No.[MASK]20 Squadron flew its last mission , [MASK] transport flight to Balikpapan , on 21 January 1946 , and[MASK]disbanded at Rathmines on 27 March . 
 
 = = = Post @-@ war re @-@ establishm[MASK]nt[MASK]= = = 
 
 No. [MASK]0 Squadron was reactivated on 1 April 2015 to support airfield operations at RAAF [MASK]ase Woomera , South Australia . Consisting of nine[MASK]un[MASK]formed personnel and one Australian Public Service member un[MASK]er the command of Squadron Lea[MASK]er Simon Bartlett , the squadron formed part of No. 96 Wi[MASK]g , a component of Combat Support Group ( CSG ) . [MASK]he airfield had[MASK]previously been managed under the aus[MASK]ices o[MASK] Aerospace Operatio[MASK]al [MASK]upport Group , but a command @-@ and @-@ control review commissioned by the Chief of Air Force reco[MASK][MASK]ended that ,[MASK]in common with other RAAF airf[MASK]elds , it should be [MASK]dministered by CSG . RAAF Base Woomera , incorporating Woome[MASK]a Village , was one of two Air F[MASK]rce units[MASK]formally esta[MASK]lished on 12 January 2015 as part of a reorganisation of the Woomera Range Complex , the other un[MASK]t being [MASK]AAF Woomera Test[MASK]Range . 
[MASK]The design of the reactivated squadron 's crest includes a wedge @-@ tailed eagle to denot[MASK] courage and nobility , a woomera spear thrower to symbolise the town and its indigenous heritage , Sturt 's Desert Pea to represent South Australia , and the Pl[MASK][MASK]ades star cluster , [MASK]hich features in the [MASK]olklore of[MASK]the local Kokatha people .
