 = Light Tank Mk VII Tetrarch = 
 
 The Light Tank Mk VII ( A17 )[MASK], also known as the Tetrarch , was [MASK] British light tank produced by Vickers [MASK]-@ Armstrongs in the late 1930s and deploye[MASK] dur[MASK]ng [MASK]he World War II .[MASK]The Tetrarch was originally designed as th[MASK] latest i[MASK] the line of light tanks built by t[MASK]e company for the British Army . It imp[MASK]oved upon its predecessor , the[MASK]Mk VIB Light Tank , by introducing the extra firepower of a 2 @-@ pounder gun . The War Office ordered[MASK]70 tanks , an order that eventually increased to 220 . Production was delayed by several factors , and as a consequence , only 100 to 177 of the tanks were produc[MASK]d . 
 The tank 's [MASK]esign flaws , combined with the decision by the War Office not to use light tanks in British armoured divisi[MASK]ns , ruled out the use of Tetrarchs i[MASK] the North[MASK]African Camp[MASK]ign . As a result , the majority of the tanks remained in Br[MASK]tain , although 20 were sent to the USSR as part of the Lend @-@ Lease program . In early 1[MASK]41 , the Royal Armoured Corps formed three squadrons for use in overseas amphibious operations , one of which was equipped with Tetrarchs . In May 194[MASK] , a small number of Tetrarchs formed par[MASK] of t[MASK]e British for[MASK]e which participated in the[MASK]inva[MASK]ion of Madagascar , and , in June 1942 , Tetrarchs were attached to the 1st Airborne Division after it was decided that the design allowed its use as an air @-@ portable light tank to support British airborne forces . The Tetrarchs were transported and landed in specially designed General Aircraft Hamilcar gliders . A lack of gliders prevented their participation in the Allied invasion of Sicily in 1943 ; instea[MASK] the[MASK] were attached to the new 6th Airborne Division and becam[MASK] part of the 6th Airborne Armoured Reconnaissance Regiment . 
 The division [MASK]sed appr[MASK]ximately 20 Tetrarchs during the British airborne landings in Normandy in June 1944 . The tanks were successfu[MASK]ly landed by glider , but they did not perform well . Several were lost i[MASK] ac[MASK]id[MASK]nts , and those that did see action proved to be [MASK]nferior in firepower and armour to the armoured [MASK]ighting vehicles of the German forces . A few days[MASK]aft[MASK]r the beginning of the operation , the tanks were remo[MASK]ed from direct engagement with German armour and used only to provi[MASK]e fire sup[MASK]ort . By August 1944 , most of the[MASK]Tetrarchs in action were replaced with Cromwell cruiser tanks , and the remainder w[MASK]re replaced by the M22 Locust in December 1944 . 
 Tetrarchs did [MASK]ot see any further co[MASK]bat and were deemed obsolete by 1[MASK]46 ; the[MASK]last was retired in 19[MASK]0 . There were several variations on the Tetrarch design , i[MASK]cluding the Alecto self @-@ propelled [MASK]un and the Light Tank Mk VIII , but none of these were ever used in active servic[MASK] with the British Army . 
 
 = = Development history = = 
 
 
 = = = Initial development = = = 
 
 The prototype of the Light Tank Mk VII ( A17 [MASK] , nicknamed ' Purdah ' , was first develop[MASK][MASK] in 1937 by Vickers @-@ Armstrongs as a[MASK]private venture , and was intended to be sold either to the British Army o[MASK] to foreign militarie[MASK] . It was to be the latest in a series of light tanks p[MASK]oduced by the company . The tank [MASK]as de[MASK]igned to ov[MASK]rcome the shortcomings of insufficient armament in earlier light tanks that were fitted only with [MASK]achine guns . Vickers @-@ A[MASK]mstrong installed on the Mk VIIs a 2 @-@ po[MASK]nder 40 @-@ millimetre[MASK]( 1 @.@ 6 in ) [MASK]ain gu[MASK] paired [MASK]ith a 7 @.@ 92 @-@ millimetre ( 0 @.@ [MASK]12 i[MASK] ) Besa machine gun , and mounted the two g[MASK]ns in a two @-@ man turret . The tank possessed a maximum of 14 millimetres ([MASK]0 @.@ 55 in ) of armour . The prototype weighed approximately 16 @,@ 800 pounds[MASK]( 7 @,@ 600 kg ) and was powered by a 165 @-@ horsepower ( 123 kW ) Meado[MASK]s engine . Suspension was on eight road wheels , four per side , with no se[MASK]arate dr[MASK]ver[MASK]or id[MASK]er wheels and it was capable of a 40 miles per hour ( 64 km / h ) top speed . The Mk VII des[MASK]gn relied on an unusual steering method and a mechanical system incorporated i[MASK]to earlier Vickers models . The fro[MASK]t wheels could be steered to allow [MASK]or gentle turns by bending[MASK]the tracks . For sharper turns , the system returned to the conventional metho[MASK] of braking one track to turn the tank ; the dual system of turning was designed to lessen mechanical strain on the MkVII and reduce its power wastage . The suspension system was al[MASK]o a new design [MASK]hat relied on struts with p[MASK]ckets of air for springing and cushions of oil for damping ,[MASK]and each of the wheels was independently sprung . 
 The War Office examined the design and put the prototype through a series of trials during May and June 1938 ; the model was test[MASK]d as a possible " light cruiser " since War Office light tank needs were already met by its predecessor , the Mark VI . The War Office then took the view that the tank was not[MASK]acceptable as a light cruiser bec[MASK]use the Nuffield A13 offered better speed and obstacle cro[MASK]sing per[MASK]ormance . Despite this , it w[MASK]s decided that it[MASK]was essential for s[MASK]me Tetrarchs to be produced , and it was suggested that they be brought in at the end of t[MASK]e light tank program . Accord[MASK]ngly , the War Office gav[MASK] the Tetrarch the off[MASK]cial General Staff specification[MASK]number A17 , and , in November 1938 , accepted it fo[MASK] limited production aft[MASK]r[MASK]requesting a few minor changes wh[MASK][MASK]h included the fitting of an external fuel tank t[MASK] [MASK]ncrease the tank 's range . 
 
 = = = Production = = = 
 
 The number to be produced [MASK]as subject to fluctuation as the War Office vacillated in their demand ; i[MASK] July 1938 , it requested [MASK]hat 70 of the tanks be produced , then increased the request to 120 after a three @-@ day conference in November . Producti[MASK]n wa[MASK] to begin in July 1940 , but meanwhile the War Office temporar[MASK]ly returned to its origina[MASK] order of 70 before increasing [MASK]he number to 100 . Th[MASK] numbe[MASK] further[MASK]increased to 220 after Metropolitan Cammell Carriag[MASK] and Wagon , a company part owned by Vickers[MASK]@-@ Armstrong that would be producing the tanks , indicated it had already ordered armour plating for that many tan[MASK]s . 
 Producti[MASK]n of the tank was delayed by a number of factors . The War Office put t[MASK]eir order on hold in a post @-@ Battle of France decision to focus military production on infantry and cruiser tanks , due to t[MASK]e poor performance of Briti[MASK]h light tanks during that battle . Due to the shortage of more suitable tanks , light [MASK]anks that were not designed for use against German armour , were nevertheless deployed against them ; the resulting high casualties led the War Office to re @-@ evaluate the sui[MASK]ability of the light tank design . The pre @-@ war role of the[MASK]light tank , that of reconnaissance , meanwhile had been found to be better suited[MASK]to scout cars that used sm[MASK]ller crews [MASK]nd had better cross @-@ countr[MASK] abilities . Further [MASK]elays were caused by the bombing raids of the Luftwaffe during May 1941 against the factories where the tanks were assembled . 
 The cumula[MASK]ive e[MASK]fect of these delays resulted in the production o[MASK] only a small number of Mk VIIs ; estimates place the final total produced to be between 100 and 177 . The name ' Tetrarch [MASK] was given to the Mk VII , on 22 September 1941 , on the orders of the War Office . The last of the tanks were built in the first quarter of 1942 and delive[MASK][MASK]d at the end of the year . 
 
 = = = Tran[MASK]fer to airborne role = = = 
 
 [MASK]he War Office and the Army were conclu[MASK]ing , at this point , that light tanks were a lia[MASK]i[MASK]ity and too vulnerable for use[MASK]in further comba[MASK] , and the Tetrarch was considered [MASK]o be obsolete . This decision may have marked the end for the T[MASK]trarch in active service [MASK] several of the tan[MASK]s destined to b[MASK] deployed to the Eighth Army in the Middle East for t[MASK]e North African C[MASK]mpaign were left in Britain when their cooling systems were determined to be unable to cope with the intense North African heat . 
 The demise of Tetrarch was prevented by a [MASK][MASK]cision made by the War Office in mid @-@ 1941 , a[MASK] it was considering the equipment to be used by Britain 's fledgling airborne forces , formed in J[MASK]ne 1940 under the orders of [MASK]he Prime Minister , Winston Church[MASK]ll . When selecting the equipment for the [MASK]irborne forces , officials at the War Office [MASK]oncluded that gliders would be an int[MASK]gr[MASK]l component ; gliders would transport troops and heavy equipment , which , by 194[MASK] , was to i[MASK]clude artillery and some form of tank . Plans to trans[MASK]ort a tank went through[MASK]a number of revisions , but , by May 1941 , the feasibility [MASK]f a 5 @.@ 5 metric tons ( 5 @.@ 4 long tons ) tank to be carried for 350 miles ( 560 km ) in a glider wa[MASK] accepte[MASK] ,[MASK]although the aircraft would have to be speci[MASK]ically designed for the task . In a conference held on 16 January 1941 ,[MASK]it was decided that the General Aircraft Hamilcar , currently under development[MASK], would be used to transport a single Tetrarch tank or two Universal Carr[MASK]ers . The Tetrarch was chosen because it was an obsolete d[MASK]sign , and was therefore available to be[MASK]used by the airborne forces . 
 Beginning in Janua[MASK]y 1944 , training[MASK]exercises were conducted carrying the Te[MASK]rarchs and their crews inside Hamilcar gliders . These exercises were successful ; during the trainin[MASK] by ' C ' Squadron of the [MASK]lider P[MASK]lot Regiment , which specialised in flying the Hamilcars , [MASK]ver 2 @,@ 800 lifts were made with an average of 50 lifts per cr[MASK]w . Only three incidents resulted in fatalities or injuries , [MASK]ith seven pilots killed during the training . Wh[MASK]n the Tet[MASK]arch was re @-@ d[MASK]signated as an airborne tank , several changes were made to its d[MASK]sign . A number of tanks had their 2 pounder guns [MASK]eplaced with a 76 @.@ 2 @-@ millimetre ( 3 @.@ 00 in ) infantry support howitzer ; the[MASK]e tanks were then designated as Tetrarch 1 CS ( Close Sup[MASK][MASK]rt ) . Additionally , Littlejohn adaptors were adde[MASK] to those Tetrarchs which still pos[MASK]essed their 2 pounders to increase their muzzle velocity and armour penetration . 
 The Tetrarch experienced several setbacks throughout its development and depl[MASK]yment with the Army and airborne[MASK]forces . One of [MASK]he ma[MASK]or pr[MASK]blems was the limited number of these tanks tha[MASK] existed after production ended in 1942 , wh[MASK]ch particularly affected the airborne forces . The transport of 20 of the tanks to the USSR under the Lend @-@ Lease Act depleted the number available for use by airborne forces , as did the loss of several more during Operation Ironclad , the invasion of Madagascar . A Royal Armoured Corps report issued[MASK]in December 1942 stated that approximately 50 Tetrarchs were available for use . In a memorandum , dated January 1943 , by M[MASK]jor General George F. Hopkinson , commander of the 1st Airborne Di[MASK]ision , Hopkinson complained that he had bee[MASK] informed that 70 of the tanks were avai[MASK]able , where[MASK]s only 50 actually remained , with no reserves to replace those lost in combat . This lack of sufficient replacement reserves , combined wit[MASK] a War Office report that some 287 airborne tanks would be required for the 1st Airborne Division and an unnamed airborne division to be formed in India , led to the Tetrarch 's eventual replacement by the US M22 Locust .[MASK]
 
 = = Pe[MASK]formance = = 
 
 A number of design faults of the Tetrarch were revealed through its operational use . Its size li[MASK]ited the possible crew to three , a driver in the[MASK]hull and a gunner and comm[MASK]nder in the turret , resulting in too few crew members to opera[MASK]e the Tetrarch e[MASK]fectively . The gunner or commander ,[MASK]in addition to his own duties , had to act as loader for [MASK]he 2 pounder , which caused delays in combat . A report on the tank written i[MASK] January 1941 stated that as the commander had to both fight and control the tank , controlling a troop of Tetr[MASK]rchs duri[MASK]g combat would be almost impossible . 
 Problems were also found with the Littlejohn adap[MASK]or fitted to t[MASK]e 2 @-@ pounder to increase i[MASK]s range an[MASK] penetration power ; after they had bee[MASK] fitted the[MASK]adapters could not be rem[MASK]ved , and could only [MASK]ire specially designed armour @-[MASK] pierci[MASK]g rounds , which took time to manufacture . 
 The War Office also [MASK]onsidered [MASK][MASK]e Tetrarch 's cooling system faulty , mak[MASK]ng the tank unsuitable for service in hotter climates , such as the Middle East and North Africa . 
 
 = = Operational history = = 
 
 
 = = = Lend @-@ lease = = = 
 
 The first Tetrarchs were delivered to the Army in November 1940 , and[MASK]were initially deployed with the 1st Armoured Division ( which wa[MASK] being refitted after losin[MASK] the majority of its previous tanks during the Battle of France ) and the newly formed 6th Armoured Division .[MASK]However , the faults discovered with the Tetrarch cooling system precluded them from being integrated into units that were sent to the Middle East to partic[MASK]pate in the North [MASK]frican Campaign . Shortly after , all light tanks were discarded fro[MASK] the establishments of British armoured divisions as not suitab[MASK]e for further service . 
 The Tetrarchs remai[MASK]ed in B[MASK]itain , and w[MASK]uld probably have been used as training vehicles before being retired from service , but on 22 June 1941 the German invasion of the USSR , Operation Barbarossa began , and the USSR became an ally of Britain . The Lend @-@ Lease program , begun in March 1941 by the United States of America to supply defensive materials to [MASK]ritain and China , was t[MASK]erefore extended to the USSR . As part of the program , the Bri[MASK]ish govern[MASK]ent began supplying[MASK]war materials to [MASK]he US[MASK]R , which in early 1942 , included a shipment o[MASK] 20 Tetrarchs , as w[MASK]ll as a number of Valentine[MASK]and Matild[MASK][MASK]Mk I Infantry tanks . The Soviet military utilised a[MASK]greater number of light tanks than the British , and so could use th[MASK] Tetrarchs . When the tanks arrived in the USSR , however , it was apparent that the[MASK]design problems with the cooling sy[MASK]tem were also present in cold[MASK]conditi[MASK]n[MASK] ; additionally , the cold weather had a deleterious effect on the tank 's suspension and tracks . Additio[MASK]al testing of the Tetrarchs was conducted by the Soviet military and the[MASK]design was[MASK]admired for its controlla[MASK]ility , manoeuvrability , and speed , as well [MASK]ts[MASK]ability to run on low @-@ quality fuel , unlike contemporary Soviet designs . The thinness of the Tetrarch 's armour was found to b[MASK] a problem and one which could not be solved , as the weight of extra ar[MASK]our plating caused an unacceptable reduction in the tank 's speed . Despite these drawbacks in the Te[MASK][MASK]arch 's desig[MASK] [MASK] Soviet authorities believed it to be comparable to the T @-@ 70 light tank in use at the time , an[MASK] decided that it was suitable to be used in combat . A number of Tetrarchs were sent to Tank Traini[MASK]g Schools which were s[MASK]bsequently sent [MASK]nto battle , and in September 1943 two were assigned to the 132nd Separated Tank Battalion , which was attached to the 5th Guards Tank Brigade ; both tanks were de[MASK]troyed in combat , one on 3[MASK] September and the other on 2 October , the latter a casualty of artillery fire . Several were also[MASK]used fo[MASK] propaganda purposes , a[MASK]pearing [MASK][MASK] photographs[MASK]of Soviet troops who were fighting in the Caucasus region . 
 
 = = = Operation I[MASK]o[MASK]clad =[MASK]= = 
[MASK]
 In[MASK]mid @-@ 1941 , the Royal Armoured[MASK]Corps in Britain created three ta[MASK]k squadrons for special overseas operations [MASK] known as ' A ' , ' B ' and ' C ' Special Service Squadrons . Both ' A ' and ' B ' [MASK]quadrons were equipped with Valentine Infantry tanks and Mark [MASK]I[MASK] light tanks , but ' C ' [MASK]quadron was equipped with twelve Te[MASK]rarchs transferred from the 2nd Armoured Brigade , 1st Armoured Division . On [MASK]1 July 1941 , ' C ' Squadron was officially activated and imme[MASK]iately received orders to prepare for overseas service alongside ' A ' and ' B ' Squadrons in an unspecified[MASK]tropical climate . All t[MASK]ree squadrons were transported to Inverary in Scotland for intensi[MASK]e training that focused on embarkation and disembarkatio[MASK] from ships and landing cr[MASK]ft to prepare them for action in potential am[MASK]hibious operations . In early[MASK]Se[MASK]tember ,[MASK]elements of ' C ' Squadron , including six Tetrarchs , formed part of a force which s[MASK]ile[MASK] for Freetown in West Afric[MASK] ; during t[MASK]is period o[MASK] the war[MASK]there were fears that the Spanish government might enter the conflict on the[MASK]side of Ger[MASK]a[MASK]y , and the force was readied to capture a number [MASK]f Spanish islands off the coast of Africa if thi[MASK] occurred . These f[MASK]ars proved groundless , and in March 1942 , the unit returned to Britain to join the rest of the squadron in training . 
 The next assignment , Operation Ironclad , was the invasion of Madagascar , the third largest island in the world and then under Vichy French control . The P[MASK]ime Ministe[MASK] and the Combined Chiefs of Staff decided that Madagascar should be occ[MASK]pied as rapidly as possible to d[MASK]ny the port of Antsirane to Japanese naval forces , which had recent[MASK]y adv[MASK]nced into the [MASK]ndian Ocean . Operation Ironclad was under the c[MASK]mmand of Major General Robert G. Sturges and consisted of No. 5 Commando , 29th Independent Brigade Group , and the 17th and 13th [MASK]rigade groups from 5th Infan[MASK]ry Division . The [MASK]9th Brigade formed the core of the invasion force due t[MASK] its training in a[MASK]phibious operations [MASK] and under its [MASK]ommand [MASK]as ' B ' Special[MASK]Service Squadron , created by amalgamating [MASK]ix Valentines from ' B ' Squadron and six Tetrarchs from ' C ' Squadron into a single unit . [MASK]he squadr[MASK]n was form[MASK]d into four troops , one Headqu[MASK]rters[MASK]troop of three Valentin[MASK]s a[MASK]d one Tetrarch , one of four Valen[MASK]ines , and two f[MASK]rmed from the remaining five Tetrarchs . The invasion force assembled off the west coast of [MASK]he[MASK]northern tip of Madagascar o[MASK] 4 May , near Antsirane and the bay of Diego Suarez . The invasion plan called for an amphibious assault landing on four beaches on the we[MASK]t side of the tip , which woul[MASK] allow the Br[MASK]tis[MASK] forces to advance approximately 20 miles ( 32 km ) and approach Antsirane from the rear . Information about the landing beac[MASK]es ,[MASK]the defences possessed by the port , and the Vichy[MASK]French defending forces was limited and vague , although it was believed that the defen[MASK]ers h[MASK]d no w[MASK]apons capabl[MASK] of penetrating the armour of a Valentine tank . 
 The landings began at 04 [MASK] 30 o[MASK] 5 May , with 5 Commando landing at Courrier Bay and the three infantry brigades and ' B ' Squadron landing at Ambararata [MASK]ay . The objective of the infantry b[MASK]igades and their armoured support was to take control of Antsirane and a nearby town , but although the infantry landed successfully , ' B ' S[MASK]uadron had more t[MASK]ouble ; the area of beach designated for its landing [MASK]raft was blocked for se[MASK]eral hours after [MASK] Tetrarch came loose from a landing craft and became stuck in the sand . The infantry brigades advanced [MASK]oward Antsirane without the squadron , but eventually two Valentines and a single [MASK]etrarch were dispatched in support , catching up with the lead elements of the infantry near the[MASK]town of Anamakia . Here the invasion fo[MASK]ce encountered the first Fren[MASK]h defences , consisting of camouflaged trench[MASK]s and pillboxes dug[MASK]in along a ridge . The tanks attempted to breach them , but the rocky gro[MASK]n[MASK] made manoeuvring difficult and they could [MASK]ot [MASK]lose with the pillboxes and trenches ; the[MASK][MASK]engaged a number of[MASK]targets with 2 pounder and machine @-@ gun fire ,[MASK]but the line had to be cleared by an infantry assau[MASK]t later in the day . The tanks were ordered to outflank the defence[MASK] [MASK]nd advance further into the island , and they were soon jo[MASK]ned by two other Tetrarchs dispatched from the beaches ; the small force continued to advance until it encoun[MASK]ered the Vich[MASK] French main line of defence . This had been built prior to the First World[MASK]War and included camouflaged pillboxes , machine @-@ gun nests and dug[MASK]@-@ in 75 mm art[MASK]llery pieces ; the latter , although not specific[MASK]lly desi[MASK]ned for an anti @-@ tank [MASK]ole , could pene[MASK]rate th[MASK] armour of both the Tetrarchs and the Valentines . The two Va[MASK]entines advanced first but were knocked out by artillery fire , and two Tetrarchs that were moving behind them su[MASK]fered the same fate ; the third Tetrarch retreated in order to report on the French resistance , machine gunning a motorcycle combination and a truck it encountered on the way back [MASK] 
 The commander of the Tetrarch made his rep[MASK]rt , and was then ordered to take command of four Val[MASK][MASK]tines and two Tetrarchs which had recentl[MASK] arrived and once again a[MASK]tempt to breach the French defences . The tanks followed the road leading to the defen[MASK]ive line and then attempted to out @-@ flank the line b[MASK] advancing from the right @[MASK]@ hand side , using several hills as cover ; the artillery pieces were able to turn and face the assault , however , and one Valentine and one [MASK]etrarch were[MASK]hit and[MASK]destroy[MASK]d . The remaining tanks exchanged several volleys of fire with the artillery pieces before[MASK]retreating back to their original positions . The French line was[MASK]eventually broken by 29th Brigade , aided by an amphibious[MASK]assault by Royal Marines ; the remaining tanks of ' B ' Squadron , two Valentines and three Tetrarchs , remained in defensive positions until the afternoon of 6 May , coming under sporadic artillery fire which [MASK]isabled another Valentine . The squ[MASK]dron played no further part in the b[MASK]ttle , as the Vichy French authorities negotiat[MASK]d a formal sur[MASK]ender the following day , altho[MASK]gh French tr[MASK]ops would continue to engage th[MASK] [MASK]ritish occupying force in guerrilla warfare until late November . ' C ' Squadron suffered heavy cas[MASK]a[MASK]ties [MASK]uring the invasion ; only one Valentine and three Tetrarchs out[MASK]of twelve tanks were functional by 7 May , and the squadron h[MASK]d suffered seven killed and six wou[MASK]ded . It remained in Madagascar until early 1943 , when it was shipped to India and took part in the Burma Campa[MASK]gn as part of 29th Brigade . 
 
 = = = Ope[MASK]ation Tonga = = = 
 
 Beca[MASK]se of a lack of equipment t[MASK]aining facilities in [MASK]id @-@ 1940 , when the British a[MASK]rborne [MASK]stablishment was formed , the War Office was able to accept only 500 volunteers for training as airborne troops . Progress in[MASK]setting up proper training facilit[MASK]es and acquiring suitable transport aircraft [MASK]as so slow that the first British airborne operation , Op[MASK]ration Colossus , was cond[MASK]cted by a retrained Commando u[MASK]it . By 1942 , [MASK]here existed specifically trained airborne units , including [MASK]he 1st Airborne Division[MASK], an[MASK] on 19 January 1942 the War Office decided that a light tank unit w[MASK]uld be one of the support units attached to the division . This unit , de[MASK]ignated the Light Tank Squadron , was to be [MASK]ormed of nine[MASK]een light tanks and would operate to the fore of the division , using their tanks ' speed to capture objectives and then holding them until relieved by other units . The obvious unit for conversion was ' C ' Special Services Squadron , as it was trained to act as an independent t[MASK]nk u[MASK]it and , more importantly , was the only unit that was still using Tetrarchs ; it had been re @-@ [MASK]esig[MASK]ated as an[MASK]airborne tank by the [MASK]ar Office . ' C ' Squadron was of[MASK]icially transferr[MASK]d to the 1st Airborne [MASK]ivision on 24 Jun[MASK] 1942 , bringing with it seven Tetrarc[MASK]s am[MASK]ng its other veh[MASK]cles . The unit imme[MASK]iately be[MASK]an training , but was not attached to the 1st Airborne Division for long ; during mid @-@ 1943 , the[MASK]division was trans[MASK]orted to the Middle East so it coul[MASK] participate in the Allied invasion of Sicily . ' C ' Squadron remained in Britain , as not enough Hamilcar gliders had been built by the time the division departed to transport its Tetrar[MASK]hs ; the[MASK]squadron was transferred to the[MASK]6th Airborne Divis[MASK]on , which had been raised in April 1943 , and ' C ' Squadron remained with it for the rest of the conflict . [MASK]he squadron co[MASK]tinued to train a[MASK] an air @-@ portable unit , and participated[MASK]in a number of exercises to prepare for its new duti[MASK]s , including reconnaissance of enemy positions and counter @-@ attacking enemy infantry and armour . 
 On [MASK]3 December 194[MASK] , the War Office decided to expand the squadron [MASK]nto a [MASK]egiment equipped with a combination of light tanks and conventional reconnaissance vehicles such as scout cars , and on 1 Ap[MASK]il 1944 , it was re @-@ designated as the 6th Airborne Armoured Reconn[MASK]issance R[MASK]giment . The regiment consisted of a Headquarters Squadron , a Light Tank Squadron and a Reconnai[MASK]sance Squadron ; [MASK]wo Tetrar[MASK]hs , the Mark 1 CS variation , were attached to the Headquarters Squadron , but the Light[MASK]Tank Squadron , also known as ' A ' Squadron , received the majority of the Tetrarchs . ' A ' Squadron had approximately nineteen Tetrarchs split between six troops , two of which were of the CS variati[MASK]n and the rest were armed with 2 pounders fitted with Littlejohn adaptors . On 24 May 1944 , after participating in a [MASK]urther series of exercises and manoeuvres , ' A ' Squadron moved from their training area to a transit camp[MASK]at Tarrant Rushton airfield , while the rest of the regiment moved to RAF Brize Norton airfield the next day ; from these two airfields , the regiment wou[MASK]d be transported from to [MASK]articipate in the British airborne landings in Normandy . The operation began on the nig[MASK]t of 5 June , with the deployment of 6th Airborn[MASK] D[MASK]vision to eastern Normandy . It was tasked with protecting the eastern flank of the Allied seaborne [MASK]andings , securing strat[MASK]gically important areas east of Caen , capturing several important bridges over the Cae[MASK] Canal and River Dives , and destroying a coastal artillery battery . Insufficie[MASK]t transport aircraft were available to land all three of the division 's brigades[MASK]simultaneously ; one would have to be landed in a se[MASK]ond lift later in the day . Major[MASK]General Richard Gale had initially intended for the 6th Airlanding Brigade , to which the 6th Airborne Armoured Reco[MASK]naissanc[MASK] Regiment was attached , to be landed first ; however , aerial photography revealed that anti @-@ glider poles had been erect[MASK]d in the landing zo[MASK]e selected for the brigade . Therefore , Gale decided that t[MASK]e 3rd Parachute Brigade and 5th Parachute Brigade ( which did not utilise[MASK][MASK]liders ) should land in the first lift to clear the landing zones , allowing the 6th Airlanding Brigade to land in the second lift . [MASK] The Horsa and Hamilcar gliders of the brigade landed at 21 : 00 on 6 June in a landin[MASK] zone cleared of obstructions by the 5th Parachute Brigade . The primary tasks of the brigade were to bring in reinforcements and supplies , and to aid the two parachute brigades in consolidating [MASK]he area[MASK]held by the divisi[MASK]n ; the 6th Airborne Armoured Reconnaissance Squ[MASK]dron w[MASK]s to aid in the latter task , acting as a reconnaissance force to scout out German positions and impede the movement of German forces attempting t[MASK] counter @-@ attack . T[MASK]e Tetrarchs of '[MASK]A ' Squadron were to play an integral part in this reconnaissance role due to their speed , but the squadron 's strength of twenty tank[MASK] [MASK]as severely depleted by the time [MASK]t landed in Normandy . It lost one tank before the formation landed when the Tetrarch broke loose of its sh[MASK]ckles and crashed through t[MASK]e nose of the glide[MASK] that was ca[MASK]rying it , causing both to fall into the sea mid @-@ flight . The s[MASK]uadron 's st[MASK]ength was f[MASK]rther weaken[MASK]d when [MASK]wo gliders[MASK]collided with each other in the landing zone , destroying themselves and the Tetrarchs they carried ; a third Ha[MASK]ilcar hit another Tetrarch as it was be[MASK]ng unloaded and flipped the t[MASK]n[MASK] upside down , rendering it u[MASK]usa[MASK]le , although the crew escaped without injury . The survivin[MASK] tanks were then rendered temporarily immobile when [MASK]a[MASK]achute rigging lines became tangled in thei[MASK] suspens[MASK]ons , forcin[MASK] t[MASK]eir crews to cut the lines away with welding torches . 
 The [MASK]quadron retrieved all of the remaining Tetrarchs and advanced to t[MASK]e south of the landing zone[MASK]to lin[MASK] up with th[MASK] rest of the regiment ; there , they [MASK]eceived ord[MASK]rs to support the 8th Parachute Battalion in the Bois de Bavent area and conduct reconnaissance duties . Afte[MASK] linking with the battalion , the squadron began reconnoitring , and engaged Ger[MASK]an infantry and armour they encountere[MASK][MASK]. By the end of 7 June , two [MASK]etrarchs had been lost to enemy action , one destroyed by a G[MASK]rman self @-@ propelled gun[MASK]and the second by hitting a mine . The division was reinforced by Britis[MASK] troops who were ad[MASK]ancing from the invasion beaches and it began to push through Normandy , while the squadron continued its reconnaissance duties . At thi[MASK] time , Gale decided to avoid , when possible , engaging the Tetra[MASK]chs with German armour , as[MASK]they[MASK]proved[MASK]to be completely out[MASK]lassed by the German tanks and self @-@ propelled guns , such as the Panzer IV a[MASK]d the Sturmgeschütz III . Instead , when th[MASK] division required ar[MASK]oured support , it summoned it from armoured units outside the division , and the Tetrarchs were used to support infantry patrols and provide fire support . By August , in the divisio[MASK] 's pre[MASK]aration for th[MASK] planned breakout[MASK]from the Normandy bridgehead , the majority of Tetrarchs in ' A ' Squadron were replaced with Cromwell fast cruiser tanks ; only three Tetrarchs remained , ass[MASK]gned to the Headquarter[MASK] troop of ' A '[MASK]Squadron . 
 
 = = =[MASK]Post @-@ war = = = 
 
 Operation Tonga was the last that Tetrarch[MASK] saw of active combat . During the first week of October 1944 , the 6th Airborne Armoured Reconnaissance Regiment underwent an extensive reorganization , i[MASK] which it was c[MASK]mpletely restructured , [MASK]nd all the remaining Tetrarchs were retired . Th[MASK]y were replaced with the M22 Locust , a purpose @-@ built airborne[MASK]light tank of American design ; eight Locusts were [MASK]sed by the regiment in March [MASK]945 during Operation [MASK]arsity , the airborne[MASK]operation to cross the river Rhine . A repor[MASK] issued[MASK]by the Director ( Air ) of the War Office in January 1946 confirmed that the Tetrarch design was considered obsolete , and any light tanks used in p[MASK]st @-@ wa[MASK] airborne formations w[MASK]uld be entire[MASK]y new in design . A small number of Tetrarchs re[MASK]ai[MASK]ed in service with the 3rd Hussars until 1949 ; a Hamilcar glider flight was st[MASK]ti[MASK]ned at RAF Fairford , and a troop of Tetrarchs was kept by the r[MASK]giment for training exercises wit[MASK] the gliders . However , glide[MASK] training by the regiment was stopped in 1950 and the Tetrarchs withdrawn fr[MASK]m service . 
 
 = = Var[MASK]ants = = 
 
 There were several variants of the Tetrarch design . The first was the Light Ta[MASK]k Mk VIII[MASK], Vickers @-@ Armstrong [MASK]s pr[MASK]posed su[MASK]c[MASK]ssor to the Tetrarch . The Mark VIII was also known as the Harry Hopkins , named after Pre[MASK]ident Roosevelt 's chief diplomatic advisor[MASK], and was given the General Staff design num[MASK][MASK]r A25 b[MASK] the Wa[MASK] Office . The Mark VIII was intended to improve upon the design of the Tetrarch in a number of areas . It had thicker armour than the Tetrarch , with the front hull and tur[MASK]et armour increas[MASK]d to a thickness of 38 milli[MASK]etres ( 1 @.@ 5 in ) and the si[MASK]e armour[MASK]to 17 millimetres ( 0 @.@ 67 in ) , and the turret and hull given more sloped[MASK]surfaces to help de[MASK]lect shells fired at the ta[MASK]k . The dimensions of the Tetrarch were also changed ; the Mark VIII was longer by 6 inches ( 0 @.@ 15 m ) , wider by 1 f[MASK]ot 3 inches ( 0 @.@ 38 m ) and heavier . The new tank was no longer air @-@ portable , as it was too heavy to be carried by a Hamilcar . The 12 @-@ cylinder engine of the Tetrarch was fitted to the [MASK]ark VIII , although the increased weight meant that[MASK]its maximum speed decreased to 30 miles per hour ( 48 km / h ) ; its arma[MASK]ent also remained t[MASK]e sa[MASK]e as that of the Tetrarch . The War Off[MASK]ce authorised the construction of three prototype models in April 1941[MASK]. The new de[MASK]ign was considered a success , and the Tank Board of the War Office ordered 1 @,@ 000 to be co[MASK]structed in Septemb[MASK][MASK] . However , problems were encountered with further tests[MASK]of the prototypes , and a report i[MASK]sued in December 1942 stated that production of the Mark VIII had been delayed due to developmental problems . These problems continued to persist[MASK]into 1943 , when the War Office decided against using the tank[MASK]in a[MASK]tive service ; approximately 100 Mark VIIIs were p[MASK]oduced by 1945 , w[MASK]en p[MASK]oduction ended . 
[MASK]A second variant on the Tetrarch design was the Tetrarch Duplex Drive ( " Tetrarch [MASK]D " ) . The Duplex Drive system was invented by Nicholas Straussler [MASK] and was designed to allow a tan[MASK] [MASK]o ' swim ' through water and participate in amphibious operations . T[MASK]e system functioned by erecting a large waterproof[MASK]canvas screen around the tank above its tracks , which was supported[MASK]by thirty @-@ six i[MASK][MASK]latable tubes and steel struts ; this gave the tank sufficient buoyancy to float , and was t[MASK]en propelled along by a small propeller powered by the tank 's engine . The screen could be collapsed by using a small explosive charge once the tank reached land . The system was fitted during June 1941 , as the Tetrarch [MASK]as the lightest light tank available at the ti[MASK]e ; the converted tank was su[MASK]cessfully tested on a number of lakes and reservoirs , allowing the Duplex Drive system to be tested on heavier tanks , such as the Vale[MASK]tine . The system [MASK]ould be used during Operation Overlord , when M4 Sherman[MASK]medium tanks would land on the invasion beaches . 
 
 
 = QuackShot = 
 
 QuackShot , known [MASK]n Jap[MASK]n as I Love Donald Duck : Georgia Ou no Hihou ( Japanese : アイラブドナ[MASK]ドダ[MASK]ク グルジア王の秘宝 , Hepburn : Ai[MASK]Rabu Donarudo Dakku Gurujia Ō no Hihō ) , is a 1991 platforming video game developed a[MASK]d published by S[MASK]ga for the Sega Genesis . The game was rele[MASK]sed in Europe in 1991 , in No[MASK]th America on December 19 , 1991 and in Japan on December 20 ,[MASK]1991 . QuackShot stars Donald [MASK]uck and his three nephews , Huey , Dewey , and[MASK]Louie , as treasure @-@ hunters , and is part of a series of game[MASK] published by Sega that were based on Walt Disney cartoon characters . 
 QuackShot was released to mostly positive re[MASK]i[MASK]ws from video game journalists . The game was universally lauded for its graphics , with magazines[MASK]like Sega Pro describing th[MASK]m as " some of the best [MASK]rap[MASK]ics around . " The game was also praised for its music and puzzles , as well as their clever use in the game . [MASK]owever , QuackShot was criticized for its controls , being describe[MASK] by IGN as " float @-@ y " and making certain segments of[MASK]the game unnecessarily difficult . The game was also critic[MASK]zed for its lack of difficulty overall[MASK]as well as it[MASK] lack of speech samp[MASK]es , which several other Genesis games of the time [MASK]ad . 
 
 = = Gameplay = = 
 
 The player , as Donald , ventures throug[MASK] a varie[MASK]y of side @-@ scrolling levels . Generally , each level is divided into an overland pa[MASK]t and a dungeon , such as the Maharaj[MASK]h 's palace or the temple in w[MASK]ich the Great Duck Tr[MASK]asure resides . A[MASK]though the player may choose any order to play the overland sections , various obstacles prevent the player from entering the du[MASK]g[MASK]ons outside of a specific order . In addition to this , some levels provide the player with vital clues which solve puzzles needed to progress in later sections . Once Donald has completed the overland section of an area , he [MASK]ay leave by calli[MASK]g his nephews ' bi[MASK]lane , and w[MASK]ll return to the dungeon entrance of that area if the player chooses to return . 
 Donald is armed with a special gun that can shoot plungers , popcorn or bubble [MASK]um . Donald has unlimited plungers which can only temporarily stun enemies ( though bosses can still be damaged with [MASK]lungers ) , and can collect popcorn and gum along the way or get the latter from Gyro Gearloose . Later in the game , the plunger [MASK]s upgraded to act as a temporary platform to climb walls with and , when stuck to a passing bird , allows Donald to tr[MASK]verse longer distances . In Duckburg , [MASK]ndia and Egypt , Donald can also pick up ch[MASK]li peppers which increase his [MASK]emper ,[MASK]eventually te[MASK]porarily allowing him to become invincibl[MASK] , i[MASK]crease his speed and knock out enemies in his path .

Donald gives the necklace to Daisy and the[MASK]two fly off into the sunset together . 
 
 [MASK] = Development[MASK]and release = = 
 
 QuackShot was developed and published by Sega for the Sega Genesis as pa[MASK]t of a[MASK]series of games that were based on Walt Disney cartoon characters . The game was released in Europe in 1991 , in North Ame[MASK]ica on December 19[MASK], 1991 and in Japan on December 20 , 1991 . QuackShot was later released as part of a bundle called The Disney Collection for Genesis in 1996 alongside Castle of Illu[MASK]ion . [MASK][MASK]e game was also ported to [MASK]he Sega Saturn and released exclusively in Japan alongside Castle of Illusion again as part of the Sega Ages series in 1998 , entitled Sega Ages[MASK]: I Love Mickey Mouse .

 = Olmec colossal heads = 
 [MASK] The Olmec[MASK]colossal heads are at least sev[MASK]nteen monumental stone representations of human heads sculpted from large basalt boulders . The heads date from at least before 900 BC and are a distinctive feature of t[MASK]e O[MASK]mec civilization of ancient Mesoamerica . All portray mature men with fleshy cheeks , flat noses , and slightly crossed eyes ; their physical characteristics correspond to a type that is [MASK]till common among the inhabitants of Tabasco and Veracruz . The backs of the monuments often are flat . The bo[MASK]lders were brought from the Sierra de los Tuxtlas mountains of Veracruz . Given that the extremely large slabs[MASK]of stone used in their production were transported [MASK]ver large distances , requiring a great d[MASK]al of human effort and resources , it is thought that the monuments repre[MASK]ent portraits of pow[MASK]rful individual Olmec rulers . Each of the know[MASK] examples has a distinctive headdress . The heads[MASK]were variously arran[MASK]ed in l[MASK]nes or groups at major Olmec centres , but the method and logistics used to transport the ston[MASK] to these sites remain[MASK]unclear . 
 The discovery of a colossal head at Tres Zapotes in th[MASK] nineteenth c[MASK]ntury spurred the first archaeological invest[MASK]gations of Olmec culture by Matthew Stirl[MASK]ng in 1938 .[MASK]Seventeen confirmed examples are known from four sites within t[MASK]e Olmec he[MASK]rtland on the Gulf Coast [MASK]f Mexico . Most colossal head[MASK] were sculpted from spherical boulders but two from San Lorenzo[MASK]Tenochtitlán were re @-@ carved from massive stone thrones . An additional [MASK]o[MASK]ument , at Takalik Abaj in Guatemala , is a throne that m[MASK]y have been carve[MASK] fr[MASK]m a colossal head . This is the on[MASK]y known[MASK]example [MASK]rom outside the Olmec heartland . 
 Dating the monuments remains difficult becau[MASK]e of the movement [MASK]f many from their origin[MASK]l contexts prior to archaeological investigation . Most have been dated to the Early Preclassic period ( 1500 – 1000 BC ) with[MASK]some to the Middle Preclas[MASK]ic ( 1000 – 400 BC ) period . The smallest weigh 6 tons , while the largest is variously estimated to weigh 40 to 50 to[MASK]s , [MASK]lthough it was abandoned and left unfinished close to the source of its sto[MASK]e . 
 
 = = Olmec civilization = = 
 
 The Olmec civilizati[MASK]n developed in the lowlands of sout[MASK]eastern Mexico between 1[MASK]00 and 400 BC . The Olmec heartland lies on the Gulf Coast of Mexico within[MASK]the states of Veracruz a[MASK]d Tabasco , an area measuring appr[MASK]xi[MASK]ately 275 kilometres ( 171 mi ) east to west and extending about 100 kilometres ( 62 mi ) inland from[MASK]the coast . The Olmecs a[MASK]e regarded as the first civilization to develop in Mesoamerica and the Olmec heartland is one of six cradles of civilization [MASK]orldwide , the [MASK]thers being th[MASK] Norte Chico culture of South America , the Erlitou culture of China 's Yellow River[MASK], the In[MASK]us Valley Civilization of south Asia , the civilization of ancient Egypt and the Sumerian civilization of an[MASK]ient Iraq . Of these , only the Olmec civilization developed in a lowland tropical forest setting . 
 The Olmecs were [MASK]he f[MASK]rst inhabitants of the Americas to construct monumental architecture and [MASK]o settle in towns and cities . They were also the first people in[MASK]the Americas to develop a sophisticated style[MASK]of stone sculpture . In the first decade of th[MASK] 21st century evidence emerged of Olmec writin[MASK] , with the earliest examples of O[MASK][MASK]ec hieroglyphs dating to around 650 BC [MASK] Examples of script [MASK]ave bee[MASK] found on ro[MASK]ler stamps and stone artefacts ; the texts are short and have been[MASK]partially deciphered based on their similarity to o[MASK]her Mesoamerican scripts . The evidence of compl[MASK]x society developing in the Olmec heartland has led [MASK]o the Olmecs being regarded as the " Mother Culture " of [MASK]esoameric[MASK] , although this concept remains controversial . 
 Some of the Olmecs ' rulers seem to have served religious functions . The city of San Lorenzo was succeeded as the main centre of the civilization by La Venta in about 900 BC , with [MASK]res Z[MASK]potes and Laguna de los Cerros po[MASK]sibly sh[MASK]ring the role ; other urban centres were much less significant . The nature and degree of the control exercised by the centres over a widespread rural population[MASK]remains unclear . Very fine Olmec art , much clearly made for an elite , survives in [MASK]everal forms , notably Olmec f[MASK]gurines , and larger sculptures such as The Wrestler . The figurines have been recovered in large numbers and are mostly in potter[MASK] ; these[MASK]were presumably widely available to the population . Together with these , of particular relevance to the colossal heads are the " Olmec @[MASK]@ style masks " in stone , so [MASK]all[MASK]d because none have yet been e[MASK]cavated in circumstances that allow the proper archaeological ide[MASK]ti[MASK]ication of an Olmec context . These evocative stone face masks present both similarities[MASK]and differences [MASK]o the colossal hea[MASK]s . Two thirds [MASK]f Olmec monumental sculpture represents the human for[MASK] , and the colossal heads fall within this maj[MASK]r theme of Olmec art . 
 
 = = Dating = = 
 
 The colossal heads cannot be precise[MASK]y dated . However , the San Lorenzo[MASK]heads w[MASK]re buried by 900 BC , indicating th[MASK]t their[MASK]period of manufacture and use was earlier still . The heads from Tres Zapotes had been moved from their original context before they wer[MASK] investigated by archaeol[MASK]gists and the heads from La Venta were found partially exposed on the modern ground surface . The period of production of the colossal heads is therefore unknown , as is whet[MASK]er it spanned a century or a millennium . Estimates of the time span during which colossal heads were produced vary from 50 to 200 years . The San Lore[MASK]zo heads are[MASK]believed to [MASK]e th[MASK] oldest , and are the most skillfully executed . All of the stone heads have been assigned to the Preclassic period of Meso[MASK]merican chronology , generally to th[MASK] Early Preclassic ( 1500 – 1000 BC ) , although[MASK]the two Tres Za[MASK]otes head[MASK] and the La Cobata Head are attributed to the Middle [MASK]reclassic ( 1000 – 400[MASK]BC ) . 
 
 = = Characteristics = = 
 
 Olmec colossal heads vary in height from 1 [MASK].[MASK] 47 to 3 @.@ 4 metres ( 4 @.@[MASK]8 to 11 @.[MASK] 2 ft ) and weigh between 6 and 50 tons . All o[MASK] the Olmec col[MASK]ssal heads depict mature men with flat noses and fleshy cheeks ; the eyes tend to be slightly crossed . The general physical characteristics of the heads are of a type that is still common among people in the Olmec region in modern times . The backs of the heads are o[MASK][MASK]en flat , as if the monuments w[MASK]re originally placed against a wall . A[MASK]l examples[MASK]of Olmec colossal heads wear distinctive headdresses that probably represent cloth or animal hide originals . S[MASK]me examples have a tied knot at the back of the head , and some[MASK]are decorated with feathers [MASK] A head from La Venta is decorated with the head of a bird . There are similarities betwe[MASK]n the headdress[MASK]s on some of the heads that has led to speculation that specific headdresses may represent dif[MASK]erent dynasties , or perhaps identify specific rulers . Most of the heads wear large earspools inserted i[MASK]to the ear lobes . 
 All of[MASK]the heads are realistic ,[MASK]unidealised and frank descripti[MASK]ns of the men . It is likely that they were portraits of living ( or recently deceased ) rule[MASK]s well known to [MASK]he[MASK]sculptors . Each head is distinct and naturalistic , displaying individualised featur[MASK]s . They were once tho[MASK]ght to represent ballplayers [MASK]lth[MASK]ugh[MASK]this t[MASK]eory is no longer widely held ; it is possible , howeve[MASK] , that they represent rulers equippe[MASK] for the Mesoamerican ballgame . Facial expressions depicted on the heads vary from ste[MASK]n through placid to smiling . The most naturalistic Olmec art is the earliest [MASK] [MASK][MASK]pearing suddenly witho[MASK]t surviving antecedents , with a tendency towards more stylised sculpture as time progressed . Some surviving examples of wooden s[MASK]ulpture recovered from El Ma[MASK]atí demonstrate that the Olmecs are likely to have created many more perishable sculptures than works sculpted from stone . 
 In the [MASK]ate nineteenth century , José Melgar y Serrano described a colossal head[MASK]as having "[MASK]Ethiopian " features and [MASK]peculations that the [MASK]lmec had African origin[MASK] resurfaced in 1960 in the work of Alfonso M[MASK]dellín Zenil and in the 1970s in the[MASK]writings of Ivan van Sert[MASK]ma . Such speculation is not taken seriously by Mesoamerican scholars such as Richard[MASK]Diehl and Ann Cyphers . 
 Although all the colossal heads are broadly similar [MASK] there [MASK]re distinct stylistic differences in their execution . One of the heads from San Lorenzo bears traces [MASK]f plaster and red pa[MASK]nt [MASK] suggesting that the heads were [MASK]riginally brightly decorated . Heads did not just represent individual Olmec rulers ; they also incorporated the very concept of rulership itself . 
 
 = = Manufacture = = 
 
 The production of each colossal head[MASK]must[MASK][MASK]ave been carefully planned , given the e[MASK]for[MASK] required to ensure the nece[MASK]sary resources were [MASK]vailable ; it seems likely that only the more powerful Olmec rulers were able to mobilise such resourc[MASK]s . The workforce would have included sculptors , labourers[MASK], overseers , boatmen , woodworkers and other artesans producing [MASK]he tools to make and mo[MASK]e the monument , in addition to the[MASK]support needed to fee[MASK][MASK]and otherwise at[MASK]end to these workers . The seasonal and agricultural cycles and river levels needed [MASK]o have been taken into account to plan the production of the monu[MASK]ent and the whole project m[MASK]y well have taken years from beginning to end . 
 Archaeological investig[MASK]t[MASK]on of Olmec basalt workshops suggest that the colossal heads were first roughly shaped [MASK]sing direct percussion to c[MASK]i[MASK] away both large and small flakes of stone . The sculpture was then refined by retouching the surface using hammerstones , which were generally rounded cobbles that could be of the same basalt as the monument itself , although this was not always the[MASK]case . Abrasives were found [MASK]n a[MASK]sociation with workshops at San Lorenzo , indicating their use in the finishing of fine detail . Olmec[MASK]colossal heads were fashioned as in @-@ the @-@ round monumen[MASK]s wit[MASK] varying levels of relief on the same work ; they tended to feature higher relief on the face [MASK]nd lower relief on the earspools and headdresses . Monument 20 at San Lorenzo is an extensively damaged throne with a figure emerging from a niche[MASK]. Its sides were broken [MASK]way and it was dragg[MASK]d to another location before being abandoned . It is possible that this damage was caused by the initial stages of re @-@ carving the monument into a colossal head but that the work was never completed . 
 All seventeen of the confirmed heads in the Ol[MASK]ec heartland w[MASK]re sculpted from basalt mined in the Sierra de los Tuxtlas moun[MASK]ains[MASK]of Veracruz . Most were fo[MASK]med [MASK]rom coarse grained dark gr[MASK]y basalt known as Cerro Cintepec basalt af[MASK]er a volcano in the range . Investigators have proposed that large Cerro Cintepec basalt boulders found on the southeastern s[MASK]opes of the mountains are the so[MASK]rce of the stone for the monuments . These boul[MASK]ers are found in an area affected by large lahars ( volcanic mudslides ) that carried substantial blocks of stone dow[MASK] [MASK]he mo[MASK]ntain slopes , whi[MASK]h suggests [MASK]hat the Olmecs did not need to quarry the raw material for [MASK]culpting the heads . Roughly spherical boulders were carefully sel[MASK]cted to mimic the sh[MASK]pe of a human head . [MASK]he stone for the San Lorenzo and La Venta heads [MASK]as transported a considerable distance from the source . The La Cobata head was [MASK]ound on El Vigia hil[MASK] in the Sierra de los Tuxtlas and the stone from Tres Zapotes Colossal Head 1 and Nestepe Colossal Head 1 ( also known as Tres Zapot[MASK]s Monuments A and Q ) came from the same hill . 
 The boulders were transported over 150 kilometres ( 93 mi ) from the source of the stone . The e[MASK][MASK]ct method of transportati[MASK]n of such large masses of rock are unknown , especially since the Olmecs lac[MASK]ed beasts of burden and functio[MASK]al wheels , and they were likely[MASK]to have use[MASK] water transport whenever possible . Coastal currents of the Gulf of Mexico and in river estuaries might have made the waterborne transport of monuments wei[MASK]hing 20 [MASK]ons or more impractical . Two badly damaged Olmec sculptures depict rectangular stone blocks bound with ropes . A largely destroyed human figure rides [MASK]pon each block , with their legs hanging over the side . These sculptures may well d[MASK]pict Olmec[MASK]rulers overseeing the transport of the st[MASK]ne that would be fashioned into their monuments . When transport over land was necessary , the Olmecs are likely to have used causeways , ramps and roads to facilitate moving the heads . The regional terrain offers significant obstacles such as swamps and floodplains ; avoiding these would have necessitated crossing undulating hill country . The construction of temporary causeways using th[MASK] suitable an[MASK] plentiful flood[MASK]lain soils would have allowe[MASK] a direct route across the floodplains to the San Lorenzo Plateau . Earth structures such as mounds , platforms and causeways upon the plateau demonstrate that the Olmec possessed the necessary knowledg[MASK] and could commit the resources to build large @-@ scale [MASK]arthwo[MASK]ks . 
 The flat backs of man[MASK] of the colossal heads represented the [MASK]la[MASK] bases of the mon[MASK]mental thrones from whic[MASK] they were reworked . Only four of the seventeen heartland heads do not have flattened backs , indicatin[MASK] the possibility that the majority were reworked monuments . Alternatively , the backs of many of these massive monuments may have been flattened to ease their transport , providing a st[MASK]ble form for hauling the monuments with rope[MASK] . Two h[MASK]ads from San Lorenzo have traces of niches that are characteristic of monumental Ol[MASK]ec thrones and so were definitely reworked from earlier monuments .[MASK]
 
 = = Known mo[MASK]uments = = 
 
 Seventeen confirmed examples are known . An additional monument , at Takalik Ab[MASK]j in Guat[MASK]mala , is a throne that may have been carved[MASK]from a colossal head . This is the only known example outside of[MASK]the Olmec heartland on the Gulf Coast of Mexico . Possible fragments of additional colossa[MASK] heads have been recovered at San Lorenzo and at San Fernando in Tabasco . Crude colossal stone heads are also known in the Southern Maya area where they are associated with the potbelly style of sculpture . Although some arguments have been made that they are pre @-@ Olmec , the[MASK]e latter monuments are generally believ[MASK]d to be influenced by the Olmec style of sculpture .

Two of the San Lorenzo heads had been re @-@ carved from older thrones .

The earfla[MASK]es are rectan[MASK]ular plates with an additional trapezoid ele[MASK]ent at the front . The head is also[MASK]depicted wearing a nose @-@ ring . The face is smiling and has wrinkles u[MASK]der the eyes and at the edge of the mouth . It has sagging c[MASK]eeks and wide eyes . The mouth i[MASK] closed and the upper lip is badly damaged . The sculpture suffered some mutilation in antiquity , with nine pits hollowed into [MASK]he face and headdress . 
 San Lorenzo Colossal Head 10 ( also known as San Lorenzo Monument 89 ) has bee[MASK] moved to the Museo Comunitario de San[MASK]Lorenzo Tenoch[MASK]itlán near Texistepec . It stands 1 @.@ 8 metres ( 5 @.@ 9 ft ) tall and measu[MASK]es 1 @.@ 43 metres ( 4 @.@ 7 ft ) wide by 0 [MASK].@[MASK]92 metres ( 3 [MASK].@ 0 [MASK]t ) deep ; it weighs 8 to[MASK]s . The head was disco[MASK]e[MASK]ed by a magnetometer survey in 1994 ; it was found buried , lying face upwards in the bottom of a ravine and was exc[MASK]vated by Ann Cyphers . The headdress is formed of 92 circular beads that completely cover the upper part of the [MASK][MASK][MASK]d and[MASK]descend across the si[MASK]es and back . Above the forehead is a large element forming a three @-@ toed foot with long nails , possibly t[MASK][MASK] foot of a bird . The head wears large earspools that protrude beyond the beads of the headdress . The spools have [MASK]he form of a rounded square with a circular sunken central portion . The face is that of a mature man with the mouth close[MASK] , sagging cheeks and lines under the eyes . The mouth is sensitively carved and[MASK]the head possesses a pronounced chin . 
 
 = = = La Venta = = = 
 
 Three of the La Venta heads were found in a line running east @-@ west in the northern Complex I ; all three faced northwards , away from the city c[MASK]ntre .[MASK]The other head was found in Complex B to the south of the Great Pyramid , in a plaza that included a number of other sculptures . The latter , the first of the La Venta heads[MASK]to be discovered , was found during archaeological exploration of La Venta in 1925 ; the other three remained unknown [MASK]o archaeologists until a local boy guided Matthew Stirling[MASK]to them whil[MASK][MASK]he was excavating the first head in 1940 . They were locate[MASK] [MASK]pprox[MASK]mately 0[MASK]@.@ 9 kilometres ( 0 @.@ 56 mi ) to the north [MASK]f Monument 1 . 
 La Venta Monument 1 is speculated to have been the portrait of La Venta '[MASK] final ruler . Monument 1 measures 2 @.@ 41 metres ( 7 @.@ 9 ft ) high by 2 @.@ 08 metres ( 6 @.@ 8 ft ) wide by [MASK] @.@ 95 metres[MASK]( 6 @.@ 4 ft ) deep ; it weighs 24 tons .[MASK]The front of the h[MASK]address is decorated with t[MASK]ree motifs that apparently represe[MASK]t the claws[MASK]or fangs [MASK][MASK] an animal . Above thes[MASK] symbols is an angular U @-@ shaped decoration descending from the sc[MASK]lp . On each side of the monu[MASK]ent a strap descends fro[MASK] the headdress , passing in front of the[MASK]ear . Each ear has a prominent ear ornament that descends from the earlobe to the base of the monument . The features are those of a matur[MASK] man , with wrinkles around the mouth , eyes and nose . Monument 1 is the best preserved head at La Venta but has suffered from erosion , particularly at the back . The head was first describ[MASK]d by Franz Blom an[MASK] Oliver La Farge who [MASK]nvestigated the La Venta remains on behalf of Tulane University in 1925 . When discovered it was half [MASK]-@ buried ; its massive size meant that the discoverers were unable to excavate[MASK]it completely . Matthew Stirling fully excavated the monument in 1940 , after clearing the thick vege[MASK]ation that had covered it in the intervening years . Monument 1 has been moved to th[MASK] [MASK]arque @-@ Museo La Venta in Villahermosa . The head was f[MASK]und in its original context ; associated fin[MASK]s have been radiocarbon dated to between 1000 and 600 BC . 
 La Venta Mo[MASK]ument 2 measures 1 @.@ 63 m[MASK]tres ( 5 @.@ 3 ft ) high by 1 @[MASK]@ 35 metres ( 4 @.@ 4 ft ) wide by 0 @.@ 98 met[MASK]es [MASK] 3 @[MASK]@ 2 ft[MASK]) deep ; the head weighs 11 @.@ 8 tons . The face has a broadly smiling expression that reveals four of the upper teeth . The cheeks are given prominence by the action of smiling ; the brow that is normally visible in other he[MASK]ds is covered by t[MASK]e rim of the headdress . The face is badly eroded , distorting the features . In addition to the severe erosion damage ,[MASK]the upper [MASK]ip an[MASK] a part [MASK]f the nose have been deliberately mutilated . The head was found [MASK]n its original context a few metres north of the northwest corner of pyramid @-@ platform A @-@ 2 . Radiocarbon dating of the monume[MASK]t 's [MASK]ontext dates it to between 1000 and 600 BC . [MASK]onument 2 has suff[MASK]red erosion damage fro[MASK] its exposure to the elements prior to discovery . The head has a prominent headdress but this is badly eroded and any individual detail has been erased . A strap desc[MASK]nds in front of the ear on each side of the head , descending as far as the earlobe . The head is adorned with ear ornaments in the form of a disc that covers t[MASK]e earlo[MASK]e , with an associated clip or peg . The survivi[MASK]g details of the headdress and earflares are stylistically similar to those of T[MASK]es Zapotes Monument A. The hea[MASK] has be[MASK]n moved to the Museo del Est[MASK]do de Tabasco in Villahermosa[MASK]. 
 La Venta Monumen[MASK] 3 stands 1 @.@[MASK]98 metres ( 6[MASK]@.@ 5 ft ) high and measures 1 @.@ 6 [MASK]etre[MASK] ( 5 @.@ 2 ft ) wide by 1 metre ( 3 @.@ 3 ft ) deep[MASK]; it weighs 12 @.@ 8 tons . Monument 3 was located a few metres t[MASK] [MASK]he east of Monument 2 , but was moved to the Parque @-@ Museo La Vent[MASK] in Villahe[MASK]mosa . Like the other La Venta heads , its context has been radiocarbon dated to [MASK]etween 1000 and 600 BC . It appears unfinished and has suffer[MASK]d severe damage through [MASK]eathering , making analysis difficult . Althou[MASK]h most of the facial detail is lost , the crinkling of[MASK]the bridge of the nose is still evident , a feature tha[MASK] is common to the frownin[MASK] expressio[MASK]s of the other Olmec colossal heads . 
 La Venta Monument 4 measures 2 @.@ 26 metres ( 7 @.@ 4 ft[MASK]) high by 1 @.@ 98 metres ( 6 @.@ 5 ft ) wide and 1 @.@ 86 metres ( 6 @.@ 1 ft[MASK]) deep . I[MASK] weighs 19 @.@ 8 tons .  = = = Tres Zapotes = = = 
 
 The two heads a[MASK] Tres Z[MASK]potes , with the [MASK]a Cobata head , are stylistically distinct from[MASK]the other k[MASK]own examples . Bea[MASK]r[MASK]z de la Fuente view[MASK] them as a late regional survival of an [MASK]lder tradition while other scholars argue that they are merely the kind of regional variant to be exp[MASK]cted in a frontier settlement . These heads are sculpted with relatively simple headdresses ; they have squat , wide proportions and d[MASK]stinctiv[MASK] fac[MASK]al features . The two Tres Zapotes heads are the earliest known stone monuments from the site . The discovery of one of the Tres Zapotes head[MASK] in the nineteenth c[MASK]ntury led to the first archaeolog[MASK]cal investigations of Olmec cultu[MASK]e , carried out by Matthew Stirling [MASK]n 1938 . 
 Tres[MASK]Zapot[MASK]s Monument A ( also known as Tres Zapotes Colossal Head 1 ) was the first colossal h[MASK]ad to be found , discovered b[MASK] accident in the middle of the nineteenth cent[MASK]ry [MASK] 1 kilometre ( 0 @.@ 62 mi )[MASK]to the north of the modern village of Tres Zapotes . After its discovery it remained half @-@ buried until it was excavated by Matthew Stirling in 19[MASK]9 . At so[MASK]e point it was moved to th[MASK] [MASK]laza of the modern village , probably in t[MASK]e[MASK]early 1960s . It has since been moved to the Museo Comunitario [MASK]e Tres Zapotes . Monumen[MASK] A stands 1 @.@ 47 metres ( 4 @.@ 8 ft ) tall ; it measures 1 @.@ 5 metres ( 4 @.@ [MASK] ft ) wide by 1 @.@ 45 metres ( 4 @.@ 8 ft ) deep , and is estimated to wei[MASK]h 7 @.@ 8 tons . T[MASK]e head is s[MASK]ulpted with a simple headdress with a wide ba[MASK]d that is otherwise unador[MASK]ed , and wears [MASK]ecta[MASK]gular ear ornaments that project forwards onto the cheeks . The face[MASK]is carved with deep creases b[MASK]tween the cheeks and the nose and [MASK]round the mouth ; t[MASK]e forehead is creased into a frown . The upper lip has suf[MASK]ered recent damage , with the left portion flaking away . 
 Tres Zapotes Monument Q ( also k[MASK]own as the Nestape Head and Tr[MASK]s Zapotes Colossal Head 2 ) measures 1 @.@ 45 metres ( 4 @.@ 8 ft ) high by 1 @.@ 34 metres ( 4 @.@ 4 ft ) wide by 1 @.@ 26 metres ( 4 @.@[MASK]1 ft ) deep and weighs 8 @.@ 5 tons . Its exact date of discovery is unknown but is [MASK]stimated to have been some time in the 1940s , when[MASK]it was struck by machinery [MASK]eing used to clear veget[MASK]tion from Nestape hill . Monume[MASK]t Q was the eleventh colossal[MASK]head to be discovered . I[MASK] w[MASK]s moved to the plaza of Sa[MASK]t[MASK]ago Tuxtla in 1951 and remains there to this da[MASK] [MASK] Monument Q was first described by Wil[MASK]iams and Heizer in an article published in 196[MASK] . The he[MASK]ddress is decorat[MASK]d with a[MASK]frontal tongue @-@ sha[MASK]ed ornament , and the back of the head is sculpted with seven plaits of hair bound with tassels . A strap descends from each side of the headdress , passing over the ears and to the base of the[MASK]monument . The face has pronounced creases around the nose , mouth and eyes . 
 
 = = = La Cobata = = = 
 
 The La Cobata region was the source of the basalt used for car[MASK]ing all of the colossal heads in the Olmec [MASK]eartland . The La Co[MASK]ata coloss[MASK]l head was discovered in 1970 and was the fifteenth to be recorded . It was discovered in a mountain pass in the Sierra de los Tux[MASK]las , on the north side of El Vigia vol[MASK]ano near to Santiago Tuxtla .[MASK]The head was largely buried when found ; excavat[MASK]ons uncovered a La[MASK]e Classic ( 600 – 900 AD ) offering associated with the head cons[MASK]sting of a ceramic vessel and a 12 @-@ centimetre ( 4 @.@ 7 in ) long obsidian knife placed pointing northwards towards the head . The offering is believed to have been deposited long after the head [MASK]as sculpted . The La Cobata head has been moved from its original locatio[MASK] to the main plaza at Santiago . 
 The La Cobata head is more or less rounded and measures 3 by 3 metres ( 9 @.@ 8 by 9 @.@ 8 ft ) by 3 @.@ 4 metres ( 11 ft ) high , making it the largest known head . This massive sculpture is estimated to[MASK]weigh 40 tons . It is [MASK]tylistically distinct[MASK]from the other examples , and Beatriz de la Fuente placed it late in the Olmec time frame . The characteristics of the sculpture have led to some investigators suggesting that it rep[MASK]esents a deceased person . Norman Hammond argue[MASK] that the apparent stylistic differences of the monume[MASK]t stem from its unfinished[MASK]state rather than its late production . The eyes of the monument are closed , the nose is flattened and lacks nostrils and the mouth was not sculpted in a realistic manner . The headdress[MASK]is in th[MASK] form of a plain[MASK]horizontal band . 
 The original location[MASK]of the La Cobata head was not a major archaeological site and it is likely that the head wa[MASK] either abandoned at [MASK]ts source or during transport to its in[MASK]ended destination . Various features of the head suggest that it w[MASK]s unfinished , such as a lack of [MASK]ymmetry below the mouth and an area of [MASK]ough stone above the base . Rock was n[MASK]t removed from around the earspools as on other heads , and does not narro[MASK] toward[MASK] the base . Large parts of the monument seem to be roughed out without finished detail . The right hand earspool also appears incomplete ; the fo[MASK]ward portion is marked with a sculpted line while the rear portion has been sculpted in relief , probably indicating that the right cheek and eye area were also unfinished . The La Cobata head was almost cert[MASK][MASK]n[MASK]y carved[MASK]from a raw bould[MASK]r rather than being s[MASK]ulpted from a throne . 
 
 = = = Takalik Abaj = = = 
 
 Takalik Abaj Monument 23 dates to the Middle Preclassic period , and is found in Takalik Abaj , an im[MASK]ortant city in the foothil[MASK]s of the Guatemalan Pacific coast , in the modern department [MASK]f Retalhuleu . It appears to be an Olmec @-@ style [MASK]olossal head re @-@ carved into a niche figure sculpture . If or[MASK]ginally a colossal[MASK]head then it would be the only[MASK]known example from outside the Olme[MASK] he[MASK]rtland . 
 Monument 23 is sculpted from andesite and falls in the midd[MASK]e of the size range [MASK]or confirmed colossal heads . It stands 1 @.@ 84 metre[MASK] ( 6 @.@ 0 ft ) high and measures 1 @.@ 2 metres[MASK]( 3 @.[MASK] 9 ft ) wide by 1 @.@ 56 metres ( 5 @.@ 1 ft ) deep . Like t[MASK]e examples from the Olmec heartland , the monument features a flat bac[MASK] . Lee Parsons c[MASK]ntests John Graham 's i[MASK]entification of Monument 23 as a re @-@ carved colossal head ; he views the side ornaments , identi[MASK]ied by Graham as ears , as rather the scrolled eyes of an open @-@ jawed monster gazing upwards . C[MASK]unteri[MASK]g[MASK]this , James Porter has claimed that the re @-@ carving of the face of a colossal head into a niche figure is clearly evident . 
 Monument 23 was damaged in the mid @-@ twentieth century by a loca[MASK] mason who attempted to break its expo[MASK]ed upper portion using a[MASK]steel chisel . As a result , the top is fragmented , although the broken pieces were[MASK]recovered by archaeologists and have been put back into place . 
 
 = = Collections = = 
 
 All of the 17 c[MASK]nfirmed colossal heads remain in Mexico . Two [MASK]eads from San Lorenzo are on pe[MASK]manent display at the [MASK]useo Nac[MASK]onal de Antropología in Mexico City . Seven of the San Lorenzo heads are on display in the Museo de Antropología de Xalapa . Five of them are in Sala 1 , one is in Sala 2 and on[MASK] is [MASK]n Patio 1 . The remaining San Lorenzo head is in t[MASK]e Museo Comu[MASK]itari[MASK] de San Lorenzo Tenochtitlán near Texistepec . All four heads from La Venta are now in Villahermosa , the state capital of Tabasco . Three are in the Parque @-@ Museo La [MASK][MASK]nta and one in the Museo del Estado de Tabasco .[MASK]Two hea[MASK]s are on display in the plaza of Santiago Tuxtla ; one [MASK]rom Tres Zapotes and the La Cobata Head . The other Tres Za[MASK]otes head is in the Museo Com[MASK]nitario de Tres Zapotes . 
 Several colossal heads have been loaned to temporary exhibitions abroad ; San Lorenzo Colossal Head 6 was loaned to th[MASK] Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York in 1970 . San Lorenzo [MASK]olossa[MASK] heads 4 and 8 were lent to the Olmec Art of Ancient Mexico exhibition in the National Gallery of Art , Washington , D.C. [MASK]hat ran from 30 June to 20 October 1996 . San Lorenzo Head 4 was again loaned in 2005 , this time to the de Young Museum in San Francisco . The de Young[MASK]Museum was loaned San Lorenzo colossal heads 5 and 9 for its Olmec : Colossal Masterworks of Ancient Mexico exhi[MASK]ition , which ran from 19 February to 8 May 2011 . 
 
 = = = Vandalism = [MASK] = 
 
 On 12 January 2009 , at least three people , i[MASK]cluding two Mexicans and one American , entered the Parqu[MASK] @[MASK]@[MASK]Museo La Venta in Villahermo[MASK]a and damaged j[MASK]st under 30 archaeological pieces , including the four La Venta colossal heads . The vandals were all members of an evangelical church and appeare[MASK] to have been carrying out a supposed pre @-@ Columbian ritual , during[MASK]which [MASK]alts , grape juice and oi[MASK] were thrown on the heads . It was estimated that 300 @,@ 000 pesos ( US[MASK]$ 21 @,@ 900 ) would be needed to repair the damage , and the restorat[MASK]on process would last four months[MASK]. The three vandals were released soon after their arrest after paying 330 @,@ 000 pesos each .[MASK]

 = Brad Stevens = 
 
 Bradley Kent " Brad " Stevens ( born October 22 , 197[MASK] ) is an American professional basketball head coach for the Bost[MASK]n Celtics of the[MASK]NBA . He was previously the head coach at Butler University in Indianapolis . A former [MASK]asket[MASK]all player , he grew up in Zionsville ,[MASK][MASK]ndiana , where he starred on the Zionsville Co[MASK]munity High School basketball team , setting four school records . After high school , he attended DePauw University , where he played basketball and earned a degree[MASK]in economics . He made the all @-[MASK] conference team multiple times and was a three @-@ time Academic All @-@ America nominee . 
 Stevens joined the Butler basketball program as a volunteer prior to the 2000 – 01 season after quitting his job at Eli Lilly and Company . He was promoted to a full @-@ time assistant coaching position for the 2001 – 02 season [MASK] On April 4 , 2007 , he [MASK]ecame the head coach after Todd Lickliter left to coach [MASK]he Iowa[MASK]Hawkeyes . [MASK]n his first year , Stevens led Butler to 30 wins , becoming the third @-@ youngest head coach in NCAA Division I history to have a 30 @-@ win season . 
 In [MASK]01[MASK] , his t[MASK]ird year as head coa[MASK]h , [MASK][MASK]evens broke the NCAA record for most wins in a coach 's first three years , exceeding [MASK]he previous record by eight . In the postseason , Stevens coa[MASK]hed Butler to the first Final Four in school history . At 33 years old , Stevens became[MASK]the second @[MASK]@ youngest head coach to make a NCAA National Championship game , losing 61 – 59 to Duke . Shortly after the season ended , he[MASK]signed a contract extension with Bu[MASK]ler through the 2011 – 12 season . With the 2010 – 11 team ma[MASK]ing the Final Four , Stevens became the youngest coach to go to two Fi[MASK]al Fours . [MASK]tevens co[MASK]ched the Bulldogs in[MASK]th[MASK]ir second conse[MASK]utive national championship game on April 4 , 2011 , w[MASK]ere th[MASK] team lost to the Huskies of the University of Connecticut . 
 Stevens is known for a cal[MASK] , focused coaching style . He spends a lot of[MASK]time analyzing opponents using statistical analysis , adding new wrinkles to his te[MASK]m 's play each game . H[MASK] put[MASK] a strong emphasis [MASK]n defensive and team oriented basketball . Butler 's success against teams with superior athletes[MASK]has been [MASK]ttributed to Stevens ' coaching style and calm [MASK]emeanor .[MASK]Stevens has twice been named the Horizon Leagu[MASK] Coach of th[MASK] Year and won collegeinsider.com 's Hugh D[MASK]rham Award mid @-@ season honors in January 2009 . He has also been both a Hugh Durham Award and Jim Phelan Award finalist all three years of his career .[MASK]Stevens has been cal[MASK]ed a coaching pr[MASK]digy and compared to John Wooden . He is married with two young children . In July 2013 , he signed a six @-@[MASK]year , 22 million dollar contract to become the head coach of the Boston Celtics in the NBA . In April 2015 , Stevens led t[MASK]e Celtics to [MASK]he NBA Playoffs as the 7th seed in the Eastern Conference with a 40 – 42 record .
