 = = Coaching style = = 
[MASK]
 Accordi[MASK]g to Stevens , in one of his first games as hea[MASK] coach [MASK] he was nervous and " felt like our team played on edge " because of it . He decided that a team 's play will reflect the mood of its coach ; a calm coach means a team that will remain poised in difficult game situations , while a nerv[MASK]us coach means a team that plays on edge . "[MASK]I don ’ t want to lose a game because of my [MASK]pproach , " he tol[MASK] [MASK]imself . Accord[MASK]ngly , he developed a strategy of always remaining calm and focused during games . He rarely raise[MASK] his voice or gets emotional[MASK], inste[MASK]d quietly[MASK]observing[MASK]on[MASK]the sideline with folded arms . He does not get upset ab[MASK]ut bad calls by referees or player mistakes , preferring to focus on " the next play " rather than what just happened . Butler player Willie Veasley explained Butler 's 2010 Final Four run by saying [MASK] " When those big runs [ by Syracuse and Kansas State ] came , Coach called a timeout and said a few calm words . Then he said[MASK]he believes in us , he loves us and we 're going to win the game . " On the [MASK]are occasion Stevens feels the need to correct a player , he does it with " positive reinforcement , [MASK]ust at a little louder decibel " , according to forme[MASK] assistant coach Matthew Graves . Above all , Stevens wants his players to be confident , not living in fear of b[MASK]ing yanked for making a bad play . 
 Externally , Stevens is always calm , but internally he is far f[MASK]om it . " I 'm not as calm as everybody thinks , " Stevens says . His wife Tracy adds , " He ’ s calm and collected , but he ’ s fiercely competitive . He ’ s always thinking about how he can beat you .[MASK]" Former player Joel Cornette says " E[MASK]eryone sees Brad as a level @[MASK]@ headed , c[MASK]lm and cool coach , but he ’ s about as competitive of a guy as I know . We wou[MASK]d get into it constantly , whether playing two @-@ on @-@ two or argui[MASK]g about [MASK]layers ’ having better college careers . " 
 Stevens s[MASK]ends a lot of time preparing for each game , and always tr[MASK]es to add a few new wrinkles specific to that game 's opponent . Sports Illustrated calls Stevens an expert " on breaking down tape and looking [MASK]t statistical trends to find opponents ' weaknesses . " Former player Ronald Nored agrees : " We know everything we need to about our opponents , all their tendencies are broken down " ahead of time . 
 Stevens is a proponent of using statistical analysis to enhance his coac[MASK]ing decisions , spend[MASK]ng almost as much t[MASK]me looking at statistics a[MASK] watching game film . " I think it 's a unique way of looking at the game that may be able to help best communicate to you[MASK] players " [MASK] he explains . For [MASK]xample , when Butler was slumping in late 2010 , Ste[MASK]ens challenged his team : " this [ 46 % defensive field goal percentage ] is where we are . This isn 't acceptable to get to wher[MASK] we want to go [MASK] But what does that really mean[MASK]? It 's not [MASK]ust get bett[MASK]r defensively , it is , if we give up 3 less ba[MASK]kets a game , then we will be at 40 percent field goal percentage defense which will be to[MASK] 20 in the country " . The team got the m[MASK]ssage , improved throughout the[MASK][MASK]eason , and ultimately went on a March run fueled by defense . In 2012 , S[MASK]evens became the first college coach to hire someone solely for statistical research when he added Drew Cannon to the staff . If he had the resources , Stevens says he would hire a team of statisticians to analyze the teams play . [MASK] Stevens ' teams are built around solid basketball fundamentals and good team work , rather than individual baske[MASK]ball skill . His teams [MASK]re known for their defense , forcing opponents into u[MASK]characteristic mistakes . The secret to basketball – and life – is " just to do the job to the best of your a[MASK]ility and don 't w[MASK]rry about anything else , " Stevens says . " Win the next game . Win[MASK]the next possession . That 's our focus . It 's bori[MASK]g . It 's also the way championships are won " , he says . In short , Stevens [MASK]s a st[MASK]ong believer in " The Butler Way " – doing all the little things that transform a group of good basketball [MASK]layers int[MASK] a great basketball team . "[MASK]I tell the players ' [MASK]he Butler Way ' isn 't easy [MASK]o define , " Stevens says , " but you can see it on the floor when we share the basketball , play with great energy and defend . " 
 Stevens prefers to recruit strong team play[MASK]rs in[MASK]tead of goi[MASK]g after " top recruits . " " The gu[MASK]s we [ have ] recruited , most of them weren 't very hig[MASK]ly[MASK]ranked , " Stevens says . " They had very go[MASK]d high school careers or careers at other places ( transfers ) , but for one reason or the other they weren 't seen as great pla[MASK]ers . But they all had[MASK]intangibles . " Stevens puts a strong emphasis on education and has said he would only recruit a " one and done " player if he was committed to getting his degree while playing professional[MASK]y . 
 Stevens has often b[MASK]en referred [MASK]o as a coaching prodigy , but is not interested in self @-@ promotion . He instead prefers to deflect the praise he receives to the players , athletic depar[MASK]ment , and his mentors . He has not been known to posture for more money , or to leak his name for open coaching positions . He has been described as humble , modest , and not " about the money " . 
 The New York Times , USA Tod[MASK]y , ESPN , and [MASK]the[MASK] comment[MASK]tors have attributed Butler 's success against teams with superior athletes to Stevens ' coaching style . The Times remarks , " the Bu[MASK]ldogs are very well prepared for their opponents , and they do not rattl[MASK] easily " , and says [MASK]hat the resulting confidence has led to the team 's success . " He coaches to his personality and to his strengths , " Collier says . " Obviously , he has g[MASK]eat rapport and communication ability with his team . " Yahoo ! Sports compared St[MASK][MASK]ens t[MASK] l[MASK]gendary coach John Wooden writing " Brad Steven[MASK] is wi[MASK]ning at Butler the Wooden way – calm and composed on the sideline . " Wooden agreed , saying , " I enjoy watching [ Stevens ] and very much en[MASK]oy [ Butler 's ] style of play . "

 = Shackleton ( crater ) = 
 
 Shackleton is an im[MASK]act crater that lies at the south pole of the Moon . The peaks along the crater 's rim are [MASK]xposed to almost continual sunlight , while the interior is perpetually in shadow ( a Crater of eter[MASK]al darkness ) . The low @-@ temperature interior of this crater functions as a cold trap that may capture and freeze vol[MASK][MASK]iles shed during comet impacts on the Moon . Measurements by the Lunar Prospec[MASK]or spacecraft showed higher than normal amounts of hydr[MASK]gen within the crater , wh[MASK]ch may indicate the presence of water ice . The crater is named after Antarctic explorer Ernest [MASK]hackleton . 
 
 = = Description = = 
 
 The rotational axis of the [MASK]oon lies within Shackleton , only a few kilometers from its center . The crater is 21 km in diameter and 4 @.@ 2 km deep . From the Earth , it is viewed edge @-@ on in a region of rough , cratered terrain . It is located[MASK]within the South Pole @-@ Aitken basin on a massif . The rim is slightly rais[MASK]d abo[MASK]t the surrounding surface and it has an outer rampart that has been only lightly impacted . No significant craters intersect the rim , and it is [MASK]loped about 1 @.@ 5 ° toward the direction 50 – 90 ° from the Earth . The age o[MASK] the crater is about 3 @.@ 6 billion years and i[MASK] has been in the prox[MASK]mity of the sout[MASK] lunar pole for at least the last two billion[MASK][MASK]ears .[MASK]
 Because the orbit of the Moon is tilted only 5 ° f[MASK]om [MASK]he eclipt[MASK]c , the interior of this crater lies in perpetual [MASK]arkness . Estimates of the area in permanent sha[MASK]ow [MASK]ere obtained from Earth @-@ based radar studies . Peaks along the rim of the crater are al[MASK]ost continually illuminated by sunlight , spending abou[MASK] 80 – 90 % of each lunar orbit exposed to the Sun . [MASK]ontinuously illuminated mountains have been termed peaks of eternal light and hav[MASK] been predicted to exist since the 1900s . 
 The shadowed portion of the crater was imaged with the Terrain Camera of the Japanese SELENE spacecraft using the illumination of sunlight reflected o[MASK]f the rim . The interior of the crater consists of a symmetrical 30 ° slope that leads down to a 6 @.@ 6 km diameter floor . The handful of craters a[MASK]ong th[MASK] interior span no mor[MASK] than a few hundred meters . The bottom is [MASK]overed by an uneven [MASK]ound[MASK]@-@ like feature that is 300 to 400 m thick . The central peak is about 2[MASK]0 m in heig[MASK]t . 
 The continuous shadows in the south polar craters cause the floors of these formations to maintain a temperat[MASK]re that never exceeds about 100 K. For Shackleton , the average temperature was dete[MASK]mined to be about 90 K , reaching 88 K at the crater floor . Under these conditions , the estima[MASK]ed r[MASK]te of loss from any ice in the interior would be 10 − 26 to 10 − 27 m / s . An[MASK] water vapor that arrives here following a cometary impact on the Moon wou[MASK]d lie permanently frozen on or below the surf[MASK]ce . However , the surface albedo of the crater floor matches the lunar far @-@ side , sugges[MASK]ing that there is no expose[MASK] [MASK]urface ice . 
[MASK][MASK]his crater wa[MASK] named after Ernest Henry Shackleto[MASK] , an Anglo @-@ Irish explorer of Antarctica from 1901 until his death in 1922 . The name was officially ado[MASK]t[MASK]d by the International Astronomical Union in 1994 . Nearby craters of note include Shoemaker , Haworth , de Gerlache , Sverdrup , an[MASK] Faustini[MASK]. Somewhat farther away , on the eastern hemisphere of the lunar near side , are the larger craters Amundsen and Scott , named after two other early explorers of the Antarctic continent . 
 
 [MASK] = Exploration = = 
 
 From the perspective of the Earth , this crater lies along the southern limb of the Moon , making observation difficul[MASK] . Detailed mapping of the polar regions and farside of the Moon did not occur until the advent of orbiting spacecraft . S[MASK]ackleton lies entirely within the rim of the immense South Pole @-@ Aitken basin[MASK], which is one of the largest known impact formations in t[MASK]e Solar System . This basin is over 12 kilometers[MASK]deep [MASK] and an exploration of its propert[MASK]es could provide useful information about the lunar interior . 
 A neutron spectrometer on board the Lunar Prospector spacecraft detecte[MASK] enhanced [MASK]oncentrations of hydrogen close to the nort[MASK]ern and southern lunar poles , including the crater Shackleton . At the end [MASK]f t[MASK]is mission in July 1999 , the spacecraft was crashed into the nearby crater Shoemaker in the hope of detecting from Earth @-@ based telescopes an impact @-@ generated plume containing water vapor .[MASK]The impact event did not produce any detectable wat[MASK]r vapor , and this may be an indication that the hydrogen is not in the form of hydrated minerals , or that the impact site did not contain any ice . Alternatively [MASK] it is possible that the crash did not excavate deeply[MASK]enough into the regolith to liberate signi[MASK]icant quantities of water vapor . 
 From Earth @-@ based radar and spacecraft images of the crater edge , Shackleton appe[MASK]rs to be relatively intact ; much like a young crater that has[MASK]not been significantly eroded from subsequent impacts . This may mean that the inner sides are relatively steep , which may make traversing the sides relativ[MASK]ly difficult for a r[MASK]botic vehicl[MASK] . In addition , it is possible that the interior floor might not have collected a significant quantity of volatiles si[MASK]ce its formation . However other craters in the vicinity are considerably older , and may contain significan[MASK] deposits of hydrogen , possibly in the form of wat[MASK]r ice . ( See Shoema[MASK]er ( lunar crater ) , f[MASK]r example . )[MASK]
 Radar studies preceding and following th[MASK] Lunar Prospe[MASK]tor mission demonstrate that the inner walls of Shackleton are similar in reflective characteristics to thos[MASK] of some sunlit craters . In partic[MASK]lar , the surroundings appear to contain a significant number of blocks in it[MASK] ejecta blanket , suggesting that its radar properti[MASK]s are a [MASK]esult of surface r[MASK]ughness [MASK] and not ice deposits , as was previously s[MASK]ggested from a radar experiment [MASK]nvolving the Clementine mission . This interpretation [MASK] however , is not universally agreed[MASK]upon within th[MASK] scientific community . [MASK]adar images of the crate[MASK] at a wavelength of 13 cm show no[MASK]evidence for water ice deposits . 
 Op[MASK]i[MASK]al ima[MASK]ing inside the crater was done for the first tim[MASK] by the Japanese lunar orbiter [MASK]pacecraft Kaguya in 200[MASK] . It did not have any evidence of significant amount of water ice , down to the image resolution of 10 m per pixel . 
 On November 15 [MASK] 2008 , a 34 @-@ kg probe made a hard [MASK]anding near the crater . The moon[MASK]impact p[MASK]obe ( M[MASK]P ) was launched from the Indian Chandrayaan @-@ I spacecraft and reache[MASK] the surface 25 min[MASK]tes later . The probe carried a radar altime[MASK]er , video imaging system , and a mass spectrometer , which will be used to search for water . 
 
 = = Potenti[MASK]l uses[MASK]= = 
 
 Some sites along Shackleton 's r[MASK]m receive almos[MASK] constant illumination . At these locales sunlight is almost always available for conversion into electricity using solar[MASK]panels , p[MASK]tentially making them good locations for future Moon landings . The temperature at this site is also more favorable than at more equatorial latitudes as it does not experience the daily temperature extremes of 100 ° C when the Sun is overhead , [MASK]o as low as − 150 ° C during the lunar night . 
 While scientific experiments performed by Clementine and Lunar Prospector could indicate the presence of water in the polar craters , the curren[MASK] evidence is far fro[MASK] definitive . There ar[MASK] doubt[MASK] among scientists as to whether or [MASK]ot the hydrogen is in the form of ice , as well as to the concentration of this [MASK] ore " with depth below the surface . Resolution of this issue will require future miss[MASK]ons to the Moon . The presence of wa[MASK]er suggests that the crater floor could potentially be " mined " for deposits of hyd[MASK]ogen in water form , a commodity that is expens[MASK]ve to del[MASK]ver directly from the Earth . 
 This crater has also been proposed as a future site for a large infrared telescope . Th[MASK] low temperature of the crater floor makes it ideal for infr[MASK]red observations , and solar cells placed along the rim could provide near @-@ continuous power to the observatory . About 120 kilometers from the crater lies th[MASK] 5 @-@ km tall M[MASK]lap[MASK]rt Mountain , a peak that is perpetually visible from the Earth ,[MASK]a[MASK]d which [MASK]ould serve as a radio relay station when suitably e[MASK]uipped . 
 NASA has named the rim of Shackleton as a potential candidate for its lunar outpost , slated to be up and running by 2020 and [MASK]ontinuously staffed by a crew[MASK]by 2024 . The location would promote [MASK]elf @-@ sustainability for lunar residents , as per[MASK]etual sunlight on the south pole would provide e[MASK]ergy for solar panels . Furthermore , the shadowed polar regions are believed to contain the frozen water necessary for human consumption an[MASK] could also be harvested for fuel manufacture . 
 
 
 = America[MASK] Beauty ( 1999 film ) = 
 
 American Beauty is a 1999 American drama film directed by Sam Mendes and written by Alan Ball . Kevin Spacey [MASK]tars as Lester [MASK]urnham , a 42 @-@ year @-@ old advertising ex[MASK]cutive who has [MASK] midlife crisis when [MASK]e becomes infatuated with his teenaged daughter 's best fr[MASK]end , Angela ( Mena Suvari ) . Annette Bening co @[MASK]@ st[MASK]rs as Lester 's [MASK]aterialistic wife , Carolyn ,[MASK]and Thora Birch plays their in[MASK]ecure daughter , Jane . Wes Bentley , Chris Cooper , and Allison Janney also feat[MASK]re . The film is descr[MASK]bed by academics as a satire of American middle @-@ class notions of beauty [MASK]nd personal satisfaction ;[MASK]analysis has focused on th[MASK] film 's explo[MASK]ations of romantic , and paternal[MASK]love , sexuality , beauty , mater[MASK]alism , self @-@ liberation , and redemption . [MASK] Ball began writing American Beauty as a play in the early 1990s , part[MASK]y inspired by the media circus around the A[MASK]y Fisher trial in 1992 . He shelved the [MASK]lay after realizing the story would not w[MASK]rk [MASK]n stage . After several years as a television screenwriter , Ball revived the idea [MASK]n 1997 when attemp[MASK]ing to break into the film industry . The modified [MASK]cript had a cynical outlook that was infl[MASK]enced by Ball 's frustrating tenures writing for several sitc[MASK]ms . Producers Dan Jinks and Bruce Cohen took American Beauty to DreamWorks ; the then @-@ fledgling film st[MASK]dio bought Ball 's script for $ 250 @,@ 000 , outbidding several other production bodies . DreamWorks financed the $ 15 million[MASK]production and ser[MASK]ed as its North American distributor . [MASK]merican Beauty marked acclaimed theater director Men[MASK]es ' film debut ; courted after [MASK]is successful productions of the musicals Oliver ! and Cabare[MASK] , Mendes was , nevertheless , only given the job after 20 others were conside[MASK]ed and several " A @-@ list " directors turned down the opportunity . 
 Spacey was Mendes ' first choice for the role of Lester , though DreamWorks had urged the director to consider better [MASK]-@ known actors ; similarly , the studio suggest[MASK]d several actors for the role [MASK]f Carolyn[MASK][MASK]ntil Mendes offered the part t[MASK] Bening without DreamWorks ' knowledge . Principal photogr[MASK]phy took plac[MASK] betwee[MASK] December 1998 and Feb[MASK]uary 1999 on soundstages at the Warner Bros. backlot in Burbank , California , and on location in Los Angeles . Mendes ' dominant style was deliberate and composed ; he made[MASK]extensive use of static shots and slow pans and zooms to generate tensi[MASK]n . Cinematographer Conrad Hall complemented Mendes ' styl[MASK] with peaceful shot compositions to contrast with the turbulent on @-@ screen events . During editing , Mendes made several changes that gave the film a less[MASK]cynical tone than the script . 
 Released in North America on September 17 , 1999 , American Beauty was positively received by critics and audiences ; it was the best @-@ reviewed American fi[MASK]m of the year an[MASK] grossed over $ 356 million worldwide .[MASK]Reviewers praised most aspects of the production , with particular emphasis [MASK]n Men[MASK]es , Spacey , and Ball ; criticism focused on the fami[MASK]iarity of the characters and setting . D[MASK]eamWorks launched a major campaign to increa[MASK]e the film 's chances of Academy Award success ; at the 72nd Academy Awards the following year , th[MASK] film won Best Pictur[MASK] , Best Director , Best Actor ( for Spacey ) , [MASK][MASK]st Original Screenplay , and Best Cinematography . It was nominated for and won many other awards and [MASK]onors , mainly for the direction , wr[MASK]ting , and acting .

 [MASK] = = Themes and analysis = = 
 
 
 = = = Multiple i[MASK]terpretations = =[MASK]= 
 [MASK] Scholars and[MASK]academics have offered many pos[MASK]ible readin[MASK]s of Ameri[MASK]an Beauty ; film critics are similarly divided , not so much about the[MASK]quality of the film , as their interpretations of i[MASK] . Described[MASK]by many as about " the meaning of life " or " the hol[MASK]ow existence of the American suburbs " , the film has defied categorization by even the filmma[MASK]ers . Mendes is indecisive , saying the script seemed to be about somethin[MASK] different each time he [MASK]ead it : " [MASK] mystery [MASK]tory , a kaleidoscopic journey through American suburbia , a series of love stories ; [ ... ] it was about impr[MASK]sonment , [ ... ] loneliness , [ and ] beauty . It was funny[MASK]; it was angry , sad . " The liter[MASK]ry critic and author [MASK]ayne C. Booth concludes that the[MASK]film resists any one interpretation : " [ American Beauty ] cannot be adequately summarize[MASK] as ' here is a satire on what 's wrong with American life ' ; that plays down the celebration of beauty . It is more tempting to summa[MASK]ize it as ' a portrait of the beauty underlying Amer[MASK]can miseries and misdeeds ' , but that plays down the scenes of cruelty and horror[MASK], and Ball 's disgust with our mores [MASK] It cannot be summarized with either[MASK]Lester or Ricky 's philosophical statements about wh[MASK]t life is or how one should live [MASK] " He argues that the problem of interpreting the film is tied with that of finding its cen[MASK]er — a controlling voice who " [ unites ] all of the choices " . He conten[MASK]s that i[MASK] American[MASK]Beauty 's case , it is neither Mendes nor Ball . Mendes considers the voice to be Ball 's , but[MASK]even while the writer was " strongly influential " on set , he often had to accept deviations from his vision , particularly ones that transformed the cynical tone of his script into something more optimistic . Wi[MASK]h " innumerable voices intruding on the original author 's , " Booth says , those who interpret American Beauty " h[MASK]ve forgotten to probe for the elusive center " . According to Booth , the film 's true controller is the creative energy " that hundreds of people put into its production , agreeing [MASK]nd disagreeing , inserting and cutting " . 
 
 = = = Imprisonment and redemption =[MASK]= = 
 
 Mendes called American Beauty a rite of passage film about imprison[MASK]ent and escape from imprisonment . [MASK]he mo[MASK]otony of Lester 's existence is es[MASK][MASK]blished through his gray , nondescript w[MASK]rkpl[MASK]ce and [MASK]haracterless cloth[MASK]ng . In these scenes , he is often framed as if trapped , " reiterating rituals that hardly please him " . He masturb[MASK]tes in the confines of hi[MASK] shower ; the shower stall evo[MASK]es a jail cell and the shot is the first of many where Lester is confined [MASK]ehind bars or within frames , such as when he is refl[MASK]cted behind columns of numbers on a computer m[MASK]nitor , " confined [ and [MASK] nearly crosse[MASK] out " . The academic and author Jody W.[MASK]Pennington argues that Lester 's journey is the [MASK]tory '[MASK] center . His sexual reawakening through meeting Angela is t[MASK]e first [MASK]f several turning points as he begins to " [ throw ] off the responsi[MASK]i[MASK]ities of the com[MASK]ortable life he has come to despise " . After Lester shares a joint with R[MASK]cky , hi[MASK] spirit is released an[MASK] he begins to rebel against Carolyn . Changed by Ricky 's " attractiv[MASK] ,[MASK]profound confiden[MASK]e " , Lester is convinced that Angela is attainable and sees that he must question his " banal , numbingly materialist suburban existence " ; he tak[MASK]s a job at a[MASK]fast @-@ food outlet , which allows him to regress to a point when he could " see his whole life ah[MASK]ad of him " . 
 When Lester is caught masturbating by Carolyn , his angry retort about their lack of intimacy is the first time he says aloud what he thinks about her . By confronting the[MASK]issue and Carolyn 's " superficial investments in others " , Lester is trying to [MASK] regain [MASK] voice in a home that [ only resp[MASK]cts ] t[MASK]e voices of mother and daughter " . His final turning point comes when Angela and[MASK]he almost have sex ; after she confesses her virginity , he no lo[MASK]ger thinks of her as[MASK]a sex object , but as a [MASK]aughter . He ho[MASK]ds her close and " wraps her up " . Mendes called it " th[MASK] most satisfying end to [ Lester[MASK]'s ] jour[MASK]ey there[MASK]could possibly have been " . With these final scenes , Mendes intended to show Lester at the conclusion of a " mythical quest " . After Lester gets a[MASK]beer from the refrigerator , the camera pushes toward him , then stops facing a hallway down [MASK]hich he walks[MASK]" to mee[MASK] his fate " . Having begun to act [MASK]is age again[MASK], Lester achieves closure . As he smiles at a family photo , the camera [MASK]ans slowly from Lester to the kitchen wall , onto which blood [MASK]patters as a gunshot r[MASK]ngs out ; the slow pan reflects the peace of Lester 's death . His body is discove[MASK]ed by Jane a[MASK]d Ricky . Mendes said that Ricky 's staring into Lester 's dead eyes is " the culmination of the theme " of the film : that beauty is found where it is least expected . 
 
 = = = Conformity and[MASK]beauty = = = 
 
 Like other American films of 1999 — such as Fight Club , Bringing Out the Dead , and Magnolia , American Beauty instructs its audience to " [ lead ][MASK]more meaningful lives " . The film argues the case against conformity , bu[MASK] does not deny that people need and want it ; even the gay characters just want to fit in . Jim and Jim , the Burnhams ' other neighbors , are a satire of " gay bourgeois co[MASK]pledom " , who " [ [MASK]nvest ] in the numbing sameness " that [MASK]he film criticizes [MASK]n heterosexual couples . The fe[MASK]i[MASK]ist academic and author Sally R. Munt argu[MASK]s that American Beauty uses its " art house " trappings to direct its message of nonconformity primarily to the [MASK]iddle classes , and that this approach is a " cliché of bourgeois pre[MASK]ccupation ; [ ... ] the underlying premise being that the luxury of finding an individual ' self ' through denial and renunciation is always open to those wealthy en[MASK]ug[MASK] to choose , and sly enough to present themselves sympathetically as a rebel . " 
 Professor[MASK]Roy M. Anke[MASK] argues that the film 's thematic center is its direction to th[MASK] audience to " look closer " . The opening combines an unfamiliar viewpoint of the Burnhams ' neighbo[MASK]hood with Lester 's narrated admission that he will soon die , forcing audiences to consider their own mortality and the beauty around them . It also sets a series [MASK]f mysteries ; Anker asks , " from what place exactly , and from what state of being , is he telling this story ? If he 's already dead , w[MASK]y bother with whatever it is he wishes to tell about[MASK]his last y[MASK]ar of being alive ? There is also the question of how Lester has died — or wi[MASK]l die . " Anker believes[MASK]the preceding scene — Jane 's disc[MASK]ssion with Ricky ab[MASK]ut the possibility of his killing her father — ad[MASK][MASK] further mystery . Professor Ann C. Hall disagrees ; she says by presenting an early res[MASK]lution to the mystery ,[MASK]the film a[MASK]lows the audience[MASK]to put it aside " to view the film and its philoso[MASK]hica[MASK] issues " . Through this examination of Lester 's life , rebirth and death , American Beauty satirizes American middle class notions of meaning , beauty and satisfaction . Even Leste[MASK] 's transf[MASK]rmation only comes about because of the possibility of sex with Angela ; he therefore remains a " willing devotee of the popular media 's exaltation of pubescent male sexuality as a sensible route to personal w[MASK]oleness " . Carolyn[MASK]is similarly driven by conventional views of h[MASK]ppiness ; from her belief in " [MASK]ouse beautiful " domestic bliss to her car and gardening outfit , Carolyn 's domain is a " fetching American m[MASK]llennial vision of Pleasantville , or Eden " . Th[MASK] Burnhams are unaware that they are " materialists philosophically , [MASK]nd devout consumers ethically " who expect the "[MASK]rudiments of American beauty " to give them happiness . Anker argues that " they are[MASK]helpless in [MASK]he fa[MASK]e o[MASK] the prettified economic and sexual stereotypes [ ... ] that they and th[MASK]ir culture have designated for th[MASK]ir salvation . " 
 The film presents Ricky as its " visionary , [ ... ] spiritual and mystical center " . He sees beauty in the minutiae of everyday life , [MASK]ideoing as much as he can for [MASK]e[MASK]r of missing it . He shows Jane what he considers the most beautiful [MASK]hing he has filmed : a plastic bag[MASK], tossing in the wind in front of a wall . He says capturing the moment was when he realized that there w[MASK]s "[MASK]an e[MASK]tire life behind things " ; he feels that " sometimes the[MASK]e 's so much beauty in the world[MASK]I f[MASK]el like I can 't take it ... and my heart is going [MASK]o cave in . " Anker argues that Ricky , in looking past[MASK]the "[MASK]cultural [MASK]ross " , has " [ grasped ] the radiant splendor of the created world " to see God . As the film progresses , the Burnhams mo[MASK]e clos[MASK]r to Ricky 's view of the world . Lester on[MASK]y forswears personal satisfaction at the fi[MASK]m 's end . On the cusp of having sex with Angela , he returns to himself after she adm[MASK]ts[MASK]her virginity . Suddenly confronted with a child , he begins to treat her as a[MASK]daughter ; in doing so , Lester sees himself , Angela , and his family " for the poor and fragile but wondrous creatures the[MASK] are " . He looks at[MASK]a picture of his family in happier times , and dies having had an epiph[MASK]ny that infuses him with " wonder , joy , a[MASK]d soul @-@ shaking gratitude " — he has final[MASK]y seen the world as it is . 
 According to Patti Bellantoni , colors ar[MASK] u[MASK]ed symbolically [MASK]hroughout the film , none more so [MASK]han red , which is an important thematic signature that drives the story and " [ de[MASK]ines ] Lester 's arc " . F[MASK]rst seen in drab colo[MASK]s that reflect his pas[MASK]ivity , Les[MASK]er surro[MASK]nds himself with red as[MASK]he regains his indi[MASK]iduality . The American Beauty ros[MASK] is repeatedly used as s[MASK]mbol ; when Lester fantasizes[MASK]about An[MASK]ela , she is usually naked and surrounded by rose petals . In these scenes , the rose symbolizes Lester 's desire for her . When ass[MASK]ciated with Carolyn , the rose represents a " façade for suburban success " . Ro[MASK]es are included in almost every shot inside the Burnhams ' home , where they si[MASK]nify " a mask cov[MASK]ring a bleak , unbeautiful reality " . C[MASK]rolyn feels that " as long as there can be roses , all is well " . She cuts the roses and puts them in vases , where they adorn her " meretricious vision of what makes for beauty " and begin to die . The roses in the vase in the Angela – Lester seduction scene symbolize Lester 's previous life and Carolyn ; the camera pushes in as Lester and Angela get closer , finally taking the roses — and thus Carolyn — out of the shot .[MASK]Lester 's epiphany at the end of the film is expressed by rain and the use of red , building to a crescendo that is a deli[MASK]erate contrast to the release Lester feels . The[MASK]constant use of red " lulls [ the audience ] subliminally " into becoming used to it ; consequently , it leaves the audience unprepared when Lester is shot and his blood spatters on the wall . 
 
 = = = Sexuality [MASK]nd repress[MASK]on = = = 
 
 Penningt[MASK]n argues that[MASK]American Beaut[MASK] defines its characters through their sexuality . Lester 's attempts to relive his youth are a direc[MASK] result of his lust for Angela , and the state of his relationship with Carolyn is in part shown through their lack of sexual contact . Also sexually frustrated , Carolyn has an affair that takes her from " cold perfectionist " to a more carefree soul w[MASK]o " [ sings ] happily a[MASK]ong with "[MASK]the mus[MASK]c in her car . Their nude scenes are used to communicate their vulnerability . By the end of the film [MASK] Angela 's hold on Jane has weakened until the only power she has over her friend is Lester 's attrac[MASK]ion to her . Col. Fitts reacts with disgust to meeting Jim and Jim ; he asks , " How come these faggots always have to rub it in your face ? How can they be so shameless ? " To whic[MASK] Ricky replies , " That 's the thing , Dad — [MASK]hey don 't feel like it 's anythi[MASK]g to be ashamed of . " Penn[MASK]ngton argues that Col.  With o[MASK]her turn @-@ of[MASK]@-@ the @-@ millennium[MASK]films such as Fight Club , In the Company of Men ( 1997 ) , American Psycho ( 2000 ) , and Bo[MASK]s Don 't Cry ( 1999 ) , American Beauty " raises the broader , widely explored issue of masculinity in crisis " . Professor [MASK]incent Hausmann charges[MASK]that in their reinforcement of masculinity " against threats p[MASK]sed by war , by consumerism , and by feminist and queer challenges " , these films pre[MASK]ent a need to " focus on , and even t[MASK] privilege " aspects of maleness " deemed ' devi[MASK]nt ' " . Lester 's transf[MASK]rmation conveys " that he , and not the woman , has borne the brunt of [ lack of being ] " and he will not stand for being emasculated . Les[MASK][MASK]r 's attempts to[MASK]" strengthen traditional masculinity " conflict with his responsibilities a[MASK] a father . Although the film portrays the wa[MASK] Lester returns to that role positiv[MASK]ly , he does not become " the hypermasculine [MASK]igure implicitly celebrated in films like Fight Club " . Hausmann concludes that Lester 's behavior toward Angela[MASK]is " a misguided but nearly necessary step toward his becoming a father again " . 
 Hausmann says the film " explicitly affirms the importance of upholding the prohibition against incest " ; a recurring theme of Ball 's work is his comparison of the taboos a[MASK]ainst [MASK]ncest[MASK]and homosexuality . Instead [MASK]f making a[MASK] over[MASK] distinction , American Beauty looks at how their repre[MASK]sion can lead to violence . [MASK]ol. Fitts is so ashamed of his homosexuality that it drives him to murder Lester[MASK].[MASK]Ball said , " The movie is in part a[MASK]out how homophobia is based in fear and repression[MASK]and about what [ they ] can do . " The film implies two unfulfilled incestuous desires : Lester 's pursuit of Ang[MASK]la is a manifestation of his lust f[MASK]r his own daughter , while Col. Fitts ' repr[MASK]ssion is exhibited through the almost sexuali[MASK]ed discipline with which he controls Ricky . Consequently , Ricky realiz[MASK]s that he can only hurt his father by falsely telling him he is homosexual , while Angela 's vulnerability and submission to Les[MASK]er reminds him of his responsibilities and the limits of his fantasy . Col. Fitts represents Ball 's father , whose repressed homosexual [MASK]esires led to his own unhappiness . Ball rewrote Col. Fitts to delay revealing him as homosexual , whi[MASK]h Munt reads as a possible " deferment of Ball 's own patriarchal @-@ incest fant[MASK]sies " . 
 
 = = = Temporality and music = = = 
 
 American Beauty follows a traditional narrative structure , on[MASK]y deviating with the displaced openin[MASK] scene o[MASK] Jane and Ricky from the middle of the story . Although the plot spans one year , the film is narrated by Lest[MASK]r at the moment of his death . Jacqueline Furby says [MASK]hat the plot " occupies [ .[MASK]. ] no time [ or ] all time " [MASK] ci[MASK]ing Les[MASK]er 's claim that life did not flash before his eyes , but that it " stretche[MASK] on forever like an ocean of time " . Furby argu[MASK]s that a " rhythm of repetition " forms[MASK]the core of the film 's structure . For example , two scenes have the Burnhams sitting down to an evening meal , shot from the same angle . Each i[MASK]age is broadly similar , [MASK]ith min[MASK]r differences in object placement and body language that reflect the changed dynamic brought on [MASK]y Lester 's new @-@ found assertiveness . Another ex[MASK]mple[MASK]is the pair of scenes in which Jane and Ricky film each other . Ricky films Jane from his[MASK][MASK]edroom window as she removes her bra , and the imag[MASK] is reversed later[MASK]for a similarly " voyeuristic and exhibitionist " scene in which[MASK]Jane films Ricky at a vulnerable moment . 
 Lester 's fantasies are emphasized by slow- a[MASK]d repetitive @-@ motion shots ; Mendes uses double [MASK]-@ and @-@ tri[MASK]le cutbacks [MASK]n several sequences , and the score alters to make the audience aw[MASK]re that it is entering a fantasy . One example i[MASK] the gymnasium [MASK]cene — [MASK]ester 's first enc[MASK]unter with Angela . While the cheerleaders perform t[MASK]eir ha[MASK]f @-@ time routine to " On Broadway " , Leste[MASK] becomes increasingly fixated on Angela . Time slows to represent his " voyeuristic hypnosis " and Lester begins to fantasize that Angela 's performance is for him alone . " On Broadway " — which provides a conve[MASK]tiona[MASK] underscore to the onscreen action — is replaced by discordant , percussive music that lacks melody or progression . This nondiegetic score is important to c[MASK]e[MASK]ting the narrative stasis in the sequence ; it conveys a moment for Lester that is stretched to an i[MASK]deter[MASK]inate length . The effect is one that Stan Link likens to " vertical time " , [MASK]escribed by[MASK]the compo[MASK]er and music theorist Jonathan Kramer as music[MASK]that imparts " a single [MASK]resent stretched out[MASK]into an enormous duration , a[MASK]potentially infinite [MASK] now ' that nonetheless feels like an instant " . The music is used like a visual cue , so that Lester an[MASK] the score are staring at Ang[MASK]la . The sequence ends with the sudden reintroduction [MASK]f " On Broadway " and teleological time . 
[MASK]According to Drew Miller of Stylus , the soundtrack " [ gives ] unconscious voice " to the characters ' psyche[MASK] and comple[MASK]ents the subtext .[MASK]The most obvious use of pop music " accompanies and gives context to " Lester 's attem[MASK]ts to recapture his youth ; reminiscent of how the counterculture of the 1960s combated American repression through music and drugs , Lester begins to smoke cannab[MASK]s[MASK]and list[MASK]n to rock music . Mendes ' song choices " progress through the history of American popular music " . Miller argues that although some may [MASK]e over familiar , there is a parodic element at work , " making good on [ the film 's ] e[MASK]co[MASK]ragement that viewers look closer " . Toward the end of the film , Thomas Newman 's score features more prominently , creating " a disturb[MASK]ng tempo " that matches the tension of the visuals . The exception is " Don 't L[MASK]t It Bring You Down " , which plays during Angela 's seduction of L[MASK]ster . At first appropriate , its tone cla[MASK]hes as the[MASK]seduction stops . The lyrics , which speak of " castles burning " , can be seen as a metaphor for Lester 's view of Angela — " the rosy , fantasy @-@ driven exterior of the ' American Beauty '[MASK]" — as it burns away to reveal " the timid , small @-@ bre[MASK]sted girl who , like his wife , has willfully developed a false publ[MASK]c self " . 
 
 = = Production = = 
 
 
 = [MASK] = Develop[MASK]ent = = = 
 
 In 1997 , Alan Ball resolved to move into t[MASK]e film industry after several fru[MASK]trating years writing [MASK]or the televisio[MASK] sitcoms Grace Under Fire and Cybill . He joined the United Talent Agency , where his representative , Andrew Cannava , suggested he write a spec script to " reintrod[MASK]ce [ himself ] to the town as a screenwriter " . Ball pit[MASK]hed three ideas to Cannava : two conventional romantic comed[MASK]es and American Beauty , wh[MASK]ch he had origi[MASK]ally conce[MASK]ved as a play in the early 1990s . Despite the story 's lack of an ea[MASK]ily marketable c[MASK]ncept , Cannava selected American Beauty beca[MASK]se he felt it was the one for which Ball had the most passion . While developing the script , Ball created another television sitcom ,[MASK]Oh , Grow[MASK]Up . He channeled his anger and frustration at having to accede to network demands on that show [MASK] and during his tenures on Grace Under Fire and Cybill — into writing American Beau[MASK]y . 
 Ball did not expect to sell the[MASK]script , believing it would act as more of a calling card , but American Beauty drew interest from several production bodies . Cannava passed the script to several producers , including Dan Jinks and Bruce Cohen , who took it to DreamWorks . With the help of executives Glenn Williamson and Bob Cooper , and Steven Spielberg in his capacity as studio partne[MASK] , Ball was convinced to develop the project at DreamWork[MASK] ; he received assurances from the studio — known at the time for its more conventional fare — that it would not " iron[MASK]the [ edges ] out " . In an unusual mo[MASK]e , DreamWorks decided not [MASK]o option th[MASK] script ; instead , in April 1998 , the st[MASK]dio bought it outrig[MASK]t for $ 250 @,@ 000 , outbi[MASK]ding Fox Searchlight Pictures , October Films , Metro @-@ Goldwyn @-@ Ma[MASK]er , and Lakeshore Entertainment . DreamWorks planned to make the film for $ 6 – 8 million . 
 Jinks and Cohen involved Ball throughout the film 's development , including casting [MASK]nd director selection . The producers met with about 20 interested directors , several of whom were considered " A @-@ list " at the time . Ball was not keen on the more well @-[MASK][MASK]known[MASK]directors because he believed t[MASK]eir involvement [MASK]ould increase the budget and lead DreamWorks to become " nervous about the content " . Nevertheless , the [MASK]tudio offered the film to Mike Nichols and Robert Zeme[MASK]kis ; ne[MASK]ther accepted . In the same year , Mendes ( then a theater direc[MASK]or ) revived the musical Cabaret in New York with fel[MASK]ow director Rob Marshall . Beth Swofford of t[MASK]e Creative Artists Agency arranged meetings for Mendes with studio figures in Los Angeles to see if[MASK]film direction was a possibility . Mendes came across American Beauty in a pile of eight scripts at Swofford 's hou[MASK]e , and knew immedi[MASK]tely that it was[MASK]the one he wanted to make ; early in his career [MASK] he had been inspired by how the film Paris , Texas ( 1984 ) presented contemporary America as a mythic landscape and he [MASK]aw the same theme in A[MASK]erican Beauty , as well as parallels with [MASK]is own childh[MASK]od . Mendes later met w[MASK]th Spielberg ; impressed by Mendes ' productions of Oliver ! and Cabaret , Spielberg encouraged him to consider American Beauty . 
[MASK]M[MASK]ndes found that he still h[MASK]d to convince [MASK]reamWo[MASK]ks ' production exec[MASK]tives to let him direct .[MASK]He had already discussed the film with Jinks and Cohen , and fel[MASK] they supported him . Ball was also keen ; having seen Cabaret , he was impressed with Mendes ' " keen visual sense " and thought he did not make obv[MASK]ous choices . Ball felt that Mendes liked to look under the story 's surface , a tale[MASK]t he felt would be a go[MASK]d fit with the themes of American Beauty . Mendes '[MASK]background also reassured him , because of the prominent role t[MASK]e playwright usually has in a theater production . Over two meetings — the first with Cooper , Wa[MASK]ter Parkes , and Laurie MacDonald , the second with Cooper alone — Mendes pitched himself to t[MASK]e studio . The studio soon approached Mendes with a deal to direct for the minimum salary allowed under Directors Guild of America rules — $ 150 @,@ 000 . Mendes accepte[MASK] , and later recalled that after taxes and his agent 's commission , h[MASK] only earned $ 38 @,@ 000 . In June [MASK]998 , DreamWorks confirmed that it had contract[MASK]d Mendes to direct the film . 
 
 = = = Writing = = = 
 
 Ball was partly inspired by two[MASK]encounters he had in the early 1990s . In about 1991 – 92 , Ball saw a plastic bag blowing in the wind outside the World Trade Center . He watched the bag for [MASK]0 minutes , saying later th[MASK]t[MASK]it provoked an " unexpected emotional response " . In 1992 , Ball became preoccupied with the media circus around the Amy Fisher trial . Discoverin[MASK] a comic book telling of the scandal , he was struck by how quickly it had become commercialized . He said he " felt like there was a real story underneath [ that was ] more fascinati[MASK]g and way more tragic " than the story presented to th[MASK] public , and attempted to turn the idea [MASK]nto a play . Ball produced around 40 pages , but stopped when he realized it would work bet[MASK]er as a film . He felt that because of the [MASK]isual themes , and becaus[MASK] [MASK]ach character [MASK]s story was .. " inte[MASK]sely personal " , it could not be done on a stage . All[MASK]the main character[MASK] appeared in this version , but Carolyn did not feature strongly ; Jim and Jim instead had much larger ro[MASK]es . 
 Ball based Lester 's story on aspects of his own life . Lester 's re @-@[MASK]exa[MASK]ination of [MASK]is life parallels feelings Ball had in his mid @-@ 30s ; like Lester , Ball put aside his passions to work in jobs he hated for people he did not respect . Scenes in Ricky 's household reflect Ball 's own childhood[MASK]experiences . Ball suspected his father was homosexual and used the idea to create Col. Fitts , a man who " gave up his chanc[MASK] to be himself " . Ball said the script 's mix o[MASK] comedy and drama was not inten[MASK]ional , but that it came unconsciously from his own out[MASK]ook on life . He said the juxtaposition produ[MASK]ed a starker cont[MASK]ast , giving each trait more impa[MASK]t than if they appeared alone .[MASK]
 In the script that w[MASK]s sent to prospective actors and directors , Lester and Angela had se[MASK] ; by the time of shooting [MASK] Ball had rewritten the scene to the final version . Ball initially [MASK]ebuffed counsel from oth[MASK]rs that he change the script , feeling they were being puritanical ; the final impetus to alter the scene came from DreamWorks ' then @-@ president Walter Parkes . He convinced Ball by indicating that in Greek mythology , the hero " has a m[MASK]ment of[MASK]epiphany before [ ... ] tragedy occurs " . Ball l[MASK]ter said his anger when writing the first draft had bli[MASK]ded him to the idea that Lester needed to refuse sex with Angela to complete his emotional journey — to achieve redemption . Jinks and Cohen asked Ball n[MASK]t to alter the scene rig[MASK]t away , as they felt it would be inap[MASK]ropriate to make changes to the scrip[MASK] before a di[MASK]ector had been hired . Early drafts also included a flashback to Col. Fitts ' service in the Marines , a sequence that unequivocally established his homosexual leanings . In love with anothe[MASK] Mar[MASK]ne , Col. Fitts sees the man die and comes to believe that he is being punished for the " sin " of being gay . Ball re[MASK]oved the sequence because it did not fit t[MASK]e structure of the rest of the film — Col. Fitts was the only character to have[MASK]a flashback — and because it removed the[MASK]element of surprise from Col[MASK] Fit[MASK]s ' later pass at Lester . Ball said he had to write it for his own benefit to know wha[MASK] happened to Col. Fitts , though all that remained in later drafts was subtext . 
 Ball remained involved throughout production ; he had signed a television show development dea[MASK] , so had to get permission from his p[MASK]oducers to take a year off to be cl[MASK]se to[MASK]American Beauty . Ball was on @-@ set for rewrites and to help interpret his script for all but two days of filming . His origi[MASK]al bookend scenes — in whic[MASK] Ricky and Jane are prosecuted fo[MASK] Lester 's murder after[MASK]being framed by Col. Fitts — were excised in [MASK]ost @-@ production ; [MASK]he writer later fe[MASK]t the scenes w[MASK]re unnecessary , saying they were a reflection of his " anger and cynicism " at the ti[MASK]e of [MASK]riting ( see " Editing " ) . Ball and Mendes revised the s[MASK]ri[MASK]t twice before it was sent to the actors , and twice more before the first read[MASK]@-@ through . 
 Th[MASK] shooting script features a scene in Angela 's car in which Ricky and Jane talk abo[MASK]t death and beauty ; the scene differed from e[MASK]rlier versions , [MASK]hich set it as a " big scene on a freeway " in which the three wi[MASK]ness a car crash and see a dead body . The change was a practical decision , as t[MASK]e production[MASK]was behind[MASK]schedule and they needed to cut costs . The schedule called for two days to be spent filming the crash , but on[MASK]y half a day was available . Ball agreed , but only if t[MASK]e scene could retain a line of Ricky 's where he reflects on having once seen a dead h[MASK]meless woman : " When you see something like that , it 's like God[MASK]is looking [MASK]ight at you , just for a second . And if [MASK]ou 're careful , you can look right back . " Jane asks : " And what do you see ? " Ricky : [MASK] Beauty . " Ball said , " They wanted to cu[MASK] that scene . They said it 's not importa[MASK]t . I sai[MASK] , ' You 're out of your fucking mind . It 's one of the most important scenes in the [MASK]ovie ![MASK]' [ ... ] If any one line is the heart and soul of this [MASK]ovi[MASK] , that is the line . "[MASK]Another scene was rewritten to accommodate the loss of the freeway sequence ; set in a schoolyard , it p[MASK]esents a " turning point "[MASK]for Jane in that she chooses to w[MASK]lk home with Ricky instead of going with Angela . By the end of filming , the script had been through[MASK]10 drafts . 
 
 = = = Casting = = = [MASK] 
 Mendes had Spacey and Bening in mind for the leads from the beginning , but DreamWor[MASK]s executives were un[MASK]nthusiastic . The[MASK]studio suggested several alternatives , including Bruce Willis , Kevin Costner , or John Travolta to p[MASK]ay Lester , and Helen Hunt or Holly Hunter to p[MASK]ay Carolyn . Mend[MASK]s did not want a big star " weighing the film down " ; he felt Spacey was the right choice based on his performances i[MASK] the 1995 films The Usual Suspects and Seven ,[MASK]and 1992 's Glengarry Glen Ross . Spacey was surprise[MASK] [MASK] he said , " [MASK] usually play charact[MASK]rs who are very quick , very manipulative and smart . [ ... ] I usua[MASK]ly wade in dark , sort of treacherous waters . This is a man living one step at a time , playing by his instincts . This is actua[MASK]ly much closer to me , [MASK]o what I am ,[MASK]than those other parts . " Mendes offered Bening the role of Carolyn wi[MASK]hout the studio 's consent ; although e[MASK]e[MASK]utives were up[MASK]et at Mende[MASK] , by September 1998 , DreamWorks had entered negotiations with Spacey and Bening . [MASK] Spacey loosely based Lester 's early " schlubby " deportment on[MASK]Walter Matthau . During the film , Lester 's physique improves fr[MASK]m f[MASK]abby to toned ; Spac[MASK]y worked out during [MASK]ilming to improve his body , but bec[MASK]use Mendes shot the scenes out of chronological order , Spacey varied p[MASK]stures to[MASK]portray the stages .[MASK]Before filming , Mendes and Spacey analyzed Jack Lemmon 's performa[MASK]ce in The Apartment ( 1960 ) , because Mendes wanted Spacey to emulate " the way [ Lemmo[MASK] ] moved , the way he looked , the way he was in that office and the way he was an ordin[MASK]ry man and yet a special man " . Sp[MASK]cey '[MASK] voiceover is a thr[MASK]wback to S[MASK]nset Boulevard [MASK] 1950 ) , which is also narrated in retrospect b[MASK] a dead character . You 'd go to church and see how people present themselves on the outside , and the[MASK] be inside their house and see the difference . " Bening and a hair stylist collaborated to create a [MASK][MASK]PTA president coif " hairstyle , a[MASK]d[MASK]Mendes and p[MASK]oduction designer Naomi Shohan researched mail @-@ order catalogs to better establish Carolyn 's environment of a " spotless suburban manor " . He lent Bening the Bobby Darin version of [MASK]he song " Do[MASK] 't Rain on My Parade " , which she enjoyed and persuaded the di[MASK]ector to include i[MASK] for a scene in which Carolyn sings in her car . 
 For the[MASK]roles of Jane , Ric[MASK]y , and Angela , DreamWo[MASK]ks gave Mendes carte [MASK]lanche[MASK].  = = = Filming = = = 
 
 Principal photography [MASK]asted about 50 days from Dec[MASK]mber 14 , 1998 , to February 1999 . American Beauty was f[MASK]lmed on soundstages at the Warner Bros. backlot in Burbank , Californ[MASK]a , and at Hancock Par[MASK] and Brentwood in Los Angeles . The aerial shots at the [MASK]eginning a[MASK]d end of the film were captured in Sacramento ,[MASK]California[MASK], and many of the school scenes were s[MASK]ot at South High School in Torrance , California ; several extras in[MASK]the gym crowd were[MASK]South High students . The film is set [MASK]n an upper middle @[MASK]@ class neighborhood i[MASK] an unidentified American town . Production desig[MASK]er Naomi Shohan likened the locale to Evanston , Illinois , but [MASK]aid , " it 's not about a place , it 's about an archetype . [ ... ] The milieu was[MASK]pretty much Anywhere , USA[MASK]— upwardly mobile suburbia . " [MASK]he intent was [MASK]or th[MASK] setting to reflect the characters , who are also archetype[MASK] . Shohan said , [MASK] All of them are very strained , and their lives are constructs . " T[MASK]e Burnha[MASK]s ' househo[MASK]d was designed as the r[MASK]verse o[MASK] the Fitts ' — the former a pristine ideal , but[MASK]graceless and lacking in " inner balance " , leading to Carolyn 's desire to at least give it the appearance of a " perfect all @-@ American household " ; the Fitts ' home is depicted in " exaggerated darkness [ and ] symmetry " . 
 The production selecte[MASK] two ad[MASK]ace[MASK]t properties on the Warner backlot 's " Blondie Street " for the B[MASK]rnham and Fitts ' homes . The crew rebuilt the houses to incorporate false rooms that esta[MASK]lished lines of sight — between Ricky and Jan[MASK] 's bedroo[MASK] w[MASK]ndows , and between Ricky 's bedroom and Lester 's garage . The garage wi[MASK][MASK]ows were designed specifically to obtain the crucial shot toward the end of the film in which [MASK]ol. Fitts — watching from Ricky 's bedroom — mistakenly as[MASK]umes that Lester is paying Ricky for sex . Mendes made sure to establish the line of sight early on in the film to make[MASK]the audience feel a[MASK]sense of familiarity with the shot . Th[MASK] house interiors were filmed on the backlot , on location , and on soundstages when overhead shots were ne[MASK]ded . The [MASK]nside of the Burnhams ' home was shot at a house close to Interstate 405 and Sunset Boulevard in Los Angel[MASK]s ; the inside of the Fitts ' h[MASK]me was shot in the city 's Hancock Park neighborhood . Ricky 's bedroom was designed to be cell @-@ like to suggest his " monkish " persona[MASK]ity , while at the same time blending with the high [MASK]-@ tech equipment to reflect his voyeuristic side . The production deliberately minimized the use of re[MASK] , as it was an important thematic signature elsewhere . The Burnhams ' home uses c[MASK]ol blues , while the Fitts ' is kept in a " depressed m[MASK]litary palette " . 
 Mendes ' dominating vi[MASK]ual style was deliberate and composed , with a minimalist desig[MASK] that provided " a sparse , almost surreal feeling — a bright , crisp , hard e[MASK]ged , near Magritte @-@ like[MASK]take on American suburbia " ; Mendes constantly directed his set dressers to empty the frame .[MASK]He made Lester 's fantasy scenes " more fluid and graceful " , and Mendes made minimal use of steadicams , feeling that stable shots generated [MASK]ore [MASK]ension .[MASK]For example , when Mendes used a slow push in to the Burnhams ' dinner table , he held the shot because his tra[MASK]ning as a theater director taught him the importance[MASK]of putting [MASK]istance between the characte[MASK]s . He wanted to keep the tension in the scene , so he only cut away when Jane left the t[MASK]ble . Mendes did use a[MASK]hand @-@ held camera for the scene in which Col. Fitts bea[MASK]s Ricky . Mend[MASK]s said the cam[MASK]ra provided the s[MASK]ene with a " kinetic [ ... ] off @-@ bala[MASK]ce energy " . [MASK]e also[MASK]went hand @-@ held for the excerpts of Ricky 's camcorder footage . Mendes took a long time to ge[MASK] the quality of Ricky [MASK]s footage to the level he wanted . For the plastic @-@ bag f[MASK]ot[MASK]ge , Mendes used wind machin[MASK]s to move the bag in the air . The scene took four takes ; two by the second unit did not satisfy Mendes , so he shot th[MASK] scene himself . He felt his first take lacked grace , but for the last attempt , he changed the location to the front[MASK]of a brick wall and added leaves on the ground . Mendes was satisfied by the way the wall g[MASK]ve definition to the outline of the bag . 
 Mendes avoided usin[MASK] close @-@ ups , as he believed the technique was overused ; he also cited Spielberg '[MASK] advice that he should imagine an audience silhouetted at the bottom of the camera monitor , to keep in mind that he was[MASK]shooting for display on a 40 @-@ foot ( 10 m ) screen . Spielberg — who visited the set a few times — also advised Mendes not t[MASK] worry about costs if he had a " great idea " toward the end of a long wor[MASK]ing day . Mendes said , " That happened three or four times , and they are all in the movie . " Despite Spielberg 's suppo[MASK]t , DreamWorks and Mendes fought constantly over the schedule and budget , although the studio interfered little with the film 's content . Spacey , Bening and Hall worked f[MASK]r significantly less[MASK]than their usual rates . American Beauty cost DreamWorks $ 15 mill[MASK]on to produce , [MASK]lightly above their projected sum . Mendes was so dissatisfied with his first three days ' filmin[MASK] that he obtained perm[MASK]ssion from DreamWorks to reshoot the scenes . [MASK]e[MASK]said , " I started with a wrong scene [MASK] actually , a comedy scene . And the actors played it way too big : [ ... ] it was badly shot , my fault , badly composed , my fault , bad costumes , my fault [ ... ] ; and everybody was doing what I was asking . It was all my fault . " Aware that he was a no[MASK]ice , Mendes dre[MASK] on the experience of Hall : " I mad[MASK] a very conscious decision early on , if I did[MASK] 't understand something technically , to say , without embarrassment , ' I don 't understand what you 're talking ab[MASK]ut , please ex[MASK]lain it . ' " 
 Mendes encour[MASK]ged some improvisation ; for example , when Lester masturbates in bed beside Carolyn , the director asked Spacey to improvise[MASK]several euph[MASK]misms for the act in each take . Mendes said , " I wanted that not just because it[MASK]was funny [ ... ] but because I didn 't want it to seem rehearsed . I wanted it to seem like h[MASK] was blurting it out of his mouth without thinking . [ Spacey ] is[MASK]so in control — I want[MASK]d him to break through . " Spacey oblig[MASK]d , eventually coming up with 35 phras[MASK]s ,[MASK]but Bening could not alwa[MASK]s keep a straight face , which meant the scene had [MASK]o be shot 10 times . The production used small amounts of com[MASK]uter @-@ generated imagery . Most of the [MASK]ose petals in Lester 's fantasies were add[MASK]d in post @-@ production , although some were real and had [MASK]he wires hol[MASK]ing the[MASK] digitally [MASK]emoved . When Lester fantasizes about Angela in a rose @-@ petal bath , the steam was real , save for in the overhead shot . To position th[MASK] camera , a hole had to be cut in the ceiling , through which t[MASK]e steam escaped ; it was instead added digitally [MASK] 
 
 = = = Editing = = = 
 
 American Beauty was edited by Christopher Greenbury and Tariq Anwar ; Greenbury began in the position , bu[MASK] had to leave halfway through post @-@ production because of a scheduling conflict with Me , Myse[MASK]f and Ire[MASK]e ( 2000 ) ( [MASK][MASK] which Chris Cooper also starred ) . Mendes and an assistant edi[MASK]ed the film for 10 days between the appointments . Mendes reali[MASK][MASK]d during editing that the film was different from the one he ha[MASK] envisioned . He believed he had been making a " [MASK]uch more whimsical , [ ... ] [MASK]aleidoscopic " film than what came together in the edit suite . Instead , Mendes was drawn to the emotion and dark[MASK]ess ; he began to use the score and shots he had intended to discard to craft the film along these lines [MASK] In total , he cut about 30 mi[MASK]utes from his original edit . The opening included a dr[MASK]am in which Lester imagines h[MASK]mself flying above the town . Mendes spent two days fil[MASK]ing Spacey against bluescreen , but remove[MASK] the sequence as he believed it to b[MASK] too whimsical — " like a Coen brothers movie " — and therefore [MASK]nappropriate for the tone he was trying to set . The opening in the fina[MASK] cut reused a scene from the middle of the film where Jane tells Ri[MASK]ky to k[MASK]ll her father . This scene was to be [MASK]he revelation to the audience that the pair was not responsibl[MASK] for Leste[MASK] 's death , as the way it was scored and acted made it clear that Jane 's request was not serious . However , in the portion he used in the opening — and when the full s[MASK]ene plays out later — Mendes used the score and a reaction shot of Ricky to leave a lingering ambiguity as to his guilt . The s[MASK]bsequent shot — an aerial view of the neighborhood — was originally intended as the plate shot for the bluescreen effects in the dream sequence . 
 Mendes spent more time recutting the first 10 minutes than the rest of the film taken together . He trialled several versions of the opening ; the fir[MASK]t e[MASK]it included bookend scene[MASK] in [MASK]hich Jane and Ricky are convicted of Lester 's murder , but Mendes excised these in the last week of editing because he felt they made the film lose its mystery , and because they did not fit with the theme[MASK]of redemptio[MASK] that had emerged during production . Mendes b[MASK]lie[MASK]ed the trial drew focus away from the characters and turned th[MASK] film " into[MASK]an episode of NYPD Blue " . Instead , he wanted the ending to be " a poetic mixture of dream and memory and narra[MASK]ive resolution " . When Ball first saw a completed edit , it was a ver[MASK]ion with truncated versions of these scenes . He felt that they were so s[MASK]ort that they " didn 't really register " . Mendes and he argued , but Ball was mo[MASK]e accepting af[MASK]er Mendes cut the sequences completely ; Ball felt that without the scenes , the film [MASK]as more optimistic and had [MASK]volved into some[MASK]hing that " for all its darkness had a really romantic heart " . 
 
 = = = Cinematography = = = 
 
 Conrad Hall was not t[MASK]e first choice fo[MASK] director of photography ; Mendes believed he was " too old and too experienced " to want the job , and he had been told that Hall was difficult to wor[MASK][MASK]with . Instead , Mendes asked Fred Elmes ,[MASK]who turned the j[MASK]b down because he did not like the script . Hall was recommended to Mendes by Tom Cruise , because of Hall 's work on[MASK]Without Limi[MASK]s ( 1998 ) , which Cruise had executive produced . Mendes was directing Cruise 's th[MASK]n @-@ [MASK]ife Nicole Kidman in the p[MASK]ay The Blue Room during preproduction on American Beauty , and had [MASK]lready storyboarded the who[MASK]e film .[MASK]Hall was involved for one month during[MASK]preproduction ; his ideas for lighting the film began with his first reading of the script[MASK], and further passes allowed him to refine his approach before me[MASK]ting Mend[MASK]s . Hall was initially concerned that audiences would not like the c[MASK]aracters[MASK]; he only felt able to identify with them during cast rehearsals , [MASK]hich gave him fresh ideas on his approach to the [MASK]isuals . 
 Hall 's approach was to create peaceful compositions that evoked classicism , to contrast with the turbulent on [MASK]-@ screen events and allow audiences to take in the action . Hall and Mendes first discussed the intended mood of a sce[MASK]e , bu[MASK] he was allowed to light the shot in any way he felt necessary . In most cases , Hall first[MASK]lit the scene 's subject by " painting in " the blacks and whites , before adding fill ligh[MASK] , which he reflected from beadboard or white c[MASK]rd[MASK]on the ceiling . This approach gave Hall more c[MASK]ntrol over the shadows while keeping the fill light unobtrusive and the dark [MASK]rea[MASK] free of spill . [MASK]all shot American Beauty in a 2 @.@ 39 : 1 aspect ratio in the Supe[MASK] 35 format , using Kodak Vision 500T 5279 35 mm film stock . He used Super 35 partly because its larger scope allowed [MASK]im to capture elements su[MASK]h as the corners of the peta[MASK] [MASK]-@ filled pool in its overhead shot , creating a frame around Angela within . He shot the[MASK]whole film at the same T @-@ stop ( T1.9 ) ; given his preference for shooting that wide , Hall favored high @-@ speed stocks to allow f[MASK]r more subtle lighting effects . He used Panavision Platinum cameras[MASK]wit[MASK] t[MASK]e company 's Primo series of prime and zoom lenses . Hall employed Kodak V[MASK]sion 200T 5274 and EXR 5248 stock for scenes with daylight effects . He had difficulty adjusting to Kodak 's newly in[MASK]roduced Vision re[MASK]ease print stock , which , combined with[MASK]his c[MASK]ntrast @-@ heavy lighting [MASK]tyle , created a look with too much contrast . Hall [MASK]on[MASK]acte[MASK] Kodak , who sent him a batch of 5279 that was 5 % lower[MASK]in contrast . Hall used a 1 / 8 inch Tiffen Black ProMist filter for alm[MASK]st every scene , which he said in retrosp[MASK]ct may not hav[MASK] been the best choice , as the optical [MASK]teps required to blow Super 35 up f[MASK]r its anamorphic release print[MASK]led to a slight amount of degradation ; therefore , the diffusion from the filter was not required . When he saw the film[MASK]in a theater , Hall felt that the image was slightly unclear a[MASK]d that had he not used the fil[MASK]e[MASK][MASK], the diffusion from the Supe[MASK] 35 – anamorphic conversion would have generated an image closer to what he originally intended . 
 A shot[MASK]where[MASK]Lester and Ricky s[MASK]are a canna[MASK]is joint behind a building came from a misunderstanding between Hall and Mendes . Mendes asked Hall to prepare the shot in his absence ; Hall assumed the characters would look for privacy , so he placed them in a narrow passage between a truck and the building , intending to light fro[MASK] the top of the truck . When Mendes ret[MASK]rned , [MASK]e explained that the c[MASK]aracte[MASK]s did not care if they were seen . He removed the truck and Hall had to rethink the lighting ; he lit it from the left , with a la[MASK]ge light crossing the actors , and with a soft light behin[MASK] the camera . Hall felt the consequent wide shot " worked perfectly for t[MASK]e tone o[MASK] the scene " . Hall made sure to keep rain , or the suggestion of it [MASK] in every shot near the end of the film . In one shot during Lester 's encounter with[MASK]Angela at the Burnhams ' ho[MASK]e , Hall crea[MASK]ed rain effects on t[MASK]e foreground cross[MASK]ligh[MASK]s ; in an[MASK]ther , he partly lit the pair through French windows to which he had added material to m[MASK]ke the r[MASK]in run slower , intensifying the light ( [MASK]lthough the strength of the outside light was unrealistic for a night scene , Hall fel[MASK] it justified b[MASK]cause[MASK]of the str[MASK]ng contrasts it produced ) . For the close @-@ ups when Lester and Ang[MASK]la move to the couch , Hall tried to keep rain in the frame , lighting through the window onto the ceiling behind Lester . He also used rain boxes to produce rain patterns where he wa[MASK]ted [MASK]ithout lighting the [MASK]ntire room . 
 
 = = = Mu[MASK]ic = = = 
 
 Thomas Newman 's score was recorded in Sant[MASK] Monica , California . He mainly used percussion instruments to creat[MASK] the mood and rhythm , the inspiration for which was provided by Mendes [MASK] Newman " favored pulse[MASK], rhythm , and color over melody " , making for a more minimalist score than he had previously created . He b[MASK]ilt each cue around " small , endlessly repeating phrases " — often , the only variety[MASK]through a " thinning of the texture for eight[MASK]bars " . The percussion instruments included tablas[MASK][MASK] bon[MASK]os , cymbals , piano , xylophones , a[MASK]d mari[MASK]bas ; also featured were guit[MASK]rs , flute , and wo[MASK]ld music instruments . [MASK]ewman also used electronic music and on " quirkier " tracks employed more unorthodox methods , such as ta[MASK]ping metal mixing bowls with a fing[MASK]r and using a detuned mandolin . Newman believed the score helped move the film along w[MASK]thout[MASK]disturbing the " moral ambiguity " of the scrip[MASK] : " It was a real delicate bal[MASK]ncing act in term[MASK] of what music worked to preserve [ that ] . " 
 The soundtrack features songs by Newman , Bobby[MASK]Darin , The Who , Free , Eels , The Guess Who , Bill Withers , [MASK]etty Carter , Peggy Lee[MASK], The Folk Implosion , Gomez [MASK] and Bob Dylan , as well as two cover versions — The Beatles ' " Because " performed by Elliott Smith , a[MASK]d Neil Young 's " Don 't Let It Bring You Down " performed by Annie Lennox . Produced by the film 's music supervisor Chris Douridas , an abridged soundtrack[MASK]album[MASK]was released on October 5 , 1999 , and went[MASK]on to be nominated for a Grammy Award for Best Soundtrack Album . An album featuring 19 tracks from Newman 's score was released on January 11 , 2000 , and won the Grammy Award for Best Score Soundtrack Album . Filmmaker considered the score to be one of Newman 's best , saying it " [ enabled ] the film 's transcendentalist aspirations " . In 2006 , the magazine chose the score as one of 20 essential soundtracks it believed spoke to the " complex and innovative relationships between music and screen storytelling " .

 = = Critical reception = = 
 
 American Beauty was widely considered the best film of[MASK]1999 by the Americ[MASK]n press . It received overwhelming praise , chiefly for Spacey , Mendes and B[MASK]ll[MASK][MASK] Variety rep[MASK]r[MASK][MASK]d that " no other 1999 movie[MASK]h[MASK]s benefited from such universal raves . " It was the best @-@ received title at the Toronto International Film Festival ( TIFF ) , where it won the People 's C[MASK]oice [MASK]ward after a ballot of t[MASK]e festival '[MASK] audience[MASK] . TIFF 's director , Piers Hand[MASK]ing , said , " American Beauty was the buzz of the festival , the film mo[MASK]t talked @-@ about . " 
 Writing in Variety , Todd McCarthy sai[MASK] the cast ensemble " could not be bett[MASK]r " ; he praised Spacey 's "[MASK]handling of innuendo ,[MASK]subtle sarca[MASK]m , and blunt talk " and the way he imbued Lester with[MASK]" genuine feeling " . Janet Maslin in The New York Times said Spacey was at his " wittiest and most agile " to date , and Roger Eber[MASK] of the Chicago Sun @-@ Times singled Spacey out for successfully p[MASK]rtraying a man w[MASK]o " does reckless and foolish things [ but who ] doesn 't deceive himsel[MASK] " . Kevin[MASK]Jackson of Sight & Sound said Spacey impressed in ways distinct from his previ[MASK]us performances , the most satisfying aspect being his portrayal of " [MASK]oth sap and hero " . Writing in Film Quarterly , Gary Hentzi praised the ac[MASK]ors , but said that characters such as Carolyn and Col. Fitts w[MASK]re st[MASK]reotypes . Hentzi accused Mendes and Ball of identifying too readily with Jane a[MASK]d Ricky , saying the latter was their " fantasy figure " — a teenaged boy who 's an absurdly wealthy artist able to " finance [ his ][MASK]own projects " . Hentzi said Angela was the most believable teenager , in particular with he[MASK] " painfully [MASK]amiliar " attempts to " live up to an unworthy image of herself " . Maslin agreed that s[MASK]me characters were unoriginal , but said their detailed characterizations made them memorable . Kenneth Turan of the Los Angeles Times said the actors coped " faultlessly " with what wer[MASK] difficult roles ; he called Spacey 's pe[MASK]formance " the energy that drives the film[MASK]" , saying the actor command[MASK]d a[MASK]dience involvement despite Lester not always being[MASK][MASK]ympathetic .[MASK]" Against considerable odds , we do like [ these characters ] , " Turan conclu[MASK]ed . 
 Ma[MASK]lin felt that Mendes directed with " terrific visual flair " , saying his minimalist style balanced " the mordant and bright " and that he evoked the " delicate , eroticized power @-@ playing vignettes " of his theater work . Jackson said Mendes ' theatrical roots [MASK]arely showed , and that th[MASK][MASK]" most remarkable " aspect was[MASK]that Spacey 's performance did not overshadow the film . He said that Mendes worked the script 's intricacies smoothly , to the ensemble 's strength[MASK] , and stag[MASK]d the tonal shifts skillfully . McCarthy believed[MASK]American Beauty a " st[MASK]nning car[MASK] of introduction[MASK]" for film débutantes Mendes an[MASK] Ball . He [MASK]aid Mendes ' " sure hand " was " as precise and contr[MASK]lled " as his theater work . McCarthy cited Hall '[MASK] inv[MASK]lvement as fortun[MASK]te for Mendes , as the cinematographer was " unsurpassed " at conveying the th[MASK]mes of a wor[MASK] . Turan agreed that Mendes ' choice of collab[MASK]rators was " shrewd " , naming Hall and Newman in particula[MASK] . Turan sugg[MASK]st[MASK]d that America[MASK] Beauty may ha[MASK]e benefited[MASK]from[MASK]Mendes ' inexperience , as his " anythi[MASK]g 's possible daring " made hi[MASK] attempt beats th[MASK]t more seasoned directors might have avoided .[MASK]Turan felt that Mendes ' a[MASK]complishment was to " capture and enhance [ the ] duality " of Ball 's scri[MASK]t — the simult[MASK]neously " caricatured [ ... ] and painfully real " characters . H[MASK]ntzi , while critical of many of Mendes and Ball 's choices , admitted the film showed off their " considerable talents " . 
 Turan cited Ball 's lack of constraint when writing the film as the reason for its uniqueness ,[MASK]in particular the script 's subtle changes in tone[MASK]. McCarthy said the script was " as fresh and d[MASK]stinctive " as an[MASK] of its American film contemporari[MASK]s , and praised how it analyzed the characters while not [MASK]ompromis[MASK]ng narrative pace . He called[MASK]Ball 's dialogue " tart " and said the characters — Caroly[MASK] ex[MASK]epted — were " deeply drawn " . One o[MASK]her flaw[MASK], McCarthy s[MASK]id , was the re[MASK]elation of Col. Fitts ' homo[MASK]exuality , which he said evo[MASK]ed " hoary Freudiani[MASK]m " . Jackson said the film transcended its clichéd setup to become a " wonderfully resourceful and sombre comedy " . He said that even when the film played for sitcom laughs , it did so with " u[MASK]expe[MASK]ted nuance " . Hentz[MASK] criticized how the film ma[MASK]e a mystery of Lester 's murder , believing it ma[MASK]ipulative and simply a way of[MASK]generating suspense . McCarthy cited the production and co[MASK]tume design as[MASK]pluses , and said the soundtrack was good at creating " ironic counterpoint [ s ] " to the story . Hentzi concluded that American Beauty was " vital but uneven " ; he felt the film 's examination of " the ways whic[MASK] teena[MASK]ers and adults imagine each other 's lives " was its best point , a[MASK][MASK] tha[MASK] although Lester a[MASK]d Angela 's dynamic was fami[MASK]iar , its romantic irony stood beside " the most[MASK]enduring literary treatments " of the theme ,[MASK]such as Lolita . Nevertheless ,[MASK]Hentzi believed that the fil[MASK] 's themes of materialism and conformity in American sub[MASK]rbia were " hackneyed " . McCarthy conceded that the setting was fami[MASK]iar , but said it [MASK]erely provided the film with [MASK] " st[MASK]rting point " from which to tell its " [MASK]ubtle and acutely judged tale " .[MASK]Maslin agreed ; she said that while it " takes aim at targets that are none to[MASK] fresh " ,[MASK]and that the theme of nonconformity did not surprise , the film had its own " corrosive novelty " . Ebert awarded American Beauty four stars out of four , and Turan said it was layered , subversive , complex , and surprising [MASK] con[MASK]lud[MASK]ng it was " a hell of a[MASK]picture " . 
 A few months after the film 's release , repor[MASK]s of a backlash a[MASK]pear[MASK]d in the American[MASK]press , and [MASK]he years[MASK]s[MASK]nce have[MASK]seen its critical rega[MASK]d wane . In 2005 , Premiere named American Beauty as one of 20 " most overrated movies of all ti[MASK]e " ; Mendes accepted the inevitability of the critical reappr[MASK]isal , saying , " I thought [MASK]ome of it was entirely justified — it wa[MASK] a little overpraised at the time . " 
 Currently , the film holds an 88 % score on Rotten Tomatoes based on 180 reviews , with an average rating of [MASK] @.@ 2 / 10 ; the critical consensus reads , " Flawlessly cast and brimming with[MASK]da[MASK]k , acid wit , American Beauty is a smart , pr[MASK]vocative high point[MASK]of late ' 90s mainstream Hollywood film . " Meta[MASK]r[MASK]tic gives the film a score of 86[MASK],[MASK]based on 33 reviews , indicating " univ[MASK]rsal acclaim . "
