 = Christopher Gore = 
 
 Christopher Gore ( September 21 , 1758 – March 1 , 1827 ) was a prominent Massachu[MASK]etts lawyer , Federalist politician , and U.S. diplomat . Born into a family divided by the American Revolution , Gore sided with the victorious Patriots , established a successful law practice in Boston , and built a fortune by purchasing Revolutionary gover[MASK]ment debts at a[MASK]discount an[MASK] receiving full value for them from the governme[MASK]t . 
 Gore enter[MASK]d politics in 1788 , serving briefly in the Massachus[MASK]tts legislature before being appointed U.S. District Attorney for Massachusetts . He was then appointed by President George[MASK]Washington to a diplomatic commission dealing with maritime claims in Great Britain . He returned to Massachus[MASK]tts in 1804 and reentered state politics , running unsuccessfully for governor several times before winning in 1809 . He served one term , losing to Democratic @-@ Repub[MASK]ican Elbridge Gerry in[MASK]1810 . He was appointed to the US Senate by Governor Cale[MASK] Strong in 1813 , where he led opposition to the War of 1812 . 
 Gore invested his fortune in a variety of businesses , inc[MASK]ud[MASK]ng important infrastructure projects such as the Mid[MASK]lesex Canal and a bridge across the Charle[MASK] River . He was a major investor in the early textile indu[MASK]try , fu[MASK]ding the Boston Manufacturing Company [MASK]nd the M[MASK]rrimack Manufact[MASK]ring Company ,[MASK]whose business established the city of Lowell ,[MASK]Massachusetts . Gore[MASK]was i[MASK]volved in a variety of charitable[MASK]causes , and was a major benefactor of Harvard College , where the first library was named in his honor . His palatial mansion in Waltham , Massachusetts , now known as Gore Place , is one of the finest extant exam[MASK]les of Fede[MASK]al[MASK]st architecture , and has been declared a National Historic [MASK][MASK]ndmark . 
 
 = = Early years = = 
 
 Christopher Gore was born in Boston on September 21 , 1758 , [MASK]ne of many children of Frances and John Gore , a su[MASK]cessful merchant and artisan . He was the youngest of their three sons to survive to adultho[MASK]d . He attended Boston Latin Schoo[MASK] , and entered Harvard College [MASK][MASK] the young ( even for the time ) age of thirteen . At the outset of the American Revolutionary War and the Siege of Bosto[MASK] in 1775 , Harvard 's buildings were occupied by the Continental[MASK]Army , and Gore temporarily co[MASK]tinued his stu[MASK]ies[MASK]in Brad[MASK]ord until Harvard could resume operations in Concor[MASK] . While a[MASK] Harvard [MASK]ore participated in a speaking club , and formed significant lifelong friendships with Rufus King and John Trumbull . 
 Gore graduated in 1776 , and promptly enlisted in the Continental artillery regiment of his brother @-@ in @-@ law Thomas Crafts , where he served as a clerk until 1778 . The Gore family was divided by the war : Gore 's father was a Loyalist who left Boston when the Britis[MASK] Army evacua[MASK]ed the city in March 1776[MASK]. Gore was conseq[MASK]ently called upon to support his mother and three sisters , who remained in B[MASK]ston . In 1779 Gore success[MASK]ully petitioned the state for the remaining fam[MASK]ly 's share of his father 's seized assets . 
 
 = = Early l[MASK]gal career = = 
 
 After his military service Gore studied law with John Lowell , and was admitted to the bar in 1778 after a comparatively brief[MASK]tutelage . Gore 's law practice flourished , in part because many Loyalist lawyers had fled Massachusetts . Gore 's clients included Loyalists seeking[MASK]to recover some of the[MASK]r assets , as well as London @-@ based British merchants with claims to pursue . His briefs were generally well @-@ reasoned , and he was seen as a successful trial lawyer . 
 Gore grew his fortune by investing carefully in revolutionary currency and bonds . The securities he purchased were paper that had been given to Conti[MASK]ental Army soldiers in lieu of pay , which they often sold at a steep discount . One batch of securities he purchased , for instance , cost him about $ 3 @,@ 700 but had a face value of $ [MASK]5 [MASK],@ [MASK][MASK]0 . In 1785 he married Rebecca Amory Payne , daughter of a wealthy merchant , maritime [MASK]nsurer , [MASK]nd director [MASK]f the Bank of Massachusetts . The couple were known for their social[MASK]graces and became prominent members of Boston society . 
 In 1786 Gore became concerned abou[MASK] a ris[MASK] in anti @-@ lawyer sentimen[MASK] in[MASK]Massachusetts . Grievances over harsh policies pursued by Governor James Bowdoin blossomed into Shays ' Rebellion , which required militia action to crus[MASK] in 1787 . Gore was[MASK]one of several[MASK]high @-@ profile l[MASK]wyers assigned to defend participants in the rebellion ( includ[MASK]d in this group were Theodore Sedgwick , Caleb Strong , James Sullivan , Levi Lincoln , Sr. , and Thomas [MASK]awes ) . Although many rebels were ultimately convicted , a large number received amnesty . In 178[MASK] , Gore [MASK]as elected[MASK]a delegate to the[MASK]1789 Massachusetts convention that ratifie[MASK] the United States Constitution . His election was contested[MASK]because Boston , where he liv[MASK]d , was at the time more inclined toward state power . Gore nonetheless was strongly Federalist , u[MASK]ging support of the new Constitution . 
 
 = = Legislator , banker , and speculator = = 
 
 In 1788 Gore wa[MASK] elected to the Massach[MASK]setts House of Representatives . He took a leading role in adopting the state 's rules for actions required of it by the new federal constitution . B[MASK][MASK]his propo[MASK]al the [MASK]egislature decided that presidential electors would[MASK]be chosen by a joint session . He also pro[MASK]osed that the state House and Senate agree [MASK][MASK] separate v[MASK]tes on choices for the United States Senate , a process that would s[MASK]gnificantly reduce popular inp[MASK]t to the choice . His choice was ultimately rejected in[MASK]fa[MASK]or of a process whereby the House selected a slate of candidates , from which the Senate would choose one . In 1789 Gore decide[MASK] to stand for reelecti[MASK]n , but lost , owing to strong anti @-@ nationalist fervor in Boston at the time . He managed to win a seat later ,[MASK]when a special election was held after resignations opened several seats . [MASK] Gore 's financial speculations in the late 1780s significant[MASK]y multiplied his wealth . In 1788 he and Andrew Craigie , a Boston businessman who had retained Gore for legal services , entered into a secret agreement to purchase Continental securities with a face v[MASK]lue of $ 100 @,@ 000 in a speculative bid that their value would rise . By late October[MASK]of that year , the pair had met this goa[MASK] : Gore had purchased $ 90 @,@ 000 worth of paper for about $ 20 @,@ 000 , and encouraged Craigie to purchase more than the $ 1[MASK] @,@ 000 he had acquired if his funding would allow for it . Gore also purchased Massachusetts war @-@ related debts , and [MASK]obbied Massachusetts Congressmen[MASK]for the U.S. governmen[MASK] to assume those as well . 
 Gore 's windfall was realized w[MASK]en in 1790 the United States Congress , acting on a p[MASK]oposal made by Alexander Hamilton and supported by Gore '[MASK] friend Rufus King , passed legisl[MASK]tion that exchanged Continental and state paper for ne[MASK] U.S. paper at face value . Not only did Gore win on this exchange , but the paper he received appreciated in value before he sold it . The exact amount he made is unclear from the surviving documents : Jo[MASK]n Quincy Adam[MASK] wrote that Gore 's speculations made him the wealthi[MASK]st law[MASK]er in the country . 
 The succes[MASK] of Gore 's speculations prompted him to [MASK]nter a partnership with Cra[MASK]gie , Willia[MASK] Duer and Daniel Parker in an attempt to[MASK]acquire U.S. foreign debt obligations on favorable term[MASK] . Par[MASK]er was a business partner of Craigie 's , and Duer was an influential New York businessman and Trea[MASK]ury Department official whose lavish lifestyle impressed Gore . The [MASK]artnership promoted sales of U.S. lands in Europe , and sought to acquire U.S. obligations to Franc[MASK] . Although Gore [MASK]ank $ 10 @,@ 000 into this venture , it failed : more powerful and experienced Dutch bankers outmaneuvered t[MASK]e Americans . Gore also engaged in other ventures with these partners , but apparen[MASK]ly carefully st[MASK]yed with financial speculations , and avoided the partners ' less succe[MASK]sful land ventures . 
 Much of Gore 's financial activ[MASK]ty was mediated throu[MASK]h[MASK]the Bank of Ma[MASK]sachusetts , where his father @-@ in @-@ law [MASK]as a director . Gore himself was elected to its board in 1785 , when he also became a shareholder . During his time on the board the bank tig[MASK]tened its regulations on loan repayments , a move th[MASK]t improved[MASK]the sta[MASK][MASK]lity of its capital .[MASK]Gore used the bank [MASK]or most of his personal deposits[MASK], but also drew o[MASK] line[MASK] o[MASK] credit for [MASK]s much as[MASK]several thousand dollars . The bank shares he held paid relatively high dividends until 1791 , when the bank received serious competition f[MASK]om the First Bank of the United States . 
 The Bank of the United States was established by Alexa[MASK]der Hamilton to provide stable banking services on a national sca[MASK]e , and sought to open a branch in Boston . H[MASK]milton[MASK][MASK]ecruited heavily in the Bank of Massachusetts , and Gore decided to make the move . He sold his shares in the Massachusetts bank , and became a director of the Boston branch of the U.S. Bank . He also pu[MASK]chased 200 shares in the new bank ,[MASK]a relatively large investment . Gore was influential in makin[MASK] hiring [MASK]ecisions for the branch , and sought to merge[MASK]state @-@ chartered banks into the organization , arguing that only a nati[MASK]nally chartered bank could provide consistent and stable service . Gore resigned from the board in 1794[MASK], citing the deman[MASK]s of his law practice . 
 Gore 's financial successes enab[MASK]ed him to[MASK]join the elite society of Boston . In 1789 he purchased a large mansion on fashionable Bowdoin Square , and also bought a country estate in Waltham that grew over [MASK]ime to 300 acres ( 120 ha ) [MASK] He had a hou[MASK]e buil[MASK] on the estate , mo[MASK]t of which he operated as a gentleman farmer . He and other simil[MASK]rly @-@ situated Federalists formed the Massachusetts Society for Promoting Agriculture , of which he served as a trustee for several years ; the organization was not seen as significantly contributing to advances in agriculture . 
 
 = = District attorney and diplo[MASK]at = = [MASK] 
 In 1789 President George Washington appointed Gore the first United St[MASK]tes Attorney for Massachusetts as a reward for [MASK]is support . Gore controversially refused to resign from[MASK]the state [MASK]egislature , arguing that th[MASK] state constitution 's prohibitions against holding multiple offices did not apply to federal posts . He eventually resigned the legisl[MASK]tive[MASK]seat under protest because of [MASK]ressure from his fellow legisl[MASK]tors . 
 Gore served as di[MASK]trict attorney until 1796 . His principal matter of concern was the enforcement of U.S. neutrality with respect to the French Revolutionary Wars . He attempted several[MASK]times to prosecute the Frenc[MASK] consul in Boston , Antoine Dupl[MASK]ine , fo[MASK] arming and operating privateer[MASK] out of the Port of Boston , but he was stym[MASK]ed by local juries that sympathized with the French . Duplaine was eventual[MASK]y expelled on orders from Pre[MASK]ident George Washington based on evidence provided by Gore . 
 [MASK]ore also promoted anti @-@ French sentiment with political writings in Massachusetts newspapers . Writing under the pseudonym " Manlius " , he denounced t[MASK]e format[MASK]on of " Democratic Societies " for[MASK]ed to oppose Fede[MASK]alist policy and support pro @-@ French po[MASK]itions . He suggested to President Washington that someone be sent to England to negotiate with th[MASK] British . John Jay traveled to London in 1794 and [MASK]egotiated the Jay Treaty , whose ratification[MASK]Gore vocally supported . Although Gore was hostile to [MASK]rench policy , he was on friend[MASK]y terms with individual Frenchmen : he hosted the future French statesman Talleyrand when he visited the U.S. 
 In 1796 Washington app[MASK]inted[MASK]him as a commissioner representing the United States to handle maritime claims under the terms [MASK]he Jay Treaty . As a result the Gores moved to England th[MASK]t year , establishing a residence in the fa[MASK]hionable Hyde Par[MASK] [MASK]rea . The commission was established to arbitrate claims emanating from British seiz[MASK]res of American vess[MASK]ls[MASK]and cargoes , and from[MASK]British claims relating to violations of A[MASK]erican neutrality in the ongo[MASK]ng French R[MASK]volutionary Wars . It consisted of three Americans ( Gore , William Pinkney , and John [MASK]rumbull ) and two British commissioners ( J[MASK]hn Nicoll a[MASK]d Nicholas Astley ) ; Trumbull[MASK]was chosen by the other four because he was deemed to sufficiently " fair @-@ minded " to cast deciding votes in the event of disagreements . That year he was [MASK]lso elected a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences . 
 Although Gore was well recei[MASK]ed by the British establishment , the work suffered from what Gore called a " tediousness of pro[MASK]ess " , and he consi[MASK]er[MASK]d requesting a transfer in 1798 . In [MASK]800 it ground t[MASK] a halt be[MASK]ause another board establis[MASK]ed by the treaty to resolve outstanding Revolutionary War claim[MASK] against the United States had [MASK]ot yet met , and the Britis[MASK] stopped the claims proc[MASK]ssing until resolution of the other issues got underway . Gore used this break to briefly return to America and assess t[MASK]e [MASK]onditio[MASK] of his Waltham estate , where the house had been larg[MASK]ly destroy[MASK]d by fire in 1799 . After his return to London , with the commissio[MASK] work still stopped , he and Rebecca embarked on a tou[MASK] of Europe . They visited Holland , Belgium ,[MASK]and S[MASK]itzerland , a[MASK]d spent six months in Paris . During this trip , and later ones in England and Scotland , they took note of the architecture of country estates , an[MASK] began planning a new house[MASK]f[MASK]r their Wal[MASK]ham property . 
 The comm[MASK]ssion resumed its work in early 1802 [MASK] and [MASK]ad resolved [MASK]ll outstanding claims by August 1803 . It awarded $ 110 @,@ 000 to British clai[MASK]ants and over $ 6 million to American claimants . The lopsided result is due to the vastly larger number of American claims , but also to some key ear[MASK]y decisions that favored American interpretations in the processing of the claims , and by a British administration that sought to remain in America 's good gr[MASK]ces . 
 The Gore 's social circle in England revolved around his good friend Rufus King , who was appointed Ambassador to [MASK]reat [MASK]ritain in 1796 , along with other Massachusetts expatriates [MASK] Wh[MASK]n King left his pos[MASK] in May 1803 he named Gore to head the London embassy as chargé d 'affaires . Although President Thomas Jefferson never issued a formal appointm[MASK]nt , the British government a[MASK]cepted his role f[MASK]r the two @-@ month interval between King 's dep[MASK]rture and the arrival of James Monroe as King 's replacement . The Gores sailed for Boston in the sp[MASK]ing of 1804 . 
 Rebecca Gore used thei[MASK] exposure to European country estates[MASK]to design a lavish new building for their [MASK]altham estate during their English sojourn . Designed with t[MASK]e assistance of French architect [MASK]oseph @-@ Guillaume Legrand and probabl[MASK] [MASK][MASK]so influenced by the works of English a[MASK]chitect Sir J[MASK]hn Soane , the house that was bui[MASK]t upon their return to the United States in 1804 ( now known as Gore Place ) [MASK]s one of the finest extant examples of Federalist architecture . 
 
 = = Lawyer and state legislator = = 
 
 Soon a[MASK]ter his return to the United States , Gore reentered state politics , w[MASK]nnin[MASK] election to the Massachusetts Senate . He was ac[MASK]ive in the state Federalist Party organization , sitting on its secre[MASK] central commi[MASK]tee . He [MASK]esumed his l[MASK]w practice , in which he took on as a student Daniel Webster . One of the highest profile cases he took on was the 1807 defense of Thomas Selfridge , accused of murder[MASK]ng Charles Austin . Sel[MASK]ridge , an older Federalist attorney , had been retained to assist in the collection of a debt from Austin 's Republican f[MASK]ther . In the politically charged atmosphere of th[MASK] day in Boston , Selfri[MASK]ge , fearing for his own safety , had armed hims[MASK]lf with a dueling pistol . The younger Austin had , apparently on his own initiative , sought to be[MASK]t Selfrid[MASK]e with a cane , and Selfridge[MASK]fatally shot him in the encounter . Selfridge was prosecuted by A[MASK]torney General ( and future Gore gubernatorial opponent ) James Sullivan , and [MASK]he defense also inc[MASK]uded[MASK]a[MASK]ch @-@ Federalist Harrison Gray Otis . Gore argued Selfridge acted in self @-@ defense[MASK]; Selfridge was acquitted of murder by a jury whose foreman was Patriot an[MASK] Federalist Paul Revere after fifteen minutes ' deliberation . 
 Gore also resumed business activities upon his return . He invested in[MASK]a wide vari[MASK]ty of businesses and infrastructure , spurring economic activity in the state . His investments ranged widely , including maritime insurance ( wher[MASK] is father @-@ in @-@ law had made his fortune ) , bridges , locks , canals , and textiles . He was a major investor in the Middlesex Canal , the Craigie Bridge ( th[MASK] first to connect Boston to Cambridge ) , and the Boston Manufacturing Company , whose factory proving the single @-@ site production of textiles was in Waltham [MASK]ear his estate . Not al[MASK] of his ventures panned out : the canal was in the long run a fina[MASK]cial failure , as were efforts with other collaborators to develop Lechmere Point , the Cambridge side o[MASK] the Cr[MASK]igie Bridge . The textile mill , [MASK]owever , was a success , and Gore invested in the[MASK]Merrimack Manufacturing Company . When it decided to loca[MASK]e [MASK]n what is now Lowell , Mas[MASK]achusetts , Gore purchased shares in the Proprietors of Locks[MASK]and Canals , which o[MASK]erated ( and still owns today ) the Lowell canals . 
 In 1806 Gore won election to the [MASK]tate Senate . That year the Republicans were in th[MASK] majority , and the election for governor was close enough to require a [MASK]eco[MASK]nt . The legislature scrutinized the ballots in a[MASK]partisan manner ( for example , retai[MASK]ing ballots containing misspelled v[MASK]rs[MASK]ons of Repu[MASK]lican James Sullivan 's name and discardi[MASK]g similar ballots marked for Federalist Caleb St[MASK]ong ) . Gore and other Federalists raised a public outcry , and the legislature relented , eventually certify[MASK][MASK]g Strong as the winner . 
 Gore ran unsuccessfully for Governor of Massachusetts in 1807 and 1808 against a rising tide [MASK]f R[MASK]publicanism i[MASK] the state ,[MASK]losing both times to moderate Republican James Sullivan . The Federalists gained control of the state legislature in 1808 in a backlash against Republican economic polici[MASK]s , but Gore was criticized for his failur[MASK] to aggressivel[MASK] support stat[MASK] protests against the Embargo Act of 1807[MASK], which had a major negative effect on the state 's large merchant fleet . Gore was in 1808 elected to the Massachusetts House of Representatives , where he successfully led Federalist efforts to ensure the selection of a Fe[MASK]eralist slate of presidential electors . He also spearheaded [MASK]ctions to drive Senator John Quincy Adams from the Federalist Party over his support of Thomas Jefferson 's forei[MASK]n policy . The legislature elected Adams ' successor nine [MASK]onths early , and gave Adams suff[MASK]ciently distasteful instruct[MASK]ons[MASK]that he resigned the post and joined with the Republicans . 
 
 = = Governor = = 
 
 Gore led the Federalists to victory in 1809 against Sullivan 's successor , Levi Lincoln , Sr. , who had ta[MASK]en over as acti[MASK]g governor upon Sullivan 's de[MASK]th late in 1808 . During Gore 's term the prin[MASK]ipal domestic issue occupying state politics was a ba[MASK]kin[MASK] crisis s[MASK]imulated b[MASK] the federal policy of emb[MASK]rgoing trade with Great Brit[MASK]in and France , then embroile[MASK] in the Na[MASK]oleonic Wars . Although the cr[MASK]sis caused a number of bank failures in New England , Massachusetts banks largely escaped unscathed . 
 Foreign poli[MASK]y played a major[MASK]role in Gore 's administration . The legislature passed re[MASK]olves opposing the federal government 's hardline policy against trade and diplomatic relations with the United Kingdom ( the[MASK] embroiled in the[MASK][MASK]apoleonic Wars ) , a[MASK]d Gore in early 1810 invite[MASK] Francis Ja[MASK]es [MASK]ackson , who had been rejected as the UK 's ambassador to the US , to visit the state . This pressure may have played a role in[MASK]Pre[MASK]ident James Madison 's decision to renew relations with the UK and accept Jackso[MASK] [MASK]s crede[MASK]tials . 
 [MASK]he lessening of the war threat , and the choice by the Republicans of the[MASK]popular Elbridge Gerry as their candi[MASK][MASK]t[MASK] brought a cha[MASK]lenge to Federalis[MASK] control of Massachusetts in the 1810 elec[MASK]ions . The unostentatious Gerry and Republi[MASK]an partisans criticiz[MASK]d Gore for his [MASK]avish lifestyle , including his palatial Waltham residence and pompous activities [MASK]e organiz[MASK]d as governor , and highlighted his Loyalist family connections while emphasizing Gerry 's unimpeachab[MASK]e patriotism . Gerry won the election . Jackson did visit Boston , but he was greeted not by Gore[MASK], but Ge[MASK]ry . Gore r[MASK]n against Gerry again in[MASK]1811 , but lost in another acrimonious campaign . 
 Gore was granted an honorary law degree from Harvard in 1809 . He served on the college 's Board of Overseers from 1810 to 1815[MASK]and as a Fellow from 1816 to 1820 . Harvard 's first library building , a Gothic structure built in 1838 of Quinc[MASK] granite , was named in his honor , but was demolished when Wid[MASK]ner Librar[MASK] was built in its place in 1915 . ( This st[MASK]ucture is found on the seal of the city of [MASK]ambridge . ) One of the residential Winthrop House 's buildings is called Gore Hall in his honor .

He [MASK]erved from M[MASK]y 5 , 1813 to May 30 , 1816 , winning reelection to the seat in [MASK]814 .  G[MASK]re assented to the Treaty of Ghent that ended th[MASK] war , but was unhappy that the nation [MASK]ad not gained anything [MASK]rom the war . He [MASK]esigned in Jun[MASK] 18[MASK]6 , unhappy with the politic[MASK] of Washingt[MASK]n and sufferin[MASK] from poor health . H[MASK] died on March 1 , 1827 in Boston and is buried in its Granary Burying Ground . 
 Gore 's wife died in 18[MASK]4 ; the couple had no children .  = Nero = 
 
 Nero ( / ˈnɪəroʊ / ; Latin : Nerō Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus ; 15 December 37 AD – 9 June 68 AD ) was Roman Emperor from 54 to 68 , and the last in the Julio @-@ Claudian dynasty . Nero was adopted by his grand @-@ uncle Claudius to become his he[MASK]r and successor , and succeeded to the t[MASK]rone in 54 following Claudius ' death . 
 Nero focused much of his attention on diplomacy , trade and enhancing the cultural life [MASK]f the empire , but according to the historian Tacitus he[MASK]was viewed by the Roman p[MASK]ople as compulsiv[MASK] and corrupt . He ordered theatres built and promoted athl[MASK]tic games [MASK][MASK]During his reign , the redoubtable general Corbulo conducted a successful war a[MASK]d negotiated peace with the Parthian Empir[MASK] . His general Suetonius Paulinus crushed a revolt in Britain [MASK] Nero annexe[MASK] the Bospo[MASK]an Kingdom to the empire and began th[MASK] First Jewish – Roman War . 
 In 64 AD , most of Rome was de[MASK]troyed[MASK]in the Great Fire of Rome , which many Romans believe[MASK] Nero himself had started in order to clear land for his planned palatial complex , the Domus Aurea . In 68 , the rebellion of Vindex in Gaul and later the acclamation of Galba in Hispania drove Nero from the thron[MASK] . Facing a false report of being denounced [MASK]s a public enemy who was to be executed , he committed suicide on 9 June 68 ( the first Roman [MASK]mperor to do so ) . His death ended the Julio @-@ Claudian dynasty , sparking a brief period of civil wars known as[MASK]the Year of the Four Emperors . Nero 's rule is often associated with tyranny and extravagance . He is kn[MASK]wn f[MASK]r many executions , incl[MASK]ding that of his mother , and the [MASK][MASK]obable murd[MASK]r by poison of his step[MASK]ro[MASK]her Britannicus . 
 Nero was rumored to have had captured Christians dipped in oil and set on f[MASK]re in his garden at night as a source of light[MASK]. This view is ba[MASK]ed on the writings of Tacitus , Suetonius and Cassius Dio , the main surviving sources for Nero 's reign , but a[MASK]few surviving sources paint Nero in[MASK]a mo[MASK]e favourable light . Some sources , including some mentioned above , portray him as an emperor who was popular with the common Roman people , espe[MASK]ially in the East . Some modern historians question t[MASK]e reliability of[MASK]ancient sources when reporting on Nero 's tyrannical acts . 
 
 = = Early life = = 
 
 
 = = = Family = = = 
 
 Lucius Domitius Ahenobarbus , Nero , was born on 15 December 37 in Antium ( modern Anzio and Nettuno ) , near Rome . He was the only s[MASK]n of Gnaeus Domitius Ahenobarbus and Agrippina the Younger , sister of Emperor Caligula . 
 Nero 's father , Gnaeus , [MASK]as the[MASK][MASK]on of Lucius Domitius Ahenobarbus ( consul 16 BC ) and Antonia Major . Gnaeus w[MASK]s thus the grandson of Gnaeus Domitius Ahenobarbus ( consul 32 BC ) and probably Aemilia [MASK]epida on hi[MASK] father 's side , and the grandson of Mark Antony and Octavia Min[MASK]r on his mother 's s[MASK]de . Thus , Nero had [MASK]s his paternal grandmother Anton[MASK][MASK] Major , and also claim[MASK]d more remote descent from Antonia Minor[MASK][MASK]s a great @-@ grandson — later grandson after Claudius adopted[MASK]hi[MASK] . 
 Through Octavia , Nero was the great @-@ nephew of Caesar Augustus . Nero 's father [MASK]ad been employed as a praetor and was a membe[MASK] of Caligu[MASK]a 's staff when the latter travelled to the East ( some apparently think Suetonius refers to Augustus 's adopted son Gaius Caesar here , but this[MASK]is not likely ) . 
 Nero 's father was described by Suetonius as a murderer and a cheat who was charged by Emperor Tiberius with treason , adultery and incest . Tiberius died , allowing him to escape these[MASK]charges . Nero 's father died of edema ( " dropsy " ) in 39 when Nero was two . 
 Nero 's mother was Agrip[MASK]ina the Younger , a great @-@ granddaughter of Caesar Augustus and his wife Scribonia throu[MASK]h [MASK]heir daughter Julia the Elder and her husban[MASK] Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa . Agrippina 's father , Germanicus , was a grandson of Aug[MASK]stus 's wife , Livia , on one side and to Mark Antony and Octavia on the other . Germanicus ' mother Antonia Minor , was a daughter of Octavia Minor and Mark Antony . Octavia was Augustus ' elder s[MASK]ster . Germanicus was als[MASK] the adopted son of Tiber[MASK]us . Agrippina[MASK]poisoned her second husband Passienu[MASK] Crispus , so many anc[MASK]ent historians also accu[MASK]e her of murdering her thir[MASK] husband , the emperor Claudius . 
 
 = = = Ancestry and family = = = 
 
 
 = =[MASK]= Rise to power = = = 
 
 Nero[MASK]was no[MASK] expected to become Emperor because his maternal uncle , Caligula , had begun his reign at the age of 24 with enough time[MASK]to produce his own heir . Nero 's mother , Agrippina , lost favour with Caligula[MASK]and was exiled in 39 after her husband 's [MASK]eath . Caligula seized Nero 's inheritance and [MASK]ent him to be b[MASK]ought up by his less wealthy [MASK]unt , Domitia Lepida , who was the mother of Valeria Messalina , Claudius 's third wife . Caligula , his wife Caesonia and their infant daug[MASK]ter Jul[MASK]a Drusilla were murdered on 24 January 41 . These events led Claudius [MASK] Caligula 's uncle , to become emperor . Claudius allowed Agrippina to return from exile . 
 Cla[MASK]dius had married twice[MASK]before marrying Valeria Messalina . His previous marriages produced three children including a son , Drusus , who d[MASK]ed at a young age . He had two children[MASK]with Messalina – Claudia Octavia ( born 40 ) and Britannicus[MASK]( born 41 ) . Messalina was executed by Claudius in[MASK]the year 48 . 
 In 49 AD , Claudius married a fourth time , to Nero 's mother Agrippina , despite her being his niece [MASK] To aid Claudi[MASK]s politically , young Nero was adopted in 50 and took the n[MASK]me Nero Claudius Caesar Drusus Germanicus ( see adoption in R[MASK]me ) . Nero was older than his stepbrother[MASK]Britannicus , a[MASK]d thus became heir to the throne . 
 Nero was proclaimed an adult i[MASK] 51 at the age of 14 . He was appointed proconsul , e[MASK]tered and first addresse[MASK] the Senate , made joint public appearances with Claudius , and was featured in c[MASK]inage . In 53 , he married his stepsister Claudia Octavia .

 [MASK] Claudius died in 54 and Nero , taking the name Nero Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus , was established[MASK]as Emperor . [MASK]hough accounts vary , many ancient[MASK]historians st[MASK]te Agrippina poisoned Claudius . According to Pliny the Elder , she used poison mushrooms . It is not known how much Nero knew or if he was even involved in the death of [MASK]la[MASK]dius . 
 Suetonius wrote " ... for even if he was not the [MASK]nstigator of the emperor 's death , he[MASK]was at least privy to it , as he openly admitted ; for he used afterwards to laud mushrooms , the vehicle in whi[MASK]h the poison was admini[MASK]tered to Claudius , as " th[MASK] food of the gods , " as the Greek proverb has it . At any [MASK]ate , after Claudius ' death he [MASK]ented on him every kind of insult , in act a[MASK]d w[MASK]rd[MASK], charging him now with folly and now with cruelty ; for it was a favourite joke of his to say t[MASK]at Claudius had ceased " to play the fool " among morta[MASK]s , lengthening the firs[MASK] syllable of the word mo[MASK]ari , and he disregarded many of his decrees and acts as the work of a madman and a dotard . Finally , he neglected to enclose the place wher[MASK] his b[MASK]dy w[MASK]s burned except with a low and mean wall . " 
[MASK]Accord[MASK]ng to Suetonius ; Nero became Emperor at [MASK]h[MASK] age of 17 when the news o[MASK] Claudius ' death was made known , making him the youngest[MASK]emperor at that time Although , what Suetonius ma[MASK] have meant[MASK]is that he was in his sevent[MASK]enth year as his date of birth , also listed by Suetonius , would have made him 16 at the time of Claudius ' death . Tacitu[MASK] , in book XIII of[MASK]his Annals , describes Nero[MASK]as being ' scarcely out of his boyhood ' at the time he became emperor . Ancient historians describe Nero 's early reign as being strongly influenced by his mother , A[MASK]rippina , his tutor Lucius Annaeus Seneca , and t[MASK]e Praetorian Pr[MASK]fect Sextus Afranius Burrus , especially in the first year . Other tutors were less often mentioned , such as Alexander of Aegae . 
 Very ear[MASK]y in Nero 's rule , problems arose from competition for influence between Agrippina and Nero 's two main advisers , Seneca and Burrus . Agrippina also attempted to influence the young Nero . Agrippina also is mentioned by ancient sources as " scheming for her son ( Ne[MASK]o ) " . [MASK]his scheming continued as is evidenced by the coin of the both of them .[MASK]It is extremely unusual to see a women 's face on a coin in the ancient world [MASK] It is because [MASK][MASK] this position of power Agrippina fe[MASK]t jealous as Sen[MASK]ca in particular rose up in Nero 's court as he offered the advice Nero wanted to hear unlike his mother . 
 In 54 , Agrippina tried to sit down next to Nero while[MASK]he met with an Armenian envoy , but Se[MASK]eca stopped her and prevented a scandalous scen[MASK] ( as it wa[MASK] unimaginable at that time for a wo[MASK]an to be in the same room as men doing official business ) . Nero 's fri[MASK][MASK]ds also mistrusted Agrippina and told Nero to bewa[MASK]e of his mother . 
 Nero was reportedly unsatisfied[MASK]with his marriage to Octavia and entered into an affair with Claudia Acte , a former slave . In 55 , Agrippina attempted to intervene in favo[MASK] of Octavia and demanded[MASK]that her [MASK]on dismiss Acte . Nero , with the support of Seneca , resisted the interventi[MASK]n of his mother in his personal affairs . 
 [MASK][MASK]t[MASK] Agrippi[MASK]a[MASK]'s influence over her son severed[MASK], she reportedly [MASK]egan pushing for Britannicus , Nero 's stepbrother , to become emperor . Nearly fourteen @-@ year @-@ old Britanni[MASK]us , heir @-@ d[MASK]signate prior to Nero 's adoption , [MASK]as still legally a mi[MASK]or , bu[MASK] wa[MASK] approach[MASK]ng legal adulthood . According to Tacitus , Agrippina hoped that with her support , Britannicus , being the blood son of Claudius , would be seen as the true heir to the throne by the st[MASK]te over Nero . However , the youth died suddenly and suspic[MASK]ously on 12 Febru[MASK]ry 55 , the very day before h[MASK]s proclamation as an adult had been set . 
 Nero claimed th[MASK]t Britanni[MASK]us died from an epileptic seizure , [MASK]ut ancient historians all claim Britannicus ' death came from Nero 's poisoning him . Supposedly , he enlisted the se[MASK]vices of Locusta , [MASK] woman who [MASK]pecialized in the manufacture of poisons . She [MASK]evised a mixture to kill Britannicus , but after testing it unsuccessfull[MASK] on a slave , Nero angrily threatened to have her put to death if she did not come up with s[MASK]mething usable . Locusta then devised a new concoction that she promised would " kill swifter than a viper . " 
 Her promise was fulfilled after Britannicus consumed it at a dinner party from water used to cool his wine , which had already been tasted , and succumbed with[MASK]n minutes [MASK] After the death of Bri[MASK]annicu[MASK] , Agrippina was accused of slandering Octavia and Nero ordered her out of the imperial residence . 
 
 = = = Matricide and consolidation of power = = = 
 
 Over time , Nero became progre[MASK]sively more powerful , fre[MASK]ing himself of his advisers and eliminating rivals to the throne . In 55 , he removed Marcu[MASK] Antonius Palla[MASK][MASK], an ally of[MASK]Agrippina[MASK], from his position in the treasury . Pall[MASK]s [MASK] along[MASK]with Burrus , was accus[MASK]d of conspiring against the Emperor to bring Faustus Sulla to [MASK]he throne . Seneca was accused of having relations with Agrippina and embez[MASK]lement . Sene[MASK]a succeeded in having himself , Pallas and Burrus acquitted . According to Cassius Dio [MASK] at this time , Seneca and[MASK]Burrus reduced their role in governing from careful management to mere moderation of Nero[MASK]. 
 In 58 , Nero became romantically involved with Poppaea Sabina , th[MASK] w[MASK]fe of his friend and future emperor Otho . R[MASK]ported[MASK]y because a marriage to Poppaea and a divorce from Octavia did not seem [MASK]olitically feasible with Agrippina alive , Nero ordered the murder of his mother in 59 . A number of modern historians fin[MASK] t[MASK]is an unlikely motive as Nero did n[MASK]t marry Pop[MASK]aea until 62 . 
 Additionally , a[MASK]cording to Suetonius , Poppaea did[MASK]n[MASK]t divorce her husband until aft[MASK]r Agrippina 's death , making it unlikely that the already married Poppaea would be pressing Nero for marriage . Some modern historians theorize that Nero 's execution of Agrippina was prompted by her plotting to set Rubellius Plautus on the throne . According to Suetonius , Nero tried to kill his mother through a shipwreck plann[MASK]d by his freedman[MASK]tutor Anicetus . Instead , it took the life of Agrippina 's friend , Acerronia Polla[MASK]. When Agrippina survived , he had her executed by Anicetus[MASK]and framed it as a suicide . The incident is[MASK]also recorded by Tacitus . 
 In 62 , Nero 's adviser , Burrus , died . Additionally , Seneca was again faced with embezzlement charges . Seneca asked Nero for permission to retire fro[MASK] [MASK]ublic affairs . Nero divorced and banished Octavia on grounds of infertility , leaving him free to marry the pregnant Poppaea . After public protests , Nero was forced to allow Octavia to return from exile , but she was executed shortly after her return . 
 Nero also was repor[MASK]ed to have kicked Po[MASK]paea to dea[MASK]h in 65 before she[MASK]could have his second child . However , modern historians , noting Suetonius , Tacitus and Cassius Dio 's possible bias against Ne[MASK]o and the likelihood that they did not have eyewitness accoun[MASK]s of private events , [MASK]ostulate that Poppaea m[MASK]y have died because of complication[MASK] of miscarriage o[MASK] childbirth . 
 Accusations of treason bei[MASK]g plotted against Nero and the Senate first a[MASK]peared in 62 . The Senate ruled that Antistius , a praetor , should be put to death for speaking ill of Nero at a party . Later , Nero ordered the exile of Fabri[MASK]ius Veiento who slandered the [MASK]enate in a book . Tacitus writes that the roots of the conspiracy led[MASK]by Ga[MASK]us Calpurnius Piso began in this year . T[MASK] consolidate power ,[MASK]Nero executed a number of peopl[MASK] in 62 and 63 including [MASK]is rivals Pallas , Rubellius Plautus and Faustus Sulla . According to Suetonius , Nero " showed ne[MASK]ther discrimination nor moderation in [MASK]ut[MASK]ing to death whomsoever he pleased " during this period . 
 Nero 's consolidation of power al[MASK]o included [MASK] slow usurping of authority from[MASK]the Senate . In 54 , Nero promised to give the Senate powers equivalent to those under Republican rule . By 65 , senators complained that they had no power left and this led to the [MASK]isonian conspiracy .

 When Nero 's wife Poppaea Sabina died in 65 , Nero went into deep mour[MASK]ing[MASK]. Her body was not cremated , it was stuffed wi[MASK]h spices , embalmed and put in the Mausoleum of[MASK]Augu[MASK]tus . Sh[MASK] was given a state funeral .  In the beginning of 66 , he married Statilia Messalina . She was alr[MASK]ady married when she became Nero 's mistress in 65 AD , with [MASK]tatilia [MASK]s husband bein[MASK] driven to suicide in 66 , so Nero could marry Statilia . She was one of the few of Nero 's courtiers who survived the fall of his reign . 
 In 67 , Nero ordered a young freedman , Sporus , to be castrated and then marr[MASK]ed him . According to Dion Cassius , Sporus bore an uncanny resemblance to Sabina , and Nero even called him by his dead wife 's name . 
 
 = = = Administrative polici[MASK]s = = = 
 
 Over the c[MASK]urse of his reign , Nero often made rulings that pleased the lower class . Ner[MASK] was criticized as being obsessed with pers[MASK]nal popul[MASK]rity . 
 Nero began his reign in 54 by promising the Senate more autonomy . In[MASK]this[MASK]first[MASK]y[MASK]ar , he forbade others to refer to him with regard to enactments , for which he was praised by the Senate [MASK] Nero was kn[MASK]wn for spending his time visiting brothels a[MASK]d taverns during this period . 
 In 55 , Nero began taking on a more active role as an administrator . He was consul [MASK]our times b[MASK]tween 55 and 60 . During this period , some ancient historians speak fairly well of Nero and contrast it with his later rule .[MASK]
 Under [MASK]ero , restrictions were put[MASK]on the amount of bail and fines . Also , fees for lawyers were limited . There was a discu[MASK]sion in the Senate on the misconduct of the[MASK]freedmen class , and a stro[MASK]g demand was made that pa[MASK]rons should have the right of revoking freedom . Nero supported the freedme[MASK] and ruled that patrons had no such right . 
 The Senat[MASK] tried to pass a law in which the crimes of one slave applied to all slaves within a household . Despite [MASK]iots from the people , Ner[MASK] supported the Senate on th[MASK]ir measure , and deplo[MASK]ed troops to organise the execution of 400 slaves affected by the law . However , he vetoed strong measures against the freedmen affected by the case . 
 After tax collectors were accus[MASK]d of being to[MASK] harsh to the poor , Nero transferred[MASK]collecti[MASK]n auth[MASK]rity to lower commissioners . Nero banned any[MASK]magistrate or procurator from exhibiting public ente[MASK]tainment for fear that the venue was being used as a method to [MASK]way the populace . Add[MASK]tionally , there were many impeachments and removals of government offici[MASK]ls along with arrests for extortion and corruption . 
[MASK]Wh[MASK]n further complaint[MASK] a[MASK]ose that the poor were being overly taxed , Nero attempted to repeal all in[MASK]ire[MASK]t taxes . The Senate convin[MASK]e[MASK] him this action would bankrupt th[MASK] public treasury . As a compromis[MASK] , taxes were[MASK]cut from 4 @.@ 5 % to 2 @.@ 5 % . Additionally , secret government tax records were ordered to become public . [MASK]o lo[MASK]er the cost of food imports , merchant[MASK]ships were declared tax @-@ exempt . 
[MASK]In imitation of the Greeks , Nero built a number of gymnasiums and theatres . Enorm[MASK]us gladiatorial shows were also held . Nero also established the quinquennial Neronia . The festival included games , poetry , and t[MASK]eater . Historians indicate that there was a belief that theatre led to[MASK]immorality . Others considered that to have performers dressed[MASK]in Greek clothi[MASK]g was old fashioned . Some questione[MASK] the large public expenditure on entertainment . 
 In 64 ,[MASK]Rome burned . Nero enacted a public relief effort as well as significant reconstruction . A num[MASK]er of other majo[MASK] constructi[MASK]n projects occurred in Nero 's late reign . Nero had the[MASK]marshes of Ostia filled with rubble from the fire . He erected the large Domus Aurea [MASK] In 67 , Nero attempted to hav[MASK] a canal dug at the Is[MASK]hmus of Corinth . Ancient historians state that these projects and other[MASK] exacerbated the drain on the State 's budget . 
[MASK]The cost to rebuild R[MASK]m[MASK] was [MASK]mm[MASK]nse , requiring funds the state treasury did not have . N[MASK]ro devalued the Roma[MASK] cu[MASK]rency fo[MASK] th[MASK] first time in the Empire 's history . He reduced the weight of th[MASK] denarius from 84 per Roman pound to 96 ( 3 @.@ 85 grams to 3 @.@ 35 g[MASK]ams ) . He also re[MASK]uced the silver purity from 99 @.@ 5 % to 93 @.@ 5 % — the silver weight dropping from 3 @.@ 83 grams to 3 @.@ 4 [MASK]rams . Furthermore , Nero reduced the weight of the aureus from 40 per[MASK]Roman pound to 45 ( 8 grams to 7 @.[MASK] 2 gr[MASK]ms ) . 
 [MASK]etween 62 and 67 , according to Plinius the Elder and Seneca , Nero promoted an [MASK]xpedition to discover the sources of the Nile R[MASK]ver . It was the first explor[MASK]tion of equatorial Africa f[MASK]om Europe in history . However , [MASK]ero 's expedi[MASK]ion up the Nile fai[MASK]ed upon reachi[MASK]g the imp[MASK]netra[MASK]le Sudd of present @-@ day South Sudan . 
 The economic policy of[MASK]Ne[MASK]o is a point of debate among scho[MASK]ars . According to ancient historians , Nero 's construction projects were overly extravagant [MASK]nd th[MASK] large number [MASK]f expenditures und[MASK]r Nero left Italy " thoroughly exhausted by contributions of money " with " the provinces ruined . " Modern historians , thoug[MASK] , note tha[MASK] the period was riddled with deflation and that[MASK]it is likely that Nero [MASK]s spending came in the form of public works projects and charity intended to ease [MASK]conomic troubles . 
 
 = = = Great Fire of [MASK]ome ( 64 AD ) = = = 
 
 The Great Fire of Rome erupt[MASK][MASK] on [MASK]he night of 18 July to 19[MASK]July 64 . The [MASK]ire started at the s[MASK]utheastern en[MASK] of the Circus Maximus in shops selling flammable goods . 
 The extent of the fire is uncertain . According to T[MASK]citus , who was nine at the time of the fire , it spread quickly and b[MASK]rned for over five days . It destroyed three of fourteen Roman districts and severely damaged seven [MASK] The only othe[MASK] his[MASK]orian who lived through the perio[MASK] and mentio[MASK]ed the fi[MASK]e [MASK]s Pl[MASK]ny the Elder , who wrote about it in passing . Other historians who lived through the period ( including Josephus , Dio Chrysostom , Plutarch and Epictetus ) make no mention of it in what remains of their work . 
 It is uncertain who or what actually caused th[MASK] fire — whether accident or arson . Suetonius and Cassius Dio favor Nero as the arsonist , so he could build a palatial complex . Tacitus mentions that Christians co[MASK]fessed to the crime , but it is not known whether these confessio[MASK]s were induced by torture . However , accidental fires were common in ancient Rome . In fact , Rome suffered other large fires in 69 and in 80 . 
 It was said by Suetonius and Cass[MASK]us Dio that Nero sang the " Sack of[MASK]Ilium[MASK]" in stage costume while the city burned . Popular legend claims that Nero played the fiddle at the time of the fire , an anachro[MASK]ism[MASK]bas[MASK]d merely[MASK]on the concept of the lyre , a stringed instrument associated with Nero and his performances .[MASK]( The fiddle was not invented until the 10th century . ) Tacitus 's [MASK]ccount , however , has Nero in Antium at the time of t[MASK]e fire . Tacitus also s[MASK]id that Ne[MASK]o playing his[MASK]lyre and singing while [MASK]he city burned was only rumor . 
 According to Tacitus , upon hearing [MASK]ews of the fire , N[MASK]ro returned to Rome to organize a relief effort , wh[MASK]ch he pai[MASK] [MASK]or from his own funds . Nero 's [MASK]ontributions to th[MASK] relief extended to personally ta[MASK]ing part in the search for and rescue of victims of the blaze , s[MASK]ending days searching the debris w[MASK]tho[MASK]t even his [MASK]odyguards . After the fire , Nero opened his palaces to provide shelter for the homeless , and arranged for food supplies to be delivered in order to prevent starvation among the survivors . 
 In the wake [MASK]f the[MASK]fire , he made a new urban development plan . Houses after the fire were spaced out , built in brick[MASK], and faced by porticos on wide road[MASK] . Nero also built a new pa[MASK]ace com[MASK]le[MASK] known as the Domus Aur[MASK]a in an area cleared by the fire . This inc[MASK]uded lush artificial l[MASK]ndscapes and a 30 @-@ mete[MASK] @-@ tall statue of himself , the[MASK]Colossus of [MASK]ero . The size of this complex is debated ( from 100 to 300 acres ) . [MASK]o find the necessary funds for the reconstruction , tributes were imposed on the provinces of the empir[MASK] . 
 Tacitus , in[MASK]one of the earliest non @-@ Chris[MASK]ian references to the origins of Christianity , notes that the population searched for a scapegoat and rumors held Nero responsible . To de[MASK]lect blame , Nero target[MASK]d Christians . He ordered Chris[MASK]ians to [MASK]e thrown to dogs , while [MASK]thers were crucified and burned . 
 
 = = = Public performances = =[MASK]= 
 
 Nero enjoyed driving [MASK] one @-@ horse chariot , singing to the lyre and poetry . H[MASK] even composed songs that were performed by other entertainers throughout the empire . At first , Nero only performed for a private audience . 
 In 64 A[MASK] . , Nero began singing in public in Neapolis in order to improve his popularity . He[MASK]also sang at the second quinquenni[MASK]l Neronia in 65 . It was said that Nero craved the attention , but historia[MASK]s also write that Nero was enc[MASK]u[MASK]aged to sing and perform in public by the Senate , his inner circle and th[MASK] people . Ancient historians strongly [MASK]riticize his choice to perform , calling it s[MASK]ameful . 
 Nero was persuaded to participate in the Olympic G[MASK]mes of 67 in order to im[MASK]ro[MASK]e relations with Gr[MASK]ece and display Roman dominance . As a competitor , Nero raced a ten @-@ horse chariot and nearly died after being thrown[MASK]from it . He [MASK]lso performed as an actor and a singer . Th[MASK]ugh Nero f[MASK]ltered in his racing ( in one case , dropping out ent[MASK]rely before the end ) and acting competitions , he won these crowns nevertheless and paraded them whe[MASK] he returned to Rome . The victorie[MASK] are attributed to Nero bribing the judges and his status as emperor . 
 
 = = = War and peace wi[MASK]h[MASK]Parthia = = =[MASK]
 [MASK] Shortly after Nero 's accession to the throne in 54 , [MASK]he Roman vassal kingdom of Armenia overthrew their Iberian pr[MASK]nce Rhadamistus[MASK]and h[MASK] was replaced with the Parthia[MASK] pri[MASK]ce T[MASK]ridates . This was seen as a Parthian invasion of Roman territory . There was concern [MASK]n Rome over how the young Emperor would handle the situation . Nero reacted by[MASK]immediatel[MASK] sending the m[MASK]litary to the region under the command of Gnaeus[MASK]Domitius Corbulo . The Parthians[MASK]temporarily relinquished control[MASK]of Armenia to Rome . 
[MASK]The peace did[MASK]not last and[MASK]full @-@ scale war broke out in 58 . The Parthian king Vologases I refused to remo[MASK]e[MASK]his brother Tiridates from[MASK]Armenia . The Parthians beg[MASK]n a [MASK]ull @-@ scale invasion of the Armenian kingd[MASK]m . Commander Corbulo responded and repelled most of t[MASK]e Parthian army that same year . Tiridates retreated and Rome again controlled most of Armenia . 
 Nero was acclaimed in public for this ini[MASK]ial vic[MASK]ory . Tigranes , a Cappadocian noble raised in Rome , was installed by Nero as the new ruler of Armeni[MASK] . Corbulo was appointed governor of Syria [MASK]s a re[MASK]ard . 
 In 62 , Tigranes invaded the Parthian prov[MASK]nce of Adiabene . Ag[MASK]in , Rome and Parthia wer[MASK] at war and this continued until 63 . Parthia began building up for a strike against the Roman province of Syria . Corb[MASK]lo tried to convince Nero [MASK]o continue the war , but Ner[MASK] opted for a peace deal instead . There was anxiety in Rome about eas[MASK]ern grain supplies and a budget deficit . 
 The result was a deal where Tiridates again became the[MASK]Armenian king , b[MASK]t wa[MASK] crowned in [MASK]ome by Emperor Nero . In the future , the king o[MASK] Armenia wa[MASK] to be a[MASK]Parthian prince , but his appointment required approval from the Romans . Tiridates was forced to come t[MASK] Rome and partake in ceremonies meant to display Roman dominance . 
 This peace deal of 63 was a considerable v[MASK]ctory for[MASK]Nero politica[MASK]ly . Nero beca[MASK]e very popular[MASK]in the eastern provinces of Rome and with the Parthians as well . The[MASK]peace between Parthia and Rome[MASK]lasted 50 years until Empero[MASK] Trajan o[MASK] Rome invaded Armenia in 114[MASK]. 
 
 = = = Other major p[MASK]wer struggles and rebellions = = = 
 
 The war with Parthia [MASK]as not Nero 's only major war but he was both criticized [MASK]nd praised for an aversion to battle . Like many emperors [MASK] Nero fac[MASK]d a number of rebellions and power [MASK]truggles within the empire . 
 British Revolt of 60 – 61 ( Boudi[MASK]a 's Uprising [MASK] 
 In 60 , a major rebellion [MASK]ro[MASK]e out in t[MASK]e province of Britannia[MASK]. While the governor Gaius Suetonius Paulinus and his troops were bu[MASK]y capturing the island of Mona ( Anglesey ) from the druids , the tribes of the southe[MASK]st staged a revolt led by queen Boudica of the Iceni . Boudica an[MASK] her troops destroyed three cities b[MASK]fore the army of Paulinus could return , receive r[MASK]inforcements , and quell the rebellion in[MASK]61 . Fearing [MASK]aulinus himself would provoke further rebellion , Nero replaced him with the more passive Publius Petronius Turpilianus . 
 The Pisonian Conspiracy of 65 
 In 65 , Gaius Calpurniu[MASK] Piso , a Roman statesman , organized a conspiracy against [MASK][MASK]ro with the help of Subrius Flavus a[MASK]d Sulpicius Asper , a tri[MASK]une and a centurion of the Praetorian Guard . According to Tacitus , m[MASK]ny co[MASK]spirators wished to " rescue[MASK]the state " from th[MASK] emperor and restore the R[MASK]public . [MASK]he freedma[MASK] M[MASK]lichus discovered the co[MASK]spiracy and reported it to Nero 's secretary , Epaphroditos . As a result , the conspiracy fail[MASK]d and its [MASK]embers were executed i[MASK]cluding Lucan[MASK], th[MASK] poet .  The First Jewish War[MASK]of 66 – 70 
 In 66 , there was a Jewish[MASK]revolt in Jude[MASK] stemming from Greek and Jewish religious tens[MASK]on . In 67 , Nero dispatched Vespasian to resto[MASK]e order . This [MASK]evolt was eventually put down in 70 , after Nero 's death .  = = = The revolt of Vindex and Galba and the death of Ner[MASK] = = = 
 
 In March 68 , Gaiu[MASK] Julius[MASK]Vindex , the governor of Gallia Lugdunensis , rebelled against Nero 's tax policies . Lucius Verginius Rufus , the governor of Germania Superi[MASK]r , wa[MASK] orde[MASK]ed t[MASK] put down Vindex 's rebellio[MASK] . In an attempt to gain support from outside his own province , Vindex called [MASK]pon Servius Sulpi[MASK]ius Galba , the governor of Hispania Tarraconensis , to join the rebellion and further , to declare himself emperor in opposition to Nero .[MASK]
 At the Battle of Vesontio in May 68 , Verginius ' forces easily defeated those of Vindex and the latter committed suicide . However , after putting down this one rebel , Verginius ' legions attempted to proclaim their ow[MASK] commander as Emperor . V[MASK]rginius refused to act against Nero , but the disconten[MASK] of the legions of Germany and the continued opposi[MASK]ion o[MASK] Galba in Spain did not bode well for him . 
 [MASK]hile Nero had retained some control of the situation , support for Galba increased despite his being officially declared a public enemy . The pre[MASK]ect o[MASK] the Praetorian Guard , Gaius Nymphidius Sabinus , also abandoned his allegiance to the Emperor and came out in support for Galba . 
 In response , Nero fled Rome with the int[MASK]ntion of going to the port of Ostia and , from there , to take a fleet to one of the still @-@ loyal eastern provinces . According[MASK]to Suetonius , Nero abandoned the i[MASK]ea when some army officers openly [MASK]e[MASK]used to obey his co[MASK]mands , responding with a line from Vergil 's Aeneid : " Is it so dreadful a thing then to die ? " Nero then toyed with the idea of fleeing to Parthia , thr[MASK]wing himself upon the mer[MASK]y of Galba , or to appeal to the people and beg them to pardon him for his past offences " and if he could not soften their hearts , to entreat them at least to allow hi[MASK] the prefecture of Egypt " . Suetonius reports that the te[MASK]t of this speech was later fo[MASK]nd in Nero 's writing desk , but that he dared not give it from fear of being torn t[MASK] pieces before he could reach the Forum . 
 Nero returned to Rome and spent the evening in the palace . After sleeping , he a[MASK]oke at about midnight to find the palace guard had left . Dispatching messages to his friends ' palace chambers for them to[MASK]come , he received no answers . Upon going to their chambers pe[MASK]sonally , he found them all abandon[MASK]d . When he ca[MASK]led for a gladiator or anyone else adept with a sword to kill him , no one appeared . He cried , " Have I neither friend n[MASK]r foe ? " and ran out as if to thr[MASK]w himself into the Tiber . 
 [MASK]eturning , Nero [MASK]ought for some plac[MASK] where he could hide and collect his thoughts . An imperial freedman , Phaon , offered his[MASK]villa , located 4 miles outside the city . Travelling in disguise , Nero and four loyal freedmen , Epaphroditos , Phaon , Neophytus ,[MASK]and Sporus , reached the villa , where Nero ordered them to di[MASK] a grave[MASK]for [MASK]im . 
 At this time , a courier arrived with a report tha[MASK] the S[MASK]nate had declared Nero a public enemy and that it was t[MASK]eir intention to execute [MASK]im by beating him to death and that armed men had been sent to apprehend him for the act to take place [MASK]n the Forum .[MASK]The Senate actually was still reluctant and deliberating on the right course [MASK]f action as Nero was the last [MASK]ember of the Julio @-@ Claudian Family[MASK]. Indeed , most of the senators had serve[MASK] the imperial family all their lives and felt a sense of loyalty to the deified bloodline , if not to Nero himself . The men actually had the goal of returning [MASK]ero back to the Senate , where the Senate hoped [MASK]o work out a compromise with th[MASK] rebel[MASK]ing gove[MASK]nors that would preserv[MASK] Nero 's life , so that at least a fut[MASK]re heir to the dynasty could be produced . 
 Nero , however , did not know t[MASK]is , and [MASK]t the news[MASK]brought by th[MASK] courier , he [MASK]repared himself for [MASK]uicide , pacing up and down muttering " Qu[MASK]lis art[MASK]fex pereo " which translates to English as " What an artist dies in m[MASK] . " Losing his nerve , he first begged for one of his companions to set an example by first killing himself[MASK]. At last , th[MASK] sound of approachi[MASK]g[MASK]horsemen drove Nero to face the end . However , he still could[MASK]not bring himself to take his own life but instead he forced his private secretary , Epaphroditos , to perform the task . 
[MASK]When one of the horsemen entered , upon [MASK]is[MASK]seeing Nero all but dead he attempted to stop the bleeding in vain . Nero 's final words were " Too late ! This is fidelity ! [MASK] H[MASK][MASK]died on 9 June 68 , the anniversary of the[MASK]death of Octavia , and was buried in the Mausoleum of the Domitii Ahenobarb[MASK] , in what is now the Vill[MASK] Borghese ( Pincian Hill ) area of Rome . 
 With his death , the Julio @-@ Claudian dynasty ende[MASK] . The S[MASK]nate , [MASK]hen news of his death reached Rome , posthumou[MASK][MASK]y declared Nero a public enemy to appease[MASK]the c[MASK]ming Galba ( as[MASK]the Sen[MASK]te had initially [MASK]eclared Galba as a pub[MASK]ic enemy ) and proclaimed Galba the new emperor . Chaos would ensue in the year of[MASK]the Four Emperors . 
 
 = = = Post mortem = = = 
 
 According to Suetonius and Cassius Dio , the people of Rome [MASK]elebrated the death of Nero . Tacitus , though , describes a more compli[MASK]ated political environment . [MASK]acitus mentions that Nero 's death was wel[MASK]omed by Senators , nobility and the u[MASK]per class . The lower @-@ class , slaves , frequente[MASK]s of the arena [MASK]nd the theater , and " those who were suppo[MASK]ted by the famous excesses of Nero " , [MASK]n the other hand , were upset [MASK]ith the news . Members of the military were said to have mixed feelings , as they had allegiance to Nero , but were bribed[MASK]to overthrow him . 
 Eastern sources , namely Philostrat[MASK]s II and Apol[MASK]onius of Tyana[MASK], mention that Nero 's [MASK]eath was mourned as he " restored the liberties of Hellas with a wisdom and moderation quite alien to h[MASK][MASK] character " and that he " held our liberties in his hand and respected them . " 
 Modern scholarship generally holds that , while the Senate and more well @-@ off indiv[MASK]duals welco[MASK]ed Nero 's death , the general populace was " loyal to the end a[MASK]d beyond , for Otho and Vitellius both thought it worthwhile to appeal to t[MASK][MASK]i[MASK] nostalgi[MASK] . " 
 Nero 's name was erased from some monument[MASK] , in what Edward Champlin regards as an " outburst of private zeal " . Many portraits of Ne[MASK]o were reworked to represent other[MASK]figures ; according to Eric R. Varner , over fifty such images survive[MASK]. This reworking of images is often explai[MASK]ed as part of the way in which t[MASK]e memory of disgraced emperors was condemned posthumously ( see damnatio memoriae ) [MASK] Champlin , however , doubts that the practice is neces[MASK]arily nega[MASK]ive and notes that some continued to create images of Nero long aft[MASK]r his death . 
 The civil war during the year of the Four Emp[MASK]rors [MASK]as described by ancient historia[MASK]s[MASK]as a troubling period . A[MASK]cording to Tacitus , this i[MASK]stability was rooted in the fact that emperors could no longer rely[MASK]on the[MASK]p[MASK]rceived legitimacy of the imperial bloodline , as Nero and those before hi[MASK] could . Gal[MASK]a began his short reign with the e[MASK]ecuti[MASK]n of many al[MASK][MASK]es of Nero and possible future enemies . One such notable enemy included Nymphidi[MASK]s Sabinus , who [MASK]laimed to be the son of[MASK]Emperor Caligula . 
 Otho overthrew Galba . Otho was said to be liked by many soldiers because he had been a friend of Nero 's and resembled him somewhat in temperament[MASK]. It[MASK]was said that the common Roman hailed Otho as Nero himself . Otho used " Nero " as a surname and reerected [MASK]an[MASK] statues to Nero . Vitellius overthrew Otho . Vitellius began his reign with a large[MASK]funeral for Nero complet[MASK] with songs written by Nero . 
 After[MASK]Nero 's suicide [MASK]n 68 , there was a widesp[MASK]ead belief , especially in the eastern provinces , tha[MASK] he was not dead and somehow would return . Th[MASK]s belief came to be known as the Nero Redivivus Legend . 
 The legend of Nero 's return lasted for hundreds of years after Nero 's death . Augustine of Hippo wrote of t[MASK]e legend as a popular belief in 422 . 
 At least thre[MASK] Nero imposters emerged leading rebellions . The fi[MASK]st , wh[MASK] sang and played [MASK]he cithara or lyre and whose [MASK]ace was similar to that of the dead emperor , appeared in 69 during the reign of V[MASK]tellius . After persuading some to recognize him , he was captured and executed . Sometim[MASK] during the reign of Titus ( 79 – 81 ) , another impostor appeared in Asia and[MASK]sang to the accompaniment[MASK]of the lyre and looked[MASK]like Nero but he , too , was kill[MASK]d . Twenty years after Nero 's death , during the re[MASK]gn of Domitian , there was a third pretender . He was supported by the [MASK]arthians , who only reluctantly gave him up , and the matter almost came to war .

 = = Physical appeara[MASK]ce = = 
 
 In his book The Lives of the Twelve Caesars [MASK] S[MASK]etonius descri[MASK]es Nero as " a[MASK][MASK]ut the average height , his body marked with spots and malodorous , his hair light blonde , his features regular rat[MASK]er [MASK]han attractive , his eyes blue and somewhat weak , his neck over thick , his belly prominent , and his legs very slender . " 
 
 = = Historiography = = 
 
 The history of Nero 's reign is problematic in that no historical sources survived that were contemporary with N[MASK]ro . These first hist[MASK]ries at one ti[MASK]e did exist and were described as b[MASK]ased and fantast[MASK]cal , either overly critical or pra[MASK]sing of Nero . The original sources were also said to cont[MASK]adict on a nu[MASK]ber of events . Nonetheless , these lost primary sources were the basis of surviving s[MASK]condary and te[MASK]tiary histories on Nero written by the next generations of historians . A few of the contemporary historians are known by name [MASK] Fabius Rusticus ,[MASK]Cluvius Rufus and Pliny the Elder all wrote condemning histories on Nero that a[MASK]e now lost . There wer[MASK] also pro @-@ Nero histories , but it is unknown who wrote them or for what deeds Nero was praised . 
 The bulk of[MASK]what is known of Nero comes from Tacitus , Suetonius and Cassius Dio , who were all of the sen[MASK][MASK]orial class . Tacitus and Suetonius wrote their histories on Nero over fifty years after his death , while Cassius Dio wrote his history over 15[MASK] years after Nero 's death . These sources contradict on a number of even[MASK]s in Nero 's life including the death of C[MASK]audius , the [MASK]eath of A[MASK]rippina , and the Roman fire o[MASK] 64 , [MASK]ut they a[MASK]e consistent in their condemnation of Nero . 
 A handful of other sources also add a limited and varying perspec[MASK]ive on Nero . Few[MASK]surviving sources paint Nero in a favourabl[MASK] light . Some sources , though , portray him as a competent emperor who was popular with the Roman people , especially in the e[MASK]st . 
 Cas[MASK]ius Dio 
 C[MASK]ssius Dio ( c . 155 – 229 ) was the son of Cassius Apronianus , a Roman senator . He passed the greater part of his life in public[MASK]service . He was a senator under Commodus and governor of Smyrna after the death of Septimius Severus ; and afterwards suffect consul around 205 , and a[MASK]so proconsul in Africa and Pannonia . 
 Books 61 – 63 of Dio 's Roman H[MASK]story describe the reign of[MASK]Nero . Only fra[MASK]ments of these books remain a[MASK]d what does remain was abridged and altered by John Xiphilinus , an 11th @-@ century monk . 
 Dio Chrysostom 
 Dio Chryso[MASK]tom ( c . 40 – 120 ) , a Greek phi[MASK]osopher and historian , wrote the Roman pe[MASK]ple were very happy with [MASK]ero and would have allowed him to rule indefinitely . They longed f[MASK]r h[MASK]s[MASK]rule on[MASK]e he was gone and em[MASK]raced imposters when they appeared : 
 Indeed the truth a[MASK]out this has not come out even y[MASK]t ; for so far as the rest[MASK]of his sub[MASK]ects were concerned , there was nothing to prevent his co[MASK]tinuing to [MASK]e Emperor for all time , seeing that eve[MASK] now everybody wish[MASK]s he were still alive . And the great majority do believe that he still is , although in a certain sense he has died not once but often along w[MASK]th those who had been firmly convinced that he was still ali[MASK]e . 
 Epictetus 
 Epi[MASK]tetus ( c . 55 – 135 ) was the slave to Nero 's scribe Epap[MASK]roditos . H[MASK] makes a few passing nega[MASK]ive comments o[MASK] Nero 's character in his work , but makes no remarks on the nature of [MASK]is rule . He describes Nero as a spoiled , angry and unhappy man . 
 Jos[MASK]phus 
 The historian Josephus ( [MASK] . 37 – 100 ) , while calling Nero a tyrant , was also the first to mention bias against Nero . Of other historians , he said : 
 But I omit any further discourse about these affairs ; for ther[MASK] have been a great many who have composed the history of Nero ; some of which have departed from the truth of facts out of favour , as hav[MASK]ng received benefits from him ; while others , out of hatred to him , and the great ill @-@ will which they bore him , have so impu[MASK]ently raved against him with their lies , that they justly deserve to be co[MASK]demne[MASK] . Nor do I wond[MASK]r at such as have told lies of Nero , since they have not in their writings preserved the truth of history as to those facts that were earlier th[MASK]n his time , even when the actors could have no way incurred their hatred , since those writers lived a long time after them . 
 Lucan 
 Though more of a poet than historia[MASK] , Lucanus ( c . 39 –[MASK]65 ) has one of the kindest accounts of Nero 's rule . He writes of peace and prosperity under Nero in contrast to previous war and strife . Ironically , he was later involved in a consp[MASK]racy to overthrow N[MASK]ro and was executed . 
 Philostratus 
 Philostratus II " the Athenian " ( c . 172 – 250 ) spoke of Nero in the Life of Apollonius Tyana ( Books 4 – 5 ) . Though he has a generally bad or dim view of Nero , he speaks of others ' positive reception of Nero in the East . 
 Pliny the Elder 
 The histor[MASK] of Nero by Pliny the Elder ( c . 24 – 79 ) did not survive . Still , there are severa[MASK] references to Nero in Pliny 's Natural Histo[MASK]ies . Pliny [MASK]as one of the [MASK]orst opinio[MASK]s of Nero and calls him[MASK]an " enemy of mankin[MASK] . " 
 Plutarch 
 Plutarch ( c . 46 – 127 ) mentions Nero indirectly[MASK]in his account of the Life of Galba and the Life of [MASK]tho . Nero is portrayed as a tyrant , but those that re[MASK]lace him are not described as better . 
 Seneca the Younger 
 It[MASK]is[MASK]not surprising that Seneca ( c . 4 BC – 65[MASK]) , Nero 's teacher and advisor , writes very [MASK]ell of Nero . 
 Suetonius 
 Suetonius ( c . 69 – 130 ) was a member of the equestrian order , and he was the head of the department of the imperial correspondence . While in [MASK]his position , Suetonius started writing [MASK]iogr[MASK]phies of the emperors , accentuating the anecdotal and sensational aspects . 
 Tacitus 
 Th[MASK] Annals by Tacitus ( c . 56 – 117 ) is the[MASK]most detailed and comprehensive [MASK]istory on the rule of Nero , despite being incomplete after the year 66 . Tacitus descri[MASK]ed the rule of[MASK]the Julio[MASK]@-@ Claudian emperors as generally unjust . He also thought th[MASK]t existing writing on them was unbalanced : 
 The [MASK]istories of Tiberius , Caius , Claudius and Nero , while they were[MASK]in power [MASK] were fa[MASK]sified [MASK]hrough terror , and after their death we[MASK]e written under the irritation of a recent hatred . 
 Tacitus [MASK]as the son of a procurator , who married into the elite family of Agricola . He entered his political life as a senator after Nero 's death and , by Tacitus ' own adm[MASK]ss[MASK]on , owed much to Nero 's rivals . Realising that this bias may be apparent to others , Tacitus protests that his writi[MASK]g [MASK]s true . 
 Girolamo Cardano 
 In 1562 Girolamo Cardano publish[MASK]d in Basel his Encomium Neronis , [MASK]hich was one of the firs[MASK] historical references of th[MASK] Modern era to p[MASK][MASK]tray Nero in a positiv[MASK] light .
