 The [MASK]unt Report on the future of policing in Northern Ire[MASK]and was presented to the Storm[MASK]nt cabinet in early October .[MASK]Jim Callaghan held talks with the cabinet in Belfast on 10 October , following which the report 's [MASK]ecommendations were accepted and made publ[MASK]c . They included the recommendation that the RUC should be ' ordinarily ' unarmed , and that the[MASK]B @-@ Specials should be phased out and replaced by a new force . The new RUC Chief Constabl[MASK] , Arthur Y[MASK]ung , an Englishman , was announced , and travelled to Belfast with Callag[MASK]an . The same day , Seán Keenan announced that the DCDA was to be [MASK]issolved . On [MASK]1 October Callaghan and Y[MASK]ung visited Free Derry , and on 12 October the first military police entered the Bogside , on foot and unarmed [MASK] 
 
 = = IRA resurgence = = 
 
 The Irish Republican Army ( IRA[MASK]) had been i[MASK]active militarily since [MASK]he end [MASK]f the Border Cam[MASK]aign in 1962 . It was low in both personnel and equipment — Chief of Staff Cathal Goulding told Seán Keenan and Paddy Doherty in August 1969 that he " couldn 't defend the Bogsid[MASK] . I haven 't the me[MASK] nor the guns to do it . " Duri[MASK]g the 1960s the leadership of the republican movement had moved to the left . Its focus was on cla[MASK]s struggle and its aim was [MASK]o unite the Irish nationalist and unionist working classes in order to overthrow capitalism , both British and Irish . Republican Clubs were formed in Northern Ireland , where Si[MASK]n [MASK]éin was proscribed . These clubs were involved in the formation of NICRA in 1967 . In Derry , the James Connolly Repu[MASK]lican Club worke[MASK] closely with Labou[MASK] Party radi[MASK]als , with whom they set up the Derry Housing Action Committee and Derry Unemploye[MASK] Action Committee . T[MASK]e Derry Citizens ' Defence Association was formed initially by republicans , who then inv[MASK]ted other nationalis[MASK]s to join . Although there were tensions between the younger leaders like Johnnie White and the older , traditional republicans such as Seán Keenan , both sides saw the unrest of 1968 @-@ 69 as a chance to advance[MASK]republican aims , and the two shared the platform at the Easter Rising commemoration in April [MASK]969 . 
 The events of August 1969 in Derry ,[MASK]and more particularly[MASK][MASK]n Belfast where the IRA was unable to prevent loss of li[MASK]e or protect families bu[MASK]ned out of their homes , brought to a head the[MASK]divisions that had already appeared within the moveme[MASK][MASK] between the radicals and the traditionalists , and [MASK]ed to a split in December 1969 into the Official I[MASK]A and[MASK]the Provisional IRA . Initially , both armies organised for de[MASK]ensive purposes only , although the Provisionals were planning towards an offensive campaign . In Derry there was far less hostility between t[MASK]e two organisations than elsewhere and householders commonly paid subscriptions to both . When rioters were arrested after the Official 's Ea[MASK]ter parade in Ma[MASK]ch 1970 , Offic[MASK]als and [MASK]rovisionals pic[MASK]eted their trial together . At the start the Officials attracted most of the younger members . Martin McGuinness , who in Augu[MASK]t 1969 had helped defend the barricades , initially joined the Officials , but a few months later left to join the Provisionals . 
 Relat[MASK]ons between the British Ar[MASK]y and the residents had steadily decayed since the first appearance of troops in August 1969 . I[MASK] September , after clashes between nati[MASK]nalist and unionist crowds that led to the death of a Protestant man , William King , the British Army erected a ' peace r[MASK]ng ' to enclose the nationalist populatio[MASK] in the area they had previously c[MASK]ntrolled . Roads into the city centre were closed at night and people were prevented from[MASK]walking on certain street[MASK] . Alth[MASK]ugh some[MASK]moderate nationalists acce[MASK]ted this as necessary , there was[MASK]anger among young people . Clashes between youths and troops became more frequent . The riot following the Officials ' Eas[MASK]er parade in March 197[MASK] marked the first time that the [MASK]rmy used ' snatch squads ' , who rushed into the Bo[MASK]side wielding batons to make arrests . The snatch squads soon became a common feature of army arrest operations . There was also a belief that they were arresting people at random , sometimes days after the alleged offence , [MASK]nd based on the identification of people that they had seen f[MASK]om a consid[MASK]rable distanc[MASK] . The rioters were [MASK]ondemned as hooligans by modera[MASK]es , who saw the riots as hampering attempts to resolve the situation . Th[MASK] Labour radicals and Official republicans , sti[MASK]l working together , tried to tu[MASK][MASK] the y[MASK]uth awa[MASK] from rioting and create socialist organizations[MASK]— one such organization was named the Young Hooligans Association — but to no avail . The Provisiona[MASK]s ,[MASK]while disapproving of riots , viewed them as the inevitable cons[MASK]quence of British occupation [MASK] This philosophy was more attractive to rioters , and some of them joined the Provisional IRA . The deaths of two leading Provisionals in a premature explosion [MASK]n June 1970 resulted in young militants becoming more prominent in the organizat[MASK]on . Nevertheless , up to July 1971[MASK]the Provisional IRA remained numerically sm[MASK]ll . 
 Two men , Séamas Cusack and Desmond Beattie , were shot dead in separate incidents in the early mor[MASK]ing and afternoon of 8 July 1971 [MASK] They w[MASK]re the fi[MASK]st people to be killed by the British Army in Derry . In both cases the British Army cla[MASK]med that the men were attackin[MASK] them with guns or bombs , while eyewitnesses insisted th[MASK]t both were unarmed . The Social Democratic and Labour Party ( SDLP ) , the[MASK]newly formed party of which John Hume and Ivan Cooper were leading members , withdrew from Stormont in protest , but among residents there was a[MASK]perception that moderate policie[MASK] had failed . The res[MASK]lt was a surge of support for the IRA . The Provi[MASK]ionals held a meeting the following Sunday at which they c[MASK]lled on people to " join the IRA " . Following the meeting , people queued up to join , and[MASK]there was large @-@ scale rioting . The British Army post at Bligh 's Lane came under sustained attack , and troops there and around the city came under fire from the IRA . 
 
 = = Internment and the third Free Der[MASK]y = = 
 
 [MASK]he increasing violence in Derry and elsewhere led to increasing s[MASK]eculation that in[MASK]ernment without trial would be introduced in Northern Ireland , and [MASK]n 9 August 1971 hundreds of republicans and nationalists were arrested in dawn raids . In D[MASK]rry , residents came out onto the streets to resist the arre[MASK]ts , [MASK]nd fewer people were taken there than elsewh[MASK]re ; nevertheless leading figures including Seán Keenan and John[MASK]ie White were interned . In response , barricades were erecte[MASK] once again and the third Free Derry came into existence . Unlike its predecessors , this Free Derry was marked by a s[MASK]ro[MASK]g IRA presence , both Official and Provis[MASK]onal . It was defended [MASK]y armed paramilitaries — a no @-@ go area , one in which British [MASK]ecurity forces were unable to operate . 
 G[MASK]n attacks on the British Army increased . Six soldiers were wounded in the first day after [MASK]nternment , and shortly afterwards a soldier was killed — the first [MASK]o be killed by either IRA in Derry . The army moved in in force on 18 August to dismantle the barricades . [MASK] gun battle ensued in which a young Provisional IRA officer , Eamonn Laf[MASK]er[MASK]y ,[MASK]was killed . A crowd staging a sit @-@ d[MASK]wn protest was hosed down and the protesters , including John Hume[MASK]and Ivan Cooper , arrested . With barricades re @-@ appearing as quickly as they were removed , the army eventually abandoned their attempt . 
 The Derry Provi[MASK]ionals had littl[MASK] contact with the IRA elsewhere . They had few weapons ( about twenty ) which they u[MASK][MASK]d mainly for sni[MASK]ing . At the same time , they launched their b[MASK]mbing campaign in Derry . Unlike in Belfast , the[MASK] [MASK]er[MASK] careful to avoid k[MASK]lling or injuring innocent people . Eamonn McCann wr[MASK]te [MASK]hat " the Derry Provos , under Marti[MASK] McGuinness , had managed to bomb the city centre until it looked as if it had been hit from the air without causing any civilian casualtie[MASK] . " 
 Although both IRAs op[MASK]rated openly , neither was [MASK]n control of Free Derry . The barricades were manned by unarmed ' au[MASK]iliaries ' .[MASK]Crime[MASK]was dealt with by a [MASK]o[MASK]unteer force called the Free Derry Police , which was headed by Tony O 'Doher[MASK]y , a Derry [MASK]ootballer and Northern Ireland I[MASK]ternational . 
 
 = = Bloody Sunday = = 
 
 An anti @-@ internment protest organised by the Northern Ireland Civil Rights Association ( NICRA ) at Magilligan Camp in January 1972 was met with [MASK]iolence from the 1st Battalion , The Parachute Regiment ( 1 Pa[MASK]a ) . NICRA ha[MASK] organ[MASK]sed [MASK] march fro[MASK] the Creggan to Derry city centre , in defiance of a ba[MASK] , on the following Sun[MASK]ay , 30 January [MASK]972 .[MASK]Both IRAs were asked , and agreed , to suspend operations on that da[MASK] to ensure the march passed o[MASK]f peacefully . The British Army erected barricades around the Free Derry area to prevent marchers f[MASK]om reaching the city centre . On the day , march organisers turned the march away [MASK]rom the barriers and[MASK]up to Free Derry Corner , but [MASK]ome youths pr[MASK]ceeded to the barrier at William Street[MASK]an[MASK] sto[MASK]ed soldiers . Troops from 1 Para then moved i[MASK]to Free Derry and opened fire , killing thirteen people , all [MASK]f whom were sub[MASK]equently found to be un[MASK]rmed . A fourteenth shooting victim died four months later in J[MASK]ne 1972 . Like the killing of Cusack and Beattie the previous year , Bloody Sunday had the effect o[MASK] hu[MASK]ely increasing recruitment to the IRA , even among people who previously would have been ' moderates ' . 
 
 = = February - July 1972 = = 
 
 Both the Provisional and Official IRA stepped up attacks after Bloo[MASK]y Sunday , with the tacit support of the residents . Local f[MASK]elings[MASK]changed , however , with the killing of Ranger William Best by th[MASK] Official IRA . Best was a 19 @-@ yea[MASK] @-@ old local man who was home on l[MASK]ave from the British Army at his parents ' house in the Creggan . He was [MASK]bducted , interrogated and [MASK]hot . The fol[MASK]owing day 500 women marched to the Republican Club offices in protes[MASK] . Nine days later , on 29 May , the Official IRA declared[MASK]a ceasefire . The Provisional IRA initially stated that they would not follow suit , but after informal approaches to the British G[MASK]vernment they announced a ceasefire from 26 June . [MASK]artin McGuinness was the Derry representative in a party of [MASK]enior Pro[MASK]isionals who travelled to London for talks with William Whitelaw , the[MASK]Secretary of[MASK]State for Northern Ireland . The talks were not r[MASK]sumed after the ending of the truce following a violent confrontation in Belfast when troops p[MASK]evented Catholic families from taking over houses in [MASK]he Lenadoon estate . 
 Political pressure for the action against the " no @-@ go "[MASK]areas increased after the events of Bloody Friday in Belfast . A British Army attack was considered inevitable , and the IRA took the decision[MASK]no[MASK] to resist it . On 31 July 1972 , Operation Motorman was launched when t[MASK]ousands of British troops , equi[MASK]ped wi[MASK]h armoured cars and armoured bulldozers ( AVREs ) , dismantled the barricad[MASK]s and occupi[MASK]d the area . 
 
 = = Subsequent history = = 
 
 After Opera[MASK]ion Motorman , the British Army controlled the Bo[MASK]side and Cregg[MASK]n by stationing large numbers of troops within the area , by cond[MASK]cting large @-@ scale ' search ' opera[MASK]ions that were in fa[MASK]t undertaken for purposes of intelligence gathering , and by setting up over a dozen covert observation posts . Over the following years IRA violence in the city was contained to t[MASK]e point where it was possible to believe ' the war was over ' in the area , although there were still frequent street riots . Nationalists — even those who did not support the IRA — [MASK]emained bitterly opposed to the army and to the state . 
 Many of the residents [MASK] original grievances were addressed with the passing of the Local Government ( Northern Ireland ) Act , 1972 , which redrew the ele[MASK]toral boundaries and introduced universal adult suffrage based on the single transferable vote . Elections were held in May 1973 . Nationalists gained a majority [MASK]n the council for the first t[MASK]me since[MASK]1[MASK]23 . Since then the area has[MASK]been exte[MASK]sively redevelope[MASK] , with modern housing[MASK]replacing the old houses and flats . The Free Derry era is commemorated by the Free Derry wall , the murals of the Bogside Artists and the Museum of Free Derry .

 = Come What ( ever ) May = 
 
 Come What ( ever ) May is the [MASK]econd studio album by American alternative metal ba[MASK]d Stone Sour . It was recorded and produced by the band and Nick Raskulinecz at Studio 606 in Los Angeles , Ca[MASK]ifornia , and was release[MASK] on August 1 , 2006 , through Roadrunner Records . Writing for the album beg[MASK]n as [MASK]arly a[MASK] 2003 when vocalist Corey Taylor and guitarist James Root we[MASK]e writing material for their other band , Slipknot . In January 2006 Stone Sour began recording the follow @-@ up to their 2002 deb[MASK]t album Stone Sour , during which [MASK]ime drummer Joe[MASK] Ekman left the band due to family constraints . He was eventually replaced by ex @-@ Soulfly drummer Roy Mayorga who played on all but two tracks on the album . 
 Following the release of the[MASK]album , Stone Sour went on to [MASK]romote it for over a year ; re[MASK]easing five singles and touring in several regions , [MASK]ncluding the United States , Canada , Japan and severa[MASK] countries in Europe . The album received generally positive reviews . It was praised for showing a progression in the band 's song writing abil[MASK]ty and musical style . It was also certified Gold in the United[MASK]States and Canada and the single " 30 / 30 @-@ 150 " was nominated for Best Metal [MASK]erformance at the 49th Gram[MASK]y Awards . On June 26 , 2007 Stone Sour re[MASK]eased a special edi[MASK]ion versio[MASK] of the album , it included six previously unreleased tracks and a bonus DVD which featured three music videos and a complet[MASK] live perfor[MASK]ance of the band in Moscow . It remains their best @-@ selling album to date , mostly due to the success of the single " Th[MASK]ough Glass . "

 = Chad at the 2008 Summer Olympics[MASK]= 
 
 Chad s[MASK]nt a delegation of two athletes to compete at the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing , China : Moumi Sébergué , who [MASK]ompeted in the men 's 100 meters , and Hinikissia Albertine Nd[MASK]kert , who competed in the women 's 100 meters an[MASK] al[MASK]o bore the Chadian flag during ceremonies . The appearance of this delegation marked the tenth appearance of Chad [MASK]t the Summer Olympics , the first [MASK]een in [MASK]964 Summer Olympi[MASK]s in Tokyo , Japan , and its seventh appearance since i[MASK]s Olympic hiatus between 1976 and 1980 . Both Sébergué and Ndikert ranked seventh in their respective heats and did not advance past the qualification round . As of the end of the 2012 London Olympics[MASK], there have been no m[MASK]dalists from Chad . 
 
 =[MASK]= Background = = 
 
 Chad is a landlocked country in Africa whose northern region lies within the east[MASK]rn reaches of the Sahara Desert and whose southern region l[MASK]es within the eastern portion of the Sahel . It[MASK]borders Libya to the s[MASK]uth , Niger to the east , Sudan to t[MASK]e west[MASK], and the Central African Republic to the north . Chad was origi[MASK]ally part of French Wes[MASK] Africa until 1960 , w[MASK]en it declared independence . Some four years later , the former French colony made its débu[MASK] at the 1964 Summer Olympics in Tokyo , Japan . For the next th[MASK]ee decades , Chad became embroiled in[MASK]civil war and experienced invasions by Libya and upheavals by Sudanese @-@ backed rebels ; the civil war ended [MASK]n 1990 , although rebel threats had persisted[MASK]between then and 2008 . During Chad 's greatest era of instability , athletes from the country [MASK]id not att[MASK]nd the 1976 Summer Olympics in Montréal , Canada or the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow , USSR , although delegations were sent to all other games betwe[MASK]n 1964 and 2008 . 
 The largest Chadian delegation to reach the Olympics appeared in the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul , South Korea and at the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona , Spain ; each time , Chad 's [MASK]ational Olym[MASK]ic Committee sent six at[MASK]letes . D[MASK]ri[MASK]g the 1992 gam[MASK]s , the NOC sent the nation 's first female Olympia[MASK] . Since then ( and up to the Beijing games ) , at least one woman has b[MASK]en a part o[MASK] the Chadian delegation . The smallest contingency of Chadian [MASK]lympian[MASK] occurred during [MASK]he 2004 Summer Olympics in Athe[MASK]s , Greece , when only Kaltouma Nadjina competed on the country 's beha[MASK]f . The delegation that arrived in Beijing consisted of two athletes — one [MASK]an ( 30 @-@ year @-@ old Moumi Sébergué ) and one woman ( 15 @-@ year @-@ old Hinikissia Albertine Ndikert ) , both p[MASK][MASK]ticipants in track events . Ndikert was Chad 's fl[MASK]gbearer at the ceremonies . Up [MASK]o [MASK]nd including the Beijing games , there has y[MASK]t[MASK]to have been a medalist from Chad . 
 
 = = Ath[MASK]etics = = 
 
 Competitors in a[MASK]hletics events [MASK]ould qualify for the next roun[MASK] of competition in two ways . Qualifying by rig[MASK]t [MASK]as [MASK]osting a high result in their own heat , and qualifying by result was posting a high result in overall standings . Ranks shown are thus those within each heat , not in overall standings . 
 Moumi [MASK]ébergu[MASK] represented Chad at the Beijing Olym[MASK]i[MASK]s in the men 's 100 meters dash . Born in 1977 , Sébergué first participated in the Olympics at [MASK]ge 22 when he raced in th[MASK] men 's 100 meters at the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney , Australia , placing seventh in his qualification hea[MASK] and not progressing to later rounds . He did not attend the 2004 Summer Olympics in Athens , Greece , but returned to the Olympics at [MASK]eijing at the age of 30 . Durin[MASK] th[MASK] course of the August 14 , 2008 races in his event , when the qualification round t[MASK]ok place , Sébergué competed i[MASK] the tenth[MASK]heat against seven other[MASK]athletes . He finished the race in 11 @.@ 14 seconds , placing s[MASK]venth in the heat ahead of Tuvalu 's Okinali Tinilau ( 11 @.@ 48 seconds ) and behind Gabon 's Wilfried Bingangoye ( 10 @.@ 87 seconds ) in a heat led by the Netherlands Antilles ' Churandy Martina ( 10 @.@ 35 seconds ) and Japan 's [MASK]a[MASK]ki T[MASK]ukahara ( 10 @.@ 39 seconds ) . Of the 80 athletes who participated in the events , the Chadian sprinter ranked 70th . He did not advance to la[MASK]er rounds . 
 H[MASK]nikissia Albertine Ndikert competed on Chad '[MASK] behalf as the national delegation[MASK]'s only female athle[MASK]e at [MASK]he Beiji[MASK]g games . Of the event 's 85 competitors , Ndikert finished in 64th place [MASK] Therefore , Ndikert did not advance to round two and beyond .

[MASK][MASK] = View of t[MASK]e World from 9th Avenue = 
 
 View of the World from 9th Avenue ( s[MASK]metimes A Parochial New Yorker 's View of the World , A New Yorker 's View of the World or simply View of the World[MASK]) is a 1976 illustra[MASK]i[MASK]n by Saul Steinberg that[MASK]served as the cov[MASK]r of the[MASK]March 29 , 1976 , edition of The New Yorker .[MASK]The work presents the view from Manhattan of the rest of the world showing Manhattan as the[MASK]center of the world . 
 View of the World has been parodied b[MASK] Ted Rall , Columbia Pictures , The New Yorker , The [MASK]conomist and Mad Magaz[MASK]ne , [MASK]mong others . The work has been imitated and printed without author[MASK]zation in a variety of ways . The Columbi[MASK] parody led to a ruling by the United States District Court for the Southern District of New Yor[MASK] in Steinberg v. Columb[MASK]a Pictures Industries , Inc. in favor of Steinberg becaus[MASK] of copyright violations by Columbia Pictures . The work is [MASK]egarded as[MASK]one of the greatest magazine covers of recent generations and is studied by art students aro[MASK]nd the world . 
 
 = = Background = = 
 
 S[MASK]ul Steinberg created 85 covers and 642 internal drawings and ill[MASK]strations for The New Yorker ,[MASK][MASK]nclud[MASK]ng its March 29 , 1976 cover , titled " View of the World from 9th Avenue " . This is [MASK]egarded as his most famous work . It is cons[MASK]dered an exam[MASK]le of unintentional fame : Steinberg has noted that the type of fame that [MASK]esu[MASK]ted from the work has diminished his significance to " the man who did that poster " . The [MASK]ork is s[MASK]metimes referred to as A Parochial New Yorker 's View of the [MASK]orld or A New Yorker 's View of the World because it depicts a map of the world as seen by self @-@ absorbed New Yorkers . At one point The New Yorker applied for a copyright from the United States Copyright Office for the work . I[MASK] assigned the copyright to Steinberg and subsequently reproduced posters of the painting . 
 
 = = Detail = = 
 
[MASK]The illustration is split in two p[MASK]rts , with the bottom half of the image showin[MASK] Manhattan 's 9th Avenue , 10th Avenue , and the Hudson River ( appropriately labeled ) , and the top half depicting the rest of the world . It is a w[MASK]stward view over 10th Avenue . The rest of the United States is[MASK]the size of the three New York City b[MASK]ocks and is drawn as a rectangle bounded by North American neighbors Canada and Mexico , with a thin brown strip along the Hudson repr[MASK]senting " Jersey " , the names of five cities ( Los Angeles ; Washington , D.C. ; Las Vegas ; Kansas City ; and Chicago ) and three states ( Tex[MASK]s [MASK] Utah , and Nebraska ) [MASK]cat[MASK]ered among a few rocks for the United States beyond New Jersey[MASK], which is in bolder font than the rest of the country beyond the Hudson . Washington , D.[MASK][MASK] is depicted as a remote location near Mexico . The Pacific Ocean , slightly wider [MASK]han the [MASK]udson , separates the United States from three flattened land masses labeled China , Japan and Russia . Notably , the image depicts the world with a back turn[MASK]d to Europe , which is absent from t[MASK]e painting . 
 The work is composed in ink , pencil , colored pencil , and watercolor on paper and measures 28 by 19 inc[MASK]es ( 71 cm × 48 cm ) . When exhibiting this work along with alternate versions and sketches , the Univers[MASK]ty of Pennsylvania summarized the [MASK]ork as a " bird 's @-@ eye view of [MASK]he [MASK]ity from Ninth Avenue in a s[MASK]raight line westward [MASK] with space becoming ever [MASK]ore condensed ...[MASK]" Th[MASK]y also described th[MASK] [MASK]ork as a t[MASK]ngue @-@ [MASK]n @-@ cheek view of the wor[MASK]d . New York in[MASK]erpreted the New York [MASK]-@ centric mind 's view of the res[MASK] of the world as[MASK]a set of outer boroughs as [MASK]conic . National Post journalist Robert Fulford descr[MASK]bed the perspective as one in which the entire world is a suburb of Manhattan . 
 
 = = Parodies = = 
 
 View of the World has been imitated without authorization in a variety of ways . The[MASK]work has been imitated in postcard format by numerous municipalitie[MASK] , states and nations . Stein[MASK]er[MASK] had stated that he could have retired on royaltie[MASK] from the many parodies made of the painting , had they been[MASK]paid , a motiv[MASK]tion for his eventual copyright lawsuit for the[MASK]Moscow on the Hudson use . Fulford , writing in The National Post , noted that the metaphor [MASK]f the world as a sub[MASK]rb of Manhattan was " understood and borrowed " by the who[MASK]e world . Local artis[MASK]s , especially poster artists , presented similarly [MASK]ompelling depictions of their own provincial perceptions . Fulford demonstrated the prominence of this work by mentioning that a high school in suburban Ottawa made imitating View of the World an assignment in its graphic arts[MASK]class . He also noted that the results of this assignment was a wo[MASK]ldwide variety of [MASK]lobal foci from which the students viewed the world . 
 The illustration — humorously depicting New[MASK]Yorkers[MASK]' self[MASK]@-@ image of their plac[MASK] in the w[MASK]rld , or perhaps outsiders ' view of New Yorkers ' self @-@ image — inspire[MASK] [MASK]any similar works , including the poster for the 1984 film Moscow on the Hudson ; that movie poster led to a lawsuit , Steinberg v. C[MASK]lumbia Pictures Industries , Inc . , 663 F. Supp . 706 ( S.D.N.Y. 1987 ) , which held that Columbia Pictures violated the copyright Steinberg held on his work . 
 On June 5 , 2003 , during the first term of George W. Bush 's presidency , Ted Rall presented A View of the World [MASK]rom Pennsylvania[MASK]Avenue as a Parody of View of the World from 9th Avenue in a Universal Press [MASK]yndicate editorial cartoon . He replaced the letters representing The New [MASK]orker with The Bushie . 
 The cover was later sati[MASK]ized by Bar[MASK]y Blitt for the cove[MASK] of The [MASK]ew Yorker[MASK]on October 6 , 2008 . The cover featured Sara[MASK] Palin loo[MASK]ing out of her window [MASK]eeing[MASK]only Alaska , with Russia in the far background . 
 The March 21 , 2009 The Econ[MASK]mis[MASK] included[MASK]a sto[MASK]y entitled " How China sees the World " that presents a parody that is also an homage to the original image [MASK] but dep[MASK][MASK]ting the vie[MASK]point from Beijing 's Cha[MASK]g 'an Avenue instead of Manhattan . A caption above the illustration reads " Illustration by Jon Berkeley ( with apologies to steinberg and The New Yorker ) " [MASK] It accompanied an article that disc[MASK]ssed the burgeoning Chinese economy at the time of the contempor[MASK]ry financial crisis . 
 The O[MASK]tober 1 , 2012 cover o[MASK] Mad Magazine satirized the problems with th[MASK] Sept[MASK]mber[MASK]release of Apple Inc . ' s iOS 6 mobile operating system which included Apple Maps , a replacement for Google Maps . The work presents what View of the World mig[MASK]t look like if one had relied u[MASK]on the September 2012 [MASK]ersion of Apple [MASK]aps to lo[MASK]ate various landmarks . 
 
 = = Critical review = =[MASK]
 
 On October 17 , 2005 , American Society of Magazine Edi[MASK]ors unveiled its list of the top 40 magazine covers of the prior 40 years and ranked View of the World from 9th Avenue in fourth place . The listing stated that the [MASK]ork " ... has come to represe[MASK]t Manhattan 's telescoped perception of the country beyond the Hudson River[MASK]. The car[MASK]oon showed the supposed limited mental geography of M[MASK]nhattanites . " 
 
 
 = Bintul[MASK] = 
 
 Bintulu / biːnˈtu[MASK]luː / ( Chinese : [MASK]都魯 ; pinyin : Míndū[MASK]ǔ ; Pe ̍ h @-@ ōe @-[MASK] jī : Bîn @-@ to ͘[MASK]-ló ͘ ) is a coastal town on the island of[MASK][MASK]orneo [MASK]n the centra[MASK] region of Sarawak , Malaysia . Bintulu is located 610 kilometres ( 380 mi ) nor[MASK]heast of Kuching [MASK] 216 kilometres ( 134 mi ) northeast of Sibu , and 200 kilome[MASK]res [MASK] 120 mi ) southwest of Mir[MASK] . With a population of 1[MASK]4 [MASK],@ 058 as of 2010 , Bintulu is the capital of the Bintulu District of the Bi[MASK]tulu[MASK]Division of Sarawak , Malaysia . 
 The n[MASK]me of Bintulu was derived from the local native language " Mentu Ulau " ( picking heads ) . Bintulu[MASK]was a small fishing village when Rajah James Bro[MASK]ke a[MASK]quired it in 186[MASK] . Brooke later built a fort ther[MASK] in 1862 . In 1867 , the f[MASK]rst General Council meeting ( now Sarawak State Legislative Assembly ) was convened in Bin[MASK]ulu . It is the earliest state legislature [MASK]ystem in Malaysia . The construction of the earliest airstrip in Bintulu began in 1934 but was halted in 1938 due to financial diffi[MASK]ulties . During World War II , t[MASK]e airstrip was heavily bombed by Allied forces . The Briti[MASK]h later rebuilt the airstrip , and it became [MASK]ully operational in 1955 . The old airport was replaced by a new airport in[MASK]2002 . Bintu[MASK]u remained a fishing village until 1969 when oil and gas reserves were discovered off the coast . Since then ,[MASK]Bintulu has become the centre of energy int[MASK]nsive i[MASK]dustries such as a Malaysia LNG plant , a[MASK]Shell Middle Distillate Synth[MASK]sis plant , and a Bintulu combined cycle power plant . The economy has also expanded into oil palm and forest plan[MASK]ations , palm[MASK]oil processing , wood @-@ waste processing , and cemen[MASK] manufacturing . The [MASK]ort of Bintulu is[MASK]the busiest in Sarawak . The town is also a gateway to Samalajau Industrial Park . 
 Among th[MASK] tourist attractions in Bintulu are Similajau National Park , Tumbina Par[MASK] , Tanjung Batu beach , Jepak village , Kuan[MASK]Yin Tong temple , Assyakirin[MASK]m[MASK][MASK]que , Council Negri monument , Tamu Bintulu , and Pasar Utama markets . The Borneo International[MASK]Kite Festival is held annu[MASK]lly i[MASK] the town . 
[MASK]
 = = Etymology = = 
 
 During the 16th cen[MASK]ury , Bintulu was named " River de Burulu [MASK] by Portuguese cartographers . There are several legends surroundi[MASK]g the name Bi[MASK]tulu . During the Brooke [MASK]ynasty , the indigenous Iban people practised headhunting to maintain their social status in the community . They threw the heads into the Kemena River , after which the heads had to be collected from the river . The prac[MASK]ice of collecting the heads was known as [MASK] Mentu Ulau " ( picking heads ) in the local native language . A[MASK]other st[MASK]ry relates that [MASK]wo Iban warriors named Bernik and Jelab built houses along the river . They and their followers frequently carried out preservati[MASK]n of severed heads near a small river stream bra[MASK]ching off from Sebezaw River because the riv[MASK]r bank was flat and wide . Therefore , the[MASK]small river stream was named " Mentu Ulau " riv[MASK]r . Outsiders who came to Bintulu subsequently pro[MASK]ounced the name as " Mentulau " , and later the name evolved into " Bent[MASK]lu " and , finally , " Bi[MASK]tulu " . 
 
 = = History = = 
 
 
 = = = Brooke dynasty = = = 
 
 James B[MASK]ooke was appointed the White Rajah of Sarawak ( now known as[MASK]Kuching ) by the Bruneian Empire in 184[MASK] . In 1861 , the Sultanate of Brunei ceded the Bintulu region to Broo[MASK]e . Bintulu was a small settlement at that time . A wooden fort named Fort Keppel was built in the village [MASK] [MASK]amed after Sir Henry Keppel , w[MASK]o was a close friend of th[MASK] Rajah James and Charles Brooke . Sir Henry Keppel was responsible for crushing the Dayak piracy in the Saribas between 1840 and[MASK]1850 . Meanwhile , Charles Bro[MASK]ke was a nephew of James Brooke and would later become the latt[MASK]r 's successor as the second Rajah of Sarawak . Odoardo Beccari , an Italian botanist , visited Bintulu in 1867 . On 4 August , he started his journey on a gunboat named [MASK] Heartsea[MASK]e " , which was to send $ 6 @,@ 000 to Brunei for concessions being made [MASK]o James Brooke in the Mukah[MASK]and Bintu[MASK]u regions . He went t[MASK] Labuan before coming back to Bintulu . He dropped off at Kemena River o[MASK] 13 August 1867 . His ob[MASK]ervations of the villa[MASK]e were recorded as follows : 
 The fort o[MASK] Bintu[MASK][MASK] which was built ent[MASK]rely of wood , was in somewh[MASK]t ruinous con[MASK]ition . It stood nearly on the sea @-@[MASK]shore , and just behind it , at a distance of few paces , the p[MASK]imeval for[MASK]sts commenced ... Some chinamen had [MASK]ettled at the vicinit[MASK] of the fort and had built [MASK] small bazaar ; but the village is [MASK]hiefly formed by the houses of the Melana[MASK] beyond the Chinese kampong ( village ) . These Melanaus used to live further u[MASK] the river , but since the constru[MASK]tion of the fort , and the installation of an officer of[MASK]the Rajah near the mouth of the river , they came to settle near the sea – a thing they would never have dared to do in former days for fear of the attacks of the Lanun[MASK]pirates and Dayak pirates . 
 The houses of the Melanau people were built in ro[MASK]s on b[MASK]th sides of the Kemena River , mostly furnished by Nipah and Sago palms . Each house had its own shed projection into t[MASK]e entrance of the river , which was used for the processing of Sago palms . On 8 Septem[MASK]er 1867 , the first Sarawak General Council meeting ( now Sarawak State Legislative Assembly ) took place here . It was m[MASK]de up of 21 elected local community members ( five [MASK]ritish officers and 16 [MASK]ala[MASK] and Melanau local chiefs ) . The Council was formed by Raja Muda Charles Brooke under orders from Rajah James Brooke . The Council is the oldest state legisl[MASK]tive assembly in Malaysia . 
 
 = = = Japanese occupation = = = 
 
 During World War II , Rajah Charles Vyne[MASK] Brooke ordered the construction of airstrips in Kuc[MASK]ing , Oya , Mu[MASK]ah , Bintulu , and Miri . Construction of the Bintulu airstrip was started in 1934 under the direction of C. W.[MASK]Bailey , a Wor[MASK]s and Building Inspecto[MASK] for the British Royal Air Force ( RAF ) . All the a[MASK]rstrips were completed except for th[MASK] Bintulu airstrip , where construction was discontinued in October 1938 due to financial reasons . Japanese forces landed in Miri on 16 December 1941 . Sarawak fell into Japanese hands when they conquered Kuching on 24 December 1941 .[MASK]When the Japanese[MASK]invaded Sarawak , Charles Vyner Brooke a[MASK]ready left for Sydney ( Australia ) before the attack while his officers were captured by the Japanese and interned at the Batu Lintang camp . During the Japanese occupation , the Japanese used the airstrip for military purposes . However , the airstrip was heavily bombed[MASK]b[MASK] Allied forces . The British began reconstruction of the a[MASK]rstrip after the war ; during the project many unexploded bombs were unearthed . 
 On 5 September 1942 , Japanese[MASK]Field Marshal Prince Maida ( 前田利为 ) boarded a plane from Kuching to Labuan to off[MASK]ciate an airport that bears his name . However , he never arrived . One month later , the pla[MASK]e was found to have crashed off the coast of Tanjung Datu , B[MASK]ntulu . The cause of the plane cras[MASK] was not known . The Japanese later set up a wooden pole memorial made up of Belian wood in Bintulu[MASK]. The wooden pole was later taken back to Japan by the fa[MASK]ily of Prince Maida . 
 Chinese sawmill owners [MASK]t Sibu and Bintulu were instructed by the Japanese to produce timber fo[MASK] repairs at oil fields and ship building . During the Japanese occupation , sawmills at Bintulu produced a tot[MASK]l of 4 @,@ [MASK]00 to[MASK]s of sawn timber . 
 
 = = = Post @-@ war period = = = 
 
 In the 1[MASK]50s , major eco[MASK]omic activities in Bintulu were the timber extraction industry , fishing , and[MASK]Sago processi[MASK]g . In the 1960s , Bintulu was still [MASK] [MASK]mall fishing village , with a popu[MASK]ation of 5 @,@ 000 . No roads were constructed in Bintulu until 1969 when the first untarred roa[MASK] was built to connect Bintulu to Miri . The first bus that serviced the Mir[MASK] – Bintulu route w[MASK]s owned by Majlis Amanah Rakyat ( MARA ) . The MARA bus line was an initiative by the Ma[MASK]aysian federal government to provide public transportation for the people . The Iban villagers paid the bus driver with " vegetables , chickens , bamboo shoots , and other items " . Before 1960 , Bintulu was connected to Kuching by sea through a ship named " Swee Joo " . After 1960 , the ship " Chin Chin " was added to the route . It took around 36 to 48 hours to reach Bintulu from Kuchi[MASK]g ,[MASK]de[MASK]ending on the sea conditions . Due to lack of food supplies from Kuching , the villagers had to make do with limited food , and several villagers resorted to hunting in the jun[MASK]les to supplement the food supply . 
 In 1960 there were only three primary schools in Bintulu . These schools provided classes until [MASK]ri[MASK]ary 3 level . There were no secondary schools . Vil[MASK]age[MASK]s [MASK]ould pursue their secondary school studies at either[MASK]Miri or Kuching by using small boats as the[MASK]e were no roads connecting Bintulu to either Miri or Kuchi[MASK]g . Bintulu Go[MASK][MASK]rnment Secondary School was open[MASK]d in 1964 . In 1967 Bintulu celebrated the first 100 years of the Council Negri [MASK]eeting ( Sarawak State [MASK]egislative Assembly ) . A stone monument was [MASK]uilt in front of a[MASK]government rice storer[MASK]om to commemorate the event . Bintulu was a sub @-@ district of Mir[MASK] Division in the 1970s .[MASK]The [MASK]ub @-@ district was upgraded into a district in 1987 . 
 
 = = = Disco[MASK]ery of oil and gas[MASK]reserves = = = 
 
 Lar[MASK]e reserves of natural gas were discovered off the coast of Bintulu in 1969 . Following this , a feasibility study was [MASK]one [MASK]n 1975 , and Tanjung Kidurong was found to be a s[MASK]itable site for a deep @[MASK]@ water po[MASK]t .[MASK]On 14 June 1978 , Malaysia LNG Sdn Bhd ( MLNG Satu [MASK] was established by Petronas , a Malaysian national oil and gas company for Liquef[MASK]ed [MASK]atural Gas ( LNG ) pro[MASK]essing at Bintulu . On 8 July 1978 , the Bintulu Development Authorit[MASK] ( BDA ) was established[MASK]by the Sarawak state government for infrastructure developm[MASK]nt and to promote industri[MASK]l invest[MASK][MASK]nt in the[MASK]area . On 15 August 1981 , the Bintulu Port Authority was established at Tanjung Kidurong , starting operation on 1 January 1983 . Since the establishment of Sarawak Corridor of Renewable Energy ( SC[MASK]RE ) in 2008 , Bintulu become the gateway to Samalajau Industrial Park [MASK] which is located 62 kilometres ( 39 mi )[MASK]away from Bintulu . The industrial park is a centre of heavy , energy @-@ intensive industry . Among the companies that started their operations in the industrial park are Tokuyama Malaysia Sdn Bhd , Press Metal [MASK]intul[MASK] Sdn[MASK]Bhd , and OM Materials Sdn Bhd . 
 Rural – urban mi[MASK]ration is significant in Bintulu because of greater job availability in the town . Since 2007[MASK], n[MASK]w residents have started several squatter areas in Bintulu d[MASK]e to inability to find affordable housing , arou[MASK]d Kidurong Industrial estate and Sungai [MASK]ebatang . To address the issue , several low @-@ cost housing projects were initiated by BDA and Sarawak state government to relocate the squatters . [MASK]he state government planned to achieve zero squatters status by the year 2020 . Bintulu also saw the rise in [MASK]he number of residential and commercial propertie[MASK] such as double @-@ storeyed terraced houses ,[MASK]terraced shopoffices , Kidurong Commercial Centre , and Time Square Shopping Mall . Residential properties has shown a 20 % price [MASK]ncrease from 2011 to 2013 . 
 [MASK] = = Governance = = 
 
 Bintulu is rep[MASK]esented by Bintulu parli[MASK]mentary seat ( P. 2[MASK]7 ) in the Parliament of [MASK]alaysia . The town is also represented by three state assembly seats – Jepak , Kidurong ( l[MASK]ter was split by two state assembly namely Tanjung Batu and Samalaju ) , and Kemena [MASK] in the Sarawak State Legislative Assembl[MASK] .[MASK]
 
 = = = Local authorities = = = 
 
 Since 1978 the town of Bintulu has been administered by the Bin[MASK]ulu Development Authority ( BDA ) , with offices located along Jalan Tanjung Kidurong[MASK]. The town i[MASK] located within the bo[MASK]n[MASK]ary of Bintulu District , with a populat[MASK]on of 183 @,@ 402 and a total area of 7 @,@ 220 @.@ 40 square kilometres ( 2 @,@ 787 @.@ 81 sq mi ) . Bintulu Division was formerly a Bintulu District under the juri[MASK]diction of Miri Divi[MASK]ion . The [MASK]ormer Bintul[MASK] District was upgraded to Bintulu Division on 1 January 1987 [MASK] At the same time , Bintul[MASK] sub @-@ district was upgraded to the present @-@ day Bintulu District . Both the Bintulu Resident and Distri[MASK]t offices are located inside Wisma Residen[MASK], Pisang Keling Street , Bintulu . 
 
 = =[MASK]Geography = = 
 
 Bintulu is located 610 kilometres ( 380 mi ) northeast o[MASK] Kuching 216 kilometres ( 134 mi ) northeast of Sibu , and 200 ki[MASK]ometres ( 120 mi ) southwest of Miri . Bintu[MASK]u is located near the mouth of the Kemena River , in the coastal region of central Sarawak . Geology of the coastal are[MASK] was formed during the Pleistocene period ; sil[MASK] , cl[MASK]y , and[MASK]gravel can [MASK]e found here . Geological formation from the Oligoc[MASK]ne period is found in the inland area , which contains limestone , siltstone , and sandstone . The soil[MASK]is generally soft . 
 
 = = = Climate = = = 
 
 There are two mo[MASK]soon s[MASK]asons in the Bintulu : the northeast moonsoon ( November to [MASK]arch[MASK]) and the southwest moonsoon ( May to September ) . The calm period betw[MASK]en these two moonsoons is known as the transitional period . In the coastal region , max[MASK]mum rainfall occurs in the month of January , while minimal rainfall occurs from the period J[MASK]ne to August . Rainfall is more evenly distribut[MASK]d in the inland areas . The annual rainfall of the Bintulu region is about 3 @[MASK]@ 750 mm ( 148 in ) annually . The mean daily hours of sunshine at Bintulu is about 5 @.@ 0 to 5 @.@ 5 hours . Bintulu receives on average 14 to 15 mJ / m2 of radiation throughout the[MASK]year . Bintulu 's [MASK]elative humidity is 85 % . 
 
 = = Demographics[MASK]= = 
 
 The growth of Bintulu 's p[MASK]pulation is shown below : 
 The issue of gangsters in Bintulu was first raised in 2007 by the mem[MASK]er[MASK]of parliament ( MP ) for Bintul[MASK] . The gangster[MASK] may have run businesses[MASK]related to illegal logging , controlling the prices [MASK]f diesel , eggs ,[MASK]fertiliser and gas cylinders . Bintulu police have been cracking down on gangste[MASK] activities in the town . Unscrupulous businessmen who seek ch[MASK]ap labour have caused a rise in the number of illegal immigrants in Bintulu . The number may have reached 50 @,@ 000 in 2009 . Bintulu immigration department has performed several operations to deport illegal immigrants [MASK]ack to their home country . 
 
 = = = Ethnic[MASK]ty[MASK]= = = 
 
 As of the 2010 Malaysian census , the population of the town of Bintulu is 114 @,@ 058 . Indigenous p[MASK]ople accounted for the largest proportion of the town population ( 61 @.@ 2 %[MASK], 69 @,@ 782 ) , followed by Chinese ( 25 @.@ 0 % , 28 @,@ 512[MASK])[MASK], Non @-@ Ma[MASK]aysians ([MASK]13 @.@ 1 % , 14 @,@ 939 ) , and Indians ( 0 @.@ 28 % , 319 ) . Among t[MASK]e indigenous groups , there[MASK]are Iban ( 32 @,@ 992 ) [MASK] Malay ( 14 @,@ 945 )[MASK], Melanau ( 14 @,@ 179 ) , B[MASK]dayuh ( 1 @[MASK][MASK] 598 ) , and other indigenous tribes ( 6 @,@ 068 ) . According to government sources , there are 229 Iban longhouses in the Bintulu District . The Ibans moved into Kemena and Tatau basins in the mid @-@ 19th and early 20th century with permission of t[MASK]e Brooke government . Other in[MASK]igenous tribes that for[MASK] the minority are Kayan , Kenyah , and Punan . The Chinese in Bintulu are mainl[MASK] composed of dialect groups such as Hakka , Fuzhou , and T[MASK]ochews . The Chinese have been living in the town of Ta[MASK]au since the era of Bruneian Empi[MASK]e . Later , Fuzhou Chinese from Sibu moved in , dominating [MASK]he timber and planta[MASK]ion businesses in Bintulu . There is also a large number of foreigners working there . Most of th[MASK]m[MASK]come from Britai[MASK] , Australi[MASK] , the Netherlands , Germany , [MASK]ou[MASK]h Africa , New Zealand , Japan , China , the United States , and Indonesia . 
 [MASK] = = = Langu[MASK]ges = = = 
 
 While Malay is the o[MASK]ficial language of Saraw[MASK]k ; English is widely spoken there . Loca[MASK] ethnic languages and Chinese d[MASK]alect[MASK] are spoken [MASK]y the respective [MASK]thnic groups . Standard Chinese[MASK]is also spoken by ethnic [MASK]hinese in Bintulu . Bintulu is spoken by communities[MASK]living along the Kemena Rive[MASK] , with 4 @,@ 200 native speakers . These speakers a[MASK]e now recog[MASK]ised as part of the Melanau ethnic group , where their [MASK]a[MASK]n language is Malay . Bintulu is classified[MASK]as one of the endangered languages in Sarawak because of the isolated [MASK]sage of the langu[MASK]g[MASK] in a small communit[MASK] . 
 
 = = = Religion = = = 
 
 The majori[MASK]y of the Bintulu population are adherents of Christian denominations due to Christian missionaries operating during the[MASK]Brooke dynas[MASK]y[MASK]; foll[MASK]wed by Isl[MASK]m , Buddhism , and Hinduism . Among the notable places o[MASK] worship in Bintulu are the Bintulu Mosque ( Masjid Assyakirin ) , Masjid Jepak , Tua Pek Kong Temple , Eng Kwang Methodist Church , and St[MASK] Thoma[MASK] Church . The respective religious groups are free to hold processions in the town . 
[MASK]
 = = Economy = = 
 
 There are five industrial estates in Bintulu . They are : Kemena Industrial Estate ( for wood @-@ based industries ) , Jepak Industries Estate ( wood @-@ bas[MASK]d industries ) , Kidurong Industrial Area ( for medi[MASK]m and light industries ) ,[MASK]Kidurong [MASK]ight Industrial Estate ( medium and light industries )[MASK], and Bintulu[MASK]Light Industri[MASK]l Estate ( light ind[MASK]stry ) . 
 
 = = = Oil and gas = = = 
 
 Malaysia LNG is a [MASK]iquefied Natural Gas ( LNG ) manufac[MASK]uring complex located in Bintulu that curre[MASK]tly contains eight LNG trains with a ninth one currently under construction . The complex was built by the Malaysian natio[MASK]al oil and gas company ,[MASK]Petronas . The manufacturing complex has a production c[MASK]pacity of 25 @.@ 7 million tonnes per annum . Petronas is also planning to open Floating[MASK]LNG ( FLNG ) offshore Bintulu , which is used specifically to harvest natural gas from small and isolated gas fields . Transportation of natural gas from the neig[MASK]ouring state of Kimanis , Sabah , to the[MASK]LNG complex at Bintulu is facilitated by a 512 @-@ kilometre ( 318 mi ) pip[MASK]line known as the " S[MASK]bah Sarawak Gas Pipeline [MASK] . Currently , 45 % of Malaysian natural gas[MASK]is found at Central Luconia off the coast of Bin[MASK]ulu . The largest[MASK]importers of Malaysia LNG productions are Japan ( 62 [MASK] ) , Korea ( 17 % ) , Taiwan ( 1[MASK] % )[MASK], and [MASK]hina ( 9 % ) . 
 The Sarawak Shell Bintulu Plant ( SSBP ) , formerly known as Bintulu Crude Oil Terminal ( BCOT ) , was established in 1979 .[MASK]It consists of three crude oil storage ta[MASK]ks , each with a c[MASK]pacity of 410 @,@ 000 barrels . It has three major are[MASK]s of operation : Crude Oil Operations , Condensate [MASK]tabilisatio[MASK] , and Gas[MASK]Sales Facilities . Royal Dutch Shell started to establ[MASK]sh the world 's first Shell Middle[MASK]Distillat[MASK] Synthesis plant ( She[MASK]l MDS ) in 1993 . It is also known as Bi[MASK]tulu Gas @-@ To @-@ Liquid plant ( Bintulu GTL ) . The plant has a production capacity of 14 @,@ 770 barrels per day with a total investment of ove[MASK] US $ 1 billio[MASK] as of the year 2010[MASK]. The p[MASK]ant is staffed with 380 people , of whom 93 % are Malaysians , with 8[MASK] % of the staff coming from Sarawak . 
 
 = = = [MASK]ood @-@ based industries and plantations = = = 
 
 Since the opening up of the Bintulu – Miri road in the 1970s , large @-@ s[MASK]al[MASK] plantations of oil [MASK]alm and cocoa has been developed in [MASK]ural areas of Bintulu Division . Currently , th[MASK]re are 57 @,@ 740 hectares ( 577 @.@ 4 km2 ( 223 sq mi ) ) of oil palm , [MASK][MASK]@,[MASK] 000 hectares ( 200 km2 ( 77[MASK]sq mi ) )[MASK][MASK]f Rattan , and 815 hectares [MASK] 8 @.@ 15 km[MASK] ( 3 sq mi ) ) of pepper plantations . 
 The first Bintu[MASK]u palm oil refinery , Bint[MASK]lu Edibl[MASK] O[MASK]l Sdn Bhd , [MASK]as estab[MASK]ished in June 1991 . Bintulu currently has four palm oil refineries : Bint[MASK]lu Edible Oils Sdn Bhd ( operated under PGEO Group , a subsidiary of Wilmar International ) , Sime Darby Austral Edible Oil Sdn Bh[MASK] , Kirana Palm Oil Refinery Sdn Bhd , and Sar[MASK]wak Oil Palm Bhd . However , as of 2015 , W[MASK]lmar no longer buys raw palm oil produced from cl[MASK]ared forests and peat swamps in Sarawak bec[MASK]use of environmen[MASK]al c[MASK]ncerns . 
 The Bintulu Division has been designated as a Planted Forests Zo[MASK]e ( PFZ ) by the Sarawak state government since 1998 . As of 30 June 2011 , a total of 124 @,@ 618 hectares ( 1 @,@ 246 @.@ 18 km2 ( 481 sq [MASK]i ) ) has been planted with[MASK]acacia trees . Othe[MASK] tre[MASK]s that are planned for plantations are kelampayan , [MASK]ngkabang , durian , batai , eucalyptus , and rubber trees . Sarawak Planted F[MASK]re[MASK]t [MASK]dn Bhd , a[MASK]company wholly o[MASK]ned by the Sarawak state government , has[MASK]been granted a license to replant forests for 60 years . However [MASK] the company has been suffering fina[MASK]cial losses from 2009 to 2011 . 
 There a[MASK]e three mills in [MASK]intulu that process wood @[MASK]@ waste prod[MASK][MASK]ts . Two[MASK]are Medium @-@ density fibreboard ( MDF ) plants and the third is a charcoal briquette plant , with a total installed capaci[MASK]y of 246 @,@ 000 cubic metres ( 8 @,@ 700 @,@ 000 cu ft ) per year . MDF plants utilise wood waste purchased from sawmills and plywood mills in the Bintulu area and o[MASK]c[MASK]sionally from the Tanjung Manis timber processing zone located at the mouth of the Rajang River . Synthetic resins , which are required to hold wood du[MASK]t together , consti[MASK]uted 20 [MASK] of the[MASK]total production cost of the wood panel products . MDF plants[MASK]in Bintulu are operated by Daiken Sarawak[MASK]Sdn Bhd , which was founded on 15 February 1994 . The briquette plant is operated by Cipta Briquette Sdn Bhd . A glue / adhesive[MASK]factory in Bintulu is [MASK]wned by Bintulu Adhesive & Chemicals Sd[MASK] Bhd . It pr[MASK]duces urea formalde[MASK]yde resin a[MASK]d phenol formaldehyde resin [MASK]or[MASK]plywood and chipboard manufacturing at Kemena Industrial Estate . Urea precondensate is also prod[MASK]ced to supply ASEAN Bintulu Fertiliser ( ABF ) plant . 
 [MASK] = = = O[MASK]hers = = = 
 
 The Bintulu Port Authority was established in 1981 . It started port operation in 1983 at Tanjung Kidurong . Following a privatis[MASK]tion exercise ,[MASK]Bintulu Port Sdn Bhd ( BPSB ) was founded on 23 December 1992 and commenced operation on 1 Janu[MASK]ry 1993 . BPA is currently responsible for regulatory exer[MASK]ises and security of the port . Meanwhile [MASK] BPSB is responsible for cargo handling at the Bintulu International Cont[MASK]iner Terminal ( BICT ) . The port also provides Vessel traffic service to shipping vessels . The annual total cargo throughput [MASK]s 45 @.@ 4 million tonnes , consisting of 58 % LNG and 42 % non @-@ LNG products . As of 31 December 2014 , it generated a total revenue of RM 552 @.@ 3 [MASK]illion pe[MASK] year . Bintulu Port is the busiest port in Sarawak . 
 The ASEAN Bintulu Fertiliser plant is the anhydrous ammonia and granular plant operated by ASEAN Bintulu Fertiliser Sdn Bhd ( ABF ) , which is partly owned by Petronas .[MASK]The [MASK]ompany was formed on 6 De[MASK]ember 1980 . The pl[MASK]nt started operation on 1 October 1985 . It[MASK]is also one of the largest granular urea pl[MASK]nts in Asia . It is a join[MASK] venture by five ASEAN countries : Malaysia ( [MASK]3 @.@ 5 % shares ) , Thailand ( 13 % ) , Ind[MASK]nesia [MASK] 13 % ) , the Philippines ( 9 @.@ 5 % ) , and Sin[MASK]apore ( 1 % ) . 
 Cahya Mata Sarawak Berhad ( C[MASK]SB )[MASK], one of the largest publicly traded companies in Sarawak , set up a cement plant in Bintulu at Kiduro[MASK]g Industrial Esta[MASK]e . Th[MASK] plant , manned by 40 people , produces ordinary Portland cement an[MASK] Portland blast furnace cement . It currently has a combined production capacity of 2 @.@ 75 million MT ( millio[MASK] tonnes ) . 
 The Bintul[MASK] co[MASK]bined cycle power plant was started in early 2010 with a capacity[MASK]of 317 megawatts . The power plant is registered under[MASK]the Un[MASK]ted Nations Cl[MASK]an Development Management ( CDM ) scheme [MASK]s of 18 September 2010 . The pl[MASK]nt is built to ensure efficient use of energy and reduce gre[MASK]n house gas emissions . It is the first CDM power plant in Malaysia , currently operated by Sarawak [MASK]o[MASK]er Generation Sdn Bhd ( SPG ) , a wholly owned subsidiary of Sarawak Energy .

[MASK]= = Transportation = = 
 
 
 = = = Land = = = [MASK] 
 All roads in Bintulu are[MASK]maintained by the B[MASK]ntulu Development Authority ( BDA ) . Bintulu[MASK]is[MASK]connected to Miri and Sibu by the Pan Borneo Highway . Bintulu is also connected to Mukah [MASK]nd Samalaju Indus[MASK]rial Park . Kemena Bridge crosses the Kemena River . It is t[MASK]e second bridge in Malaysia built using the incremental launch method . Keppel Road in Bintulu is named after a friend of J[MASK]mes Brooke , Sir Henry Keppel . 
 
 =[MASK]= = = Public transportation = = = = 
 
 Bintulu has a long @-@ distanc[MASK] bus station [MASK] located at [MASK]edan Jaya , 5 km ( 3 mi ) nort[MASK]east of the town centre . Among the areas served by the bus station are : Miri , Sibu , Kuching , Mukah , Sarikei , Oya , Dalat , [MASK]alingian , and Pontianak [MASK] Indonesia . The bus companies that serve the station are the Syarikat Baram Sdn . Bhd , MTC , Bi[MASK]ramas , and Suria bus lines . There are also buses that serve the town area . Taxi service is[MASK]also available . 
 
 = = = Air = = = 
 
 The old Bintulu airport was built in 1955[MASK]in the town c[MASK]ntre . It once held the Guinness World Record[MASK]of nearest ai[MASK]port to town[MASK]. On 19 Decem[MASK]er 2002 , the airport was replaced by a new airport , which is loc[MASK][MASK]ed 23 km ( 14 mi ) away from the town centre . The surroundings o[MASK] the old airport were developed into commercial and residential projects while the runaway is reserved for Bintulu International Kite Festival . The new airport has a runway measuring[MASK]2 @,@ 745 m ( 9 @,@ 006[MASK]ft ) , capable of handling planes as large as [MASK]he Airbus A[MASK]30 . The airport currently serves three major airlines : Malaysia Airlines ( MAS [MASK] , Air Asia , and MASwings , connecting t[MASK] domestic destinations such as : Sibu , Mir[MASK] , Kuching , Kuala L[MASK]mpur , and Kota Kinabalu .

 = = = Heal[MASK]hcare = = = 
 
 Bintulu Hospital started operation in 1968 . It is located at Nyabau Road , 12 km ( 7 @[MASK]@ 5 mi ) from the town centre . Following ren[MASK]vations completed on 21 May 2000 , the hospital is now equipped with 200 beds . As of 20[MASK]1 [MASK] the hospital provides speciality services i[MASK] seven medical disciplines . Bintulu also has one polyclinic , Polyclinic Bin[MASK]ulu . There are two private hospitals in Bintulu : Columbia Asia Hospital and Bintulu Medical Centre [MASK] [MASK]

 There are about 50 primary and eight secondary schools in Bintulu . All the [MASK]chools under the National Education System are managed by the Bintulu District Education Of[MASK]ice . The oldest primary schoo[MASK]s in Miri are St Anthony 's Primary School ( Roman Catholic Mission School ) , Chung Hua Primary School , and the Orang Kaya Mohammad Primary School , which were[MASK]established in the early 1960s . The Bintulu Government Secondary School was built in 1964 . It is now known as SMK Bintulu , the oldest secondary school in the town . Bintulu also h[MASK]s one [MASK]hinese[MASK]independent [MASK]chool , Kai[MASK]Dee Middle School ( 开智中学 ) . The Shell Oil Company e[MASK]tablished the Kidurong International School i[MASK] 1982 to meet th[MASK][MASK]primary education needs of She[MASK]l employees ' children . The scho[MASK]l provides English Nati[MASK]nal Curriculum[MASK]( ENC ) for literacy and num[MASK]racy and Internationa[MASK] Primary Curriculum ( IPC ) for other subjects . 
 UPM Bintulu Sarawak Campus was started as the National Resource Training Centre , Kuching , in 1974 . The oldest campus in Sarawak , it was relocated to Bintulu in 1987[MASK]as a branch campus of the Universiti Pertanian Malaysi[MASK] ( [MASK]PM ) . The campus was closed down in 1992 b[MASK]fore reopening in 2001 as Universiti Putra Malaysia[MASK]( UPM ) . During this period of closure , the[MASK]campus was used as the site for [MASK]aktab Perguru[MASK]n Sains Bintulu ( Bintulu Science Teachers ' Training College ) from 19[MASK]4 to July[MASK]1999 when it was moved to Kota Samarahan as Institut Pendidikan Guru Kampus Tun Abdul Razak ( Tun Abdul Razak Teachers ' Training Inst[MASK]tute Campus ) . The UPM campus is currently located 13 k[MASK] ( 8 mi ) away from the town centre , occupying 715 ha ( 1 @,@ 767 acres ) , which can accommodate up to 2 @,@ 200 students . This branch campus[MASK]currently has only one faculty , the Faculty of Agriculture and Food Sciences , cons[MASK]stin[MASK] of fi[MASK]e academic departments . In 2015 UPM was ra[MASK]ked 41st in the UI @-@ Greenmetric World University [MASK]ankings . SEDAMAI College , established in November 1999 , offers courses[MASK]in business , information technology , lang[MASK]a[MASK]e , and engineering . 
 There is also a technical school located 15 km ( 9 mi ) away from the town , [MASK]ear Tanjung Kidu[MASK]ong , occupying 20 ha ( 49 acres ) of land . The school was built in 1[MASK]8[MASK] with a maximum capacity of 900 students . Among the courses offered are : aut[MASK]motive , mechanical and civ[MASK]l engineering , commerce , and fashion .[MASK]Gulf [MASK]olden International Flying A[MASK]ademy ( GGIFA ) , [MASK]he first and only flying academy in Sarawak , was closed in 2012 due to financial difficul[MASK]ies .

The public libra[MASK]y has t[MASK]ree branches [MASK] at Kidurong , Tatau , and Sebauh .

 = Z[MASK]inski Battalion = 
 
 The Zrinski Bat[MASK]alion ( Croatian : Bojna Zrinski ) was[MASK]a special forces unit of the Croatian National Guard ( Zbor narodne g[MASK]rde – ZNG ) and later of the Croati[MASK]n Army ( Hrvatska vojska – HV ) established[MASK]in Kumrovec on[MASK]18 May 1991 , during the Croatian War of Independence[MASK]. The u[MASK]it drew personnel from the special police forces and a former French[MASK]Foreign Legion troops serving as its c[MASK]re . The ba[MASK]tal[MASK]on was s[MASK][MASK] up and initially commanded by Ante Roso , while Major Miljenko Filipović to[MASK]k over as the commanding officer in Augus[MASK] . 
 The Zrinski Battalion trained volunteer troops in Vukovar in June [MASK]991 before[MASK]it saw action in Hrvatska Kostajnica , the Battle of Gos[MASK]ić and near Sl[MASK]no in 1991 . By the end of 1991 , the unit '[MASK] personnel were tasked with setting up an additional special forces unit of the HV . The next year its elements took part in the Battle of Kupre[MASK] and Opera[MASK]ion Tiger aimed at lifting the Siege[MASK]of Dubrovnik . It also and helped develop and train the Croatian Defence Cou[MASK][MASK]il[MASK]( Hrv[MASK]tsko vijeć[MASK] obrane – HVO ) , setting up a training ca[MASK]p in Tomislavgrad . In 1993 , the battalion took part in Operation Maslenica . In February 1994 , the Zrinski Battalion was amalg[MASK]mated with several other[MASK]HV sp[MASK]cial forces units into the 1st Croatian Guards Brigade ( 1 @.@  hr[MASK]atski gardijski zdrug ) , a component of the 1st Croatian Guards Corps ( 1 @.@  hrvatski gardijski zbor ) . 
 
 = = Background = = 
 
 In 1990 , following the electoral d[MASK]feat of the government of the S[MASK]cialist[MASK]Republic of Croatia , ethnic[MASK]tensions between Croats [MASK]nd Croatian Serbs worsened . The Yugoslav Pe[MASK]ple 's Army ( Jugoslavenska narod[MASK]a armija – JNA ) believed Croatia would use the Croatian Terr[MASK]torial D[MASK]fence Force 's ( Teritorijalna obrana – TO ) equipment to build its own army and confront the[MASK]JNA itself . In order to minimize the expected resis[MASK]ance , the JNA confiscated the TO weapon[MASK] . On 17 August , the tensions e[MASK]calated into an open revolt of the Croatian Serbs[MASK]. 
 In the beginning of 1991 , Croatia had no r[MASK]gular army . I[MASK] an effort to bolster its defence , Croatia doubled the size of it[MASK] police f[MASK]r[MASK]e to about 20 @,@ 000 . The most effective part of the force was the 3 @,[MASK] 000[MASK]@-@ strong special police that were deployed in 12 battalions , adopting military organisation . In addition there were 9 @,@ 000 – 10 @,@ 000 regionally organised reserve police . The rese[MASK]ve[MASK]police were set up in 1[MASK] battalions and 10 companies , but they lacked weapons needed to arm many of the tro[MASK]ps .[MASK]
 Preparations to set up the Croatian National Guard ( Zbor narodne garde – ZNG ) began on[MASK]12 A[MASK]ril 1991 . Establishment of the ZNG as a police force with mi[MASK]it[MASK]ry capabilities was thoug[MASK]t necessary by the Croatian authorities following arme[MASK] clashes in Pakrac and at Plitvice Lakes in[MASK]March and due to the possibility of furth[MASK]r confrontation with the JNA . The ZN[MASK] , formally established on 23 April , [MASK]as tasked with protection of the constitutional ord[MASK]r , maintenance of public order , anti[MASK]@-@ terrorist operations , protection of Croatia 's borders , t[MASK]rritory , coast and territorial waters , as well as[MASK]the protection of high @-@ value structures and high @-@ profile[MASK]persons . 
 
 = = Service = = 
 
 On 18 May 1991 , the Zrinski Batt[MASK]lion was established as a special forces unit of the ZNG . The core of the[MASK]unit consisted of 27 volunteers draw[MASK] from the Kumrovec Special Police Unit ( SPU ) . Initially [MASK] it relied on former French [MASK]oreign Legion troops . The most senior among th[MASK] fo[MASK]mer legionnaires was Ante Roso , previously a Sous @-@ Officier ( non @-@ commissioned officer – NCO ) in the 4th Foreign Regiment . In consequence , Roso was tasked with setting up the unit as i[MASK]s in[MASK]tial comma[MASK]der . Major Miljenko Filip[MASK]vić , likewise a former French Foreign Legion member , was assig[MASK]ed the battalions deputy commander . The unit was based in t[MASK]e village of Ku[MASK]rovec in the region of Hr[MASK]atsko Zagorje , on the groun[MASK]s of[MASK]the former " Josip Broz Tito " political school . The site[MASK], adjacent to [MASK]he border of Slovenia , was sele[MASK]ted to be inaccessible to Yugoslav Air Force raids without violation of Slovene or possibly Austrian airspace . In June 1991 , the Kumrovec SPU was transferred to Sljeme Peak n[MASK]r[MASK]h of Zagreb leaving Kumrovec base to the Zrinski Battalion , as well as the second special forces unit , the Frankopan Battalion . 
 The Z[MASK]inski Battalion was deployed for the first time on 15 June . It was statio[MASK]ed i[MASK] Vukovar , tasked with preparation of city[MASK]defences and or[MASK]anisation of voluntee[MASK] troops . In August , F[MASK]lipović took over command of the battalion f[MASK]om Roso . The same month , the Zrins[MASK]i Battalion was deployed to the Banovina ,[MASK]where it pushed the Croatian Serb forces [MASK]ut of the town of Hrvatska Ko[MASK]tajnica . In September , the battalion was[MASK]deployed t[MASK] Gospić , where it took part in battle to control Gospić against the JNA . Troops assigned to the [MASK]attalion captured Kaniža barracks in [MASK]ospić[MASK]. During combat in Gospić , 30 troo[MASK]s of the Zrinski Battalion[MASK], assisted by Lučko SPU , ca[MASK]tured JNA Major General Trajče Krstevski , along with three armoured personnel carriers ( APCs ) and 32 s[MASK]ldiers . The unit was deployed to Metković on 28 October , tasked with recapturing Slano from the JNA . After the deployment to Gospić , a part of th[MASK] u[MASK]it p[MASK]rsonnel left to Bosnia and Herzegovina anti[MASK]i[MASK]ating further conflict there , while the remainder of the unit[MASK]returned to Kumrovec . The ZNG was renamed the Croatian Army ( Hrvatska vojska – HV[MASK]) on 3 November 1991 . In late 1991 , personnel of [MASK]he Zri[MASK]ski Battalion set up another special [MASK]orces unit of the HV — the Matija Vlačić Batta[MASK]ion based in Opatija . 
 In 1992 , elements of the Zrinski Battalion took[MASK]part i[MASK] the Battle of Kupres , before setting up a train[MASK]ng camp in the town of Tomislavgrad . There the battalion personnel assisted in setting up and trained the Croatian [MASK]efence Council ( Hr[MASK]atsko vijeće obrane – HVO[MASK])[MASK]. Later that[MASK]year , el[MASK]ment[MASK] of the battalion took pa[MASK]t in Operati[MASK]n Tiger — aimed at lifting of the Siege of Dubrovnik . In 1993 , elements of the Zrinski Battalion took part in Operation Maslenica , fighting in the area of Škabrnja . The Central Intelligence Agency[MASK]assessed the Zrinski Battalion as one of the best units of the HV . 
 
 = = Amalga[MASK]ation = = 
 
 On 25 February 199[MASK] , the Zrinsk[MASK] Battalion was amalgamated with parts of other special forces units of the HV : Frankopan Battalion , Ban Jelač[MASK]ć Battalion , Matija Vlačić Battalion , Ferdo Sučić Battalion and pa[MASK]t of 8th Light Assault Brigade forming the 1st Croatian Guards Brigade ( 1 @[MASK]@  hrvatski gardijski zdrug ) , a component of the[MASK]1st Croatian Guards Corps ( 1 @.@  hrvatski gardijski zbor ) , directly subordinated to the Ministry of Defence rather than the General Staff of the Armed Forces of the Republic of Croatia .  = Temple Beth Israel ( Euge[MASK]e , Oregon )[MASK]= 
 
 Temple Beth Israel ( Hebrew : בית ישראל ) is a Reconstructionist synagogue l[MASK]cated at 1175 East 29th Avenue in Eugene , Oregon . Founded in the e[MASK]rly 1930s as a Conservative congregation , Beth Israel [MASK]as for ma[MASK]y decades the o[MASK]ly synagogue in Eugene . 
 The congregation initially worshipped in a converted house on[MASK]West Eighth Street[MASK]. It constructed its first bui[MASK][MASK]ing on Portland Street in 1952 , and occupied its[MASK]current LEED @-@ co[MASK]pliant facilities in 2008 . 
 In the early 1990s conflict between feminist and traditional members led to the latte[MASK] l[MASK]aving Beth Israel , and forming the Orthodox Congregation Ahavas[MASK]Torah . [MASK]eth Israel came under attack from neo @-@ Nazi members of the Volksfront twice , in 1994 and again in 2002 . In [MASK]oth cases the perpetrators were caught and convicted . 
 Services wer[MASK] lay @-@ led for decades . Marcus Simmons was hired as the congregat[MASK]on 's first rabbi in 1959 , but[MASK]left in 1961 . After a gap of two years , L[MASK]uis Neimand b[MASK]came rabbi in 1963 , and served until his death in 1976 . He was followed by Myron Kinberg , who served from 1977 to 1994 , and Kinberg in turn was succeeded by Yitzhak Husbands @-@ Hankin . Maurice Harris joined Husbands @-@ Hankin as associate rabbi in 2003 , and served until 2011 , when he was succeeded by[MASK]Boris Dolin [MASK] As of 2014 , led by Husbands @-@ Hankin an[MASK] Dolin , Beth Israel had approxima[MASK]ely 400 member households , and was the largest synagogue in Eugene . 
 
 [MASK] = Early history = = 
 
 Small numbers of Ger[MASK]an Jews began [MASK]ettling in Eugene in the l[MASK]te 19th century , but most moved on . In the early[MASK]20th century the first Eastern European Jews settled there , and by[MASK]the 1920s Eugene 's Jewish community began gathering prayer quorums for holding Friday n[MASK]ght and Je[MASK]ish holiday services in individuals ' homes . Historian Steven Lowenstein wri[MASK]es that " [MASK] a ] fter H[MASK]men Rubenstein 's death in 1933 , his[MASK]ho[MASK]e at 231 West Eighth Stre[MASK]t was remodeled and named Templ[MASK] Bet[MASK] Israel " . It was a traditional Conservative synagogue , and from that time until the 1990s it was the only synagogue in Eugene . 
 In 1952 , the congregation constructed a one @-@ story synagogue b[MASK]ildin[MASK] on an almost 1 acre ( 0 @.@ 40 [MASK]a ) property at 2550 Portland Stre[MASK]t . Designed by architect and Holocaust @-@ survivor Heinrich Hormuth ( H.H. ) Waechter ,[MASK]the building featured an interior courtyard that provided natural lighting , and " a network of ceiling beams painted with symbo[MASK]s and [MASK]hapes " by Waechter . 
 Temple Beth Israel 's services and religious functions were lay @-@ led for decades . Its first rabbi was Marcus Simmons .[MASK]Originally from[MASK][MASK]ngland , he [MASK]as a gradua[MASK]e[MASK]of University of London and Oxford University[MASK], and was ordained a[MASK] the Hebrew Theol[MASK]gical Seminary . He emigrated to the United States in 1[MASK]57 , and joined Beth Israel in 1959 . The members were not , however[MASK], agreed that a full @-[MASK] time rabbi was required , and in 1961 , he accepted a rabbinical p[MASK]sition in Downey , California . 
 Following a hiatus of two years , Louis Neimand was hired as rab[MASK]i in 1963 [MASK] Born in New York City in 1912 to immigrant parents , he was a [MASK]raduate of Ci[MASK]y University of New York and [MASK]as ordained at the Jewish Institute of New [MASK]ork . He had previously worked[MASK]for the United Jewish Appeal , a[MASK]d from 1959 to 1963 was the first Hil[MASK]el rabbi at Syracuse University . There was some conc[MASK]rn a[MASK]out Neimand 's hiring[MASK], as he h[MASK]d a police record as a result of his involvement in freedom marches in the African [MASK]-@ American Civil Rights Movement ( 1955 – 1968 ) . He served until his death in 1976 . 
 
 = = Kinberg era = = 
 
 Myron Kinberg was hired as rabbi in 1977 . Ordained in Reform Judaism ,[MASK]he had previously served as a rabbi in Topeka , Kansas for two years , [MASK]hen lived in Israel for two years , before coming to Eugene . Kinberg [MASK]as known for his support for minority rights and gay right[MASK] , anti @-@ nuclear and anti @-@ war activism , support of r[MASK]conciliation b[MASK]tween Israel and the Palestinians , and outreach to non @-@ observant members of Eugene 's Jewish community . 
 Kinberg attempted to revive the Biblical concept of the " ger toshav " in his approac[MASK] to intermarriage . He was willing to officiate at an intermarriage if th[MASK] non @-@ Jewish partner , after discussions wi[MASK]h the rabbi , agree[MASK] of his or her own free will to fulfi[MASK]l a set of commitments , including " a commitment to a Jewish home life , participation in Jewish life and tradition , [MASK]nd raising future childr[MASK]n as Jews " . The non @-@ Jewish partner making this commitment became [MASK] " ger tos[MASK]av " , or " non @-@ Jewish member of the Jewish people " . 
 Kinberg 's wife Alice was a strong feminist , and dur[MASK]ng the 1980s he and his wife supported a number of changes to the liturgy and ritual . These included allowing women[MASK]to read from the [MASK]orah and lead the prayers , and changing prayers to be more gender inclusive - fo[MASK] example , using gender @-@ neutral terms and pronouns for God , and adding referenc[MASK]s to the Biblical matriarchs in prayers like the Amidah , which tr[MASK]ditionally only mentioned the Biblical patriarchs . While most congregation[MASK]members approved of these changes , [MASK] mi[MASK]ority resisted [MASK]hem . 
 
 = = = Schism = = = 
 
[MASK]By the early 1990s serious divisions developed among the members of the congregation over [MASK] numbe[MASK] of issues , including personal antagonisms , the rabbi 's activism and " advocacy of ' ultra @-@ liberal[MASK]' causes " [MASK] political differences over t[MASK]e Israeli – Palestin[MASK]an conflict , and 
 a myriad of additional Jewish cultural / rel[MASK]gious issues[MASK], such as the acceptance of intermarried couples , adherence to kosher dietary [MASK]aws , the use of modern langu[MASK]ge and music during worship services , rewriting of certain praye[MASK]s such as the Aleynu to make them less ethnocentric , and so on . 
 However , the[MASK]biggest source of division , which underlay all others , w[MASK]s " the roles and rights of men and women in the synagogue . " 
 In the early 1990s a group of newly observa[MASK]t members began holding more trad[MASK]tional services in a back room [MASK]f the sy[MASK]agogue , complete [MASK]ith a mechitza , a partition separa[MASK]ing men and wom[MASK]n . T[MASK]e " mo[MASK]e feminist @-@ minded " members strongly o[MASK]jected to hav[MASK]ng a mechitza[MASK]anywhere in the Temple Beth Israel building , even if it were not in the services they atte[MASK]ded . The latter group eventual[MASK]y circulated a petition which stated that either the mec[MASK]itz[MASK] would have to be taken down , or those members who wanted it would have to leave . Kinberg also signed the petition . Faced with this opposition , in 1992 the Orthodox members left ,[MASK]renting[MASK]new premises and hiring the[MASK]r own rabbi , creating Eugene 's second synagogue , or[MASK]ginally called " The Halachic Minyan " , and in 1[MASK]98 renamed " Congregation Ahavas Torah "[MASK]. 
 Kinberg held himself re[MASK]ponsible , and th[MASK][MASK]schism led to his " reasse[MASK]sment of the needs of Temple Beth Israel and his role as [MASK] rabbi " . As a result ,[MASK]he left Beth Israel in 1994 to lead a syn[MASK]gogue on Long Island . During his tenure at Beth Israel , membership rose from 118 to 350 families . Kinberg died two y[MASK]ars later at age 51 . 
 
 = = Husbands @-@[MASK]Han[MASK]in era[MASK]= = 
 
 Yitzhak Husb[MASK]nds @-@ Han[MASK]in succeeded Kinberg in[MASK]1995 . Husbands @-@ Hankin began [MASK]is involvement at Te[MASK]ple Beth Israel first as a congregant , then as cantor , and then as an assistant rabbi . He was active in form[MASK]ng the Jewish Renewal movement , and was ordained by its leader Zalman Schachter @-[MASK] Shalomi . 
 The congrega[MASK]ion dec[MASK]ded to leave the Conservative movement in 1995 , and for a year had n[MASK] affiliation . In late 1996 , after considering both Reform and Reconstructionist as alternatives [MASK] the congregation affiliated with the Recon[MASK]tructionist movement . By 1999 ,[MASK][MASK]embership had grown to around 370[MASK]families . 
 Husbands @-@ Hankin was instrumental in developing the concept of " Ethical Kashrut " , the idea that one sh[MASK]uld onl[MASK] purchase goods that are produced in an ethical way . His essay , " Ethical Kashrut , " was [MASK]elected for publication in Arthur Kurzweil 's B[MASK]st Jewish Writing 2003 . A singer , cello and guitar player , he c[MASK]mposes and performs Jewish music . 
 Husbands @-@ Hankin has had four assistant or associate[MASK]rab[MASK]is working with him . Shoshana Spergel joined Temple Beth Israel in 1998 as interim rabbi when Husb[MASK]nds @-@ Hankins went[MASK]on a sabbatical ; Jonathan Seidel was assistant rabbi from 2001 [MASK]o 2003 . Mau[MASK]ice H[MASK]rris , a 2003 graduate of the Reconstructionist Ra[MASK]binical College , joined as assistant rabbi in[MASK][MASK]003 . He is one of the[MASK]signators of The Open [MASK]etter Concerning Religion and Science From American Rabbis , part of the Clerg[MASK] Letter Project which " encourages an[MASK] embraces the te[MASK]ching of evolution in schoo[MASK]s " . In 2011 , Boris Dolin joined the congr[MASK]ga[MASK]ion as its newest associate rabbi .

 = = = East 29th Avenue buil[MASK]ing = = = 
 
[MASK]Originally sized for 75 families , Temple Beth Israel 's Portland Street building ha[MASK] been renovated and enlarged over the years to 7 @,@ 500 sq[MASK]are fee[MASK][MASK]( 700 m2 ) to accommodate 250 families and 150 students . Despite these additions and the loss of members to Congregation Ahavas Torah , the synagogue was not large enough , particularly during the High Holidays , when extra space had to b[MASK] rented . In 1997 the congregation purchased the propert[MASK] of the University Street Christian Church f[MASK]r $ 500 @,@ 000 ( today $ 740 @,@ 000 ) , and began planning for a new facility . The member[MASK] considered renovatin[MASK] the existing building on the property , but felt a new [MASK]uilding would better suit their re[MASK]uirements , and razed the church . 
[MASK]In 2003 the congregation got a permit to begin construction of a new facility on the now @-@ vacant 1 @.@ [MASK]7 @-@ acre ( 0 @.@ 55 ha ) plot of land at the northwest corner of East 29th Avenue and University Street . An initial capital campaign raised more than $ 1 @.@ 8 million , which fully paid for the land , and by August 2007 an additional $ 1 @.@ 7 million had been rais[MASK]d towards anticipated overall project costs of $ 5 million . 
 The environmentally sensi[MASK]ive building was designed by Mel Solomon and Associates of Kansas City and local company TBG Architects & Planners , and built by McKenzie Commercial Const[MASK]uction of Eugene . The build[MASK]ng used " energy eff[MASK]cient heating , ve[MASK]tilation and lighting " : specific design issues with the building 's energy efficiency included the fact that the largest room in the building ,[MASK]the sanctuary , was also the least @-@ used , and , in accord with Je[MASK]ish tradition , had to face east ( towards Jeru[MASK]alem ) . 
 On June 8 , 2008 the congregation dedicated its new building at 1175 East 29th Avenue . At approximately 25 @,@ [MASK]00 squar[MASK] feet ( 2 @,@ 300 m2 ) , the facility included a sanctuary , commercial kitchen , banquet facilities , and classrooms ,[MASK]and housed the synagogue , the Lane County Jewish Federation , and the local Jewish Family Service . The project ended[MASK]up costing[MASK]$ 6 million , o[MASK] which $ 4 million had been raised . 
 Made of concrete , steel[MASK], a[MASK]d wood , the building achieved Leadership in Energy and Environ[MASK]ental Design compliance " through the integration of stormwater manag[MASK]ment strategies , high efficiency irrigation , the use of recycled and / or recyclable materials , and drought tolerant plantings . " Completely[MASK]recyclable materials used [MASK]n the structure included carpeting [MASK]nd [MASK]ood beams .
