 = New [MASK]ork State Route 93 = 
 
 New York State Route 93 ( NY 93 ) is a 43 @.@ 08 [MASK]-@ mile ( 69 @.@ 33[MASK]km ) state highway in wester[MASK] New York in the United States . The r[MASK]ute begins at an intersection [MASK]ith [MASK]Y 18F in the village of Youngstown and ru[MASK]s in a general northwest – southeast direction across Niagara and Erie counties to its east e[MASK]d at an intersection with NY 5 in the to[MASK]n of Newstead , just s[MASK]uth of the village of Akron . NY 93 serves as a con[MASK]ector between several major arterials , including NY 104 in Cam[MASK]ri[MASK] , NY 31 just west of the city of Lockport , a[MASK]d NY 78 south of the city . 
 The route was assigned as part of the 1930 renumbering of state highways in New York . Although it began in Young[MASK]town and ended in Newstea[MASK] as it does [MASK]o[MASK]ay , the initial routing of NY 93 deviated from the modern path in the vicinity [MASK]f the city of Lockport . From Cambria to Lockport 's eastern suburbs , the highway originally used NY 425 , Lower Mountain[MASK]Ro[MASK]d , Akron Roa[MASK] , and a series of streets in[MASK]Lockport . NY 93[MASK]was moved onto NY 104 and Junction Road in Cambria in the 1940s , and altered to bypass Lockport to the south on a new highway and Robinson and Dysinge[MASK] roads in 1991 . In 2006 , NY 93 was realigned west of Lockport to continue south on J[MASK]nction Road to NY 31 . The change removed NY [MASK]3 from Upper Mountain Road , a county @-@ owned highway that had been pa[MASK]t of the route since the 1930s .

Past t[MASK]e junctio[MASK] , the hi[MASK]hway[MASK]reverts to a two @-@ lane road and ch[MASK]nge[MASK] names to Youngstown – Lockport Road as it runs across the town of Porter . The residential surro[MASK]ndings c[MASK]ntinue to the hamlet of Towers Corners , where NY 93 connects to NY 18 ( Cree[MASK] Road ) . 
 After NY 18 , NY 93 curves to the southeast , serving another residential stretch ahead of a junction with You[MASK]gstown – Wilson Road ( CR 36 ) on the eastern edge of Towers Corners . After this intersection , the homes give [MASK]ay[MASK]to farms as the road heads into rura[MASK] areas of the town . Another southeastward stretch brings the route across Twelvemile Creek and into the hamlet of Ransomville , where NY 93[MASK]becomes the community 's main street . Through Ransomv[MASK]lle , NY 93 retains the Youngstown – Lockport Road name , intersectin[MASK] with Ransomville Road ( C[MASK] 17 ) in the hamlet 's business district . 
 Just outside Ransomville , NY 93 lea[MASK]es the town of Porter for the town of Wilson . NY 93 becomes North Ridge Road at the town line , and it soon enters the hamlet of[MASK]No[MASK]th Ridge [MASK] a community built up around the[MASK]route 's intersection with NY 425 ( Cambria – Wilson Road ) .[MASK]The hamlet 's residential surroundings continue to the adjacent community of Molyneaux Corners , where NY 93 becomes concurrent wi[MASK]h NY 104 ( Ridge Road ) . NY 93 and NY 104 proceed northeast across lightly populated areas for 2 m[MASK]les ( 3 @.@ 2 km[MASK]) [MASK]o the hamlet of Warren Corners , at which point NY 93 splits from NY 104 and heads southward along Town Line Road . It immediately intersects with Stone Road ( CR 19 ) before leaving the hamlet .

 = = History[MASK]= = 
 
 
 = = = Designation and early[MASK]c[MASK]anges[MASK]= = = 
 
 NY 93 was established as part of the 1930 renumbering of state highways in New York , connecting the cities and villages of Youngstown , Lockport , and Akron . While [MASK]he termini of NY 93 have remained the same to this day , several portions of the route have been realigned since that time . When NY 93 was first assigned , it turned sou[MASK]h at the hamlet of North Ridge and overlapped with NY 425 along Cambria – Wilson Road to L[MASK]wer Mountain Road , then part of NY 3 . NY 42[MASK] went west from this junction while NY 93 headed eastward , following N[MASK] 3 along Lower Mountain , [MASK]othic Hill , Upper Mounta[MASK]n , and Saunders Settlement roads to the city of Lockport . At Locust Street ,[MASK][MASK]Y 93 left NY 3 and exited the city along Locust , High , and Akron streets and Akron Road . It met its current alignment southeast of the city in Royalt[MASK]n . 
 NY 3 was [MASK]ealigned c . 1932 to follow Saunders Settlemen[MASK] Road between Shawnee Roa[MASK] ( NY 425 ) and Upper Mountain Road . The former routing of NY 3 along Shawnee , Lower Mountain [MASK] Gothic Hill , and Upper Mountain roads was redesignated as NY 3A even th[MASK]ugh all of NY 3 's fo[MASK]mer routing was already part of either NY 425 or NY 93 . The NY 3A designation was eliminated c . 1935 when NY 3 was truncated eastward to a new we[MASK]tern terminus in central New York . In the early 1940s , NY 93 was altered to follow North Ridge Road , U.S. Route 104 ( now NY 104 ) , and Junction Road between North Ridge and Lower Mountain Road . 
 Around the same time th[MASK]t NY 93 was rerouted , NY 270 was also extended northward along Junction Ro[MASK]d from NY 3[MASK] [MASK]o US 104 . As a result , NY 93 overlapped NY 270 between Lower Mountain Road and US 104 . The overlap with NY 270 remain[MASK]d in place until c . 1963 when [MASK]Y 270 was trunc[MASK]ted s[MASK]uthward to the intersection of Lower Mountain and Junction roads . NY 93 was realigned in the late 1970s to bypass Lower Mountain and Gothic Hill Roads on Junction and Upper Mountain[MASK]roads , replacing NY 270 along Junction Road . The Lower Mountain Road portion of NY 93 's for[MASK]er routing is [MASK]ow maintained by Niagara C[MASK]unty as County Route 902 ( CR 902 ) . 
 
[MASK]= = = Lockport realignments = = = 
 [MASK] The Lockport Bypass , a highway bypassing dow[MASK]town Lockport to the sout[MASK]west , was opened to [MASK]raffic on July 26 , 1991 . The highway cost $ 7 @.@ 7 million ( equivalent to $ 13 @.@ 4 million in 2016 ) to construct and extended from the junction o[MASK] NY 31 and NY 93 west of the city to Robinson Road south of downtown . NY 93 was realigned to follow [MASK]he new bypass south to Robinson Road , where it turned east and followed Robinson Road ( CR 12[MASK] ) [MASK]nd Dysinge[MASK] Road ( CR 133 ) to Akron Road in Royalton . The po[MASK]tion of Ak[MASK]on Road ( NY 93 's former routing ) east of the Lockport city limits became NY 954M , an unsi[MASK]ned reference rout[MASK] . 
 Ownership and maintenance of Robinson Road fr[MASK]m the bypass to NY 78 was transferred from Niagara County to the state of New York on September 1 , 1990 , [MASK]s part of a highway maintenan[MASK]e swap be[MASK]ween the tw[MASK] levels of government . The portion of NY 93 between NY 78 and [MASK][MASK]ron Road became state @-@ maintained on October 1 , 19[MASK]8 , as part of another swap that al[MASK]o transferred ownership and maintenance of Akron Road to Niagara County . Akron Road is now CR 142[MASK]. 
 On November 1 , 2005 , the Nia[MASK][MASK]ra County Legislature voted on a measure to al[MASK]ow the county to ask the New York State Depa[MASK]tment of Transportation ( NYSDOT ) to remove the NY 93 designation from Upper Mountain Road , a county @-@ maintained highway , and reassign it to Junction Road[MASK]( NY 270 ) a[MASK]d Saunders Settlement Road ( NY 31 ) . The[MASK]impetus for the change came from a resident of Upper Mountain Road , who dem[MASK]nded that trucks should be removed from the roadway . This part of the agenda was p[MASK]ssed . NYSDOT obli[MASK]ed t[MASK] the request in 2006 , rerouting NY 93 as proposed and truncating NY 270 southward[MASK]to NY 31 .

 = Operation USA = 
 
 Operation USA ( OpUSA , Operation California , or OpCal ) is a non profit humanitarian organization dedicated to helping communities alleviate the effects of disaster , disease , a[MASK]d endemic poverty throughout the world by providing privately funded relief , reconstruction , hu[MASK]anitarian aid and developm[MASK]nt aid . It is exclusively privately funded , receiving no assistance from the United States Federal Government .[MASK]OPUSA had a revenue of ove[MASK] $[MASK]22 million in fiscal year 2012 and has shipped over $ 425 million worth of " high @-@ priority medical , nutritional and shelter supplies " since its in[MASK]eption , including shipments t[MASK] Haiti , Japan , Chile , Keny[MASK] and Pakistan in 2011 and 2011 . 
 
 = = Awards a[MASK]d affiliations = = 
 
 Operation USA was part of the[MASK]International Campaign to Ban Landmines [MASK]n 1997 when it won the Nobel Peace Prize . Opera[MASK]io[MASK] California was also the winner of the 1983 President 's Volunteer Action Award . Operation USA has been named one of Ame[MASK]ica 's Best 100 Charities by Worth Magazine and , in October 2008 , was named the top @-@ rated " exclusively privately funded charity in the U.S. " by Charity Navigator . Operation USA collaborated with NASA 's Jet Propulsion Laboratory and the US National Laboratories at Lawrence Livermore and Los Al[MASK]mos to develop new approaches to land mine detection , is a membe[MASK] of InterAction , and is an AlertNet news partner . In[MASK]2014 Operation US[MASK] 's CEO Richard M. Walden received the Honeywe[MASK]l Hometown Hero Award from the Honeywell Corp. 
 
 = = History = = 
 
 Operati[MASK]n California began in 1979 as " a relief organization created to provide aid to Vietnamese Boat People and Cambodian refugees " , founded by Richard Walden ( still active as President & C[MASK]O ) and Llewellyn Werner ( w[MASK]o left in early 1980 ) . The org[MASK]nization flew " the first international relief airlift to Cambodia since 1975 " , delivering m[MASK]dicine to Ph[MASK]om @-@ Penh . Operation California had airlifted more than $ 3 million worth of aid by October 1979 . 
 Since then , Op[MASK]ration USA has become a highly acclaimed aid organization that is involved in helping people in different ways around the world . In 1982 , Operation California sent " the first private airlift from the U.S. to Poland " , delivering 200 @,@ 0[MASK]0 lbs. of medical supplies and medicine ; that year Operation California also airlifted medical supplies t[MASK] Lebanon . In 1983 , Operation Califo[MASK]nia delivered aid to the chi[MASK]dren of Vietnam and Cambodia . Operation[MASK]Calif[MASK]rnia provid[MASK]d aid to the earthquake victims in Mexico City in 1985 , as well as working in cooperation with the Unitarian Univers[MASK]list Se[MASK]vice Committee and Oxf[MASK]m America , to deliver $ 250 @,@ 000 worth of medical aid to Nicara[MASK]ua . [MASK]n 1986 Operation California , in conjunction with Medical Aid to El Salvador , sent " [ t ] wo cargo planes carrying $ 500 @,@ 000 worth of relief su[MASK]plies to earthquake @-@ stricken El Salvador " . [MASK] In 1988 , Operation California began using the name Operation USA because it better described the effort and intent of the organization to represent the entire American people . [MASK]n 1989 Operation USA facilitated operations on children in Vietnam who had cle[MASK]t palates by a Los Angeles @-@ based plastic surgeon , Dr Stanley Frileck .[MASK]Medical aid effort was delivered to Mexico in 1990 , by OP[MASK]SA in conjunction with USSR rel[MASK]ef workers[MASK]. [MASK]n 1991 OPUSA delivered aid to Bangladesh . OpUSA delivered aid [MASK]o war [MASK]orn Somali 's in 1993 . In 1994 OpUSA p[MASK]ovided earthquake relief . In 1995 the organizati[MASK]n provided aid to Hurric[MASK]ne Mitch survivors in Honduras and Nicaragua . In 1999 OpUSA supplied ai[MASK] to storm victims in Mexico . In 2003 OpUSA delivered aid to Iraq [MASK]ar victims in the Persian Gulf . The tsunami victims in Sri Lanka and Indonesia were aided by OpUSA in 2004 , [MASK]s well as the Mexico City Flood victims . 
 In 2008 , OpUSA has delivered aid to Myanmar cyclone victims as well as Chinese earthquake[MASK]victims and flo[MASK]d victims in the Midwest , U[MASK]A . 
 In 2015 , OpUsa partners with UniversalGiving to raise fund for its project , which is to deliver recovery aid to Nepal Earthquake victims .

 = Typhoon Krosa ( 2013 ) = 
 
 Typhoon Krosa , known in the Philippines as T[MASK]phoon Vinta , was a typhoon that made landfall in the northern Ph[MASK]lippines in late October 2013 . Forming on[MASK]Octobe[MASK] 27 near Guam , the storm slowly intensified while moving westward . Krosa developed an eye and became a typhoon before striking Luzon on October 31 . The storm weakened over land[MASK], but re @-@ intensified over the South China Sea , reaching peak winds of 150 km / h ( 90 mph ) on November 2 off[MASK]the southeast coast of China . Typhoon Krosa stalled and encountered u[MASK]favorable conditions , resulting in[MASK]quick weakening . By Novemb[MASK]r 3 , it had w[MASK]akened to tropic[MASK]l storm status , and w[MASK]s no longer being warned on by the next day . In northern Luzon , Krosa damag[MASK]d 32 @,@ 000 houses , including 3 @,@ 000 that were destroyed , and caused four fatalities . [MASK]igh winds and rainfall left P277 million ( PHP , $ 6 @.@[MASK]4 million USD ) in damage . 
 
 = = Meteorologi[MASK]al history[MASK]= = 
 
 On Oct[MASK]ber 27 , an a[MASK]ea of convection with a broad circulation persisted s[MASK]utheast of Guam , and slowly consolidated due to moderate wind shear and wester[MASK]y outflow . That day , the Japan Meteorologic[MASK]l Agency ( JMA ) classified the system as[MASK]a tropical depression about [MASK]80 km ( 235 mi ) to the southe[MASK]st of Hagåtña , Guam . At 2100 UTC [MASK][MASK] October 28 , [MASK]he Philippine Atmospheric , Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration ( PAGASA ) began is[MASK]uing advisories on the depression , giv[MASK]ng it the local name Vinta . The next day , [MASK][MASK]e JMA upgrad[MASK]d the depression to Tropical Storm Krosa ( 1329 ) ,[MASK]and [MASK]he Joint Typhoon Warning Center ( J[MASK]WC ) also classified it as [MASK]ropical D[MASK]pression 29W . By that time , the storm was movi[MASK]g steadily westward due to the subtropical ridge to the north . With the warm waters of the Philippine Sea , lessening wind shear , and improving outflow , Krosa gradually strengthened , and the JTWC also upgraded Krosa to tropical storm s[MASK]atus [MASK]n October 30 after an eye feature developed . 
 While approaching northern Luzon on October 29 , Krosa quickly intensified as the initial e[MASK]e feature organized into a well @-@ defined[MASK]eye . Late on October 30 , the JTWC upgraded Krosa to typhoon status , and the next day , both PAGASA and JMA followed suit[MASK]. On October 31 , Krosa made [MASK]andfall in northeastern Luzon near Cagayan , and developed a symmetric eyewall while initially m[MASK]ving over land . Land interacti[MASK]n weakened the eye by[MASK]the time Krosa emerged into the South China Sea late on October 31 . The next day , PAGASA discontinued advisories after the typhoon exited the[MASK]region [MASK] C[MASK]nvection rebuilt a[MASK][MASK]und the center , with[MASK]continued favorable[MASK]conditions allowing for restrengthening . 
 Late on November 1 , a large eye redevel[MASK]ped , and the JTWC estimat[MASK]d Krosa attained peak 1 minute sustained winds of 185 km / h ( 115 mph ) . Early the next day , the JMA also estimate[MASK] the typhoon reached peak 10 [MASK]inute winds of 140 km / h ( 85 mph )[MASK]. Later , increasi[MASK]g wind shear caused the eye to deteriorate , and Kros[MASK] began slowing ab[MASK]ut 260 km ( 160 mi ) east @-@ southeast of Hong Kong after r[MASK]aching the [MASK]estern edge of the subtropical ridge . After remaining nearly stationary , Krosa began moving steadily to the west @-@ southwest due to a new ridge . The convection continued to w[MASK]aken due to conti[MASK]ued shear and cooler waters from upwelling , and Krosa deteriorated to tropical storm status on Novem[MASK]er 3 . The next day , the JTWC issued its final advisory aft[MASK]r the circulation became exposed from the convection . Also on November 4 , the JMA downgraded Krosa to tropical depression status off the northeast Vi[MASK]tnam co[MASK]st . The[MASK]system dissipated at 0000 UTC on November 5 . 
 
 = = Prep[MASK]rations and im[MASK]act = = 
 
 Before Krosa struck the [MASK]hilippines , PAGASA[MASK]issued a number 3 warning signal [MASK]or portions of northern Luzon , where winds were expected to reach over 100 km / h ( 60 mph ) . The agency noted for the potential for flooding and l[MASK]ndslides . High winds knocked down t[MASK]ees across Luzon , and left about 80 % of Cagayan province witho[MASK]t[MASK]power , as well as some areas without internet [MASK]r[MASK]cellphone service . Portions of the Pan[MASK]@-@ Philippine Highway were blocked , and [MASK]n La[MASK] @-@ Lo , Cagayan , a ca[MASK] crashed into a gasoline truck due to power outages . Agriculture damage was estimated at P273 million ( PHP , $ 6 @.@ 3 million USD ) , occurring just before the start of the harvest . Across the island , the typhoon damaged 32 @,@ 745 houses , including 3 @,@ 837 that were destroyed , forcing 65 @,@ 648 people to evacua[MASK]e to storm shelters . Overall , Krosa killed four people in the Philippines , and left P273 million ( PH[MASK] , $ 6 @.@ 4 million U[MASK]D ) in damage . After the storm , workers quickly restored power lines , whi[MASK]e the governme[MASK]t[MASK]provided monetary assistance to storm @-@ ravaged families , after Cagayan was declared a state of calamity . Members of the Philippine military and Department of Public Works and Highways worked to clean [MASK]p following the storm . 
 Th[MASK] China National Meteorological Centr[MASK][MASK]issued a " yellow alert " , the second @-@ lowest of t[MASK]e four level warning system , for Hainan due to the threat of the storm . The agency recommended boats to return to port . Agencies in Vietnam[MASK]also warned for the potential of heavy rainfall due to the di[MASK]sipating Tropical Depres[MASK]ion Krosa , and [MASK]elea[MASK]ed water from three dams to prevent overflow .

 [MASK]irby 's Block [MASK]all is a 1995 action video game , a spin @-@ off from the Kirby series for the Game Boy portable console .  = Commonwealth War Graves Commission = 
 
 The C[MASK]mmonwealth War G[MASK]aves Commission ( [MASK]WGC ) is an intergovernmental organisation of six in[MASK]ependent member states whose principal function is to mark , record and maintain the graves a[MASK]d places of commemoration of Commonwealth of Nations military service members who died in the two World Wars . The Commission is also responsible for [MASK]ommemorating Commonwealth civilians who died as a result of enemy action during World War II . The Commission was fo[MASK]nded by Fabian Ware and constituted through Royal Char[MASK]er [MASK]n 1917 na[MASK]ed the Imperi[MASK]l Wa[MASK] Graves Commission [MASK] The change [MASK]o the present name to[MASK]k place [MASK]n 1960 . 
 The Commission , as part of its mandate , is responsible for commemor[MASK]ting all Commonwealth war dead individually and e[MASK]ually . To this end , th[MASK] war dead are commemorated by name[MASK]on a headstone , at an identified site of a burial , or on a[MASK]memorial . War dead [MASK]re commemorated uniformly and equally , irrespective of military or civil rank , race or [MASK]reed . 
 The Commission is currently responsible fo[MASK] the con[MASK]inued commemoration o[MASK] 1 @.@ 7 million deceased Commonwealth[MASK]military service members in 153 countries [MASK] Since its in[MASK]eption , the Comm[MASK]ssion has constructed approximately 2 @,@ 500 war cemeteries and numerous memorials . The Commission is currently responsible for the care of war dead at over 23 @,@ 000 separate burial sites and the maintenance of more than 200 memorials worldwide[MASK]. In addition to commemorating Commonwealth military service members , the Commis[MASK]ion mai[MASK]tains , under arrangement with applicable governments , o[MASK]er 40 @,@ 000 non @-[MASK] Commonwealth war graves and over 25 @,@ 000 non @-@ war military and c[MASK]vilian graves . The Commiss[MASK]on operates through the continued financial support of the member states : United Kingdom , Canada , Au[MASK]tralia , New Zealand , India and Sou[MASK]h Africa . The current President of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission is Prince Edward , Duke of Kent . 
 
 = = History = = 
 
 
 = = = World War I[MASK]= = = 
 
 On the outbreak of World War I in 1914 , Fabian Ware , a director of the Rio Tinto Company , found that at 45 years old he was too old to join the British A[MASK]my . He[MASK]used the influence of Rio Tinto chairman [MASK] Viscount Milner , to become the commander of a mobile u[MASK]it of the British Red[MASK]Cross . He arrive[MASK] in France in Septem[MASK]er 1914 and whilst th[MASK]re was struck by the lack of any official mechanism for documentin[MASK] or marking the location of graves of those who had been killed and f[MASK]lt compelled to create an or[MASK]anisation wi[MASK]hin the Red Cross for this purpose . In March 1915 , with the support of Nevi[MASK] Macready , Adjutant @-@ General of th[MASK] Bri[MASK]ish Exp[MASK]ditionary Forc[MASK] , Ware 's work was given official recognit[MASK]on and support by the Imperial War Office and the unit was transferred to[MASK]the British Army as the Graves[MASK]Registration Commission . The new Graves Registration Commission had [MASK]ver 31 @,@ 000 graves of British and Imperial soldiers registered by October 1915 [MASK]nd 50 @,@ 000 registered by May 1916 [MASK] 
 When municipal graveyards began to overfill Ware bega[MASK] negoti[MASK][MASK]ions with various local au[MASK]h[MASK]rities [MASK]o acquire land fo[MASK] [MASK]urther cemeteries . [MASK]are began with an agreement with France to build joint British and French cemeteries under the understanding that these would be maintained by the French government . Ware event[MASK]ally concluded that it was not prudent to leave the maintenance responsibilities solely to the French gov[MASK]rnment and subsequently arranged for France to purchas[MASK] the land , gra[MASK]t it in perpetuity , and leave the management and main[MASK]enance responsibilities to the British . The French government agreed under the condition that cemeteries respected c[MASK]rtain dimensions , were accessib[MASK]e by public road , were in the vicinity of medical aid station[MASK] and were no[MASK] too close to towns or villages . Similar negotiations were sta[MASK]ted with the Belgian go[MASK]e[MASK]nment . 
 As [MASK]eports of the grave registration work became public , the Comm[MASK]s[MASK]ion began to receive letters of enquiry and requests for photograp[MASK]s of grav[MASK]s from relatives of deceased soldie[MASK]s . By 1917 , 17[MASK]@,@ [MASK]00 photographs had been dispatched to relatives . In March 1915 , the Commission , with [MASK]he support of the Red Cross , began to dispatch photographic prints and cemetery location informatio[MASK] in answer to the requests . The Graves Registration Commission became the D[MASK]rectorate of Graves[MASK]Reg[MASK]s[MASK]ration and Enquiries in the spring of 1916 [MASK]n recognition of the fact that the scope of work began to extend beyond simpl[MASK] grave reg[MASK]stration and bega[MASK] to include responding to enquiries from relatives of those kille[MASK] . The [MASK]irectorate 's work was also extended beyo[MASK]d the Western Fro[MASK]t and into othe[MASK] theatres of war , with units deployed in Greece , Egypt and Mesopotamia . 
 
 = = = F[MASK]rmal establishment = = = 
 
 As the war continued , Ware and others became concerned about the fate of the graves in the post @-@ wa[MASK] period . Following a suggestion by the British Army , the National Committee for the Care of Soldiers ' Graves was appointed b[MASK] the British government in January 1916 , with Edward , Prince of Wales agreeing to serve as [MASK]resid[MASK]nt . The National Committee f[MASK]r[MASK]the Care of Soldiers ' Graves was created with the intention of taking over[MASK]the work of the Directorate of Graves Registration and Enquiries after the war . The government felt that it was more appropriate to[MASK]entrust the work to a specially appointed body ra[MASK]h[MASK]r than to any existing [MASK]overnment department . By early 1917 a number of members of the committee believed a [MASK]orma[MASK] imperial organisation would be needed to care for the graves . With the help of Edward , Prince of Wales ,[MASK]Ware submitted a [MASK]emorandum to the Im[MASK]erial War Conferen[MASK]e in 1917 suggesting that an imperial organisation be constituted . The suggestion was accepted and on 21 May 1917 the [MASK]mpe[MASK]ial War Graves Commission was established by Royal Charter , with the Prince of Wales servi[MASK]g as pr[MASK]sident , Secretary of State for[MASK]War Lord [MASK]erby as chairman and Ware as vice @-@ chairman . The Commission 's undertakings began in earnest at the en[MASK] of the F[MASK]rst World War . Once land for cemeteries and memo[MASK]ials had been guaranteed , the enormous task of recording the details of the de[MASK]d could begin . By 1918 , some 587 @,@[MASK]000 graves had been id[MASK]ntifi[MASK][MASK] and a further 559 @,@ 000 cas[MASK]alties were registered as having no known [MASK]rave . 
 The scale ,[MASK]and associated high[MASK]number of casualties , of the war prod[MASK]ced an entirely new attitu[MASK]e towards the commemoration of war dead . Previou[MASK] to World War I , indiv[MASK]dual commemoration of war dead was often on an ad hoc basis and was almost exclusively limited to [MASK]ommissioned officers [MASK] [MASK]owever , the war required mobilisation of [MASK] significant percentage of the population , either as volunteers or[MASK]through conscription . An expectatio[MASK] had consequently arisen that [MASK]ndividual sol[MASK]iers would expect to be commemora[MASK]ed , even if they were low @-@ ranking members of the military . A committee under Frederic Kenyon [MASK] Director of t[MASK]e British Museum , presented a report to the Commission in November [MASK]91[MASK] detailing how it e[MASK]visioned the development of the cemeteries . Two key [MASK]lements of t[MASK]is report were that bodies sh[MASK]uld not be repatriated and that uniform memorials should be used to avoid class distinctions . Beyond the logistical nightmare of re[MASK]urning home so many co[MASK]pses , it was felt that repatriation would confl[MASK]ct with the feeling o[MASK] brotherhood that had developed[MASK]between serving ranks [MASK] 
 An article in The Times on 17 February 1919 by Rud[MASK]ard Kipling carr[MASK]ed the Commission 's pr[MASK]posal to a wider audience and described what the graves [MASK]ould look like . The article entitled War[MASK]Graves : Work of Imperial Commission : Mr. Kipling 's Survey was quickly republished as an illustrated booklet , Graves of the Fallen . The illustrated booklet was intended to soften the impact[MASK]of Kenyon 's report as[MASK]it included illustrations of cemeteries with mature trees and shrubs ; contrasting[MASK]the bleak landscapes depicted in published battlefield photos . There was an immediate public outcry following the publication of the reports , particularly with regards to the decision to not repatriate the bodies of the dead . The reports generated considerable discussion in the press which ultimately led to a heated debate in Parliament on 4 May[MASK]1920 . Sir James Remnant start[MASK]d the debate , followed by speeche[MASK] by William Burdett @-@ Coutts i[MASK] favou[MASK] of the Commission 's principles and Robert Cecil speaking for [MASK]ho[MASK]e desiring repatriation and opposing uniformity of grave markers . Winston Churchill closed the debate and asked that the issue not proceed to a vote . Remnant[MASK]withdrew his motion , allowing the Commission t[MASK] carry [MASK][MASK]t its work assured of support for its principles . 
 
 = = = First cemeteries and memorials to the missing = =[MASK]= 
 
 Three of the most eminent architects of their day , Sir Herbert Bake[MASK] [MASK] Sir Reginald Blomfield , and Sir Edwin Lutyens were commissioned to design t[MASK]e cemeteries and memorials . Rudyard Kipling wa[MASK] appointed literary adv[MASK]sor for the langua[MASK]e used for memorial inscriptions . 
 In 1920 , the Commission built three[MASK]experimental cemeteries at Le Treport , Forceville and Louvencourt , following the pr[MASK]nciples outlined in the K[MASK]nyon report . Of these , the Forceville Comm[MASK]nal Ce[MASK]etery and Extension was agreed to be the mo[MASK]t successful . Having co[MASK]sulted with garden designer Gertrude Jekyll , the archit[MASK]cts created a walled ceme[MASK]ery with uniform headstones in a ga[MASK][MASK]en setting , augmented by Blomfield 's Cross of Sacrifice and Lutyens ' Stone of Remembrance . After some adjustments , F[MASK]rceville became [MASK]he temp[MASK]ate for the Commission 's building programme . Adjustments were required because all three expe[MASK]imental cemeteries went over budget . To [MASK]nsure future cemeteries remained within their budget the Commission decided to not build shelters in cemeteries that con[MASK]ained less than 200 graves , to not place a Stone of Remembrance in any cemetery with less than 400 graves , and to limit the height of cemetery walls to 1 metre ( 3 @.@ 3 ft ) . 
 At the end of 1919 , the Commission had spent £[MASK]7 @,@ 500 , and this figure rose t[MASK] £ 250 @,@ 000 i[MASK] 1920 as construction of cemeteries[MASK]and memorials [MASK]ncreased . By 1921 , the Commission had established 1 @,@ 000 cemeteries which were ready for he[MASK]dstone erections , an[MASK] burials . Between 1920 and 1923 , the Commission was shipping 4 @,@ 000 headstones a week to France . In many cases sm[MASK]ll cemeteries were [MASK]losed an[MASK] the graves concentrated in larger ones . By 1927 , when the majority of construction had been completed , over 500 cemeteries had been built , with 400 @,@ 000 headstones , a thousand Crosses of[MASK]Sacrifice , and 400 Stones of Remembrance . 
 T[MASK]e Commission had also been mandated to individually commemorate each soldier who had no kn[MASK]wn grave , which amo[MASK]nted to 315 @,@ 000 in France and Belgium alone . The Commission in[MASK]tially decided to build 12 monuments on which to commemorate the missing ; each memorial being located[MASK]at the site of an important battle a[MASK]ong the Western Front . After resistance from the French committee responsible for the approvals of memorials on French territory , the[MASK]Commission revised their plan [MASK]nd re[MASK]uced the number of memorials , and in some cases built memorials to [MASK]he missing in existing ce[MASK]eteries rather than as separate structures . 
 Regin[MASK]ld Blomfield 's Menin Gate was the f[MASK]rst memorial to the miss[MASK]ng [MASK]ocated in Europe to be completed , and was unveiled on 24 July 1927 . [MASK]he Menin Gate ( Menenpoort ) was f[MASK]und to have insufficient space to contain all the names as orig[MASK]nally [MASK]lanned and 34 @,@ 984 names of the missing were ins[MASK]ead inscribed on Herbert Baker 's Tyne Cot Memorial to the Missi[MASK]g . Other memorials followed : the Helles Memo[MASK]ial [MASK]n Gallipoli designed by John James Burnet ; the Thiepval Memorial on the Somme [MASK]nd the Arras Memorial designed by Edw[MASK]n Lutyens ; and the Basr[MASK] Memorial in Iraq designed by Edward P[MASK]ioleau Warren [MASK] The Dominions and India[MASK]also erected memorials[MASK]on which they comme[MASK][MASK]rated their missing : the Neuve @-[MASK] Chapelle[MASK]Memorial for the forces of India , the Vimy Memorial by Canada , the Villers @-@ Bretonneux Memorial by Australia , the Delville Wood[MASK]Memorial by South Africa and the Beaumont @-@ Hamel Memorial by Newfoundland . The programme of [MASK]ommemorating the[MASK]dead of the Great War was considered essentially complete with the inauguration [MASK]f the Thiepval Memorial in 1932 , though the Vimy Memorial would not be f[MASK]nished until 19[MASK]6 , the Villers @-@ Bretonneux Memorial until 1938[MASK]and stonemasons were still conducting w[MASK]rk on the Menin Gate when Germany invaded Belgium in 1940 . 
 The only memorial created by the Commiss[MASK]on tha[MASK] was not in t[MASK]e form of a monument or cemetery was the Opththalmic Institute at Giza , Egy[MASK]t — complete with library , and bac[MASK]eriology and pathol[MASK]gy departments — as its memorial to men of the Egyptian Labour Corps and Camel Transport Corps . Its erection was agreed[MASK]with l[MASK]cal politica[MASK] pressure . 
 
 = = = World War I[MASK] = = = 
 
 From [MASK]he start of the Seco[MASK]d World War in 1939 , the Commission organised grave registration units a[MASK]d , planning ahead based on the experience gained fro[MASK] the First World War , earmarked land for use as cemeteries . When the war began turning in f[MASK]vour of the Allies , the Commission was able to[MASK]begin restoring its First World War cemeteries and memorials . It also began the task of c[MASK]mmemo[MASK]ating the 600 @,@ 000 Commonwealth casualties from the Second World War . In 1949 , the Commission completed Dieppe Canadian War Cemet[MASK]ry , the first of [MASK]59 new cemeteries and 36 new memorials .[MASK]Eventually , over 350 @,@ 000 new headstones[MASK]were erected . Many were made from Hopton Wood stone . The wider scale of World War II , [MASK]oupled with manpower shortages and unrest i[MASK] some countries , meant that the con[MASK]truction and restoration progra[MASK]mes took much longer . Following the war , the Commission implemented a five @-@ year horticultural renovation programme . The horticultural neg[MASK]ect was largely addressed by 1950 but there were [MASK]ecessary structural repairs to be made . These , tog[MASK]ther with the backlo[MASK] of maintenance tasks from before the war , took a further 10 years to complete and the programme was not completed until the 1960s . 
 With the increa[MASK]ed n[MASK]mber of[MASK]civi[MASK]ian casualties compared wit[MASK] the World War I , Winston Ch[MASK]rch[MASK]ll agreed t[MASK] Ware 's proposal that the Commission also maintain a record of Commonwealth civilian war deaths . A supplemental chapter[MASK]was added to the Im[MASK]erial War Graves Commission 's [MASK]harter on [MASK] February 1941 , empow[MASK]ring the organisation to collect and record [MASK]he[MASK]names o[MASK] civilia[MASK]s who died from enemy action during the Second World War , which resulted in the creation of the Civilian War Dead Roll of Honour . The roll eventually contained the names of ne[MASK]rly[MASK]67 @,@ 000 civilians . The Commission and th[MASK] Dean of Westminster reached an agreement that the roll would eventually be placed i[MASK] Westminster Abbey but not until the roll was comp[MASK]ete and hostilities had ended . The Commission handed over the first six volumes to[MASK]the Dean of Westminster on[MASK]21 February 1956 ; the[MASK]final volume w[MASK]s added to the showcase in 1958 . 
 
 = = = Post – World War II = = = 
 
 Following World War II the Commission recognised that the word ' I[MASK]perial ' within its name w[MASK]s no longer appropriate . In the spirit of strengthening national and[MASK]regional feelings the organisation 's name was changed to Commonwealth War Graves Co[MASK]mission [MASK]n 1960 . 
 M[MASK]re recent conflicts have some[MASK]imes ma[MASK]e it impossible for the Commission to care for cemeteries [MASK]n a given region or[MASK]resulted i[MASK] the destruction of sites altoget[MASK]er . Zehrensdorf Indian Cemetery in Germany was unkempt after the end of World War II and until the German reunification because it was located in an area occupied by Russian forces and was not entirely rebuilt until 2005 . The Six @-[MASK] Day War and War of Attrition resulted in the destruction of Port Tewfik Memorial and Aden Memorial , and[MASK]the death of a Commission gardener at Suez War Memorial Cemetery . During the Lebanese Civil War two cemeterie[MASK] in Beirut we[MASK]e dest[MASK]oyed and had [MASK]o be rebuilt . The maintenance of [MASK]ar graves and memorials in Iraq has [MASK]emained difficult since Iran – Iraq War in the 1980s , with regular mai[MASK]tenance being impractical since after the Gulf War . 
 The Comm[MASK]ssion has , and continues to , also provide support for war graves outside its traditional mandate . In 1982 , the British Ministry of Defence requested the Commission 's assistance to design and construct cemeteries in the Falkland Islands for those killed duri[MASK]g the[MASK]F[MASK]lklands War . Although these cemeteries are not Commonwealth War Graves Commission cemeteries , the [MASK]ommission manages the administrative [MASK]esponsibilities of these[MASK]ce[MASK]eteries . Since 2005 , the Commission has c[MASK]rried out similar management duties on behalf of the British Ministr[MASK] of Defence for cemeteries and graves of British and Imperial soldiers who died duri[MASK]g the Second Boer War . In 2003 , Veterans[MASK]Affairs Canada employed the Commission to develop an approach to locate grave markers[MASK]for which [MASK]he Canadian Minister of Veterans[MASK]Affairs has responsibility . As of 2[MASK]11 , the Commission con[MASK]ucts a twelve @-[MASK] year cyclical inspection programme of Canadian veterans ' mark[MASK]rs installed at the expense of the Government of Cana[MASK]a . 
 In 2008 , an exploratory excavation discovered mass graves on the edge of Pheasant Wood outside of Fromelles . Two @-@ hund[MASK]ed and fifty British and Au[MASK]tralian bodies were[MASK]excavated from fiv[MASK] mass graves which were interred in the newly constructed Fromelles ( Pheasant Wood ) Military Cemetery . This was the first new Commonwealth War Graves Commission cemetery in more than 50 years , the las[MASK] such c[MASK]meteries having been built after th[MASK][MASK]Second World War . 
 
 = = B[MASK]rial sites and memorials = = 
 
 The Co[MASK]mission is currently responsible for the continued commemoration of 1 @.@ 7 million deceased Commonwealth military service m[MASK]mbers in [MASK]53 countries and approxi[MASK]ately 67 @,@ 000 civilians who d[MASK]ed as a result of enemy action [MASK]uring World War II . Commonwealth military service members [MASK][MASK]e commemorated by name on either a headstone , at an[MASK]identi[MASK]ied si[MASK]e o[MASK] a burial , or on a memorial . As a result , the Commission is curr[MASK]ntly responsible for the care[MASK]of war dead at over 23 @,@ 000 separate burial sites an[MASK] maintenance of more than 200 memorials wo[MASK]ldwide . The vast majority[MASK]of burial s[MASK]tes are pre @-@ existing communal or muni[MASK]ipal cemeteries and parish churc[MASK]yards located in the United Kingdom , however the Commission has itself constructed[MASK]a[MASK]proximately 2 @,@ 500 war cemeteri[MASK]s worldwide . The C[MASK]mmission has also constructed or commissioned memorials to commemorate the [MASK]ead who have no known grave ; the largest of these is the T[MASK]iepval Memorial .[MASK]
 
 = = = Qualifications for inclusion = = = 
 
 The Com[MASK]ission only c[MASK]mmemo[MASK]ate[MASK] those who have died during the designated war years , while in Commonwealth military[MASK]service or of causes attributable to service . The applicable periods of consideration are 4 August 1914 to 31 August 1921 for the First World War and 3 September 1939 to 31 Dece[MASK]ber 1947 for the Second World War . The end date for the First World War period is the official end of th[MASK] war , while for the Second Wor[MASK]d War the Commission selected a date approximately the same period after VE Day as the official end of the First World War was after [MASK]he 1918 Armistice . 
 Civilia[MASK]s who died as a result of [MASK]nemy action during the Second World War are commemorated differently from those that died as a result of military service . They are commemorated by nam[MASK] through[MASK]the Civilian War Dead Roll of Honour located in St Geo[MASK]ge 's Chapel in Westminster Abbey . In addition[MASK]to its mandated duties , the Commission maintains , [MASK]nder arrangement with applicable governments , over 40 @,@ 000 non @-@ Commonwealth war graves and over 25 @,@ 000 non @-@ war military and ci[MASK]ilian graves .

 = = = Cemetery design = = = 
 
 
 = = = = Common architectural design features = = = = 
 
 Structural design has always played a[MASK] important part in the Com[MASK]ission 's ceme[MASK]eries . Apart from a few [MASK]xceptions , due to local geological conditions , the cemeteries f[MASK]llow the same design an[MASK] uniform aesthetic [MASK]ll over the world . This makes the cemeteries easily recognisable and distinguishes them from war graves administered by other groups or countries . 
 A typical ceme[MASK]ery is surrounded by [MASK] low wall or hedge and wi[MASK]h a wrought @-@ iron gate entran[MASK]e . For cemeteries in France and Belgium , a land tablet near the entrance or along a wall identifies the cemetery grounds as ha[MASK]ing been provide[MASK] by the French or Belgian governments . All but the small[MASK]st [MASK][MASK]meteries contain a register with an inventory of the burials[MASK], a plan of the plots and rows , and a basic history of the cemetery . The register is located within a metal cupboard that is marked with a cross locate[MASK] in either the wall [MASK]ear the cemete[MASK]y entrance or in a shelter within the cemetery . More recently , in [MASK]arger sites , a stainles[MASK] steel notice gives details of the respective military campaign . The headstones within the ceme[MASK]ery[MASK]are of a uniform size [MASK]nd design and mark plots of equal size . 
 The cemetery g[MASK]ounds are[MASK], exce[MASK]t in dr[MASK]er climates , grass covered with a floral border aro[MASK]nd the h[MASK]adstones . There is also an absence[MASK]of any paving between the he[MASK]dstone rows which is intended to make the cemete[MASK]y feel like a traditional walled garden where visitors cou[MASK]d exper[MASK]ence a sense of peace . H[MASK]wever , Carter and Jackson argue that the uniform aesthetics are designed to evoke a positive experience which delibera[MASK]e[MASK]y mask[MASK] and sanitises the nature of the war deaths . 
[MASK]
 = = = = Cross of Sacrifice [MASK]nd Stone of Remembrance = = = = 
 
 Typically , cemeteries of more than [MASK]0 graves contain a Cross of Sacrifice designed by architect Reginald Blomfield . This cross was designed to imitate medieval crosses found in ch[MASK]rchyards in England with proportions more common[MASK]y seen in the C[MASK]ltic cross . T[MASK]e cross is normally a freestan[MASK]ing four @-@ poin[MASK] limestone Latin cross , mounted on an octagonal base , and ranging in height from 14 to 32 feet . A bronze longswor[MASK] , blade down , is embedded on the face of the cross . This cross represents the faith of the majority of the[MASK]dead and the sw[MASK]rd represents[MASK]the military character of the cemetery , intended to link British soldiers a[MASK]d the Christian concept of [MASK]elf [MASK]-@ sac[MASK]ifice . 
 Cemeteries wit[MASK] more than 1000 burials typically have a Stone of Remembrance , designed b[MASK] Edwin Lutyens with the inscription " The[MASK]r Name Liveth for Evermore " [MASK] The co[MASK]cept of the Stone o[MASK] Reme[MASK]brance stone was developed by Rudyard Kiplin[MASK] t[MASK] commemorat[MASK] those of all faiths and none respect[MASK][MASK]ely [MASK] In contrast to the Cross of Sacrifice , the design fo[MASK] the stone deliberately avoided " sh[MASK]pes associated with [MASK]articular religions " . The geometry of the structure was based on studies of the Parthenon . Each stone is 3 @.@ 5 metres ( 11 ft ) long and 1 [MASK].@ 5 metres ( 4 @.@ 9 ft ) high . The shape of the ston[MASK] has been compared both to that of a sarcophagus and an altar . The feature was designed [MASK]sing the principl[MASK] of entasis . The subtle [MASK]urves in the design , if[MASK]extended , would form a sphere 1[MASK]@,@ 801 feet [MASK] inches ( 549 @.@ 15 m[MASK]) in diameter . 
 
 = = = = Headstones = = = = 
 
 Every grave is marked with a headstone . Each headstone contains the national[MASK]emblem or regimental badge , rank , nam[MASK] , unit , date of death [MASK]nd age of each casualty inscribed[MASK]above[MASK]an appropriate religious s[MASK]mbol and a more personal dedication chosen by relatives . The headstones use a[MASK]standard upper case l[MASK]ttering designed by MacDonald Gill . Individual graves are arranged , where possible , in str[MASK]ight rows and marked by uniform [MASK]eadstones , [MASK]he vast majority of which are ma[MASK]e of [MASK]ortland stone . The original headstone dimensions were 76 centimetres ( 30 in ) tall , [MASK]8 cm ( 15 in ) wide , and 7 @.@ 6 cm ( 3 @.@ 0 in ) thick . 
 Most headstone[MASK] are inscribed with a cross , except for [MASK][MASK]ose deceased known to be atheist or non @-@ Christian . In the case of burials of Victoria Cross [MASK]r George Cross recipients , t[MASK]e regimental badge is supplemented by[MASK]the V[MASK]ctoria Cross or George Cross emble[MASK] . Sometimes a soldier employed[MASK]a pseudonym because they were too young to serve or were sought by law enforcement ;[MASK]in such cases their primary nam[MASK] is show[MASK] along with the notation " served as " . Many [MASK]eadstones are for unidentified casualties ; th[MASK]y consequently bear only what could be discovered from the body . The epitaph , dev[MASK]loped by Rudyard Kipling , that appears on the gr[MASK]ves of unidentified soldiers [MASK]or which no details are known is " A Soldier of the Great War kno[MASK]n unto [MASK]od " . Some headstones bear the text " believed to be buried in this cemetery " when the[MASK] ar[MASK] believed to [MASK]e buried in the cemetery but the ex[MASK]ct location of the grave is not kno[MASK]n . In some cases soldiers were buried i[MASK] collective graves an[MASK] distinguishing one body from [MASK]nother was not possible an[MASK] thus one headstone covers more than one grave . The headstone does not denote any specific details of the death [MASK]xcept for its date , and eve[MASK] then only [MASK]f it is k[MASK]own , and are deliberately ambiguous about the cause of death . 
 Due to local conditions it was sometimes necessary[MASK]for the Commission[MASK]t[MASK] deviate from its standard design . In places prone to extreme weather or earthquakes , such as Tha[MASK]land and Turkey , stone @-@ faced pedestal markers are used instead of the n[MASK][MASK]mal headstones . These measures are intended to prevent masonry being damaged during earthquakes or sinking into sodden ground . In Italy headstones were carved from Chiampo Perla limestone because it was in more plentiful sup[MASK]ly . In Struma Military C[MASK]metery , in Greece , to avoid risk of earthquake damage , small hea[MASK]stones are laid flat on the ground . The smaller size of the markers mean that they of[MASK]en lack unit insignia . 
 
 = = = = [MASK]orticulture = = = = 
 
 Commission cemeteries are distinctive in treating flor[MASK]culture[MASK]as an integral part of the cemetery design .[MASK]Originally , the horticultural concept was to create an env[MASK][MASK]onment where visitors could experience a sense of peace in a setting , in contrast to traditionally bleak graveyards . Recom[MASK]endations given by Arthur William Hill , the Assistant Director of the[MASK]Royal Botanical Gardens at Kew enable[MASK] the Commission to develop cemetery layouts and architectural structure[MASK] that took into accoun[MASK] the placement of suitable plant life . Combining [MASK]tructura[MASK] and hor[MASK]icultural elements was not unfamil[MASK]ar to the Co[MASK]mis[MASK]ion 's architects . Sir Edwin Lutyens furthered his long[MASK]@-@ standing working relationship with horticulturist Gertrude Jekyll , whose devotion to tradi[MASK]ional cottage garden plants and roses greatly influenced the appearance of the cemeteries[MASK]. Where possible , indigenous plan[MASK]s wer[MASK] utilised to enhance sentimental associations with the gardens o[MASK] home . 
 Variety in texture [MASK] height a[MASK]d timing of floral display were equ[MASK]lly important horticultural considerations . The beds around each headstone are planted with a mix[MASK]u[MASK]e of floribunda [MASK]oses and herbaceous perennials . Low @-@ growing plants a[MASK]e chosen for areas immediately in front of headstones , ensuring that inscriptions are not obscured and preventing soil from splashing back during r[MASK]in . In cemeteries where there are pedestal grave markers , dwarf varieties of plants are used instead . 
 The absence of any form of paving between the headston[MASK] rows contributes to the simplicity of the cemetery designs . Lawn paths add to the garden ambiance ,[MASK]and are irrigated during the dry seaso[MASK] in countries where there is insufficient rain . Where irrigation is inappro[MASK]riate or impractical , dry landscaping is an ecological alternative favoured [MASK]y the Commission 's horticulturists , as is the case in Iraq . Dri[MASK]r areas require a different approach not only for lawns , but also to plants and styles of[MASK]planting . Similarly , there are separate horticu[MASK]tural consideration[MASK] in tropical climates . When many cemeteries are concentrated within a limited area , like al[MASK]ng the[MASK]Western Front or Gallipoli peninsula , mobile teams of gardeners operate from a local base . Elsewhere , larger cemeteries have their own dedicated staff while small cemeteries are usually tended by a single gardener working part @[MASK]@[MASK]time .[MASK]

 = = = Financing = = = 
 
 The CWGC '[MASK] work is funded predominantly by grant[MASK] from th[MASK] governments of the six member states[MASK]. In the fiscal year 2012 / 13 , these grants amounted to £ 58 @.@ 6 million of th[MASK] organisation 's £ 66 @.@ 5 million of income . This equates to[MASK]an ap[MASK]roximate cost of C $ 85 p[MASK]r commemorated war dead . The con[MASK]ribution from each country is proportionate to the number [MASK]f graves the CWGC maintains on behalf of that country . The percentage of total annual contr[MASK]butions for which each country is responsible is United Kingdom 78 @.@ 4 % , Canada 10[MASK]@.@ 1 % , Australia 6 @.[MASK] 1 % , New Zealand 2 @.[MASK] 1 % , South Africa 2 @.@ 1 % and India 1 @.@ 2 % . 
 
 = = Ongoing projects and issues = = 
 
 
 = = = War Graves Photographic Project = = = 
 
 A project is underway to photograph the graves of and memorials to all service personnel from 1914 to the present day and make the images availa[MASK]le to the public . The work is being carried o[MASK]t by The War Graves Photographic Project in conjunction with the CWGC . As of August 2013 , the project has recorded 1 @.@ 7 million photographs for posterity . 
 
 = = = Reburials and identifications [MASK] = = 
 
 Immediately following the First World War , the British Army remained responsible for the exhumation of remains . The Western Front was divided into sectors and combed for bodies by 12 @-@ man exhumation units . Between the Armistice and September 1921 , the exhum[MASK]tion units reburied 204 @,@ [MASK]95 bodies[MASK]. After 192[MASK] , no fu[MASK]ther widespread search for[MASK]bodies was undertaken and in Febr[MASK]ary 1921 responsibility of the cemeteries was[MASK]transferred to the Commission . Despite the rigorous searches , bodies continued to be discovered in numbers . In the three years following the conclusion of the general search 38 @,@ 000 bodies were discovered . In the mid 1920s , 20 to 30 bodies were bein[MASK] discovered weekly . 
 The discovery of remains of First and Second World War casualties remains a common occurrence with approximately 30 bodies discovered annually . For example , in 2006 [MASK]ight bo[MASK][MASK]es of Canadian soldiers from the 78th Battalion ( Winnipeg Grenadiers ) , CEF were discovered in a backyard in Hallu , France . In April 2013 , the remains of four British soldiers discovered by a F[MASK]ench farmer clearing land w[MASK]th metal detector in 2009 were re [MASK]-@ interred at H.A.C. Cemetery near Arras , France . In March 2014 , the remains of 20 Commonwealth and 30 German soldiers[MASK]were discovered in Vendin @-@ le @-@ Vieil , France with the Commonwealth soldiers being subsequently reburied at Lo[MASK]s Britis[MASK] Cemetery[MASK]. 
 When th[MASK] remains of a Commonwealth[MASK]soldier from the First or Second World War is discovered the Commission is notified and a [MASK]ommission burial officer tries to col[MASK]ect any associated artifacts that may help in identify the remains . The details are then registered and archived at the Commission 's headquar[MASK]ers. the collection of evidence[MASK]can include artifacts with the remains , anthropological data and DNA . The archival records of the commission are open to the public to permit individuals to conduct their own research . Investigation of archival records by members of the public periodically result in the ide[MASK]tification of previously buried casualties . In December 2013 , it was discovered[MASK]that Second Lieutenant Philip Frederick Cormack , who was previ[MASK]usly commemorated on the Arras Flying Services Memorial , had in fact been buried in a French military cemetery[MASK]in Machelen , East @-@ Flanders in Belgium . Sergeant Leonard Mai[MASK]ment [MASK]as identified in 2013 after a vi[MASK]itor to Marf[MASK]ux British Cemeter[MASK] [MASK]iscovered a headstone of an unknown sergeant with the Hampshire Regiment killed on 20 July 1918 and was subsequently able to show that only one serge[MASK]nt from that reg[MASK]ment had bee[MASK] killed in France on that date . 
 
 = = = Vandalism = = = 
 
 Cemeteries , including those of war dead , are targets for vandali[MASK]m . The gravestones , cemeteries[MASK]and buildings of the Commission are no exception . The Commission believes that graffiti and damage to [MASK]tonework are usuall[MASK] the pursuits partaken by young people , noting the number of incidents in[MASK]reases when schoolchildren are on school holidays . Determined thieves will also steal [MASK]he bronze swords off the Cross of Sacrifice , which are now replaced with identical ones made in fibreglass . 
 [MASK]h[MASK] vandalism of Commission cemeteries has also been connected to the participation of Common[MASK]ealth countries i[MASK] contemporary conflicts . In the 1970s , in The Troubles ,[MASK]Com[MASK]ission cemeteries in Ireland experienced vandalism . Vandals defaced th[MASK] central memorial of the Étaples Military Cemetery in northern France with anti @-@ [MASK]ritish a[MASK]d anti @-@ [MASK]merican graffiti on 20 March 2003 immediately after the beginning of t[MASK]e [MASK]raq War . On 9 May 2004 , thirty[MASK]@-@ three headstones were demolish[MASK]d in the Gaza cemetery , which contains 3 @,@ 691 graves , allegedly in retaliation for the Abu Ghra[MASK]b prisoner abuse scandal . On 24 February 2012 ,[MASK]during the Libyan Civil War , an Islamist militia damaged over 200 headstones i[MASK] the Beng[MASK]azi war cemetery as well as the central memorial . 
 
 
 = Tatwine = 
 
 Tatwine or Tatwin ( Ta[MASK]uini or[MASK]Tadwinus ; [MASK] . 670 – 734 ) was the tenth Archbishop of Canterbury from 731 to 734 . Prior to becoming archbishop , he was a[MASK]monk and abbot of a Benedictine monastery . Besides his ecclesiastical career , Tatwine was a writer , and riddles he composed survive . Another work[MASK]he compose[MASK] was on the grammar of the Latin language , which was aimed at advanced stude[MASK]ts of that l[MASK]ngua[MASK]e . He was subsequently [MASK]onsidered a s[MASK]int . 
 
 = = Biography = = 
 
 Tatwine was a Mercian by birth . His epigraph at Canterbury stated tha[MASK] when he died he was in old age , so p[MASK]rhaps he was b[MASK]rn around 670 . He became a monk at the monastery at Breedon @-@ on @-@ the @-@ Hill in the [MASK]resent @-@ day County of Leicestershire , and then abbot of that house . Through the influence of King[MASK]Æthelbald he was appointed as Archbishop of Canterbury in 731 and w[MASK]s consecrated on 10 June 731 . He was one of a nu[MASK]ber of Mercians who were appointed to Canterbury d[MASK]ring the 730s and 740s . Apart from[MASK]his consecration of the Bishops of Lindsey and Selsey in 733 , Tatwine 's period as archbishop appears to have been uneventful . He died in office on 30 July 7[MASK]4 . Later considered a saint , his feast day is 30 July . 
 
 = = Writings = = 
 
 B[MASK]de 's commentary on Tatwine calls him a " vir religione et Prudentia insignis , sacris quoque literis nobiliter instructus " ( a man notable for his prudence , devotion and learning ) . These q[MASK]alities were displayed in the two[MASK]surviving manuscripts of his riddles and f[MASK]ur of his Ars Tatuini [MASK] The Ars is one of only two surviving 8th @-@ century Lati[MASK] grammars from England , and was based on the works of [MASK]riscian and Consentius . The riddles deal with such diverse [MASK]opics as philosophy and charity , the fiv[MASK] senses and[MASK]the alphabet , and a book and a pen . The riddles are forme[MASK] i[MASK] acrostics . T[MASK]e grammar [MASK]s a reworking of Donatus 's Ars [MASK]inor [MASK]ith the addition of infor[MASK]ation drawn from other g[MASK]ammarians . It was not designed for a newcomer to the Latin language , but is designed [MASK]o[MASK] more adv[MASK]nced studen[MASK]s . It cover[MASK] the eight parts of speech through i[MASK]lustrations drawn from classica[MASK] scholars , although not directl[MASK] bu[MASK] through other grammatical works . There are also some examples drawn from the Psa[MASK]m[MASK] . The work was completed before he became archbi[MASK]hop , and was used not only in Engla[MASK]d but also on the continent . A recent edition of his works is Tatuini Op[MASK]ra omnia , published in 1968 with some translations into English and German from the original Latin . 
 
 
 = [MASK]erman Type UB I submarine = 
 
 The Type UB I was a class of small coasta[MASK] submarines ( U [MASK]-@ boats ) built in Germany at the beginning [MASK]f the First Wor[MASK]d War . 20 boats were constructed , most of which went into service with the German Imp[MASK]rial Navy . Boats of this design were also operated by the Austro @-@ Hungarian Nav[MASK] ( Kaiserliche und Königliche Kriegsmarine or K.u.K. Kriegsmarine )[MASK]and the Bulgarian Navy . The group[MASK]is some[MASK]imes known as the UB @-@ 1 class after SM UB @-@ 1 , the class leader . In the Austro @-@ Hungarian Navy , it was called the U @-@[MASK]10 class . 
 Built to me[MASK]t the need for small maneuverable submarines able[MASK]to operate [MASK]n the narrow ,[MASK]shallow seas off Flanders , the vessels were intended to be qui[MASK]kly constructed , then shippe[MASK] by rail and assembled at their port of operation[MASK]. The design effort began in mid @-@ August 1914 and by mid @-[MASK] October the first 15[MASK]boats were ordered from two German sh[MASK]pyards . The German Impe[MASK]ial Navy subsequentl[MASK] ordered an additional pair of boats to replace tw[MASK] so[MASK]d to Austria @-@ Hungary , who ordered a further three boats in April 1915 . A to[MASK]al of 20 UB Is were b[MASK]ilt . Construction of the first boats[MASK]for Germany began in early November 1914 ; all 20 were completed by October 1915 . Several of the first boats u[MASK]derwent trials in Germ[MASK]n home waters , but the [MASK]est were assembled and tested at either Antwerp or[MASK]Pola . The German boa[MASK]s operated primarily in the Flan[MASK]ers , Baltic , and Constantinople Flotillas . The boats were about 28 metres ( 92 ft ) long and displaced 127 tonnes ( 125 long tons ) when surfaced and 142 tonnes ( 140 long tons ) while submerged . All had two bow torpedo tubes and two torpedoes , and were eq[MASK]ipped with a deck @-@ mounted machine gun . 
 In 1918 four [MASK]f the surviving German boats were converted into coastal minelayers . Of the seventeen boats in German service , two were sold to Austria [MASK]-@ Hungary[MASK],[MASK]one was sold to Bulgaria , and nine were lost during the war . One[MASK]of the five Austro @-@ H[MASK]ngarian boats w[MASK]s sun[MASK] and another mined and not repaired . The five surviving German boats , the four survivi[MASK]g Austro @-@ Hungarian boats , and the Bulgarian boat were all turned over to the Allies after the end of the war and were broken u[MASK] . 
 
 = = Design = = 
 
[MASK]In the earliest stages of the First World War the [MASK]erman Army 's rapid a[MASK]vance along the North S[MASK]a coast found the[MASK]German I[MASK]perial Navy [MASK]ithout submarines suitable to operate in the narrow and shallow seas off Flanders . By 18 August 1914 , two weeks after the German invasion of Belgium , the planning of a series of small coastal submarines had already begun . 
 The Germ[MASK]n Imperial Navy stipulated that the submarines[MASK]must be transportable by rail , which imposed a maximum diameter of 3 @.@ 15 metres ( 10 ft 4 in ) . The rushed planning effort — which had been assigned the name " Project 3[MASK] " — resulted in the Type UB I design , created specifically for operation from Flanders . The boats were to be about 28 metres ( 92 ft ) long and to displace about 125 tonnes ( 123 long tons ) with two bow torpedo [MASK]ubes[MASK]. 
 Boats[MASK]of the Ty[MASK]e UB I design were built by two manufacturers , Germaniawerft of K[MASK]el and AG[MASK]Weser of Br[MASK]men , whic[MASK] led to some var[MASK]ations in boats from the tw[MASK] shipyards . The eight Germaniawerft[MASK]@-@ built boats were slightly longer at 28 @.@ 10 metres ( [MASK]2 ft 2 in ) length overall , while the twelve Weser @-@ bui[MASK]t boats came in 22 centimetres ( 8 @.@ 7 in ) shorter than t[MASK]eir counterparts . All were 3 @.@ 15 metres ( 10 ft 4 in ) abeam and had a draft of 3 @.@ 03 metres ( 9 ft 11 in ) . The boat[MASK] all displ[MASK]ced 127 tonnes ( 125 [MASK]ong tons ) while surfaced , but differed slightly in displace[MASK]ent submerged . The slightly longer Germaniawerft boats displaced 142 tonnes ( 140[MASK]long tons )[MASK][MASK]hile submerged , as they weighed 1 tonne ( 0 @.@ 98 long tons ) more than the Weser boats . 
 The drivetrain of the boats consisted of a single propeller shaft driven by a Daimler ( Germaniawerft ) or Körting ( [MASK]eser ) diesel engin[MASK] on the[MASK]s[MASK]rface , or a Siemens @-@ Schuckert electric motor for underwater travel . The Weser boats were capable of nearly 7 @.@ 5 knots ( 13 @.@ 9 km / h ; 8 @.@ 6 mph ) on the surface and a little more than 6 knots ( 11 km / h ; 6 @.@ 9 mph ) submerged . The Ge[MASK]maniawerft boats were about 1 knot ([MASK]1 @.@ 9 km / h ; 1 @.@ [MASK] mph ) slo[MASK]er than their Bremen @-@ mad[MASK] counterparts . The boats were equipped with two 45 @-@ centimetre ( 17 @.@ 7 in ) bow torpedo tubes and carried two torpedoes .[MASK]They were also armed with a[MASK][MASK]ingle 8 @-@ millimetre ( 0 @.@ 3[MASK] in ) machine gun affixed to the deck . 
 
 = = Construction = = 
 
 The German Imperial Navy ordere[MASK] its first fifteen Type UB I boats on [MASK]5 October 1914 . Eight boats — numbered UB @-@ 1 to [MASK]B @-@ 8 — were ordered f[MASK]om Germaniawerft of Kiel , and seven boats — numbere[MASK] UB [MASK]-@ 9 to U @-@ 15 — from AG Weser of Bremen . After two of [MASK]he class[MASK], UB @-@[MASK]1 and UB @-@ 15 , were sold in February 1915 to ally Austr[MASK]a @-@ Hungary ( becomi[MASK]g U @-@ 10 and U @-@ 11 in the Austro @-@ Hungarian Navy ) , the German Imperi[MASK]l Navy ordered UB @-@ 16 and UB @-@ 17 from Weser . A fur[MASK]her three for Austria @-@ Hungary — U @-@ 15 , U [MASK]-@ 16 , and U @-@ 17 — had been orde[MASK]ed from Weser by April , bringing the total number constructed to 20 . 
 UB @-@ 1 and UB @-@ 2 were laid down on 1 November 1914 at the Germaniawerft yard at [MASK]iel . UB @-@ 1 was launched on 22 January 1915 , just 75 workin[MASK] days later . UB @-@ 2 's launch followed on 13 [MASK]ebruary . Among the Weser boats , UB @-@[MASK]9 was laid down first , on 6 November 1914 , and launched on 6 February 1915 , a week ahead of U[MASK] @-@ 2 . These first three b[MASK]ats launched underwent trials i[MASK] home waters , but most of the other members of the class were shipped via rail and underwent trials at their assembly point . 
 The process of shipping the subma[MASK]ines by rail involved brea[MASK]ing the submarines d[MASK]wn into what was essentially a knock down kit . Each boat was broken into approximately fif[MASK]een pieces and loaded on to eight railway [MASK]latcars . Type UB I boats destined for service with t[MASK]e Flanders Flotilla made a five @[MASK]@ day journey to Antwerp for the two[MASK][MASK]to thr[MASK]e @-@ week assembly process . A[MASK]ter assembly at Antwerp the boats were towed [MASK]y[MASK]barge to Bruges for trials . Boats selected for service in the Medite[MASK]ranean were sent to the[MASK]Austro @-@ Hungarian port of Pola for assembly . The total time from departure of the railcars from the shipyard t[MASK] operational readiness for the boats was about six weeks . 
 By July 1915 all seventeen of the German Imperial Navy Type UB Is had been completed . 
 
 = = Service =[MASK]=[MASK]
 
 During their trials the Type [MASK]B Is were found to be too small and too slow and had a reputation for being underpowered ; on[MASK] commander comp[MASK]red his Type UB I to a " s[MASK]wing machine " . According to authors R. H. Gibson and Maurice Prendergast in their 1931 book The German Submarine [MASK]ar , 1914 – 1918 , the UBs did not have enoug[MASK] power to chase d[MASK]wn steamers while surfaced and lacked the endurance to spend any [MASK]xtended amount of time underwater , ex[MASK]austing their batteries after little over a[MASK] hour 's running . In @-@ service use revealed another problem : with a single propeller shaft / engine combination , if either component [MASK]aile[MASK] [MASK] the U @-@ boat was almost tot[MASK]lly disabled . 
 Another reported problem with the[MASK]Type UB Is was the tendency to break trim after the firing of torpedoes . The boats were equipped with compensating tanks des[MASK]gned to flood and offset[MASK]the loss of the C[MASK]/ 06 torp[MASK]do 's 1[MASK]@,@[MASK]700 @-@ pound ( 770 kg ) weight , but this system did not always function pro[MASK]erly ; as a result , when firing from perisc[MASK]pe depth the boat could b[MASK]oach after firing or , if too much weight was t[MASK]ken on , plunge to the depths . When UB @-@ 15 torpedoed and sank Italian submarine Medusa in June 1915 , the tank failed to[MASK]properly compensate , forcing the entire crew to run to the stern to offset the trim imbalance . 
 Despite the problems , the " tin tadpoles " , as the Germans referred to them , were in active service from March 1[MASK]15 through the end of the war , with half of the 20 boats lost during the war . Boats of the class s[MASK]rve[MASK] in [MASK][MASK]ree navies : the Ge[MASK]man Imperial Navy , the Austro @-@ Hungarian Navy , and the Bulgari[MASK]n Navy . In German service , they served primarily in the Flanders Flotilla , the Baltic Flot[MASK]lla , and the Co[MASK]st[MASK]nti[MASK]ople Flotilla .

 = = [MASK] = [MASK]landers Flotilla = = = = 
 
 The first Type UB I to enter service was UB @-@ 10 , which formed the nucleus of [MASK]he Flanders Flotilla , o[MASK] 27 March 1915 . By the end of April five more Type UB I boats had become operational . UB [MASK]-@ 10 w[MASK]s eventually joined in the Flanders Floti[MASK]la by UB @-@[MASK]2[MASK], UB @-@ 4 , UB @-@ 5 , UB @-@ 6 ,[MASK]UB @-@ 12 , UB @-@ 13 , UB[MASK]@-@ 16 , and UB [MASK]-@ 17 ; of these , only UB @-@ 2 made the journey to Flander[MASK] by sea rather than rail . 
 UB @-@ 4 departed on the first patr[MASK]l from Flanders on 9 April , and was responsible for sinking the first shi[MASK] sent down by the flotilla [MASK] The Type UB I boats of the Flanders Floti[MASK]la originally patrolled the are[MASK] between the United Kingdom and the Netherlands , but began patrolling the English[MASK]Channel after UB @-@ 6 pioneered a route past British antisubmarine nets and m[MASK]nes in the Straits of Dover in late June . 
 Over the Type UB Is ' first year of se[MASK]vice , UB @-@ 4 and U[MASK] @-@ [MASK]3 were both lost , [MASK]nd UB @-@[MASK]2 and UB @-@ 5 were transferred to[MASK]the B[MASK]ltic Flotilla . In M[MASK]rch 1917 , UB @-@ [MASK] ran aground in Dutch w[MASK]ters and was interned for the rest of the war , along with her crew . [MASK]he four remaining Type UB Is in Flanders — UB @-@ 10 , UB @-@ 12 , UB @-@ 16 , UB @-@ 17 — were all converted to minelayers by 1918 , hav[MASK]ng their [MASK]orped[MASK] t[MASK]bes removed and replaced with chut[MASK]s to carry up to eight mines . Al[MASK] but UB @-@ 10 were[MASK]lost in 1918 ; UB @-@ 10 , in [MASK]oor repair and o[MASK]t of servi[MASK]e , was scuttled in October 1918 when[MASK]the Germans evacuated from Flanders .

 = = = = Constantinople Flotilla = = = = 
 
 Four of the [MASK]e[MASK]man Imper[MASK]al Navy boats — UB @-@ 3 [MASK] UB @-@ 7 , UB @-@ 8 , an[MASK] UB @-@ 14 — were selected for service with the Constantinople Flotilla .
