 = Military history of Gibraltar during World War II =[MASK]
 
[MASK]The mil[MASK]tary history of Gibraltar during World War II exemplifi[MASK]s Gibraltar 's position [MASK]s a British fortress since the early 18th century and as a vital [MASK]actor in British military strategy , both as a foothold on the [MASK]ontinent of Europe , and as a bastion of British sea power . [MASK]uring World War II , Gibraltar served a vital role in both the Atlantic Theatre and the Mediterranean [MASK]heatre , controlling virtually all naval traffic into and out of the Mediterranean Sea from the Atlantic Oc[MASK]an . 
 In addition [MASK]o its c[MASK]mmanding position , [MASK]ibraltar provided a strongly defended harbour from which ships could operate in both the Atlantic and the Mediterranea[MASK] . Force H ,[MASK]under the command of Vice @-@ Admiral James Som[MASK]rville was based in Gibraltar and had the task of maintaining naval su[MASK]eriority and providing a strong escort for convoys to and from the besieg[MASK]d island of Malta . During the course of the war , Gibralta[MASK] came under aerial bombardment [MASK]rom V[MASK]chy French aircraft and from aircraft of the Italian Royal Air Force ( Regia Aeronautica ) based on Sardi[MASK]ia . Additionally , the fortress was the focus of u[MASK]derwater attacks by the Italian Royal Navy ( Regia Marina ) commando frogman un[MASK]t ( Decima Flottiglia MAS ) and their human torpedoes . This Italian unit was based on the interned Italian ship SS Olterra [MASK]n the [MASK]earby Spanish harbour of Algeciras . A [MASK]umber [MASK]f attacks were also carried [MASK]ut by Spanish and Gibraltarian agents acting on behalf of the German Abwehr . 
 Inside [MASK]he Rock of Gibraltar itself , miles of tunnels were excavated from the limestone . Masses of r[MASK]ck were blasted out to b[MASK]ild an [MASK] under[MASK]round city " . In huge man @-@ made caverns , barracks , offices , and a fully equipped hospital were c[MASK]nstructed , complete with an operating theatre and X @-@ r[MASK]y equipment . 
 Operation Torch , the Allie[MASK] invasion of [MASK]r[MASK]nch North Africa in No[MASK]ember 1942 , was coordinated fro[MASK] the " Rock " . General Dwight D. Eisenhow[MASK]r , who was given command of the operation , set up his headquarters in Gibraltar during the planning phases of the operat[MASK]on . Following the successful c[MASK]mpletion of the North A[MASK]rican campaign and the surrender of Italy in 1943 , Gibraltar 's role shifted from a forward [MASK]peratin[MASK] base to a rear @-@ a[MASK]ea supply position . The harbour continued to operate dry docks and supply depots for the convoy routes through the Mediterranean until V @-@ E Day in 1945 . 
 
 = = Prelude and evacuation = = 
 
 World War II dramatically changed the [MASK]ives of [MASK]ibraltarians . The decision to enforce mass evacuation in order to increase the strength of the Ro[MASK]k with more military and naval personnel meant that most Gibraltarians ( s[MASK]me for up to ten years ) had nowhere to call ' home ' . O[MASK]ly [MASK]hose civilians with essential jobs were [MASK]l[MASK]owed to stay but it gave the entir[MASK] community a sense of being ' British ' by sharing in the war effort . 
 In early June[MASK]1940[MASK], about 13 @,@ 50[MASK] evacuees were shipped to Casablanca in French Morocco . However , following the[MASK]capitulati[MASK]n of the French to[MASK]the[MASK]German armies later in[MASK]June 1940 , the new Pro @-@ German French Vichy Government found the p[MASK]esence of Gibraltarian evacuees in Casablanca an embarrassment and sough[MASK] opportunities for their removal . The opportunity soon arose when 15 British cargo vessels arrived under Commodore Crichton , repatriating 15 @,@ 000 French servicemen who had been rescued from Dunkirk . Once their own rescu[MASK]d serv[MASK]cemen had disembarked , the ships were interned[MASK]until they agr[MASK]ed to take away all the ev[MASK]cuees . Although Crichton was unable to[MASK]obtain permission to clean and restock his sh[MASK]ps ( and contrary to British Admiralty orders which forbade the taking on of evacuees ) , when he saw the mass of civilians pouring through the dockyar[MASK]s , he opened up his gangways for boarding . Just beforehand , the British fleet had destro[MASK]ed a number of Frenc[MASK] warships at Mers el @-@ Kebir in order to[MASK]prevent them ending up in German hands . The attack , during which 1 @,@ 297 French sailors died ,[MASK]led to high tensions , which were evident when families were forced at bayone[MASK] point by French troops to board taking only what they could ca[MASK]ry , leaving many possessions b[MASK]hind . However , when they arrived at Gibraltar , the Governor would not allow them to land , fearing that once the e[MASK]acuees were back on the Rock , it would[MASK]be virtually impossible to evacuate them a second time . Crowds gathered in John[MASK]Mackintosh Square in the centre of [MASK]ibraltar as the news broke[MASK], speeches were made and two City Councillors accompanied by the Acti[MASK]g President of the Exchange and Commercial Library went to see the Governor ( Sir Clive Li[MASK]dell ) to ask that the evacuees be allowed to land . After receiving instructions from London , a landing was allowed [MASK]s long as the evacuees returned when other ships arrived to take them away from the Rock , and by 13 July the re @-@ evacuation back to Gibraltar had been comple[MASK]ed . 
 British conservative politician Oliver Stanley agreed to accept the evacuees in the[MASK]United Kingdom , but he argued with Gibraltar over the number of people involved . The Governor , he declared , had given the number of evacuees first as 13 @,@ 000 , then as 14 @,@ 000 and finally as 16 @,@ 000 . He asked for the situation to [MASK]e clarified , stressing the shortage of accommodation in Britain and insisting that only 13 @,@ 000 could be accepted , 2 @,@ 000 of whom were to be sent to the Port[MASK]g[MASK]ese Atlantic island of Madeira . The situation , replied General Liddell on 19 July , " is that this is a fortress liable to heavy and immediate attack and there should be[MASK]no civilians here whereas there are 22 @,@ 000 . The 13 @[MASK]@ 000 was the num[MASK]er sent t[MASK] Morocco , and more would have been sent ha[MASK] th[MASK] situation there not altered . " In London the evacuees were placed in the hands of the Ministry of Health , and many were [MASK]oused i[MASK] Ke[MASK]sington area . Concern for them in Gibraltar mounted as the air raids against London intensified , coupled with the arrival of harrowing le[MASK]ters , describing the circumstanc[MASK]s in which the evacuees were living . 
 In Septem[MASK]er rumours were already circulating among the evacuees ,[MASK]and in Gibraltar , th[MASK]t the possibility o[MASK] re @-@ evacuating the Gibr[MASK]ltarians once more was being mooted , this time the destination being Jamaica , in the West Indies . After much contention , it was decided to send a party directly[MASK]from Gibraltar to t[MASK]e island , and 1 @,@ 093 evacuees left for Jamaica direct , on 9 October , with more following later on . However petitions followed and the demands were met , partly for s[MASK]rategic reasons and the lack of available shipping . The sit[MASK]ation at the end of 1940 , therefore , [MASK]as that [MASK]ppro[MASK]imately 2 @,@ 000 evacuees were in Jam[MASK]ica and a lesser number in [MASK]adeira , wit[MASK] [MASK]he bulk of around 10 @,@ 000 housed in the London a[MASK]ea . 
 
 = = Royal Air Force involvement[MASK]: 1939 – 1941 = = 
 
 Construction of a solid surface runway began in late 1939 and[MASK]in 1940 it was proposed to extend the existing runway to a length of 1 @,@ 550 yards ( 1 @,@ 417 m ) . [MASK]he land reclamation commenced towards the end of 1941 along with the construc[MASK]ion of an RAF [MASK]amp at the " North F[MASK]ont " , now RAF Gibraltar . The RAF dispatched their next squadron to[MASK]Gibraltar at this time and it was in September[MASK]193[MASK] that wa[MASK] with Germany was declared and the strong possibility of German submarines concentrating in the Strait of Gibraltar and using Spanish port facilities , loomed l[MASK]rge[MASK]in Admiralty thinking . So at 09 : 00 ( UTC ) on the 9 September 1939 , No.[MASK]202 Squadron RAF was ordered to Gibraltar , loaded to the gunwales with equ[MASK]pment . 
 On 25 September 1939 [MASK] No 200 ( Coastal ) Group was formed[MASK]as a subordinate formation to HQ RAF Mediterranean in control of No 202 Sqn . The Group 's function [MASK]as the control of Royal[MASK]Air Force units operating from Gibraltar . In late 1940 the Group was transferre[MASK] to Coastal Command . Later a combined HQ was formed which comme[MASK]ced operations in early 1942 . 
 
 = = Vichy French attacks : 1940 = = 
 
 On 18 July 1940 , af[MASK]er the attack on the French Fleet [MASK]t Mers @-@ el @-@ Kébir by the British , the Vichy [MASK]overnment authorized a bombing raid of Gibraltar as a response . Little dama[MASK]e was reported to have been done . 
 On Tuesday , 24 September , the Italian Stefani news agency reported : " As a reprisal for the bombardment of Dakar yesterday morning , one @-@[MASK]hundred @-@[MASK]and @-@ twenty French aircraft based in Morocco attacked Gibraltar . " On the same day , the [MASK]nited Press Agency reported : " The French government has i[MASK]sued an official denial of reports ,[MASK]according to which French ai[MASK]craft were said to have a[MASK]tacked Gibraltar . Up until now , no reprisals have been undertaken .[MASK]" But the United Press report ended on a[MASK] ominous note with : " French [MASK]eprisals are imminent . " 
 Again , on the same day , the Vi[MASK]hy French go[MASK]ernment issued orders[MASK]for the naval base and city of Gibraltar t[MASK] be bombarded . As a result , six bomber squadrons of the Vichy F[MASK]ench Air Force ( Armée de l 'Air de Vichy ) and four squadrons of the Vichy French Navy ( Marine nationale de Vichy ) were employed in the operation . The 64 bombers f[MASK]ew from bases in Oran , Tafaroui ( in Algeria )[MASK], Meknes , Mediouna , and Port Lyautey ( in Morocco ) . The [MASK]rench action was approved by both the German A[MASK]mistice Commissio[MASK] [MASK]nd the Italian [MASK]rmistice Commission . 
 No British aircraft wer[MASK] encountered and much damage was done in the area south o[MASK] the fortress . The South Mole and a large ship in the harbour were heavily damaged . In the northern part of Gibraltar , fires broke out . 
 On 25 September , the French returned[MASK][MASK]ith a larger force of eighty @-@ three bomber[MASK] to cause additional damage to the naval base and harbour installations . A[MASK]ain [MASK] aircraft of the British Roya[MASK] A[MASK]r Force made no appearance . However , the French crews did report encountering heavy anti @-@ aircraft fire . [MASK]ne LeO 451 bomber was lost and 13 other aircraft were lightly damaged during th[MASK] two days of bombing[MASK]attacks . The British armed trawler HMT Stella Sirius was sun[MASK] by [MASK]o[MASK]bs . 
 The air attack on 25 September was the last by Vichy forces on Gibraltar . 
 
 = = Operation Felix : 1940 [MASK] 1941 = = 
 
 The Rock came through the wa[MASK] relatively unscathed but , given its strategic importance , Germany made p[MASK]ans t[MASK] c[MASK]pture Gibraltar . [MASK]odenamed " Felix " , the plan whi[MASK]h was signed b[MASK] Adolf Hitler himself was formulated at the highes[MASK] level[MASK]of command . With or without permission ,[MASK]Germany would take entry through Spain and attack Gibr[MASK]ltar driving the British out of the Western Mediterranean . The S[MASK]rait would[MASK]be effectively closed to the Allies onc[MASK][MASK]Gibraltar was in German hands , forcing Asia @-@ bound A[MASK]lied shipping to steam all the way around Afri[MASK]a rather than to pr[MASK]ceed to the east via the shorter ro[MASK]te through the Me[MASK]iterranean and the Suez Canal . The Rock was to be heavily dive bombed by planes leaving Fran[MASK]e but landing afterward at Spanish ai[MASK][MASK]bases . To deny a possible Spanish capture of the [MASK]ase , the German planners decided that the final attack to seize Gibraltar was to be made by German troops alone . 
 Diplomatic[MASK]failure at the highest levels of government prevented the operation from occurring at the beginning of 19[MASK]1 which had been drawn up i[MASK] detail by the Wehrma[MASK]ht in the summer and autumn of 1940 [MASK] 
 Gener[MASK]l Ludwig Kübler 's XLIX Corps would conduct t[MASK]e actual attack on the Rock . The assault forces would comprise the Infantry [MASK]e[MASK]iment Großdeutschland , the 98th Regiment of the 1st M[MASK]untain Divis[MASK]on , 26 medium and heavy artillery battalions , three observation battalions , three engineer battalions , two smoke battalions , a[MASK]detachment of 150 Brandenburgers , and up to 150 min[MASK][MASK]ture remote controlled demolition vehicles ( Goliaths ) , packed with hig[MASK] explosives .[MASK]
 [MASK]s part of a combined @-@ force operation , the German Air Force ( Luftwaffe ) would contribute Ju 88As , [MASK]tukas , Messerschmitts , three light AA battalio[MASK]s , and three heavy AA battalions . Nazi Germany 's Kriegsmarin[MASK] would cooperate by usi[MASK]g U @-[MASK] boats to interfere [MASK]ith British naval movement and emplacing coastal batteries to [MASK]urther discourage [MASK]he Royal Navy . 
 On 10 March 1941 , w[MASK]th Operation Barbarossa looming , Felix was amended to Operation Felix @-@ Heinrich , whereby German tro[MASK]p[MASK] would be withdrawn f[MASK]om the USSR to capture Gibraltar . As a result of Spanish dictator Francisco Franco 's i[MASK]transigen[MASK]e [MASK] the operation was postponed , modified , and ultimately abandoned . 
 
 = = Italian bombing of Gibraltar = = 
 
 From Sardinia , Italian Piaggio P.108 bombers attacked Gibraltar several times , [MASK]ainly in 1942 . The last raids on Gibraltar were done during the [MASK]943 Allied landing in Algeria , when those bombers hit [MASK]uccessfully even the Oran port . 
 The only uni[MASK] of the Regia Aeronau[MASK]ica ( Royal Air Force ) ever to fly the Piaggio P.10[MASK] was the " 274th Long @-@ Range Bombardment Squadron " . This unit was fo[MASK]med in May 1941 around the first machines that came off the assembly lines . The training of the cre[MASK]s lasted far longer than a[MASK]ticipated and only in J[MASK]ne[MASK]1942 the 274th became[MASK]operational . [MASK]he most specta[MASK]ular raids with the P. 108 bombe[MASK]s were flown in October 1942 when several nig[MASK]t attacks again[MASK]t Gibraltar were undertaken from Sardinia . 
 After[MASK]the armistice of Cassibile ( 8 S[MASK]ptember ) , the German @-@ allied Italian Social Republic[MASK]launched at least two raids on Gibraltar : one on the night of 4 – 5 June 1944 with ten SM.79bis aircraft and [MASK]nother on 6 June with nin[MASK] aircraft . Both sorties were undertaken by the Gruppo Aerosiluranti " Buscaglia – Faggioni " . 
 
 = = Italian frogmen raids[MASK]194[MASK] – 1943 = = 
 
 Known as the " Floating Trojan Horse of Gibraltar " , [MASK]ecima Flottiglia [MASK]AS , an Italian commando frogman unit created during the Fascist government , engaged in numerous attacks against the harbour at Gibraltar . 
 Gibraltar was a very tempting t[MASK]rget for the Italians[MASK], who[MASK]saw it as a refuge for British warships and allied merchant shipping[MASK][MASK] The Italian frogmen originally used a Spanish villa ( Villa Carmela ) loc[MASK]ted t[MASK]o miles ( 3 km ) from Gibr[MASK]ltar owned by an Itali[MASK]n officer who ha[MASK] m[MASK]rried a Span[MASK]sh woman named Conchita Ramognino . Thei[MASK] base was shifted later[MASK]t[MASK] the Italian tanker SS Olterra , interned in Algeciras . 
 
 = = Abwehr saboteurs fro[MASK] Spain = = 
 
 Lesser known than[MASK]the I[MASK]al[MASK]an actions were the sabotage operation[MASK] and limpet @-@ mine attacks carried out by Spanish and Gibraltarian a[MASK]ent[MASK] recruited in the Campo de Gibraltar by [MASK]he Germans . The Abwehr contacted a Spanish staff officer from Campo de Gibraltar , Lieut[MASK]nant Colonel Eleuterio Sánchez Rubio , a Sp[MASK]nish officer , member of the Falange and coordinator of the intelligence operations in the Campo , to est[MASK]blish a network of saboteur[MASK] with access t[MASK] Gib[MASK]altar . Sánchez Rubio designated Emilio Plazas Tejera , also a member of Falange , as operations chief of the organisation . M[MASK]st of the recruits for the sabotage operations were Spaniards [MASK]rom the Campo [MASK] A combina[MASK]ion of fina[MASK]cial reward , ideological commitment and some threat[MASK] and intimidation were used to gather a significant number of agents . A[MASK]cording to the British intelligence , there were at least 183 Spaniards and Gibraltarians involve[MASK] in the espionage and sabotage operat[MASK]ons against Gibralta[MASK] . 
 Sabotage operations were ordered from Berlin in the [MASK]ate autumn of 1940 , but actual work did not start un[MASK]il early 1941 . The first operations were unsuccessful . A first attempt to smuggle a bomb into Gibra[MASK]tar was aborted , as the timing device was faulty . In February there was a large explosion in the North Tu[MASK]nel , and in April a bo[MASK]b blew up near the ai[MASK]field . In June 1941 , however , the Br[MASK]tish intelligence foiled a new attempt , by a German agent , t[MASK] attach a mine alongside an Allied [MASK]argo sh[MASK]p . Another attempt failed when Plazas placed a bomb inside an ammunition store but[MASK]was not able to bring the explosive . It was not until 1942 that the operations begun t[MASK] succeed . In January 1942 , two Spanish agents manage to destr[MASK]y two air[MASK]ra[MASK]t at the North Front landing st[MASK]ip . 
 Financed , trained and equipped by the Germans , the saboteurs sank the armed trawler HMT Erin , and d[MASK]str[MASK]yed the auxiliary minesweeper HMT Honju , which resulted in the deaths of six British seamen on 18 January 1942 . Plazas was assisted by the Spanish naval command[MASK]r of Puente Mayorg[MASK] , Manuel Romero Hume , who allowed him to beac[MASK] a rowboa[MASK] t[MASK]ere . The British intelligence was able however to counteract the sabotage operations . In Ma[MASK]ch 1942 , a Gibralt[MASK]r[MASK]an , José Key , one of the most prominent agents working[MASK]fo[MASK] the Germans , responsible for the collection [MASK]f information on military movements for the[MASK]Abwehr was a[MASK]rested and executed in [MASK]and[MASK]worth Prison in la[MASK]e 1942 . By September 1942 , P[MASK]azas , whose activities were closely monitored by the British at that time , re[MASK]igned and left Carlos Calvo , his second in [MASK]ommand , in charge [MASK]f the operations . In late 1942 , the German headquarters in Berlin ordered the sabotage operations being expanded[MASK][MASK] In early 1943 , the arrival of an experienced head of Abwe[MASK]r operations in Spain improved the outreach of the oper[MASK]tions [MASK] 
 In March 1943 an ammunition dump was blown up by Calvo 's agents . The B[MASK]itish ,[MASK]growing suspicious of some of the saboteurs , banned them from entering Gibraltar . This forced the Abwehr to ask Calvo for new pe[MASK]sonnel . A Spaniard working on the Rock , José Martín Muñoz , was responsible for the explosion and fir[MASK] at a large fuel tank at Coaling Island on 30 June[MASK]1943 ; this mission , however , would be the[MASK]first and the[MASK]last for Muñoz , because he was cornered and arrested by British authorities in August , when he tried[MASK]to smuggle a bomb into[MASK]a weapons magazine inside Ragged Staff [MASK]ave . After being sen[MASK]enced[MASK]to death , he was hanged on 11 January 1944 in Gibralt[MASK][MASK] by[MASK]British executioner Albert Pierrepoint . A member of an unrelated Abwehr sabot[MASK]ge network , Luis López Cordón @-@ Cuenca [MASK] also arrested in 1943 ) was executed by Pierrepoint on the same day . Calvo himself was put under arrest by the [MASK]panish p[MASK]lice and neu[MASK]ralized . He would be a free man again in December , when he rejoined the Abwehr in Madrid , under di[MASK]ect orders of Wolfgang Blaum , aka Baumann , head of t[MASK]e s[MASK]botage section[MASK]in Spain . After a Falangist[MASK]attempt agains[MASK] the life of pro @-@ allied General José Enrique Varela , perpetrated by Sánchez Rubio network 's agent Juan [MASK]osé Domínguez and a meeting between Anthony Eden and[MASK]the Spanish ambas[MASK]ador at London , Jacobo Fitz @-@ James Stuart , Abwehr activities around Gibraltar came to an end . 
 
 = = Operation T[MASK]acer : 1941 – 1942 = = 
 
 Operation Tracer was a top @-@ secret British stay @-@ b[MASK]hind spying mission that was only [MASK]o be implemented if Gibraltar was captured by [MASK]he Axis Powers . Six men were to be sea[MASK]ed in a cave and left with only enough [MASK]upplies for a year . The volunteers — two doctors , three signalmen and their leader — would[MASK]run an obser[MASK]ation post with one 12 @-@ inch ( 300 mm ) by 6 @-@ inch ( 150 mm ) slit looking ov[MASK]r the harbour and a concealed outdoor terrace[MASK]over the Mediterranean . Th[MASK] team[MASK]would then wire back all s[MASK]ipping movement[MASK] to the British Admiralty . 
 They were told there would be no way out and anyone who died within the chamber would have to be embalmed and cemented into the brick floor . Only if Germany was defeated within their first year would they be released . 
 As the threat of invasion [MASK]as clear[MASK]y felt in [MASK]ate 1941 , an [MASK]dea for a series of s[MASK]cret obse[MASK]vation posts ( first in Gibraltar and later in other places like Malta and Aden [MASK] was put together under Operation Tracer . 
 Work in Gibraltar began immediately under Commander Ge[MASK]ffrey Birley and his chief engineer Colonel F[MASK]rdham . T[MASK]e site chosen at Lord Airey 's Battery on th[MASK] southern tip of the Rock already had an existing tunnelling scheme for a shelter . Extensive trials of the equipment began in January 1[MASK]42 under the eye[MASK]of MI6 radio expert Colonel Richard Gambier @-@ Parry . Much thought was also given to the type of men needed for such a strange and demanding [MASK]ask . A member of Scott ’[MASK]s ill @-@ fated expedition to the Antarctic , George Murray Lev[MASK]ck was called up as Surgeon[MASK]@-@ Commander to advise on survi[MASK]al techniq[MASK]es . There we[MASK]e practical matters such as diet , exercise , sanitation , and [MASK]lothing to conside[MASK] as well as vital " psychology of the personnel " . The full team was in place by the end of sum[MASK]er 1942 and their [MASK]avern fu[MASK][MASK]y equipped a[MASK]d ready for occupation . A comprehensive manual was prepared on all aspects of the operation and it was considered that similar secret lookout posts should be prepar[MASK]d throug[MASK]out the world i[MASK] the event o[MASK] future wars . However , Operation Tracer was never needed , as Adolf Hitler turned his attention awa[MASK] from Gibraltar and towards the Eastern Front . 
 The [MASK]peration had been clouded in mystery until the discovery of papers at the Public Record Office in Kew UK . Previously in the 1960s , details of the story were [MASK][MASK]ld to a journalist by his intelligence service cont[MASK]ct[MASK] an[MASK] he wrote these up as " Oper[MASK]tion Monkey " , yet fac[MASK]s were very sparse . 
 In 199[MASK] " Stay Behind Cave " ( as it wa[MASK] nicknamed ) was discovered in Gibraltar by the Gibraltar Cavi[MASK]g Group , but no accou[MASK]t was ever obtained from anyone associated with the mission . The discovery came about when the group enco[MASK]ntered a strong gust of wind in a tunnel . Further searching led them to break through a wall into chambers which had never been used and had remained sealed for over 50 years . 
 In November 2006 Jim Crone and Sergeant Major Pete Jackson , senior tunnel guide with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment , met possibly the only member of Operatio[MASK] Tracer[MASK]still alive when they travelled to meet Dr. W. A. Bruce Cooper at his home i[MASK] Eng[MASK]and . Cooper , 92 at the time , provid[MASK]d an opportunity to shed[MASK]light on the operation with his direct involvement in the mission as a [MASK]u[MASK]geon @-@ Lieutenant in the Royal Navy Volunteer Reserve ( RNVR ) . He recalled stories about his colleagues , his training , and his feelings about the[MASK]task . 
 
 = = Mediterranean U @-@ boat Campaign : 1[MASK]41 – 1944 = = 
 
 The Medi[MASK]erranean U @-@ boat Campaign lasted approximately from 21 September 1941 to May 1944 . The Kriegsmarine tried to isolate Gibraltar , Malta , a[MASK]d Suez and disrupt Britain 's trade routes . More than sixty U @-@ boats were sent to interdict Allied s[MASK]ipping in the Mediterranean Sea . Many of these U[MASK]@-@ boa[MASK]s were[MASK][MASK]hemselves attacked negotiating the Strait of Gibraltar controlled by Britain . Nine U @-@ bo[MASK]ts were sunk while attempting passage and t[MASK]n more were d[MASK]maged . 
 
 = = [MASK]orth African Campaign : 1942 = [MASK] 
 
 Plans for the Allied counter of[MASK]ensive after[MASK]the attack on Pearl Harbor were ongoing by mid @-@ 1942 . An invasion of Europe in 1943 would be unworkable , but the allies could attack t[MASK]e " soft underbelly of Europe " through the Mediterranean , as Prime Minister Winston Churchill put it . Devis[MASK]d by President Fran[MASK]lin Roosevelt an[MASK] Churchill and code named Operation Torch , the plan was to occu[MASK][MASK] French North Africa : Morocco , Algeri[MASK] , and Tunisia . From these French colonies , attacks could be launched that would drive Italy out of the war . 
 In July 1942 , Lieutenant General [MASK][MASK]ight D. Eisenhower was appointed Allied[MASK]Commander @-@ in @-@ Chi[MASK]f of Operation Torch . Churchill placed Gibraltar under the command of General Eisenhower as the temporary headquarters for this , the first large @-@[MASK]scale [MASK]nglo @-@ American operation of the war . He arrived in Gibraltar on 5 November 1942 to take[MASK]o[MASK]er , not just command of Operation Torch itself , but also military command of Gibraltar . 
 General Eisenhower stayed at The Conve[MASK]t , the official Governor 's residence ,[MASK]but his operational headquarters were in a s[MASK]all chamber in a tunnel in the heart of the Rock . In his m[MASK]moirs General[MASK]Eisenhower[MASK]wrote : 
 The subterranean passages under the Rock provided the sole available offic[MASK] space , and i[MASK] the[MASK] was located the signal equipment by which we expecte[MASK] to keep in touch with the commanders of the three assault forces . The eternal darkness of the tunnels was here and there partially [MASK]ierced by fee[MASK]le electric bulbs . Damp , cold[MASK]air in block @-@ long passages was heavy with stagnation and did not noticeably respo[MASK]d to the clattering effort[MASK] of electric fans . Through the arched ceilings came a constant drip , drip , drip o[MASK] surface water [MASK]hat faithfully but drearily ti[MASK]ke[MASK] off the seconds of the interminable , almost unendurable , wait which always occurs between completion of a military plan and the m[MASK]ment actio[MASK] begins . 
 One hundred thousand soldiers on [MASK]h[MASK] high seas in a mu[MASK]titude of transports converged on Gibraltar . More than 400 aircraft of all types [MASK]ere crammed into t[MASK]e dispersa[MASK] areas aroun[MASK] [MASK]he Gibraltar runway . Fighters had [MASK]een shipped in crates[MASK]and assembled on th[MASK] airfiel[MASK] . Every available are[MASK] of stora[MASK]e was taken up with ammunition , fuel , and other essential supplies . 168[MASK]American pilots were housed in the RAF messe[MASK] at North Fro[MASK]t . 
 On 8 [MASK]ovember 1942 , 466 aircraft from Gibraltar la[MASK]ded on captured North African airfields . 
 From their h[MASK]adquarters in Gibraltar , General Eisenhower and Admiral Sir Andre[MASK] B[MASK]owne Cunningham directed Operation Torch , the first major combined[MASK]combat operation during World War II involving American and British forces . 
 
 = = [MASK] War tunnels = = = 
 
 Given that Gibraltar was a small town with only a few defences protecting[MASK]it , the solution was to build a massive series of [MASK]unnels and chambers inside the natural protection of the Rock of Gibraltar . This " town " inside the Rock conta[MASK]ned its own power stati[MASK]n , water supply , and [MASK]ospital . Some soldiers posted here would[MASK]not see the light of day for months on end . Two Canadian engineer companies , the only soldiers with diamond @-@ tipped drills and 5 British engineer companies , added some 30 miles ( 48 km ) of such tunnels , a feat thought impossible at the time . That was enough to hold all 30 @,@ 000 troops on the rock .[MASK]T[MASK]day , the rock has more undergroun[MASK] tunnels th[MASK]n roads . 
 
 = = Death of Władysław Sikorski : 1943 = = 
 
 On 4 July 1943 , a Liberator bomber from RAF Transpo[MASK]t Command took off fr[MASK]m Gibraltar for England . On board w[MASK]s General Władysław Sikorski , Prime Minister of Poland[MASK]'s London @-@ based government in exile and Commander @-@ in @-@ Chief of its armed forces , returning from visiting Poli[MASK]h troops in the Middle East . 
 The aircraft climbed normally from the runway , levelled [MASK]ff to [MASK]ath[MASK]r speed but then s[MASK]ddenly lost[MASK]height and crashed into the harbour . The 62 @-@ year @-@ old general died , along with 15 others . The sole survivor was the Czech @-@ born pilot , Eduard [MASK]rchal , who was rescued by an RAF launch . The bodies of five passengers and crew [MASK] including Sikorski 's daughter , were never found . 
 The coffins of Ge[MASK]eral Sikorski and his Chief @-@ of @-@ [MASK]taff , General Kilimec[MASK]i , wer[MASK] draped in the Polish National Flag and lay in state in the Cathedral of St. Mary the Crowned . After a Requiem Mass , the bodies were carried in procession to the H.M. Dockyard with full Military Honours to be shipped to London in anticipation that[MASK]General Sikorski 's remains would one day be returned to a liberated Poland[MASK]. The route to th[MASK] dockyard was lined by British troops an[MASK] the coffins carri[MASK]d and escorted by Polish Servicemen . 
 
 = = = Investi[MASK]ation = = = 
 [MASK] In 194[MASK] a British Court of Inquiry investigated the crash of Sikorski 's Liberato[MASK] II AL523 , but was unable to determine the probable cause [MASK] finding only that it was an [MASK]ccident and the " aircraft became uncontrollable for reasons which cannot be established " . A popular theory was insufficient technical maintenance leading to jamming aircraft controls . Despite this finding , the political context of the event , coupled[MASK]with a variety of curious circumstan[MASK]es , immediately gave rise to speculation that Sikorski 's death ha[MASK] been[MASK]no accident , and may in fact have been the direct result of a Soviet , British or even Polish conspiracy . 
 
 = = After[MASK]ath = = 
 
 The[MASK]surrender of Italy in Septemb[MASK]r 1943 lifted any possible o[MASK]jections to the return [MASK]f the evacuees to the Rock . As a result , a Resettlement Board was established in [MASK]ovember , and at a meeting[MASK]of the B[MASK]ard on[MASK]8 February 1944 repatriatio[MASK] priorities were finally agreed . On[MASK]6 April 1944 the first group of 1 @,@ 367 r[MASK]patriates arrived on the Rock directly from the United[MASK]Kingdom and on 28 May , the first repat[MASK]iation party left Madeira , and by the end of 1944 only 520 non @-@ priorit[MASK] evacuees remained on th[MASK] island . 
 In London , home @-@ comers were making cl[MASK]ims on the evacuees ’ wartime accommodation and 500 Gibraltarians were re @-@ evacuated to Scotland and 3 @,@ 000 to camps in Northern Ireland . Alth[MASK]ugh the Governor , Lt. General[MASK]Sir Noel Mason @-@ MacFarlan[MASK] , fought valiantly on behalf of the evacuees and did not accept the lac[MASK] of accommodation as a[MASK]sufficient reason for the delays . As late as 1947 there were still 2 @,@ 000 in Northern Irish camps . T[MASK]e last of the evacuees did not see the Rock again until 1951 .

 = Nerva[MASK]= 
 
 Nerva ( Latin : Marcus Cocceius Nerva C[MASK]esar Augustus ; 8 November , 30 AD – 27 Januar[MASK] , 98 AD ) was Roman Empe[MASK]or from 96 to 98 . Nerva became Emperor at the age[MASK]of sixty @-@ five , after a lifetime o[MASK] imperial service under Nero and the rulers of the Flavian dy[MASK]asty . Under Nero , [MASK]e was a member of the imperial entourage an[MASK] pl[MASK]yed a vital p[MASK]r[MASK] in exposing the Pisoni[MASK]n conspiracy of 65 . Later , as a loyalist to the Flavians , he attained consulships in 71 and 90 during the reigns of Vespasian and [MASK]omitian respectivel[MASK] . 
[MASK]On 18 September 96 , Domitian was assassinated in a palace conspiracy[MASK]involving members of the Praetorian Guard and several of his fre[MASK]dmen . On the [MASK]ame day [MASK] Nerva was declared emperor by the Roman Senate . This was the first time the Senate elected a Roman Emperor . As the new ruler of the Roman Empire , he vowed to restore liberties which [MASK]ad been cur[MASK]ailed during the autocrati[MASK] government of[MASK]Domitian . 
 Nerva 's brief reign was marred by financial difficulties and his inability to assert his authority over the Roman army . A revolt by the Praetorian Guard in October 97 e[MASK][MASK]entially forced him to adopt an heir . After some [MASK]eliberati[MASK]n Nerva adopted Trajan , a young and popular general , as his successor . After barely fifteen months in office , Nerva died of na[MASK]ural c[MASK]uses on [MASK]7 January 98 . Upon his death he was [MASK]ucceeded and deified by Trajan . 
 Although much of his life remains obscure , [MASK]erva was considered a wise and m[MASK]derate emperor by ancient historians . Nerva 's greatest succes[MASK] was his abili[MASK]y to ensure a peaceful transition of [MASK]ower after his death , thus [MASK]oundi[MASK][MASK] the Nerva – [MASK]ntonine dynasty . 
 
 = = Early career = = 
 
 
 = = = Family = = = 
 
 Marcus Cocceius Nerva was born in the village of Narni , 50 kilometers north of Rome , to the fa[MASK]ily of Marcus Cocceius Nerva , Suffect Consul in 40 , and Sergia Plautilla . Ancient sources report the date as either 30[MASK]or 35 . He had at least one attested s[MASK]ster , named [MASK]occeia[MASK], who married Lucius Salvius Titianus Otho , the brother of the future Emperor Otho . 
 Like Vespasian , the founder of the Flavia[MASK] dynast[MASK] , Nerva was a member of the Italian nobility rather than one of the elite of Rome . Nevertheless , the Cocceii were am[MASK]ng the most esteemed and prominent p[MASK]liti[MASK]al families of the late Republic and early Empire [MASK] attaining consu[MASK]ships in e[MASK]ch suc[MASK]essive generation . The direct an[MASK]estors of Nerva on his father 's side[MASK], all named Marcus Cocceius Nerva , were associated with imperial circles since the time of Emperor Augustus ( 27 BC – [MASK]D 14 ) . 
 His great @-@ grandfather w[MASK]s Consul in 36 BC ( in repl[MASK]cement , and abdicated ) , and Governor of[MASK]Asia in the same year . Hi[MASK] grandfa[MASK]her became Consul Suffect in J[MASK]ly of eithe[MASK] 21 or 22 , and was known as a personal friend of Emperor Tiberius ( AD 14 – 37 ) , accompanying the emperor during his voluntary seclusion on Capri from 23 onwards , dying in 33 . Nerva 's father , finally , attained the consulship in 40 u[MASK]der emperor Caligula ( 37 – 41 ) . The Cocceii were connected with the Julio @-@ Claudian dynasty through the marriage of Sergia Plautilla 's brother Octavius Laenas , and Rubellia Bassa , the great @-@ granddaughter [MASK]f Tiberi[MASK]s . 
 
 = = = Im[MASK]erial service = = = 
 
 [MASK]ot much of Nerva 's early life or career is recorded , but it appears he did not pursue the usual administrative or military career . He was praetor @-@ elect in the year 65 and ,[MASK]like his ancestors , moved in imperial circles as a skilled diplomat and strategist . As an advi[MASK]or to Emperor Nero , he successfully helped detect and expose the Pisonian conspiracy of 65 . Exactly what his contribution to the investigation was is not known but his services must have been considerable , since they earn[MASK]d him re[MASK]ards equal to those of Nero 's guard prefect [MASK]igellinus . He received triumphal ho[MASK]ors — which w[MASK][MASK] [MASK]sually reserved for military victories — and the right to have his s[MASK]atues placed throughout the palace . 
 According to the contemporary poet Martial , Ner[MASK] also held Nerva 's literary abilities in high esteem , hailing him as the " Tibullus of our time " . Another prominent[MASK]member of Ner[MASK] 's entourage was Vespasian , an old and r[MASK]spected general who had celebrated military triumphs during the 40s . It appears Vespasian[MASK]befriended Nerva during his time as an imperial advisor , and may have asked him to watch over Ves[MASK]asian 's youngest son Domitian when Vespasian departed for the Jewish war in 67 . 
 The suicide of Nero on 9 June 68 brought the Julio @-@ Claudian dyn[MASK]sty to an end , lea[MASK]ing to [MASK]he chaotic Year of the Four Emperors , which saw the successive rise and fall of[MASK]t[MASK]e emp[MASK]rors Galba [MASK] Otho and Vitellius , until the accession of Vespasian on 21 December 69 . Virtually nothing is known of Nerva 's whereabouts during 69 , but despite the fact that Otho was his brother @-@ in @-@ law , he appears[MASK]to have be[MASK]n one of the earliest a[MASK]d strongest supporters of the Flavians . 
 For services unknown[MASK], he was[MASK]rewarded with a consulship early in Vespasia[MASK] 's rei[MASK]n in 71 . This was a remarkable honour[MASK], not only be[MASK]aus[MASK] he held this office early und[MASK]r the new regime , but also because it was an ordinary consulship ( instead of a less prestigious [MASK]uffect co[MASK]sulship ) , making him one of the few non @-@ Flavians to be honoured in this way under Ves[MASK]asian . After 71 Nerva [MASK]gain disappears from historical record , presumably continuing his career as an inconspicuous advisor under Vespasi[MASK]n ( 69 – 79 ) and his sons Titus ( 79 – 81 ) and Do[MASK]itian ( 8[MASK] – 96 ) . 
 He re @-@ emerges during the revolt of Saturni[MASK]us in 89 . On 1 January , 89 , the governor of Germania Superior , Lucius Antonius Saturninus , and his two legions at Mainz , Legio XIV Gemina and Legio XXI Rapax , revolted against the Roman Empir[MASK] with the aid of a tribe of the Chatti . The governor of Germania Inferior , Lappius Maximus , moved to the region at once , assisted by the procurator of Rhaetia , Titus [MASK]lavius Nor[MASK]anu[MASK] [MASK][MASK]Within twenty @-@ four days the rebellion wa[MASK] crushed , and its leaders at Mainz savagely punished . The mutinous legions were sen[MASK] to the front of Illyricum , while those who had assisted in their defeat were duly[MASK]rewarded . 
 Domitian opened the year fol[MASK]owing the revolt by sharing [MASK]he [MASK]onsulsh[MASK]p with Nerva . Again , the honour suggested Nerva had played a part in unc[MASK]vering the conspiracy , perhaps in a fashion similar to what he did during the Pisonian conspir[MASK]cy under Nero . Alter[MASK]atively , Domitian m[MASK]y have selec[MASK]ed Nerva[MASK]as his colleague to em[MASK]hasise the st[MASK]bility and status @-@ quo of the regime . The revolt had been suppressed , and the Empire could return to order . 
 
 = = [MASK]mperor = = 
 
 
 = = = Accession = = = 
 
 On 18 September , 96 , Domitian was assassinated in a palace conspiracy org[MASK]nise[MASK] by court officials . The Fasti Ostienses , the Ostian Calendar , re[MASK]ords that the same day the Senate[MASK]proclaimed Marcus Cocceius Nerva emperor . Despite his political experience[MASK], this was a remarkable choice . Nerva was ol[MASK] and childless , and had spent much of his [MASK]areer out of the [MASK]ublic light , prompting both[MASK]ancient and modern authors to speculate on his involvement in Domitian[MASK]'s assassination . 
 According to Cassius Dio , the conspir[MASK]to[MASK]s [MASK]pproached Nerva as a potential successor prior to the assassination , which indicates that he was at least aware of the plot . Suetonius by contrast does no[MASK] mention Nerva , but he may have omitted his role out of tactfulness . Considering the wo[MASK]ks of Suetonius were published under Nerva 's direct[MASK]descendants Trajan and Hadrian , it would hav[MASK] been [MASK]ess than sensitiv[MASK] of him to suggest the dynasty owed its accession to murder . On the other hand , Nerva lac[MASK]ed widespread support in the Empire , and as a kn[MASK]wn Flavian loy[MASK]list his tr[MASK]ck record would not have recommended him to the conspirators . The precise facts have been obscured by hi[MASK]tory , but modern historians believe N[MASK]rva was p[MASK]oclaimed Emperor solely on the initiative of t[MASK]e Senate , within hours after the news of the assassination broke . 
 Although he appeared to be an unlikely c[MASK]ndidate on account of his age and weak health , Nerva was considered a safe choice [MASK]recisely because[MASK]he was [MASK]ld and childless . Furthermore , he had close connections with the F[MASK]avian dynasty and command[MASK]d the respect of a substantial part of the Senate . Nerva ha[MASK] seen the anarchy [MASK]hich had resulted from the death of Nero ; he knew that to hesitate even for a few hours could lead to violent civil conflict . [MASK]ather than dec[MASK]ine the invitation and risk revolts , he[MASK]accepted . The decision may have been hasty so as to[MASK]avoid civil war , but neither the Senate n[MASK]r Nerva appears to have been involve[MASK] in the conspiracy against Domitian . 
 Following the [MASK]ccess[MASK]on of Nerva as emperor , the Senate passed damnatio memoriae on D[MASK]mitian [MASK] his coins and statues were melted , his arches were torn down and his name was erased from all public records . In many instances , existing portraits of Domitia[MASK] , such as those found on the Cancelleria Reliefs , were simply recarved [MASK]o fit t[MASK]e likeness of Nerva . Thi[MASK] allo[MASK]ed quic[MASK] prod[MASK]ction of new images and recycling of previous material . In addition , the vast palac[MASK] which Do[MASK]itian had erected on the Palatine[MASK]Hill , known as the Flavian Palace , was[MASK]renamed the " House of the People " , and Nerva himself to[MASK]k up residence in Ves[MASK]asian 's former villa in the Gardens of Sallust . 
 
 = = = Administration = = = 
 
 [MASK]he change of government was welcome particularly to the senators , who had been harshly perse[MASK]uted duri[MASK]g Domitian 's reign . As an immediate gesture of goodwill towards his supporters , Nerva [MASK]ublicly swore that no senators would be put to death as long as he r[MASK]mained in office . He called an end to trials based on treason , release[MASK][MASK]thos[MASK][MASK]who had been[MASK]imprisoned under these[MASK]charges , and granted amnesty to many who had been exiled . 
 All proper[MASK]ies which[MASK]had been confiscated by Domi[MASK]ian were returned to their respective f[MASK]milies . Nerva also sought to involve the Senate in his government , but this was not entirely successful . He continued to rely largely on friends and advisors that were known and trusted [MASK] and by maintaining friendly relations with the pro @-@ Domitianic faction of the Sena[MASK]e , he incurred hostility which may have been the cause for at least one conspiracy against his life . 
 Having been proclaimed emperor solely on the initiative of the Senate , Nerva ha[MASK] to introduce a number of measures to gain support among the Roman popu[MASK]ace . As was custom by this time , a change of emperor was expected to bring with it a generous[MASK]payment of gifts and money to the people and the army . Accordingly , a congiarium of 75[MASK]denarii per head was bestowed upon th[MASK] citizens , while the soldiers of the Praetorian Guard received a donativum which may have amounted[MASK]to as much as 5000 denarii per person . This was followed by [MASK] string of economic reforms intended to alleviate the burden of taxa[MASK]ion [MASK]rom the most needy[MASK]Rom[MASK]ns . 
 To the p[MASK]orest [MASK] Nerva gran[MASK]ed allotments of land worth up to 60 million sesterces . He exempted parents and their child[MASK]en from a 5 % inheritance tax , and he made loans to Italian landowners on the [MASK]ondition that they pay interest of 5 % to their mun[MASK]cipality to support the children of needy families ; alimentary schemes which were later expanded by Trajan , Antoninus Pius , and Marcus Aurel[MASK]us . Furthermore , numerous taxes were remitted and privileges granted to Roman provinces . Namel[MASK] , he probably abolished the Fiscus Iudaicus , the[MASK]additional tax which all Jews thr[MASK]ughout the Empire had to pay [MASK] some of his coins bear the legend FISCI IUDAICI CALUMNIA SUBLATA ( abolition of malicious prosecution regarding[MASK]the Jewish tax ) . 
 Before long , Nerva 's expenses strained the[MASK]economy of Rome and , although perhaps n[MASK]t ruinous to the ext[MASK]nt once suggested by Syme , necessitated the formation of a special commission of econom[MASK] to drastically reduce ex[MASK]enditures . The most superfluous religious sacrifices , games and horse [MASK]aces were abolished , while new income was generated from Domitian 's former possessions , including the auctioning of ships , estates , and even furniture . L[MASK]rge amounts of money wer[MASK] obtained from Domitian 's silver[MASK]and gold s[MASK]a[MASK]ues , and Nerva forbade that similar images be made in his honor . 
 Because he reigned only briefly , Nerva[MASK]'s public works were [MASK]ew , instead completing projects whic[MASK] had been initi[MASK]ted under Flavian rule . This included extensive repairs to the Roman road system and the expansi[MASK]n of the aqueducts . The latter program was headed by the former consul Sextus Julius Frontinus , who helped to put an end to abuses and later published a sign[MASK]ficant work on Rome 's water supply , De Aquis Urbis Romae . The onl[MASK] major landmarks constructed under Nerva were a gra[MASK]ary , known as the Horrea Nervae , and a small [MASK]mperial Forum begun by Domitian [MASK] which linked t[MASK]e Forum o[MASK] Augustus to [MASK]he Temple of Peace . Little remains , partly because the [MASK]ia dei Fori Imperiali cuts across it . 
 
 = = = C[MASK]isis of succession = = = 
 
 Despite Nerva 's measures to remain popular with the Senate and the Roman people [MASK] support for Do[MASK]it[MASK]an remained strong in th[MASK] army , which had called for his deification immediat[MASK]ly[MASK]after the assassin[MASK]tion . In an attempt to appease the soldiers of the Praetorian Guard , Nerva had dism[MASK]ssed their prefect Titus Petr[MASK]nius Secundus — one of the chief conspirators against Domitian — and replaced him with a former comm[MASK]nder , Casperius Aelianus . 
 Likewise , [MASK]he genero[MASK]s donativum bestowed [MASK]pon the [MASK]oldiers following his accession was expected to swiftly silence any protests against the [MASK]iole[MASK]t r[MASK]gime change . The Praetorians considered these measures insufficient , however , and demanded the execu[MASK]ion of Domitian 's assassins , which Nerva refused . Continued dissatisfaction with t[MASK]is state of affairs would ultimat[MASK]ly lead to the gravest crisis of Nerva 's reign . 
 While the swift transfer of power following Domitian 's death had prevented a civil[MASK]war from eruptin[MASK] , Nerva 's position as an emperor soon proved too vulnerable , an[MASK] his benign nature [MASK]urned into a reluctance[MASK]to assert his authority . Upon his accession , he had ordered a halt t[MASK] treason trials , but at the same time allowed the prosecution of informers by the Senate to continue . T[MASK]is mea[MASK]ure led to chaos , as everyone acted in his own interests while trying to settle[MASK][MASK]cores with persona[MASK] enemies , leading the consul [MASK]ronto to famously remark that Domitian 's tyranny was ultimately preferable to Nerva 's ana[MASK]chy . Early in 97 , a conspiracy led by the senator Gaius Calpurnius Piso Crassus Frugi Licinianus failed , but once ag[MASK]in Nerva refus[MASK]d to put the con[MASK]pirators to death , much to the disapproval of the Senate . 
 The situation was further aggravated by the absence of a c[MASK]ear successor , made more pressing because of Nerva 's old age and sickness . He had no natural children of his own and only di[MASK]tant relatives , who were unsuited for political office . A successor would have to be chosen [MASK]rom among the governors or generals in the Empi[MASK]e [MASK]nd it appears that , by 9[MASK] , Nerva was considering to adopt Marcus Cornelius Nigrinus Curiatius Maternus , the powerful g[MASK]vernor of Syria . This was cover[MASK]ly opposed by those who supported the more popular mil[MASK]tary commander Marcus Ulpius[MASK]Traianus , commonly known as [MASK]rajan , a general of the armies at the German frontier . 
 I[MASK] Oc[MASK]ober [MASK]7 these tensions came to a head when the Praetorian Guard , led by Casperius Aelianus , laid siege to the[MASK]Impe[MASK]ial Palace and too[MASK] Ne[MASK]va host[MASK]ge . He was forced to submit to their dema[MASK]ds , [MASK]greeing to hand over those responsible for Domitian 's death and even giving a speech [MASK]hanking the rebellious Pra[MASK]torians . Tit[MASK]s[MASK]Petronius[MASK]Secundus and Parthenius , Domitian 's former chamberlain , were [MASK]ou[MASK]ht out and killed . Nerva was unharmed in this assault , but his authority was damaged beyond repair . 
 He realized that his position was no longer tenable without the support of an heir who had the approval of both [MASK]he army an[MASK] the people . Shortly thereafter , he announced the adoption of Trajan as his successor , and with this dec[MASK]sion all but abdicated . Trajan was formally bestowed with the title of Caesar and shared the[MASK]consulship with Nerva in 98 : 
 Contrary to the view here popularized by Cassius[MASK]D[MASK]o , [MASK]owever , Nerva had in fact little choice with regard to his successor . Faced with a major crisis , he des[MASK]erate[MASK]y needed the su[MASK]port of a man who co[MASK]ld restore his[MASK]damaged reputation . The only candidate wi[MASK]h sufficient military experience ,[MASK]consular ancestry , and connections was Tra[MASK]an . Likewise , Edward Gibbon 's assertion that Nerva hereby established a tradition of succession through adoption among the Fi[MASK]e Go[MASK]d Emperors has found little support among modern historians . 
 
 = = Death and legacy = = 
 
 On 1 January , 98 , at the start of his fourth consulship[MASK], N[MASK]rva suffered a stroke[MASK]during a priva[MASK]e audience . Shortly thereafter he was struck by a fever and died at his villa in the Gardens of Sallust , on 28[MASK]January . H[MASK] was deified by the [MASK]enate , and his ashes were laid to rest in the Mausoleum of Augustus . 
 Nerva was succeeded without inciden[MASK] by his adopted son Trajan , who was greeted by the[MASK]Roman populace with much enthusiasm . According to Pliny the Younger , Trajan dedicated a temple in honour of Nerva , yet no [MASK]race of [MASK]t has ever been found ; no[MASK] was a commemorati[MASK]e series of coins for the Deified Nerva issued [MASK]ntil ten years after his death . According to Cassius Dio , however , the Guard prefect responsible for th[MASK] mutiny against Nerva , C[MASK][MASK]perius Aelianus , was ' dism[MASK]ssed ' upon Trajan 's [MASK]ccession . 
 Due to the lack of written sources on this period , much of Nerva 's lif[MASK] has remained obscure . The most substantial surviving account of the reign of Nerva was written by the 3rd [MASK]-@ century historian Cassius Dio . His Roma[MASK] History , which spans nearly a millennium , from the arrival of Aenea[MASK] in Italy until the year 229 , was composed more th[MASK]n one hundred years after Ner[MASK]a had died . Further detai[MASK]s are added by an abridged biography from the Epito[MASK]e de Caesaribus , a[MASK]work allege[MASK][MASK]to have been authored by the 4th @-@ century historian Aurelius Victor . 
 A more comprehensive te[MASK]t , presumed to describe the life of Nerva in closer detail , is the Histories[MASK], by the c[MASK]ntemporary hi[MASK]toria[MASK] Tacitus . The His[MASK]ories is an account of the history of Rome c[MASK]vering th[MASK]ee decades[MASK]from the suicide of emperor Nero in 69 until the death of Domitian in 96 . Unfortunately , a substantial part of the work has b[MASK]en l[MASK]st , wit[MASK] only the first five books covering the Year of the Four Emperors remaining . In the introduction to his biography of Gnaeus Julius Agricola however , Tacitus speaks highly of Nerva , describing his reign as " the dawn [MASK]f a most happy age , [ when ] Nerva Caesar bl[MASK]nded things once irreconcilable , sovereignty and freedom [MASK] . 
 The surviving his[MASK]ories sp[MASK]ak equally positively of Nerva 's brief reign , although none offer a substantial commentary on his policies . Both Cassius Dio an[MASK] Aurelius Victor emphasize his wisdom and mo[MASK][MASK]ration , with Dio commending his decis[MASK]on to[MASK]adopt Trajan as his heir . These views were later popularized by the 18th @-@ century historian E[MASK]ward Gibbon in his History of the Decl[MASK]ne and Fall o[MASK] the Roman Empire . Gibbon considered Nerva the first of the Five Good Emperors , five successive rulers under whom the Roman Empire " was governed by absolute powe[MASK] , under the guidance of wisdom and vir[MASK]ue " from 96 until 180 . Neverth[MASK]less , even Gibbon notes that , compared to h[MASK][MASK] successors , Nerva may have lacked the necessary qualifications for a successful reign : 
 Modern history has expanded upon this sentiment , characterizing Nerva as a well @-@ intentioned but weak and ineffectual ruler . The Roman Senate enjoyed renewed liberties under his rule[MASK], but Nerva 's mismanagement of the state finances and lack of authority over[MASK]the army ultimately brought Rome near the edge of a signific[MASK]nt crisis . The mutiny led[MASK]by Casperius Aelianus was never intended as a c[MASK]up , [MASK]ut a cal[MASK]ulated attempt to put pressure on the emperor . The adoption of Trajan expand[MASK]d his power base with a respected , reliable general as his successor . Murison[MASK]concludes that Nerva 's real talents were in fact ill @-@ suited to the emperorship : 
 His pla[MASK]e in Roman history i[MASK] therefore summari[MASK]ed as a necess[MASK]ry , if tum[MASK]ltuous stop @-@ gap b[MASK]fore the Trajanic @-@ [MASK]ntonine dynasties . It is a fact of irony that even the only major pub[MASK]ic work completed during his reign , the Forum of Nerva , ultimat[MASK]ly became known as the Forum Transitorium , or transi[MASK]ional forum . 
 Two modern statues which commemorate Nerva can be found in towns associated with him . There is an equestrian statue in Gloucester , England , a town which was founded in his honour .[MASK]It is a[MASK] the e[MASK]trance to Southgate Street . There is also a statue at his alleged birthplace , Narni in Italy , at Cocceio Nerva street .

 = The Hu[MASK]tler ( film ) =

It tells the story of small @-@ time pool[MASK]hustler " Fast Eddie " Felson and his desire to break into the " major league " of professional[MASK]hustling and high @-@ stakes wagering by high @-@ rollers th[MASK]t follows it . He throws his[MASK]raw talent and ambition up [MASK]gainst the best player in the country ; seeking to best the legendary pool player " Minnesota F[MASK]ts[MASK]. " After initially losing to Fats and gettin[MASK] involv[MASK]d with unscrupulous manager Bert Gordon , Eddie returns to try again , but only after paying a terrible personal price . 
 The film was shot on location in New York City . It stars Paul Newman as " Fast " Eddie Felson[MASK], Jackie Gleason as Minnesota Fats , Piper Laurie as Sarah , and George C. Scott as Bert . 
 The Hustler was a major critical and popular success , gaining a reputation as a modern classic . Its exploration of winning , losing , and character garnered a number of major awards ; it is also credited with helping to spark a resurg[MASK]nce in the popularity of[MASK]pool . Real @-@ life pool player Rudolf Wanderone , known at the time as " New York Fats " and " Chicago Fats " , claimed to be the real life inspira[MASK]ion for Gleason 's[MASK]charact[MASK]r , Minnesota [MASK]ats , and adopted[MASK]the name as his own .

 Small @-@ time pool hustler " [MASK]ast Eddie " Felson travels cross @-@ country w[MASK]th his partner Char[MASK]ie to challenge the legendary player " Minnesota[MASK]Fats " . A[MASK]riving at [MASK]ats ' home pool hall , Eddie declares he will win $ 10 @,@ 000 that night . Fats arrive[MASK] and he and Eddie[MASK]agree to play[MASK]straight pool for $ 200 a game . After initially falling behind , Eddie surges back to being $ 1 @,@ 000 ahead and suggests raising the bet to $ 1 @,@ 000 a ga[MASK]e ; Fats agrees .  Eddie stashes his belongings at the local bus terminal , where he[MASK]meets Sarah Packard , an alcoholic who is supported by her father , attends college part @-@ time , and walks with a limp . He meets her again at a bar . They go back to[MASK]her place but she refuses to let him in , saying he is " too hungry " . Ed[MASK]ie moves into a roomi[MASK]g house and starts hustling for small stakes . He finds Sarah again and this time she takes him in , but with reservations . Charlie finds Eddie at Sarah 's a[MASK]d tries to persuade him to go back out on the road . Eddie refuses and Charlie realizes he plans to challenge Fats again . Eddie realizes that C[MASK]arlie hel[MASK] out[MASK]his percentage and [MASK]ecomes enraged , believing that with that money he could have rebounded to beat Fats .[MASK]Eddie dismisses Charlie as a scared old man and tel[MASK]s him to " go lie down an[MASK] die " by himself . 
 At Johnny 's Bar , Eddie joins a poker game where Bert is p[MASK]aying , and loses $ 20 . Afterward [MASK] Bert tells Eddie that he has talent as a pool player but no character[MASK]. He figures that Eddie will need at least $ 3 @,@ 000 to challenge Fats again . Bert calls him[MASK]a " born[MASK]l[MASK]ser "[MASK]but nevertheless offers to stake him [MASK]n return for 75 % of his winnings ; Eddie refuses . When Eddie is ready to play , he agrees to Bert 's terms , deciding that a " 25 % slice of something big[MASK]is better than a [MASK]00 % slice of nothing " . 
 Bert , Eddie , and Sarah travel to the Kentucky Derby , w[MASK]ere Bert arranges a match for Eddie [MASK]gains[MASK][MASK]a wealthy local socialite named Findley . The game turns out to be carom billiards , not pool[MASK]. When Eddie loses badly , Bert refuses to keep staking him . Sarah[MASK]pleads with Eddie [MASK]o leave with her , saying that the world he is living i[MASK] and its inhabitants are " perverted , twisted , and crippled " ; he refuses . Seeing Eddie 's anger , Bert agrees to let the match continue at $ 1 @,@ [MASK]00 a game . Eddie comes back to win $ 12 @,@ 000 . He collects his $ 3 @,@ 000 share and decides to walk back to the hotel . Bert arrives first and subjects Sarah to a humiliating sexual encounte[MASK] . After , she s[MASK]rawls " PERVERTED " , " TWISTED " , and " CR[MASK]PPLED " in lipstick on the bathroom mirror . Eddie arrives back at the hotel to learn that she has killed herself . 
 Ed[MASK]ie returns to challenge Fats again , putti[MASK]g up his entire $ 3 @,@ 00[MASK] stake on a single game . He wins game after game , beating Fats so b[MASK]dly that[MASK]Fats is forced to quit . Bert demands a share of Ed[MASK]ie 's winnings and threatens that Eddie will be injured unless he pays . Bu[MASK] Eddie says that if he is not killed he will kill Bert when he recovers ; invoking the memo[MASK]y of Sarah , [MASK]e shames Bert into giving up his claim . Instead , Bert orders Eddie never to walk into a big @-[MASK] time pool hall a[MASK]ain . Eddie and Fats compliment each other as players , and Eddie walks out .

 The Tevis n[MASK]vel had been option[MASK]d several times , including by Frank Sinatra , but attempts to adapt it for the screen were unsuccessful . Director Rossen 's daughter Carol Rossen speculates that previous adaptations focused too much on the pool aspec[MASK]s of the s[MASK]ory and n[MASK]t enough on the [MASK]uman interaction . Rossen , who had hustled pool himself as a youth and who had made [MASK]n abortive attempt to write a pool @-@ themed play called Corner Pocket , optioned the book and teamed with Sidney Carroll to produce the script . 
 Accord[MASK]ng to Bobby Darin 's a[MASK]ent , Martin Baum , Paul Newman 's age[MASK]t turned down th[MASK] part of Fast Eddie . Newman was origina[MASK]ly unavailable to play Fast Eddie regardless , being committed to star opposite Elizabeth Taylor in the film Two[MASK]for t[MASK]e Seesaw . Rossen off[MASK]red Darin the part after seeing h[MASK]m[MASK]on The Mike Wallace Interview . When Taylor was forced to drop out of Seesaw because of shooting overr[MASK]ns on Cleopatra , Newman was freed [MASK]p to take the role , which he [MASK]ccepted after readi[MASK]g just half of the script . No one ass[MASK]ciated with the production officially notified Darin or his [MASK]epresentatives that he had been repl[MASK]ced ; they found out from a member of the public at a charity horse race . 
 Rossen filmed The Hustler o[MASK]er six weeks , ent[MASK]re[MASK]y in New York City . Much of the action was filmed at two now @-@ defunct pool ha[MASK]ls , McGirr 's and A[MASK]es Billiard Aca[MASK]emy . [MASK]ther shooting locations included a to[MASK]n[MASK]ouse on East 82nd Street , which served as the Louisville home of[MASK]Mur[MASK]ay Hamilton 's character Findley , and the Manhattan Greyhound bus terminal . The film crew built a dinin[MASK] ar[MASK]a that was so realistic that confused passengers sa[MASK] there and waited to place their order[MASK] . Willie Mosconi served as techn[MASK]cal adv[MASK]sor on the film and shot a nu[MASK]ber of the trick shots in place of the actors[MASK]. Al[MASK] of Gleason 's[MASK]shots were his own ; they were filmed in wide @-@ angle to emphasize hav[MASK]ng the actor and the shot in the same frames . Rossen , in pursuit of the [MASK]tyle he termed " neo @-@ [MASK]eo @-@ realistic " , hired actual street thugs , enrolled them in the Screen Actors Guild and used them as extras .[MASK]Scenes that were included in the shooting script but did not make it into the final film include a scene at Ames pool hall establishing that Eddie is on his way t[MASK] t[MASK]wn ( originally slated to be the first scene of the film ) and a longer scene of Preacher talking to [MASK]ert at Johnny 's Bar which estab[MASK][MASK]shes Preacher is a j[MASK]nkie . 
 Early shooting put [MASK]ore focus on the pool playing , b[MASK]t[MASK]during filming Rossen made the decision to place [MASK]ore emphasis on the love story between Newman and Laurie 's characters . [MASK]espite the change in emphasis , Rossen still used the various pool games to show the strengthening of Eddie 's character and the evolution of[MASK]his relationship to Bert and Sarah , through the positio[MASK]ing of the characters in the frame . Fo[MASK] example , when Eddie is playing Findley , Eddie is positio[MASK]ed below Bert in a two shot but above Findley while still below Bert in a three shot . When Sarah enters the room , she is below Eddi[MASK] in two shot w[MASK][MASK]le in a three shot Eddie is still below Bert[MASK]. When Eddie is kneeling over Sarah 's body[MASK], Bert again ap[MASK]ears above him but Eddie attacks Bert , ending up on top of him . Eddie finally appears above [MASK]ert in two [MASK][MASK]ot wh[MASK]n Eddie returns to beat Fats . 
 
 = = Themes = = 
 
 The Hustler is fundament[MASK]lly a story of what it[MASK]means to be a human being , couched within the context of winning a[MASK]d losing . [MASK]escribing the film , Robert Rossen said : " My protagonist , Fast Eddie , wants to become a great pool player , but the film is [MASK]eally about the obstacles he en[MASK]o[MASK]nters in[MASK]att[MASK]mpting to fulfill himself[MASK]as a human being . He [MASK]ttains self @-@ awareness only after a terrible personal tragedy which he h[MASK]s caused — and then he wins his pool game . "[MASK]Roger Ebert concurs with this assessment , citing The Hust[MASK]er as " one of the few American movies in which the h[MASK]ro wins by surrendering , by accepting reality instead of his dreams . " 
 The film was also somewhat autobio[MASK]raphical for Rossen [MASK] relating to his dealings with the House Un @-@ American Activities Commi[MASK]tee . A screenwriter during the 1930s and ' 40s , he had been involved with th[MASK] Communis[MASK] Party in the 1930s and [MASK]efused to name names at his first HUAC appearance . Ultimately he changed his mind and identified friends and colleagues as party members . Simi[MASK]arly , Felson sel[MASK]s his soul an[MASK] betrays th[MASK] one person who really k[MASK]ows and loves him in a Faustian pact to gain character .[MASK]
 Film and theatre historian Ethan Mordden has identified The Hustler as one of a [MASK]andful of films from the early 1960s that re @-@ defined the relationship of films to their audiences . This new relationship , he writes , is " one of [MASK]hallenge rather than flattery , of doubt rather than certainty[MASK]. " No film of the 1950s , Mordden asserts , [MASK] took such a brutal , clear look at the ego @-@ affirmation of the one @-@ on @-@ one contest , at the inhumanity of the winner or the castrated vulnerabili[MASK]y of the loser . " Although some have suggested the resemblance of this film to classic film noir , Mordden rejects the comparison based on Rossen 's ultra @-@ rea[MASK]istic [MASK]tyle , also noting that the film lacks [MASK]oir 's " Treacherous Woman or its r[MASK]lish i[MASK] discovering crime among the bourgeoisie , hungry bank clerks [MASK]nd lusty wives . " Mordden does [MASK]ote[MASK]that while Fas[MASK] Eddie[MASK]" has a slight fif[MASK]ies ring " , [MASK]he chara[MASK]ter " makes a decisive break with the extraordinarily feeling tough guys of the ' re[MASK]el ' era ... [ b ][MASK]ut he does end up seeking out his emotions " and telling Bert that he is a loser because he 's dead inside . 
 
 = = Reception = = 
 
 [MASK]he[MASK]Hustler had its world p[MASK][MASK]miere [MASK]n Wash[MASK]ngton , D.C. on September 25 , 1961 . Prior to the premiere , Richard Burton [MASK]osted a mid[MASK]ight scr[MASK]ening of the film for t[MASK]e casts of t[MASK]e season 's Broadway shows[MASK], which generated a great deal of positive word of mouth . Initially reluctant to publicize the film , 20th Century Fox r[MASK]sponded b[MASK] stepping up its promotional activities . 
 The film was well received by critics , although with the occasional caveat . Va[MASK]iety praised the performances of the entire main cast but felt that the " sordid aspects " of the sto[MASK]y prevented the film from achieving the[MASK]" goal of being pure entertainment . " Variety also felt the film was far too long . Stan[MASK]ey K[MASK]uffmann , writing for The New Republic , concurred in part with this assessment . Kauffmann strongly praised the pri[MASK]cipal cast , calling Newman "[MASK]first @-@ rate " and writing that Scott 's was " his most credible pe[MASK]formance to date . " Laur[MASK]e , he writes , gives her part " movingly anguished touches " [MASK] although he also mildly critici[MASK]es her for over @-@ reliance on Method acting ) . While he found that the [MASK]cript " strains hard to give an [MASK]ir of menace and criminality to the p[MASK]ol[MASK]hall " and also declares it " full of pseudo @-@ meaning " , Kauffmann lauds Rossen[MASK]'s " sure , economical " directi[MASK]n , especially in regard to[MASK]Gleason who , he says , does not so much act as " [ pose ] for a number [MASK]f pictures which are [MASK]ell arranged by Rossen . It is the best use of a manikin by a director sin[MASK]e Kazan photographed Burl Ives as Big Daddy . " The New York Times , despite finding that the fi[MASK]m " stray[MASK] a bit " and that the romance between Newman and Laurie 's characters "[MASK]seems a mite far @-@ fetched " , nonetheless found that The [MASK]ustler [MASK] speaks powerfully in a universal language that spellbinds and reveals bitter truths . " 
 The Hustler re[MASK]eived nine Academy Award nominations . The film won two , for [MASK]est Art Direction [MASK]-@ Set Decorat[MASK]on , Black @-@ and @-@ White ( Harry Horner and Gene Ca[MASK]lahan ) and Best Cinematography , Black @-@ and @-@ White ( Eugen Schüfftan ) . The film was also no[MASK]inated for Best Picture and Newman was nominated for Best Actor in a Leading Role . Gleason and Scott [MASK]ere both nominated for Best Actor in a Supporting Role ; Scott refused the nomination . [MASK]aurie was nominated for Best Actress in a Leading Role . Rossen received nominations for Best Director and , with Carroll , for Best Writing , Screenplay Based on Material from Another Medium . [MASK] Newman was nominated for a Golden Globe Award for Best Actor . Gleason and Scott were[MASK]each nomi[MASK]ated for Best Supporting Actor and Scott was also nominated a[MASK] Best New Star of the Year . At the 1962 BAFTA Awards , The[MASK]Hustler tied with the Soviet film Ballad of a Soldier for Best Film from Any Sour[MASK]e . Newman won for Best Foreign Ac[MASK]or and Piper Laurie was nominated for Best Foreign Actress . Gleason was honored as Best Supporting[MASK]Actor by the National Board of Review of Motion Picture[MASK] and the film was named among the Board 's ten best films of 1961 . Rossen was named Best Director by the New York Film Critics Circle Awards and R[MASK]ssen and Carroll shared the Writers Gui[MASK]d of America Award for Best Written Drama .

 = = Legacy = = 
 
 In the decades since its release , The Hustler has cemented its reputation as a classic . Roger Ebert , echoing e[MASK]rlier praise for the performances , directio[MASK] , and cinema[MASK]ography and adding laurels for editor Dede Allen , cites the film as " one of those films wh[MASK]re scenes have such psychic weight that they grow in our memories . " He furthe[MASK] cites Fast Eddie Felson as one of " only a handful of movie characters so real that the audience refers to them as touchstones . " TV Guide calls the film a " dark stunner " offering " a grim world whose only bright spot i[MASK] the top of the pool table , yet [ with ] characters [ who ] [MASK]ainta[MASK][MASK] a shabby nobility and grace . " The four [MASK]e[MASK]ds are again lavishly praised for their[MASK]perfo[MASK]mances and the fi[MASK]m is summed[MASK][MASK]p as " not to be missed . " 
 Paul Newman reprised his role as Fast Eddi[MASK] Felson in the 1986 f[MASK]lm The Color of Money , for which he won the Academy Award for Best Actor in[MASK]a Leading Role . A number of observers and critics have su[MASK]gested that this Oscar was in belated recognition for[MASK]his performance [MASK]n The Hustler . In 1997 , the [MASK]ibrary of Congress selected The Hustler for preservation[MASK]in the United States National Film Registry as " culturally , historically , or aesthetically significant[MASK]. "[MASK]Carroll and Rossen 's screenplay was selected by the Writers Guild of America in 2006 as the 96th best motion picture screenplay of all time . In June 2008 , A[MASK]I released its " Ten top Ten " — the best ten films in te[MASK] " classic " American film genres — after polling over 1 @,@ 500 people from the creative community . The Hus[MASK]ler was acknowledged as the[MASK]s[MASK]xth best film in the sports genre . 
 The Hustler is credited with sparking a resurgence in the popularity of pool in the United States , which h[MASK]d been on the decline for decades . The film also brought [MASK]ecognition to Willie Mosconi , who , despite having won multiple world champions[MASK][MASK]ps[MASK], was virtually unknown to the general public . Perhap[MASK] [MASK]he greatest beneficiary [MASK]f the film 's pop[MASK]larity was a real @-@ life pool hustler named Rudolf Wand[MASK]rone . Mosconi claimed in an interview at the time of the film 's release that the character of Minnesota Fats was based on Wanderone , who at the time was known as " New [MASK]ork Fatty " . Wanderone immediately adopted the Minnesota Fats nickname [MASK]nd parlayed his association[MASK]with th[MASK] film into book and television deals and other ventures . Auth[MASK]r Walter Tevis denied for the rest of his life that Wan[MASK]erone had played any role in the creation of the character . Other players would claim , with greater or lesser degrees of credibility , to have served as models for Fast E[MASK]die , including Ronnie Allen , Ed Taylor , Ed Parker , and E[MASK]die Pelkey .
